webTitle: C'mon, Tony, where's the Big Idea?

fields.headline: C'mon, Tony, where's the Big Idea?
fields.standfirst:
After the non-politics of the Nineties, New Labour needs to find a direction, a slogan that will engage our interest (and indignation)

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair has spent most of the six years since his election as Labour leader trying to lower expectations: no great transfer of wealth from rich to poor, no sudden splurge of spending on education or health, no new dawn for public ownership, no gleaming new trains or Tube lines.
fields.body:
Tony Blair has spent most of the six years since his election as Labour leader trying to lower expectations: no great transfer of wealth from rich to poor, no sudden splurge of spending on education or health, no new dawn for public ownership, no gleaming new trains or Tube lines. The main themes were 'modernisation' and 'constitutional reform', and nobody ever stormed a Winter Palace under slogans like that. Nor did anyone compose a song to the effect that the people's flag was deeply prudent.

Yet in the past year, Mr Blair has made such extravagant promises that one sometimes wonders if he has taken leave of his senses. More, one doubts his grasp of either arithmetic or economics. At the Labour Party conference last autumn, we had the promise to abolish child poverty in a generation. Then on David Frost's sofa one Sunday in January, in the midst of a flu crisis (which figures now reveal to have been a real one, though people accused Ministers of talking it up in order to disguise inadequacies in the NHS), we had the promise to bring the proportion of GDP spent on health up to the European average. Now the Guardian reports 'an audacious strategy' to abolish NHS waiting lists.

Each promise, in its way, is preposterous. Poverty is usually defined as living on less than half the national average income; the quickest way to reduce poverty, therefore, is to soak the rich with taxation at levels that one would expect Mr Blair to judge politically unacceptable. Bringing health spending up to the European average requires a rise of at least one-third from present levels (I say 'at least' since there is nothing to stop other European countries increasing their spending, as they have done consistently for the last 20 years, thus raising the standard Mr Blair has to reach). Abolishing waiting lists requires the repeal of a fundamental law of economics: that scarce resources must be rationed in some way and if they are not rationed by price or by some other means (such as a judgment that some cases are more deserving than others) they must be rationed by queuing. This is not to say that queuing is necessarily a bad thing - since almost anyone can take their place in a queue, it is probably the most democratic and egalitarian means of distributing resources - merely to observe that, where services are offered free, it is almost an inevitability.

So Mr Blair's promises remind me of the agendas for journalists' union conferences that I attended some 20 years ago. These were packed with motions requiring the union leadership to bring an 'immediate' end to the British 'occupation' of Northern Ireland, to 'oppose' American 'imperialism', and such like. The leadership would usually rule these out of order on the grounds that they were 'incapable of implementation'. Mr Blair's big ideas are likewise incapable of implementation.

Is that a bad thing? Not at all. Any political or religious movement needs a compass, something to give it bearings, benchmarks against which it can judge its mundane, day-to-day choices. Christians have been striving for the Kingdom of Heaven for 2,000 years; it is not expected to arrive, as the Americans would put it, any time soon. Labour used to have its Clause 4; but nobody seriously thought that the workers by hand or by brain would ever control significant sectors of industry. Margaret Thatcher aimed to roll back the state and to reduce the burden of taxation. She came nowhere near either aim (if anything, she was further away from her goals when she left office than when she entered it) but at least the country understood her intentions and, for that reason, she changed, for better or worse, the national culture.

The weakness of Mr Blair's mysterious Third Way has always been its lack of such sense of direction; we can see the roads he doesn't want to travel far more clearly than the one he does. Long before Labour came to power, I remember discussing with a senior New Labour adviser how a left-wing government could give civil servants a simple guiding light, something that would concentrate their thoughts and channel their mental energies. Thatcher's governments, the adviser observed, were guided by a very simple question: 'How can we create a market?' That dominated everything Whitehall did; Ministers and civil servants knew, when they started to frame policy, that anything that failed to address that question was doomed. What would be the equivalent for Labour? Something like 'how can we increase equality of opportunity?' we thought - though, somehow, that didn't seem precise enough or bold enough? But over the past three years, I fear, the question has been nothing more than 'how can we avoid offending middle England?' or 'how can we get a good headline in the Sun or the Daily Mail ?' Just as no Tory policy got beyond the starting blocks without passing the market test, so no New Labour policy gets anywhere without passing the David Yelland/Paul Dacre test.

The Thatcher formula led, to be sure, to absurdities, notably the internal market in the NHS and, long after Thatcher herself had left office, the botched privatisation of the railways. Mr Blair's initial popularity was based, in part, on his resistance to politics driven by ideology.

But I do not think that, in the end, politics can flourish unless the voters are offered some clarity of goals. It is said that people become cynical when politicians make impossible promises and then fail to achieve them. I think they become more cynical when the promises are circumscribed and technical. Was it, for example, so clever of New Labour to promise that the under-sevens in state schools would be taught in classes of fewer than 30, knowing, first, that class sizes in the private sector are enormously lower and, second, that to achieve this aim within available resources, older pupils would have to be taught in even larger classes?

To reduce politics to questions of management (Blair's 'what works?') is to reduce it to little more than the kind of choice we make between gas appliances or video recorders or a new pair of shoes. It tells people that politics can make only a marginal difference to their lives, that it doesn't really deal in big ideas at all. That is essentially the message from the Clinton presidency (where the Third Way trail was blazed), with the result that less than half the eligible population voted in 1996. And despite the attempts to jazz up politics in Britain - directly-elected mayors, polling stations open for several days, more postal voting - the same message is emerging here, with the turnout only 33.6 per cent in the London mayoral elections, supposedly the most exciting contest for years.

That is bound to worry a Labour Government because low turnouts invariably favour governments of the Right. But all politicians should be worried, not that they are failing to sell their own particular parties, but that they are failing to sell democratic politics as a source of idealism and inspiration.

I hope that the Nineties - in which just about the most memorable political idea, because of its sheer banality, was John Major's cones hotline - will turn out to have been an aberration. I hope that politicians can once more engage our deepest feelings and deepest prejudices, bringing angry voices to the radio phone-ins and the newspaper letters columns, as the Oxbridge entry issue has done over the past two weeks. I hope that Tony Blair continues to make reckless promises and that Gordon Brown continues to wage class war. We've had campaigns for real ale, real cheese, real education; let's now have a campaign for real politics.

Peter Wilby is editor of the New Statesman

fields.headline: This gynaecologist harms us all
fields.standfirst: The horrifying case of Rodney Ledward is a symptom of a greater sickness at the heart of the NHS
fields.trailText: If there is one golden thread connecting Old and New Labour, it is the commitment to the National Health Service. There is no member of the Cabinet who does not believe in the Bevanite conception of the NHS - a service providing equality of treatment free to every Briton, regardless of age, race, class, gender or geography.
fields.body:
If there is one golden thread connecting Old and New Labour, it is the commitment to the National Health Service. There is no member of the Cabinet who does not believe in the Bevanite conception of the NHS - a service providing equality of treatment free to every Briton, regardless of age, race, class, gender or geography. Despite New Labour's temporising elsewhere, we should take it at its word on the NHS.

The problem is not the shared goal, it is the means. And here the Government's lack of an overarching philosophy and political coherence is undermining its capacity to achieve the end that it wants. Promises of more spending, shorter waiting-lists and a tougher regime for consultants are all welcome as far as they go, but the problems are much more deep-seated. The NHS is suffering a gathering crisis of legitimacy. Patients and the public at large want a voice and a systematic framework in which they can trust that high quality health care is assured over time.

Yet what is on offer is an increasingly politicised service where effective decision-making is still tightly held at the centre and where some of the policies, notably the Private Finance Initiative (PFI) as it operates in health, are undermining the equality and evenness of provision that the Government seeks.

Three recent events underline the problem; more lie ahead. There is the exercise in public consultation - the so-called health census - to inform the National Plan for Health that has been exposed as little more than a PR stunt. There is the extraordinary fight to prevent the downgrading of Kidderminster General Hospital (part of a larger PFI deal for the nearby Worcester Royal Infirmary), where 19 out of 42 seats on the local district council are held by independent, newly elected councillors who, as members of 'Health Concern', are pledged to fight the plans and are bringing their protest to London next week in a street march. And there is the growing public dismay at medical incompetence, highlighted again by last week's Ritchie Report into Rodney Ledward, the Kent consultant gynaecologist and obstetrician who, over a 16-year career, maimed and harmed any number of women through botched operations.

At first glance, these cases might seem unconnected, yet what binds them together is the great accountability gap that sits in the NHS as a brooding cancer. As long as it remains unaddressed, it will expose the contradictions that beset the Government's NHS policies.

The unprecedented scale of the consultation exercise being mounted before the publication of the National Plan for Health in July is a tacit recognition of the accountability gap. The country's surgeries and supermarkets have been flooded by 12 million leaflets inviting us to identify the three key things we want from the NHS. These have to be completed and sent back by Monday at the latest, a week from start to finish.

However, as Mori's Bob Worcester has said, this is not a serious exercise in finding out what the public wants or the trade-offs it might make between varying claims on NHS resources; that would require intense quantitative and qualitative research. Rather, it is a high-profile exercise in trying to demonstrate that the Government is 'listening', even though it knows the results will be unrepresentative and profoundly compromised by the tight time-scale. But it needs to show that readiness because nothing less will do in today's democratic climate.

Automatic deference to authority is steadily weakening. We live in more democratic times, where everybody believes their voice should be heard. Legitimacy, by government, line manager or NHS consultant has to be earned. The Ledward case, together with the palpable weakness of both NHS managers and the General Medical Council alike in dealing with this rogue consultant, is another nail in that coffin.

Ledward, like Harold Shipman, may be an exception, but the reality is that the system did not catch either early enough and in today's climate such deficiencies are no longer acceptable. The Ritchie Report assembles an impressive list of reforms, bolstering NHS complaints procedures which should be extended to the private sector and calling for beefed-up powers for the General Medical Council. And the Government has responded by saying either reform is in train or it will be.

But as with the census, the larger democratic point is missed. The reason why the health ombudsman is weak, complaints procedures are feeble and regulation is delegated to the medical profession in the shape of the General Medical Council is not some accident - it is because the British doctrine is that accountability lies with the Minister in Parliament and that any other mechanism might challenge that ultimate authority. Thus the ombudsman is kept weak because he or she might challenge the authority of the Minister. There is a linear connection between British constitutional arrangements and Ledward's capacity to practise.

This doctrine is not going to be challenged by New Labour. Instead, the party rel ishes the control it confers; the centre can thus control the terms of the health debate while offering a patina of accountability through consultation exercises like the national census or patients' focus groups. This allows polices like the PFI to be protected, which would not otherwise survive the scrutiny of the democratic rough house.

Yet Kidderminster gives the lie even to this proposition. To scale down Kidderminster General so that it no longer offers in-patient beds, and diverting patients to Worcester, whose Royal Infirmary is being replaced with a PFI hospital that can only afford three-fifths of the existing acute beds, is outrageous. This is not a plan to improve Worcester's health provision that has been driven by Worcester's health needs, settled by open argument. Rather, it is a top-down scheme imposed upon the county by the exigencies of offering private contractors their appropriate financial returns within impossibly tight public-sector expenditure constraints.

Yet the democratic voice cannot be suppressed. Alan Milburn dares not visit Worcester for fear the cameras might catch him with the protesters; next week, the stakes will be higher again as they carry their protest to London. And this is not the Socialist Workers Party; this is middle England in force.

The Government really does want to deliver a better NHS. New money, new schemes and renegotiating the deal with consultants are helpful, but they will not crack the problem. To do that it must close the accountability deficit, with all that implies - delegating power, toughening up regulations, offering elections to health boards and accepting that if the PFI changes the fundamental character of the hospital service, then it must be reformed. It means nothing less than a democratic constitution for the health service, the case the commission I chaired recommended six weeks ago. Our case gets stronger by the day.

webTitle: We must reach out to all traditions

fields.headline: We must reach out to all traditions
fields.standfirst:
Northern Ireland's new Education Minister Martin McGuinness gives his personal view of the way forward in peace

Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Just last week, while I was going through some papers at home, my daughter and my grandson came to visit. It was a joyous occasion as always, with the child making its way around the room precariously, holding on to the furniture for support.
fields.body:
Just last week, while I was going through some papers at home, my daughter and my grandson came to visit. It was a joyous occasion as always, with the child making its way around the room precariously, holding on to the furniture for support. All of a sudden, he let go and took his first unsteady steps unsupported.

After the excitement at the wondrous moment had subsided and we had settled back to more mundane things, I began to think about the significance of that first step and how it could be applied to the present political situation.

I thought to myself - if unionist leaders could just look at the result of last week's vote at the Ulster Unionist Council as them letting go of the furniture and taking that first step towards a new and equal society, it could be a major step towards building trust with the republican/nationalist community.

Likewise, the republican/nationalist community must let go of the furniture as well and take the first step towards trusting that unionists are changing and that they no longer want to dominate and discriminate against us.

We must learn to walk together, to work together and build a future together in which our children and grandchildren can live in a society where religion and political persuasion does not determine where they live, play, be educated or work.

As an Irish republican, I will continue to work towards the day when we have an Irish Republic free from interference, from the political influence, of a British government.

I want to see a new Ireland where equality is the foundation of society. I believe that by working to have the Good Friday Agreement implemented in full that we can start the journey towards that goal.

I know that unionists do not share in my vision of a united Ireland and that they will work just as diligently to prevent such an eventuality. But I have to say that, although I accept their right to do so, I also believe that many of them accept that, as we build a society of equals, all of the reasons of privilege and position - most of them, particularly for the working class unionist, a misconception - that sustained the desire by the unionist population to maintain the union with Britain will become irrelevant. It is for precisely this reason that the rejectionist unionists are fighting so hard to prevent all of the changes envisioned in the Good Friday Agreement from happening.

My greatest hope is that through peaceful and democratic means, and by building on the Good Friday Agreement, we can convince unionists that a united Ireland is the best option for all of us. I hope to be able to demonstrate through exercising my duties as Education Minister that unionists have nothing to fear from Irish republicans. I hope to demonstrate to them that republicans will not discriminate. I hope to demonstrate that republicanism is capable of embracing all creeds and cultures on this island and harnessing the good from all of them for the benefit of society as a whole.

I hope that by successfully exercising our responsibilities, all of the Ministers in the Executive - from whatever party - will demonstrate that Irish people are capable of self-government. We do not need English, Scottish, Welsh or any other nationality's Ministers coming here to dictate how we should govern any part of our country. I hope that by showing unionists that together we can deliver good government through our own abilities that they will have the confidence to recognise that, along with our brothers and sisters in the rest of the country, we can make this island the envy of our neighbours.

I started back in my department at the beginning of last week and I intend to take up where I left off; that is trying to make a difference where it will make the most impact for those most in need.

When I returned, I said that it was great to be back - and I meant it. I was coming back with the added advantage of the experience from the short period in office earlier in the year. We had begun much good work and established a good working relationship within the department and the wider education sector. I look forward to building on this solid foundation.

In my role as Education Minister, I hope to be seen as a 'builder' in this evolving process. There are, of course, many challenges ahead but I believe that we are capable of laying down sound foundations for the future. I believe that we can build an education system that will both inspire and give hope to all our children.

Education is the key to future prosperity and individual fulfilment; it must have the highest priority for any government. In our own situation, moving away from a climate of conflict and division, education has a key role to play in creating an inclusive, tolerant and stable society. I will therefore endeavour to ensure that the provision of education is a central priority for the Executive, the Assembly and the North-South Ministerial Council.

One of the most contentious issues ahead of us is, undoubtedly, that of the selection procedure. Despite the fact that we have a reasonably successful education system here, there are still far too many of our young people who go through their school years with a sense of failure at not making the 'grade'.

My department has commissioned research into this whole area. It is a very detailed piece of work, which is at an advanced stage and I look forward to initiating a full debate on the way forward later this year.

Another major issue that I intend to tackle is the legacy of under-funding, which has left schools in a particularly poor condition. But we also need to develop an environment conducive to good education and this isn't just an issue of securing more finance, although that is essential.

We need to put some thought into the type of schools we are building - that they are modern, comfortable and somewhere young people will want to go for all the right reasons. One of my first engagements on resuming as Education Minister was to host a major conference with my counterpart from the South, Michael Woods, and Sean Farren, Minister of Further and Higher Education Training and Employment. The keynote speaker was Richard Riley, US Education Secretary.

I was encouraged to see some 200 people from the whole island of Ireland attend and share experiences and challenges that we all face in education. It is also important that we benefit from our contacts with the United States, where there has been a very significant amount of research in key educational areas, such as special needs.

All of this confirms my profound belief that together we can move forward with confidence and with vision and that the department has a key role to play in providing the dynamic leadership we need to continue to chart the course away from conflict.

As Education Minister, I intend to lead from the front, with the support of my officials and the wider education sector. There are huge challenges ahead and I am under no illusions. But we must remember that the vast majority of people are willing to embrace change and to try to move forward on a sound basis. So at the end of my first week back in my department, yes, I am optimistic for the future and confident that I will be able to take steps to improve a system which is good but will be better.
fields.bodyText: Just last week, while I was going through some papers at home, my daughter and my grandson came to visit. It was a joyous occasion as always, with the child making its way around the room precariously, holding on to the furniture for support. All of a sudden, he let go and took his first unsteady steps unsupported. After the excitement at the wondrous moment had subsided and we had settled back to more mundane things, I began to think about the significance of that first step and how it could be applied to the present political situation. Likewise, the republican/nationalist community must let go of the furniture as well and take the first step towards trusting that unionists are changing and that they no longer want to dominate and discriminate against us. We must learn to walk together, to work together and build a future together in which our children and grandchildren can live in a society where religion and political persuasion does not determine where they live, play, be educated or work. As an Irish republican, I will continue to work towards the day when we have an Irish Republic free from interference, from the political influence, of a British government. I want to see a new Ireland where equality is the foundation of society. I believe that by working to have the Good Friday Agreement implemented in full that we can start the journey towards that goal. I know that unionists do not share in my vision of a united Ireland and that they will work just as diligently to prevent such an eventuality. I hope to demonstrate to them that republicans will not discriminate. webTitle: Blair goes back to work and takes on doctors

fields.headline: Blair goes back to work and takes on doctors
fields.standfirst: The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair returns from paternity leave tomorrow to launch a new offensive on the NHS, warning it can expect no favours unless it accepts change.
fields.body:
Tony Blair returns from paternity leave tomorrow to launch a new offensive on the NHS, warning it can expect no favours unless it accepts change.

The Prime Minister spent much of his time off working on new ideas for health reforms - ranging from relaxing controls on some prescription drugs to channelling more patients through the NHS Direct hotline.

His first major meeting will be with Health Secretary Alan Milburn to work out the final shape of his much-vaunted National Plan for the NHS.

Blair has told colleagues that reform will be bolder than originally planned and that the NHS cannot be immune from criticism just because a Labour government designed it, adding: 'The question is no longer whether we need to reform, but by how much and how quickly.'

His words signal a clash with sceptical doctors, who last week criticised plans to cut waiting lists by operating round the clock in what may be the first of several battles.

But Blair's only regret is said to be that he did not grasp the nettle earlier. One aide said: 'The Prime Minister and Alan now believe that perhaps we have thought for too long that most of the health service's problems could be solved by money alone. We hadn't fully grasped the scale of reform that we needed.'

Milburn will underline the message on Tuesday, when he will say his job is 'fighting for patients, not defending the status quo and in some cases the indefensible'.

The onslaught will be seen as a deliberate strategy to soften opposition to the plan before it is published. Many doctors feel the Government's problem is not too little modernisation but too much.

Attempts to canvass the views of patients and staff were condemned last week as a cosmetic exercise giving too little time for responses, while doctors are uneasy about plans for round-the-clock operating and reform of their contracts.

Tomorrow Blair, Milburn and junior Health Ministers will discuss a list of major weaknesses which the national plan will tackle. These include insufficient capacity for operations, barriers between the professions, and 'bed-blocking' - infirm elderly people being left in hospital because social services cannot find them anywhere else to go.

Six teams of experts have been working on the plan and interested parties have put forward more ideas. One of these is a call from the Royal Pharmaceutical Society for pharmacists to issue repeat prescriptions of certain drugs without reference to a doctor. The list could include contraceptive pills - likely to outrage the family values lobby - HRT and asthma drugs.

NHS Direct, the hotline staffed by nurses, is likely to be extended as a first port of call for non-urgent treatment, 24 hours a day. But critics argue there is a risk of bad advice.

Blair has also studied plans for a 'virtual university' for staff training and extending nurses' role in primary care. Other items for the plan could include reform of the General Medical Council to tackle dangerous and incompetent doctors, an overhaul of training to improve attitudes to patients, and moves to limit the time some NHS consultants spend on private practice.

webTitle: Europe 'enforcer' to crack whip for Blair

fields.headline: Europe 'enforcer' to crack whip for Blair
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair is set to give one of Britain's most influential government officials sweeping powers to take control of European policy across all departments.
fields.body:
Tony Blair is set to give one of Britain's most influential government officials sweeping powers to take control of European policy across all departments.

The secret appointment of a 'European enforcer' to co-ordinate and promote links with the Continent and prepare for adoption of the euro is being viewed as a clear signal that the Prime Minister wants to boost his control over key European decisions.

The news comes as William Hague, the Conservative leader, plans an attack against the Government's European policy with a revamp of the 'Keep The Pound' campaign. In a speech on Friday he will attack Blair for fudging the European issue and call on people to sign the 'Keep The Pound' pledge card.

He hopes that the European attack, backed by a national advertising campaign, will echo recent agenda-setting forays into the areas of pensions, asylum-seekers and crime.

The new enforcer post will be taken up by one of the most respected European figures in government, Sir Stephen Wall, the official UK representative to the European Union. He will join the Cabinet Office and be given responsibility for European policy. It is the first time such a role has been created.

Putting him in the Cabinet Office, rather than the Foreign Office or the Treasury, reveals Blair's desire to keep control of European policy firmly with Downing Street.

Government sources said the move also shows Blair wants to reinvigorate the European agenda and will expect Wall to offer advice about planning for a referendum on Britain's entry to the euro, expected soon after the next general election.

'Wall is seen as pro-European,' a Minister said. 'By moving him into the Cabinet Office, the Prime Minister is showing he wants action.'

Blair is concerned that a lack of 'joined up thinking' is making the Government's European policy appear weak and divided.

Blair is worried that France and Germany are planning a two-speed Europe, which would leave Britain lagging behind its powerful commercial competitors.

Wall is one of the most eminent and long-serving European thinkers in government. During the Conservative administration he was the man who tackled Margaret Thatcher over the tone of her infamous anti-European Bruges speech.

Blair came under increasing pressure yesterday to come off the fence over the single currency.

His mentor and confidant, Lord Jenkins, warned that his standing as a Prime Minister could be tarnished unless he took action. Pointing out that Britain had made a habit of joining in European initiatives late, Jenkins said the ground needed to be prepared for a referendum through a 'substantial build-up' in order to persuade hostile voters.

fields.headline: Britain's UFO secrets revealed
fields.standfirst:
Scientist's pressure for information opens up hidden government files on strange sightings in the sky government files
Freedom of information: special report
fields.trailText: Scientist's pressure for information opens up hidden government files on strange sightings in the sky government files
fields.body:
On 15 February 1999 an air traffic controller in Scotland noticed something strange on his radar screen. A bright blip on his screen suggested there was a very large object travelling at 3,000mph over the Scottish coastline heading south-west to Belfast.

The size of the blip suggested the object was 10 miles long and two miles wide. Two minutes later the object disappeared from the radar screen.

Three months earlier, MoD documents record that a commercial pilot flying over the Midlands reported an unusual object travelling at 'very high speed' with a very bright strobe light flashing once every 20 seconds.

Although the two incidents were unrelated, both were reported to a little-known department in the Ministry of Defence, known as Secretariat (Air Staff) 2a. This is the secretive section in Whitehall which collates reports of unidentified flying objects that cross British airspace.

Whitehall has traditionally treated reports of UFO sightings as highly classified and only released information to the public after 30 years. But the parliamentary Ombudsman insisted that the MoD hand this information to Colin Ridyard, a research chemist from Wales.

Dr Ridyard had been seeking information relating to UFO sightings by pilots or radar operators between July 1998 and July 1999. Initially the MoD refused on the ground it would be too expensive. But after the intervention of the ombudsman, Michael Buckley, the MoD agreed to release the information as a one-off exercise for £75. The Ministry handed two reports to Ridyard, yet official information from the Civil Aviation Authority suggests there had been additional sightings. During the same period the CAA said it reported two more UFO sightings to the MoD, neither of which the Ministry disclosed.

According to official CAA reports, in the same month that a radar picked up an enormous object flying across Scotland, a pilot flying over the North Sea became startled when his aircraft became illuminated by an 'incandescent' light. Three other aircraft in the area reported seeing a ball of light moving at high speed. Air traffic controllers reported there were no strange aircraft in the area, but five minutes later an operator at a weather station picked up a fast-moving object on his radar.

The other incident which CAA reported to the MoD occurred in June 1999 when the pilot of a B757 flying over the North Sea reported an unidentified military-looking aircraft passing close by in the opposite direction. Nothing was seen on the plane's radar or by air traffic controllers. The MoD told the Authority that there were no military aircraft known to be in that area at the time.

Although an MoD spokeswoman would not discuss individual sightings, she said all these events had perfectly normal explanations. 'Some-times radars have spurious readings caused by military aircraft in the vicinity, and radar-jamming facilities and bright lights on the underside of aircraft can be caused by events on the ground.'

In a letter to one of Ridyard's local MPs, Defence Minister John Spellar said: 'My department has no interest or role with respect to UFO/flying saucer matters or to the question of the existence or otherwise of extraterrestrial life forms - about which we remain open-minded.'

However, declassified gov ernment documents in the Public Records Office from June 1965 reveal that 'it was official MoD policy to play down the subject of unidentified flying objects and to avoid attaching undue public attention or publicity to the subject... as a result we have never had any political pressure to mount a large-scale investigation'. Other documents from that time state: 'The press are never to be given information about unusual radar sightings_ and [unusual visual] sightings are in no circumstances to be disclosed to the press.'

But Ridyard said: 'This is not about little green men, but about freedom of information. It is clear there are many strange incidents that happen in the British skies that are kept secret. There may be issues of aircraft safety or natural phenomena, but by keeping this information secret these incidents cannot be scrutinised by the public or the scientific community.'

One of the most infamous incidents relating to a UFO sighting in Britain only came to light through US freedom of information legislation. This revealed that in December 1980 three security patrolmen investigating a potential air crash near the US Air Force base in Suffolk saw a strange glowing triangular object hovering in the forest near the base which had a 'pulsing red light on top and blue lights underneath'.

An official report by Lieutenant-Colonel Charles Halt , the deputy base commander, included a description of the events and stated that the next day three depressions were found in the forest where the object was discovered which showed radiation readings. Later that night three star-like objects were seen in the sky moving 'rapidly in sharp angular movements'.

webTitle: Irish-Americans urged to fly the flag at Drumcree

fields.headline: Irish-Americans urged to fly the flag at Drumcree
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Portadown's disputed Garvaghy Road could soon resemble the 51st state of the United States. Nationalists opposed to the Orange Order's annual march from Drumcree church down the controversial route have asked Irish-Americans to sponsor flagpoles along the road and send the flags of their individual states to fly alongside the Irish tricolour this summer.
fields.body:
Portadown's disputed Garvaghy Road could soon resemble the 51st state of the United States. Nationalists opposed to the Orange Order's annual march from Drumcree church down the controversial route have asked Irish-Americans to sponsor flagpoles along the road and send the flags of their individual states to fly alongside the Irish tricolour this summer.

The Garvaghy Road Residents' Coalition has advertised its offer to fly the flags of the 50 American states on the world wide web. Americans will pay £300 for the privilege of seeing their home state flag and the tricolour on the road during the loyalist marching season.

The money will be used to buy permanent flagpoles on Garvaghy Road, one of the main arterial routes into Portadown town centre, and which Orangemen have been barred from marching along for two years.

So far, however, only one American state has pledged to sponsor a tricolour and send its state flag - Arkansas, the home state of President Bill Clinton.

The advertisement to sponsor a flag first appeared on the Republican Bulletin Board, a pro-Sinn Fein website. Noraid, the republican movement's support group in the US, has called on Irish-Americans to back the campaign, which is bound to infuriate Portadown's majority loyalist community.

An Irish-American supporter of the Garvaghy Road community, Sherry O'Brien, pledged last week to bring flags to Portadown.

David Jones, spokesman for the Portadown Orange Order, said nothing the nationalist residents' group did surprised him any more. 'They would do anything for publicity, even invite the flying of flags of another country,' he said. 'On one level it's a bit of a joke. But the irony is they will accept the flags of American states, but don't want to see the flag of the country they live in and of the majority community in Portadown - the Union Jack.'

Jones said Portadown Orangemen were determined to continue their protest at Drumcree despite the ban. He said there had been no hint of renewed 'proximity talks' between the local Orange Order and the nationalist residents with a view to ending the dispute.

Drumcree has the potential not only to divide unionists and nationalists across Northern Ireland. In recent days the North's principal parades dispute has caused schisms in the ranks of loyalism. The Ulster Defence Association - the largest Protestant paramilitary force - has been rocked by splits over the movement's attitude to Drumcree. The UDA's central leadership in Belfast has ordered all its so-called brigade areas not to turn up at Drumcree this summer and to 'police' Protestant areas to ensure there is no violence in the first two weeks of July.

But two UDA brigades, the North-West and North Antrim, have pledged to support the Drumcree Orangemen and will join street protests if the Order is again barred from marching along the Garvaghy Road.

The North-West and North Antrim UDA brigades were also incensed that Gary McMichael, chief spokesman for the UDA-aligned Ulster Democratic Party, attended a cross-community service in a Garvaghy Road Roman Catholic church last week.

One UDA source complained: 'Gary McMichael was able to walk on the Garvaghy Road, yet Orangemen from the town are barred from doing so.'

fields.headline: Real IRA armed with super mortar
fields.standfirst: Key weapon perfected by terrorist turncoat is revealed as Martin McGuinness condemns Hammersmith bombing Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: The Real IRA, which is suspected of bombing Hammersmith Bridge in London last week, has perfected a new, highly accurate mortar weapon. It is the work of a former Provisional IRA 'engineer' who has defected to the breakaway terrorist group, say intelligence reports.
fields.body:
The Real IRA, which is suspected of bombing Hammersmith Bridge in London last week, has perfected a new, highly accurate mortar weapon. It is the work of a former Provisional IRA 'engineer' who has defected to the breakaway terrorist group, say intelligence reports.

The defector developed the mortars fired at Heathrow airport in 1993 which brought air traffic around the capital to a standstill. The latest device is a heavily updated version of those.

Security forces on both sides of the Irish border are on a high alert this weekend following the reports about the new work of the 'engineer'. He lives in Dundalk, and joined the dissident group only after the Provisionals' decision last month to open its arms dumps to inspection by independent international observers.

He helped build the Provos' 'barrack- buster', a mortar capable of penetrating heavily-fortified army bases in South Armagh. One of his devices downed an Army helicopter in 1993. He also had a hand in making the mortars that landed in Downing Street during a Gulf War Cabinet meeting being chaired by the then Prime Minister, John Major, in 1991.

A senior Irish police officer said the new weapon, designated the Mark 19 by the British Army, is 120mm in calibre, and was test-fired last month at a joint RUC and Army base at Rosslea, Co Fermanagh. It is regarded as highly accurate, even when fired almost 200 yards from its target.

The revelation that the Real IRA has acquired this mortar follows the explosion of a small bomb under Hammersmith Bridge, which brought much of west London to a standstill last Thursday. If the group did plant the bomb, as police believe, this would be its first successful attack on mainland Britain.

Martin McGuinness, the Sinn Fein MP and Northern Ireland Education Minister, yesterday said his party 'totally and absolutely opposed' the Hammersmith attack. All nationalists and republicans should respect the wishes of the people and abide by the Good Friday Agreement.

'I think people who are involved in that type of behaviour should respect what the people want and stop their behaviour immediately,' McGuinness added.

A senior Irish police officer told The Observer the disruption caused by the explosion was 'a major boost to the Real IRA's morale because they can claim they have taken the republican war into the enemy's capital.

'But the defection of the "engineer" and the fact that they have the Mark 19 is probably even more serious in the long run. After the Rosslea attack the line went out that the device fired was an amateurish job, but further investigation found that the mortar was of an entirely new type.

'It was missing a few component parts, and the only conclusion we drew was that it was a test firing to see how accurate it was. Next time they will hit their target because it was highly accurate.'

The Provisional IRA in south Armagh was 'badly shook up' over the defection, he added. Republicans there say scores of former Provos have gone over to the new group in recent months.

The security forces on both sides of the border intensified their patrols last weekend because they feared a Mark 19 attack might be imminent. It would have been staged to coincide with the decision by David Trimble's Ulster Unionist Council on whether the party should re-enter the power-sharing Executive with Sinn Fein - perhaps swinging wavering delegates against their leader's plan.

Sixteen Real IRA suspects, including the organisation's alleged leader, Michael McKevitt, were rounded up by the Irish police and held for 72 hours under the Republic's anti-terrorist laws.

The Real IRA's tactics have shifted from the indiscriminate car bombing of towns in Northern Ireland to pinpoint mortar attacks on military bases and the disruption of life in British cities.

This shift is a result of the international outcry over its Omagh bombing atrocity two years ago, which killed 29 men, women and children. The Real IRA was forced to call a ceasefire, which effectively ended a year ago.

The choice of Hammersmith Bridge is highly symbolic. It has been a target of IRA campaigns since 1939 when a terrorist unit blew it up at the start of the Second World War. At the time the IRA was colluding with agents of Nazi Germany to disrupt the British war effort.

Four years ago the Provisional IRA again tried to destroy the bridge following the Canary Wharf bomb. The Semtex explosives used in that unsuccessful attack were found following a bungled police raid on the home of Diarmuid O'Neil, an English born IRA member who lived in the Hammersmith area. O'Neil was shot dead during the raid but, according to the RUC, some of the Semtex smuggled into London remained undetected.

The RUC now believes that the Real IRA, some of whose members directed the Provisionals' 1996 mainland bombing campaign, have stolen the explosives from secret hiding places in London.

Last week's Hammersmith attack is also a challenge to the Sinn Fein leadership. According to one former IRA commander: 'The Real IRA are saying to Gerry Adams and Martin McGuinness, "If it was right to try and blow up the bridge four years ago, then it still is today. The war goes on".'

Police in London, Dublin and Belfast are convinced that more attacks in London are imminent, though they have only sparse information on the Real IRA unit in the capital. They believe it is composed of 'unknowns' who are recent recruits.

Officers point to the arrest of three university students picked up in 1998 while they attempted to place firebombs in the West End of London. Six incendiary bombs and a quantity of Semtex were found during the anti-terrorist operation. One of the proposed targets of the summer firebomb campaign was Harrods in Knightsbridge. All three, Anthony Hyland, Liam Grogan and Darren Mulholland, were jailed for a total of 69 years by an Old Bailey jury last year for their part in the incendiary devices conspiracy. None of the trio was an experienced IRA activist.

So far no one has claimed responsibility for last week's bridge bomb, but the security forces in Ireland are convinced that the Real IRA was behind it.

The group was founded at the end of 1997 after a stormy Provisional IRA convention in Falcarragh, Co Donegal. McKevitt, then the Provos' quarter-master general in charge of its huge arsenal, argued that republicans should not sign up to the Mitchell principles on non-violence.

Martin McGuinness and Gerry Adams wanted the party to support the principles so it could remain in the all-party talks that led to the Good Friday Agreement. McKevitt, however, claimed that would mean signing away the IRA's historic right to wage war for a united Ireland. He and his supporters walked out, and later formed the new terrorist group.

Earlier this year, The Observer revealed that the Real IRA's political allies, the 32 County Sovereignty Committee, had formed a London branch and held public meetings in Kilburn.

fields.headline: Army withdraws another 500 soldiers
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Five hundred British soldiers are to be withdrawn from Northern Ireland in order to bolster the peace process. Sir Ronnie Flanagan, the RUC Chief Constable, yesterday announced the latest reduction in troop levels, which brings the number of soldiers in the province to 13,500, the lowest level since 1970.
fields.body:
Five hundred British soldiers are to be withdrawn from Northern Ireland in order to bolster the peace process. Sir Ronnie Flanagan, the RUC Chief Constable, yesterday announced the latest reduction in troop levels, which brings the number of soldiers in the province to 13,500, the lowest level since 1970.

The soldiers from the 3 Para battalion, based in Dungannon, are at the end of their six-month tour of duty in the border region and will not be replaced. The Army described the move as a 'clear demonstration of the improved security situation'.

The cuts come as a number of army installations in North and West Belfast, Tyrone and South Armagh continue to be dismantled. However, security sources say that if the terrorist threat was to grow, troop levels would be quickly increased, particularly if next month's Drumcree parade degenerated into violent clashes in Portadown.

The Army still has 16,000 soldiers available in the event of an emergency in Northern Ireland. The highest number of troops in the province at one time was during Operation Motorman in 1972 when 43,000 soldiers were based there.

fields.headline: Israeli retreat leaves border blurred
fields.standfirst: Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: Since the last Israeli troops and tanks rolled out of southern Lebanon on 24 May, defining the new frontier between the countries has become an exercise in geography and geopolitics.
fields.body:
Sweat dripping from the end of his nose as he laboured under a blazing midday sun, Moshe Bar craned his neck and squinted, trying to sight a straight line along the new fence he was helping to build between Israel and Lebanon.

'Good fences, good neighbours,' he shouted over the din of a generator, sounding more like American poet Robert Frost than a tough Israeli building contractor.

In the Middle East, though, neighbours have never found it simple to draw a dividing line between them.

Since the last Israeli troops and tanks rolled out of southern Lebanon on 24 May, defining the new frontier between the countries has become an exercise in geography and geopolitics.

Using yellowed maps and satellite technology, United Nations cartographers have been redefining the colonial-era frontier that meanders from the Mediterranean coast to the foothills of the Golan Heights, slicing through stony hills, bisecting backyards, halving orchards, even dividing a village.

UN verification of Israel's withdrawal from Lebanon, expected within days, hinges on agreement that the Israelis have fallen back to the internationally recognised 1923 border drawn by Britain, which administered the then-Palestine, and France, which ruled what are now Syria and Lebanon.

As the modern map-makers went about defining the 50-mile frontier with splashes of paint and stone markers, conflicting claims have bubbled to the surface.

Geographers say ambiguities stem from human beings leaving their mark on the landscape: building roads, changing the direction of watersheds, filling in river beds and eradicating other landmarks.

'It becomes a question of translating the map of then to the reality of today - a physical reality that in some areas has changed,' said Amnon Kartin, a professor of geography at Tel Aviv University.

webTitle: Putin meets Clinton in Kremlin arms talks

fields.headline: Putin meets Clinton in Kremlin arms talks
fields.standfirst: Russia: special report
fields.trailText: Two days of intense arms negotiations begin in Moscow today as Vladimir Putin sits down with Bill Clinton to host his first Russian-American summit.
fields.body:
Two days of intense arms negotiations begin in Moscow today as Vladimir Putin sits down with Bill Clinton to host his first Russian-American summit.

There was little expectation that the talks would lead to a breakthrough in an on-going stalemate over nuclear defence systems - which looks set to dominate the summit - despite a hint from Putin that he might be prepared to work with America to develop a joint nuclear shield.

America's well-developed plans to construct a multi-billion dollar missile defence shield - son of Star Wars - continue to cast a chill over US-Russian relations. Russia has adamantly opposed the project and consistently refused to amend the crucial 1972 Anti-Ballistic Missile treaty to allow America to start building the system.

Informal talks between the two leaders were due to begin over dinner last night in the Kremlin, shortly after Clinton's arrival in Moscow. Also on the agenda are economic relations between the two countries, particularly the timetable for a resumption of IMF lending to Russia.

Putin, who has repeatedly emphasised the importance of Russia's relations with the West since his arrival at the Kremlin, has much work to do if he hopes to establish friendly ties with America. US-Russian relations have worsened in recent years under the cumulative effect of Nato's plans for expansion eastwards, the Kosovo conflict and the ongoing arms deadlock.

Human rights activists have called on Clinton to address recent abuses of press freedom and Russia's conduct during its war in Chechnya. A Human Rights Watch report released yesterday detailed a massacre committed by Russian soldiers in the Chechen capital Grozny in which at least 60 civilians were killed, but in a conference designed for presidential bonding the issue looked set to be low on the agenda. Instead officials will be focusing on arms control and exploring ways out of the nuclear defence impasse.

In an interview last week, Putin suggested the US and Russia could build a missile shield jointly to protect against attack from so-called rogue nations such as North Korea and Iraq.

Washington officials reacted coolly, and political commentators in Moscow agreed there was little chance the suggestion would be accepted.

Before he left Germany yesterday Clinton and 13 other world leaders from the centre-left resolved at a summit in Berlin to step up government efforts to manage the global 'New Economy' for the common good. After a brainstorming session hosted by German Chancellor Gerhard Schröder the 14 leaders declared in a formal communiqué that the state should not only check the excesses of financial markets but ensure wealth being created by new technologies such as the Internet is fairly distributed.

'We want economic growth and social justice,' Clinton told a news conference. 'We don't believe in just laissez-faire economics but we don't believe governments alone can solve these problems.'

Schröder, a Social Democrat who has coined the phrase 'New Centre' for the reforms he is pursuing in the German economy, said there must be a 'balance of power' between elected authority and the might of the financial markets. 'We don't want financial markets to dominate politics,' he told the conference at his chancellery offices, which just a decade ago housed the Communist leadership of East Germany.

French Prime Minister Lionel Jospin said the summit, entitled 'Progressive Governance in the 21st Century', expressed the need for a 'return to politics'. Jospin has been a critic of too rapid an abandonment of traditional socialist ideals.

Prime Minister Tony Blair - leading preacher of a 'Third Way' between old-style socialism and unfettered capitalism - dropped out of the summit to be with his new baby.

webTitle: Holy Russia resurrects the  tsarist myth

fields.headline: Holy Russia resurrects the  tsarist myth
fields.standfirst:
Amelia Gentleman visits the site of the 1918 massacre of the imperial family in Yekaterinburg, where a £5m shrine will rise to 'Nicholas the Good'

Russia: special report
fields.trailText: Amelia Gentleman visits the site of the 1918 massacre of the imperial family in Yekaterinburg, where a £5m shrine will rise to 'Nicholas the Good'
fields.body:
Two orthodox priests, a handful of fervently religious pensioners and some local monarchists last week began the macabre task of excavating the ruins of the house where Russia's last tsar was murdered with his family.

Working with spades and rakes brought from their gardens, a group of 40 volunteers scraped at the soil, attempting to carve out the precise boundaries of the windowless cellar where Tsar Nicholas II, his wife Alexandra, four daughters and son were shot by a Bolshevik execution squad in July 1918.

Once the room has been located, the construction of a massive church in honour of the Romanov family will begin - the altar positioned at the exact point where the assassinations were committed. Highlighting the project's gruesome origins, the building, expected to cost at least £5 million, will be consecrated as the 'Church on the Blood'.

The impassioned excitement which the excavation project has inspired in this provincial city in the Urals is further evidence of intensifying nostalgia for Russia's royal family. The same phenomenon was reflected last week in an announcement that the Russian Orthodox Church is to satisfy popular demand, after years of angry debate, and canonise the tsar and his family as royal martyrs in August.

For most of the twentieth century Soviet governments feared that the Romanov execution site could become a shrine for repressed monarchists and a pilgrimage point for Orthodox Christians; officials swiftly converted the modest two-storey house into a museum of the revolution. In 1977, they demolished the building altogether, covered the ruins with a thick layer of asphalt and built a five-lane road next to the spot.

Last week, as bulldozers removed the Tarmac and volunteers began to dig beneath the surface, the site achieved the shrine-like aura which officials had worked so long to keep out. Some diggers were furtively gathering handfuls of earth in plastic bags. 'Take some home with you,' Emma Popova, a local teaching assistant, said. 'This is holy soil. When the church is built, this place will become our Jerusalem. People will travel from all over the world to pray here.'

Most of the volunteers were elderly Yekaterinburg residents, people who learnt at school that Nicholas II was a cruel oppressor, and that the Orthodox faith was harm ful nonsense. Shifting perspectives on Russia's history over the past decade have left many of them with a strange sense of guilt.

'Ours is the most sinful generation. For most of our lives we didn't know what religion was and we didn't pray,' said Lydia Shaladineva, 62, a retired farmer. 'It's only recently that we've found out the importance of religion and that Tsar Nicholas was a good, kind man. We need to have a church here so we can ask forgiveness for our indifference to his death.'

In this confused rush to reassess the past, Nicholas's faults - his anti-Semitism, his ineffectual hold on power - have been blithely forgotten. 'Nicholas was a good man because he did so much for the Orthodox Church. It would be lovely to have another tsar like him,' another volunteer, Valentina Devichova, 61, said as she rested after almost an hour of digging. 'But then, Stalin wasn't such a bad man either.' Father Alexander, the priest overseeing the project, waved incense over the ruins and said prayers as the digging continued. Before the revolution, Yekaterinburg had been blessed with more than 30 churches, he said, but by the late Eighties only one remained in service. Over the past decade, the local patriarchy restored 11, but the town was still short of places to pray.

Many of the diggers had come in search of Romanov memorabilia. But their hopes of finding trinkets dropped carelessly in the grounds were unlikely to be realised; most of the time the family was locked up inside. Nicholas whiled away the hours playing dominoes with his children and reading War and Peace .

Around 2am on 17 July 1918, the tsar and his family were woken by their guards and led down to the cellar. A few minutes later, six executioners were brought in by a local Bolshevik apparatchik and ordered to fire. Some accounts attest that the princesses were protected from the explosion of bullets by jewels sewn into their underclothes. Their assassins are said to have been forced to finish the job with bayonets.

Even the younger of the two on-site priests, Father Yury, 22, was excited by the morbid possibilities of the excavation. 'It would be nice if we found a bit of wall from the cellar with a bullet in it. Of course, it would be a miracle if we did, but miracles like this happen. It's all in the hands of God,' he said. By the end of the week an old cartridge had been unearthed, but local archaeologists were not convinced it was connected with the execution. The skeletons of a woman and a small child were also dug up, but volunteers learnt that the bodies dated back a century before the Romanovs were killed.

The remains of all the family, except Prince Alexei and Princess Maria ,were found by archaeologists in 1991 and buried by the Bolsheviks in the woods outside Yekaterinburg. The search for remnants of the missing two is to be launched again soon.

But a large pile of bricks and stone fragments from the walls of the cellar has been gathered and will be used in construction of the church. Architects have included an accurate recreation of the underground room in their designs. 'This will be a very holy place for prayer,' Grigory Mazaev, the supervising architect, said. The five-cupola building will stand 56 metres high and has been designed in a Russo-Byzantine style typical of late-nineteenth-century churches - updated to include two lifts and underfloor heating. 'It was the style Nicholas favoured himself,' Mazaev said.

Over the past decade the Romanov church project has been cursed with scandal and conflict. In the early Nineties a local priest collected a considerable amount of money to pay for it. Later both the priest and the money disappeared. The project was resurrected in the mid-Nineties, and an architect was commissioned to draw up the plans. But a row broke out with the local administration and he withdrew his design. This time Mazaev is confident that the bulk of the new project will be completed by 2002.

However, the question of funding continues to cause trouble. No state money is forthcoming, so the bulk will come from private donations and sponsors. And the extravagance of the project has shocked many, particularly given the manifold social problems troubling Yekaterinburg, where crime and drug addiction are rife.

None of the volunteers seemed unduly concerned by the expense. 'The young people in this town are crippled by problems - unemployment, drug abuse, crime - but that's precisely why we need a church here,' one woman said.

Shaladineva, who receives a monthly pension of 706 roubles (£16) a month, agreed that the £5m price tag was irrelevant. 'Before I started going to church, I was always short of money. But then I started praying and God began to help me. Last month my pension went up by 50 per cent,' she said.

Working with spades and rakes brought from their gardens, a group of 40 volunteers scraped at the soil, attempting to carve out the precise boundaries of the windowless cellar where Tsar Nicholas II, his wife Alexandra, four daughters and son were shot by a Bolshevik execution squad in July 1918. Once the room has been located, the construction of a massive church in honour of the Romanov family will begin - the altar positioned at the exact point where the assassinations were committed. Highlighting the project's gruesome origins, the building, expected to cost at least £5 million, will be consecrated as the 'Church on the Blood'. The impassioned excitement which the excavation project has inspired in this provincial city in the Urals is further evidence of intensifying nostalgia for Russia's royal family. The same phenomenon was reflected last week in an announcement that the Russian Orthodox Church is to satisfy popular demand, after years of angry debate, and canonise the tsar and his family as royal martyrs in August. For most of the twentieth century Soviet governments feared that the Romanov execution site could become a shrine for repressed monarchists and a pilgrimage point for Orthodox Christians; officials swiftly converted the modest two-storey house into a museum of the revolution. In 1977, they demolished the building altogether, covered the ruins with a thick layer of asphalt and built a five-lane road next to the spot. Last week, as bulldozers removed the Tarmac and volunteers began to dig beneath the surface, the site achieved the shrine-like aura which officials had worked so long to keep out. Some diggers were furtively gathering handfuls of earth in plastic bags. 'Take some home with you,' Emma Popova, a local teaching assistant, said. 'This is holy soil. When the church is built, this place will become our Jerusalem. People will travel from all over the world to pray here.' Most of the volunteers were elderly Yekaterinburg residents, people who learnt at school that Nicholas II was a cruel oppressor, and that the Orthodox faith was harm ful nonsense. Shifting perspectives on Russia's history over the past decade have left many of them with a strange sense of guilt. 'Ours is the most sinful generation. For most of our lives we didn't know what religion was and we didn't pray,' said Lydia Shaladineva, 62, a retired farmer. 'It's only recently that we've found out the importance of religion and that Tsar Nicholas was a good, kind man. We need to have a church here so we can ask forgiveness for our indifference to his death.' In this confused rush to reassess the past, Nicholas's faults - his anti-Semitism, his ineffectual hold on power - have been blithely forgotten. 'Nicholas was a good man because he did so much for the Orthodox Church. It would be lovely to have another tsar like him,' another volunteer, Valentina Devichova, 61, said as she rested after almost an hour of digging. 'But then, Stalin wasn't such a bad man either.' Father Alexander, the priest overseeing the project, waved incense over the ruins and said prayers as the digging continued. Before the revolution, Yekaterinburg had been blessed with more than 30 churches, he said, but by the late Eighties only one remained in service. Over the past decade, the local patriarchy restored 11, but the town was still short of places to pray. Many of the diggers had come in search of Romanov memorabilia. But their hopes of finding trinkets dropped carelessly in the grounds were unlikely to be realised; most of the time the family was locked up inside. Nicholas whiled away the hours playing dominoes with his children and reading War and Peace . Around 2am on 17 July 1918, the tsar and his family were woken by their guards and led down to the cellar. A few minutes later, six executioners were brought in by a local Bolshevik apparatchik and ordered to fire. Some accounts attest that the princesses were protected from the explosion of bullets by jewels sewn into their underclothes. Their assassins are said to have been forced to finish the job with bayonets. Even the younger of the two on-site priests, Father Yury, 22, was excited by the morbid possibilities of the excavation. 'It would be nice if we found a bit of wall from the cellar with a bullet in it. Of course, it would be a miracle if we did, but miracles like this happen. It's all in the hands of God,' he said. By the end of the week an old cartridge had been unearthed, but local archaeologists were not convinced it was connected with the execution. The skeletons of a woman and a small child were also dug up, but volunteers learnt that the bodies dated back a century before the Romanovs were killed. The remains of all the family, except Prince Alexei and Princess Maria ,were found by archaeologists in 1991 and buried by the Bolsheviks in the woods outside Yekaterinburg. The search for remnants of the missing two is to be launched again soon. But a large pile of bricks and stone fragments from the walls of the cellar has been gathered and will be used in construction of the church. Architects have included an accurate recreation of the underground room in their designs. 'This will be a very holy place for prayer,' Grigory Mazaev, the supervising architect, said. The five-cupola building will stand 56 metres high and has been designed in a Russo-Byzantine style typical of late-nineteenth-century churches - updated to include two lifts and underfloor heating. 'It was the style Nicholas favoured himself,' Mazaev said. Over the past decade the Romanov church project has been cursed with scandal and conflict. In the early Nineties a local priest collected a considerable amount of money to pay for it. Later both the priest and the money disappeared. The project was resurrected in the mid-Nineties, and an architect was commissioned to draw up the plans. But a row broke out with the local administration and he withdrew his design. This time Mazaev is confident that the bulk of the new project will be completed by 2002. However, the question of funding continues to cause trouble. No state money is forthcoming, so the bulk will come from private donations and sponsors. And the extravagance of the project has shocked many, particularly given the manifold social problems troubling Yekaterinburg, where crime and drug addiction are rife. None of the volunteers seemed unduly concerned by the expense. 'The young people in this town are crippled by problems - unemployment, drug abuse, crime - but that's precisely why we need a church here,' one woman said. Shaladineva, who receives a monthly pension of 706 roubles (£16) a month, agreed that the £5m price tag was irrelevant. 'Before I started going to church, I was always short of money. But then I started praying and God began to help me. Last month my pension went up by 50 per cent,' she said.

webTitle: Savers net winnings with lucky seven

fields.headline: Savers net winnings with lucky seven
fields.trailText: Suddenly the figure seven has new significance. If you are looking for a savings account, 7 per cent is the best easy-access rate available now.
fields.body:
Suddenly the figure seven has new significance. If you are looking for a savings account, 7 per cent is the best easy-access rate available now. In a climate where savers are stuck permanently with single-figure interest rates, this top figure comes from Nationwide building society, with its new internet-based account, e-Savings. The rate is guaranteed to stay at least 0.5 per cent above base rate until January. You cannot quite get at your money instantly because it has to be transferred from the savings account, via the net, to a Nationwide current account, although you needn't have your salary paid into it.

But with the attractive interest rate, payable on as little as £1, and the rate guarantee, it's not a bad deal. But only, of course, for savers who have access to the internet. This is another example of superior deals for those with net access over those without.

Nationwide's branch-based rates are better than those of most banks, so it is not the industry's worst offender here. The society also gives access to the net, and its net products, through terminals at branches. But as access to the net spreads, increasing take-up of internet accounts and reducing costs for saving institutions, we should see the benefits trickling out across all savings and mortgage products. As a mutual, Nationwide should lead the way.

It has done well to buck the trend among banks to launch internet operations with wacky new names. But most other banks have good reason for wanting to carve out new identities. Nationwide's record with customers in recent years has been netter than most; it doesn't need to reinvent its brand.

Stockbrokers are not noted for deep thinking over the nature of share-ownership - beyond the best way to spread it to their advantage. Gavin Oldham, founder of Share Centre, is different. He is giving away shares in his business because he believes his customers have a right to them.

There could be ulterior motives; a shareholder base composed of customers may be less demanding than big City institutions. But Oldham's share issue - which is proving popular with clients - is an innovative experiment in corporate ownership.

webTitle: Fiji festers as coup talks fail

fields.headline: Fiji festers as coup talks fail
fields.standfirst:
Speight wrecks peace hopes and unrest spreads, reports John Aglionby in Suva

Special report: the Fiji coup
fields.trailText: Fiji was in political chaos again last night with the failure of coup leader George Speight's negotiations with the military to resolve the two-week crisis in the Pacific island nation, when both accused the other of breaking promises made days earlier.
fields.body:
Fiji was in political chaos again last night with the failure of coup leader George Speight's negotiations with the military to resolve the two-week crisis in the Pacific island nation, when both accused the other of breaking promises made days earlier.

After two days of encouraging progress, Speight insisted on being given total control of the Fijian government before releasing his 30-odd hostages and the military made an appeal for national unity against the coup.

Now it is unlikely that the captives the failed businessman turned terrorist is holding in the parliament compound, including the prime minister Mahendra Chaudhry and ministers, will be freed soon.

Meanwhile, in a sign that the turmoil is escalating beyond the capital Suva, several hundred people yesterday held the first ever rally to demand independence for the economically prosperous western half of the main island, Viti Levu.

Speight said the military, who declared martial law on Monday in the absence of a functioning government, was no longer willing to let the country's tribal chiefs decide who should rule and was insisting on sharing power.

The Great Council of Chiefs (GCC) was due to meet tomorrow to choose between a civilian-military interim government or a purely civilian one. The leaders were also to decide on the extent to which Speight and his followers would be represented in the new government.

Military spokesman Lieutenant Colonel Filipo Tarakinikini said they were only reacting to a 'surprising' new set of demands by Speight, who seized his hostages and declared himself ruler of Fiji on 19 May.

These included: executive authority being transferred to the GCC; Speight having power to name the president and himself being included in the interim government; and immunity from prosecution and civil action for Speight and his hundreds of supporters holed up in the parliament compound.

Speight 'has reneged on our earlier agreement which came as a surprise to all of us', Tarakinikini said. 'We are considering the message [he] has delivered.'

For his part, Speight described military commander Commodore Frank Bainimarama as being 'a little bit stubborn'. 'We were planning to [free the hostages on Sun day] but because of this change in the army's stance, that's going to be put off for a little while,' he said.

He said the hostages would only be released 'after all has been confirmed by the GCC. In other words it requires the army to support the GCC, that it should have the final say.' No time has been set for the resumption of talks.

Last night the military made its first public statement openly attacking the coup plotters. Tarakinikini said: 'The solution presented by Mr Speight and his lot will not achieve the promises they are presently making.

'In our assessment what's happening to us is a moral recession of the lowest kind. Mr Speight and his lot have come up with an oversimplistic solution to the problems, the social problems facing our country.

'This is a time for us to stand up and defend the democracy that we believe in. We must rally together to overcome the present crisis and build a country where no one is marginalised, where no one feels threatened.'

Speight has used the frustrations of thousands of poor farmers and urban youths living in and around Suva.

Throughout last week he constantly changed his demands, each time making them stronger.

On Friday he suddenly said that he would like to be prime minister and yesterday's announcement that he would name the president indicates that he is unlikely to end the crisis until he has exactly what he wants. The person he wants as the new president, former teacher and retired rugby player Ratu Jope Seniluli, has no experience of national level politics.

Speight appears to be winning the political battle but there are signs that he is losing control on the ground.

A week ago the parliament compound had a festival atmosphere as 2,000 poor Fijian farmers gathered to see the messiah who would deliver them from poverty.

Yesterday the atmosphere was different. There were few smiles among the couple of hundred bored people sheltering from the tropical sun under army issue tents or in the parliamentarians' offices.

A dozen musicians, singers and preachers from the local Church Mission Fellowship provided entertainment, although they were having to compete against the constant thud of men pounding 'kava'. This is a local root that acts as a stimulant when crushed and mixed with water.

Local criminals make up more of Mr Speight's followers than when the coup was launched. They made their presence felt on Friday night when a mob of several dozen men stormed out of the parliament compound and looted nearby houses and gardens.

Shocked, some of Speight's original supporters locked the mob out. The thugs then threw stones at their supposed comrades. They were only allowed back in when an army squad arrived and shot one man in the leg and arm.

The army responded yesterday by increasing roadblocks around the compound.

Whoever emerges victorious will also have to contend with the separatist demands from the people in the west of Viti Levu. Dozens of chiefs from the region led yesterday's independence rally.

Tavita Momoedonu, local chief and government minister until the coup, said: 'We are fed up with Speight. We are fed up with being trampled on by the East. We have to say enough is enough.'

It is not yet clear whether the region, which generates well over half of Fiji's GDP, will be able to secede soon, analysts say. But they add that the separatists are a clear manifestation of the massive social, political and tribal undercurrents that are tearing at the fabric of the nation.
