webTitle: 'We can't prevent them  murdering each other'

fields.headline: 'We can't prevent them  murdering each other'
fields.standfirst:
One year after the UN 'liberation' of Kosovo, the killing goes on. Peter Beaumont reports from a province still gripped by fear, corruption and multi-ethnic violence.

Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: One year after the UN 'liberation' of Kosovo, the killing goes on.  Peter Beaumont reports from a province still gripped by fear, corruption and multi-ethnic violence.
fields.body:
Vlastimir Miric and Sinisa Dimic were travelling a 'safe' road. But in the Crescent, a semi-circle of Serbian villages around Pristina, nothing is certain for the Serbs who have chosen to stay.

The men were driving on a road created by British soldiers of K-For, the Kosovo protection force, which should have allowed them travel between their villages unmolested by ethnic Albanians. What should have been the most secure area in the province is patrolled by helicopters and armoured cars.

But it was not enough to stop the killers. Some time on Thursday night an anti-vehicle mine was laid by the British road. As the Serbs drove to market it exploded, the blast ripping through the front of their car. Miric, 41, and Dimic, 38, were killed outright. The Nalasa family riding in the back were badly injured. Ristic is 31. Her daughters, Krostna and Bojana, are five and two.

Yesterday, as their families mourned, the British Army opened another new road in the Crescent, built under the auspices of Operation Trojan, whose aim is to improve protection and conditions for the Serbs. The timing has not been lost on the Serbs or senior British officers, few of whom doubt the enormity of the task that now faces them in trying to protect the Serbian population. 'We are doing our best,' said one. 'But the truth is, if people are determined, we cannot stop them murdering each other.'

It is a sentiment that resonates with the entire international presence in the region. For as K-For and the United Nations Mission in Kosovo (UNMIK) prepare to mark next week's first anniversary of their presence in the former south Serbian province, it has been plunged into a sense of crisis by a series of brutal attacks on Serb civilians. These are designed, senior officials believe, to put pressure on Kosovo's remaining 95,000 Serbs to leave for good.

Few are in any doubt about the significance attached to the time chosen for the killings, which are intended to capitalise on the expected disappointment and alarm of Kosovo Serbs who had been led to believe by Belgrade propaganda over the last 12 months that Serbian police and soldiers would return to the province in the next few weeks.

The latest spate of murders began last Sunday evening, when two adults and a four-year-old child were killed in a drive-by killing in the village of Cernica in the so-called Iron Triangle of villages in the south-east of Kosovo. On Wednesday a shooting in the village of Babin Most killed one and injured another.

On Thursday it was the turn of the Serbs of Klokot, when gunmen attacked on a quiet country road, killing a woman and injuring her two male companions.

The murders - which followed a weekend of fighting in villages along the southern border with Serbia - were committed by members of the Liberation Army of Presevo, Medvedja and Bujanovac (UCPMB), which is seeking to reclaim three towns in so-called 'Eastern Kosovo', which remains in Serbia proper. They have highlighted a growing sense within the international community in Kosovo that its mission is in danger of losing its way.

More serious still for their morale is the suspicion that, now the Kosovars have got the upper hand, extremists within their community have rediscovered their determination to cleanse Kosovo of its last Serbs as thoroughly as Slobodan Milosevic tried to cleanse it of Albanians only a year ago.

A year into its mission the UN and K-For have been forced to accept that the remaining Serbs cannot live within the majority ethnic Albanian community without round-the-clock protection. The few hundred that remain in Pristina are guarded 24 hours a day by soldiers of the British brigade. Most are too afraid to venture out to work. The remainder - the vast majority - live either in the north among Serbian communities sustained by contact with Serbia proper to the north, or in fortified hamlets, villages and ghettoes, unable to move except in heavily protected buses. The latest killings simply underline what many within the UN mission now believe - that the much-vaunted policy of preserving a multi-ethnic Kosovo, as set out in Security Council Resolution 1244, has failed. Instead K-For and its soldiers are being forced into cantonisation, locking the Serbs within high-security pockets.

'You've got to be realistic,' said one K-For officer last week. 'These people are not going to live together. Officially the policy is for a multi-ethnic society. Unofficially we would just be happy if they could live side by side without murdering each other.' Another officer was more direct. 'We are just holding the line. We are simply marking time until the international community decides whether Kosovo deserves to have independent status.'

It is likely to be a long wait. For the issue of Kosovo's final status - as an independent nation on the same model as Bosnia, Croatia and Slovenia - is the question haunting the anniversary of Nato's first military engagement in 50 years. For while Nato and its allies won the war, the question is whether the international community is winning - or can win - the peace on terms that it does not find repellent.

And in the current crisis of confidence it is Kosovo's vague legal status (within a wider federal Yugoslavia but outside President Milosevic's control) that has become Kosovo's Catch-22. More properly its has become Catch-1244 for the Security Council resolution that keeps it in a state of legal limbo while in all other respects it creeps towards a de facto independence.

Its borders - in theory policed by Yugoslav police - are controlled by the UN. And for the majority of ethnic Albanians, its independence has already happened, if not by referendum then by popular assent. The only stumbling block is the continuing presence of the Serbs, whose own claim - recognised under Resolution 1244 - is the brake on Kosovar ambitions.

The conviction that Kosovo's independence is an imminent and legal formality is not shared by Kosovo's UN administrator, Bernard Kouchner. 'I know the wish of the majority of Kosovars is for independence, but it is not my problem,' he said recently in the Bulgarian capital of Sofia.

Instead, Kouchner and Daan Everts, head of the mission for the Organisation for Security and Co-operation in Europe, will propose to the Security Council later this month that any decision on Kosovo's final status is deferred for up to five years. Instead of independence, Kosovars will be offered a 'contract with Kosovo' which would provide guaranteed security of their borders from Serb attack and international aid in exchange for political development and putting their claims to independence on hold.

'I think there are enough reasonable people here. They realise they are reliant on us. They are beggars. They are not choosers,' said Everts last week. 'They know that, without the protection of the international community, they would be overrun by the Serbs within one day.'

But even the most moderate ethnic Albanians have grown increasingly frustrated with the international community, a view reflected by Albanian students last week. 'This is our country now,' said Vlora, aged 19, as she watched a parade on Children's Day. 'The sooner the UN realises that and lets us get on and run our lives the better. We must be allowed to run our own affairs.'

It is a frustration felt on both sides. Many in the UN mission are disillusioned by the continuing attacks on Serbs, by criminality, allegations of murder and corruption within the ethnic Albanian political élite and by the sense that the mission in Kosovo has completely lost its way.

'The truth about what is really going on here is being suppressed,' says a senior international officer in the UN police force. 'There are incidents going on all the time that are simply not publicised. There is a deliberate denial of what is really going on. The honeymoon period that greeted our arrival is over. Instead we are accepting the unacceptable. In our rush to get a local police force set up, we are accepting candidates into the force for training that are suspects in murders. Worse than that, we are simply ignoring the criminality of senior figures in the ethnic Albanian community because the UN does not want to rock the boat.'

Another was more bitter. 'Right from last summer, from the beginning of our mission here when the killings, threats and abductions started, we just have not been taking things seriously enough... I think we all - aid workers, diplomats and journalists included - made a mistake. We didn't speak to the right people. Instead we spoke to the kind of people who we found attractive, and in the process we overestimated their influence in the Albanian community...

'We missed the fact that a large part of Kosovar society and the KLA was a petty mafia run by thugs. We have got to take some blame for who we chose to deal with.'

While it is unquestionably true that, after years of persecution, conditions for the majority in Kosovo have improved in the last 12 months, the flip side is that the persecution of minorities in the new Kosovo is as pernicious and insidious as anything ever practised by Milosevic's thugs.

'There was a cartoon in one of the local papers that sums up the problem,' said a diplomat last week. 'It shows a Serb washing his hands that are dripping with blood with a huge knife in his pocket - and a little Albanian boy with a little blood and a tiny knife at the same sink. There is a feeling that what is happening now is not the same thing as happened to them.'

Critical to the disillusionment of many in the UN mission here was the recent murder of Ekrema Rexha, aged 38, a former Kosovo Liberation Army commander, known during the conflict by his nom de guerre, Commander Drini. A former Yugoslav Army officer who was fluent in seven languages and popular with journalists for his charm and diplomacy, he had left the KLA after the arrival of the K-For mission last June and had joined the local administration in the southern city of Prizren as a safety and environmental officer.

Commander Drini was gunned down outside his home in southern Kosovo as he bent down to change a tyre on his car. A gunman shot him eight times in the body and, as a coup de grace, once in the head. As he fell to the street, his wife rushed to cradle his body, screaming: 'Wake up. Wake up. We have a son and another baby on the way.'

Drini's funeral attracted 30,000 mourners, many of whom believed that he was killed by Serbs seeking revenge for his exploits during the civil war. But in the weeks that have followed investigators from the international community have become convinced that he was killed in a political power struggle with former senior colleagues in the KLA.

'It is now becoming clear that Drini was killed because he was becoming so outspoken about the rapid descent into criminality of some of his former colleagues in the KLA,' said one OSCE official. 'Commander Drini was perceived as being far too close and helpful to the UN. His disillusionment over people he believed were involved in murders and racketeering had him marked as a UN collaborator. Politically he had also made dangerous ene mies. He had been sounded out to stand in the elections slated for October and he was a popular figure. We believe there are those of his former colleagues who may have felt threatened by that.'

'He was a moderate. There are those who felt he was becoming too moderate and was too close to the UN,' said an international policeman with the UN force. 'There is a strong suspicion that this was a politically motivated murder, Albanian on Albanian.'

It is a view rapidly gaining currency within the Kosovar community. Drini himself had said before his murder that his family was being intimidated by those 'who did not want to see a democratic state being formed'.

The murder of Drini is doubly worrying for the UN mission as it tries to guide Kosovo towards local elections in the autumn, the first test of its nascent democratic institutions. fields.bodyText: Vlastimir Miric and Sinisa Dimic were travelling a 'safe' road. But in the Crescent, a semi-circle of Serbian villages around Pristina, nothing is certain for the Serbs who have chosen to stay. The men were driving on a road created by British soldiers of K-For, the Kosovo protection force, which should have allowed them travel between their villages unmolested by ethnic Albanians. What should have been the most secure area in the province is patrolled by helicopters and armoured cars. But it was not enough to stop the killers. Some time on Thursday night an anti-vehicle mine was laid by the British road. As the Serbs drove to market it exploded, the blast ripping through the front of their car. Miric, 41, and Dimic, 38, were killed outright. The Nalasa family riding in the back were badly injured. Ristic is 31. Her daughters, Krostna and Bojana, are five and two. Yesterday, as their families mourned, the British Army opened another new road in the Crescent, built under the auspices of Operation Trojan, whose aim is to improve protection and conditions for the Serbs. The timing has not been lost on the Serbs or senior British officers, few of whom doubt the enormity of the task that now faces them in trying to protect the Serbian population. 'We are doing our best,' said one. 'But the truth is, if people are determined, we cannot stop them murdering each other.' It is a sentiment that resonates with the entire international presence in the region. For as K-For and the United Nations Mission in Kosovo (UNMIK) prepare to mark next week's first anniversary of their presence in the former south Serbian province, it has been plunged into a sense of crisis by a series of brutal attacks on Serb civilians. These are designed, senior officials believe, to put pressure on Kosovo's remaining 95,000 Serbs to leave for good. Few are in any doubt about the significance attached to the time chosen for the killings, which are intended to capitalise on the expected disappointment and alarm of Kosovo Serbs who had been led to believe by Belgrade propaganda over the last 12 months that Serbian police and soldiers would return to the province in the next few weeks. The latest spate of murders began last Sunday evening, when two adults and a four-year-old child were killed in a drive-by killing in the village of Cernica in the so-called Iron Triangle of villages in the south-east of Kosovo. On Wednesday a shooting in the village of Babin Most killed one and injured another. On Thursday it was the turn of the Serbs of Klokot, when gunmen attacked on a quiet country road, killing a woman and injuring her two male companions. The murders - which followed a weekend of fighting in villages along the southern border with Serbia - were committed by members of the Liberation Army of Presevo, Medvedja and Bujanovac (UCPMB), which is seeking to reclaim three towns in so-called 'Eastern Kosovo', which remains in Serbia proper. They have highlighted a growing sense within the international community in Kosovo that its mission is in danger of losing its way. More serious still for their morale is the suspicion that, now the Kosovars have got the upper hand, extremists within their community have rediscovered their determination to cleanse Kosovo of its last Serbs as thoroughly as Slobodan Milosevic tried to cleanse it of Albanians only a year ago. A year into its mission the UN and K-For have been forced to accept that the remaining Serbs cannot live within the majority ethnic Albanian community without round-the-clock protection. The few hundred that remain in Pristina are guarded 24 hours a day by soldiers of the British brigade. Most are too afraid to venture out to work. The remainder - the vast majority - live either in the north among Serbian communities sustained by contact with Serbia proper to the north, or in fortified hamlets, villages and ghettoes, unable to move except in heavily protected buses. The latest killings simply underline what many within the UN mission now believe - that the much-vaunted policy of preserving a multi-ethnic Kosovo, as set out in Security Council Resolution 1244, has failed. Instead K-For and its soldiers are being forced into cantonisation, locking the Serbs within high-security pockets. 'You've got to be realistic,' said one K-For officer last week. 'These people are not going to live together. Officially the policy is for a multi-ethnic society. Unofficially we would just be happy if they could live side by side without murdering each other.' Another officer was more direct. 'We are just holding the line. We are simply marking time until the international community decides whether Kosovo deserves to have independent status.' It is likely to be a long wait. For the issue of Kosovo's final status - as an independent nation on the same model as Bosnia, Croatia and Slovenia - is the question haunting the anniversary of Nato's first military engagement in 50 years. For while Nato and its allies won the war, the question is whether the international community is winning - or can win - the peace on terms that it does not find repellent. And in the current crisis of confidence it is Kosovo's vague legal status (within a wider federal Yugoslavia but outside President Milosevic's control) that has become Kosovo's Catch-22. More properly its has become Catch-1244 for the Security Council resolution that keeps it in a state of legal limbo while in all other respects it creeps towards a de facto independence. Its borders - in theory policed by Yugoslav police - are controlled by the UN. And for the majority of ethnic Albanians, its independence has already happened, if not by referendum then by popular assent. The only stumbling block is the continuing presence of the Serbs, whose own claim - recognised under Resolution 1244 - is the brake on Kosovar ambitions. The conviction that Kosovo's independence is an imminent and legal formality is not shared by Kosovo's UN administrator, Bernard Kouchner. 'I know the wish of the majority of Kosovars is for independence, but it is not my problem,' he said recently in the Bulgarian capital of Sofia. Instead, Kouchner and Daan Everts, head of the mission for the Organisation for Security and Co-operation in Europe, will propose to the Security Council later this month that any decision on Kosovo's final status is deferred for up to five years. Instead of independence, Kosovars will be offered a 'contract with Kosovo' which would provide guaranteed security of their borders from Serb attack and international aid in exchange for political development and putting their claims to independence on hold. 'I think there are enough reasonable people here. They realise they are reliant on us. They are beggars. They are not choosers,' said Everts last week. 'They know that, without the protection of the international community, they would be overrun by the Serbs within one day.' But even the most moderate ethnic Albanians have grown increasingly frustrated with the international community, a view reflected by Albanian students last week. 'This is our country now,' said Vlora, aged 19, as she watched a parade on Children's Day. 'The sooner the UN realises that and lets us get on and run our lives the better. We must be allowed to run our own affairs.' It is a frustration felt on both sides. Many in the UN mission are disillusioned by the continuing attacks on Serbs, by criminality, allegations of murder and corruption within the ethnic Albanian political élite and by the sense that the mission in Kosovo has completely lost its way. 'The truth about what is really going on here is being suppressed,' says a senior international officer in the UN police force. 'There are incidents going on all the time that are simply not publicised. There is a deliberate denial of what is really going on. The honeymoon period that greeted our arrival is over. Instead we are accepting the unacceptable. In our rush to get a local police force set up, we are accepting candidates into the force for training that are suspects in murders. Worse than that, we are simply ignoring the criminality of senior figures in the ethnic Albanian community because the UN does not want to rock the boat.' Another was more bitter. 'Right from last summer, from the beginning of our mission here when the killings, threats and abductions started, we just have not been taking things seriously enough... I think we all - aid workers, diplomats and journalists included - made a mistake. We didn't speak to the right people. Instead we spoke to the kind of people who we found attractive, and in the process we overestimated their influence in the Albanian community... 'We missed the fact that a large part of Kosovar society and the KLA was a petty mafia run by thugs. We have got to take some blame for who we chose to deal with.' fields.headline: Going to pieces
fields.trailText: I'm left with the dodgy brakes, which is fine for getting my wife to work, but she's surely not expecting me to drive it?
fields.body: I have so impressively acquitted myself as a person capable of being in charge of checking the oil in the car and guessing how much air is in the tyres before my wife drives off to Robin Hood's Bay for a few days' well-earned relaxation alone with all the children that I now seem to have been mistaken for someone with sufficient time on his hands to do something about our ridiculous bed, which creaks every time anyone so much as exhales near it, let alone attempts any movement of the rhythmical sort on the infrequent occasion that we might find ourselves alone in it. 'What - today?' I screech. 'No time like the present,' says my wife, ruling out the past for obvious reasons, and mindful that the future (as measured from now until Saturday) will be short of trained supervisory staff to stand over me until it gets done. 'It won't take long,' she says. Wrong. I haul the mattress off to reveal not only possibly the last remaining parallelogram-shaped bed in Hertfordshire but an unusual shortfall in the number of bits holding it together, which now explains how the removal men managed to put it together so quickly when we moved in last summer. 'It needs some screws,' I say. 'I'll just nip out to Do-It-All. I won't take long...' No way. Suddenly they're running late and absolutely MUST get to the McDonald's at Newport Pagnall or somewhere by lunch, which means I'm left with the brown Metro with the dodgy brakes we borrowed from her mother, which admittedly is fine for getting my wife to work but she's surely not expecting me to drive it? 'Well, I suppose you could walk,' she says. 'You'll be back this time tomorrow!' How hilarious. There's a cooked chicken in the fridge, she adds as she drives off, the children blowing kisses and making faces in the back, as though I'm incapable of opening a tin of soup. This should be the point where I lie down on the sofa and enjoy the novelty of being able to hear myself sniff (I have a cold) without being told to find a tissue if I wouldn't mind, but instead I'm obliged to drive the rattletrap up to Do-It-All and back, and spend the rest of the afternoon discovering how difficult it is to think up enough swearwords to make a bed rectangular using no method more technically orthodox than banging your fingers with a hammer. At last I've finished, but by now the damned thing's got so much metal in it I need a forklift truck to get it back against the wall. Come seven o'clock, the thrill of being left to my own supposedly leisure-oriented devices has worn off, so I walk eight miles up to the village and park myself in a pub, where I soon come to the attention of the locals by provocatively reading a book outside library opening hours. But before anyone gets the chance to call the police, the bloody quiz starts up and the place is jam-packed full of people chewing Biros and conferring over the likely weight of the common shrew. This isn't the best time to leave my spot and go off to the toilets to look at stupid prints of dogs playing snooker and a sign on the hand drier saying 'Wash your hands' - I mean, like you'd be drying your hands if you hadn't yet worked out how to get them wet - and sure enough by the time I get back I have been crowded out into the fireplace by an overweight, frowning couple in matching Camra sweatshirts with a loudspeaker in my ear. 'Question FOUR,' the quizmaster is booming. 'What material were George Washington's false teeth made of?' Actually, I do know this one, but I'm afraid I wouldn't lean across the table to offer the hand of friendship with a confident if unsolicited ejaculation of the word 'wood' if they paid me. After hours of this, someone wins £5 and I stagger out with six pints of Guinness inside me and try to find my way home down the hill and up the lane in the pitch black now that summer's here and all the trees have grown leaves. Naturally I have neglected to leave a light on, though this is not an issue because I have now strayed from the path and begun stumbling through the woods, which strictly speaking only counts as a short cut if you live in the next county. But at last I'm standing in the kitchen devouring a chicken whole without using a plate and drinking milk from the carton before clomping up to bed as loud as I want. Now for a decent night's... Creak. phil.hogan@observer.co.uk

webTitle: The site offends? We'll pluck it out

fields.headline: The site offends? We'll pluck it out
fields.trailText: How to censor the net (in England and Wales anyway) in three easy stages.
fields.body:
How to censor the net (in England and Wales anyway) in three easy stages.

Step One. Find a website that annoys you. This could be because it defames you of course, but a page which pokes fun at you, ridicules your taste in cigars or contains impertinent links to your own website will do just as well.

Step Two. Find out the name of the Internet Service Provider (ISP) which hosts the offending site. This is easy to do. First you use the Tracert programme (it comes with Windows) to find the internet address of the host; entering the address in the Ripe Whois database will then give the name of the ISP. After that, all you need is a telephone directory.

Step Three. Get your solicitor to write a threatening letter to the ISP demanding that they remove the offending page or pages. If the company is based in England or Wales, you will be gratified to discover that the offending material will quickly disappear from the web - even if your complaint is frivolous, preposterous or just plain barmy. Neat, eh?

How does it work? Simple. The moment the ISP receives your solicitor's letter, it will consult its lawyers, who will immediately recommend that the ISP complies with your request. In support, they will cite the celebrated libel case in which a British academic complained to Demon Internet about some defamatory material contained in Usenet postings which were relayed by Demon (and thousands of ISPs throughout the world). Demon failed to respond to his complaint, and on 26 March last year Mr Justice Morland ruled in the High Court that the company was liable for the content of a Usenet discussion group. The Morland ruling is now a precedent, with the effect that all ISPs in England and Wales are prima facie liable for any defamatory material that they know they are carrying, irrespective of where it originated.

Of course, it is possible that an ISP faced with your complaint might investigate it, judge it to be frivolous or unfounded and respond with a missive saying 'see you in court, sunshine', much as a serious newspaper would do. But ISPs are run by businessmen whose main interest is making money, not defending free speech. And most lawyers specialise in the legal discipline known as CYA (covering your ass). So most (English and Welsh) ISPs will take the easy way out and yank pages upon receipt of a complaint.

You think I jest? BBC journalist Giles Wilson recently conducted an ingenious experiment to see how robust British ISPs are in the face of legal complaints. He wrote a spoof web page ridiculing a colleague, posted it on the web and then asked a range of ISPs what they would do if his colleague complained.

Robert Fox of BB-Online, a small ISP that hosts about 2,000 sites, said: 'I'd pull the site down. I'd try to contact the client, but I would have to pull it down.' A BT spokesman said that they would look at the offending site first 'but wherever possible we would wish to avoid any legal proceedings'. Rhian Ball, of Freenetnames, said: 'If the solicitor wrote to us, we would take it down. We've got our own lawyers, and they would always advise that if there were any doubts, we should take it down'. And Nicholas Lansman, of the Internet Service Providers' Association, told Wilson: 'I think ISPs would take the decision to accept the notice and remove the content.'

All of which is a far cry from the libertarian view of the net as a medium that would be immune to censorship. It also explains why the phrase 'poor lawyer' is an oxymoron.

John.Naughton@observer.co.uk

fields.headline: Expansion goes before a fall
fields.trailText: The BBC's economics editor, Peter Jay, once joked that introducing Margaret Thatcher to monetarism was like showing Genghis Kahn a map of the world.
fields.body:
The BBC's economics editor, Peter Jay, once joked that introducing Margaret Thatcher to monetarism was like showing Genghis Kahn a map of the world.

Monetarism, as a means of controlling inflation, proved a disaster; but the combination of old-fashioned deflation and generally bashing the unions did the trick instead - at least for a time.

Jay has gone on to make a fair attempt to conquer the economic history of the world in his forthcoming book Road to Riches or The Wealth of Man (Weidenfeld). It is wonderful for anyone who wants to put current fashions, such as the so-called new economy, into perspective.

Jay declares an open verdict on whether mankind can continue reaping the benefits of technological progress without being overcome by ecological or other disasters.

With regard to more immediate problems, Jay reminds us of his conclusion in the Seventies that 'high employment could no longer be underwritten by expansionary fiscal and monetary policies without an unacceptable consequence for prices'.

That led him to monetarism, which I did not find mentioned in this book. But he notes as one of the important features of globalisation that it 'must have changed the supply and demand balance for labour and therefore the relative bargaining power of capital and labour'.

I read Jay's book during the week that the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development published its latest Economic Outlook. In the early Seventies it was a synchronised expansion among the OECD countries that preceded the oil crisis and what Jay calls 'one more turn of the inflationary screw'.

The interesting thing about the OECD's latest forecasts is that they are robust enough to worry the OECD itself and to bring back memories of what can happen when expansions get out of control.

Thus the OECD tells us: 'World economic prospects are brighter than they have been for some time. OECD-wise output growth for this year is projected at 4 per cent, the fastest pace for more than a decade.' But it goes on to worry that, instead of 'redistributing demand' across countries, international trade may now be helping 'to transmit overall domestic demand growth and rising inflationary pressures in individual countries'.

The OECD is concerned about the impact on oil and other commodity prices, and on 'core inflation' and 'inflation expectations'. It also notes that financial markets are hardly acting as a 'stabilising force' - on the contrary. Basically it is telling us that, unless brilliantly handled by central bankers, world economic expansion could get out of hand, and the resulting 'correction' could be very painful.

We are likely to hear more warnings of trouble in store this week when the highly respected Bank for International Settlements publishes its annual report. The BIS was one of the few bodies to sound the alarm in advance of the Asian crisis of 1997. It is in close touch with the mar kets, and is bound to be concerned about reports that the financial markets are becoming more illiquid as they become more concentrated.

There are concerns among central bankers about the ability of the global system to handle a stock market crash and/or a collapse of the dollar. The last time there was a threat to the system was in the summer of 1998. As the BIS general manager Andrew Crockett recently said, the Russian debt default brought a flight to both quality and liquidity. 'In the event, the danger was averted by timely reductions in interest rates and an officially encouraged rescue of LTCM (Long-term Capital Management)... Nevertheless it had been a close call. It was a great irony that the Soviet Union had a good name in international capital markets for servicing its debt, and that it was post-Communist Russia, via the events that led to that default, that tested the Western financial system to the limits of its creativity. The result was the US Federal Reserve first cut rates, as Crockett says, in order to save the system, and was subsequently slow to raise them. All the emphasis now is on raising interest rates to cool the boom.

Globalisation may have altered the balance of power between capital and labour, and therefore assisted the battle against inflation. But what concerns the OECD and central bankers is that the laws of supply and demand have not been repealed by globali sation, and the inflationary dangers of a synchronised boom cannot be dismissed.

The question is whether central banks, if they raise rates aggressively, will once again be faced with a threat to the system.

Jay offers an interesting challenge for governments of the left or centre that are hailing the consequences of globalisation. 'The challenge,' he says, 'is not how to isolate the home economy from global market forces, but how to recycle the income that is flooding in from the enhanced profitability of capital back to the bulk of ordinary consumers whose income as workers has relatively diminished.'

Jay dares to suggest that there be public and corporate welfare schemes 'financed out of the general stream of corporate profits and the general pool of taxation'. This, as he acknowledges, is very close to the European Social Model, which is often the object of mockery by our Labour Ministers. It would involve standing up to the press barons of whom Labour lives in fear - and who pay so little tax themselves.

fields.headline: Second city looks skyward
fields.standfirst:
Birmingham's airport has been neglected by travellers but now it's ready to be a hub, says Joanna Walters
Transport in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Birmingham's airport has been neglected by travellers but now it's ready to be a hub, says Joanna Walters
fields.body:
The cold, hard fact about Birmingham International Airport is that more people from the region travel to Manchester and London to catch their planes than to their local airport.

This is a situation that airport managing director Brian Summers and his team want to remedy over the next decade. The airport is growing rapidly and doubled its traffic during the Nineties to seven million passengers a year, with particularly buoyant development in the last three years. But it has always been a source of frustration that the airport serving Britain's second city and its vital industrial region is not 'self-sufficient' when it comes to providing air services for the local population.

Passenger traffic from Birmingham's airport could easily double in the next decade without the need for extra runways or terminals. Almost half these passengers come directly from the West Midlands region, many from the East Midlands and the rest from an area stretching from the Severn to the Wash. Summers estimates that the airport serves half the business travel needs of the 15 million people living within a two-hour drive of the airport, but only 37 per cent of the demand for holiday flights. He said: 'At the moment, more people in our regional market go elsewhere for their air services than come to us.'

The dream is to build up services, both scheduled and charter, over the coming years so that the airport satisfies more and more of local people's travel needs.

Many airlines have been reluctant to fly routes from Birmingham, either because they felt they could not make money or simply that flying from Manchester, Heathrow and Gatwick is so lucrative and popular they decided it obviated the need to serve Brum.

But Summers said this is changing. The UK air travel market is growing at around 6 per cent a year, people want to fly from their local airport and the Birmingham team constantly lobbies airlines, using route and market analysis showing which new services might be viable.

'People used to think we do not need to fly from Birmingham because it is all about services from London. But now people are increasingly saying Birmingham is here in its own right and we need to have good air service links; we know there are good services from Manchester and London, but we want them here in our own region.'

Birmingham had an air link to Heathrow until 1993 when the airline operating it, British Midland, pulled out.

The move was seen as a blow at the time, but Summers said that, with hindsight, it helped Birmingham to become stronger as an independent airport.

'In many ways our history is almost blighted by our proximity to London, but in the last 10 years we have turned around that situation. Since flights to Heathrow finished it has helped us become more self-sufficient, developing our own routes and becoming more accessible - being used as an entry point into the global system rather than just a feeder airport,' he said.

Birmingham International Airport now has two non-stop, daily scheduled services to the United States: American Airlines to its hub at Chicago, and Continental Airlines flying into New York's Newark airport.

Up to three-quarters of the passengers using these services are not going to Chicago or New York but are connecting there for other US destinations, or even flights to Central and South America and Canada. Toronto is coming on stream this summer. New services to Pakistan began in April and the flights to Islamabad, Lahore and Karachi, operated by Pakistan International Airlines, have proved a significant boost to the airport's international standing.

The flowering of international airline alliances and growth of 'hub' airports on the Continent are both developments in the airline industry that have benefited Birmingham and made the region less reliant on London for its air services in recent years.

Airlines, the airports, business travel agents in the area and passengers themselves are increasingly waking up to the fact that long-haul connections are often better made by flying from Birmingham to somewhere such as Amsterdam or Paris, then transferring - rather than trekking to Heathrow.

Travellers heading from Birmingham to Australia, for example, now often prefer to fly with British Airways to Frankfurt and transfer onto BA's partner airline, Qantas, for its service to Sydney, rather than driving or taking the train to London. Similarly, a Sabena flight from Birmingham to Brussels gives passengers a 50-minute connection to Johannesburg.

Summers said: 'There is no reason for Midlands travellers to go to Manchester for European scheduled services, because we have got virtually the same network. It has grown up around British Airways, but now other European carriers, such as Lufthansa, KLM and Air France are building up their connections.

'With airline alliances and international connections over various hub airports on the Continent becoming more sophisticated, Birming ham is now just another entry point into the global system. Increasingly, you plug into the world network from your local airport, and we want to build on this trend.'

Birmingham has missed some transatlantic opportunities, however, because of the restricted air agreement between the UK and US.

The rules about which airlines could fly where across the Atlantic were relaxed partially in 1994 and this sparked the initial development of scheduled flights to the US.

But the failure thus far of the UK and US to agree a deal to open up Heathrow to greater transatlantic competition has had a knock-on effect on all regional airports, including Birmingham.

Because airlines, principally from the US but also companies such as British Midland, are focusing their fight on winning transatlantic access to Heathrow, they refuse to launch services from places like Birmingham in case it undermines their efforts to expand in London.

It is felt that at least one or two other US routes would have been started out of Birmingham over the last five years if the Heathrow question had been resolved.

There is now growing expectation that the UK and US will pull off a new air transport accord this summer - their last chance to do so before the Clinton administration battens down for the November election and all other major issues are sidelined.

It may not be a full-blown removal of restrictions between Heathrow and the US for all carriers, but a further partial opening up of the London hub will be a major development.

If more airlines achieve their target of flying transatlantic from Heathrow, then airports such as Birmingham, Manchester and Glasgow hope the companies will then turn their attention to potentially lucrative new US routes from the regions. But Summers warned: 'We have been held back by the transatlantic impasse. But, conversely for us, it might take some time for us to get over the opening up of Heathrow if there is a new bilateral deal.

'The US carriers will want to pour into Heathrow and there will be a massive competitive market situation. It could be a bloodbath and the regions will suffer collectively in this sort of arena. But eventually it will settle down and we might have to wait for that before we see benefits.' Summers added that he supported the adoption of an 'open position' across the Atlantic, but insisted that the UK must get a fair deal for its airlines.

Meanwhile, Birmingham is busy with its steady expansion programme.

It is in year four of a 10-year, £260 million spending programme to modernise its facilities and increase capacity at the airport. It is already the third largest airport in the UK for charter traffic, although only 38 per cent of the annual 7 million passengers are flying charter on package holidays, with 62 per cent using scheduled airlines.

The current investment programme was launched in 1997 after the airport's ownership structure changed, in line with government policy, from an entirely public-sector organisation into a public-private partnership. It is now owned 49 per cent by the seven West Midlands local authorities and 40 per cent by Irish airport business Aer Rianta, with small percentages held by National Car Parks, John Laing and an employee share trust. The airport employs 5,300 staff directly on site and this is forecast to increase to 12,300 by 2011.

It is all a long way from the humble beginnings of the then Elmdon airstrip planned by Birmingham City Council in 1928 on a site eight miles south-east of the city. Its development was put on hold by the Depression.

No sooner had the airport opened in 1939 than it was requisitioned for military purposes and Stirling and Lancaster bombers were sent from local factories, via Elmdon, to the RAF in the Second World War.

Commercial scheduled services resumed in 1949 and now 160 services depart from the international airport daily. Summers said: 'We are a vital part of the infrastructure for the whole region.'

fields.headline: The emperor's new roles
fields.standfirst:
CNN mogul Ted Turner talks to Lucy Rouse about being sidelined by AOL Time Warner
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: CNN mogul Ted Turner talks to Lucy Rouse about being sidelined by AOL Time Warner
fields.body:
Walking into Ted Turner's office on the eve of the 20th birthday of his treasured news network CNN is a poignant experience. Cluttering every inch of wall space are the trophies of 40 years at the peak of the world's global media industry. But what's so chilling about these mementos is how far and how fast Turner is slipping from his glory days.

On Turner's capacious desk is a motto: 'If you can't lead, follow or get out of the way.' And Turner is getting out of the way, or at least being elbowed aside by a gaggle of men in suits - the men from AOL and Time Warner, to which Turner sold his cable broadcasting empire just four years ago.

Braving out the latest restructuring which sees Turner lose executive control of his broadcast networks he yells: 'When companies merge, people always get laid off, right. What's the big deal about that? And the merger hasn't gone through yet. So I've got my pink slip, right. But something could happen to the merger. My favourite song - I was listening to it today - is 'One Day At a Time, Sweet Jesus' . Just take one day at a time; there may not be a next week anyway, the way things are; it's very uncertain.'

Exactly what is uncertain is left unspoken. But in what is being described by CNN insiders as a bloodless coup, Turner is being demoted in favour of AOL executives as the online service provider merges with Time Warner. News of the management restructuring - set to be operational once the $143 billion merger is finalised in the autumn - emerged this week at CNN's World Report, an annual event that brings politicians and CNN heavyweights together for a week-long conference.

The detail of the new management was given in a press release four weeks ago. But the news that Turner's only title once the merger is completed will be 'special advisor and vice-chairman'- a non-executive role he shares with at least one other suit - only appeared in the Los Angeles Times a few days before.

Gerald Levin, chief executive of AOL Time Warner, is frank. 'It's my responsibility to put in place a structure that maximises the tremendous talent that we have - most particularly in the case of Ted. What we're attempting to do, and Ted fully understands this, is to take his capability and give him a broader platform so that he can provide the kind of wisdom that's necessary in our company.'

But here's the rub - and it comes from AOL Time Warner chairman Steve Case. 'He will play a bigger role on the overall strategy of the company. He was surprised by the speed of the decision. Gerry came and said here's a structure and suddenly a week or so later we announced and I think he was surprised by the pace of that. But he asked to play a broader role and that's the role he's going to play.'

What Turner is left with is a whole lot of anecdotes. About how Fidel Castro gave him the idea for launching CNN International (the dictator was watching a pirated version of the American channel in Communist Cuba at the time); about how the start of the Gulf War in 1991 was 'unquestionably' CNN's finest moment; and about how his obsessive hate for rival Rupert Murdoch has mellowed to a mild dislike. 'He's an easy person not to like. I don't hate him... I have hated him but, as Martin Luther King said, hate is a burden to bear.'

In place of the fighting talk of recent times is an alarming acceptance of Murdoch's position in the world. 'I don't want to talk about Rupert today. I've said enough about Rupert to last a lifetime.

'I just wish him the best of luck with his new young wife. I heard he had a mild case of cancer so I hope he gets healthy soon. My fingers are not crossed.'

When it comes to his own media interests, Turner is already working at arm's length. Asked about accusations of news broadcasters dumbing down, Turner replies: 'There's always been some news media that try and exploit the dumbing down of news. And there's a lot of pressure because the dumber you are, a lot of times that will get a bigger audience. And we're not immune from it. We ran a lot of stuff on OJ Simpson; we ran a lot of stuff on the death of Diana.'

And then comes a story of how, earlier this week, he thought twice before intervening in the day-to-day editorial decision-making of CNN.

'On CNN Headline News... the China trade bill being approved was second and we led with something very small; maybe a school kid killed the teacher or something. I was just appalled. I almost called in, but I didn't - and an hour later they'd reversed the stories.' You get the feeling that, five years ago, Turner would have made that call.

And the issue comes up again, as Turner is asked what his latest editorial con tribution to CNN was. 'Most recently I've asked them to do a major series of stories on the nuclear weapon situation because it's gone off people's radar... That's one of the stories recently but I don't do it all the time because CNN do a pretty good job of going out and digging up the stories.'

Laudable in intent, but a world away from the strategic synergy talk of the suits leading the AOL Time Warner.

Looking ahead to his own place in the media of the future, he's equally sanguine about the news agenda 20 years from now. 'I hope we'll be doing what we're doing today,' he says. 'Reporting the news honestly and fairly with a strong emphasis on international news... I wish we were more accurate and better but you can always find things to criticise. Generally I'm pretty pleased with it.'

So how will he protect his beloved CNN? 'All you can do is the best that you can. It's one reason why I merged with Time Warner. Rupert Murdoch wanted to acquire CNN five years ago, 10 years ago. That's how I got to know him. And he was very charming.

'But I studied what he stood for in journalism and Time was best. So I thought that merging with a company that had a history of strong journalistic integrity would be best.

'There's no way you can prepare for every eventuality. Some bad person could take over Time Warner. I mean it could happen, but you have to go with the odds and you can't stay forever.

'I couldn't stay here forever anyway. You get too old or you die. Crazy Horse, the great Indian chief, was fighting against American soldiers with guns and all he had was a bow and arrow. He said only the rocks live forever and that's right.'

'He's an easy person not to like. I don't hate him... I have hated him but, as Martin Luther King said, hate is a burden to bear.' In place of the fighting talk of recent times is an alarming acceptance of Murdoch's position in the world. 'I don't want to talk about Rupert today. I've said enough about Rupert to last a lifetime. 'I just wish him the best of luck with his new young wife. I heard he had a mild case of cancer so I hope he gets healthy soon. My fingers are not crossed.' When it comes to his own media interests, Turner is already working at arm's length. Asked about accusations of news broadcasters dumbing down, Turner replies: 'There's always been some news media that try and exploit the dumbing down of news. And there's a lot of pressure because the dumber you are, a lot of times that will get a bigger audience. And we're not immune from it. We ran a lot of stuff on OJ Simpson; we ran a lot of stuff on the death of Diana.' And then comes a story of how, earlier this week, he thought twice before intervening in the day-to-day editorial decision-making of CNN. 'On CNN Headline News... the China trade bill being approved was second and we led with something very small; maybe a school kid killed the teacher or something. I was just appalled. I almost called in, but I didn't - and an hour later they'd reversed the stories.' You get the feeling that, five years ago, Turner would have made that call. And the issue comes up again, as Turner is asked what his latest editorial con tribution to CNN was. 'Most recently I've asked them to do a major series of stories on the nuclear weapon situation because it's gone off people's radar... That's one of the stories recently but I don't do it all the time because CNN do a pretty good job of going out and digging up the stories.' Generally I'm pretty pleased with it.' So how will he protect his beloved CNN? 'All you can do is the best that you can. It's one reason why I merged with Time Warner. Rupert Murdoch wanted to acquire CNN five years ago, 10 years ago. That's how I got to know him. And he was very charming. 'But I studied what he stood for in journalism and Time was best. So I thought that merging with a company that had a history of strong journalistic integrity would be best. 'There's no way you can prepare for every eventuality. Some bad person could take over Time Warner. I mean it could happen, but you have to go with the odds and you can't stay forever. 'I couldn't stay here forever anyway. You get too old or you die. Crazy Horse, the great Indian chief, was fighting against American soldiers with guns and all he had was a bow and arrow. He said only the rocks live forever and that's right.'

webTitle: The Midas of mobiles dials up a fantasy too far

fields.headline: The Midas of mobiles dials up a fantasy too far
fields.trailText: Every new industry needs its maverick entrepreneur, its Freddie Laker, its Richard Branson, its Henry Ford. And mobile telephony has Hans Snook, the 'high priest' of talking while walking, who seldom moves without a Moog synthesiser striking up a fanfare and a puff of dry ice obscuring the hem of his long leather trench coat.
fields.body:
Every new industry needs its maverick entrepreneur, its Freddie Laker, its Richard Branson, its Henry Ford. And mobile telephony has Hans Snook, the 'high priest' of talking while walking, who seldom moves without a Moog synthesiser striking up a fanfare and a puff of dry ice obscuring the hem of his long leather trench coat.

In another life he would have been a member of German techno band Kraftwerk. But as it is, Snook sits on top of Orange - a suitable place for a man who is the keenest advocate of colonic irrigation since Fergie moved to Southfork and Princess Diana passed on. And last week he pulled off a terrific personal coup, by writing his own lucrative contract to hang on to the top slot and virtual autonomy at Orange after its £30 billion purchase by France Télécom. There was never really any doubt that Snook would get what he wanted. Where else were the French going to drum up such a master showman, who raves with unconfined enthusiasm about '300 per cent penetration' and 'a device for every day of the week'?

To listen to his evangelising about impossible feats of future growth for Orange, one wonders whether he is cultivating the 'mobies', a wireless branch of the moonies (preferred dress code orange, of course). While Snook's enthusiasm is a marvellous thing to behold, it is easy to detach his proselytising from some cold, hard common sense. That £30bn seems to be a hefty price for Orange is not in doubt, even France Télécom's finance director was of the opinion that it was 'not cheap'.

Snook has never, in fairness, gone on the record to defend the price paid, but he can be satisfied that his wizardry at brand- and service- building should have been so successful as to make the French hand over such a huge quantity of weak euros.

Being big in the game is for now more important than being profitable. Which is why Orange commanded such a high price to keep the French in competition with Chris Gent's Vodafone Mannesmann. Being religiously sceptical about anything that might capture the markets' imagination, it is as well to ask whether the hurry to acquire mass mobility hasn't lost sight of the ultimate value of the industry.

Snook's Mr 300 per cent act is charming and, when our TVs are in fact big-screen telephones with high-speed internet downloads instead of quaint cathode ray tubes, we may indeed have a device for every day of the week. However, as the country and indeed the Continent expect talk to become ever cheaper, and even free, the expectations of third-generation and Wap phones (unkindly dubbed Crap phones by some) are high indeed. In fact Vodafone expects that an outlay of £80bn on 3G licences will yield 15 per cent, or more than £90bn over 20-years.

Inflationary pressure will ease this burden, but it either means subscribers paying more, or penetration soaring, and quickly. Supplying your customers with free improving technology while they expect bills to fall will be tricky, if not impossible.

But at least Snook has time and a large protected French monopoly on his side. The tanking of the first wave of 3G expectations (due to happen in about a year's time), may shake out the weaker players and dent stocks, but Orange and Vodafone are in the gladiatorial ring for the long slog. What will test the faith of investors is if Snook's penetration bottoms out, so to speak, at nearer 75 per cent than 300 per cent, or if there is another major health scare (as there is almost bound to be), or if one of the third- placed competitors starts a kamikaze mission to make prices unsustainably low.

Like the internet, mobile telephony will only proliferate. So far it has had the drop on the net because it has been able to charge for its product and will benefit from the initial plague of technoliterates spending hours surfing the net via their utterly inadequate handsets. It benefits from comparisons with the highly transitory valuations attached to far flimsier companies, such as Freeserve.

But one can't help feeling that we consumers will be asked to part with more cash than we would strictly like for the pleasure of having our ears fried and our eyes strained.

And this is where Snook's vision comes apart for many. We would all quite gladly buy into the utopia which has us watching the web from the train, plane and automobile, and even that has us being penetrated by 100 per cent. The fashion-conscious would even acquiesce to the idea of a device for every day of the week.

But buying into a vision is one thing. Paying for the bloody thing is quite another.

fields.headline: The whey ahead...
fields.standfirst:
From cheese to car parts, business-to- business online exchanges are taking off. Faisal Islam reports
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: From cheese to car parts, business-to- business online exchanges are taking off. Faisal Islam reports
fields.body:
Dairy produce can rarely have achieved so pioneering a place at the heart of the new economy. A fortnight ago, Sainsbury sourced its entire quarterly supply of economy mild cheddar using an internet auction.

A process that normally takes several weeks was whittled down to four hours. The auction used, an online exchange for retailers set up by Sears, Carrefour and Sainsbury.

The growth of industry-sponsored business-to-business (b2b) exchanges is accelerating. The automotive, airline, chemicals and textiles industries are already heading towards launching exchanges this year.

All around the world competitor companies are joining forces to harness the net's transparency and accessibility to cut procurement costs, reduce inventories and broaden supply networks.

The promise of b2b e-commerce is essentially that it can iron out inefficiencies in the supply chain. But there is also scope for buyers to get together to exert monopoly power in tight markets and force down supplier margins.

B2b became a watchword for discerning internet investment during the market's exuberant peaks. A survey by PriceWaterhouseCoopers showed that investment in b2b internet applications in Britain is now, for the first time, bigger than in business-to-consumer (b2c).

Using the internet in well-established businesses contrasts with the fickle world of business-to-consumer e-commerce, where factors such as 'sticky' page impressions, viral (word of mouth) marketing, content and brand strength are what drives stock market valuations of profitless and possibly revenue-free business models.

But b2b does not require the savage marketing costs that are beginning to floor consumer-facing companies.

B2b prospects have, however, fallen foul of statistical exuberance. The press releases announcing new industry exchanges compete to name the most staggering amount of business that might pass through the exchange.

Analysts predicted that a trillion dollars of transactions would be conducted in online exchanges by 2002. But this does not say anything about the future prospects of b2b ventures. As Morgan Stanley pointed out in a recent market report, the New York stock exchange supported transactions worth $7.3 trillion in 1998 - but the profit they earned was just $101m.

Far from being the 'next big thing', pure b2b companies, such as Ariba and Com merceOne, were affected by the recent market turmoil more than most, losing more than two-thirds of their market value since mid-March. Market jitters reflect doubts over exactly who will be the main beneficiaries of implementing b2b e-commerce.

The large manufacturing industry exchanges - for example in the automotive business, where Ford, DaimlerChrysler and GM have joined forces - all make a point of prospects for flotation. The partners generally have equity stakes alongside a technology partner. The assumption is that if a large volume of b2b transactions happen on an exchange, it has intrinsic value.

But prospects for revenue are limited - as the NYSE figures illustrate. Taking small percentages from these huge transactions may seem one revenue-raising possibility. But significant commissions would mean that users would lose any incentive to shift to online procurement. Exchanges are more likely to charge nothing at all to attract buyers and suppliers.

Buyers appear to be the likely winners from the intro duction of these exchanges: they can make savings by improving coordination with suppliers and coaxing their margins down.

After just six weeks of the GlobalNetXchange, Sainsbury has already seen benefits. 'We've seen some saving plus a broadening of our supply,' says Patrick McHugh, group e-commerce director. The auction for the cheese supply was open to invited companies only, with the final decision on the basis of quality.

Auctions will be a comparatively minor function for such exchanges, but they bring their own problems. How do you ensure quality standards are met, and what is to stop competing suppliers colluding to keep prices high?

The key benefit of exchanges lies in integrating procurement with demand forecasting, and exchanging information that could help to cut surplus inventory. In the European car industry alone, Morgan Stanley estimates there is the potential for saving $2,700 per car.

But much of this benefit is old hat. A large chunk of internet b2b is souped-up supply chain management and enterprise resource planning. What's new is the ability for competitors to pool their purchasing to buy more cheaply.

There are two types of purchase - direct and indirect. The distinction is crucial in overcoming regulatory hurdles. If competitors cooperate on components or supplies for resale they are likely to invite the attention of competition authorities. Inquiries from the US Department of Justice have already delayed the launch of the automotive industry exchange.

At the moment the nascent exchanges are tiptoeing around the prospect of coming together to source direct supplies. Supermarkets talk of joining forces to order trolleys or bags, rather than their baked beans.

It's not necessarily the buyers who will garner all the benefits of b2b. It depends on the market structure, says Professor Mohan Sawhney, Silicon Valley's leading b2b guru.

Three-quarters of the world's supply of palladium - a vital ingredient in catalytic converters for car exhausts - comes from Russia, which could set up its own b2b exchange to supply the metal.

'It is when the market is fragmented on both sides that a market-maker could capture the benefits of b2b,' says Sawhney.

In a pre-emptive effort to appease competition authorities, the airline and automotive exchanges will be 'independently' run and managed.

But Sawhney, who advises a number of exchanges, believes that the industry-sponsored exchange announcements are attempts to 'hijack liquidity' from more nimble independents. Either way, the concept of an exchange being as valuable as many of the suppliers who use it is a new idea.

It is based on the belief that value-added services can be sold alongside the goods themselves to facilitate transactions on an exchange.

Sawhney says: 'There are other elements - quality consideration, supplier standards certification, and settlement - that broaden the scope of the offering, providing an end-to-end service.'

Aside from legal challenges, the industry-sponsored exchanges will require cooperation between the strongest of competitors. It took the members of one large exchange six weeks to work out which company name would come first on the press release.

And for the dairy industry? As price pressures increase, there will be a need to increase supply efficiency and reduce surplus inventory.

So the next time a supermarket cashier registers a sale of economy mild cheddar, there will be a b2b e-commerce connection to a cow in Somerset.

fields.headline: A question of breeding
fields.trailText: When Cherie Blair became the poster girl of British motherhood, it threw fresh light on a media trend. It has become difficult to open a magazine or paper without coming across a chattering-class diary on 'Gestation and Beyond'.
fields.body:
When Cherie Blair became the poster girl of British motherhood, it threw fresh light on a media trend. It has become difficult to open a magazine or paper without coming across a chattering-class diary on 'Gestation and Beyond'. Whether the parenting elite are on to their first or fourth child, or merely fretting about their (lack of) fertility, their experiences are dutifully documented in the press, as if they were of global significance. To my knowledge, there are no regular (skint, struggling) mums or dads keeping such journals, and maybe it's time to ask why. Who decided that blue-collar parenting went out with Cathy Come Home, while the procreative travails of privileged professionals is good news for newspapers?

Reading these accounts, what really hammers home is how good some people are at tailoring reality to suit their own needs. They make waiting lists for baby gyms, clashing 'play dates' and second cars breaking down sound like everyman truths and not alien concepts to 90 per cent of the working population. The coverage surrounding the Blair Baby was a case in point. All that waffling about Cherie's age and Tony's 'time off', as if their situation was somehow unusual. None of us thought to state the bleeding obvious, which was: it's only mature, solvent professionals like the Blairs who seem to be 'allowed' to have babies these days.

Watching the gorgeously denim-clad Tony rolling around on the floor with his newborn son, one didn't think: 'What does that sad old crock think he looks like?' or 'I hope someone helps him get up again.' In fact, one didn't think much at all. The current climate dictates that, while we recoil from Italian grandmothers who decide to get into the family way, fortysomething alpha couples such as the Blairs are welcome to add to the population explosion at any time. As the average age for first-time parenthood has risen among professionals, so too has general tolerance and perception. It is no longer a crime to be 'too old' to conceive. 'Too young' or 'too poor' is a different matter.

It says something that in a culture supposedly obsessed with promoting The Family, poorer, younger families, especially those headed by single parents, are portrayed as irresponsible, fast-breeding vermin. British Rail used to talk nebulously of the 'right' and 'wrong' kind of snow on the tracks, much to the derision of the populace. What isn't quite so amusing is the growing suspicion that the government is covertly thinking in terms of the 'right' and 'wrong' kinds of babies.

Britain has the highest teenage-pregnancy rate in Europe - 46,000 teenagers give birth each year, 8,400 are under 16, and the vast majority end up as single mothers on benefit. It is sad enough to think of these near-virtual babies having babies - to think that they might be perceived as having the 'wrong' kind of babies is tragic.

The sparse, doomy coverage meted out to single parents is in stark contrast to the massive amount of positive publicity elitist parenting enjoys. We never seem to read hilarious accounts of breast-feeding mishaps by single mothers. And why not? Don't they have breasts? You've also got to ask why feminism remains so eerily silent when so many of our number are being tactically 'pest-controlled'. It underpins what some of us have long suspected - namely that (middle-class) feminists only care about issues that affect other middle-class women. If they think about low-income women at all, it seems to be purely in terms of what they can hire them for: cooking, cleaning, or - natch - looking after the kids. Mainstream feminism recognises low-income women, alright - as staff.

Part of the problem for single parents is their near-invisibility in terms of positive media. They sorely need some of the publicity the Beautiful Couples, and their equally beauteous children, enjoy - and women everywhere should be fighting to make sure they get it. Monogrammed maternity is all very well, but it serves us to remember that only 2 per cent of parents in Britain have the cash or the room to employ a nanny, and even fewer of us would want to squander precious brain space on worrying about which prestigious baby-massage class to visit next.

On a wider level, we should never get to the point where parenthood is means-tested, either openly or with surreptitious government measures which punish the 'bad' non-nuclear family units and reward the 'good' with Budget Day choc drops. Nor should we applaud some pregnancies and mourn others. Maybe it would be a nice gesture in these post-Leo times for certain sectors of the media to counteract the craze for elitist parenting by publishing some first-hand testimonies from different kinds of families, with different kinds of experiences. Never mind fractured lives, and poverty of opportunity - what the progeny of single parents seem to suffer from most at the moment is lousy PR.

It underpins what some of us have long suspected - namely that (middle-class) feminists only care about issues that affect other middle-class women. If they think about low-income women at all, it seems to be purely in terms of what they can hire them for: cooking, cleaning, or - natch - looking after the kids. Mainstream feminism recognises low-income women, alright - as staff. Part of the problem for single parents is their near-invisibility in terms of positive media. They sorely need some of the publicity the Beautiful Couples, and their equally beauteous children, enjoy - and women everywhere should be fighting to make sure they get it. Monogrammed maternity is all very well, but it serves us to remember that only 2 per cent of parents in Britain have the cash or the room to employ a nanny, and even fewer of us would want to squander precious brain space on worrying about which prestigious baby-massage class to visit next. On a wider level, we should never get to the point where parenthood is means-tested, either openly or with surreptitious government measures which punish the 'bad' non-nuclear family units and reward the 'good' with Budget Day choc drops. Nor should we applaud some pregnancies and mourn others. Maybe it would be a nice gesture in these post-Leo times for certain sectors of the media to counteract the craze for elitist parenting by publishing some first-hand testimonies from different kinds of families, with different kinds of experiences. Never mind fractured lives, and poverty of opportunity - what the progeny of single parents seem to suffer from most at the moment is lousy PR. barbara.ellen@observer.co.uk

fields.headline: Disaster alert over British jet
fields.standfirst: 'Your pilot has been poisoned': full investigation
fields.trailText: A type of jet used by the Royal Family and hundreds of thousands of British holidaymakers is facing calls for it to be grounded after evidence that pilots have been overcome by toxic fumes and that its engines are prone to failure.
fields.body:
A type of jet used by the Royal Family and hundreds of thousands of British holidaymakers is facing calls for it to be grounded after evidence that pilots have been overcome by toxic fumes and that its engines are prone to failure.

An Observer investigation has discovered that a confidential warning was issued to pilots last week by British Aerospace, maker of the BAe 146, stating that flying too high in cloudy conditions could lead to engines stalling simultaneously. The document reveals that BAe received four reports of such incidents in 1999.

The BAe 146 has also been involved in several incidents where engine faults led to toxic gas leading into the cabin. There were reports of passengers being turned into 'zombies', cabin crew being poisoned and pilots who felt unable to fly.

An investigation by the Australian government, to be published this month, is expected to condemn the company for risking the health and safety of passengers and crew. Hundreds of cabin staff and several pilots around the world, including two in Britain, are claiming that inhaling these fumes made them seriously ill.

There are 206 of the aircraft operating worldwide, carrying 100 passengers on short-haul journeys. Most major airlines, including British Airways, KLM, Lufthansa and Aer Lingus, operate it. The Royal Family uses three 146s for official duties.

Dick Best, the safety official who certified the plane for use in Australia, said: 'If I had known of the BAe 146's problems I would have had serious doubts about okaying it.'

Bruce D'Ancey, assistant general secretary of the British pilots' union Balpa, said: 'Whenever one engine fails it is an extremely serious. The fact that several engines have failed on a number of occasions means that urgent action is needed.'

The most recent incident occurred on 30 April, when three engines failed on a BAe 146 of the Canadian operator AirBC on a flight to the US. The plane dived 19,000 feet and a full emergency was declared. It was only when it was 5,000ft above Denver that power was restored and a disaster averted.

BAe is warning pilots not to fly the aircraft at more than 26,000ft in cloud because its system to stop ice forming in the engines is faulty. Technically the problem is known as a 'rollback': the engines become choked and lose their thrust as the aircraft reaches high altitude.

The written BAe warning, obtained by The Observer, states: 'It is clear that flight crews will have difficulty in recognising the onset of rollback... For the majority of events there were simultaneous engine rollbacks and on three occasions all four engines were affected.'

A second BAe document shows that the company was forced to issue its first warning to airlines about the problems in 1997 after 12 such 'rollback' incidents affected 27 engines. In three of those cases, all four engines failed.

The fact that similar problems are occurring two years after the first warning means pilots are unable to interpret weather conditions properly and fly above 26,000 ft, risking disaster, say experts. Industry sources blame a design fault on an engine developed for helicopters flying at lower altitudes.

A Civil Aviation Authority official said she was unaware of the BAe warning, but would investigate. However, she said: 'We are aware of the reports of fumes entering the cabin and are working with BAe to solve the problem.'

BAe insisted the jet was safe. A spokesman said the two problems were unconnected and rare.
