webTitle: Army bullies force desertions to a record

fields.headline: Army bullies force desertions to a record
fields.standfirst: Full report: Bullied army recruits being forced to desert
fields.trailText: Desertions from the Army, often prompted by bullying and mistreatment, have reached record levels, prompting warnings of a crisis in the armed forces. Experts last night said that levels of desertion and absence without leave are higher than at any other time since the end of National Service.
fields.body:
Desertions from the Army, often prompted by bullying and mistreatment, have reached record levels, prompting warnings of a crisis in the armed forces. Experts last night said that levels of desertion and absence without leave are higher than at any other time since the end of National Service.

Previously unreleased statistics show that last year the Army recorded 1,998 cases of desertion and being Awol (absent without leave) - one for every 48 soldiers.

This compares with a figure of one in 75 in 1996, when there were 5,000 more soldiers than today, but only 1,345 cases of desertion and Awol. At the time that figure was considered a historic high.

An Observer investigation has discovered that many young soldiers decide to desert or go Awol after mistreatment and bullying by their superiors or colleagues. The Special Investigation Branch of the military police - which is responsible for its most important and complex inquiries - currently has more than 30 investigations under way into allegations of brutality.

At least 30 servicemen are separately taking the Ministry of Defence to the High Court after suffering assaults from fellow-soldiers, according to legal sources. If their cases succeed, the MoD could be forced to pay out compensation totalling millions of pounds.

Almost all the cases of desertion and offences occur among junior ranks in infantry regiments - the lowest paid and least motivated units in the Army. But such soldiers are indispensable - even on today's hi-tech battlefield - and the MoD is going to great lengths to recruit the young soldiers it needs.

The absenteeism exacerbates an already serious man power crisis. The Army is now under strength by at least 7,000 men. At current rates of recruitment it will be more than 30 years before all the vacant positions are filled.

The absence periods range from a mere 36 hours to several months - or even years in some cases.

An analysis of court-martial records by The Observer revealed that soldiers are often retained in the army after lengthy periods of absence because their units cannot afford to lose more manpower.

Absenteeism generates further work for over-strained junior officers. 'Some units are fine, but in others the problems are so bad that [officers] spend half their time chasing absent soldiers around,' one said last week.

Many desertions and Awols occur when the Army fails to take account of recruits' domestic difficulties. On many occasions, soldiers go absent because they have been denied - or feel certain they will be denied - compassionate leave to visit dying relatives or to assist in family crises. They are often only tracked down when they run foul of civilian police.

Experts estimate that most infantry battalions have two or three soldiers Awol at any one time. Across the Army that means that two or three entire platoons of soldiers are unaccounted for.

fields.headline: Shoaib express gaining speed
fields.trailText: Shoaib has eyes on the prize, much ado about match-fixing, and when Steve Ogrizovic bowled Viv Richards (really).
fields.body:
Shoaib Akhtar was not slow to talk speed when Nottinghamshire unveiled their new signing last week. He confirmed that his top reading on the speed gun was 97mph, and that he was looking forward to reaching something similar - with a £10,000 prize at stake this summer, and with Darren Gough having already posted 93mph.

Gough has one apparent advantage. He is likely to playing in the Test matches and the triangular series, in which - being televised - the Freeserve Speedster will be employed. At present, Shoaib's county is due to be televised only twice, in National League games. But agents for the Speedster say that the sponsor may well be prepared to finance use of the equipment at untelevised county games if interest justifies it: 'for example, if Shoaib and Glenn McGrath are both in action.'

Further, it seems likely that the £10,000 prize money will go directly to the winner - unlike man-of-the-match and other awards that go into team pools. All of this strongly suggests a new dimension to county cricket - when most believed there was nothing that could be done to give it wider appeal - though traditionalists may not be happy if individual contests threaten to hijack the game.

Just what can you do to guard against match-fixing? How many players are likely to come forward with allegations and evidence? And is all the corruption to be found in Australia?

Such questions arise with the news that cricket chiefs down there have appointed barrister Greg Melick, formerly a member of the National Crime Authority, as a full-time special investigator who will examine 'any credible allegations that may arise'. In addition, all Australian teams will be subject to an 'education and regulation' programme including induction sessions and regular re-briefings.

By contrast, the England and Wales Cricket Board are introducing no special measures, but a spokesman says they will continue to rely on the talk they always give to players prior to an overseas tour. If that sounds complacent, the alternative conclusion is that the Aussies may be over-reacting.

If only the whizz kids of the promotional world had realised it, they would surely have produced square-shaped cricket stumps with which to draw attention to a sponsor's name. Few people other than experts in cricket law were aware of this, but the stumps could have been any shape - and also much wider - because the laws have never stated otherwise.

Until now, that is. Partially because of a new, bigger stump camera, the new laws that will apply from October specify a minimum and maximum stump width, and also require a rounded profile. Over the next few weeks Inside Edge will look closer at some of the more radical law changes.

What do goalkeepers do when they grow old? In the case of Steve Ogrizovic it's the same old thing he always did in the summer, only more so. That is, seam bowling, in which his powers are not entirely diminished at 42.

After a record 601 first team games for Coventry City - a stint that started in 1984 - Ogrizovic has a commitment only to coaching the Under-17 team. That enables him to take over the captaincy of the cricket club to which he has also given long service, Coventry and North Warwicks.

The former goalie was a good enough cricketer to play Minor Counties cricket, his days with Shropshire being highlighted by a famous NatWest win against Yorkshire, and by a single memorable moment against Somerset. 'People always remember that I bowled Viv Richards,' he says. 'They don't remember that it was with a no-ball.'

webTitle: Queen and Camilla meet at royal party

fields.headline: Queen and Camilla meet at royal party
fields.trailText: The Queen met Camilla Parker Bowles, the Prince of Wales's long-time love, at a private party yesterday lunchtime attended by Princes William and Harry, Buckingham Palace confirmed last night.
fields.body:
The Queen met Camilla Parker Bowles, the Prince of Wales's long-time love, at a private party yesterday lunchtime attended by Princes William and Harry, Buckingham Palace confirmed last night.

In what was being seen as a carefully choreographed move to make Camilla's relationship with Prince Charles acceptable to the public, the meeting was arranged to take place at a birthday party for exiled Greek King Constantine and was being billed as a significant thawing in the Queen's attitude to her son and heir's relationship with the divorcee.

It is understood that the Queen knew Parker Bowles, 52, would be among the guests at the party at Highgrove near Tetbury in Gloucestershire when she decided to attend.

A Palace spokesman said: 'The Queen attended a birthday party for King Constantine given by the Prince of Wales at Highgrove this lunchtime and Mrs Parker Bowles was among the guests.'

It is understood that the two women met during the party, also attended by King Harald of Norway and Queen Margrethe of Denmark.

The Queen has known Camilla Parker Bowles for many years, before and after her failed marriage to Andrew Parker Bowles, but has rarely met her in public or private.

News of the meeting was first revealed by the News of the World . The paper's editor, Rebekah Wade, is known to be close to the Camilla camp. Her fiance, former EastEnders' star Ross Kemp, is a patron of Camilla's charity, the National Osteoporosis Society. Wade and Kemp are regular guests at fund-raising parties for the charity.

Yesterday's meeting, although significant, is not thought to herald any further change in Royal attitudes. The Prince of Wales, 51, has already said he has no intention of marrying Camilla, described as third woman in a crowded marriage in Princess Diana's televised interview shortly before her death in 1997.

Harold Brooks-Baker, publishing director of Burke's Peerage, said he believed that the meeting could signal a royal wedding within a year.

He said the Prince could freely marry the divorced Parker Bowles in the Church of Scotland. But as the future head of the Church of England, he would more likely wait until that church changed its rules to allow remarriage for all divorcees.

A thawing in the Queen's attitude towards her son and heir's long-time mistress had been hinted at by palace sources for a while. All that had remained was a suitable venue.

fields.headline: Family feud thwarts secret funeral
fields.standfirst: British family of 95-year-old grandmother taken to US by relatives take legal steps to halt her burial
fields.trailText: The case of the 95-year-old great-grandmother flown across the Atlantic took a macabre turn yesterday when her family learnt her body had been secretly returned to Britain for a private burial.
fields.body:
The case of the 95-year-old great-grandmother flown across the Atlantic took a macabre turn yesterday when her family learnt her body had been secretly returned to Britain for a private burial.

The British family of Johannah Gayle, who was taken to the US against their wishes by American relatives, was yesterday told by police that her body had been flown back to Gatwick Airport. She was to be buried in Margate, Kent, after a church service in nearby Maidstone. Only the US relatives and Gayle's friends were to attend.

Gayle, who has 19 grandchildren and 15 great-grandchildren, was dying of cancer of the bladder when she was taken to Williamsburg, Virginia, by her daughter, Kathleen Lawrence, 65. She died last Sunday - and her British family was only informed of the death by a distant cousin.

Her son Tony Gayle, 57, said yesterday: 'I find this appalling. First they take her to the States without telling us, and now they arrange for a funeral that we're not informed of.'

Three weeks ago Mrs Lawrence and her children drove the elderly woman to Heathrow, where they tried to catch a flight to Washington. After presenting airport police with documents claiming to hold power of attorney over her, the party was dissuaded from boarding. But they later reached the US by a route as yet undetermined by the Foreign Office.

Yesterday Gayle's daughter, Paulina Stockell, 59, who lives in Sutton Valence, Kent, said: 'The whole thing seems ludicrous - it's caused us untold grief. What did they think they were doing, smuggling her back here without letting us know? I do not understand my sister's actions at all - she does not seem to feel any remorse.'

Mrs Stockell added: 'If I had arranged for the abduction of a US citizen from over there, I'm sure the Marines would have been out in force looking for me. But in this country we just turn a blind eye and see it as a domestic incident.' '

Money can hardly be behind the Americans' action. Gayle managed on a state pension, and owned only her modest two-bedroom cottage.

The transatlantic crossing prompted the Maidstone MP Ann Widdecombe to ask Interpol to help trace Gayle.

Mrs Lawrence and her children, daughter Robin and her son Peter, arrived at the elderly woman's home in early April for an annual visit. 'We had told them she had cancer, so perhaps they thought this was their last chance to see her,' Mrs Stock ell said. 'But immediately they started to overwhelm the situation. They were all armed with information on cancer downloaded from the internet. 'Peter would storm around saying, "God damn! The Americans haven't used radiotherapy since the Seventies." He just seemed to have this immense battery of literature on cancer.'

The trio installed themselves in Gayle's home. Often both the grandchildren would sleep in her bed. Visitors were barred, doctor's appointments cancelled, even the home help was discouraged from entering. 'I always thought I was close to my sister Kathleen,' Mrs Stockell said. 'We were emotionally close - I would call her in the US almost every night. So this kind of behaviour by her and her children seemed completely irrational. Was it jealousy - did they envy my relationship with my mother?'

Three weeks ago Paulina and her brother Tony were finally allowed to see their mother. As she made her way upstairs, Kathleen and her three sons hurried up before her, still attempting to block her way. When they reached the bedroom, the quartet stood guard like cornerstones in front of the bed.

'It was like a military exercise,' Mrs Stockell said. 'To me, it seemed like they wanted to keep her to themselves.' Mrs Stockell's husband witnessed the Americans carrying Gayle into a car. They cheerfully told him they were taking her to Hastings for the day. 'I was immediately suspicious, my mother couldn't possible travel,' Mrs Stockell said.

She alerted Heathrow police and Special Branch, who detained the party at check-in. Meanwhile Tony Gayle raced down from Oxford to confront them. 'The police stopped them from boarding all the flights to Washington that day,' Mrs Stockell said. 'I thought they would come back here.'

But as Tony and the police turned their back, the American party got away. 'They raced to another part of the airport,' Mrs Stockell said.

Both Mr Gayle and Ms Stockell have taken legal action to block the funeral, intending to bury their mother near her home in Sutton Valence. The body is now with a coroner.

'Not content with taking her without our consent, they've now silently returned her,' Mr Gayle said yesterday. 'Did they expect us not to find out? Did they think we'd just forget about our mother?'

'To me, it seemed like they wanted to keep her to themselves.' Mrs Stockell's husband witnessed the Americans carrying Gayle into a car. They cheerfully told him they were taking her to Hastings for the day. 'I was immediately suspicious, my mother couldn't possible travel,' Mrs Stockell said. She alerted Heathrow police and Special Branch, who detained the party at check-in. Meanwhile Tony Gayle raced down from Oxford to confront them. 'The police stopped them from boarding all the flights to Washington that day,' Mrs Stockell said. 'I thought they would come back here.' But as Tony and the police turned their back, the American party got away. 'They raced to another part of the airport,' Mrs Stockell said. Both Mr Gayle and Ms Stockell have taken legal action to block the funeral, intending to bury their mother near her home in Sutton Valence. The body is now with a coroner. 'Not content with taking her without our consent, they've now silently returned her,' Mr Gayle said yesterday. 'Did they expect us not to find out? Did they think we'd just forget about our mother?'

webTitle: The Prince, the editor and Camilla's long road to acceptance by the Palace

fields.headline: The Prince, the editor and Camilla's long road to acceptance by the Palace
fields.trailText: In June 1997 the invitations started appearing: come and join Camilla Parker Bowles for a party in aid of her charity, the National Osteoporosis Society. Newspaper editors were going to be there, with a fair sprinkling of celebrities and publishers.
fields.body:
In June 1997 the invitations started appearing: come and join Camilla Parker Bowles for a party in aid of her charity, the National Osteoporosis Society. Newspaper editors were going to be there, with a fair sprinkling of celebrities and publishers.

It wasn't just any old party. This was Camilla's coming out party, the place where she would be presented to the public in a new, softer light - the woman once compared unfavourably with a horse by the tabloid press had decided that the only way to defend her image was to attack.

This was the woman who had been having an affair with the next king. They had first met in 1972 and had a brief fling. They had rekindled their relationship in the Eighties.

In the Nineties, Andrew Morton's book lifted the lid of the sham of the royal marriage. When Charles confessed to adultery, Camilla was reportedly pelted with bread rolls at a Wiltshire supermarket.

She was a public enemy. Everybody loved Diana - her trips to landmine-infested Angola, her compassion for the victims of Aids, her bashfulness, her shoddy treatment at the hand of Buckingham Palace.

But Diana's halo was slipping. She had been pictured watching a heart operation; it looked like a snatch picture, so why was she in full make-up? Then there was the picture of her meeting royal reporters in cars down side roads to spin her story in the press.

There followed the holiday with Dodi al Fayed when she called for privacy but then spent most of the time in a swimsuit on the top of the Fayeds' villa in St Tropez.

The Parker Bowles party was going to be a remarkable move into the limelight. But then Diana died, and the party was abandoned.

Fast forward three years - and months of careful preparation. Yesterday the Queen met Camilla at Charles's Gloucestershire home, Highgrove, at a party thrown to mark the sixtieth birthday of former King Constantine of Greece. It was their first 'public' meeting and could scarcely have been more high-profile.

The story broke in the News of World but other papers were full of it as the royal machine went into briefing overload. The new editor of the News of the World , Rebekah Wade, is a close friend of many in the royal circle, including Mark Bolland, the prince's deputy private secretary. Her fiance, the former EastEnders actor Ross Kemp, is a patron of the National Osteoporosis Society and a friend of Camilla. Wade and Kemp are regular guests at parties organised by Camilla.

A week earlier the News of the World ran a story that Camilla had not been invited to the Queen Mother's hundredth birthday party.

Everyone assumed that the relationship between the Queen and Camilla was as frosty as ever. But moves had been afoot behind the scenes to change that. Charles and Camilla had recently taken an official trip to Scotland, staying at the Queen's Edinburgh residence, Holyrood House. Camilla accompanied Charles on official engagements. It was only a matter of time.

It has been a long road to this destination. Prince Charles's staff, including Bolland, the man who guides all media coverage of the heir to the throne, have been carefully advising on which steps to take.

First the links were small-scale. When a member of Camilla's staff, Amanda MacManus, leaked information about Parker Bowles meeting Prince William, there was an inquiry and she was sacked from Camilla's office.

The statement announcing the decision in July 1998 did not come from Camilla's office but was credited to St James's by the Press Association - many took this as the first official recognition that the relationship between Charles and Camilla existed.

Two months earlier Buckingham Palace had confirmed that Camilla spent a weekend at Sandringham as a member of a house party hosted by the Prince of Wales.

In August the same year Charles let it be known that he was heartened by a Mori poll that showed that the public was warming to Camilla.

In October there were again carefully staged exits from a wedding that they both attended. They sat in different pews but the message was obvious.

In January last year came the first photographs together. They were seen on the steps of the Ritz after a fiftieth-birthday party for Camilla's sister, Annabel Elliott.

Move by move by move. In March Camilla appeared at a fashion show. In October there was a palpable thawing of relations between her and the Queen when Camilla praised Cahrles effusively during a royal charter presentation ot the Prince's Trust.

Today's papers are full of the story, with hardly a critical word. The news has also been zipped around the world on Reuters and Associated Press newswires: the ongoing saga of the British royals still holds a mystical allure for many people abroad. Now the talk will be of marriage and the effect such a significant meeting could have on their relationship and the British constitution. The rapprochement between the monarch and the heir's favourite has been planned for years, right back to that party in 1997. Meticulously. But this time nothing has to be abandoned because of a tragedy in an underpass in Paris.

webTitle: Introducing the West Indies touring party

fields.headline: Introducing the West Indies touring party
fields.standfirst: Many old friends and a few new faces
fields.trailText: A profile of the squad that we'll be seeing a lot of this summer.
fields.body:
RD Jacobs (Leeward Islands) Reliable gloveman who is in a bit of a slump with the bat.

JC Adams (Jamaica, capt) Impressive average in the high 40s for this reliable left-hander.

RD King (Guyana) Bowls on the quick side of medium and will provide vital support for the strike bowlers.

CEL Ambrose (Leeward Islands) Last series for this great fast bowler who is only 12 wickets away from the magic 400 mark.

BC Lara (Trinidad) He's back and could be the straw that stirs the drink but how thirsty for success is he?

SL Campbell (Barbados) One of the few right-handers in the top order and did well the last time he was here.

NAM McLean (Windward Islands) Quick but expensive with the ball. Can bat a bit as well.

S Chanderpaul (Guyana) Reliable left-hander who often plays the anchor role in the middle order.

MV Nagamootoo (Guyana) Yet to play a Test, but is a leg spinner who can bring the ball back into the right-hander.

CD Collymore (Barbados) Back-up medium pacer with a single Test wicket to his name.

FA Rose (Jamaica) Bowls quickly with a knack of taking vital wickets.

CH Gayle (Jamaica) Youthful finger-spinner who can provide useful runs down the order.

RR Sarwan (Guyana) Young, brilliant batsman who is being spoken of as the next Lara.

AFG Griffith (Barbados) Another left-hand bat who has never really settled in the side.

CA Walsh (Jamaica) No reason to think that the indestructible Walsh won't add to his world record haul of Test victims.

WW Hinds (Jamaica) Has played only five Tests but averages in the high 50s and is set to shine.

fields.headline: Relaxing in the rain
fields.trailText: Ed Giddins: 'Nasser Hussain is the ringleader when it comes to taking the piss but he's not immune from it himself. He's accused me of being an anorak but he just can't keep his eyes off Ceefax.'
fields.body:
There are two types of cricketer. Some like to have regular nets so that they can stay in the groove and tinker with their technique, others don't mind having a bit of a break every once in a while.

The net regulars tend to be batsmen, but I fall into the second category. It doesn't matter how long I've had off, I seem to be able to hit the spot once I'm back bowling, so the recent enforced lay-off due to the weather hasn't bothered me too much. At least I haven't had the chance to bowl myself out of form!

The important thing is to keep the body ticking over. A gentle one-hour run every day keeps the heart rate up and the blood pumping. Since we haven't been able to play since the Lord's Test I've spent quite a bit of time on the paths of Wimbledon Common.

Stretching and warming down after exercise keeps injuries at bay and so are just as vital as the work-outs themselves.

Every couple of days I've headed off to the gym and done some weight work. This hasn't been lots of pumping iron but more using light weights in order to keep the muscles stimulated and used to some power exertion, which is exactly what is required when bowling.

Since the first Test I've been a bit busier than usual. The media have wanted to know more, so I must be doing something right, but I'm not about to start opening supermarkets in Magham Down. It's important to keep your head down and remember that there is a job to be done at times like these.

Joining up with the England squad again on Tuesday was great as the team spirit is so good. Two things keep team spirit high; the first is winning - and we intend to carry on doing that. The second is the merciless ribbing that goes on endlessly in the dressing room.

The important thing is to give as good as you get but I've been on the receiving end a fair bit this week.

We were supposed to report for duty at around 1pm on Tuesday, the idea being to have a spot of lunch and then start work at about half past two. On arriving at the ground at one I noticed a fair few of the boys outside working. It's at moments like these you really panic, thinking you've misread the details and are about to be up to your neck in it.

I changed at top speed and headed on to the field to be greeted by a chorus of abuse along the lines of: 'Here he comes, takes a few wickets and thinks he can roll up at any old time.' The captain even suggested that I go back to the hotel until Thursday and that he would give me a ring to let me know the result of the toss so I could decide what time to turn up.

I smelt the rat and it turned out that due to the grotty weather forecast the lads had decided to skip lunch. I'm relieved that I can still read some simple instructions.

Nasser Hussain is the ringleader when it comes to taking the piss but he's not immune from it himself. He's accused me of being an anorak but he just can't keep his eyes off Ceefax. He looked at the county scoreboard twice in 10 minutes whilst they were taking lunch at Ilford on Thursday. What was he expecting to see? The menu? I fear his problem is greater than mine.

webTitle: Proper Test is yet to come

fields.headline: Proper Test is yet to come
fields.trailText: Vic Marks: 'Taking a thrashing like gentlemen.' This was the headline for the first first-class match I played in. It was at the Parks in April 1975 against Sussex. This comes to mind while watching England play Zimbabwe.
fields.body:
'Taking a thrashing like gentlemen.' This was the headline for the first first-class match I played in. It was at the Parks in April 1975 against Sussex, and as usual the University XI were being walloped. We (Oxford University) were out of our depth, but as we were constantly reminded: 'We may be out-bowled, we may be out-batted, but we'll jolly well out-field the opposition.'

All of which comes to mind while watching England play Zimbabwe. The gulf between the two sides is not so different than that between the university sides of old (I'm not sure about the current ones, having seen Oxford Universities bowl this summer) and their county opposition. You can see it in the attitude of the batsmen.

In most Tests batsmen consider it a plus if they score runs. Against the Zimbabweans I sense a different approach from the English batsmen (though they would never admit it). They are only delighted to avoid failure; they know there are easy pickings to be had. This brings a peculiar kind of pressure not to waste a golden opportunity to bolster their place and average. There is relief, rather than jubilation, when they reach their landmarks. I saw the same when playing for Oxford. Out came the county batsmen to score their runs and it was remarkable if they failed.

The Zimbabweans at Trent Bridge - unlike at Lord's - field superbly and their bowlers strive earnestly, but at this level they are pea-shooters. Pommie Mbwanga knows roughly where the ball is going to land but it takes an awful long time to get there. Even the much-lauded Heath Streak has looked ordinary in this match.

webTitle: England make the most of it

fields.headline: England make the most of it
fields.standfirst: In humid conditions England take the upper hand in the second Test at Trent Bridge
fields.trailText: Third day: It was a bowler's day at Nottingham: a lot of swing and a little seam. So Zimbabwe's response to England's 374 is not so bad as it sounds. Fifty-one for two is about par for the course, but it still leaves them with much work to do to save this match.
fields.body:
It was a bowler's day at Nottingham: a lot of swing and a little seam. So Zimbabwe's response to England's 374 is not so bad as it sounds. Fifty-one for two is about par for the course, but it still leaves them with much work to do to save this match.

England could have done with more than 13 overs at their opponents, two of which were wasted by a rusty-looking Andrew Caddick. Indeed in another era the England captain might have have declared in mid-afternoon yesterday.

It was dank and humid and the ball was bending in the air venomously - prime conditions for England's trio of pacemen. But in the current climate unorthodox declarations arouse too many suspicions. Hussain, though an independent thinker, dare not do it and didn't. Instead England batted on throughout the afternoon with their Lancastrians, Mike Atherton and Chris Schofield to the fore. If you believe the cliché this was, of course, because Lancastrians are schooled to play the game in the omnipresent Stygian gloom of Manchester. In fact they amassed a substantial total because of the excellence of Atherton against the swinging ball, the inability of the Zimbabwean bowlers to control it and Schofield's endearing wit with the bat.

Atherton gave us a mini-masterclass against the moving ball. Admittedly he could watch it pass harmlessly to the keeper on far too many occasions. If not, the head remained perfectly still; he moved into position late and played late, allowing the ball to meet the middle of his blade, rather than going off in pursuit of it. Some of his cover-driving was exquisite.

The England opener was already in the comfort zone when play began a mere 75 minutes late: 96 not out and the prospect of facing the weakest Test attack in the world. He chalked up his fourteenth Test century and the fiftieth of his first class career without too much trouble. He clipped his first ball from Whittall through mid-wicket for three. Next he played a maiden, which included several bouncers from Neil Johnson; then a controlled pull in Johnson's next over and he was there.

He now has one more Test hundred to his name than Alec Stewart; Graeme Hick has scored 60 more first class centuries. The first statistic interests him more. Atherton, I suspect, will enjoy the central contract system. In recent times he has not appeared to enjoy county cricket or prosper in it; he's never been a voracious gleaner of runs like Mike Gatting or Graham Gooch, who scored a vast number of county runs seemingly at will; Atherton needs plenty of mental energy to bat well. Being spared his Lancastrian duties for much of the forthcoming seasons could prolong his career. How David Gower would have enjoyed a central contract, not to mention Bob Willis.

Stewart never settled. Half-forward to a gentle swinging delivery from Whittall he became the first of three lbw victims, having added just one to his overnight score. Flower immediately took the new ball, which swung prodigiously but his bowlers could not control it. Their champion, Heath Streak, was as culpable as any. Even so Nick Knight soon departed. It had been rumoured that he had cured his problem of falling over to the off-side, his head too close to cover point and playing around his front pad. Not yet he hasn't. He received a gentle, regulation inswinger from Whittall and missed it. This presented a fine opportunity for Andrew Flintoff but he could not take advantage.

He delivered a couple of thumping drives but soon tried to pull Mbangwa and was palpably lbw. Chris Schofield, in pursuit of his first Test run, fared much better. He began with a punched back-foot drive for three and then proceeded to bat with a quirkiness all too reminiscent of Jack Russell. There are plenty of moving parts when Schofield is at the crease; he drives with a flourish though not always a straight bat and there was an eccentric falling hook - not quite so elegant as Rohan Kanhai in his pomp - that landed fortuitously in front of Mbangwa at long leg before spinning out of reach to the boundary. This pair of Lancastrians added another 39 and surprisingly Atherton was the one to go - in an unusual manner for him, caught at extra cover driving at Mbangwa.

For once he forgot to wait for the ball and instead cracked it in the air straight to Grant Flower. He cannot claim to be duped by a slower ball for it was delivered at 70mph, the pace of Mbangwa's stock delivery.

Caddick holed out to mid-off as people tend to do off Nkala and Gough edged to give Streak his solitary wicket. All the while Schofield improvised cleverly; there was a reverse sweep to bring up his 50, an even more audacious upper cut from a Streak bouncer before he sacrificed himself with a declaration imminent. If he can bowl as well... Later his solitary over in Test cricket yielded nine runs.

For Zimbabwe, Grant Flower's horrendous run continued when caught at bat/pad in Gough's first over. Whittall then plundered Caddick's wayward first two overs for 22 runs before he was lbw to Ed Giddins. Then they were grateful that the gathering gloom could take them off the field.

webTitle: The art of bluffing the Mexican way

fields.headline: The art of bluffing the Mexican way
fields.trailText: Kevin Mitchell: Martin O'Neill's most endearing characteristic is a commitment to a project and a wish to be seen to doing the right thing. I can't think of a single person in football who is so worried about his principles.
fields.body:
For reasons that are not important, I was privy to some weird negotiations between Peter Johnson and Martin O'Neill during the last World Cup.

Johnson, an unusual man, was in the process of getting rid of the equally unusual Howard Kendall as Everton coach. O'Neill seemed to be the coach he wanted as Kendall's replacement.

What happened, though, was that, through an intermediary, they took part in what a friend of mine calls the Mexican Stand-off. Basically, this involves bluffing, double-bluffing and, occasionally, triple-bluffing - he knows that I know that he knows I know he knows, sort of thing. A Double Mexican, for instance, requires the first party to commit to a meeting, then not turn up; meanwhile, the second party does not turn up, either - although the first party never discovers that, because he was not there himself. A classic Double Mexican. There is also a Triple Mexican, but I can't remember how it works.

From memory, Johnson, a chairman with the weakest hold on a club that would not have been devastated to see him go, was on his boat and only available when he wanted to be, even though the new season was fast approaching and Kendall was obviously not going to carry on in the job. O'Neill, meanwhile, was commentating on the World Cup and, when contactable, seemed very keen to engage in serious discussions with Johnson. This went on for several days, a string of unanswered phone calls at both ends of the negotiations. And, as far as I am aware, they never spoke. A rare Triple Mexican, perhaps?

If this is how football clubs are run, is it any wonder that they end up in the mire? It would be intolerable in any other line of business involving so much money and so many people, yet football blunders on, a haven of anarchy.

As we know, O'Neill did not go to Everton, Kendall quietly (or boisterously, if you believe the rumours) left football behind and Leicester City were to benefit from the continued attentions of their intense and inspirational coach.

Now he has finally moved on. The BEF left Dunkirk quicker than O'Neill departed Filbert Street. I doubt there would have been the sort of grandstanding and parlaying that attended his near-exit two years ago when O'Neill was working out his contract to move to Parkhead over these past days, but it is certain he will have dwelt on his decision like a man possessed. This is O'Neill's most endearing characteristic, probably, a commitment to a project and a wish to be seen to doing the right thing. He did the same at Wycombe, after all.

I can't think of a single person in football who is so worried about his principles.

Nevertheless, it must be maddening trying to get an answer out of him.

fields.headline: Why O'Neill had to leave
fields.standfirst: Will he, won't he? Leicester's departing manager explains why he chose Celtic
fields.trailText: If Martin O'Neill thinks with half as much emotional intensity as he watches football, he must have been exhausted by the time he actually put pen to paper in Glasgow.
fields.body:
If Martin O'Neill thinks with half as much emotional intensity as he watches football, he must have been exhausted by the time he actually put pen to paper in Glasgow. All week long he had been deliberating, wavering, considering his options. Like the good and bad angels from a medieval morality play, you can imagine the Leicester voice and the Celtic voice fighting it out in his head. 'Ah, Martin,' said the Celtic voice, temptingly, 'Follow your heart. Come to your promised land.' Bingo.

'No, stay Martin,' interjected the Leicester City voice, persuasively, 'Why abandon it all for such a monumental risk?' Oh, decisions, decisions.

Vacillation is not usually considered a virtue in football management. But the fact he took so long weighing it all up (not for the first time, as Nottingham Forest, Everton and Leeds can testify) should not necessarily be interpreted as a weakness. Actually in his case it's a strength. The fact that he cares enough to give so much thought to his dilemmas reveals a considerate side which his players seem to warm to, certainly those who phoned him to wish him luck the evening he finally confirmed his departure. Leicester's spirit of loyalty and effort and togetherness stems from the character of the manager.

He is concerned that critics might give him a black mark for leaving Leicester in the lurch, which was never his intention and is the basic reason why he pondered so long and hard. One of his priorities is to find a day to go back there to say his farewells. 'Obviously after four-and-a-half years there's a great attachment,' he explains. 'I had a lot of time for a lot of people there. The set-up was excellent. In the end, however strongly I felt about Leicester I couldn't turn this down. I suppose my background had an influence. Celtic are an absolutely massive club and they have been starved of success. It will not come easy, it's daunting but it's really exciting at the same time.'

Those he's leaving behind must recognise this is the right moment for a gifted and ambitious man to extend himself. He has taken Leicester to its optimum level - top half of the Premiership, a Worthington Cup, Europe. City cannot realistically aspire to anything more right now. The only way for O'Neill to take the next step was to move on up. His career path so far gives him confidence: 'When I started in management at non-league level people said, "Oh, he can't do it in the League". When I got into the League people said "Nah, he can't do it in the Premiership." After that is was, "Well, he hasn't won the league yet." My Premiership record is good enough to suggest I should have a crack at managing a club of Celtic's size. If this job gives me the chance to expand on my talents, I'll be glad to.'

So, this is the pursuit of a dream. The legends of the Lisbon Lions and Jock Stein - 'just immortalised up there', he gushes - genuinely stir his soul. No PR fluff, O'Neill means it. For Celtic supporters waiting in the drizzle to greet him, he is a saviour. There can be no more warming feeling for the faithful than to feel one of their own is in charge. Their welcome convinced O'Neill he had made the right decision. Having said that, an inbred affection and association is no instant recipe for success, as everyone knows. He will have to be ruthless to deliver as Celtic Football Club dream-maker.

'Everything is brilliant except for the team,' he observed on his first day. There is much work to be done. Celtic play a more adventurous, fluid style of football than the competitive hustlers who thrived at Filbert Street. It will be fascinating to see if he has more creative strings to his bow at a club with the resources to acquire players with more star quality, and indeed how the Celtic squad respond to O'Neill's fervent brand of management. He is used to working with underrated achievers who drew strength from proving the doubters wrong. Multimillion-pound egos living with the fever of enormous expectation and profile in the green half of Glasgow are a different proposition. 'People may ask if he can manage people who cost £5-6 million,' muses City old boy Steve Claridge. 'Personally I've got no doubts.'

Nor has O'Neill: 'People forget I was involved in European football as a player and worked under a marvellous manager who didn't care about reputations. Trevor Francis arrived for £1m and played his first game in the third team. As far as I'm concerned players are players. You might pick up Matt Elliott and Neil Lennon from lower clubs but these boys are top-quality players - and I've seen egos to match as well, Stan Collymore for example.

'The idea is to try and win, and win with style. Talented players make exciting teams and if we can get some more to add to the obvious talent already there we have a chance. That is something I'm intending to build on.'

Next week, he will have a day running through 'everything with everyone' at Celtic before taking home a video of each of last season's games for homework - but he will make no decisions until he has worked with the players himself. Pre-season training starts at the end of June (scuppering the family holiday) and any gaps from Euro 2000 TV commitments will be spent hot-footing it to Glasgow.

Taking up the challenge of renovating a side that finished 21 points behind their only true rivals is evidence of the incorrigible romantic in O'Neill. In times when the essence of sport is increasingly polluted by Mammon, what a breath of fresh air it would be if the Ulsterman could make a success of it at Celtic Park.

'I'll give it my very best shot, and if it doesn't work... I'll kill myself,' he said, with a typical flourish. The Premiership will be a poorer place without him.

Brown, Blunkett and Cook, et al, have tried to make capital out of the case of schoolgirl Laura Spence but the Government is happy to leave the majority of pupils in Kent subject to the disadvantageous 'selection' system of grammar schools and give absolutely no help to parents.

Those wishing to get it changed are required to collect 46,000 signatures over an area 60 miles by 25 miles. It is a task which is almost impossible to achieve but which is being stoically pursued by a small number of people who wish to see an end to this discriminatory and abhorrent method which subjects children to academic failure at such an early stage in life.
Sid Hollands, Maidstone, Kent

The one-sided reporting on this matter has been very disappointing and frustrating, particularly for those of us from Northern comprehensives who have studied at Oxbridge. I graduated from Newnham College, Cambridge, last year, having come from my local comprehensive, Durham Johnston.

My Head of Sixth form has in fact been contacted by the press during this furore, but because he is perfectly satisfied with the Oxbridge admissions procedure and the number of his students who study there, his comments have not been reported.

In my year group alone, 30 gained straight As at A-level, nine of whom went on to Oxbridge. We did not find that the admissions system discriminated against us and nor did any of my Cambridge friends from northern comprehensives.
Lydia Aers, London NW6

Gordon Brown surely rattled a few cages, not least this Oxford don's. Does Mr Dawkin's 'strong belief' that there is no élitism at his university (Comment, last week) have a more empirical base than Gordon Brown's?

Before he rails at an outsider's ignorance, perhaps he should adopt a more scientific approach and read the rather damning evidence of a fellow don, A.H. Halsey.
Kath Thompson, Sheffield

Once rejected by her first choice of university, it seems that Laura Spence had to choose between studying medicine at another English university (for which she was offered a place) and paying a sizeable sum of money for the privilege - because of the length of time needed to qualify as a doctor, she would probably start her career with a major debt - or she could study, with an attractive scholarship; probably starting her career with, if not money in the bank, then a much smaller debt. Some choice!
J.R. Adams, Brackley, Northants

An important issue has been ignored during the latest row about the supposed Oxbridge bias against applicants from comprehensives: the selection policy for postgraduate students, which favours home-grown graduates, while a handful of other universities provide most of the non-Oxbridge minority of British students.

Very able research students who at first-degree level have out-performed many of their contemporaries at Oxford and Cambridge are often passed over in favour of safe but dull bets already known to the dons.
David Nowell, New Barnet, Herts

I note that Laura Spence's abilities extend beyond the medical. In your picture of her (Focus, last week), she is carrying a pile of books; all good for the scholastic image. But why is she carrying Vols 23 and 24 of the 'Encylopaedia of Weapons and Warfare'? Either these were the first books said some media wonk could lay his hands on, or she knew the stink that was being stirred up in her name.
Ian Stone, Cambridge

fields.headline: Said & Done
fields.trailText: Thousands of Euro 2000 tickets remain unsold, a new England anthem for the summer, plus all the tales from the tabloids...
fields.body:
Euro 2000 - ticket systems buckle

With just six days to go before Euro 2000, organisers have admitted that thousands of tickets remain unsold after an administrative collapse similar to that experienced at France 98. The final 48,000 tickets were made available last week on a premium rate phone-line and at an outlet in Rotterdam - both of which were vastly under-equipped. Visitors to the outlet found staff taking 40 minutes to deal with each individual purchase, while callers to the hotline were put on hold for up to an hour, charged 30p a minute and crashed off the system as they were about to pay. Organisers claim to be tackling the problem by opening new ticket booths in Liege tomorrow. 'We were a bit overwhelmed,' admits spokesman Richard van der Eyk. 'All the tickets we put on sale are for games that did not sell out on the internet. We thought these were the unpopular events.' Among these 'unpopular events' are the opening ceremony, featuring joint host nation Belgium, and England v Romania. Tickets remain available - if that's the right word - for both.

Keegan's Italian Job remix

Another late contender for Euro 2000's unofficial England anthem: Kentish Town bedsit outfit G15 have recorded Three Mini Coopers - a Euro 2000-themed, King-Kev-credibility-boosting dance remix of the music from the classic 60s film The Italian Job. The remix - originally by Fatboy Slim - has already featured on Radio One, but the writers are still looking for a record label to snap them up. This and the rest of their 21 tracks can be sampled on www.gentinternational.com - and unlike the other unofficial contenders, this one's actually pretty good.

Oaf hits web: Mellor fame spreads

New website of the month: www.mellorout.co.uk - a title-says-it-all vehicle for the campaign to remove 'sweaty oaf' David Mellor from BBC 5 Live, and for selling the hugely successful Said & Done- endorsed Mellor Out T-shirts. So far the shirts have raised almost £5,000 for the Crystal Palace Supporters Trust, with sales recorded - strangely - in the USA, Sweden and New Zealand...

Said & Done: david.hills@observer.co.uk

Tales from the tabs

LEE-DS UTD: HENDRIE QUITS VILLA Lee Hendrie is set for a £6m move to Leeds - David O'Leary will sell Alfie Haaland and David Hopkin to make way: Haaland will join Man City this week.

LEICESTER SWOOP FOR TAYLOR Leicester are ready to move for Gillingham boss Peter Taylor: Taylor - also wanted by Sheffield Wednesday - has refused a new contract at Priestfield.

AND THE REST...

Barcelona have told Manchester United to give them £50m or forget about signing Luis Figo: retiring president Josep Luis Nunez has told United to 'pay up or shut up'; Manchester City have pulled out of a deal for Andrei Kanchelskis after Rangers demanded £4m; Robert Pires will complete his £7m move to Arsenal after Euro 2000 - he could be joined by Juve's Edgar Davids if Arsene Wenger agrees to a swap deal with Patrick Vieira; Inter are losing their battle to stop Uruguayan striker Alvaro Recoba quitting for an unnamed mystery Premiership club: 'If I think about my future,' says Recoba, 'I know I must leave'; Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink's arrival at Chelsea means the end for Gianfranco Zola: 'I hope Chelsea will give me the opportunity to leave and I hope Napoli will sign me,' says Zola; Ray Wilkins could return to Crystal Palace from Chelsea as first-team coach if Palace's takeover goes through; Coventry have ruled out a bid for Bolton's Claus Jensen - but could sell Noel Whelan to Derby ; Southampton are favourites to land Mark Draper from Villa ; Liverpool have offered Steven Gerrard a £5m, five-year contract; Martin O'Neill wants Everton's Don Hutchison at Celtic ; Spurs , Forest and Sheffield Wednesday are chasing Millwall's Neil Harris; and Birmingham are set to up their £3m offer for West Brom's Lee Hughes - they could offer Paul Furlong or Dele Adebola in part-exchange.

webTitle: Change or else: a Parkhead warning

fields.headline: Change or else: a Parkhead warning
fields.trailText: Celtic's new manager may have to alter his management style if he is to succeed in breaking Rangers' stranglehold, according to former Parkhead general manager Jock Brown, the brother of Scotland coach Craig Brown.
fields.body:
Celtic's new manager may have to alter his management style if he is to succeed in breaking Rangers' stranglehold, according to former Parkhead general manager Jock Brown, the brother of Scotland coach Craig Brown.

'Martin O'Neill seems to have modelled himself on Brian Clough, who got the most from many moderate players at Derby and Forest,' he said. 'But when he tried the same style with household names at Leeds the players did for him. That should be a warning.'

Brown, who left Parkhead in 1998 after Celtic's last title success, added: 'He is leaving a one-club provincial city for a massive city dominated by two clubs. One half of Glasgow is always anti and the other half can be anti after two or three bad results. The difference between Rangers and Celtic is that Rangers is an institution, whereas Celtic is a family riven with the same emotions and passions as any other family.

'When I was at Celtic the players used to tell me they had 22 minutes in a game to win over the crowd. Now they tell me it's eight. Martin has a tough job on his hands but if he succeeds the rewards will be terrific.

'If I had any advice for him it would be "don't look at the tabloids". They had my brother going to Hong Kong recently - even after he denied the story.'

fields.headline: Darkside to chirpy boss
fields.trailText: Alan Smith: Martin O'Neill's appointment as Celtic manager this week may be good news for the Glasgow club - that remains to be seen - but it leaves a huge shadow hanging over the next manager of Leicester, as I know from experience.
fields.body:
Martin O'Neill's appointment as Celtic manager this week may be good news for the Glasgow club - that remains to be seen - but it leaves a huge shadow hanging over the next manager of Leicester, as I know from experience.

I was the man who replaced O'Neill at Wycombe Wanderers when he left them for a short and ill-fated spell as Norwich's manager five years ago. It would have been a tough enough act to follow under normal circumstances, but my life was not made any easier by the 'ghost' of O'Neill that haunted me and successive managers.

Whether it was scrutinising local papers for any hint of criticism of his regime or even turning up on the terraces to watch our games, which he did on a few occasions, I had a feeling that he found it hard to let go, which did not help me much.

He was, naturally, a hero at Wycombe for taking a run-of-the-mill amateur club out of non-League and into the Third and then Second Division.

The public may see him as the smiling Irishman with an impish wit, but there is another side to O'Neill which is somewhat darker. He can play the political game and can manipulate situations mostly to his benefit, and his style of management does not endear him to the rest of the football world in general.

There is no doubt whatsoever that he has modelled himself on Brian Clough and his maverick management methods. At Wycombe, players said sometimes they would not see him from Monday to Friday and then he would turn up in the dressing room on the Saturday ready for a team talk just before kick-off.

Yet while he could be that laidback in his day-to-day approach, he could also be vicious with his criticism, reducing grown men to tears in the dressing room. He could also be obsessive, sometimes spending hours locked in his office watching videos of games, with no one, not even the chairman, allowed to interrupt him.

Like Clough, he has always insisted on being his own man and is never afraid to fall out with directors. It is no secret that he did not get on with several board members at Leicester and the club's internecine strife almost tore them apart last year. I can see boardroom problems ahead in Glasgow. It looks like the town will not be big enough for both O'Neill and Kenny Dalglish and clearly it is the latter who will have to go if push comes to shove.

O'Neill is the sort of man who keeps his own counsel and does not mix easily - I would never expect to see him at a coaching conference, for example. I would question whether he will be able to motivate Celtic's players in the same way he has done at Wycombe or Leicester. It will be fascinating to see how he gets on at Celtic, which is a massive job. Finishing second is not good enough, but it is hard to see how you can displace Rangers.

webTitle: Bold Barthez looks forward to life at a new joint

fields.headline: Bold Barthez looks forward to life at a new joint
fields.trailText: Manchester United's new £10 million goalkeeper, Fabien Barthez, attributes some of his fierce commitment and warrior spirit, so loved by Sir Alex Ferguson, to a few covert puffs on a cannabis joint.
fields.body:
Manchester United's new £10 million goalkeeper, Fabien Barthez, attributes some of his fierce commitment and warrior spirit, so loved by Sir Alex Ferguson, to a few covert puffs on a cannabis joint.

Not the best of examples, of course, from a goalkeeper who went on to win the World Cup and is first choice for his country. Barthez, however, believes his encounter with soft drugs helped him become the true heir to Peter Schmeichel that Ferguson believes he has found.

His world may have seemed a little lovelier under the influence, but it briefly fell apart with a routine dope test that showed positive four years ago. He explains: 'It is a paradox, but the punishment I received made a big contribution to my progress. During the two-month ban I received, I was alone face-to-face with myself. I felt a great emptiness around me. I thought it was all so easy.

'Football was just one marvellous thing after another and I had fallen into a kind of rut. The fact that now I was nothing any more brought me back to reality. I understood that I had not totally embraced the demands of this job'.

Barthez did so with a vengeance and, like Schmeichel before him, he has a penchant for keeping the minds of his team-mates on their game, too. He may have apologised for his French accent on his arrival in England but, once he has his feet under the dressing-room table, it is a sound United players might get to know well. Perhaps, at times, to resent.

Monaco, like United, won their own national championship by a distance, but not without some unqualified public lambasting from captain Barthez even when he was out injured and catching their matches only on TV. For the football creed of Barthez, who trampled over many hurt feelings in Monaco, finds a lot of room for slanging matches.

'I start from the principle that the more you shout at each other, the better it is,' says Barthez. 'I think it is necessary. There is always the temptation of being the individual in football and I have seen how dangerous that can be. For club or country, whatever the ground and whatever the level, the career of a player depends on the behaviour and performance of his team-mates. One single guy can throw everything in the air and shatter your career. Wherever I play, this is the message I try to deliver.'

Barthez cut short training with the French squad in Casablanca with a touch of tonsillitis and could make way against Japan today for Bernard Lama, so he may not be delivering too many messages in the immediate future.

What exactly goes on within the most celebrated bald head in France - it serves as a hamburger ad for McDonald's - is known only to himself, of course. But whatever it is comes up with a curious mix of apparently headstrong rushes from goal and the most intense concentration.

Elie Baup, the coach of Bordeaux where Barthez started his pro career, says: 'His major mental quality is his strength of character, his competitive rage. The confidence he has in himself allows him to go in search of the ball in extreme situations. He knows his own limits and potential.

'Even when he was young, the job came first and he would ask advice about preparation and diet. Philippe Bergeroo, the goalkeeping coach at the World Cup, told me he used to finish sessions with Fabien exhausted. He makes a few mad decisions during a match because his reading of the game is out of the ordinary, but they usually come off. It is rare for his risk-taking - sometimes with no real point - to have serious consequences.'

Ferguson will be happy to hear it. On the other hand, he may discover he has signed a player who can be a strange cove at times. Such is his mental application that Barthez, once the job is finished, does not always feel the need to share in the celebrations or otherwise of his team-mates.

He was a notable absentee among the French players in Paris on the evening of their World Cup final triumph over Brazil, preferring to slip away to see a few childhood friends from his native Pyrenees. Baup says: 'Fabien is the kind of guy who is capable of totally cutting himself off for days, of shutting himself up in a room to recuperate. He is a grafter and, physically, it is very important for him to work because that is not his strong point.'

Perhaps Barthez had grown too big for Monaco, who were irritated by his growing tendency to pick and choose his matches. They were angered, too, by his tactless smiles for his old mates at Marseille after a team-mate, Marcelo Gallardo, had been beaten up in the players' tunnel. So he had better watch his step at Old Trafford.

Otherwise he might find he is not the only one who can shout.

webTitle: Car hire extras hit UK drivers

fields.headline: Car hire extras hit UK drivers
fields.trailText: British motorists are paying more than twice as much in add-on car rental costs as drivers in some other European countries.
fields.body:
British motorists are paying more than twice as much in add-on car rental costs as drivers in some other European countries.

Easyrentacar, a new hire company, says Mercedes charges more for cars supplied to its bases in Glasgow and London than to its Barcelona business - meaning basic rental prices are higher.

The company is also forced to set a higher additional mileage fee on top of that: drivers who rent one of the company's vehicles in Barcelona pay 8p for each extra mile they drive above a 75-mile-a-day limit, compared with 20p for each extra mile charged to UK customers. The additional fees are levied because Mercedes buys vehicles back for prices linked to their mileage.

'British consumers realise they pay over the odds for lots of things, not just cars,' said James Rothnie, a spokesman for Easyrentacar, which was launched six weeks ago. 'We set these charges because they are exactly what Mercedes charges us. We have told Mercedes that any reduc tion it makes will be passed directly to the customer.'

fields.headline: Barmby's late surge
fields.standfirst: The Everton midfielder has emerged as a strong contender for a starting position in England's Euro 2000 campaign
fields.trailText: The Everton midfielder has emerged as a strong contender for a starting position in England's Euro 2000 campaign
fields.body:
Kevin Keegan knew all along he would have to lose six players from his squad by this weekend. The players knew, the country knew and despite the best efforts of the nation's media to inject a degree of melodrama into the process - 'How will you actually break it to them, Kevin? Will it be the hardest thing you have ever done?' - the cull was achieved as quietly and sensibly as professionals have a right to expect.

No story there then, unless Andy Cole suddenly decides he is not injured after all and complains another England manager has got it in for him. Until that happens, the real story is who made it into the squad. Did Gareth Barry imagine as recently as a month ago he would be in the final 22 for the European Championships? Steven Gerrard has been more frequently mentioned as a possibility, but the Liverpool midfielder made his debut only on Wednesday and up to that point could not possibly have been expecting to edge out more senior players.

And what about Nick Barmby? Not even considered for the Argentina game, by Keegan's own admission, Barmby had been planning a family holiday in America this summer until a sparkling 20-minute cameo against Ukraine put him straight into the 22 with a reasonable chance of figuring in England's starting line-up against Portugal.

'Nick has made a late run,' said Keegan, stating the obvi ous but also making use of one of the game's best-loved romantic scenarios. Everybody knows that Geoff Hurst made a late run into Alf Ramsey's thinking in 1966, and ended up the hero of the hour. Keegan, one feels, was looking for someone to make a late run. He would have been disappointed if none of his 28 had managed to surprise him.

Without veering into Hoddlesque crankiness, Keegan seems to believe in fate, or at least that events should be allowed to unfold without excessive interference from him. His whole philosophy is that England will come good in Euro 2000 when the time arrives, so the more players making unanswerable cases for selection the merrier.

That is why Barmby could be in or around the Portugal game. On the evidence of Wednesday's performance, he could easily shade the other form midfielder, Steve McManaman, for the left-sided midfield role.

McManaman had a reasonable game against Ukraine, though it is clearly unreasonable to expect him to reproduce his Real Madrid performances. It remains to be seen how effective the new, improved McManaman would be playing on the left in a 4-4-2 formation, but Keegan now knows Barmby can be effective just about anywhere.

Neither would Keegan hesitate to make a late, unexpected change. Apart from the fact that he is mildly obsessed with the way Ramsey went about things in 1966, Keegan happens to believe an England team need to be kept on their toes.

'You can't just walk in as an England manager and say "Right, this is going to happen",' he said. 'You have to give the players time to get used to the new situation. It's only now that I look at them and think I've got them really together and ready, for instance.

'I've brought one or two surprise players into the squad, and the senior players are never quite comfortable about that. They wonder what I have in mind, which is only natural, but that's a good thing. You don't really want a team or a squad which picks itself. I certainly don't want too many of our players on comfort street.'

Sentiments most people would share, even if Keegan has been less than ruthless in disturbing the comfort zone that Alan Shearer has inhabited this past 15 months.

Barmby, who scored the first England goal under Glenn Hoddle in Moldova but lost form and spent almost four years outside the England reckoning, would be happy to help Keegan out anywhere on the pitch.

'I like to play quite far upfield but just behind the main strikers, and it doesn't make much difference whether I play in the centre, wide right or even out on the left,' he said. 'England are currently bemoaning the lack of a natural left-footer, but it's not as if everyone else has got one. If you look at a lot of Italian sides you just see four good midfielders spread across the pitch, and the guy out on the left is often right footed. I'm not sure it's the specialist position people make out.'

Just as well, since England lost their last specialist when Jason Wilcox pulled out. With better finishing ahead of Barmby on Wednesday, England could have turned a comfortable victory into something more impressive, since before the introduction of the Everton player the Ukraine defence were coping easily with what little was being produced from open play.

In the final analysis both England goals came from dead-ball situations and involved errors from a young and inexperienced goalkeeper, whereas Nigel Martyn was given a thorough workout by a Ukraine team operat ing at far from full throttle. Assuming that the defence will tighten when England revert to a back four, which in turn assumes England would not dare begin a tournament with one wing-back over- committed to attack and the other reluctant to stray too far from defence, the supply of goals appears to be the most pressing problem.

Shearer and Michael Owen will get first opportunity, and everyone is hoping the former can rise to the occasion as he did in Euro 96, since Emile Heskey is not exactly giving Keegan a selection headache. Had Cole missed the sort of chance Heskey squandered at Wembley, he would never have heard the last of it.

Yet say what you will about Keegan and his squad, the manager is at least facing the firing squad bravely and without a blindfold. 'This is an exciting opportunity, and I want everyone to enjoy it,' he said. 'I think the fans can look forward with optimism. They can write us off if they want, I don't know what their definition of success or failure would be, but if you are asking me we have got to be thinking about trying to win the competition.

'I know that's difficult, but that's what the players are focusing on, and I don't see anybody with a better chance. As a nation we have under-achieved for quite a long time, and I just want us to play to our maximum. We have a chance if we play like we really can. I can't honestly say that's happened under me yet, but a tournament would be a great time to do it.'

fields.headline: 'Your pilot has been poisoned'
fields.standfirst: Toxic fumes and engine failures can make flying on the BAe 146 a risky business for millions of holidaymakers gas leaks and sudden power failures
fields.trailText: Captain Niels Gomer was in good spirits. It was Friday afternoon, the skies were clear over Sweden and, like his 90 or so passengers, he was looking forward to the weekend.
fields.byline: Antony Barnett, Tina Clark and Dalbert Hallenstein
fields.body:
Captain Niels Gomer was in good spirits. It was Friday afternoon, the skies were clear over Sweden and, like his 90 or so passengers, he was looking forward to the weekend.

But as that cold November afternoon turned into dusk, events on flight BU925 turned into something that would have not been out of place in an episode of the X Files .

Gomer felt 'strange' and queasy. He then became dizzy and groggy. Fearing the air in the cabin was to blame he used an oxygen mask. But the symptoms remained and he prepared for an emergency.

Outside the cockpit, many passengers had fallen asleep. They could not be woken by the cabin crew, who were also feeling extreme discomfort. One steward said passengers were acting like 'zombies'.

Fortunately, the first officer had reacted well to the oxygen and managed to land the plane safely. Many of the passengers could not be woken even after landing. Some later said they felt as if they were 'moonwalking'.

The incident was described by Swedish air authorities as 'extremely serious'. They found that faulty seals allowed highly toxic engine oil containing organophosphate to pollute the cabin air.

The authorities sent the engine of the British-made BAe 146 to be investigated, hoping this was a one-off.

Unfortunately, their optimism appears to be ill-founded. An Observer investigation has uncovered numerous similar incidents which could have spelt disaster for millions of British holidaymakers who fly on these planes to Europe. Many of the world's major airlines use the plane and the royal family has three such aircraft.

In Australia, criticism of the plane by pilots and crew forced the government to act. An investigation by the Australian Senate has found that six pilots and numerous flight attendants have all been hit by toxic fumes filling the cabin. Many have been unable to work since.

It is not just toxic fumes entering the cabin that appear to make flying on a BAe 146 a risky venture.

Just over a month ago, a BAe 146 belonging to Canadian operator AirBC was cruising at 29,000ft on a flight from Winnipeg to Denver when its number one engine lost power. The pilot informed air traffic control, requesting a lower altitude.

But as the aircraft passed through 26,000ft, two further engines failed and the pilot declared an emergency. The BAe 146 then dived another 16,000ft before power was regained just 5,000ft above Denver.

Once again, optimism that this was an isolated incident has proved wide of the mark.

Last year four BAe 146s reported similar engine failures. It is highly unusual for even one aircraft engine to suffer problems, but as a British Aerospace warning obtained by The Observer reveals in three cases all four engines had problems that could have led to disaster.

A second British Aerospace document, dated 1997 and obtained by The Observer, reveals that the company knew of 12 such engine failures that had already occurred on its planes.

In aircraft engineering parlance, these problems are known as 'roll-backs'. When an aircraft in cloud reaches a height of more than 26,000ft, ice begins to form in the engine. To stop this happening, the air that flows through the jet engines is compressed to heat it up. Hot air melts the ice and keeps the plane flying.

Experts believe what is happening with the engines on the BAe 146 is that the de-icing systems are failing causing the engines to choke.

So are the problems of toxic fumes and engine failures connected? While British Aerospace plays the problems down, some aircraft experts have no doubt that there is an inherent fault in the engine design of the BAe 146.

They are convinced that the cause lies in the fact that the engines of the BAe 146 were converted from helicopter engines, the same ones used in the famous US Chinook helicopter.

Monty Armstrong, a senior Australian aviation engineer who worked for Ansett Airlines, which has a large fleet of BAe 146s, says that because the engine was originally designed for helicopters it is suitable for low altitudes. Armstrong told The Observer: 'Helicopters do not, generally speaking, fly to high altitudes. There is no pressurisation in helicopters, but high- flying jets need a lot of pressurised air to do many different things like de-icing engines in cloud.

'The problem is that in these conditions the plane sometimes sucks out too much compressed air out of the engine, and the result is ether unstable or unsustainable engine combustions causing the engine to shut down.'

According to Bill Gunston, editor of Jane's All the World's Jet Engines, no other jet has suffered multiple roll-backs so frequently as the BAe 146 and in such large numbers.

The international authorities have recognised the problem. An airworthiness directive issued last September ordered modifications to the engine, but airlines have until 31 December 2002 to comply.

In 1997, BAe warned pilots not to fly their aircraft above 26,000ft in clouds. But it is clear recent incidents mean that these warnings appear to have had little impact.

Dick Best, a former official at Australia's Civil Aviation Safety Authority and responsible for certifying the plane, said: 'If I had known of the BAe 146's problems, I would have had serious doubts about okaying the jet for Australia.'

As might be expected, both British Aerospace and the airlines using the aircraft have mounted a vigorous defence of theses planes.

A BAe spokesman said: 'The two conditions might emanate from the 'same engine but there is absolutely no connection. Rollback problems are 'rare and only occur in certain extreme weather conditions of high altitude.

'The cause has been identified and a modification developed that has proved to be effective in tests conducted in 1998. A number of operators have already modified their aircraft.' He added: 'There are more than 200 of these aircraft flying daily worldwide, having flown 4.5 million hours. In all this time no aircraft has been lost or damaged as a result of rollback.' While the company acknowledges that there have been some problems with toxic fumes, it argues that tests have been carried out on cabins to show the risks are minimal.

Indeed, the company points out that many other makes of aircraft also have problems with toxic fumes poisoning the air in the cabin.

British Aerospace also stresses that the aircraft is internationally certified as safe by all the major aviation authorities including the FAA in the United States and the CAA in Britain.

A CAA spokeswoman confirmed this. She said: 'We are aware of the reports of fumes entering the cabin and are working with BAe to solve the problem. But we believe the aircraft meets all our safety criteria.'

Privately, many in the industry are waiting for the conclusions of the Australian Senate investigation. But the chair of the committee, Senator John Woodley, has personally experienced choking fumes while flying in a BAe 146. It is unlikely they will give the aircraft the all-clear.

This weekend thousands of British holidaymakers are boarding BAe 146s on their way to Amsterdam, Florence and Paris.

They will be hoping - along with their friends and relatives - that action to prevent a serious accident due to the apparent defects is not taken too late.
