webTitle: Hawking to join God in the spotlight

fields.headline: Hawking to join God in the spotlight
fields.standfirst: A Brief History of Time hits the stage - spiced up by its author's private life
fields.trailText: A Brief History of Time hits the stage - spiced up by its author's private life
fields.body:
It will surely go down as the most ambitious stage production ever mounted by a cast of four: astrophysics, sex, love, betrayal and religion - all covered in two brief acts.

God and Stephen Hawking , a new play starring Robert Hardy as God and Stephen Boxer as Hawking, tackles some of the biggest philosophical questions out there.

The play - already billed as 'a major new theatrical production' and 'an extraordinary revelation of the life and vision of one of the most famous and revered men on the planet' - goes into rehearsal next month and has been written by Robin Hawdon with the co-operation of Hawking's first wife, Jane. It does not, though, have the blessing of the professor himself. Hawking, the wheelchair-bound theoretical physicist of world renown, is known for his dislike of public interest in his personal life.

Publicity for the show, to tour the regions this summer before making a bid for a transfer to the West End, says the script was written 'without the specific consent and co-operation' of Hawking.

Hawdon's script is based largely on descriptions of phe nomena such as The Big Bang and black holes from Hawking's hugely successful book, A Brief History of Time .

'I have tried to explain, fairly simplistically, a lot of the ideas in the book, which, let's face it, was written to introduce the layman to science,' said Hawdon, whose other work includes The Mating Game, and adaptations of Kingsley Amis's The Old Devils and Marc Camoletti's farce Don't Dress for Dinner .

'The new play will also cover the story of Hawking's life itself - from his early twenties onwards,' added Hawdon. 'We have looked at his first marriage and for the early part of his story he can speak using his own voice. Later on we plan to replicate the synthesised voice that he has to use today.' The part of Hawking, who now lives with his second wife and former nurse Elaine Mason, has gone to Stephen Boxer, familiar for his role in the current television drama Rough Treatment. Boxer will act in a wheelchair most of the time.

Hawking is the longest-surviving sufferer of motor neurone disease.

The acclaimed stage and television actor Robert Hardy, known and loved for playing Siegfried Farnon in All Creatures Great and Small has moved on to playing God himself in this production.

'It will be a terrifically fun role for Robert,' said Hawdon. 'He has played Winston Churchill on television, so I am not sure if this is a step up or down, but this time he will also be playing Einstein, Newton and Pope John Paul, so there will be a lot of running around changing costumes and wigs.' Other characters, including Jane Hawking, will be played by two supporting actors.

'The third element of my play,' said Hawdon, 'is the whole question of what the scientific theories of the late twentieth century have done to orthodox religion. Throughout the play the character of God realises that he is being called into question by the new scientific theories, and although it is a serious play, I hope there will be some funny moments.'

Hawking's first wife has been in contact with Hawdon during script-writing and made some alterations to an early draft. Last year she published her own book, Music to Move the Stars: A Life with Stephen , controversially saying her ex-husband was a 'tyrant' with 'the body of a holocaust victim and the needs of an infant'.

With her husband's consent she had a boyfriend during their marriage, but in 1990 the professor left her, and their three children, after 25 years.

Hawdon said he was careful to paraphrase many of Hawking's major theories for copyright reasons.

The playwright hopes to capture the interest of at least some of the 25 million readers who have bought A Brief History for his show, which opens at the Theatre Royal Bath and is directed by Jonathan Church.

'The interest is obviously out there,' Hawdon said, adding that he suspects that some of those who did not make it through the whole book will come along to see the stage play instead.

Vanessa Thorpe vanessa.thorpe@observer.co.uk

Publicity for the show, to tour the regions this summer before making a bid for a transfer to the West End, says the script was written 'without the specific consent and co-operation' of Hawking. Hawdon's script is based largely on descriptions of phe nomena such as The Big Bang and black holes from Hawking's hugely successful book, A Brief History of Time . 'I have tried to explain, fairly simplistically, a lot of the ideas in the book, which, let's face it, was written to introduce the layman to science,' said Hawdon, whose other work includes The Mating Game, and adaptations of Kingsley Amis's The Old Devils and Marc Camoletti's farce Don't Dress for Dinner . 'The new play will also cover the story of Hawking's life itself - from his early twenties onwards,' added Hawdon. 'We have looked at his first marriage and for the early part of his story he can speak using his own voice. Later on we plan to replicate the synthesised voice that he has to use today.' The part of Hawking, who now lives with his second wife and former nurse Elaine Mason, has gone to Stephen Boxer, familiar for his role in the current television drama Rough Treatment. Boxer will act in a wheelchair most of the time. Hawking is the longest-surviving sufferer of motor neurone disease. The acclaimed stage and television actor Robert Hardy, known and loved for playing Siegfried Farnon in All Creatures Great and Small has moved on to playing God himself in this production. 'It will be a terrifically fun role for Robert,' said Hawdon. 'He has played Winston Churchill on television, so I am not sure if this is a step up or down, but this time he will also be playing Einstein, Newton and Pope John Paul, so there will be a lot of running around changing costumes and wigs.' Other characters, including Jane Hawking, will be played by two supporting actors. 'The third element of my play,' said Hawdon, 'is the whole question of what the scientific theories of the late twentieth century have done to orthodox religion. Throughout the play the character of God realises that he is being called into question by the new scientific theories, and although it is a serious play, I hope there will be some funny moments.' Hawking's first wife has been in contact with Hawdon during script-writing and made some alterations to an early draft. Last year she published her own book, Music to Move the Stars: A Life with Stephen , controversially saying her ex-husband was a 'tyrant' with 'the body of a holocaust victim and the needs of an infant'. With her husband's consent she had a boyfriend during their marriage, but in 1990 the professor left her, and their three children, after 25 years. Hawdon said he was careful to paraphrase many of Hawking's major theories for copyright reasons. The playwright hopes to capture the interest of at least some of the 25 million readers who have bought A Brief History for his show, which opens at the Theatre Royal Bath and is directed by Jonathan Church. 'The interest is obviously out there,' Hawdon said, adding that he suspects that some of those who did not make it through the whole book will come along to see the stage play instead. fields.headline: England man by man
fields.standfirst: Euro 2000 build-up: How Keegan's men rated in Malta
fields.trailText: How Keegan's men rated in Malta.
fields.body:
RICHARD WRIGHT 6

Some debut. Showed inexperience in conceding two penalties. Redeemed himself with two late saves.

GARY NEVILLE 7

Reliable as usual. Made some important tackles and blocks.

SOL CAMPBELL 7

Commanding in air, occasionally caught out on ground but quick to recover.

MARTIN KEOWN 6

Scored a goal and had one chalked off, but square in defence.

PHIL NEVILLE 6

Quiet game, relieved to be back at left-back. Crossing disappointing.

DAVID BECKHAM 7

Dead balls excellent, but ineffective in open play. It's worrying that England's chief threat revolves around his set-piece plays.

PAUL SCHOLES 7

Passed well, ran well, almost scored. Saving himself for real thing. Certain for berth in team next week.

DENNIS WISE 7

Recovered from uncertain start to figure in several attacks. No threat to Ince or Gerrard in defensive midfield position.

NICK BARMBY 8

England's liveliest attacker. Made second goal, should have scored with first-half header.

ALAN SHEARER 6

Still no goals, despite clear first-half opportunity. Lack of chances becoming a worry.

KEVIN PHILLIPS 6

Twice close to scoring in first half. Ineffective in generally flat England performance after the interval.

EMILE HESKEY 7

Scored late in game as sub for Shearer, and could have had more. Catalyst for England's best attacking period.

OTHER SUBSTITUTIONS: Gareth Southgate (for Keown); Gareth Barry (for Beckham); Steve McManaman (for Scholes); Paul Ince (for Wise); Robbie Fowler (for Phillips).

webTitle: Drug plague crosses the Irish Sea

fields.headline: Drug plague crosses the Irish Sea
fields.standfirst: A deadly epidemic is ravaging Dublin's heroin addicts, reports Mary Holland
fields.trailText: Dublin newspapers carried a bleak message for heroin addicts yesterday. Large advertisements warned there could be contaminated supplies of the drug on sale and urged users to contact a doctor immediately if they noticed any unusual symptoms, particularly an abscess or swelling close to an injection site.
fields.body:
Dublin newspapers carried a bleak message for heroin addicts yesterday. Large advertisements warned there could be contaminated supplies of the drug on sale and urged users to contact a doctor immediately if they noticed any unusual symptoms, particularly an abscess or swelling close to an injection site.

The intervention comes in the wake of the deaths of eight young addicts in Dublin since the beginning of May. There is speculation the cases could be linked to similar instances in Glasgow, where 16 addicts have died from 'unusual severe illness' that could have been caused by contaminated heroin.

Dr Kristey Murray, of the US Centres for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta, arrived in Dublin last week to help the inquiry into the illness, while another official for the centres has travelled to Glasgow.

The most immediate task is to deal with the crisis facing large numbers of young heroin-users and their families. As well as the warnings in national newspapers to be alert for any unusual symptoms, a 24-hour helpline is in operation and 12 clinics will be open in the wider Dublin area over this weekend.

Whether these measures will reach those who are most vulnerable, the thousands of addicts who inject heroin and are not in touch with any of the social services provided, is a cause for serious concern. One counsellor said yesterday: 'If an addict needs heroin, he or she will inject.'

The crisis has focused a harsh spotlight on a problem which most Irish people would prefer to ignore since it hardly impinges on the more comfortably off sections of a society doing well in a time of economic boom.

Ireland's addicts are the youngest in Europe, with an average age of 24, compared with 34 in the Netherlands. The overwhelming majority come from the most socially deprived areas of large cities, although senior police officers have recently expressed concern that the drug is becoming more available in rural areas.

In Dublin alone there are 13,000 heroin-users, of whom 4,500 are on treatment programmes and 400 more are on waiting lists. That means that 8,000 addicts are not in touch with any of the social services offering some form of help. It is these young men and women who are most at risk from injecting contaminated heroin.

As Anna Quigley, co-ordinator of the Dublin-based City Wide Campaign against Drugs, commented: 'There's no point in telling an addict not to inject. If it were that simple, we wouldn't have a heroin problem.'

There are no official figures of deaths from heroin use, but one estimate put the number of deaths in 1998 at 90. This does not begin to touch on the devastation caused to families who have lost young sons and daughters to the drug. Last month Dr Brian Farrell, the Dublin city coroner, spoke of the drug having reached 'epidemic proportions' after he had heard evidence of six deaths related to heroin use in a single day.

The government has made efforts to stem the crisis. Ireland has the highest rate of drug-related crime in the EU and part of the initiative has sprung from the need to deal with this. Twelve task forces have been set up in Dublin and Cork to bring together health boards, gardai, probation and welfare services, together with local community groups.

Last month proposals were brought forward for setting up an independent body to oversee the fight against drugs, and public hearings are planned to draw in local activists. A drugs court is to be set up in Dublin, which will offer non-violent addicts opportunities for supervised treatment and rehabilitation.

Many people working at street level with addicts believe that all this, while welcome, might be still too little and too late. They point to the fierce local opposition to setting up clinics anywhere outside the poorest inner-city areas.

Some argue that what is needed is a much more radical approach which would take the supply of heroin out of the hands of criminal gangs. Father Sean Cassin, a member of the National Drugs Strategy Team, has argued that Ireland should follow Switzerland's example and prescribe heroin for young addicts.

The government's own task force has recognised - and emphasised - that the drugs problem cannot be solved in isolation from the underlying causes of 'social exclusion, poverty, unemployment, lack of recreational and other facilities' throughout large areas of inner cities.

Public attention was focused on drugs last week because of the scare over contaminated heroin. But whether the political will exists to deal with the problem in the wider social context of poverty is another question.

As Vincent O'Doherty, who works with addicts in Dublin, put it: 'If we had had eight deaths from heroin in Castleknock [a prosperous suburb of the capital] we would have had a public inquiry. This has been mainly confined to the children of the poor. Life in the inner city is cheap.'

fields.headline: Atherton enjoys life
fields.standfirst: The former England captain is proving to be the class act in a very average game
fields.trailText: Kevin Mitchell singles out the former England captain as the class act in a very average game.
fields.body:
In the metaphorical and literal gloom of Nottingham these past few half-days, Michael Atherton's class has provided the perfect antidote to cricket of towering inadequacy. If he can carry his form into the more serious business ahead against West Indies, he will have brightened up our alleged summer considerably.

At 32, Atherton has reached a second peak, achieving a mastery and calm that compensate for his obvious loss of flexibility through his chronic back problems. What is encouraging for Atherton and England is that he looks more at ease with himself than does the disturbingly plump Brian Lara, whom Jimmy Adams said last week he hoped would blossom again now he is in his thirties. Colin Croft, meanwhile, reckons Lara has to work on his fitness and 'Like Viv Richards and Gary Sobers before him, he needs to recognise that the world is not so full of geniuses.'

Even geniuses have to work. While the troubled Lara sought professional help in New York and solitude in Trinidad after abandoning Test cricket temporarily, Atherton got to work at Old Trafford, fiddling with bits of his technique. Lara, out for one against Worcestershire on Friday, might yet torture England this season, but it is Atherton who has made the more definitive statement about his long-term rehabilitation.

There is art in his obstinate occupation of the crease, the ruddy face underneath the curls concealing grimness that only the best bowlers can penetrate - but rarely can so good a Test century have been surrounded by such sub-standard bowling by the opposition, indifferent fielding and, it has to be said, poor support from his own team-mates.

The exception here was the skittish Chris Schofield, a young man so confident in his eccentric ability with the bat that he reverse-swept Bryan Murphy for his first 50 in light that would please a mugger. When he tennis-batted him over the slips for four, then got out trying to reverse-sweep Murphy's leg-break, it appeared England might have discovered not just a decent lower-order bat in the Lancashire spinner, but a player with a bit of character and personality about him.

In what is otherwise another mismatch, Atherton earlier had ploughed gracefully on after resuming on 96. A rare pull for his century - 'I knew I had to get on with it, with the new ball due' - was followed by a succession of beautiful square drives.

Then, after going chancelessly through the gears for seven weather-marred hours, he drove in the air to extra cover to give Pommie Mbangwa his second wicket. 'Well you'd settle for 136,' said Atherton 'but nobody likes to throw it away.'

This was a day for old sweats, and few have sweated more profitably for England than Atherton. He made his Test debut here, in the fifth Test against Australia in 1989, and got a duck; a year later - the year Lara entered Test cricket - he returned to Nottingham to score the first of his 14 Test hundreds to date, and yesterday he posted his fifth on the ground, level with Ian Botham and one behind Denis Compton. 'It means Beefy is not going to be able to give me so much stick,' he said. It is what passes for a joke with the man who secretly liked being Mr Grumpy.

I remember bumping into Atherton in the team hotel in Antigua the day two winters ago that he advised the team management he'd had enough. He looked down at a British tabloid lying on the reception desk and contemplated what mincemeat they might make of him after another day of toil against a fading West Indies team still too powerful for England. It was easy to imagine that he would not just resign the captaincy that night but give up the game altogether. But Atherton is a man of many surprises. Since his return to the England side after that miserable tour, he has reinvented himself.

He is not quite the undergraduate dasher who arrived at Lancashire from Cambridge in the late Eighties, more the seasoned pro visited by lightness, content to lead from behind in his own quiet way. And you can be sure he will not spare a jot of sympathy for Lara if he fails to reignite his talents this summer.

webTitle: Lottery cash to be aimed at poor

fields.headline: Lottery cash to be aimed at poor
fields.trailText: The bodies that hand out billions of pounds of Lottery money are to be ordered to abolish widespread regional discrepancies which mean some areas are getting the equivalent of a few pounds a head compared with the national average of £90.
fields.body:
The bodies that hand out billions of pounds of Lottery money are to be ordered to abolish widespread regional discrepancies which mean some areas are getting the equivalent of a few pounds a head compared with the national average of £90.

Chris Smith, the Culture Secretary who has responsibility for the Lottery, will tell the committees which run the funds that they must make more effort to direct money into deprived areas.

Smith hopes his action will play well in Labour's heartland areas which get the least money from the Lottery, described as a 'tax on the poor' because deprived areas spend most on it but receive the least back in grants.

Figures compiled for Smith's department reveal that north-east Derbyshire gets just £3.89 a head compared with between £150 and £200 a head in parts of central London, which has received huge Lottery cash injections for major projects such as the Royal Opera House, Tate Modern and the Dome.

Other areas that have received very little Lottery money include Knowlsey in Liverpool at £12 a head, Rotherham, also £12, and south Staffordshire, with £7.18 a head.

Although Smith will praise action already taken by the Lottery distributors to give out cash more fairly, he will say more must be done.

'It was the well-heeled areas with good connections which took greatest advantage of the application process,' a Government source said.

'Poorer areas often don't have the large cultural institutions which have received huge amounts of cash and so they are missing out. We have to tackle that to make sure there is a fairer distribution of the money raised by the Lottery.'

The areas, many of them at the heart of former coal mining areas, will be targeted by a special action team which will help local communities put together smaller scale Lottery bids.

The six bodies that give out Lottery money - the Arts Council, the Heritage Lottery Fund, the Millennium Commission, the Charities Board, Sport England and the New Opportunities Fund - will also be told to allow greater flexibility in how they judge Lottery bids.

Officials believe that smaller communities can miss out because they cannot afford the expensive consultants who put together major Lottery bids for city areas. They believe that the application process is too complex for many small organisations and must be simplified. The Government will also consider relaxing rules on partnership funding, the extra money groups applying for Lottery grants have to secure from other sources if their application is successful.

A Government briefing paper says the bodies that hand out the money will have to 'bear in mind the role the Lottery can play in reducing economic and social deprivation'. The paper also says they need to 'ensure that all regions and parts of society can benefit from the Lottery'.

Smith will highlight a pilot scheme in Barnsley, South Yorkshire, where £3 million of cash was earmarked for the area before applications came in.

Teams were then sent out to encourage applications from local groups and help was given putting together the complex documents required.

Figures from Camelot, the company that runs the Lottery, reveal that areas such as Derby, Sunderland, Leeds and Keighley spend the most on Lottery tickets.

People in Sunderland North have spent £143 million on tickets, but received only £15 million back in grants.

In London there are also wide discrepancies. Westminster and the City of London have done very well out of the Lottery, while Tottenham - whose residents spent £63 million, the 14th highest amount, on tickets - has received just over £5m in grants.

Kamal Ahmed

fields.headline: Brideshead demolished
fields.standfirst: Demonised as the don who turned down Laura Spence, Magdalen's medicine tutor is in fact a campaigner for state schools. And he's working on a cure for Parkinson's. Some demon: 'I can tell a bullshitter when I see one, and a lot of independent-school applicants are bullshitters. The great thing is how surprised they seem when we turn them down'
fields.trailText: It is hard, frankly, to see how Gordon Brown could have got it more thunderously, extravagantly wrong. He could have accused Stephen Hawking of dumbing-down, or Tony Blair of stubborn blind faith in principle
fields.body:
It is hard, frankly, to see how Gordon Brown could have got it more thunderously, extravagantly wrong. He could have accused Stephen Hawking of dumbing-down, or Tony Blair of stubborn blind faith in principle. He could, one supposes, have rugby-tackled a Dunkirk veteran on the quayside yesterday and accused him of desertion from the field of battle.

But the more the Laura Spence affair rolls on, the more it seems obvious that whoever advised Brown to shoot himself so grandiosely in the foot should now take the same shotgun and do the decent thing. For the man cast by government as the villain of the piece, the senior tutor in medicine at Magdalen who sat on the panel that refused Laura entrance, emerges with each utterance as perhaps the most sainted academic in Britain. It's not enough that he's practically found a cure for dyslexia. Nor that he's close to discovering a cure for Parkinson's. Nor that he's been lauded by two current Cabinet Ministers for his work (while, incidentally, being repeatedly refused funding by their departments). He also appears to have been more active than anyone in campaigning to get more state pupils into the university, launching summer schools to reassure them that the 1930s image of snobbish dons and prejudiced interviews is over.

Brown hasn't apologised; politics dictates he can't. But I feel sure that, had he been he sitting beside us in John Stein's office for two hours last Friday, by the end he would have been grovelling among the mess of papers on the floor - papers touching on such apposite topics as 'parasites' and 'hyperexcitability' - and begging forgiveness.

And he would probably have got it. For Stein is a bit of a charmer. Ruthlessly intelligent, of course, and you know he won't suffer fools for long. (I make the mistake, when he's in mid-flow on pupil numbers, of automatically, and rather snottily, correcting his 'less' to a 'fewer'; his eyes narrow momentarily, and not with humour). But extremely human with it. Funny and passionate when he talks about his brother Rick's cooking, and how he tries to get down to Padstow as often as possible. Adolescently coy as he blushes before the blue gaze of our young female Danish photographer. Suddenly vulnerable, worried, as he takes a call from his young daughter, teaching in India, who has phoned to let him know she's contracted amoebic dysentery. ('Oh God. Hell. Awful. And her mother's going to be distraught.') And angry, extremely angry, when he starts to talk about the Government - which he voted for and supported, and feels quite monstrously let down by.

Far from being worried by pupils with a lack of confidence, he's become more adept, he says, at spotting those with too much. 'I've been in the business for 30 years. Rather than attacking the dons, he says, there are a few things the Government could be doing to help. 'Most of the complaints we get when we talk to state pupils are that they have no training for interviews. Surely that's something the Government could tackle.' Or it could reconsider tuition fees. webTitle: Accident-prone climber lucky to survive plunge

fields.headline: Accident-prone climber lucky to survive plunge
fields.trailText: Britain's top mountaineer, Alan Hinkes, has narrowly escaped a freezing, lonely death after plunging into a crevasse close to the summit of the world's third highest peak. The accident has dashed his hopes of being the first Briton to climb all the world's 8,000m-plus peaks. A successful ascent would have left him only two of the 14 to climb.
fields.body:
Britain's top mountaineer, Alan Hinkes, has narrowly escaped a freezing, lonely death after plunging into a crevasse close to the summit of the world's third highest peak. The accident has dashed his hopes of being the first Briton to climb all the world's 8,000m-plus peaks. A successful ascent would have left him only two of the 14 to climb.

Hinkes, who is rapidly earning himself the sobriquet of 'Britain's unluckiest living mountaineer', was descending a steep glacier around 2,000ft (650m) below the 28,149ft (8,586m) summit of the mountain on Tuesday morning last week when a bridge made of ice and snow gave way beneath him.

The 47-year-old had been forced to give up his summit bid after four days of climbing because of deep snow which threatened to avalanche. But only hours after turning back to base camp disaster struck.

It is not the first time that Hinkes has found himself in trouble on a Himalayan mountain. Three years ago the former school teacher had to call off his assault on the Pakistani peak of Nanga Parbat when he slipped a disc after sneezing on dust from a chapatti.

On a previous expedition, to the mountain of Makalu in Nepal, Hinkes, who comes from Northallerton in Yorkshire, slipped on a leaf on a muddy path while on the approach march to the mountains. He impaled his thigh on bamboo and had to be carried to safety in a helicopter.

This time Hinkes, climbing the South-West face of the mountain, bounced off the icy walls of the crevasse as he fell, shattering two bones in his left arm before landing on an icy ledge. 'As I fell I heard a metallic crack as my left elbow smashed into the ice. I thought it was just a piece of equipment snapping,' he told his support staff in Britain on a satellite phone last week. Beneath the ledge the ice fell away into a void. 'I am very, very lucky to be alive.'

Despite intense pain Hinkes, who had been climbing alone, managed to scrabble up the almost sheer walls of the crevasse to reach the surface. But from there he had to find a way down to his base camp nearly 7,500ft (2,200m) below where his cook and three Nepali porters were waiting for him.

The descent took nearly two days with Hinkes battling thigh deep drifts of snow and high winds before reaching relative safety. With one arm hanging uselessly he was forced to abseil - a dangerous manoeuvre in the best conditions. Even from base camp Hinkes faces an arduous trek across glaciers and through forest to reach proper medical attention in the Nepali capital of Kathmandhu. Friends have no doubt that he will return to Kangchenjunga.

webTitle: In the land of the café owners Waseige is king

fields.headline: In the land of the café owners Waseige is king
fields.standfirst: A cunning 60-year-old grandfather is leading Belgium into Euro 2000 and has become the ultimate national hero
fields.trailText: Robert Waseige is a tubby little man with large spectacles who enjoys cigars, whisky, and sitting at home in his slippers watching basketball on TV. He also manages the Belgian football team.
fields.body:
Robert Waseige is a tubby little man with large spectacles who enjoys cigars and whisky. He also likes sitting at home in his slippers watching basketball on TV. His wife, Aline, says: 'When he walks around in shorts, I often think, "He looks nowhere near 60."' In fact Waseige looks like a 60-year-old café owner.

Yet the bespectacled Belgium manager has achieved the sort of feats normally associated with a cartoon superhero. Ten months ago he took over a side that had become a national joke on a par with the country's police force. Now, six days before Belgium kick off Euro 2000 against Sweden in Brussels, some people are invoking the great 'Red Devils' of the early 1980s. Clearly Waseige has a secret.

Belgium under his predecessor George Leekens were farcical. On a tour of Asia last summer the team was accompanied by just one fan, and at one point last year they lost five games in a row without scoring. Finally, against Finland last August, they cracked the nut, scoring three times.

Sadly they also conceded four. Leekens, who had considered resigning at half-time, was sacked.

Waseige thought he should have been given the job years before. That he was not, it is whispered, is because he drinks even more than the average Belgian.

In his first match in charge Belgium put five goals past an incredulous Holland. Admittedly they also let in five, but it was a start. In six games since, the side have lost only once (bizarrely, to England), have hammered Morocco 4-0, and beaten Italy and Norway away.

When they received Holland in Brussels in March, legendary Dutch total football was on display: overlaps down the wing, one-touch passing and volleyed goals resembling Johan Cruyff's against Brazil in 1974. This time, though, it was played by the Belgians. Waseige's players talk of their manager with the fervour of Moonies. How has he done it?

'I don't think I have an important statement to make about that,' he says. Waseige speaks in the soothing and understated tone of a publican addressing a tired and emotional regular. A native French-speaker, at press conferences he speaks alternate sentences in Dutch and French to please both halves of the country, translating himself as he goes along. Most people like him.

In this he reminds Belgians of Guy Thijs, coach of the great Belgian side of the 1980s. A chubby old man always seen with whisky and cigar, Thijs looked like a café owner. That, in fact, was his secret. He would ask his players how their wives were, or how the team should play. Then they would go out and beat Argentina. Afterwards they would have a few drinks.

Ever since Thijs retired Belgians have been looking for his reincarnation. In a land where 38 per cent of adults resemble café owners, the surprise is that it took so long to find him. Waseige was born to the job. There is something earthy about Belgium - the beer, the chocolates, the statue of Manneken Pis, the decaying houses in smart city centres - that is exemplified by Waseige. He is the cunning little man, the ultimate Belgian hero, the nation's grandfather. Waseige hates being called a grandfather, but part of his mystique is that he is a family man. His wife loves talking to the press, and both of them enjoy boasting about their sons.

What is the coach's secret? Gert Verheyen, a Belgian midfielder, says: 'Psychology, eh?' But what does Waseige do? 'He talks,' says Verheyen.

Like Thijs, he also lets his players talk, and talk about anything. For the first week of their training camp for Euro 2000, Waseige barely mentioned football. Instead he had his charges playing golf or basketball or going for long walks, as if they were in health farm for stress disorders.

Leekens always emphasised how bad his players were ('You can't drive a diesel like a Formula One car'), and under his rule Belgian modesty turned into masochism. He also kept changing the side.

Waseige seems to believe that Belgian footballers today are much of a muchness. The last great player of the 1980s, Enzo Scifo, recently emphasised his descent into middle age by buying himself his own club, Charleroi FC. He will not play at Euro 2000.

With no stars, Waseige likes to stick with the same eleven. That keeps things simple. Naming his team before the Dutch match in March, he seemed to have trouble remembering all their names. '...And Mpenza,' he concluded triumphantly. 'That's Emile Mpenza,' the Belgium press officer added.

Pressed further as to his secret, Waseige reveals: 'I have a fixed system.' His key player, Marc Wilmots, elaborates: 'There is clarity now. We play 4-4-2. That's it, period.' Often the Devils even attack, a departure from Belgian tradition. The opener against Sweden could turn out to be less dull than it looks on paper.

Asked what he will do an hour before kick-off, Waseige says: 'I will stay a little to one side and light up a good cigar. Somebody in the stadium is going to have to stay calm.' His wife won't be there, because she has to babysit the grandchildren.

When they received Holland in Brussels in March, legendary Dutch total football was on display: overlaps down the wing, one-touch passing and volleyed goals resembling Johan Cruyff's against Brazil in 1974. This time, though, it was played by the Belgians. Waseige's players talk of their manager with the fervour of Moonies. How has he done it? 'I don't think I have an important statement to make about that,' he says. Waseige speaks in the soothing and understated tone of a publican addressing a tired and emotional regular. A native French-speaker, at press conferences he speaks alternate sentences in Dutch and French to please both halves of the country, translating himself as he goes along. Most people like him. In this he reminds Belgians of Guy Thijs, coach of the great Belgian side of the 1980s. A chubby old man always seen with whisky and cigar, Thijs looked like a café owner. That, in fact, was his secret. He would ask his players how their wives were, or how the team should play. Then they would go out and beat Argentina. Afterwards they would have a few drinks. Ever since Thijs retired Belgians have been looking for his reincarnation. In a land where 38 per cent of adults resemble café owners, the surprise is that it took so long to find him. Waseige was born to the job. There is something earthy about Belgium - the beer, the chocolates, the statue of Manneken Pis, the decaying houses in smart city centres - that is exemplified by Waseige. He is the cunning little man, the ultimate Belgian hero, the nation's grandfather. Waseige hates being called a grandfather, but part of his mystique is that he is a family man. His wife loves talking to the press, and both of them enjoy boasting about their sons. What is the coach's secret? Gert Verheyen, a Belgian midfielder, says: 'Psychology, eh?' But what does Waseige do? 'He talks,' says Verheyen. Like Thijs, he also lets his players talk, and talk about anything. For the first week of their training camp for Euro 2000, Waseige barely mentioned football. Instead he had his charges playing golf or basketball or going for long walks, as if they were in health farm for stress disorders. Leekens always emphasised how bad his players were ('You can't drive a diesel like a Formula One car'), and under his rule Belgian modesty turned into masochism. He also kept changing the side. Waseige seems to believe that Belgian footballers today are much of a muchness. The last great player of the 1980s, Enzo Scifo, recently emphasised his descent into middle age by buying himself his own club, Charleroi FC. He will not play at Euro 2000. With no stars, Waseige likes to stick with the same eleven. That keeps things simple. Naming his team before the Dutch match in March, he seemed to have trouble remembering all their names. '...And Mpenza,' he concluded triumphantly. 'That's Emile Mpenza,' the Belgium press officer added. Pressed further as to his secret, Waseige reveals: 'I have a fixed system.' His key player, Marc Wilmots, elaborates: 'There is clarity now. We play 4-4-2. That's it, period.' Often the Devils even attack, a departure from Belgian tradition. The opener against Sweden could turn out to be less dull than it looks on paper. Asked what he will do an hour before kick-off, Waseige says: 'I will stay a little to one side and light up a good cigar. Somebody in the stadium is going to have to stay calm.' His wife won't be there, because she has to babysit the grandchildren.

fields.headline: Wagner's own soap opera
fields.standfirst: The family battle for control of the lucrative Bayreuth festival is as complex as any of the Ring composer's plots, writes  Denis Staunton
fields.trailText: The family battle for control of the lucrative Bayreuth festival is as complex as any of the Ring composer's plots.
fields.body:
It is an tale of blood and honour, of dynastic succession and fratricide, played out against the swelling tones of Richard Wagner's music in the Bavarian hilltop opera house at Bayreuth. But in the latest manifestation of the Wagner family's endless internal feud, the coveted treasure is not a ring of gold but control of the annual Bayreuth festival and the composer's legacy.

A 24-member committee will this week name a successor to Wolfgang Wagner, the composer's 80-year-old grandson who has run the festival for almost half a century. The three candidates are all Wagners - Wolfgang's wife Gudrun, his daughter Eva and his niece Nike - and they all loathe one another.

Regardless of the committee's decision, however, it's clear that there is little chance of a smooth transfer of power at Bayreuth to a new generation.

The latest twist in the tale began last year, when Wolfgang agreed that the procedure for choosing a successor should be set in motion, declaring that he did not want to continue running the festival 'as a mummy or a robot'.

But in its eagerness to end Wolfgang's reign the committee neglected to secure from him a firm date of departure. When Wolfgang heard that the choice was likely to fall on Eva, rather than on his wife Gudrun, he announced that he had no intention of terminating his contract as festival director, which will end only with his death.

Most insiders believe that Wolfgang's plan is to install the 56-year-old Gudrun as a caretaker director until their 22-year-old daughter Katharina, who has just finished a theatre studies degree, is ready to take over.

But Nike a cultural historian who has long been the critics' favourite, is withering about Gudrun, who was Wolfgang's secretary before she became his wife.

'Everybody knows that Gudrun reached her position as a collaborator through the marriage bed and not through art and culture. My guess is that our theatre and music people will regard her candidature as the laughing stock of the nation,' she said.

Wagner family feuds are almost as much a part of Bayreuth tradition as the operas themselves. Although the festival is now controlled by a foundation and is partly financed from public funds, its constitution specifies that its director should 'in principle' be a Wagner.

Wolfgang has been at odds with most of his family since 1976, when he told Playboy that none of his relations was fit to succeed him. Since then, he has banned his son Gottfried from setting foot in the opera house and dismissed his daughter Eva's work at Covent Garden and the Paris Opera as unimpressive.

Nike has long been the most uncomfortable thorn in the old man's side, not least because of her claim that Wolfgang is guilty of suppressing information about the Wagner family's relationship with the Nazis.

Hitler was a fanatical admirer of Wagner, becoming a close friend of the family long before he came to power in 1933. Wolfgang's English-born mother, Winifred, was especially close to Hitler, who once described her as 'the only person I could marry as Führer'.

Although the young Wolfgang referred to Hitler as 'Uncle Wolf', he was quick to distance himself from the Nazis after the Second World War and did his best to play down the family's links to the fascist leadership.

With his brother, Wieland, Wolfgang defied international opposition to resurrect the festival in 1951 and assumed sole control of it after Wieland's death in 1966.

The festival is undoubtedly a commercial success, with all performances sold out months in advance. But there are signs that Bayreuth is losing some of its artistic prestige. 'There must be a change, because the institution of Bayreuth and its director are both going senile,' according to Nike.

Although a new production of the Ring opens this year, few Bayreuth productions have made a critical impact during the past three decades.

Nike's solution is to effect a revolution at the theatre on the 'green hill', starting a second season around Whitsun to satisfy some of the demand for tickets and extending the repertoire to include some of Wagner's early works. She wants to bring the festival closer to local people by staging live performances in the town centre, and her most radical proposal is to perform works by modern and contemporary composers influenced by Wagner.

'Bayreuth must be viewed in the context of the changes taking place in the world of opera at large. At the heart of the opera scene, its Wagner productions must be in keeping with its unique status. It must be able to offer a trendsetting, contemporary Wagner, and in doing so bridge the gap between late nineteenth-century Wagner and the twenty-first century,' she wrote last week.

Wolfgang rejected Nike's plan as 'absurd', and by Thursday, Gudrun had published her own manifesto, a long-winded call to leave things more or less as they are. 'The Bayreuth festival must under no circumstances become a specialised repertory theatre, it must retain its singularity and the special circumstances of its way of life against all trends towards levelling out. The demand today is for evolution - by no means revolution,' she wrote.

The committee looks certain to reject both Nike and Gudrun in favour of Eva, who has worked at Covent Garden and the Paris Opera and is currently an artistic adviser to the festival at Aix-en- Provence. Eva has taken the wise precaution of saying nothing about her plans for Bayreuth, but this reticence has not been enough to prevent a last-minute falling out with her cousin, Wieland Lafferentz, who runs the Mozarteum Foundation in Salz-burg. Lafferentz announced last week that he was no longer interested in running Bayreuth with Eva, whom he described as 'inexperienced', and that he now wanted to run the festival on his own.

The latest bout of family feuding has prompted some Bavarian politicians to look at various ways of wresting control of Bayreuth from the Wagners. They argue that the festival is too important an element in Germany's culture to be left to the mercy of such a strikingly dysfunctional family.

More optimistic observers hope that naming a successor will create such momentum for change that Wolfgang will feel obliged to step down sooner rather than later.

But the old patriarch issued a warning last week that he would take his lead from Germany's disgraced former Chancellor, Helmut Kohl, and 'sit it out' until the committee agreed to appoint his wife to succeed him.

 Denis Staunton writes for The Irish Times

It's a dreary town, but the music is out of this world

Bayreuth, a small, drab town of beer, sausages and cheap shoe shops, has no obvious charms as a shrine, writes Fiona Maddocks. Yet thousands of people from all over the world pay homage each year to the works of Richard Wagner (1813-1883), the obsessive, ambitious, visionary composer whose dream was to create a Complete Work of Art in which music, words and drama unite in a powerful whole. He wasn't Hitler's favourite composer though he may have been Goebbels's.

Wagner built a theatre to his own specifications, aided financially by gay, mad King Ludwig II, on a green hill above the town at which the annual festival now takes place.

Today this opera house, one of the best in the world acoustically, still serves its original purpose: to perform Wagner's music dramas and nothing else. It's a temple to high art and Germanic seriousness: no plush or gilt, just hard wooden seats; no Wagner T-shirts or key-rings, only his texts, in German, in the bookshop.

Nowhere are audiences more attentive, singers and orchestra better prepared. It's done with love, and it shows. The waiting list extends for years ahead.

Wagner's greatest achievement is The Ring , a complex four-part extrava ganza of dragons, dwarfs and incest sung in archaic German written by the composer himself.

Much of it is set at the bottom of the Rhine. One of its most misappropriated highlights is 'The Ride of the Valkyries', in which eight war-maidens dance, ride or fly across the stage shrieking 'Hojotoho! Hojotoho!'. Performed over a week and lasting about 18 hours, depending on the speed of the conductor, it is the focus of the festival.

It is one of the most complex and far-reaching works of art ever conceived. There's no other way to explain how you can spend a week in Bayreuth and say, in all honesty, you've had the time of your life.

webTitle: Veterans demand British memorial to Kwai dead

fields.headline: Veterans demand British memorial to Kwai dead
fields.trailText: A man died for every five metres of track laid. Working in stifling heat and living on starvation rations, British prisoners forced to build the infamous Thailand-to-Burma railway for the Japanese endured an appalling ordeal. More than 100,000 men lost their lives.
fields.body:
A man died for every five metres of track laid. Working in stifling heat and living on starvation rations, British prisoners forced to build the infamous Thailand-to-Burma railway for the Japanese endured an appalling ordeal. More than 100,000 men lost their lives.

Now, nearly 58 years after the opening of a simple bridge over the River Kwai signalled the completion of the project, a campaign has been launched to force the Government to fund a memorial for the forgotten heroes who built the railway.

The bridge, whose building is the central theme of the fictional film starring Alec Guinness, is one of the most popular tourist attractions for the half a million Britons who visit Thailand each year. Australia and the United States have memorials and visitor centres; even the Japanese have put up a plaque.

But war veterans and their families are accusing Britain of failing to ensure that the ultimate sacrifices of Second World War soldiers are remembered and of allowing the bridge to be run as a 'fun fair'.

Backed by the British military attaché to Bangkok, Colonel Johnny Thoyts, moves are finally afoot to try to right what he calls a 'dreadful insult' to those who died. Thoyts is seeking sponsorship to build a visitor centre and memorial, but so far only foreign business people have shown any interest in supporting the scheme.

Work on the bridge began in October 1942 and finished in December 1943. But many tourists leave the bridge none the wiser about the brutality and bravery which characterised the work.

The only reminder of British dead are the isolated cemeteries, which veterans or families on pilgrimages make a point of visiting. After the war, bodies found dumped in mass graves at the POW camps or buried where they fell - exhausted, sick and malnourished - were transferred to two cemeteries. A spokesman for the Commonwealth War Graves Commission said: 'It is true there is no memorial, although we would like to think the cemeteries are fitting memorials.'

Bill Holtham leads a prison camp survivors' group still campaigning for compensation and an apology from the Japanese. At his Essex home last week, he watched the celebrations surrounding the sixtieth anniversary of Dunkirk with some bitterness. 'Everyone knows about Dunkirk; heroes coming home. They were doing re-enactments and that's great to remember. But that railway needs remembering, too. The Kwai bridge is run like a fun-fair, a commercial enterprise, an insult.'

He added: 'I was sent to the railway with 1,680 soldiers. In three months, 250 were left alive. We were just skeletons. I could make my thumb and index finger into a circle and slide it up and down my upper arm. We were beaten and starved and murdered. The atrocities were beyond belief. At the end all we got was a soldier's farewell. Many survivors committed suicide when they returned home; the mental damage was dreadful. We should never forget.'

Another POW, US seaman Stanley Willner, travelled thousands of miles to attend a commemoration at the Kwai bridge. But when the time came to walk across in a ceremony of reconciliation with his Japanese captors, he froze. 'I just couldn't do it,' he said. 'All I could remember was the horror of that experience and I just could not walk across that bridge.'

Very few survivors have ever managed to forgive, let alone forget. But unless a lasting tribute is built, the memory of what Britain's soldiers sacrificed could die with them.

fields.headline: Shearer injury scare
fields.trailText: England skipper Alan Shearer handed coach Kevin Keegan a knee injury scare after leaving the action as a precaution in the second half.
fields.body:
England skipper Alan Shearer handed coach Kevin Keegan a knee injury scare after leaving the action as a precaution in the second half.

Afterwards Shearer was careful with his words as he explained why he came off after falling awkwardly.

'I came off as a precaution,' he said. 'It's not too bad and we have a couple of days off - so that helps. It was a tough game and we knew that they would make it tough. Conditions made it difficult because it was hot out there.'

Coach Kevin Keegan said: 'People will say we won't win Euro 2000 playing like that and they'd be right. Perhaps it's good to get a display like that out of the way.'

webTitle: Bullied army recruits  being forced to desert

fields.headline: Bullied army recruits  being forced to desert
fields.standfirst: Beaten and humiliated young soldiers face a stark choice: suffer in silence or seek compensation in the courts.  Jason Burke  reports
fields.trailText: Beaten and humiliated young soldiers face a stark choice: suffer in silence or seek compensation in the courts.
fields.body:
He waS perfect army material. Stuart William Newton was straight out of school, with a good family background, fit and keen and proud to be posted to one of the British Army's finest and most historic regiments.

But last week a court martial heard how brutality and violence had turned a perfect recruit into a hunted man wanted for desertion.

The transcript of the court- martial proceedings - a public document - reveals how the young rifleman from the King's Regiment went Awol after being humiliated in a twisted initiation rite and to escape a campaign of systematic bullying.

Soon after arriving at the regiment, Newton and his unit were sent to Cyprus. One night at 2am the 17-year-old was awakened by violent banging on his door. Though he was nervous of initiation rites, he unlocked it carefully - only to be be grabbed by a group of older soldiers and dragged into another room.

There, with two other new recruits, he was forced to strip and sing the company song with a crowd of soldiers jeering at his genitals. When he stumbled over the words he was forced to run naked around the barrack block.

Far worse was to come. Over the next months his superiors in the unit subjected him to vicious bullying. The slightest infraction of orders - a less than perfectly cleaned room for example - resulted in punches to the head.

On occasions Newton was made to stand with his eyes shut while a non-commissioned officer hit him with a clenched fist. When he was threatened with violence after discovering a money- lending ring among his fellow soldiers - with 100 per cent interest enforced by beatings by NCOs - Newton decided that he had to go Awol.

His army dream in tatters, he became another statistic in the army legal services' log. The Army's Special Investigation Branch (SIB) has now launched an investigation. Lawyers for Newton refused to speak to The Observer .

Newton's case is by no means isolated. Though the Army has made strenuous efforts to tackle bullying, the problem still persists.Legal sources say that the SIB is now running more than 30 inquiries into bullying and initiation rights in the Army.

Robert Peterson, a solicitor specialising in personal injury claims by serving and former personnel, says that his firm alone has 60 complaints under way. Though almost all experts say that bullying is less prevalent now than it was a decade ago, it is still widespread.

In the last three years Peterson and other solicitors have been involved in cases including allegations of:

 Women soldiers made to parade in T-shirts soaked in water by male superiors;

 A recruit allegedly tied to a cannon, stripped and then whipped with belts by NCOs;

 Recruits being tied to beds or trees and urinated on;

 Recruits being forced to undergo the 'regimental bath' - dunking in a tub filled with urine, vomit and sometimes faeces;

 Recruits being beaten so badly they need hospital treatment;

 Mock executions of servicemen;

 A recruit beaten and threatened with being drowned in the sea.

Certain forms of intitiation rite seem to be repeated. Many involve recruits being forcibly stripped. Often they have homoerotic overtones. Many of the complaints involve servicemen having their genitals or anus handled.

Most of the rites and the bullying seem restricted to the junior ranks of infantry regiments but are not unknown in elite regiments, according to legal sources.

With dozens of compensation claims to be decided by the High Court in the coming months, the Army faces a bill that could total several million pounds - but the impact will be more than financial.

The Army is undertaking a massive recruitment drive and is committed to eradicating its image as racist, homophobic and full of bullying corporals. Every high-profile case makes changing that image harder.

It is all a far cry from the vision of Geoff Hoon, the Defence Secretary. He has spoken of his desire for an up-to-date army offering an up-to-date career. Though many enlightened senior officers are trying to steer the Army in new directions, the military culture is proving resistant to change.

Although the haemorrhaging of staff has largely been staunched in the last six months, the Army is still des perately short of men. Net recruitment is running at only 15 men each month and the 3,000 extra soldiers granted in the most recent Strategic Defence Review have yet to be found, and overall the Army is at least 7,000 under strength.

An analysis of scores of courts-martial records reveals serious structural problems within the armed forces. Though many soldiers go absent to escape bullying, most unauthorised absences and desertions are caused by family problems.

Soldiers are often serving a long way from their homes when a domestic crisis breaks and, senior officers admit, the Army is still poor at dealing with such situations.

The courts-martial records - around 150 servicemen are court-martialled for absenteeism each year - are full of cases such as the infantry private prosecuted for going Awol to try to repair his relationship with his wife after tours of duty in Germany and Northern Ireland. His solicitor told the court that his client was "fully aware of the seriousness of the offence but felt he had no option but to save his marriage".

Another soldier - a private in the 1st Battalion, The Cheshire Regiment - went Awol for nearly a year after his girlfriend told him to choose between the Army and her. A gunner in the 39th Royal Artillery Regiment disappeared after his girlfriend miscarried.

Other soldiers - including experienced and motivated men - say they went Awol after being denied permission to take time off after finding that their parents or even spouses had fatal illnesses. Once absent, many men stay away from their units for fear of the punishment they will almost certainly receive.

The Observer survey also reveals that many cases of absenteeism are provoked by lack of job satisfaction. Recruits who hope to be mechanics end up as gunners, in one case, or serving in infantry regiments. Despite training and 'life skills' being a major plank of army recruitment pitches, it is still often hard to establish any control over one's career as a junior soldier. After their attempts to transfer fail some run away.

Senior military officers last week said that they were aware of both problems and a number of measures were being planned to improve welfare services on offer to servicemen.

In a bid to ease the pressure on servicemen's relationships, the Government recently announced a bonus to be paid to soldiers with families who are separated from them for long periods.

Many of the traditional barriers are starting to be broken down: there are now women artillery gunners and helicopter pilots and the number of ethnic minority troops is creeping up.

The Government has also launched a series of measures to encourage recruitment. The ban on homosexuals has been lifted, there have been recruiting drives in young offenders' institutions and last week The Observer revealed that women were to be tested for combat roles for the first time.

The Government, it seems, is prepared to countenance radical steps to tackle the problem. The question is whether they will be enough.

Some time in the coming weeks the Royal Marines will follow The Parachute Regiment and pull out of the fetid Lungi airport and leave Sierra Leone to its dismal future.

Their safe return - so far no British servicemen have been killed or injured - will be welcomed by more than just their friends and family. Recruitment officers throughout the country will breathe a sigh of relief. For the days when the prospect of a glorious death on the battlefield thrilled the nation's youth are long since gone.

Experts all agree that any army reflects the society that produces it.

'In Vietnam the discipline of the American Army fell apart as a result of race and drugs - both societal issues,' said Professor John A. Jackson, a sociologist specialising in the military at Trinity College, Dublin. 'That provoked a huge change in the American Army and the British Army is going through the same thing.'

The Army would have to adjust to a 'less deferential, less hierarchical, less patriarchal' society to attract young people.

'The old structures imposing discipline are breaking down and that poses great difficulties for an organisation that relies on unthinking and unquestioning obedience to orders.'

Others point to the quality of life enjoyed by modern teenagers. 'They are used to having their own rooms at home, to going out, to taking drugs, to having girlfriends,' said Eric Joyce, a former major in the Adjutant-General's Corps whose campaign to highlight the problems of the Army and subsequent dismissal became a cause célèbre .

'As soldiers they live four to a room in poor accomodation miles from home - and miles from any girls who'll look at them. Neither the pay nor the lifestyle are really good enough to compensate for what they have to give up.

'Few soldiers want to be doing what they do. They leave as soon as they can,' Joyce said.

Stories of recruits having to do their initial training in trainers because their feet are too soft to cope with army combat boots reinforce the image of a soft nation increasingly ill at ease with the hard facts of traditional military service. The revelation of high-profile cases of bullying and racist or sexist harrassment do the Army's campaign to change its image a great deal of harm.

The new commanding officer of the Household Division - which includes the Guards regiments, the Life Guards and the Blues and Royals - has made a point of implementing a zero-tolerance policy towards bullying among his troops.

Jackson says that peace-keeping may provide one possible model for the future of the Army. 'It would involve emphasising different skills,' he said. 'Tolerance, problem-solving, compassion, flexibility and imagination as well as the use of force. It would be an army that is far closer to our modern, pluralistic society.'

But such a change will take time. And it will come too late for Stuart William Newton. He was found not guilty because he was under duress - but his hopes of a life as a soldier are gone.

Rocked by scandal

fields.headline: 'We know we must change'
fields.standfirst: Senior officer  Sebastian Roberts  says the Army is now putting right its mistakes
fields.trailText: Senior officer  Sebastian Roberts  says the Army is now putting right its mistakes
fields.body:
Field Marshal Lord Kitchener pointed at our ancestors, proclaiming imperiously 'Your Country Needs You', and millions joined up. Even without conscription, war is a great recruiter: the strongest recruiting in recent years followed the Falklands War. The Army always has to work hard to sustain full manning in peacetime.

Whatever the Army's size, the last 10 per cent seems always to be a challenge. The detailed reasons change over the years, but for an all-volunteer, professional Army the underlying problem will always be to persuade enough people that the rewards are worth the sacrifices: the risk of death on operations; the subordination of self to the team and the mission; and the awful responsibility of the legal right and duty to fight and if necessary kill according to one's orders.

This is relatively easy when people believe that the reward is the survival of their society, but much harder when there is no obvious threat. From the end of the Cold War the problem has not been just the lack of a threat, and the solution is not just a matter of good advertising.

Success on operations, demonstrably being a force for good in the world, are absolutely vital, but despite continuous operational success - the Gulf war, Bosnia, and a growing variety of peacekeeping operations - through the Nineties the Army was not recruiting or retaining enough soldiers. This caused us to examine closely the image we present and how close we are to society and people's aspirations and expectations.

This has led to many high-profile initiatives: stamping out sexism, racism, bullying and initiation rites have all been the subjects of action by the Army's highest commanders. While none of these ills were endemic, let alone epidemic, they were sufficiently widespread to demand a robust approach which is widely regarded as effective and exemplary.

Maintaining the improvement depends on keeping up this programme of change, not quick fixes or good advertising. The Army's greatest asset continues to be operational success. Kosovo, East Timor and Sierra Leone are successes of which all soldiers - and potential recruits - are justly proud.

But we also recognise the need to address the aspirations of our soldiers and their families if we are to retain them. If they are to invest their lives, the Army - and the nation - must make it worthwhile. Full manning is never easy in peacetime - but peace in places like Sierra Leone depends on us achieving it: and with the nation's support we will.

 Brigadier Sebastian Roberts of the Irish Guards, director corporate communications (Army), has been a soldier for 24 years ,serving in Zimbabwe, Belize, The Falklands, Northern Ireland and the Balkans

webTitle: UK firms deal in war gems

fields.headline: UK firms deal in war gems
fields.standfirst: Jewellers eager to buy Sierra Leone diamonds
fields.trailText: British diamond dealers are secretly trading gems from rebel-held areas of Sierra Leone, helping to fuel the civil war in the west African state and putting British soldiers at risk.
fields.byline: Jason Burke, Nick Paton Walsh and Brian Johnson-Thomas
fields.body:
British diamond dealers are secretly trading gems from rebel-held areas of Sierra Leone, helping to fuel the civil war in the west African state and putting British soldiers at risk.

An Observer investigation has found that dealers in London's Hatton Garden jewellery quarter are eager to buy gems dug up by rebels to help fund their battle for control of Sierra Leone's diamond fields. Tens of thousands of people have been killed in the fighting.

Our reporter brought gems back into Britain after travelling to the rebel stronghold of Kenema, 200 miles south of Freetown, the capital of Sierra Leone.

He found eager buyers in London, despite the fact that it is the policy of the London Diamond Bourse - a self-regulating body for the capital's diamond trade - to expel any of its members that are caught dealing in gems from conflict areas.

Posing as a United Nations worker newly returned from the area, our reporter contacted several dealers in Hatton Garden. All conversations were secretly recorded.

No guarantees were offered that the gems were not smuggled in breach of British Customs law or UN regulations. Some dealers said they had dealt in so-called conflict diamonds - those from African war zones - in the past and would be happy to do so again.

Our reporter said he could set up a regular supply of 'rough', or uncut, diamonds. Dealers in London, Antwerp and other major dealing centres buy up rough diamonds to finish and sell on to retail jewellers.

Gerald Landon, of DB Gem Setters in Hatton Garden, was offered 200 one-carat rough diamonds which, it was made clear, came from Sierra Leone. Our reporter said he was looking to make a profit of up to £50,000 and could guarantee a regular supply of diamonds from the troubled west African state.

'If the material is good enough, we pay the sort of price that would be hopefully acceptable by your side and everybody can earn some sort of living out of [it],' Landon said. In a subsequent conversation he said he had dealt 'indirectly' in gems from Sierra Leone before. 'There have been goods from that part of the area... it's come from that neck of the woods.'

At Holts dealers in Hatton Garden, the director agreed to view a future consignment of gems our reporter said would be available when he next returned from the west African state.

'That is our business... We deal with a whole range of stones cut and uncut,' the director said.

Nick Gray of NW Associates expressed concern about the gems' origin but said that 'on a very small scale' he would be interested.

'It's a tricky business. It just is. There's been a lot of controversy over the sourcing of diamonds... One's always a bit nervous, et cetera,' he said. He expressed an interest in seeing a small sample and discussed the possibility of a regular supply.

British diamond dealers are coming under increasing pressure to establish more stringent controls on the trade. In Antwerp, the world's largest and oldest diamond-dealing centre, strict documentation setting out the provenance of all gems is required. Although the system has flaws - last month The Observer revealed that a black market in gems from conflict zones is still flourishing - it has made the sale of conflict diamonds far harder.

Buyers, such as the gem giant De Beers, have said they will shun stones from war zones. Diamonds are at the root of the conflict in Sierra Leone. The latest fighting, which forced the intervention of British troops, was sparked when UN peacekeepers tried to enter the diamond-producing areas that provide the bulk of rebel forces' funding.

It is not against the law to buy or sell diamonds from Sierra Leone. A gem can be traded legitimately, provided that it has a Customs document to prove its lawful entry into the country.

Frederick Hager, president of the London Diamond Bourse, said: 'If a member was known to be dealing in conflict diamonds, he would cease to be a member. There was a move in [the US] Congress to make every diamond worth more than £60 carry a certificate of origin, but that's totally impossible. Anyone who knows anything about diamonds will tell you that it's childish to suggest.'

At present, only Angolan diamonds are under UN sanctions. But campaigners are to step up the pressure on the government and regulatory authorities. 'Diamonds are a warlord's best friend,' said one. 'If we are serious about ending Africa's suffering then the British Government has to get a grip with the diamond trade and that has to start at home.'

Last night Customs and Excise officers said that they would investigate the findings of The Observer .

fields.headline: Irish drug baron shot dead
fields.trailText: Derek Dunne, one of Ireland's biggest heroin traffickers, has been shot dead in Holland.
fields.body:
Derek Dunne, one of Ireland's biggest heroin traffickers, has been shot dead in Holland.

The body of the 33-year-old from north Dublin was discovered outside his apartment in the town of Singerstrat, near Amsterdam, yesterday. A second man, an ex- soldier from Dublin, was found critically injured in the apartment, while a third was found in handcuffs.

Dutch police say several people were seen leaving the scene in a car, later found burnt out. The shooting is reportedly linked to a row among rival gangs. Dunne left Ireland four years ago after a fall-out with rival criminals. The man shot in his apartment is an associate of John Gilligan, the Dublin criminal charged in connection with the murder of journalist Veronica Guerin. The man shot in Dunne's apartment is wanted for questioning about her murder.

Last month three young Irishmen were tortured and mutilated before being shot dead in a flat at Scheveningen outside The Hague.

That murder was linked to another major Dublin heroin lord who had lost two major shipments of drugs and guns the previous year.

fields.headline: England in a Wright spot
fields.standfirst:
Malta 1
Wright 29og
England 2
Keown 23, Heskey 75
att: 10,023
fields.trailText: Déjà vu for debut keeper as Keegan's men struggle to victory in final warm-up for Euro 2000.
fields.byline: Paul Wilson at the Ta' Qali Stadium, Valetta
fields.body:
As pointers to Euro 2000 form go, this was about as unconvincing as England can get, though in fairness Kevin Keegan's men were up against two Malta teams.

The home side named 22 players for this game and used the lot, with substitutes coming and going with bewildering rapidity. England duly looked bewildered, and were grateful for two saves by debutant goalkeeper Richard Wright late in the game to prevent the ignominy of being held by Malta for the first time.

Wright was hardly a hero, however, since he was principally responsible for keeping Malta in the game. Six days ago Wright helped Ipswich into the Premiership and there were uncanny similarities yesterday. He faced two penalties, both of which he gave away (he was responsible for one at Wembley); he failed to save one (but was rescued yesterday by the referee ordering it to be retaken); saved another (only for that to become an own goal, just as unlucky as his donation to Barnsley).

'If we play like that in Euro 2000 we'll be on the first plane home,' said Keegan, who is so aware that this sort of game offers only a hiding to nothing that he intends playing only top-line opponents in future.

This was a truly dreadful England performance, though no one seriously imagines his side will play like this against Portugal in eight days' time.

'I don't think it's fair to judge us on games like this, judge us on what we do at the tournament,' said Alan Shearer, who is once again going into a competition with questions over his form and value to the side. Everyone knows what happened in Euro 96, but Shearer was part of a highly effective partnership with Teddy Sheringham then. There is no evidence of anything so productive this time. Until Emile Heskey took over from Shearer the England attack was blunt, with their only goal coming from a defender.

Martin Keown had a goal disallowed in the 11th minute but he was uncomfortable in a back four that was never allowed to settle. Carmel Busuttil and Gilbert Agius proved quicker on the turn than Keown and Sol Campbell on several occasions.

None of this seemed likely to matter once England took the lead after 23 minutes, when a David Beckham free-kick found Keown unmarked for a far-post header, though somewhat comically Malta were back on level terms within six minutes. Barmby missed a chance to put England comfortably ahead when he headed straight at Ernest Barry, and regretted it almost immediately when Malta broke out of defence. David Carabott reacted quicker than the England defence to Noel Turner's long ball through the middle, but though Wright was left exposed, he showed his inexperience in rushing from his line and colliding with the Maltese striker. The referee delighted the locals by pointing to the spot, then incensed them once Carabott had scored by demanding the penalty be retaken. Carabott went the same way the second time but this time struck Wright's right-hand upright, only for the ball to rebound into goal off the hapless goalkeeper.

Shearer was substituted five minutes into the second half, by which stage England could easily have been a goal down. Turner looked suspiciously offside in the 46th minute, but the flag stayed down and he really should have scored, or at least tested Wright, instead of giving Gary Neville time to make a vital block.

Though at no time could either Heskey or England be described as impressive, his arrival brought a more defined attacking edge. Paul Scholes flashed a near-post shot wide from Heskey's cross, then the substitute himself got on the end of a Barmby cross from the left only to miss with a tame header when scoring looked easier. Goals are not really Heskey's forte, though it was the Liverpool player who provided the winner 15 minutes from the end, finishing from five yards out with Barmby once again the provider.

Heskey's first international goal should have spared England's blushes, though there were more of those for Wright two minutes before the end. Once again England were caught square to a through-ball, and this time Wright was hesitant, coming out later rather than sooner and clearly bringing down Nenad Veselji. He redeemed himself by not only saving Carabott's penalty but throwing himself at a second effort by Veselji moments later.

Debutants and goalkeepers usually prefer quiet lives, and Wright will have been relieved to hear the final whistle. He might not see much action in Holland and Belgium, but David James probably feels like buying him a drink.
