webTitle: The shame of our asylum shambles

fields.headline: The shame of our asylum shambles
fields.standfirst: Politicians must accept responsibility
fields.trailText: Tomorrow The Observer will welcome Jack Straw and Ann Widdecombe to a debate on asylum we are sponsoring. Although it would be presumptuous to guess what our guests will say, we feel certain that the politicians who are so keen to tell others that they cannot enjoy rights without responsibilities will not accept their share of responsibility for a brutal social crisis.
fields.body:
Tomorrow The Observer will welcome Jack Straw and Ann Widdecombe to a debate on asylum we are sponsoring. Although it would be presumptuous to guess what our guests will say, we feel certain that the politicians who are so keen to tell others that they cannot enjoy rights without responsibilities will not accept their share of responsibility for a brutal social crisis.

Since the fall of the Berlin Wall opened the Eurasian land mass, all European countries have had more refugees asking for sanctuary. Inevitably, there have been strains. Britain stands out because of the failure of an incompetent Home Office to deal honestly and efficiently with desperate people. For years there has been a virtually unreported Whitehall farce in which, at enormous expense to the taxpayer, the Civil Service failed to install the computer system to handle asylum claims. The result is a backlog of 100,000 applications. The Child Support Agency fiasco became a national scandal. But then divorced fathers have votes and buy papers. Asylum-seekers are often frightened foreigners with few friends and are the target of choice for a right-wing and occasionally far-right-wing press. It was politically convenient as well as populist for Straw and Widdecombe to go along with this diversion from the inability of Labour and Conservative Ministers to show the most elementary bureaucratic competence.

It is now impossible for any refugee, however genuine, to arrive in Britain without false papers - mendacious protestations of politicians that 'we have nothing against authentic asylum-seekers' notwithstanding. Those who are already here have been pushed into poverty to justify the unproven assertion that it is generous benefits rather than fear that drives the third to a half of asylum seekers who are found to be genuine to Britain. The results are all around us. Last week we reported on the unbelievably squalid conditions in which refugees are being forced to live in Liverpool. A few days later, the Audit Commission warned that the system of ordering asylum seekers out of London was close to collapse. Today we bring you news of Graham King, an Essex wheeler and dealer with no experience of helping the victims of torture, who will make millions from asylum-seekers living on £35 a week.

We hope our debate will be intelligent and courteous. If it is, it will make a refreshing change from the combination of buck-passing, victim-blaming and playing of the race card which has characterised the asylum debate until now.

fields.headline: Corelli revisited
fields.standfirst: The truth is fine, but it may be dull
fields.trailText: Not only does Louis de Bernières know how to write a bestselling novel, he has an appealing grasp of diplomacy. As Captain Corelli's Mandolin starts filming in Greece, de Bernières has confessed that for the Greek edition of the book he revised his earlier negative assessment of the wartime communist resistance.
fields.body:
Not only does Louis de Bernières know how to write a bestselling novel, he has an appealing grasp of diplomacy. As Captain Corelli's Mandolin starts filming in Greece, de Bernières has confessed that for the Greek edition of the book he revised his earlier negative assessment of the wartime communist resistance. 'It became clear to me that many people were genuinely offended by my portrayal... whereas the communists massacred entire villages in some places, I understand that in others they set up drama classes,' he said .

Whatever next? Kingsley Amis's reputation might have been improved had he listened to feminists and revised Stanley and the Women, his misogynist tale of an advertising executive surrounded by mad, carping or stupid women. And Jane Austen may have been less enthusiastic about the Navy, notably in Persuasion, had she considered the feelings of the victims of the keelhaulings meted out by her heroes. Corelli's willingness to let the truth get in the way of a good story is certainly as admirable as it is unusual. But trying to please everyone can lead only to some very dull books.

webTitle: Secret burial of granny is thwarted

fields.headline: Secret burial of granny is thwarted
fields.standfirst: British relatives launch legal action to stop funeral of 95-year-old taken to US
fields.trailText: The case of the 95-year-old great-grandmother flown across the Atlantic took a macabre turn yesterday when her family learnt her body had been secretly returned to Britain for a private burial.
fields.body:
The case of the 95-year-old great-grandmother flown across the Atlantic took a macabre turn yesterday when her family learnt her body had been secretly returned to Britain for a private burial.

The British family of Johannah Gayle, who was taken to the US against their wishes by American relatives, was yesterday told by police that her body had been flown back to Gatwick Airport. She was to be buried in Margate, Kent, after a church service in nearby Maidstone. Only the US relatives and Gayle's friends were to attend.

Gayle, who has 19 grandchildren and 15 great-grandchildren, was dying of cancer of the bladder when she was taken to Williamsburg, Virginia, by her daughter, Kathleen Lawrence, 65. She died last Sunday - and her British family was only informed of the death by a distant cousin.

Her son Tony Gayle, 57, said yesterday: 'I find this appalling. First they take her to the States without telling us, and now they arrange for a funeral that we're not informed of.'

Three weeks ago Mrs Lawrence and her children drove the elderly woman to Heathrow, where they tried to catch a flight to Washington. After presenting airport police with documents claiming to hold power of attorney over her, the party was dissuaded from boarding. But they later reached the US by a route as yet undetermined by the Foreign Office.

Yesterday Gayle's daughter, Paulina Stockell, 59, who lives in Sutton Valence, Kent, said: 'The whole thing seems ludicrous - it's caused us untold grief. What did they think they were doing, smuggling her back here without letting us know?'

Money can hardly be behind the Americans' action. Gayle managed on a state pension, and owned only her modest two-bedroom cottage.

The transatlantic crossing prompted the Maidstone MP Ann Widdecombe to ask Interpol to help trace Gayle.

Mrs Lawrence and her children, daughter Robin and her son Peter, arrived at the elderly woman's home in early April for an annual visit. 'We had told them she had cancer, so perhaps they thought this was their last chance to see her,' Mrs Stockell said. 'But immediately they started to overwhelm the situation. They were all armed with information on cancer downloaded from the internet. 'Peter would storm around saying, "God damn! The Americans haven't used radiotherapy since the Seventies." He just seemed to have this immense battery of literature on cancer.'

The trio installed themselves in Gayle's home. Often both the grandchildren would sleep in her bed. Visitors were barred, doctor's appointments cancelled, even the home help was discouraged from entering. 'I always thought I was close to my sister Kathleen,' Mrs Stockell said. 'We were emotionally close - I would call her in the US almost every night. So this kind of behaviour by her and her children seemed completely irrational. Was it jealousy - did they envy my relationship with my mother?'

Three weeks ago Mrs Stockell's husband witnessed the Americans carrying Gayle into a car. They told him they were taking her to Hastings for the day. 'I was immediately suspicious, my mother couldn't possible travel,' Mrs Stockell said.

She alerted Heathrow police and Special Branch, who detained the party at check-in. Meanwhile Tony Gayle raced down from Oxford to confront them. 'As Tony and the police turned their back, they got away - raced to another part of the airport,' Mrs Stockell said.

Both Mr Gayle and Ms Stockell have taken legal action to block the funeral, intending to bury their mother near her home in Sutton Valence. The body is now with a coroner.

'Not content with taking her without our consent, they've now silently returned her,' Mr Gayle said yesterday. 'Did they expect us not to find out? Did they think we'd just forget about our mother?'

fields.headline: No new arms race
fields.standfirst: The US missile policy is wrong
fields.trailText: Britain has for so long defined its defence and security interests as coterminous with those of the US that the habit of following Washington has become ingrained. However, the US's proposed National Missile Defence System threatens to change the equation.
fields.body:
Britain has for so long defined its defence and security interests as coterminous with those of the US that the habit of following Washington has become ingrained. However, the US's proposed National Missile Defence System threatens to change the equation. If a last test is successful this July, a consensus is growing in the US that it should establish a $50 billion system of satellite radar and interceptor sites that will destroy incoming missiles from so-called rogue states like North Korea. But such a system breaches the 1972 anti-ballistic missile treaty under which Russia and the US agreed not to build a comprehensive defence against the other as a guarantee against a first strike. America may make itself partially safe, but would expose the rest of the world to a new arms race.

In Moscow today, President Clinton will try to persuade President Putin to allow the US plan to go forward, with Putin countering that Russia would like to be behind the new shield. No less seriously, Putin has persuaded the Duma to halve Russia's nuclear warheads under Start II and halve them again under Start III. All this will be put in peril by the US plan.

Technologically, the US proposals do not offer the US the security it craves. They have been driven by a combination of Republicans and the military/industrial lobby. Germany and France have spoken out, but the Blair Government reserves its position. It hopes the test will be unconclusive, and the whole issue will be dropped.

It is an ignoble strategy. Britain's position is pivotal; if we came out against, opponents in Washington will have their hand strengthened - and the whole proposal would be more difficult. We should assert our sovereignty. Be certain that we will not, and that Britain's Eurosceptics will be as supine over this as they are shrill over the imagined encroachments of the EU over matters much less fundamental.

fields.headline: News in Brief
fields.trailText: An eight-year-old boy from Greater Manchester died after trapping his neck in his grandmother's electrically powered reclining chair. Firefighters had to use cutting equipment to dismantle the chair.
fields.body:
Boy, eight, dies as neck is trapped in granny's chair

An eight-year-old boy from Greater Manchester died after trapping his neck in his grandmother's electrically powered reclining chair. Firefighters had to use cutting equipment to dismantle the chair.

Two rescued in yacht race

A man and a woman were rescued by coastguards after falling overboard from their yachts amid force 5-6 easterly winds during a race sponsored by the police in the Firth of Clyde off Inverkip.

Teenage ride to tragedy

A 16-year-old girl died and four other teenagers, all from Stourbridge in the West Midlands, were injured when their car left a narrow road and rolled down a hill, near Llanbedr in North Wales.

Boy drives classic bargain

Joseph Myers, aged nine, from Burton, Hants, bought a blue 1934 Standard 10 for £1,400 after saving his pocket money for five years. He and his father plan to restore it.

Pet paradise

The first hotel for exotic pets whose owners are on holiday has opened at Farnsfield, Notts. It charges £1.50 a day for tarantula spiders, snakes and other creatures.

Reeling in a fortune

A pair of rare Hardy White-Wickham fishing reels which cost £37 when made in 1929 were sold for £43,000 at auction by Phillips, London.

Brighton buffs

Campaigners seeking the right to wear no clothes in public are to march through Brighton this afternoon. The demonstration by the Freedom to Be Yourself Group coincides with World Naturist Day.

Former fire chief faces rape and assault charges

An ex-senior fire officer has been charged with two rapes and three indecent assaults. George Heyes, 44, of Bamburgh Close, Radcliffe, Manchester, will appear before Rochdale magistrates on Monday.

Hawk swoops at air fair

One of the world's most secret military aircraft, the F-117A Nighthawk Stealth fighter, performed a 10-minute display at the Biggin Hill International Air Fair.

Warren seeks costs over Tyson

Frank Warren, promoter of boxer Mike Tyson's coming fight in Scotland, plans to seek recovery of his court costs from a rape charity which unsuccessfully challenged Home Secretary Jack Straw's decision to allow the fighter into Britain.

fields.headline: De Bernières on the resistance
fields.trailText: After the writing of Corelli it became clear to me that many people were genuinely offended by my portrayal of the communist resistance, or simply thought that it was inaccurate. I haven't actually changed my mind about what I think is the truth, but I had to bear in mind the possibility that I might be wrong.
fields.body:
After the writing of Corelli it became clear to me that many people were genuinely offended by my portrayal of the communist resistance, or simply thought that it was inaccurate. I haven't actually changed my mind about what I think is the truth, but I had to bear in mind the possibility that I might be wrong.

The story of the resistance is extremely complex, and whereas the communists massacred entire villages in some places, I understand that in others they set up drama classes... so one's interpretation will depend entirely upon which part of Greece one is talking about.

In Greece these issues are still very much alive, and there is still much vehement hatred bubbling away just beneath the surface. Whereas my opinion about all this doesn't matter too much outside Greece, it matters very much within it, and it was never part of the purpose of Corelli to stir up bad blood. Corelli is about other themes, and I wouldn't want the book to be distorted for Greek readers, which is why I agreed with my publishers and translator that some of my language and opinions should be moderated. The Greeks don't need some foreigner sticking his oar in when they can, and do, perfectly well argue among themselves.

I would like to add that whereas, in my opinion, the behaviour of the communist resistance left much to be desired, the persecution of communists after the war was an absolute disgrace and gave them back any moral high ground they might have lost. fields.headline: Laser surgery may ruin eyes
fields.trailText: A top doctor has warned that up to a million people are at risk of disintegrating eyeballs after 'miracle' laser surgery for short sight. Richard Branson and Friends star Courtney Cox are among those who have had this increasingly popular treatment for vision defects.
fields.body:
A top doctor has warned that up to a million people are at risk of disintegrating eyeballs after 'miracle' laser surgery for short sight. Richard Branson and Friends star Courtney Cox are among those who have had this increasingly popular treatment for vision defects.

John Marshall, professor of ophthalmology at St Thomas's Hospital and the UK's top expert on the Lasik technique, said there is growing evidence of long-term damage. He believes it can lead to the cornea being so eroded that it starts bulging, and that parts of the cornea may even become dislodged.

The operation enables those with defects to manage without contact lenses or spectacles. However, according to Marshall, they could end up needing their entire cornea transplanted.

'There have been a number of reports of erosion of tissue, with people having to have their corneas transplanted,' said Marshall, who would not risk the technique himself. He is to publish his warning in a science journal.

Use of Lasik has exploded in recent years after heavy promotion by private eye clinics who offer it as a painless, instant cure for short sightedness. Commercial pressures saw the technique rapidly authorised in the US, though almost nothing is known of its long-term effects.

More than a million Americans have had the operation. Britain's largest private eye surgery group Optimax has performed it 3,000 times in the last 18 months.

'We are very concerned about the massive numbers of people taking Lasik with no follow-up,' said Marshall. The technique, which costs £750 per eye, and is not available on the NHS, takes minutes, is virtually pain-free, and leads to an immediate improvement in eye sight. It uses an expensive computer-controlled machine, which carves out the eye with a laser. When Branson had it done he was back at work the next day.

The old technique - called PRK - caused considerable pain; eyesight remained blurred for weeks. But that technique, tested for 10 years before being authorised, has been proved by countless studies to be safe in the long term.

Lasik involves cutting through the 'fibrils' that hold the cornea together, which never regrow. It also involves scraping off a third or more off the thickness of the cornea. 'If someone cut through a third of the radial wires on your car tyre and replaced them with rubber solution, would you drive on that?' said Marshall. 'There is a possibility that a blow to the eye could dislodge a flap of the cornea. If you got punched in the eye or were playing rugby, who would know what could happen?'.

Even though the technique is brand new, Marshall has so found three cases where patients had to have cornea transplants because they disintegrated after the operation. Patients are rarely warned about the risks. When The Observer phoned Optimax posing as a patient, a consultant said: 'All the research shows it's a safe treatment, a proven treatment.'

Dr Manek Patel, of Optimax, who does Lasik operations, said: 'I can't see any danger. Throughout the world, people are switching to this operation because it is quick, relatively painless and has reliable results.' He predicted that by 2005, Britain would match the US, where 90 per cent of such eye surgery is Lasik.

However, he admitted: 'Nobody knows what the effects after 10 years are. But how would patients wait 10 years for it? Are we supposed to do 10 patients and wait 10 years? Science doesn't work like that.'

Armies around the world have used such surgery to improve the sight of key personnel. But the Australian army has not used Lasik, concerned that soldiers' eyes might be damaged.

David Gartry, a consultant eye surgeon at Moorfields Hospital, who helped draw up the Lasik guidelines for the Royal College of Ophthalmologists, said: 'If you stick to the guidelines there shouldn't be a problem.' However, he confessed: 'No one can say with certainty that 50 years from now, there will not be some sort of problem.'

He also said it was 'almost certain' that surgeons in Britain were going beyond guidelines, taking away between a half and two-thirds of the cornea in patients with extreme short sight. 'That's totally unwarranted. If it's thin, like a balloon, the pressure from behind will make the cornea bulge out and distort the image' he said. 'It's not using it the way it is meant to be used.'

webTitle: America's most wanted: armed, dangerous and living in London

fields.headline: America's most wanted: armed, dangerous and living in London
fields.standfirst: Where did New York's hardest Yardie gangsters run to when police wrecked their empires? The UK's criminal underworld knows the answer...
fields.trailText: One belongs to a gang of notorious mass murderers. Another rapes and sodomises the children of people who owe him money. A third has shot, stabbed and tortured his way to the top of the criminal underworld. These, the world's most violent Yardie gangsters, are believed to be hiding in London.
fields.body:
One belongs to a gang of notorious mass murderers. Another rapes and sodomises the children of people who owe him money. A third has shot, stabbed and tortured his way to the top of the criminal underworld. These, the world's most violent Yardie gangsters, are believed to be hiding in London.

Charles Brackett, Mervin Benjamin and Maxwell Bogel are all fugitives from the FBI and are said to have made several visits to the UK as part of their bid to evade capture. The trio are native Jamaicans, but until recently were based in New York.

Bogel made his name as an enforcer with a vicious gang known as the Shower Posse - because they showered victims with bullets from Uzi sub-machineguns. Since 1996 his role has been to collect debts from those who owe the gang for drugs.

To do this, he broke into their homes, kidnapped their children and brutalised them repeatedly until the gang was paid. His victims were often tied up for 30 hours at a time. One, a 12-year-old girl, also endured rape and sodomy.

Last year Bogel, who has a string of previous convictions, was tried and convicted in absentia of attempted murder, kidnapping, rape, sodomy, robbery and possession of firearms. He received a sentence of 68 years.

Now the man described by US marshals as 'armed, extremely dangerous and one of the most sought after criminals in the United States,' is believed to be here. Sources in the London's Yardie underworld say a man fitting Bogel's description has been seen in London several times in the past year.

Deported from the US, Bogel is believed to have come to Britain in a bid to re-enter America indirectly.

Charles Brackett, Mervin Benjamin and Fabian O'Neal Littlejohn are also believed to be moving in and out of London on false papers. They are all key members of the Poison Clan, responsible for 30 murders and the sale of millions of pounds worth of crack, heroin and guns.

The gang's name comes from a cult martial arts movie and refers to its members' willingness to kill their own as well as others. Poison Clan was founded by Devon 'Chubby' Beckford after killing two crack-dealing colleagues who had refused to let him branch out on his own.

Under him, the Clan quickly grew, using violence to convince other dealers to buy from the Clan and share their profits. Those who resisted were dealt with ruthlessly.

When a group of cannabis dealers from suburban Richmond refused to capitulate, Chubby told one of his footsoldiers, Jimmy Fingers (he had accidentally shot one of his fingers off) to teach them a lesson. Four clan members set off for Sugar Bottom at 4.15 that afternoon.

When police arrived at the clansmen's destination they found three bodies sprawled in the small and blood-spattered front room. Another wounded man had managed to crawl down a hallway towards the back door. The killers were nowhere to be found.

Following an extensive police and FBI operation, the gang was broken up in 1997 with 28 defendants - including Beckford, who narrowly avoided the death sentence - being brought before the courts and convicted on drugs and violence charges. Brackett, Benjamin and Littlejohn, however, are still on the run.

They are not the first wanted Yardies to make the trip across the Atlantic. Victor Francis, a leading member of the Brooklyn-based Renkers Posse, fled to Britain in the mid-Nineties after being indicted in New York on 16 charges, including murder, attempted murder, robbery, theft and drug dealing. He was eventually arrested when police found him running a crack den in Acton with his brother.

Earlier this year, 38-year-old Winston Harris, the leader of a Yardie gang called the Lock City Crew, was jailed for life for shooting dead a man at the Bridge Park leisure centre in Wembley. The shooting broke out after the wife of a member of the rival Cartel Crew drove into the centre's car park to see an event.

One of the security guards who was also a member of the Lock City Crew criticised her poor parking and told her to try again. The woman then flew into a rage, smashed a bottle and had to be escorted away by police, but she returned 20 minutes later with her Cartel Crew husband.

Lock City members saw this move as a direct attack on their territory - Bridge park was a major crew meeting place - and a hideout for their caches of drugs, guns and ammunition.

Winston and three others retrieved guns they always kept hidden in a sports bag nearby, locked the door of the leisure centre to prevent anyone leaving during their planned raid and went to track down their rival. But in the panic that followed, Harris let off a shot which killed a bystander, Dion Holmes, passing through his heart and liver.

Harris, who had served several jail terms in New York and had fled here to avoid further charges, regularly travelled between the two countries on false passports.

He was convicted of murder along with three others. Ironically a Jamaican national, Anthony Wray, another member of the LCC present that day and who Scotland Yard plan to charge with Dion Holmes's murder, is believed to be hiding abroad, probably New York.

One detective said last night: 'These fugitives should on no account be approached by members of the public.'

MAXWELL BOGEL Wanted for: kidnapping, rape, robbery, sodomy of 12-year-old girl Also known as: Max Bogle, Paul Robinson, Ike Box Date of birth: 22/1/1963 Known for: Ruthless, brutal debt collecting for vicious Shower Posse ARMED AND HIGHLY DANGEROUS

MERVIN BENJAMIN Wanted for: Multiple murders, assaults, robberies, drug-trafficking Also known as: Benji Date of birth: 10/8/1965 Known for: Flitting back and forth across the Atlantic on false papers, gun-running activities WANTED FOR MULTIPLE MUDERS

CHARLES O. BRACKETT Wanted for: gang-warfare related murder, robbery and assault Also known as: Charlie Chase Date of birth: 28/8/1964 Known for: Being one of few members of the once powerful Poison Clan who is still at large. WANTED FOR SEVERAL MURDERS

webTitle: Heaven-sent chance for a longer life

fields.headline: Heaven-sent chance for a longer life
fields.trailText: Want to live longer? Skip the gym and health food shops and go to church instead. A religious life will not only save you from eternal damnation but also extend your time on Earth and keep your weight down, according to psychologists.
fields.body:
Want to live longer? Skip the gym and health food shops and go to church instead. A religious life will not only save you from eternal damnation but also extend your time on Earth and keep your weight down, according to psychologists.

Any synagogue, mosque, monastery or temple will do - as long as you pop in regularly.

Several research projects have already pointed to a link between spirituality and lower blood pressure, less heart disease and lower rates of depression. And this week an analysis of 42 scientific studies, examining 126,000 people, will provide evidence that churchgoers are 29 per cent more likely to live to an old age.

Next month a research project will start in the UK to see if the same results hold true. Professor Mary Gilhooly, director of Paisley University's Centre for Gerontology and Health Studies, is one of the leaders of the two-year study. She said the aim of the study, the first of its kind in Britain, will be to examine how people maintain good health, including looking at links between longevity and spirituality.

One hundred of the healthiest survivors drawn from the Midspan project - in which health and death rates have been monitored among 15,000 people since 1972 - will be compared with 100 unhealthy people matched by age, gender and social class.

'It may well prove that religion is a major factor in good health,' said Gilhooly. 'People are much more religious in the United States than here, so it will be interesting to see if the results stand up in our secular society.

'It makes people nervous if they think you have to become religious or join a church if you want to live for ever,' she said. 'But religion may be preventing people from doing things which may be deemed as unhealthy, such as drinking alcohol.'

Monsignor Kieran Conry, a spokesman for the Roman Catholic Church in England, said avoidance of alcohol was not something always strictly observed among Catholics. 'I'm sceptical of the idea that this phenomenon may be down to a puritanical lifestyle. Perhaps evangelists or Methodists here may be prone to that, but anyone who has been to an Irish Catholic wedding or a clergy conference, for that matter, will know there is no hesitation in the Church towards seeing alcohol as one of God's many gifts.

'But, seriously, I think the secret is that religion encourages people to accept themselves and their failings more easily. People disposed to a religious life do, in my experience, tend to be of a fairly benevolent, balanced and open disposition.

'I know that is a huge generalisation, but a certain type of person is disposed to religion and its demands. A community-based life helps a lot in dealing with stress, and a lot of sin being discussed in the confession boxes is not perhaps sin but anger, an emotion which it helps to talk about. All healthy stuff.

'Of course, it's just like going to the gym; you have to commit yourself fully to the programme.

'One might think people would be quite keen to get into heaven - but a bit of extra time down here can help in spreading the word.'

webTitle: Dyke plans News at Ten on the BBC

fields.headline: Dyke plans News at Ten on the BBC
fields.standfirst: Director-general prepares to flout tradition and take advantage of ITN's sinking of its flagship
fields.trailText: The director-general of the BBC, Greg Dyke, is secretly squaring up to do battle with the guardians of one of the most sacred of the corporation's institutions: its Nine O'Clock News bulletin.
fields.body:
The director-general of the BBC, Greg Dyke, is secretly squaring up to do battle with the guardians of one of the most sacred of the corporation's institutions: its Nine O'Clock News bulletin.

An announcement on plans to strengthen the popular appeal of BBC1 news and to move its main programme back in the evening schedule is expected soon. It is now thought likely to form part of the speech that Dyke will give at the Edinburgh Television Festival on 25 August, although a final decision on the changes has not yet been made.

Dyke is also believed to be weighing up the benefits of moving BBC2's Newsnight back to an 11pm slot and, more controversially still, of introducing a greater commercial ethos throughout the corporation.

This week several of those working high in the management of television news have privately admitted they are confidently awaiting the birth of a longer flagship news programme to replace the Nine O'Clock News later this year.

'The news bulletin which goes out at nine may well be something of a British institution, but Greg is determined to believe that he can build his own institutions,' said one source at the top of the news division.

The move would be a belated response to ITN's decision, over a year ago, to stop running its popular News at Ten .

'There is a void at that time now,' said Michael Brunson, the former political correspondent for ITN. 'Ten o'clock is absolutely the best time for a bulletin. What is amazing is that so far neither the BBC nor Channel Four news has moved to it.'

Brunson said the later time often gave ITN an advantage over the BBC: 'It is because of the way things work in this country, not just Parliament, but the newspapers too. As a result we were often first with the next day's big stories.'

News At Ten attracted about 5.5 million viewers, a million more than recent figures for its earlier BBC rival. ITV's new Nightly News at 11pm draws an average audience of only 3.5 million people. The Newsnight audience is still considered fairly strong for a late-night, factual strand. Following its recent facelift, viewing figures were up 8 per cent to 1.1million.

Speculation about the BBC's plans to move its Nine O'Clock News back to ten - and to turn it into a longer, magazine-style programme - first surfaced two months ago, with the start of a fullscale review of the BBC's news output. The rumour was officially ruled out.

On Friday, however, a spokesman for the BBC admitted that the move has been considered as part of a review of all the corporation's news coverage. 'All sorts of discussions have gone on about news at various levels,' a spokesman told The Observer. 'All I can say is that a move of the late evening news is not going ahead at the moment.'

One admirer of Dyke told The Observer this week that, far from wanting to downgrade or sensationalise the news, the plans being discussed are designed to strengthen the editorial input of BBC journalists into the news and to make sure that it reaches larger audiences. Dyke is known to mistrust the Government's control of the daily agenda and is wary of offering the public the established diet of headlines without context.

But if he does push for an extended late news programme on BBC1, the prestige of Newsnight will certainly be damaged. 'There is no way that Newsnight could continue as it is if that was the case,' said one insider who has worked for the programme. 'This would really be the final sword thrust.'

A BBC correspondent said Alan Yentob, the BBC's former controller of programmes, had been determined to make the same change five years ago but had been defeated. 'He thought it was the weakest part of the BBC1 schedule, but it proved too difficult a move to make,' he said.

This week several of those working high in the management of television news have privately admitted they are confidently awaiting the birth of a longer flagship news programme to replace the Nine O'Clock News later this year. 'The news bulletin which goes out at nine may well be something of a British institution, but Greg is determined to believe that he can build his own institutions,' said one source at the top of the news division. webTitle: 'Craven' BBC pulls show on prince's birthday

fields.headline: 'Craven' BBC pulls show on prince's birthday
fields.trailText: The BBC was condemned last night as 'craven' after bosses admitted they had shelved a controversial film about the monarchy - due to be screened on Prince William's eighteenth birthday on 21 June - because it was too critical of him.
fields.body:
The BBC was condemned last night as 'craven' after bosses admitted they had shelved a controversial film about the monarchy - due to be screened on Prince William's eighteenth birthday on 21 June - because it was too critical of him.

Dear William, an open letter to the prince from an 18-year-old pupil at a Liverpool comprehensive, condemns the monarchy as outdated and says the royal family should be abolished.

It was scheduled to be screened in prime time as the prince celebrated his birthday with members of the royal family, but last week BBC chiefs decided they would pull it.

The move was bitterly criticised by royal commentators yesterday. Anthony Holden, biographer of Prince Charles and Princess Diana, said Greg Dyke, the BBC's director-general, had bowed to Establishment pressure. 'The BBC should reflect Britain as it really is, not as Buckingham Palace would like to think it is. Dyke needs to be more robust.'

In Dear William, which was filmed two weeks ago on Merseyside, Barry Hale, a pupil at Gateacre School, delivers 'an alternative birthday message' to William.

The BBC cast him because, it said, he had 'strong, mature' views, which 'best reflected how young people in Britain feel today'. Hale contrasts his life with that of William and concludes that the prince should give up his right to the Crown 'because it is not good for the country and it is not good for you'.

The BBC admitted yesterday that it had planned to run the short film at 7.30pm in a personal opinion slot on the prince's birthday but had had second thoughts.

'We decided to commission a programme from one of Prince William's generation to mark the birthday of the world's most famous 18-year-old,' a spokeswoman said.

'On reflection, we have decided that it is not appropriate. The tone is not right. We shall show it later.'

The spokeswoman denied that the programme was pulled in order to mend fences with Buckingham Palace after the furore over the corporation's decision not to broadcast live pictures of the Queen Mother's hundredth birthday pageant. But one well-placed source told The Observer this weekend: 'The BBC took a public battering over the Queen Mother episode and it is hyper-sensitive about the way it deals with the royal family at the moment.

'The last thing the executives want to do is to attract more criticism by releasing a programme that has a go at the prince on the day he becomes a man.

'They commissioned a good, balanced, representative programme and then lost their nerve.'

The criticism is echoed by Holden, who has written extensively about Prince William.

'The BBC's move is craven,' he said. 'Would they do this for a politician - for Tony Blair?

'Would they shelve a programme reflecting accurate and therefore mixed public views about him because it is his birthday? I think not.

'If William decides that he wants to be king, then the views of people like Hale are exactly the sort of views he ought to be exposed to - opinions that come from beyond Eton and the social playing fields of rural England.

'The thoughts of his real-life contemporaries are more representative of Britain's increasingly sceptical view of the monarchy than those of the sycophants and flatterers who surround him every day at home and at school.'

The headteacher of Gateacre comprehensive school, Peter Barnes, said he was shocked by the BBC's decision. 'Barry is a super lad - deputy head boy. He is not some ranting, republican yob. He even interviewed me as part of his 'letter to William'. It seemed like a very balanced, reasonable piece of work.

'The BBC is being too precious by half.'

Hale said that he had been told by the BBC not to talk to anyone about the programme.

A Buckingham Palace spokesman merely said it would be inappropriate to comment on BBC editorial matters.

webTitle: Pontius Pilate rail chiefs 'must face jail'

fields.headline: Pontius Pilate rail chiefs 'must face jail'
fields.trailText: The train driver who was jailed for the death of five people in the Purley rail crash 10 years ago is to appeal against his conviction, amid calls for rail company executives to be held more responsible for such disasters.
fields.body:
The train driver who was jailed for the death of five people in the Purley rail crash 10 years ago is to appeal against his conviction, amid calls for rail company executives to be held more responsible for such disasters.

The Observer has learnt that Robert Morgan, who spent four months in jail after he drove through a red signal into another train, wants his conviction overturned due to fresh evidence about the layout of signalling at the crash site.

His decision comes as the inquiry into last year's Paddington disaster hears of weaknesses across a 'complacent' privatised industry that puts profits before safety.

A safety campaigner this weekend called for rail industry bosses to be put behind bars if the Cullen inquiry into Paddington finds their companies were negligent.The inquiry has heard how a multitude of failings by the industry combined to cause the disaster. Thames Trains rejected a £5 million plan to fit automatic train protection to its vehicles, which would have prevented the crash, but paid dividends to shareholders worth more than £7 million.

The inquiry has also heard that Railtrack signallers failed to switch the points or radio the driver when the signal was passed at danger because they regarded it as 'just another spad' and expected the driver to brake.

There will be evidence, revealed in The Observer last month, that a misaligned rail could have jolted the Thames train to indicate wrongly the signal ahead as green.

Carol Bell, who was injured in the 1998 Southall crash and now campaigns on behalf of Southall and Paddington victims, said the Railtrack and Thames Train chiefs - Gerald Corbett and Terrance Worrall respectively - should face the prospect of prison sentences.

'If Railtrack was found to be negligent, Corbett has to put his neck on the line... that means being prosecuted. If Thames Trains was found to be negligent then, yes, Worrall should be in jail. You cannot take on a job like that and then be Pontius Pilate and wash your hands of it all,' she told The Observer.

Railtrack last week announced annual profits of £360m. Bell runs the Safety on Trains Action Group with Maureen Kavanagh, who lost her only child in the Southall crash. Bell did not know how shareholders 'could live with themselves' as they received dividends while the network was at risk of further crashes.

Kerry Hodder, widow of the driver of the Thames train at Paddington, will have a statement read to the inquiry tomorrow. She has given birth to a daughter, having discovered that she was pregnant days after her husband, Michael, died in the crash.

Worrall admitted last week that Thames Trains had not given Hodder adequate instruction about the complex route out of Paddington.

webTitle: Grief provides no hiding place for LAPD's chief

fields.headline: Grief provides no hiding place for LAPD's chief
fields.standfirst: His granddaughter has been gunned down. Now Bernard Parks may lose control of his police force as Washington loses patience, reports  Christopher Reed
fields.trailText: The street warfare that has plagued Los Angeles for decades has now reached into the family of the police chief himself, with the gang-related fatal shooting of his 20-year-old granddaughter.
fields.body:
The street warfare that has plagued Los Angeles for decades has now reached into the family of the police chief himself, with the gang-related fatal shooting of his 20-year-old granddaughter.

The tragedy comes as the beleaguered chief, Bernard Parks, is faced with loss of control of his force over a long-running scandal which stems from conflicting theories of modern urban policing. The Department of Justice in Washington, exasperated at LA police intransigence, is threatening to use federal legislation to enforce reforms, reducing Parks to a factotum.

Yesterday police spokesmen still refused to release the identity of the male companion of Lori Gonzalez, the granddaughter. The man was the real target of a gunman who fired as she drove her car away from a restaurant in an inner-city neighbourhood last week. The man ducked and Gonzalez was shot in the head.

Gonzalez, whose parents divorced 18 years ago, would have been 21 today. She lived with her father in Mission Viejo, where she was a college student, taught Sunday school and worked as a drugstore clerk and telephone operator. Rather than go camping with her father, stepbrother and sister, she chose to visit her mother in Los Angeles over the Memorial Day holiday last weekend.

Her companion is now known to be a street gangster with a criminal record who was wounded in a shoot-out three weeks ago with gang rivals. Police questioned and then released him. The gunman, who was black and probably carrying out a vengeance shooting, ran away and disappeared.

The controversial and increasingly isolated Parks, an African-American career officer, has been a rigid defender of the force during the present corruption scandal in its inner-city Rampart division. Dozens of officers have been disciplined or are under investigation for framing innocent people.

Parks is desperately trying to fend off government rule over his 10,000-officer force. At the heart of the crisis is the rise of paramilitary techniques pioneered by the LAPD and supported by Parks, in which élite squads of heavily armed officers are deployed with near autonomy to roam the streets administering 'blue justice'.

Critics claim this kind of policing has exacerbated gang activity by creating a military atmosphere. Their alternative is 'community policing' in which officers befriend the neighbourhoods they patrol.

It was the LAPD that invented the Swat (Special Weapons and Tactics) teams now common across America, in which officers in body armour toting submachine guns are increasingly relied upon to make arrests.

It was an élite Rampart squad, the anti-gang Crash (Community Resources Against Street Hoodlums) that sparked the present scandal. Crash became a gang itself, with its own tattoo and grinning skull insignia. The unsupervised unit had its own building, made its own rules and enforced a reign of terror in black and Hispanic neighbourhoods.

But last autumn a 'supergrass' exposed widespread criminal activity at Rampart after he was arrested for stealing 6lb of cocaine from an evidence locker. Among police framings was a young, unarmed man the officers shot, who is now paralysed.

Altogether nearly 100 convictions have been dismissed and the cost of legal actions from victims could bankrupt the city, critics claim.

Last week federal authorities presented the civic lead ership with a list of demands, including a computerised system for tracking officers and new investigative and disciplinary procedures for dealing with wayward policemen.

Federal officials also insist that any deal with the city should be a consent decree filed with a federal court, putting the department under a federal monitor and judge. Parks and Mayor Richard Riordan are arguing for a more informal memorandum of understanding.

Parks, who had been on holiday with his family in North Carolina, considered the matter so important that he flew to Washington to meet senior federal officials even after receiving word of his granddaughter's killing.

webTitle: Massacre tale muddied as witness proves a fake

fields.headline: Massacre tale muddied as witness proves a fake
fields.standfirst: Lies that led to exposé of Korean War atrocity harm press agency and Pentagon
fields.trailText: Lies that led to exposé of Korean War atrocity harm press agency and Pentagon
fields.body:
Behind the glorious Art Deco façade of its New York headquarters, one of the mainmasts of the world's media, Associated Press, is scrambling to salvage its credibility. Its most remarkable story of recent times has been thrown into doubt.

The central and most compelling witness to AP's story of a shocking massacre by American forces has turned out to be a fake.

AP and an investigative reporting team was awarded the Pulitzer Prize for unveiling the massacre of hundreds of Korean citizens - many of them women and children - by US troops on and around a bridge at No Gun Ri in July 1950. It was an atrocity second only to the Vietnam's My Lai massacre in America's book of shame.

The story detonated consternation, soul-searching and praise. Last year it was splashed over every daily newspaper from the tabloids to the New York Times.

Tom Brokaw, the superstar anchorman of Nightline, flew to Korea with Edward Daily, the GI who so vividly confessed his part in the carnage, for a tearful reunion with survivors. Daily became an overnight celebrity, embodying both the atrocity and the healing - survivors were in turn flown over to emotional prayer meetings in the US, 'reunited' with and hugging Daily.

But after weeks of investigation, argument and counter-argument, AP has been forced into admitting that Daily could not have been at No Gun Ri. Further inquiries by The Observer show that even before the story was released, it was the subject of bitter argument at AP, with the president of the company himself unsure of its veracity.

A military academic has condemned Daily's dazzling military career as fantastical. Daily's fabrication of his service record has him captured by the communist North Koreans, decorated for heroic antics and rescuing his platoon comrades under enemy fire. In fact, he was a mechanic in a lacklustre rear-echelon battalion.

Daily was last week forced into admitting that he 'cannot dispute' the discovery that he is a fake, and has confessed to having gleaned his account from obsessive conversations at veterans' reunions.

His hoax has ramifications beyond AP: at issue is not whether the massacre happened - which the Pentagon has all but confirmed - but whether the troops obeyed an order by firing, or acted on the spur of the moment.

According to AP, there was an order: 'No refugees to cross frontline. Fire everyone trying to cross frontlines. Use discretion in case of women and children.' Daily had told AP: 'The command looked at it as getting rid of the problem the easiest way. That was to shoot them in a group.'

As soon as the story was published, the Defence Secretary, William Cohen, ordered the army's inspector-general to conduct an investigation, for which Daily has been interviewed at length. If the commission appointed by the Pentagon concludes that the soldiers were given orders to fire, that could mean a war crime had been committed.

The State Department is also concerned that US-Korean relations could suffer.

AP's story was narrated principally by four US soldiers - Daily, Delos Flint, Eugene Hasselman and Herman Patterson - who claimed they were witnesses to and participants in the carnage, and are now haunted by remorse.

The first doubts over the veracity of the story came from a veterans' website, stripes.com. Then came an instructor at West Point Marine Academy, Major Robert Bateman, who said he could see 'big problems' with the witnesses' accounts, especially that of Daily, whom he labelled 'the biggest fake combat veteran extant' for whom 'the AP team fell'.

Two servicemen involved gave interviews to US News and World Report and one, Patterson, said a quote about 'wholesale slaughter' had been taken out of context by AP. Moreover, said the magazine, documents showed Flint had been evacuated wounded from the area the day before the massacre, on 26 July.

The magazine added that, although Daily repeats in his interview that 'my memory is that I was there at No Gun Ri', his service records showed him to have joined H Company, 2nd Battalion, 7th Cavalry Regiment, eight months after the massacre, and not to have been a machine gunner, as he had claimed to AP.

The AP empire then struck back, releasing full transcripts from the two men interviewed by US News , showing that they had not been quoted out of context. In a separate report, the agency said other GIs recalled seeing Daily at the scene that day. Hasselman not only insists that he was there, but that he recalls Daily being there too.

There was also a further document to counter the crit ical argument that Flint had been evacuated from the zone - a 'morning report' showing that he had been wounded on the day of the massacre.

The next day, the US News executive editor Brian Duffy was forced to concede that 'we should have cited the morning report that said he was wounded on the 26th, and on our part that was an oversight'.

But now comes the definitive blow, from Bateman at West Point. He shows conclusively that Daily is not only lying, but has gone to great lengths to invent his records. Sources investigating the case say the veteran falsified a letter saying that he had been taken prisoner of war, and that the numerous decorations and commendations with which he impressed AP reporters were also false.

Subsequent inquiries show that Daily also acted as a pointman for AP, putting them in touch with his contacts on the veterans' network, mainly people he had met, pretended to know of old, and whose stories he had adopted as his own.

Sources investigating the case say the veteran falsified a letter saying that he had been taken prisoner of war, and that the numerous decorations and commendations with which he impressed AP reporters were also false. Subsequent inquiries show that Daily also acted as a pointman for AP, putting them in touch with his contacts on the veterans' network, mainly people he had met, pretended to know of old, and whose stories he had adopted as his own.

webTitle: Wellington gives knights order of boot

fields.headline: Wellington gives knights order of boot
fields.trailText: The Queen's Birthday Honours List next weekend will have some notable omissions from the southern hemisphere. New Zealand has joined Australia in abolishing titular state honours.
fields.body:
The Queen's Birthday Honours List next weekend will have some notable omissions from the southern hemisphere. New Zealand has joined Australia in abolishing titular state honours.

The first effects will be seen when the Birthday List contains no new Kiwi knights or dames.

The titles already bestowed on mountaineer Edmund Hillary, opera singer Kiri Te Kanawa and other New Zealanders are safe, but in future their ennobled ranks will be swelled only by personal honours from the Queen.

The reform is part of a modernisation programme by the Labour government, headed by Prime Minister Helen Clark, who won power six months ago.

A review is under way to assess whether the country should also sever its 150-year-old link with the Privy Council in London. Clark questions the worth to her country of a final appeal court 12,000 miles away.

Her predecessor, the National Party leader Jenny Shipley, said the honours were worth keeping. Clark, however, said a new honours system, approved by the Queen, has come not a moment too soon.

'Knight and damehoods overshadow not only our highest honour, the Order of New Zealand, but also a large number of other awards given for an extraordinary variety of services to a wide cross-section of the community,' Clark said.

'Our own developing traditions, the strengthening of our own cultural and national identity and the argument for New Zealanders to be honoured in a distinctive New Zealand way, tipped the scales against titular honours in New Zealand's own orders'.

The Order of the British Empire has also been scrapped for native New Zealanders in favour of the indigenous awards, which include the Order of New Zealand, an Order of Merit and gallantry awards.

More than half the population wanted the change, an opinion poll shows.

Among the dissenters was the vice-chairman of the Monarchist League, Noel Cox, who labelled the Prime Minister 'Comrade Clark' over the scheme.

Cox believes New Zealand honours without titles lack the impact and international recognition of knighthoods. However, Canada, Australia and most other countries in the Commonwealth no longer award titles with honours.

In Australia, Bob Hawke's Labour administration finally ended titular honours in the Eighties.

Clark said: 'Australia, a country noted for backing its heroes and heroines, has managed without knighthoods. There are distinguished New Zealanders who have not received high honours because they were not prepared to accept a title. The new system will be much more inclusive.'

webTitle: French renew love affair with the olive

fields.headline: French renew love affair with the olive
fields.standfirst: Plan to boost production of oil that gives longer life
fields.trailText: Plan to boost production of oil that gives longer life
fields.body:
They are scattered all over the sleepy South, enclosed by crumbling drystone walls, overgrown with weeds: the forgotten olive groves of France, many of them 300 or more years old, yielding their crops year after year to lie rotting in the sun.

Not for much longer, however, if a new government plan bears fruit. Convinced by mounting medical evidence that a Mediterranean diet keeps you healthier for longer, France aims to double its olive-oil output by paying farmers a premium to bring neglected groves back to life.

'There's undoubtedly a romantic notion about it. A lot of people think it's their dream job: you just sit around all year in the sun and let the things grow, then bust a gut for a couple of days at harvest time,' said Patrice Minchelli, who has taken advantage of the scheme to restore a grove of 210 century-old olive trees outside Aix-en-Provence.

'Sadly, that's not true. You have to prune, replant, fumigate, irrigate, keep the bugs off, hang your nets, harvest by hand. It is magical, but you have to love olive trees as others love the sea or the mountains. You have to tend them like a child.'

The government is paying growers such as Minchelli £600 to £1,200 a hectare to restore groves to full production, trying to boost French output - which has fallen by nearly a quarter over the past two decades and by 80 per cent since the Second World War - to 5,000-6,000 tonnes a year from 2,000-3,000 today.

It also wants to grab for France a larger slice of a market that has grown spectacularly since 1980: health-conscious people in France now buy nearly 80,000 tonnes of olive oil a year, compared with under 20,000 tonnes 20 years ago. Most of it comes from southern Europe's big three oil-producing countries: Spain, Italy and Greece.

'We are small compared with the more southerly countries,' admitted Marie-Noelle Mussato from the Olive Oil Information Centre in Paris. 'But our plus-point is that we also produce the highest proportion of high-quality virgin or extra-virgin oil, unadulterated by chemical additives or heat-treatment.'

As part of an aggressive bid to capture the upper end of the fast-expanding European market, France is busily creating appellation contrlée and grands crus labels - similar to those applied to high-quality wines - for olive oils from eight different regions, including Nyons, Les Baux-de-Provence and Haute-Provence.

In return for being able to charge £12 to £15 a bottle for their oil, growers must abide by strict quality-control rules, including producing oil from one clearly defined variety of olive and harvesting crops exclusively by hand.

The result is a product that merits the devotion more usually shown to the output of a top Bordeaux chateau. 'A good olive oil must be fragrant, but not excessively so,' said Eric Verdier, chief taster at Oliviers & Co, one of several upmarket oil merchants to have opened in Paris.

'There should be notes of freshly cut grass, artichoke, almond, apple and green pepper. It should be light and fluid, not too viscous, and cover the tongue easily.'

Some 150 new growers have taken up the challenge over the past two years, according to the national producers' association. Many started out as dreamers, like Edmond Plawczyk, who bought five hectares of disused grove - 800 trees, the grandest of them 300 years old - outside Nice. About 350 trees are producing oil for the first time since the 1950s.

'You become part of a tradition that stretches back to pre-antiquity,' he said. 'But it costs you time, sweat and energy, and don't ever think you'll get rich quick. Most people reckon you need 1,500 to 2,000 trees to make a living - maybe £10,000 a year.'

If you think of snapping up a disused grove and retiring to a life of semi-leisure in the sun, be warned: southern France is at the northern edge of the zone in which olives grow. In 1956, a frost wiped out six million of the country's 8.5 million trees, and a repeat cannot be ruled out.

fields.headline: Mounties punish fragrant offences
fields.trailText: The Canadian province of Nova Scotia has outlawed perfume in public places after claims that it contains toxic chemicals .
fields.body:
The Canadian province of Nova Scotia has outlawed perfume in public places after claims that it contains toxic chemicals .

The ban, observed in government buildings, 80 per cent of schools and a growing number of private workplaces includes all fragrances, including those in hairspray and gel, mouthwash and deodorants. Some employees have been sent home to shower for being too sweetly scented.

The ban signals a victory for anti-perfume activists who lobbied outside the City Hall of the province's capital, Halifax, wearing gas masks. Their complaint is that fragrance is 97 per cent composed of undisclosed chemicals, some of which cause MCS - multiple chemi cal sensitivity. Critics say MCS is a spurious condition.

Karen Robinson, president of Citizens for a Safe Learning Environment, says: 'It makes us look like zealots and hypchochondriacs, and that's not the case. This ban on fragrance will affect the pocketbook of the cosmetic industry, and they're very powerful. It makes sense for them to discredit those campaigning against them.'

In Halifax not everyone has come to terms with the anti-perfume rule. An 84-year-old woman was escorted from a council meeting at City Hall for having a dab of perfume behind her ears.

Sheet Harbour High School was the scene of another scent showdown when a 17-year-old pupil refused to trade in his hair gel and deodorant for unscented alternatives. It almost got him a criminal record. His teacher, highly sensitive to fragrance, blamed the scent for triggering a vomiting attack. She called the incident an 'assault' and was backed by the school. The teen was handed over to the Royal Canadian Mounted Police but released without charge.

webTitle: Black teens score high in self-esteem

fields.headline: Black teens score high in self-esteem
fields.standfirst: US study confounds anti-racism activists
fields.trailText: The poor academic and economic achievement of black people is often blamed on low self-esteem, the result of discrimination from birth and endless negative stereotypes. But the most definitive study on the subject now contradicts this belief: black teenagers do not have lower self-esteem than whites, but higher.
fields.body:
The poor academic and economic achievement of black people is often blamed on low self-esteem, the result of discrimination from birth and endless negative stereotypes. But the most definitive study on the subject now contradicts this belief: black teenagers do not have lower self-esteem than whites, but higher. Anti-racism campaigners claim that the report suggests there is even more discrimination against blacks than previously thought.

In an article in the US journal Psychological Bulletin, an African-American psychologist shows that whatever the effects of racism, poor self-esteem is not one of them. Except for the very young and very rich, blacks have higher self-esteem than their white counterparts, she demonstrates, and have had for years.

Bernadette Gray-Little, a professor of psychology at the University of North Carolina, performed a complex review of every piece of research available on black self-esteem. Using a technique called meta-analysis, her research culled data from the studies and treated them as if they were part of one giant study, making her results less likely to be the result of chance.

'There have been inconsistencies in the results of the studies on this topic over time,' says Gray-Little. 'I wanted to see if I could find any basis for a firm conclusion. And if inconsistencies occurred, I wanted to know when and why.'

She found that before the age of 10, whites slightly surpass blacks in self-esteem. Everyone's self-esteem dips in the later years of school. After that, blacks narrowly but consistently surpass whites, up to the age of 21, the upper limit of the study.

The self-esteem gap seems to depend on wealth. Low-income blacks show higher self-esteem than low-income whites. But the gap disap pears at higher income levels. The study also shows that black self-esteem has not risen over time. The theory of many psychologists was that as blacks gained in civil liberties, their self-esteem would rise. But the study shows it has never been low.

The report will confound black activists who have seen raising black self-esteem as the key to overcoming social disadvantage. At the all-black Paul Robeson Academy in Detroit, students start the day by standing up and proclaiming: 'I feel like somebody. I act like somebody. Nobody can make me feel like a nobody!'

In Britain, many companies now have mentoring schemes to help people from ethnic minorities. The Millennium Commission is funding a three-year programme to expand such schemes.

But Chris Myant of the Commission for Racial Equality welcomes the study: 'These results are very interesting. They suggest the level of discrimination is far higher than thought because here is a group with high self-esteem who are underachieving, and so must be having higher obstacles put in their way. It suggests that what is holding black people back is not their own attitudes, but those of society as a whole.'

Ekow Eshun, style commentator, broadcaster and former editor of men's magazine Arena, said he was saddened that anybody needed to do a survey to show what most young, black people know from personal experience.

'Black kids do not have low self-esteem,' he said. 'They are actually forced to think very hard about who they are and to find ways of being themselves by social attitudes. They do not feel like sportsmen or pop stars or thieves or any of the other stereotypes. They feel like real people. It is not surprising that the kids from wealthier backgrounds have lower self-confidence, though. It isn't that they feel bad about being black, but they are more likely to live in an environment where there are more people to treat them worse. Think of a young, black kid at an English public school and you'll know what I mean.'

Trevor Phillips, Britain's high profile black politician and Greater London Authority chairman, is sceptical about the study but fears its implications: 'If true, it implies that the orthodoxy that blacks fail in school because of low self-esteem is not true. The tendency has been to blame black families for not giving black children confidence.

'You can conclude that either black children are essentially stupid, which I don't think is legitimate, or there's a lot more discrimination than we thought.

'You have to ask what these schools are doing to make these children underachieve. It doesn't mean we have nothing to worry about - it's even more worrying.'

Gray-Little puts forward several reasons for blacks having higher self-esteem than whites. One suggestion is that it is the result of group pride. Few whites think of themselves as part of a coherent ethnic group, nor do they get satisfaction from their ethnic identities. 'Blacks, a highly identifiable social group, emphasise their desirable distinctiveness,' she writes.

Sandra Graham, professor of education at University of California in Los Angeles, who describes the study as 'the definitive statement on the issue', says the results contradict the orthodox view. 'The prevailing view is that society puts you in a certain place and that influences how you feel. But the research has not supported that idea.'

But Gray-Little suggests that blacks do get their ideas about self-worth from others, but not from whites. Friends, family and neighbours project the impressions that matter. Whites have little say in how blacks feel about themselves.

fields.headline: Peru spurns Fujimori's 'triumph'
fields.standfirst: Opposition plans 'peaceful insurrection' to prevent President from taking office
fields.trailText: Opposition plans 'peaceful insurrection' to prevent President from taking office
fields.body:
In the jungle province of Satipo, in northern Peru, a photograph of opposition presidential candidate Alejandro Toledo adorned polling booths last weekend, despite an election-day prohibition of political propaganda.

Toledo, a Harvard-educated economist, was wearing a red headband and had a shifty look. 'Toledo Threatens' was written above his photograph; 'No To Terror' was scrawled beneath.

Small wonder the Satipo district turned in 98 per cent of votes for President Alberto Fujimori, who ended hyperinflation and a brutal insurgency that devastated isolated outposts such as Satipo.

Troops visited villages before election day, warning that if Toledo were elected, Peru would be plunged into terrible war. Toledo had already withdrawn from the race, citing 'serious irregularities' in the electoral process, an opinion seconded by the Organisation of American States observer mission, which pulled out before election day. The OAS observers asked for a 10-day postponement of the vote to verify electronic vote-counting machinery, but the request was turned down by the National Electoral Council.

In Lima on election night, the victorious Fujimori hid from public view while the supposed loser, Toledo, celebrated his defeat in style, with 70,000 supporters at the biggest political rally of the past 10 years. While Fujimori claimed 74 per cent of votes, that slipped to 40 per cent when spoilt votes and absentee ballots were included. 'He ran alone and still lost,' read one headline.

Toledo addressed the crowd for an hour, promising to lead a 'peaceful insurrection' to culminate in a rally of four million Peruvians on 26 July, to prevent Fujimori from taking office. The new congress has 68 opposition deputies, against Fujimori's 52, sufficient to block the President's inauguration on 28 July.

But no one underestimates Fujimori, who has made Houdini-like escapes from similar crises during his 10-year rule.

The US State Department described the elections as 'illegitimate' but Fujimori, who braved diplomatic pressure when he shut down congress in 1992, did not bat an eyelid. The US position was 'unjust', he said, breaking silence last week to describe the elections as 'incident-free'.

A day later the US backtracked, saying the elections were 'seriously imperfect' rather than null and void. Fujimori smiled; the US position was 'objective', he said. First reports filtered through, as five opposition deputies said they were offered $10,000 a month to back Fujimori's voting bloc in the new parliament.

Last Wednesday the 34 OAS ambassadors deferred a decision on the crisis until the organisation's annual General Assembly this week.

The Andean nations are in the middle of a severe political crisis; Venezuela postponed presidential elections due to be held the same day as Peru's; Ecuador suffered a brief coup last January; Bolivia declared martial law to quell a popular uprising last month and every day sees Colombia sink deeper into civil war.

The prospect of outside intervention in Peru's affairs sent shivers up the Andean spine, whose governments fear a similar spotlight may be held up to their own fragile democratic institutions.

The centre of Lima was filled with protests every evening last week, always accompanied by the stench of tear gas, as police overreacted to the demonstrations.

A broader crisis dates back to Fujimori's 'self-coup' in 1992, abolishing political parties. He shut down congress and dissolved the supreme court, moulding replacement institutions in his likeness. The move was then popular with Peruvians, fed up with corruption and inefficiency.

Fujimori implemented an economic plan that pleased investors but hurt the poor, with three million children being withdrawn from school, their parents unable to afford small entrance fees. While unemployment stands at 10 per cent, under-employment, meaning poorly paid part-time work, affects 60 per cent of the population.

Fujimori's luck ran out over the past year. He failed to muster support for a third election term, as citizens yearned for a new face in power.

'I manage Peru's problems as if I were in front of a chess board,' boasted Fujimori, a loner who craves perpetual power. He appears to have lost too many important pieces on the chessboard and spent last week locked away in his office, pondering whether to concede the game or fight to the bitter end.

But no one underestimates Fujimori, who has made Houdini-like escapes from similar crises during his 10-year rule. The US State Department described the elections as 'illegitimate' but Fujimori, who braved diplomatic pressure when he shut down congress in 1992, did not bat an eyelid. The US position was 'unjust', he said, breaking silence last week to describe the elections as 'incident-free'. A day later the US backtracked, saying the elections were 'seriously imperfect' rather than null and void. Fujimori smiled; the US position was 'objective', he said. First reports filtered through, as five opposition deputies said they were offered $10,000 a month to back Fujimori's voting bloc in the new parliament. Last Wednesday the 34 OAS ambassadors deferred a decision on the crisis until the organisation's annual General Assembly this week. The Andean nations are in the middle of a severe political crisis; Venezuela postponed presidential elections due to be held the same day as Peru's; Ecuador suffered a brief coup last January; Bolivia declared martial law to quell a popular uprising last month and every day sees Colombia sink deeper into civil war. The prospect of outside intervention in Peru's affairs sent shivers up the Andean spine, whose governments fear a similar spotlight may be held up to their own fragile democratic institutions. The centre of Lima was filled with protests every evening last week, always accompanied by the stench of tear gas, as police overreacted to the demonstrations. A broader crisis dates back to Fujimori's 'self-coup' in 1992, abolishing political parties. He shut down congress and dissolved the supreme court, moulding replacement institutions in his likeness. The move was then popular with Peruvians, fed up with corruption and inefficiency. Fujimori implemented an economic plan that pleased investors but hurt the poor, with three million children being withdrawn from school, their parents unable to afford small entrance fees. While unemployment stands at 10 per cent, under-employment, meaning poorly paid part-time work, affects 60 per cent of the population. Fujimori's luck ran out over the past year. He failed to muster support for a third election term, as citizens yearned for a new face in power. 'I manage Peru's problems as if I were in front of a chess board,' boasted Fujimori, a loner who craves perpetual power. He appears to have lost too many important pieces on the chessboard and spent last week locked away in his office, pondering whether to concede the game or fight to the bitter end.

fields.headline: Website offers whingers 50p to complain
fields.trailText: Consumers will be paid to whinge about everything from high car prices to bad hotel rooms by a pan-European firm which has hundreds of thousands of amateur watchdogs monitoring services and shops on the Continent.
fields.body:
Consumers will be paid to whinge about everything from high car prices to bad hotel rooms by a pan-European firm which has hundreds of thousands of amateur watchdogs monitoring services and shops on the Continent.

From Tuesday, British shoppers, sports fans and art lovers will be urged to set aside polite reserve and start complaining.

Ciao.com, set up by a group of young entrepreneurs, will pay new members £1 to register and 50p for every 'quality' opinion they contribute on any one of eight subjects.

The Consumers' Association welcomed the venture as a sign of the net's ability to cut promotional hype and allow ordinary people to swap useful information free. 'Often consumers want impartial opinions on goods and services and they do not know where to look,' said a spokeswoman. 'It is a very interesting idea to pay people for good quality information in a range of consumer fields.'

It is the first forum for direct cross-border consumer comparisons, attempted by the Government in a controversial price study early this year.

'The strength of enabling ordinary consumers to register their views is that these are the sorts of opinions which people find most helpful,' said Tom Cadogan, 27, head of Ciao.com UK.

Would-be book reviewers, film critics, TV presenters and amateur whingers make up the hundreds of thousands of contributors in Germany, France, Italy, Austria and Spain.

'There is a definite psychological profile of writers which is different to the readers,' said Cadogan. 'There are real experts who write about cars, computers and homes and gardens and they get read a lot. They are the kind of troublesome people who sit in your local pub and know all the answers on the trivia games. We put the most popular writers in the hall of fame. They will be paid for the number of times their opinions are read.'

The German site, launched in November, has logged 350,000 opinions. Best-read subject areas are cars, homes and gardens.

Funding for the British arm of Ciao.com is being provided by Apax Partners, the venture capital firm which backed DJ and TV presenter Chris Evans's buy-out of Virgin Radio.

Translations of opinions logged by foreign consumers are planned.

Fears that the site might be flooded with the sort of obscure, eccentric ramblings found in myriad chat rooms prompted stringent quality control. Opinions are screened for obscenity and legal problems.

Users can downgrade 'unhelpful' opinions and views that receive the most hits automatically float to the top of subject areas. Attempts to manipulate the site are picked up by software similar to programs used to identify unusual patterns on stock markets.
