webTitle: Old South to haul downits battle flag

fields.headline: Old South to haul downits battle flag
fields.standfirst: Protests persuade South Carolina to surrender on symbol of segregation
fields.trailText: Protests persuade South Carolina to surrender on symbol of segregation
fields.body:
At noon on 1 July, the Confederate battle flag will be lowered from its pole atop the dome of the state capitol in Columbia, South Carolina, thereby closing a bitter war that for decades has cut deep and painfully at old wounds in the New South.

'Thank you, Jesus, thank you,' roared a (white) Democratic senator as the vote to bring down the 'Stars and Bars' was passed, reflecting the shredded emotions and sheer fatigue that have characterised the most highly charged symbolic battle in America. Governor Jim Hodges last week endorsed the Bill with both his signature and relief that 'we will no longer be the only state with the flag on our dome'.

The flag-lowering will probably be a tumultuous scene, as protesters and the odd Ku Klux Klansman face off against jubilant Confeder ate flag-burning crowds. The notion of a national flag is of special significance to Americans in a way that the British find hard to understand. The Stars and Stripes, ubiquitously flown, is more than an emblem, it is what unifies the country, it is America's fragile essence, claimed across all political and ideological barriers as a metaphor for the land itself. And the Confederate flag means all these things to many whites in the South.

They insist the flag is a nostalgic symbol not of racism but of 'heritage', a lost world of grace and wealth laid waste by the barbarians of the industrial North. In this camp, there is a blindness (or rather a pretence at blindness) to what the flag means to its opponents: the real barbarism of slavery.

A Confederate flag on a car bumper in the South is intended to strike terror into the heart of a black person, and does so. Atop a government building, it is an act of brazen humiliation. To one side it means glory, to the other it means enslavement. It is a fundamental divide across America's deepest wound, the Civil War.

The flag's removal next month is itself a powerful sym bol of reckoning - of the Old South making way for the New - coinciding as it does with the conviction last week of two Klansmen for firebombing a black church in 1963, and with a host of other racist murder and lynching cases reopened and being tried. And it dovetails into mounting pressure for the passage of a Congressional Bill setting up a commission to draft a system of reparations to be paid in compensation for slavery.

The South Carolina legislature also voted to observe Martin Luther King Day - the last state to do so - having rejected the idea as recently as March. And ground was broken in front of the state house for a monument celebrating black American history.

One of the iconic figures in the campaign to have the flag removed was Tom Turnipseed, who three decades ago was national director of George Wallace's 'Segregation Forever' campaign and whose grandfather was a Wizard in the KKK.

Turnipseed is now a card-carrying member of the National Association for the Advancement of Coloured People and was a co-plaintiff in a case taken by the left-wing Southern Poverty Law Centre against the Klan in South Carolina over the burning of a black church, which resulted in a damages award of $37 million against the KKK and brought about its near-destruction in the state.

Turnipseed's conversion is seen by the black lobby as tantamount to seeing the light. 'That Dixie symbol is a-comin' down,' he says now, 'we're gonna take it down.'

But the removal of the Stars and Bars from the dome is not an outright defeat for the flag's supporters. Indeed, the outcome of the battle of the battle flag only serves to symbolise ambivalence and irreconcilability in the South.

The vote was closer than expected - 66 to 43 in the lower house. And the motion passed was a botched compromise. A smaller, lower battle flag will fly in front of the capitol, beside a monument to slain Confederate soldiers.

The half-solution created electoral chaos, with some black representatives voting against it. The NAACP has said it will continue a boycott on tourism in South Carolina, with which it dramatically raised the stakes of the flag debate last year. Many whites who support the flag voted to remove it because of the boycott's economic impact on a state that likes to boast about glorious beaches and down-home friendly folks.

Even the leader of the pro-flag faction, Glenn McConnell, said: 'We're like General Lee when he said there's nothing left for me to do but to get terms from General Grant. I love seeing the flag atop the statehouse, but moving it is the best thing for South Carolina.'

fields.headline: It's always groundlings' day
fields.trailText: Promenaders at Sadler's Wells had a close-up view of the exotic instruments used by Rambert's London Musici orchestra: Andean panpipes for Ghost Dances, plastic tubing swooshed through the air to make a keening sound during Four Scenes, Christopher Bruce's bittersweet evocation of childhood.
fields.body:
Rambert Dance Company Sadler's Wells, London EC1

Promenaders at Sadler's Wells had a close-up view of the exotic instruments used by Rambert's London Musici orchestra: Andean panpipes for Ghost Dances, plastic tubing swooshed through the air to make a keening sound during Four Scenes, Christopher Bruce's bittersweet evocation of childhood.

Front-stalls seats had been removed to provide standing room at £4.50 a head for contemporary dance groundlings. Newcomers could start to recognise the dancers, whose faces were barely discernible from the further reaches of the theatre, thanks to low lighting. Rambert's opening programme was otherwise accessible, designed to lure audiences back for more this week, when seats and prices revert to normal.

Glen Tetley's Embrace Tiger and Return to Mountain, which opened the triple bill, served as an introduction to the company and to modern dance. Tetley created it in 1968, two years after Ballet Rambert had transformed itself from a struggling ballet troupe into a cutting-edge ensemble. The experimental choreography combines American modern dance with ballet and Chinese martial arts: the title refers to moves described in a T'ai Chi manual, Tetley's primer for the piece.

Embrace Tiger looks and sounds, now, like an attempt to invent the future. Sophisticated aliens would surely mate like this, all passion controlled; music (Morton Subotnick's 1967 Silver Apples of the Moon) would be electronic; clothing sleek, spare, unisex. Men, however, would still be in thrall to women.

Tetley stylises sexual encounters, the strangest duet involving an acolyte serving a priestess on pointe. By the end, the 10 dancers are paired off, mirroring each other like molecules multiplying into eternity.

Tetley may have been wrong about the future but his sci-fi ceremony is still mesmerising. Christopher Bruce, following in his footsteps as a myth-maker, stays closer to home in Four Scenes. Intercut sequences summarise a day in the life of an individual, a family. The linking motif is a gesture of catching at something you can never hold for long. A child picks up a hopscotch stone; an adolescent combs his hair; a mature couple link arms. Premonitions of loss haunt the carefree youngsters skimming the stage in games, jigs and reels.

Dave Heath's score, combining two of his compositions on Celtic themes, provides catchy folk music. The audience responded warmly, recognising the pangs of growing up, of growing old. These are sentiments Bruce is adept at exploiting, for they feature in many of his cyclical rites of passage.

Ghost Dances, from 1981, is his classic life-and-death piece. South American peasants are picked off, one after the other, by grisly spectres lurking in the Andean heights. But still they keep on dancing to breathy flute music before succumbing to disease or oppression.

As stony-hearted as the set, I find it hard to care about such plight and the skull-masked capers by the messengers of death go on for far too long.

fields.headline: An enigma with no variations
fields.standfirst: Even Donald Sutherland can't inject character into a star vehicle that stays leadenly earthbound
fields.trailText: Enigmatic Variations | Stones in his Pockets | The Tempest | Moments of Madness
fields.body:
Enigmatic Variations Savoy Theatre, London WC2

Stones in his Pockets New Ambassadors, WC2

The Tempest Globe, SE1

Moments of Madness BAC, SW11

Until now, the Hollywood stars who've laid siege to the London theatre have come away with their reputations enhanced. Not any more. It's not that Donald Sutherland lacks presence at the Savoy; on the contrary, assurance streams off him. But after 20 years away from the stage, he has chosen to return in a flat-footed play. It makes his skill look too easily won.

Eric-Emmanuel Schmitt's Enigmatic Variations is a star vehicle, a two-hander with frequent opportunities for emotional volatility and, in the translation from the French by Sutherland's son Roeg, hardly a memorable phrase. A charismatic, prize-winning author (guess who?) has immured himself on a remote Norwegian island, where he plays the part of a gun-toting eccentric genius. He is visited by an apparently docile journalist, (blandly played by John Rubinstein), and finds the landscapes of his emotional and literary world turned upside down.

The title is draped in clues. There is, as in Elgar's composition, a mysterious dedicatee. The assumptions of the opening moments are unpicked, and unpicked again, to suggest different versions of the past - versions often guessable. And when one of the men starts to tickle the ivories, it is to play The Enigma Variations .

Sutherland carries off his part with a lofty insouciance: a lupine grin, a loping gait, a sudden flash of fervour. But he can't make a play made up of mechanical tricks look as if it's driven by character. And he can't surmount the usual difficulty of dramas featuring writers - is the way authors speak supposed to echo their work on the page?

When Sutherland an-nounces that he felt a 'tender repulsion' towards his lover's breasts because she wasn't very pretty, it's to be hoped the audience are expected to start questioning his lovableness. But are they supposed to think he's a dodgy writer? It's one of the few puzzles in a play insufficient in enigmas and variety.

Anyone doubting that two-handers can show depth and dexterity should go to the New Ambassadors, where Stones in his Pockets has arrived from the Tri-cycle. Marie Jones, author of a galaxy of plays, including Women on the Verge of HRT , has written a nimble examination of the exploitative, collusive relationship be-tween Hollywood and rural Ireland, in which all the parts in a big cast are played by two gifted actors, Conleth Hill and Sean Campion.

Stones in his Pockets is halfway between a double-act and a play: this has helped to make it hugely popular. It's a zestful lesson in how one small stroke, if it's the right one, can create a character: Hill turns himself from a male extra into a female star by crooking his finger to tuck an imaginary wisp of hair behind his ear. Campion regroups his vertebrae to become an ancient blusterer or a squirming schoolboy. Each does so with one change of jacket and shoes.

This is not simply a demonstration of versatility. Jones writes sentences that sing. And the structure of her play is part of what she has to say. Stones in his Pockets looks at fictional notions of character - at how the Americans make the Irish re-imagine themselves. She adds to her point by showing people in the process of making themselves up.

Watching Shakespeare at the Globe is not like seeing his plays anywhere else. The audience is not divided by lights from the actors and they are subjected, literally, to the same weather.

To see The Tempest at the Globe on a tempestuously dripping spring evening is to see a space in which colours have more lustre and to hear lines about clouds and water as if they've been newly written.

As Prospero, Vanessa Redgrave need only nod up at the grey sky when talking about Providence - or the 'great globe itself' - to make you feel you're sharing a secret. Lines about melting into thin air caused one pakamak-hooded ground-ling to peer into the ether to see what had happened. Lenka Udovicki's production needs this help. It's a fitful affair. It has in Jasper Britton a powerful Caliban, who looks like a half-finished clay model, roars like a freedom fighter and is cheered by the audience. It has a doll-like, blanched Ariel, played by Geraldine Alexander. And it has in Vanessa Redgrave a whimsical Prospero, not tormented, but by turn utterly disenchanted and sweet. It's not difficult to think of her as unwomanly: she rummages a lot in her pockets; neither her voice nor gestures are caressing; she has something of the old sea-salt about her, and an elusive accent that swings between Scots and Irish.

The difficulty with her performance is more unexpected. She can alight on a line and squeeze out an idiosyncratic significance. She is caustic about any excitement at a brave new world, but on the way she jettisons whole banks of verse in a barely inflected growl.

Volcano Theatre Company is well-named. Its productions are eruptions. In Moments of Madness this Swansea-based troupe claims Ron Davies's excursion onto Clapham Common as the inspiration for a state-of-the-nation piece - the Welsh nation, that is.

Five limber performers somersault, sing and soliloquise their way through episodes which begin with a satire on conference life and end in a bloody mutiny. They do so in a gleaming steel gym, shaped to resemble the hold of a ship, punctured by hatches and flaps which regularly, clangingly, shoot open to provide perches for characters, ledges for dotty objects - a pram, a rocking-horse, a plastic doll. But you'd have to be Merlin to follow the lava-like flow of consciousness here, or to work out, without recourse to a programme, that the show has been prompted by Ron Davies, whose interesting mysteries are neglected.

This talented company has tied itself to a maddening statement by Howard Barker instructing theatre practitioners that it's time to stop telling its audience 'stories they can understand'. Why?

The difficulty with her performance is more unexpected. She can alight on a line and squeeze out an idiosyncratic significance. She is caustic about any excitement at a brave new world, but on the way she jettisons whole banks of verse in a barely inflected growl. Volcano Theatre Company is well-named. Its productions are eruptions. This talented company has tied itself to a maddening statement by Howard Barker instructing theatre practitioners that it's time to stop telling its audience 'stories they can understand'. Why?

fields.headline: All the president's mien...
fields.standfirst: With his extraordinary opera Nixon in China about to open over here, composer John Adams explains why he sees Tricky Dicky as a tragic hero such as Caesar
fields.trailText: John Adams is the most inventive and ebullient of contemporary American composers, and the most widely performed. Outgrowing the hypnotic drone of minimalism, he has taken on the classical tradition and annexed its august forms
fields.body:
John Adams is the most inventive and ebullient of contemporary American composers, and the most widely performed. Outgrowing the hypnotic drone of minimalism, he has taken on the classical tradition and annexed its august forms; his opera Nixon in China, first performed in Texas in 1987, has its English stage premiere at ENO on Wednesday as a certified classic. The man himself, a spry, greying elf now aged 53, restores to music its ancient, sacred functions - making audible the orderly structure of the universe in his symphonic treatise Harmonielehre, assuaging human pain in his Whitman setting The Wound-Dresser.

Imagine my surprise, therefore, when Adams - at breakfast last weekend in Vancouver, where he is conducting at a festival of new music - ordered the music in the restaurant turned off. Or rather it was Muzak, as viscous as maple syrup, which he asked to have unplugged. 'I'm being a crank this morning,' he said. John Cage, his early hero, thought that the street noise outside his Manhattan window was musical; the ears of Adams himself are stricter.

'I hate Muzak,' he said, repeating his request. Then he scanned the menu. 'I'll have a rattlesnake steak and a blueberry shake,' he decided. Neither item was on offer: he just enjoys making words rhyme. For Nixon in China, he insisted on a libretto in heroic couplets. 'I can't set prose to music. It's too - well, prosaic.' By now he was negotiating with the addled waitress. 'Grapefruit juice and pancakes. No sausage, I don't eat meat.'

Adams lives in Berkeley, across the bay from San Francisco: intestinal purity is a compulsory creed, along with air purged of cigarette fumes and Mantovani tunes.

The night before, I'd heard him conduct his recent symphony, Naive and Sentimental Music. The title derives from Schiller's contrast between poets who are instinctive and those who are self-conscious; a bumptious little tune sets out on the road, and gets its heart broken by some Mahlerian cataclysms. 'I always liked that essay of Schiller's, more than Goethe's opposition between classical and romantic or Nietzche's Apollonian versus Dionysian. I thought it summed up my personality.' That personality, as Adams has often said, is schizoid. He can be moody, introspective and lyrical, and also - as in what he calls 'the overgrown boogie-woogie' of Fearful Symmetries - prone to uproarious misbehaviour. He calls this side of himself 'the trickster'. 'I'm like a coyote,' he said. 'They're shrewd, they can outwit their hunters.'

His Chamber Symphony combines the atonal knottiness of Schoenberg with the crass mayhem of Roadrunner cartoons. Nixon in China ends elegiacally, after a raucous chorus celebrating prize pigs and a parodic skit about the beleaguered peasantry.

Goethe, Nietzsche and Schiller were all proposing choices, whereas Adams contrives to be both naive and sentimental. 'I want both,' he admitted, 'I want it all. Isn't that typically American? How can you avoid being jingoistic, when you have my name?' He is indeed an American version of Adam, the discoverer and sole proprietor of new aural worlds. 'My works,' he said 'aren't a dialectic of opposites, like classical sonata form. I send the air through large sonic structures, I take big blocks of sound and I kind of strum them. As you listen, you move through a landscape or a terrain' - a pristine Eden in El Dorado, the wind sculpted bluffs and buttes of the Nevada desert in Hoodoo Zephyr.

In 1971, Adams dramatised his quest for a personal paradise by uprooting himself from New England and driving to San Francisco. 'I was disgusted with the East Coast. At Harvard, music went from Gregorian chant to Webern - no jazz, nothing vernacular. It took a considerable act of will to reject what I'd been taught, and I knew no one out West. For a while, I worked on the waterfront in Oakland. I was a real settler on the frontier.'

Nixon in China, about American innocents abroad in the wiliest and most cynically elderly of cultures, voices Adams's gratitude to his adopted state. 'Oh, California!' sighs the homesick Pat Nixon during a bilious Peking banquet. Her aria, 'This is prophetic!', is a benediction of her own country and Nixon himself ingenuously declares 'America is good at heart'. Adams rejects descriptions of the work as pop art, as if Mao were like Andy Warhol - a bright, bland visage, not a compound of a poet, philosopher, mass murderer and profligate womaniser. 'I wanted to get beyond irony and disgust, which were Warhol's reactions. This country is so caught up in its own mythology - no, sorry, I mean that country: I forgot we're in Canada! Every day the national symbols of the United States are abused by the media. They use the Statue of Liberty to sell tampons or the Grand Canyon to flog Land Cruisers. I wanted to take these grand beliefs of ours back from the advertisers who've perverted them.'

Hence the lofty idealism and sad nostalgia of Adams's Nixon. 'At the time, he was Tricky Dick, a butt for comedians in night clubs. I despised him as a politician, but in the opera he's a presidential Everyman. I don't care what he thought of the piece. I treated him as Shakespeare did Henry IV or Julius Caesar: he was an archetype. Who cares that Pat never said anything in real life? In the opera, she sings; she becomes what Jung calls the anima.'

Nixon, arriving in Peking, excitedly announces that his visit to Mao is being studied by 'the eyes and ears of history'. Adams shares this sense of mission. The opera was planned as an addition to the ancestry of the form, as if updating Handel's Julius Caesar in Egypt. The score quotes from Wagner and Madame Mao (for Adams China's Robespierre) mimics the witchy coloratura tirades of Mozart's Queen of the Night in The Magic Flute. ' I wrote it to inaugurate a new opera house in Houston; the other work they did for the opening was Aida. Well, Nixon has its own triumph scene, when the 747 lands on stage. And both operas have elephants in them!'

It's native bravado, not arrogance, which makes Adams measure himself against Verdi or compare his own dramaturgy with Shakespeare's. As he said when describing the way his Chamber Symphony teases Schoenberg, 'I deal with him as an American: I stick my tongue out, and wag my ears.' Despite the impertinent pluck which he shares with coyotes and the unkillable Roadrunner, the Nixon commission brought with it a crushing burden of expectation: he felt as if he were 'pregnant with the royal heir'. If the Adams who composed Nixon was Princess Diana, charged with perpetuating the dynastic line, then his current labour is even more momentous. For his next act, he is impersonating the Virgin Mary. In December, as a commemoration of the millennium, he will bring forth a child who was conceived immaculately. The Chatelet in Paris asked him for a new opera, but he offered instead an oratorio. 'It's about Nativity. It will be,' he said with supreme self-possession, 'my Messiah'.

I wondered about his credentials. 'I'm a lapsed Christian. I started out Episcopalian, then my mother switched to Unitarianism. That's a very Yankee religion, without crosses, sceptical about everything.'

So how can a sceptic portray the virgin birth? 'Well, I could have decided that Jesus was a natural-born child who grew up to be Mahatma Gandhi. But I think it has to be a miracle and I have my own Byzantine way of rationalising that. The divine conception amplifies what's already a miracle. When my daughter was born, suddenly there weren't five people in the delivery room, there were six! You can talk all you like about sperms, eggs, cell division and zygotes; that doesn't explain it.'

The new work was initially entitled How Did This Happen? The query, Adams noted, is not a quote from some unbelieving CNN correspondent in Bethlehem; it translates a Latin phrase in the Christmas antiphon. Nevertheless, he has just changed the oratorio's name. It will now be called El Niño. He told me this as we were walking through the Vancouver streets in driving rain. Wasn't El Niño, I asked, the demonic infant cradled in Pacific troughs, who might be dumping all this water on us? 'No, no,' he said. 'This is La Niña, she's his younger sister!" Off he waded beneath his umbrella to keep his appointment with destiny.

Before we parted, he had a request. As aware of his public identity and his place in history as the politicians in Nixon, he said: 'I hope you won't mention that I asked to have that Muzak turned off? I wouldn't want to look like a snob.'

A trickster myself, I shook his soggy hand and gave him my solemn promise. Coyotes may be cunning, but so are dingoes.

Nixon in China opens at the Coliseum, London (020 7632 8300), on Wednesday and runs in repertory until 21 June

fields.headline: It's a jungle out there... if you're a trombonist
fields.trailText: Rediscovered musical oddities have given the BOC Covent Garden Festival its own disinctive stamp of charm. You would have to have been in a very grumpy mood not to enjoy the latest, a soap-operatic precursor of Are You Being Served? featuring self-tying bow ties, French polyester knickers and flower-patterned chamber pots.
fields.body:
BOC Covent Garden Festival

BBC Music Live

Rediscovered musical oddities have given the BOC Covent Garden Festival its own disinctive stamp of charm. You would have to have been in a very grumpy mood not to enjoy the latest, a soap-operatic precursor of Are You Being Served? featuring self-tying bow ties, French polyester knickers and flower-patterned chamber pots. Who says opera doesn't inhabit the real world? It's not easy to find the name of Mischa Spoliansky in a dictionary of music. A minor Russian-German composer, he flourished in Berlin until Hitler came to power, when he escaped to London, wrote anti-Nazi music and the scores for nearly four dozen films. Later he began painting portraits of Marlene Dietrich and other friends, reputedly giving up when he ran out of wall space. His works still enjoy regular performances in German-speaking countries. In Britain, he is virtually unknown.

His hilarious 1932 satire, Send for Mr Plim (Rufen Sie Herrn Plim!) was a highlight of this year's festival, semi-staged by Paul Curran and designed by Rodney Grant. This was a UK premiere (an abridged and revamped version at Battersea Arts Centre last year is a matter of some dispute). The festival's director, Kenneth Richardson, provided a witty new translation which was conspicuously faithful to the music. The setting is a department store where the customers always complain and are always right. A scapegoat must be found. Mr Plim (Harry Nicoll), 'whose chances are slim', has to take the blame for every ill. His masters will feign his instant dismissal every time anyone complains, thus demonstrating to the customer that action has been taken.

This offers an opportunity for several delicious set pieces, redolent of Berlin café-cum-cabaret in the style of Weill, though less biting. Frances McCafferty works herself into a frenzy as the monstrous, fur-bedecked Frau von Recklitz, 'President and Top Dog of the Women's Institute of Spandau'. Lillian Watson rages in a parodying coloratura aria in which, as a wealthy shopaholic, she maps out her purchasing world: Brussels for chocs, Switzerland for socks and for a pin, only Berlin will do. She finds the pin but the shop refuses to deliver it to the car. It's all silly, frothy and fun. Well cast and smartly, if a little smoothly, played by the BBC Concert Orchestra conducted by Robert Ziegler, this was a thoroughly engaging 45 minutes.

Marie McLaughlin, with dancer Maxine Fone, completed the double-bill with a strong account of Weill's Seven Deadly Sins. Look out for the Radio 3 broadcast. Other festival events included a superb concert of Tudor church music by The Sixteen at Temple Church as part of their 'choral pilgrimage' and a new opera by Roxanna Panufnik (b1968). This 75-minute work is based on Paul Micou's zany novel The Music Programme, with a libretto by the author. Set in an African jungle, it features a United Nations-funded music camp now being investigated by a UN envoy. All the oddball musicians who have enjoyed its patronage for years now have to account for themselves, with bizarre results. This concoction of ingredients, from the frustrated wife who obsessively practises Mozart to the indolent, alcoholic slide trombonist, gives Panufnik scope for jungle sounds, African and jazz rhythms and classical pastiche. The Linbury Studio acoustic does not help the singing voice when it comes to hearing words, and made this episodic work confusing to follow but the Teatr Wielki-Polish National Opera per formed with commitment.

The rain must have helped BBC Music Live win a bigger audience than it deserved. I confess to total bafflement over this scatter-gun affair, which is frustratingly vague in aim and ethos. Despite assiduous study of the Radio Times and other publicity material, I could find no comprehensive list of events except by trial, error and much flicking of pages, like piecing together a jigsaw in the dark. On Radio 3, the Wigmore Hall's Haydn/Bartok Quartetathon (a word to make the bravest cringe) was relayed at so many different times of day I missed it all. And on what grounds was the violinist Maxim Vengerov's Barbican recital, recorded the previous week, tagged as part of the extravaganza whereas the pianist Leif Ove Andsnes's, in the same slot the day before, was not? But pity poor Radio 3 being tarred with this Music Live brush. The network was only doing what it does without anyone's help every day.

The thinking behind the jumble of broadcasts across networks on Bank Holiday Monday was simply too arcane to penetrate. BBC Young Musicians 2000, with its gifted winner, 18-year old cellist Guy Johnston, had a welcome coherence but nothing much to do with Music Live (which it wasn't). But where was the BBC's commitment to living composers? By chance I stumbled across Roald Dahl's Revolting Concert from Cardiff (BBC1), only listed in tiny print (though it provided all the next day's newspaper pictures owing to the presence of the author's granddaughter, Sophie Dahl). Dahl's rhymes were set to interesting music by Tobias Picker, Eleanor Alberga, Kurt Schwertsik and others. Was it new? Was it specially written? No one said.

As for the live, heavily cut and costly Marriage of Figaro, you'd hardly expect a niggling music critic to be the target audience but who was? The small straw poll of people I asked, including children of an age and inclincation to enjoy it, had abandoned the struggle early on, bored, cross and confused. Why, they asked, was it not in the original language with subtitles then at least they'd have grasped what was going on. Now we know what the Doming down of music is like, give me Top of the Pops any day. What a ghastly BBC muddle. Roll on the Proms.

fields.headline: Pecking orders
fields.standfirst: The Erotic Review's editor has whooped it up at five hen nights over 10 years, each of which charted the changing status of women and proved that girls have more fun - and better strippers
fields.trailText: When I was 12, I remember discussing with my sister, Holly, and our closest friends our prospects for the year 2000. We would be 32 by then, decrepit Sevenoaks housewives with several children, incapable of having fun. The prospect didn't distress us; we just accepted it as our destiny.
fields.body:
When I was 12, I remember discussing with my sister, Holly, and our closest friends our prospects for the year 2000. We would be 32 by then, decrepit Sevenoaks housewives with several children, incapable of having fun. The prospect didn't distress us; we just accepted it as our destiny.

Twenty years have flown past and our expectations have been splendidly confounded - we still have fun and none of us lives in Sevenoaks. However, of the nine of us, five are married, an unusually high proportion by today's standards. Holly got married a month ago and as I undertook the exacting task of organising her hen night it occurred to me that, just as Christmas is the one reliable date when you'll see your entire family, hen nights are the only time when a group of frantically busy women are guaranteed a proper reunion.

These reunions have become such a ritual that they should no longer be hostages to fortune and a bobby-dazzler from Tiffany's. Any of our circle should be able to claim her hen night as a rite of passage and a chance to reflect that girls are a girl's best friend.

The five hen nights my group of friends have already celebrated span eight years and cover an age gap of 10 years - the first of us to get married was 24 at the time, while my sister is now 34. Each event was rigorously recorded for posterity and as I sift through the stills I realise that I am looking at a photo-essay that charts the evolution of working women over the Nineties, that peculiarly feminine decade which saw the rapid rise of women in the workplace and the near eradication of old, male-dominated industries.

The professional lives of the women in our group reflect those changes; only two, both doctors, work in the public sector; five of us work in the booming service and communication industries (an accountant, a marketing executive, two journalists and a photographer); one is a full-time mother; the last is a single parent, eco-warrior and tree-hugger who works part-time as a Yoga teacher, a drama teacher to small children and a carer in an old people's home. We couldn't be more representative of professions and concerns that are increasingly colonised by women.

Hen nights, in themselves, helped define the new order. They don't even exist if you go back beyond the Eighties. There may have been all-girl parties evolved from the American tradition of a 'bridal shower', but these were sedate affairs. Women, went the thinking, embraced marriage without a backward glance. Marriage, for women, was a vocation. Men, on the other hand, had stag parties because they were abandoning the carefree life of the bachelor and so were entitled to one last fling.

Feminism changed all that. The hen night was a natural spin-off of the sisters' more landmark victories: if women were entitled to equal opportunities in the workplace, then they were bloody well entitled to a drunken night out with their mates and some spirited entertainment from a stripper.

The evolution of my school friends away from potential recruits to the gin and Volvo brigade of Sevenoaks housewifery was gradual. When I look at photos of our 24-year-old selves, I can scratch the surface and see the laddered Lycra of just relinquished student days. Bee and Rachael are still at St Bart's, not quite through their final medical examinations; Olly is on a BBC trainees' course; Polly and Holly have just been to Russia on some sort of ecologically-sound exchange scheme; Sally and Lizzie have a toehold on the corporate rung, and I'm about to be sacked from my job as editor's PA at GQ .

The bride-to-be, Sarah, is as keen as mustard to get banged up and start painting nurseries. Giving up her job is no problem - her fiancé is easily able to keep a roof over her head. So far, so traditional. I catch Sarah's bouquet, and when I get married, two years later, it will be a similar story. My income is negligible and my career prospects poor, my spouse-to-be older than me and tolerant. Mostly, I sit on the sofa at home, eating chocolates and reading novels. But the seeds of change are in the air: Sally and Lizzie already have new company cars (a swanky BMW in Sally's case). And when I'm ill on my hen weekend, the medics are now qualified enough to tell me blithely that I mustn't worry about combining antibiotics with alcohol - they never do.

These two first hen weekends, in the early Nineties, reveal us as worthy precursors of the ladette brigade. Both take place in Brighton, with the seediest hotels we can possibly find as our bases, packed in four to a room. Both entail a group of about 18 women tracking down every karaoke bar, every disco (and we mean D.I.S.C.O), and passable-looking straight man over the age of consent. Both share the adornment of a male stripper, in fact, the very same stripper. Mikey (a dental technician by day) is so good that he is called out of retirement for my hen weekend. One of the reasons Mikey is good is that he never leaves and is not averse to couching down, in time-honoured fashion, with one of the hens.

On Sarah's hen weekend, the task of finding straight men who aren't strippers is made easier when we discover we are sharing our hotel with an entire stag party. Within 24 hours, the groom has proposed to Sarah's cousin and she has slapped him for his perfidy. Despite this perky interchange, we are struck by how dull stag nights are compared to the frolics enjoyed by hens. The average stag night consists of drinking, a stripper, more drinking. And that's it. (My husband found the prospect of a stag night so unappealing that he stayed at home and watched The Right Stuff instead.)

The male bondng thing is rubbish - men who don't know one another are unlikely to return from a stag party as mates, but women often make new bosom friends on a hen night. On the hen nights I've been on, we've variously told ghost stories, re-enacted the scene of espousal, with sound effects, played sardines and lain on the beach and done a Mexican wave of air-inflated stomachs. When these things pall, there's always that inexhaustible topic of conversation: sex. About 80 per cent of my sexual knowledge comes from hen-party conversations.

By the time Bee gets married, in 1998, things have evolved again. She is marrying a fellow doctor and they're pretty much on an equal footing. Her hen night is more sophisticated than Sarah's and mine. It's a night out in London, starting at a cocktail bar, moving on to a chic Soho restaurant and then to Car Wash, the Seventies disco. The 16 or so women could be described as young, urban professionals. Even the sex aids we lavish upon Bee are expensive, de luxe models. The mood is spendthrift and reckless. Sarah is the only mother, one boy and a girl on the way; the rest have put it on hold. Sally and Lizzie have whizzy new jobs and I have become editor of an obscure erotic journal. The pace is fast, there's a whiff of excess in the air and our livers are becoming frailer. The two-day hangover has become a harsh reality.

By the winter of 1999, a month before Sally's wedding (to my little brother), there is a noticeable shift. The more ambitious members of our group of nine are becoming mellower. We're in our thirties and the disco, stripper, thing is less appealing. It's hardly a body-blow when we receive an invitation for a weekend in a Cotswold farmhouse. In fact, it's what we feel like. There's a spot of karaoke for old time's sake, but the real highlights are a long walk and the group cooking sessions. Clearly, we're getting old.

Sarah lies in bed, heavily pregnant, and you can feel the hormonal surge as we lay hands on her bulging stomach. When you look outside the house, there's a whole row of gleaming cars. Lizzie has a sporty little Puma, Sally a Golf GTI, while Sarah has a vast, new Jeep thing. And these cars normally live outside equally desirable residences. My friends have become women of property. When Hereward marries Sally, he will marry a cottage in Kent and a professional older woman, a couple of years his senior, who earns 'considerably more' than he does.

And the trend continues. Holly also marries a strapping younger man who is not, as yet, in the same income bracket. And when I organise her hen night, the invitees included a cluster of women in their mid-thirties who are dropping babies left, right and centre. It is clear that we're into a whole new ball game. Money is less of an object; comfort, and the chance of a long night's sleep, is at a premium. What we need is a house that's both large enough to house 16 women, several of whom are heavily pregnant, and is hospitable terrain to a smattering of infants.

We are talking grand luxe: we want sofas, Agas and blazing log fires. Luckily, Rural Retreats (an agency that lets country houses equipped to the standard of country-house hotels) comes up trumps with Bruisyard Hall, a spectacular manor house in Suffolk which, appropriately enough, had once been a nunnery. Whereas once we pined for all-night raves and cheap thrills, now we pine for a weekend of lie-ins and girl talk. The tatty glamour of Brighton gives way to the dappled bricks, deer forest and sunlit meadows of Bruisyard. And there are no regrets.

Well, not many. Personally, I always think it's a shame if a woman waves goodbye to her single status without a final, good, hard stare at the gonads of some naked man who is not her husband. So, it is fortunate that two stray travellers, dressed only in highwayman's robes, masks and tricorn hats, should stray to that part of remote Suffolk and hammer on the door of Bruisyard Hall around midnight on the day of our grand hen banquet, and fortunate indeed that it's the bride-to-be who opens the door just as they carelessly expose their nether quarters to the elements. I suppose there are some things you just never grow out of.

webTitle: But if only they had a bass player...

fields.headline: But if only they had a bass player...
fields.trailText: They may be be named after a road junction back home in Oregon, but Sleater-Kinney are far from dull. Indeed, they are the latest example of a metaphorically quiet, but actually loud, revolution on the margins of pop. Not only are they all-female, but they don't have a bass player. How many more rules of rock can they break?
fields.body:
They may be be named after a road junction back home in Oregon, but Sleater-Kinney are far from dull. Indeed, they are the latest example of a metaphorically quiet, but actually loud, revolution on the margins of pop. Not only are they all-female, but they don't have a bass player. How many more rules of rock can they break?

The sound on their third album, All Hands on the Bad One , is fiery and angular. Thanks mostly to lead singer Corin Tucker's rich voice and barbed lyrics, the group they evoke most is the great English post-punk quartet, the Au Pairs, but with sweet harmonies.

Sitting in the bar at the ICA in London, Tucker and drummer Janet Weiss do most of the talking, the third member, Carrie Brownstein, being almost supernaturally shy. Ask after influences and Weiss will offer the Clash, REM and the Dream Syndicate. Tucker, whose father teaches psychology and is an amateur musician, grew up with his Velvet Underground and Patti Smith records, later taking inspiration from Sonic Youth, Kristen Hirsch and the wilfully shambolic Bikini Kill, who 'changed everything for me'.

I wonder if Sleater-Kinney was always intended to be male-free? Tucker, whose easy manner barely hints at her intensity on stage, answers indirectly. 'I'm interested in the kind of dynamics women have with each other. I think it's a really powerful creative force and I think that there are so many things hidden beneath the surface of women, so many internalised notions of what we should do and be, that it's really difficult to work with each other. The process of examining those is a challenge, but is interesting.'

So you chose this form because it seemed difficult? 'Not just that. It has a special meaning to people. When you see these three women playing this powerful music, it really means something. Also, there's still this issue for women who sing in bands, with people saying, "Oh, she's just the singer". That doesn't happen.'

The three are still told they need a bassist, but rightly agree that the deftness of their sound owes much to the lack of one. All Hands on the Bad One is more confident and refined than their nevertheless superb last effort, The Hot Rock.

Tucker suggests a growing joy in playing with the conventions of the rock tradition as part of the reason for this. 'We listen to a lot and are knowledgeable about what's gone before. We're just not very interested in regurgitating it.'

Asked whether people are intimidated by their aggression in performance, Tucker shoots back: 'Oh yeah', as though the answer was blindingly obvious. The opening tune on this record is called 'The Ballad of a Ladyman, I remember'. Are they the ladymen? All three look at each other and grin, Tucker proceeding to tell the tale of an appearance they made at last year's Bowlie Weekender at Camber Sands, hosted by Scottish band Belle & Sebastian. There was a blackboard in the artists' reception area, indicating which chalets the groups had been assigned. Next to theirs, someone had scrawled 'Chalet 216: ladymen - yes'. It became a joke, though it unsettled them.

'I think it's as much to do with the way we deliver the message,' says Weiss. 'We're maybe a little bit more wild, more reluctant to play things by the book. It was strange, even in that little indie-rock world, where everything's supposed to be cool and liberated, someone had their guard up because we're an all-woman band.'

'We're not like these little Scottish girls,' Tucker adds with a leer. 'Or boys. We're more manly than most of those indie-rock boys. We could just crush them!'

webTitle: First you don't see it - now you do

fields.headline: First you don't see it - now you do
fields.standfirst: The Gilbert Collection is worth millions. The previously hidden courtyard it uncovers is priceless
fields.trailText: To judge by his wax effigy, Arthur Gilbert is a genial old cove. Even though he was born in London he has the sun-filled permanent half smile of decades of Californian affluence. And he has chosen to have himself portrayed in shorts and sneakers working at his desk at the exit of the Gilbert Collection
fields.body:
Somerset House , London WC2

Dulwich Picture Gallery SE21

Wallace Collection , W1

To judge by his wax effigy, Arthur Gilbert is a genial old cove. Even though he was born in London he has the sun-filled permanent half smile of decades of Californian affluence. And he has chosen to have himself portrayed in shorts and sneakers working at his desk at the exit of the Gilbert Collection, Britain's newest museum, recently opened by the Queen Mother no less, which certainly shows a certain wit.

The room around him, deep in the bowels of Somerset House, is an exact replica of his office back in Los Angeles. The walls are cluttered with a disarmingly artless collection of family pictures, photographs, portraits, and the bric-a-brac of a life rich in incident. I couldn't see it, but there is no doubt a Tiffany framed copy of the certificate from the College of Osteopathic Medicine in 1994 naming him Humanitarian of the Year somewhere, along with the parchment that testifies that he is an honorary trustee of the Armand Hammer United World College of the American West.

It's not exactly Jeremy Bentham, whose embalmed remains have been propped up in a glass case at the main entrance to University College in London ever since he died. But it is an installation uncomfortably reminiscent of the funeral rites of the wealthier type of ancient Egyptian, a reminder of just how closely museums are still linked with the search for immortality.

Presumably accommodating a wax dummy is a price well worth paying - along with £20.75 million from the Heritage Lottery Fund - to secure what the fund suggest is 'one of the most important gifts ever made to the British nation', a £100m collection of gold, silver and mosaic of an elaboration that would have silenced even the late Barbara Cartland.

But waxworks are something of a new departure for British museums. The Metropolitan Museum in New York may have been reduced to accepting bequests specifying that paintings are displayed in exactly the same configuration in which they hung in the donor's living room, but in Europe even such a figure as Baron Thyssen, not generally noted for his natural reticence, was content with nothing more than a portrait hanging on the pink entrance wall of the otherwise chaste Thyssen Museum in Madrid. And that is stuffed full of enough old masters to eclipse Gilbert's snuff boxes.

The museum, it must be said, is beautifully designed by the architects, Peter Inskip and Peter Jenkins, with the display installation by 3D Concepts in consultation with Dyson Design.

But whatever the attractions of such treasures on show - as giddying in their range as the silver gates presented by Catherine the Great to the monastery of Pechersk Lavra in Kiev, and a coconut shell into which the Stations of the Cross have been worked in fine detail - it is not the Gilbert Collection that is Somerset House's biggest draw. It is the sudden revelation of one of London's most magnificent and unknown urban spaces.

Somerset House was begun in 1776 by Sir William Chambers, with later additions by Sir Robert Smirke, and Sir James Pennethorne. It was one of the first purpose-built office blocks in the world, the birthplace of Britain's modern civil service. It was from here that Britain ran its Navy, administered its records for births, deaths and marriages, and collected taxes. The Inland Revenue still clings on to some of the building, though not for much longer.

Chambers created what is outwardly a palace, approached both from the river, and from the Strand to the north. A great white Portland stone facade sits on a massive rusticated base looking out over the Thames, ranged around a monumental courtyard.

The Gilbert Museum is an important building block in a long-term plan to bring the whole of this magnificent complex of indoor and outdoor spaces fully into public use for the first time. Wandering through the Piranesian interiors that climb from the Gilbert Collection in the basement, through the range of rooms earmarked for a display of works from the Hermitage, you become forcefully aware of the presence of the past.

What was an invisible everyday smudge on the landscape, hidden by buses and traffic, is suddenly revealed as completely out of the ordinary, a building which despite its unassuming urbanity is nevertheless a place in which decisions were made that affected countless lives.

The shock of the sudden discovery feels a little like going on holiday in your own town and seeing it for the first time.

Two decades ago, the courtyard in Somerset House would have been turned into a shopping mall along the lines of Covent Garden. Since then, we have grown up about cities and it is now thankfully being left almost alone - cleaned, tidied, floodlit, embellished by fountains that are the work of Jeremy Dixon and Edward Jones.

There will be a café, and other galleries inside. But the courtyard and the newly opened river terrace will be primarily a place for events, for people to gather for concerts, to sit outside, to watch performances, or simply to eat their sandwiches.

Under the direction of Timothy Sainsbury, the Somerset House Trust - working with Jacob Rothschild who secured the Gilbert Collection - an extremely sophisticated attempt is being made to give London a new kind of urban space, and to teach us how to use it. Given the present state of Trafalgar Square and Leicester Square we will need all the help we can get.

Two other Lottery projects in London, both the work of Rick Mather, an architect who has recently established himself as an important influence on London's cultural landscape with his masterplan for the South Bank Centre, show an equal level of sophistication in addressing historic architecture.

Mather's reordering of the amenities of Dulwich Picture Gallery, built by Sir John Soane between 1811 and 1814, is a model of discretion in the presence of one of the most sublime pieces of architecture anywhere, while the new sculpture garden for the Wallace Collection does a marvellous job of extracting coherence and calm from a house that has been constantly worked and reworked over the past century, and which boasts a collection just as florid as Arthur Gilbert's.

Even though he was born in London he has the sun-filled permanent half smile of decades of Californian affluence. And he has chosen to have himself portrayed in shorts and sneakers working at his desk at the exit of the Gilbert Collection, Britain's newest museum, recently opened by the Queen Mother no less, which certainly shows a certain wit. The room around him, deep in the bowels of Somerset House, is an exact replica of his office back in Los Angeles. The walls are cluttered with a disarmingly artless collection of family pictures, photographs, portraits, and the bric-a-brac of a life rich in incident. I couldn't see it, but there is no doubt a Tiffany framed copy of the certificate from the College of Osteopathic Medicine in 1994 naming him Humanitarian of the Year somewhere, along with the parchment that testifies that he is an honorary trustee of the Armand Hammer United World College of the American West. It's not exactly Jeremy Bentham, whose embalmed remains have been propped up in a glass case at the main entrance to University College in London ever since he died. But it is an installation uncomfortably reminiscent of the funeral rites of the wealthier type of ancient Egyptian, a reminder of just how closely museums are still linked with the search for immortality. Presumably accommodating a wax dummy is a price well worth paying - along with £20.75 million from the Heritage Lottery Fund - to secure what the fund suggest is 'one of the most important gifts ever made to the British nation', a £100m collection of gold, silver and mosaic of an elaboration that would have silenced even the late Barbara Cartland. But waxworks are something of a new departure for British museums. The Metropolitan Museum in New York may have been reduced to accepting bequests specifying that paintings are displayed in exactly the same configuration in which they hung in the donor's living room, but in Europe even such a figure as Baron Thyssen, not generally noted for his natural reticence, was content with nothing more than a portrait hanging on the pink entrance wall of the otherwise chaste Thyssen Museum in Madrid. And that is stuffed full of enough old masters to eclipse Gilbert's snuff boxes. The museum, it must be said, is beautifully designed by the architects, Peter Inskip and Peter Jenkins, with the display installation by 3D Concepts in consultation with Dyson Design. But whatever the attractions of such treasures on show - as giddying in their range as the silver gates presented by Catherine the Great to the monastery of Pechersk Lavra in Kiev, and a coconut shell into which the Stations of the Cross have been worked in fine detail - it is not the Gilbert Collection that is Somerset House's biggest draw. It is the sudden revelation of one of London's most magnificent and unknown urban spaces. Somerset House was begun in 1776 by Sir William Chambers, with later additions by Sir Robert Smirke, and Sir James Pennethorne. It was one of the first purpose-built office blocks in the world, the birthplace of Britain's modern civil service. It was from here that Britain ran its Navy, administered its records for births, deaths and marriages, and collected taxes. The Inland Revenue still clings on to some of the building, though not for much longer. Chambers created what is outwardly a palace, approached both from the river, and from the Strand to the north. A great white Portland stone facade sits on a massive rusticated base looking out over the Thames, ranged around a monumental courtyard. The Gilbert Museum is an important building block in a long-term plan to bring the whole of this magnificent complex of indoor and outdoor spaces fully into public use for the first time. Wandering through the Piranesian interiors that climb from the Gilbert Collection in the basement, through the range of rooms earmarked for a display of works from the Hermitage, you become forcefully aware of the presence of the past. What was an invisible everyday smudge on the landscape, hidden by buses and traffic, is suddenly revealed as completely out of the ordinary, a building which despite its unassuming urbanity is nevertheless a place in which decisions were made that affected countless lives. The shock of the sudden discovery feels a little like going on holiday in your own town and seeing it for the first time. Two decades ago, the courtyard in Somerset House would have been turned into a shopping mall along the lines of Covent Garden. Since then, we have grown up about cities and it is now thankfully being left almost alone - cleaned, tidied, floodlit, embellished by fountains that are the work of Jeremy Dixon and Edward Jones. There will be a café, and other galleries inside. But the courtyard and the newly opened river terrace will be primarily a place for events, for people to gather for concerts, to sit outside, to watch performances, or simply to eat their sandwiches. Under the direction of Timothy Sainsbury, the Somerset House Trust - working with Jacob Rothschild who secured the Gilbert Collection - an extremely sophisticated attempt is being made to give London a new kind of urban space, and to teach us how to use it. Given the present state of Trafalgar Square and Leicester Square we will need all the help we can get. Two other Lottery projects in London, both the work of Rick Mather, an architect who has recently established himself as an important influence on London's cultural landscape with his masterplan for the South Bank Centre, show an equal level of sophistication in addressing historic architecture. Mather's reordering of the amenities of Dulwich Picture Gallery, built by Sir John Soane between 1811 and 1814, is a model of discretion in the presence of one of the most sublime pieces of architecture anywhere, while the new sculpture garden for the Wallace Collection does a marvellous job of extracting coherence and calm from a house that has been constantly worked and reworked over the past century, and which boasts a collection just as florid as Arthur Gilbert's.

fields.headline: Two men in a U-boat
fields.trailText: Hollywood, so far, has found two action blockbusters for 2000. One is Gladiator, the return of the Roman epic. The other is this Boy's Own yarn about Second World War submarine derring-do. Both have their special effects, but neither seeks to make a display of them. Old-fashioned adventure returns with an added punch. Movies can do what they do best naturally.
fields.body:
U-571 (116 mins, 12) Directed by Jonathan Mostow; starring Matthew McConaughey, Harvey Keitel

This is a week for the simple virtues: pace, professionalism, verve. It is what separates U-571 from the rest of a disconsolate pack - and thereby, perhaps, hangs a broader thesis. Hollywood, so far, has found two action blockbusters for 2000. One is Gladiator, the return of the Roman epic. The other is this Boy's Own yarn about Second World War submarine derring-do. Both have their special effects, but neither seeks to make a display of them. Old-fashioned adventure returns with an added punch. Movies can do what they do best naturally.

So, it's 1942 again and Hitler's U-boats, shielded by the uncrackable Enigma code, are sinking Allied convoys at will. But one German sub, the eponymous 571, gets cornered and badly damaged in mid-Atlantic. Its calls for help are intercepted back in the good old USA, though, and Captain Bill Paxton and crew are dispatched to pose as a Nazi rescue mission, seize the wounded sub and get hold of the vital Enigma code kit. You need no gift of prophesy to guess at the second hour of mayhem. The only question is who lives and who dies.

What's on offer? Not his torical accuracy to events 'inspired' by the exploits of Brit (not Yankee) crews. This is a very contorted Enigma variation. Not any profound exploration of claustrophobia and fear 160 metres deep. Das Boot might never have existed. Not even gimcrack philosophy. Nobody soliloquises about the futility of war; nobody, indeed, suggests that such a thought would ripple the blandness of their minds. No, this is a movie of 40 years ago come back to find a modern audience - and Jonathan Mostow delivers with elan.

Mostow is one of the new, young directors who knows how to fire impact from standard scenarios. He showed that, a couple of years ago, in Breakdown (when a distraught Kurt Russell lost his wife in the desert inhabited by J.T. Walsh and other menacing flakes). He shows it again here - and his style is to seem to possess no style. The storytelling is always terse and clear. No little directorial flourishes or curlicues. Nothing gets lost in the gloom of the boat. Psychological complexity is how First Lieutenant Matthew McConaughey takes command and learns to be a man - but even that requires only 1.5 changes of facial expression. The rest of a cast mostly devoid of stars is asked to be athletic, drilled and virtually interchangeable. Only Harvey Keitel, as the gnarled Chief Klough, is out of the age range and treading oddly shallow water, in search, presumably, of an untaxing pay day.

It would be false to claim much for U-571 beyond a compulsive competence, but that is also no mean virtue. The technical details are spot on, the inevitable leaks and creaks make you shiver in your seat. Nearly two hours go by without let, hindrance or longueur. All those weeks as champion of the American box office, until Gladiator came, provide their own testimony - and maybe signal a movement back to Hollywood basics.Who needs bloated sci-fi when seven men in a U-boat can whip up so much of a storm. If Mostow is going to make a career out of new wine in old bottles, he might try a western next.

Philip French is on holiday

webTitle: Travolta, Polanski, Ben Elton. You'd think one of them could get it right

fields.headline: Travolta, Polanski, Ben Elton. You'd think one of them could get it right
fields.trailText: Battlefield Earth | The Ninth Gate | Maybe Baby | Broken Vessels | Mal | The King of Paris | Wisconsin Death Trip | Shergar
fields.body:
Battlefield Earth (117 mins, PG) Directed by Roger Christian; starring John Travolta, Forest Whitaker

The Ninth Gate (133 mins, 15) Directed by Roman Polanski; starring Johnny Depp, Emmanuelle Seigner

Maybe Baby (104 mins, 15) Directed by Ben Elton; starring Hugh Laurie, Joely Richardson

Broken Vessels (91 mins, 18) Directed by Scott Ziehl; starring Todd Field, Jason London

Mal (85 mins, 18) Directed by Alberto Seixas Santos; starring Sofia Aparico, Pauline Cadell

The King of Paris (102 mins, 12) Directed Dominique Maillet; starring Philipe Noiret

Wisconsin Death Trip (76 mins) Directed by James Marsh

Shergar (91mins, PG) Directed by Denis Lewiston; starring Ian Holm

The rest of the week is, essentially, a tale of three tragedies. Tragedy One, already a legendary Lear among turkeys, is Battlefield Earth, in which a few residual hairy human morons (circa AD3000) confront a race of hairy alien morons called Psychlos whose lust for gold doesn't extend to knowing about Fort Knox. John Travolta, plastically padded, plays the arch villain with an accent that rambles between Alan Rickman and Noël Coward. Forest Whitaker is his terminally stupid sidekick, Barry Pepper (from The Green Mile) the pig-tailed blond bombshell who saves our world. These are arguably fine actors. But nothing, of course, can save this enterprise.

L. Ron Hubbard, the father of scientology, wrote the original novel 20 years ago and Travolta, a loyal follower of L. Ron, has been dreaming of producing and starring in it for more than a decade. That's probably the real tragedy. The director, Roger Christian, won an Oscar for his Star Wars sets, but here his most relevant previous form seems to be Taco Bell commercials.

The computer special effects are by early Amstrad and the plot is a hirsute mystery. What was it supposed to be? Independence Day without the laughs? The Empire Strikes Out? The most desultory fact, as turkeys go, is that it isn't even a decent giggle. It doesn't, and you don't, have a clue. The wreck of reputation and judgment is absolute.

The Ninth Gate offers more poignant sorrow and pity in the guise of Tragedy Two. Roman Polanski directed some of the twentieth-century's most memorable movies - masterpieces such as Chinatown, precise terrors such as Rosemary's Baby. Where, through the barren Eighties and Nineties, has that talent gone? It lives here in the understated beginnings of this occult thriller as Johnny Depp's book-dealer hero is hired to track down the only three copies of an ancient satanic text which, properly pieced together, can summon Lucifer, but then, suddenly, everything goes to hell.

Barbara Jefford, as a bizarre German countess, is handed five minutes of unspeakable dialogue and immolated; Mrs Polanski (Emmanuelle Seigner, a very mature student) turns into a mix of Batgirl and Emma Peel; Frank Langella's evil genius sounds like the director-general of the CBI. The end is neither frightening nor funny, pure Eurotosh. No wonder Depp, toiling quietly away, looks dazed and confused.

But perhaps Tragedy Three, the direst of the lot, is Maybe Baby . Ben Elton can do anything, right? Tell stand-up jokes, churn out sitcoms, pen hit plays and bestselling books. Is there anything he can't do? The answer, alas, is that he can't write and direct a 'romantic comedy' about IVF (based on his own trueish-to-personal-life novel) in which a BBC producer in an infertile marriage turns author of a play about being a BBC producer in an infertile marriage. Pirandello times three. Even Fellini would have passed on that. The original Maybe Baby was just about tolerable because the novelist in Elton could talk directly to the reader and the embarrassments were private ones. Open the notion out on a big screen, though, dot it with crudely funny bits from Rowan Atkinson and Dawn French and endless shagging dog stories ('lay lines' and the rest), and romance dies with a cringe.

Joely Richardson's harassed wife looks sweetly stalwart in satin knickers with her legs in the air; Hugh Laurie's hubby bids for the sympathy vote. Elton merely points his camera at them and hopes for the best. Can you make a comedy about sperm counts and desperation? Probably. You can make a comedy about anything if you leave the humanity in. Here, though, the slapstick and the sniggers emerge so randomly as to appear merely callous. There's no self-awareness, no sense of discipline. The Lottery, for once, isn't to blame. This is a BBC production, so you paid directly, but no man from Auntie rode shotgun against the crassness. A tragedy of the ego.

The word on the (Wardour) street, meanwhile, is suitably downbeat. Don't expect much box-office cheer for the next few weeks. June is for football, not films - prime time to clear your distribution bottom drawer of stuff with no sell-by date. That means the terrible clinkers: but it also means a few interesting sales bargains. Broken Vessels (from 1998) is one such and Scott Ziehl, its director, is a talent to watch.

Fresh-faced Jason London, an innocent with a guilty secret, arrives in Los Angeles and lands a job as a privatised ambulance man alongside the entirely non-innocent Todd Field, who wants to be a cop, not a paramedic. He seems to have most of the relevant LA qualifications for that ambition: booze and drugs on the job, thievings to feed his habits. London is soon on the Faustian road to ruin and the two of them spiral towards hell in a welter of bloody accidents, dementia and deceptions. Grim? Of course. This is the Scorsese world of Bringing out the Dead and the strain is unrelenting. You can feel the nerve ends tear. But Ziehl has a gift for raw action and, better still, a pungent wit. The scene where London's camp flatmate leaves him in charge of his cherished goldfish for the weekend and our hung-over hero pukes in the tank is high comedy. Field provides a riveting study in moral disintegration; London congeals in a yellowed sweat of depravity. It all gets a little formulaic in the end, lost among druggy lurchings, yet the energy is compulsive.

Alberto Seixas Santos's Mal (or Evil), by coincidence, is really the LA of Magnolia translated to Lisbon. A middle-aged Irish woman (Pauline Cadell) is tortured by the infidelities of her infernally handsome lawyer husband (Rui Morrison); an old man from the country hunts for his runaway granddaughter; street kids rob and murder. And gradually the disparate tales are woven together into a human definition of the film's title.

What's good is the acting (from Cadell and Morrison especially, locked in a self-destructive passion they can't escape) and the detailed observation of a seedy, unfamiliar city. Seixas Santos draws his stories from the rhythms of ordinary life. What isn't so successful is a finale which swings almost apologetically into grand symbolism and is over in a trice. You wish it had rained frogs instead.

There are no such taxing moments to The King of Paris, trundling out an inexplicable five years after its French release - a theatrical piece in every sense. Philippe Noiret is Derval, the big star actor of the early Thirties, Wolfit bitten by bloodhound. He meets an ambitious Hungarian girl by the Seine, beds her and gives her a job. His son falls for her, too, so there's more tragedy and rivalry and hatred as the protégée (Veronika Varga) turns actress and outstrips her mentor.

It's a solid piece, full of velvet plush fit for a West End matinée and familiar Gallic faces grimacing to order. Dominique Maillet directs competently enough; Varga looks uncannily like Helena Bonham Carter and, triumphing in The Seagull, has some of her limpid quality. But this is really a custom-built vehicle for Noiret, moving between bombast, grief and ridiculous love with relaxed certainty. Great actor plays great actor? Collectors of ripe screen performances will want this one for their album. Buy now while stocks last.

Stocks of Wisconsin Death Trip will be only briefly available at the National Film Theatre before an Arena appointment on BBC2 in July. Either way, they're worth chasing. This isn't any sort of Texas Chainsaw Massacre, but a haunting docu-drama culled from the turn-of-the-century news columns of the local paper in Black River Falls, Wisconsin. The German, Norwegian and Polish settlers who came to scratch a living as farmers turn to murder or suicide or madness in a seemingly inexhaustible catalogue of actual horrors, delivered in elegiac tableaux by James Marsh. American life didn't somehow become a bizarre mixture of folksy sentiment and manic brutality: it was always thus, defined by desperation.

So to the bottom of the bottom drawer. How do you fancy a fairy tale called Shergar , in which the eponymous Derby winner is rescued from the IRA by a farm boy (Tom Walsh) and hidden behind the caravan of a charismatic literary tinker (Ian Holm)? A movie where Ireland is really the Isle of Man and Mickey Rourke plays a terrorist chieftain? If you're already making your excuses, you're not alone. The director (Denis Lewiston, from The Professionals and much other television) has had to form his own distribution company to give it an outing at the Odeon multiplex, Epsom.

And yet, in a way, you can understand his dogged wrath. This is a decently crafted, decently entertaining exercise. National Velvet reworked by Dick Francis. Holm looks as though he's enjoying it; Laura Murphy is a fragrant ingénue; only Rourke's amazing frozen-face job threatens the PG rating. In a better, less cynical world, horse-loving 12-year-olds would fill the stalls from Plumpton to Pontefract - and there would be no tragedies.

webTitle: How dare they call my film a turkey

fields.headline: How dare they call my film a turkey
fields.standfirst: The director of the new John Travolta epic defends himself against his many critics
fields.trailText: The director of the new John Travolta epic defends himself against his many critics
fields.body:
As art director on Life of Brian I witnessed first hand religious censorship when the finance was withdrawn on grounds of blasphemy. It was later that George Harrison who saw the script for what it was, fully funded it. Martin Scorsese's Last Temptation of Christ caused a similar outcry, severely damaging its release. Christians were objecting to the way that the life of Christ was being depicted in the movie.

John Travolta and I have been questioned by almost every journalist about the connection between Battlefield Earth and the Church of Scientology. This is a presumption made because L. Ron Hubbard, the author of the novel on which the movie is based wrote Dianetics and founded the Church of Scientology of which John Travolta is a member. Hubbard wrote the following in the preface to the novel, worried that he would be blamed by members of the Church for not including any of its beliefs and philosophies: 'I know that I will be accused of not including any of my serious work in this book, but I have put on my professional writers hat and written a science fiction novel.'

In 1982 science fiction was mostly about the cold technical world of robots and computers. Hubbard wanted to write a fast-paced, Pulp Fiction style tale of villains and heroes, with the archetypal hero's journey at its heart. He was the biggest selling author of pulp-fiction of his era and Stephen King calls Fear - another of his novels - 'a classic of its genre'.

I was offered the script of Battlefield Earth due to a combination of my film Nostradamus and my experience on Episode I: Phantom Menace and other Star Wars movies. What director would turn down the chance to work with John Travolta? So accepting a near impossible schedule and low budget restraints, I set out to try to pull off something unusual, aware that science fiction usually receives a lukewarm critical reception.

In America the inference is that Battlefield Earth contains scientology's philosophy and that subliminal messages are buried in the film. It is also suggested that revenues from the movie will somehow end up in the Church. This is not true.

To set the record straight, I am not a member of the Church of Scientology, nor, to my knowledge is any other member of the crew. The film was put together and produced by John Travolta's manager Jonathon Krane and entirely funded by Eli Samaha, both Jewish, and distributed by Warner Brothers. I believe we all have a right to choose whichever philosophy or religion fulfils our needs.

If a Jewish producer hired a Jewish writer to write a script, and then hired a Jewish director to make the film, do we cry 'Judaism' or judge the film for what it is?

The second myth put over in the US which I wish to dispel is that the movie cost $75-100 million dollars. I only had $14m for production and $9m for the special effects. When I directed the second unit for Phantom Menace, the special effects budget alone was $60m. The total Battlefield Earth budget including above the line costs is $51m, less than the cost of the sets of an average studio sci-fi action film. We grossed $12.5m on our opening weekend with a quarter of the advertising budget of any rival studio picture. With the entire budget of the film covered by foreign pre-sales, the US box office is already showing a $20m dollar profit.

The movie is obviously not to everyone's taste. Our decision was to follow the book closely and make the movie into a fast-paced comic strip with an ironic side to it. It's been labelled 'pulp science fiction'. Every shot in the movie was 'dutch-angled' (the camera was always slightly tilted in the way that comic illustrations are never level). George Lucas, Billy Bob Thornton and Quentin Tarantino have all told us how much they loved the movie. Tarantino told John Travolta that it would become a cult classic. They and the bulk of the audiences who have seen the movie so far, have enjoyed it for what it is - comic strip fun without pretension.

fields.headline: web watch
fields.trailText: One group of people delighted by the row over access to university for the less privileged are those at freefund, a new site 'providing the first, easily accessible internet database of thousands of UK student scholarships and bursaries'.
fields.body:
One group of people delighted by the row over access to university for the less privileged are those at freefund, a new site 'providing the first, easily accessible internet database of thousands of UK student scholarships and bursaries'.

More money is due to become available to poorer students, including new kinds of bursaries for about 10,000 of them next year.

The freefund idea is a relatively unusual one, but, at the other end of the originality spectrum, more and more sites are opening up for homebuyers. And many existing homebuying sites are introducing new frills as a way of generating a bit more publicity.

Netmortgage prides itself on scoring 'another first' - 'a facility to highlight Catmarked mortgages'. These are loans which can claim to meet the Government Cat standard (covering charges, accessibility and transparency). They do not tend to have the keenest rates on offer, but they do have sensible features to protect borrowers.

Compuserve, meanwhile, is publicising its 'mortgage calculator', which helps you work out how much mortgage lenders will be prepared to lend you and how much your monthly payments would be for different levels of loan.

Easier plc is letting potential sellers across the country register their properties for viewing by potential buyers. This is a free service, made possible because names of site users are made available to conveyancers, lenders and other companies that have something to sell.

Assertahome is another database of available properties which offers the ability to search by postcode (a very common facility on this kind of site), information on schools and local amenities, and links to lenders, estate agents and other players in the property market.

Moneysupermarket has recently launched another frill: a 'rate alert' system through which consumers can ask to receive emails if new mortgages and other products are launched with particularly good rates.

Many sites provide very similar information, and there are many signs that parts of the internet are getting very crowded.

Direct Travel Insurance has just put out a rather testy statement highlighting some of the problems: 'There is a very real danger that the public can be mistaking company identities when logging onto the internet. The protection of known and respected trading names is open to abuse on the internet where there is a Wild West type situation and some cowboys.'

www.netmortgage.co.uk

www.easier.co.uk

www.assertahome.com

www.moneysupermarket.com

www.direct-travel.co.uk
