webTitle: Refund on Time machine warranty doesn't add up

fields.headline: Refund on Time machine warranty doesn't add up
fields.standfirst: Has your bank, building society or insurer treated you badly? We seek justice for our readers
fields.trailText: Has your bank, building society or insurer treated you badly? We seek justice for our readers.
fields.body:
I took delivery of a Time computer on 24 December and was sold an extended warranty for £299 plus Vat (£351.32). The terms of the warranty were delivered with the computer and only then did I realise that they did not include as much as I had been told. I decided to cancel the warranty immediately. I was was unable to contact Time by phone so I wrote on 10 January. Despite six letters and numerous phone calls, I have heard nothing.
RB, Kirkcudbright

 With Money Writes' prompting, Time has agreed to refund the cost of the extended warranty, but only after deducting a £50 administration fee and £29.52 for the time that had elapsed between your receiving it and cancellation. This is grossly unfair as you tried to cancel the policy immediately and only because you had been misled about what you were buying. Time has now been persuaded to forward the full amount, although a subsequent phone call from Customer Services told you that they had refunded the cost excluding Vat. This error has been corrected and you should have received £351.32.

Mis-sold policy: Cash for distress

We complained to Standard Life about the mis-selling of an endowment policy in 1992. Standard Life upheld our complaint, admitting that our policy assumed investments would grow at 9.7 per cent a year, whereas it should have been 8.5 per cent, and offered to refund the premiums plus interest. We accept the offer, but feel they should also pay a small amount for the upset this caused. Since receiving the offer, however, we have learnt that there will shortly be a vote about Standard Life demutualising and that we could receive a windfall. What should we do?
GW, Newquay

 You can change your mind about not wanting the policy and ignore the fact that Standard Life agreed it was mis-sold. The offer stands for 30 days, after which the insurer closes the file. You will learn on 27 June whether Standard Life is demutualising, so you could wait till then before acting. Although this is outside the 30 days, you can ask the company to reopen the file and expect the same terms, with interest paid up to date.

If Standard Life is not forced to demutualise now, it could be at a later date, so you would have to decide whether you felt the policy had been mis-sold or whether to keep it in the hope of a windfall.

If you cancel it, you can ask for compensation but are unlikely to get it. The Ombudsman awards extra only rarely if a policyholder has suffered real distress.

Transfer assets: Avoiding tax

How can I find out about setting up a trust to transfer assets to my children to avoid inheritance tax, without consulting a solicitor in the first instance?
BM, Bristol

 Ask your bank or insurer for leaflets about making wills: some include information on trusts. Legal & General has a free 'Guide to Trusts' - ring 0500 909090.

Inland Revenue leaflet IR152 Trusts explains trusts and their taxation; IHT3 describes inheritance tax.

The Society of Trust and Estate Practitioners (Step) has a free leaflet 'Why Make a Trust?' Step is at PO Box 13272, Eagle House, 110 Jermyn Street, London SW1Y 6ZH. The Which? Guide to Giving and Inheriting covers trusts (£9.99 from bookshops or the Consumers' Association: 0800 252 1000).

 Write to Margaret Dibben, Money Writes, The Observer, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER and include a phone number. Do not enclose SAEs or original documents. Letters are selected for publication and we cannot give personal replies. The newspaper accepts no legal responsibility for advice.

fields.headline: What's the catch?
fields.trailText: A body called the Consumer Enrichment Centre has been inviting readers around the country to take part in a contest for a first prize of £6,000.
fields.body:
A body called the Consumer Enrichment Centre has been inviting readers around the country to take part in a contest for a first prize of £6,000.

To enter you must complete the simple qualifying task of circling the words 'gold' and 'win' in the following mixture of letters 'flagoldrawinter', fill in the processing and entry form and include a payment for £5. To encourage you to take part, the mailshot says: 'I have seen thousands of pounds slip away from people like you because they failed to respond. Do not be one of them. Send your £6,000 Processing & Entry form now.'

The Advertising Standards Authority has already been asked by Derby and Hampshire councils to investigate the mailing on the grounds that it exaggerated the chances of winning a large cash prize.

The ASA agreed that the headline and body copy of the mailing implied the recipient had a good chance of winning.

The watchdog body has asked the Con sumer Enrichment Centre to make clear in future mailings that it is simply issuing an invitation to consumers to take part in a competition.

The small print of the promotional literature states that 500,000 entries are expected, of which 375,000 contestants or 75 per cent are expected to circle the words correctly, 75,000 or 20 per cent are expected to get the level two tiebreaker right, and 1,500 or 2 per cent are expected to submit the level three final tiebreaker. One reader who sent this mailshot in to 'What's the Catch?' says: 'I note that they expect entries worth £2.5m, for a total of £12,000 in cash prizes, and that prizes can be increased by up to 50 per cent at an additional cost of up to £90.

'Sounds like a good profit margin.'

 The Royal Mail has published a free guide to controlling what mail you receive and how to improve your chances of winning competitions. For a copy write to: Freepost Fair Play.

Have you seen a mailshot or advertisement that looks too good to be true? Write to 'What's the Catch?', The Observer, 119 Farringdon road, London EC1R 3ER.

webTitle: Help me keep my head above water

fields.headline: Help me keep my head above water
fields.standfirst: At 52, Maureen Maguire has quit the rat race to study art. Can she get by without the millstone of a student loan, she asks  Helen Pridham
fields.trailText: At 52, Maureen Maguire has quit the rat race to study art. Can she get by without the millstone of a student loan, she asks Helen Pridham
fields.body:
Vital statistics Maureen Maguire
Age: 52
Lives in: South London
Occupation: Student
Earns: Nil
Mortgage: £27,500
Debts: None
Investments: £3,000 in a Tessa, £6,000 in a Pep, £18,000 in an Egg postal account, shares
Pension: Past membership of three employers' schemes
Aim: To find the best way to make use of her savings to fund a three-year university course

Maureen was made redundant from the corporate finance department of a merchant bank around 18 months ago. She is delighted to have escaped the City rat race and to be doing something which she really enjoys. Since last September she has been attending a foundation year course in art and design at Lewisham College and later this year she is hoping to start a three-year degree course in fine art and art history. At the same time she has been studying for a qualification in physiology, anatomy and massage and plans to study reflexology at evening classes next year.

Her ultimate goal is to have her own business - doing some art, counselling and massage. She says she envisages herself being the feel-good person in people's lives. 'I still have many friends who work in the City who hate their jobs but they have to continue working to keep the money coming in. I really don't want to get back into that position,' Maureen says.

In the meantime, though, she wants help to find the best way of keeping her head above water using her existing financial resources while she is studying.

'I don't particularly want to take student loans because I know I will have to pay them back again.' By living frugally, Maureen hopes she can get by. She has calculated she needs about £10,000 a year to make ends meet. Fortunately, her endowment mortgage is small and only costs her a modest £150 per month.

Maureen's main source of money for the future is the redundancy payment of £25,000 which she got from her last employer. She used it to set up a Tessa and a Pep and open an Egg account. She also has approximately 1,000 shares in Lloyds TSB from an employee share-save scheme and a similar amount in the shares of her previous employers, Close Brothers.

Over the past year she has managed to survive on money she saved while temping after she was made redundant. She is hoping to get some more secretarial work during the summer holidays this year to boost her coffers although she feels her age often counts against her. She realises that another potential source of income is to let out a room in her three-bedroom home but she is reluctant to do this unless she has to as she likes having her own space.

One thing she is not too worried about is her pension provision. During her working life she has accumulated several job-related pensions. One is a small pension from her first job which she had forgotten about until she recently discovered some old documents. On enquiry she found that will provide her with around £500 per year when she gets to age 60. More importantly, however, she has a pension from Hill Samuel where she worked for more than 17 years which she believes will be in the region of £10,000-£11,000 a year.

Finally, she will also receive a small pension from her most recent employers, Close Brothers.

Adviser 1: Gillian Cardy
First of all, I would suggest Maureen makes full use of this year's Isa allowance to invest £7,000 in a high-yield bond fund for a high, tax-free income. She may wish to consider using some shares to fund the subscription.

Any other capital not needed for living expenses should be gradually phased into Isas in future tax years to build a fund of tax-free income. Her existing Pep could also be switched within Gartmore to a high-yield bond fund to generate income.

In the short term, a student loan is a possibility. A more radical solution is to consider a transfer of her pensions into one personal pension plan and consider drawing the benefits now. This entails a detailed assessment of what she would be giving up at 60 in return for income now. But the reason why this might prove attractive is because most company pension schemes allow for payment of a spouse's pension. If she was to transfer the value of the pensions, this would be allowed for in the transfer value, but she would not be required to use the transfer value to buy a spouse's pension, enhancing the income.

She could consider flexible annuity options, such as phased retirement, in effect living each year on part of the tax-free cash and part of the income from a small number of segments within the plan. She should retain her Standard Life policy as she may benefit if the demutualisation proceeds.
 Gillian Cardy works for financial advisers Professional Partnerships.

Adviser 2: Amanda Davidson
As to Maureen's short-term requirement for income, there is little she can do with her savings to generate the amount she requires. She cannot afford to take risks so I suggest she keeps it where it is and uses up the money in her Egg account first before she cashes in Peps and shares. However, she may like to consider transferring £3,000 of her deposit savings to a mini-cash Isa so she is not taxed on any of the interest.

She should take a student loan and put it in a deposit account. Student loans do not have to be repaid until studies end so she will benefit from interest built while she studies.

A key area of cost saving is her mortgage. Nobody these days should have an ordinary variable rate mortgage because they are effectively subsidising the special deals offered to new borrowers. She should approach her current lender to see what special deals it has to offer. By taking a discounted or fixed-rate deal, she should be able to reduce her payments. Naturally she should hang on to her Standard Life endowment in case of a windfall.

The pension she quotes from Hill Samuel looks quite high. She should check to ensure she will be getting what she expects. She should check her state pension, as her benefit may be affected if she fails to pay National Insurance contributions while studying.
 Amanda Davidson works for financial advisers Holden Meehan.

 Advice is for guidance only.

Do you want to appear in Wealthcheck?
Write, including daytime and evening telephone numbers, a brief list of circumstances and any investments, to: Wealthcheck, The Observer, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, or e-mail:cash@observer.co.uk. You must be prepared to be interviewed and photographed.

Her existing Pep could also be switched within Gartmore to a high-yield bond fund to generate income. In the short term, a student loan is a possibility. A more radical solution is to consider a transfer of her pensions into one personal pension plan and consider drawing the benefits now. This entails a detailed assessment of what she would be giving up at 60 in return for income now. But the reason why this might prove attractive is because most company pension schemes allow for payment of a spouse's pension. If she was to transfer the value of the pensions, this would be allowed for in the transfer value, but she would not be required to use the transfer value to buy a spouse's pension, enhancing the income. She could consider flexible annuity options, such as phased retirement, in effect living each year on part of the tax-free cash and part of the income from a small number of segments within the plan. She should retain her Standard Life policy as she may benefit if the demutualisation proceeds.  Gillian Cardy works for financial advisers Professional Partnerships. Adviser 2: Amanda Davidson As to Maureen's short-term requirement for income, there is little she can do with her savings to generate the amount she requires. She cannot afford to take risks so I suggest she keeps it where it is and uses up the money in her Egg account first before she cashes in Peps and shares. However, she may like to consider transferring £3,000 of her deposit savings to a mini-cash Isa so she is not taxed on any of the interest. She should take a student loan and put it in a deposit account. Student loans do not have to be repaid until studies end so she will benefit from interest built while she studies. A key area of cost saving is her mortgage. Nobody these days should have an ordinary variable rate mortgage because they are effectively subsidising the special deals offered to new borrowers. She should approach her current lender to see what special deals it has to offer. By taking a discounted or fixed-rate deal, she should be able to reduce her payments. Naturally she should hang on to her Standard Life endowment in case of a windfall. The pension she quotes from Hill Samuel looks quite high. She should check to ensure she will be getting what she expects. She should check her state pension, as her benefit may be affected if she fails to pay National Insurance contributions while studying.  Amanda Davidson works for financial advisers Holden Meehan.  Advice is for guidance only. fields.headline: Cashpoints
fields.trailText: House prices slip
fields.body:
House prices slip

Homeowners should not be alarmed by news that house prices fell by 0.4 per cent last month, according to the latest figures from Nationwide. 'While underlying demand for housing may have slackened during May, there is little to suggest that the market is heading for a significant downturn,' says Nationwide director David Parry. The slight fall 'may have been affected by jitters in the stock market, the withdrawal of mortgage interest tax relief and fears of higher interest rates'.

Late cheques

Banks fail to process a quarter of the cheques paid into current accounts in the time they themselves say is reasonable.

New research from Which? - based on a survey of 440 cheques - shows that one in four 'paid into current accounts at the top 11 banks and building societies failed to clear on time'. The researchers say that 'by dragging their heels, banks inconvenience their customers - and can rack up profits'. It can take three days for a cheque to go through the clearing system and, in the worst cases, another eight days before the account-holder can withdraw the money.

Boiler room alert

Beware of financial salespeople offering you 'a free research report into a company in which you hold shares, or a free gift or a discount on their dealing charges,' says the Financial Services Authority. They may be bona fide but they could be the type of unscrupulous dealer portrayed in the new film Boiler House . Even with a UK address they could still be cowboys: it could just be a forwarding address. The FSA suggests you check to see firms are registered in the UK. Ring 0845 606 1234 or see www.fsa.gov.uk.

Windfall plans

Bradford & Bingley predicted last week that its 2.5 million savers and borrow ers would receive between £647 and £815 in its flotation, planned for later this year. Ballot papers were issued last week and the deadline is 12 July.

Standard Life also mailed voting documents to its members - deadline 23 June - although the management remains vehemently opposed to the conversion plans being put forward by policyholder Fred Woollard.

Friends Provident has promised formal demutualisation proposals to its members next year, while Scottish Provident promised a decision on its status by late summer.

Web taxpayers

Taxpayers wanting to file their tax return via the internet - and save £10 off their tax bill - will have to wait until the end of the month before they can complete the electronic form. Users need to download some free software, which is still being tested by the Inland Revenue and will not be ready until June at the earliest. There are other teething problems. Many people trying to register - the first step in the process - are finding the system reluctant to accept their initial details. See www.inlandrevenue.gov.uk.

fields.headline: Out of the shadows
fields.standfirst: Prince William turns 18 this month. Will he embrace his father's tweedy heritage or seek out Diana's place in the spotlight? In this penetrating insight, Britain's top royal biographer reveals the truth about a young man with a mind of his own
fields.trailText: There will be mixed royal emotions at Prince William's eighteenth birthday party on 21 June, when this last, best hope for the monarchy's long-term future, 'as earnest and dutiful as his father, as wayward and fun-loving as his mother', becomes eligible to inherit the throne in his own right
fields.body:
There will be mixed royal emotions at Prince William's eighteenth birthday party on 21 June, when this last, best hope for the monarchy's long-term future, 'as earnest and dutiful as his father, as wayward and fun-loving as his mother', becomes eligible to inherit the throne in his own right. Which future king will eventually emerge from his sleek teenage chrysalis: the Windsorised Spencer, solemnly bent on his royal destiny, or the Spencerised Windsor, ready to play fast and loose with his hereditary privilege?

Much royal breath has yet to be held, as tabloid reports of William's drug-taking chums vie for space with a long, hot summer of bad-news polls for his father, no doubt showing, as they consistently have to date, that even diehard monarchists would rather pass on King Charles III and get on with William V, offering as dramatically new, young and dynamic a face to the world as the succession from Thatcher-Major to Blair.

It won't happen, of course. 'Out of the question!' snort courtiers. Regardless of public opinion, Britain's unwritten constitution will take its predetermined, unswerving, blithely undemocratic course. One day the Queen will die, Charles will succeed her, William will become Prince of Wales, and Britain will continue to bumble along in its quaint way as a Ruritanian theme-park of a nation, preferring a head of state chosen by accident of birth to anything as unreliable as a ballot-box.

Once the world beyond Eton shows William what his contemporaries really think of the institution of monarchy - it is among his own age group that scornful indifference rides highest - might he develop doubts about his birthright? In the meantime, he will no doubt be glad to be spared as long as possible a job he has seen ruin his father's life and kill his mother. If an adoring nation demands his cute features on its coins and stamps instead of Charles's, however, how will he respond? Could he really be persuaded to usurp the long-awaited throne of the father he clearly adores?

The jury, far from being out, hasn't had time to convene. But a Pandora's box has remained wide open, as Diana transparently intended when she made her own views clear in the 1995 Panorama interview which sealed her marital fate and ensured her banishment to outer royal darkness. The future king's mother wanted the 'top job' to go straight to her son, bypassing her confused, faithless husband. 'Who knows what fate will produce?' she mused darkly. 'Who knows what circumstances will provoke?'

Like a true daughter of her own much older and more English dynasty, she also envisaged a monarch who was more Spencer than Windsor. 'Look how tall William's getting!' she used to crow to friends as her elder son shot up like a slender but sturdy stalk, past six feet in his mid-teens. 'He's much more a Spencer than a Windsor!' Almost three years since her death, Diana's boast sounds more than ever like wishful thinking.

From the symbolic moment, only weeks later, when Prince Harry escorted his father to a Spice Girls concert in a suit and tie, rather than the regulation teenage jeans and T-shirt his mother would have encouraged, all trace of Spencer influence on Diana's sons has been ruthlessly expunged by the Windsors with the cold calculation that is their dynastic trademark (and the secret of their survival).

Strategic statements from an ever cannier royal press office, touchingly asking for Diana to be allowed to rest in peace, have also contributed to the brutal process - the Queen's veto on commemorations of her daughter-in-law's death, Charles's complicity in her posthumous trashing by Penny Junor - which has seen the mother of William and Harry swiftly Tippexed from the royal family album.

And thus from the national memory, to a degree surprising to those who cannot forget that remarkable first week of September 1997. At the time, when Diana's brother Charles Spencer promised the watching (and applauding) world that the 'blood family' would continue to shape William's upbringing, Britain's two noblest houses seemed set for a battle royal over the character and lifestyle of the future king, blessed with his mother's looks if not yet her populist touch.

Then Charles Spencer's fragile halo was tarnished by his own seamy divorce, his commercialisation of his much-mourned sister's memory and the discovery that, despite his concern for William's welfare, he had no plans to move back to Britain from South Africa. His and Diana's sisters, Sarah and Jane, made a braver effort to continue the parental work she so ardently began. But now it is clear the Windsors have won an easy victory.

Diana's true friends mist up at the thought of her missing her beloved Wills's eighteenth birthday. 'She would,' they say, 'have been so proud.' Might she also have been a tad worried? Is Charles? Is the Queen? As he formally attains manhood, William is the world's most eligible bachelor, heir to a 10-figure fortune and the most glamorous job on the planet. He's a looker, too: tall, strapping, drop-dead handsome, with a tousled crop of (natural) blond hair and Botticelli features fresh-minted from those of his mother, around whose same dazzling smile the world for a while seemed to turn.

Even if he weren't who he is, William would turn heads and break hearts. But, given his uniquely storm-tossed life so far, and the fragile, mildly depressive psycho-profile of both his parents, it seems a miracle that he isn't a gibbering basket-case. The story of William's first 18 years has amounted to little more than that of his parents' visceral and all too public marital warfare. Before he even entered his teens, both had chosen to confess on global television to adultery, his father expressing a spooky ambition to morph into his mistress's Tampax, his mother owning up to indoor as well as outdoor riding lessons with a dashing cavalry officer.

Their protracted public catfight was resolved only by a brutal divorce, stripping the princess of her royal rank and consigning her (as even the Daily Telegraph has put it) to the 'demi-monde', where she met her end in the arms of an Onassis-type playboy lover.

William, say his friends, has made a remarkable recovery from the abrupt loss of his devoted (too devoted?) if somewhat unstable mother. His father is visibly relieved to have Diana out of the way, flourishing as never before since she has not been around to harass and upstage him, but William seems to have bottled up his grief and filed it in some corner cupboard of his life. One day, you sense, it must return to haunt him. 'It's amazing,' says one young chum. 'If you hang out with him - considering the shit he has gone through - even right after it happened you wouldn't notice that anything had bothered him at all.'

Not, perhaps, altogether healthy. But William has been trained from birth to wield the stiff upper Windsor lip which supposedly symbolises the hopes and dreams of a great nation, once a mighty empire, even if, in Tony Blair's supposedly 'modernised' Britain, this seems incongruous. But in these irritatingly democratic times, when hereditary peers are kicked out of Parliament after a mere 600 years, the monarchy's best hopes of even medium-term survival rest in the box-office appeal of this seemingly pleasant young innocent, with signs of both his mother's winning ways and his father's stultifying gravitas.

At least Diana was around long enough to leave William memo ries more down-to-earth than the young Charles was ever allowed: queueing in Marks & Spencer to pay for his purchases, playing video games alongside children his own age in Piccadilly Circus, fast food at Planet Hollywood, fun days out at Thorpe Park, even sneaking under age into 18-certificate films (not to mention, of course, visiting the homeless). Weekends with Charles, meanwhile, consisted of what Diana called 'killing things' - hunting and shooting - plus tweedy charades and some racy under-age driving of Range Rovers around the royal estate amid hour upon hour of fatherless frolics with surrogate mum Tiggy Legge-Bourke. So which parent has left the stronger mark on William?

Like Diana more than Charles, the student prince is a card-carrying fun lover who can party with the best of them. Friends joke that he lost his innocence somewhere in the Aegean last summer during his father's annual freebie cruise aboard Greek billionaire John Latsis's yacht. 'He likes women a lot,' one double-barrelled chum recently told America's Talk magazine. 'Yes, he's definitely a player.'

Talk 's current issue mischievously pairs off the prince with a gallery of potential future Queens, from Princess Madeleine of Sweden and one Isabella Anstruther-Gough-Calthorpe to Holly Branson, Elizabeth Jagger and Madonna's three-year-old daughter Lourdes (well, Diana was five when Charles turned 18). 'He's never even met Isabella Anstruther-Gough-Calthorpe,' spluttered a pal. 'She'd like to meet him, though...'

It is supposedly because of the comely 'Izzy' Winkler, a 22-year-old socialite studying philosophy at Edinburgh University, that William has set his academic sights on the Athens of the North rather than Oxbridge, like his father (and all recent male monarchs) before him. But this is a twenty-first-century prince who emails his fellow teen-star Britney Spears, admits to fancying Baby Spice and has even been seen 'snogging' the 25-year-old that mutual friends saucily refer to as his 'cousin', Emma Parker Bowles, niece of his father's long-time consort Camilla. 'Nothing much came of it,' his chum told Talk. 'But still, it's pretty good, to snog a 25-year-old when you're only 17.'

Snogging - and much more - is high on the agenda of the gilded British youth among whom William moves: many a virginity is surrendered beneath the manicured bushes at house parties in the 'royal triangle' of rural Gloucestershire (close to his father's organic farm at Highgrove) or Norfolk (near granny's pile at Sandringham).

Amid a fusillade of double-barrelled names, from Duckworth-Chad to Palmer-Tomkinson, horny young toffs with nicknames like Hoggins and Rollo love bandying tampon jokes while throwing bread rolls at their belles at the end of hedonistic days spent hunting, shooting, fishing, getting drunk and singing rugby songs.

Much as he loves this world, and feels alarmingly at home in it, young William already shows a measure of the caution born of centuries of royal breeding. Like Charles more than Diana, he is said by friends to be 'wary', 'canny', 'not terribly experimental', reluctant to push the royal envelope further than eons of propriety allow. A chip off the old block, above all, in flaunting an indifference to hoi polloi - hunting to hounds, for instance, in defiance of public opinion, not to mention government policy - 'he doesn't,' according to one friend, 'give a toss what people think'.

There have, meanwhile, been encouraging signs that the prince is human: an almighty row with his father, for instance, over the venue for his eighteenth birthday party. Charles favoured the deadly dull setting of Highgrove, whose new 7,000 sq-ft Orchid Room is more suited to earnest conferences about the environment than an all-night rave for Blighty's latest crop of black-tied Hooray Henrys and giggling, falling-out-of-their-party-frocks neo-Sloanes.

The party animal in William wanted a London nightclub. But he had to learn an early lesson, which is ominous for his future, by swallowing a compromise in the shape of a semi-stately thrash at Windsor Castle, courtesy of his grandmother, with the oldsters retiring tactfully at midnight to let the young things rave on. Another early lesson might be a caution that the party falls right in the middle of his A-levels when he should be revising.

William has already shown his capacity for raving (in the strictly ballroom sense) at last summer's Cartier polo lunch, where he held court as a guest of his 26-year-old chum Edward van Cutsem, son of the couple closest to Charles and Camilla. In wraparound sunglasses and navy blue blazer with gold buttons - 'a little Eurotrash,' according to fashion guru Daisy Garnett, 'but, hell, it worked' - Wills apparently spent most of lunch romancing Victoria Aitken, daughter of Jonathan, the former Tory Minister who was jailed for perjury. So hard did Victoria laugh at her future king's jokes that she looked, to one watching journalist, 'like she might swallow his head'.

Breaking all the royal rules, William had not told the Palace, nor its press office, nor indeed his father of his plans to attend the lunch. 'What are you doing here?' the Queen asked him in surprise, barely recognising her favourite grandson behind his wraparounds. William was blasé. 'Why should he tell the Palace about everything he does?' mused a friend. 'He doesn't. He does what he wants and that's the end of it.'

Not for long. At the Cartier lunch, Wills may be the racy prince who mixes with a louche, witless set of drug-dabbling friends. Otherwise, as royals go, he is conventionally privileged, and disturbingly at ease with it all. How many other British 17-year-olds have their own car, flash apartment (a set of rooms at St James's Palace) and a Coutts gold card?

In his last year at Eton he is reported (again like his father) to be 'no more than averagely bright', taking A-levels in biology, geography and history of art which will decide his university place, according to Buckingham Palace 'strictly on merit'. Although a fine shot (which runs in the family, despite his mother's loathing for blood sports) and a keen swimmer (as was Diana), he is not otherwise as sporty, least of all on horseback, as most of his royal cousins and forebears.

William does not seem to be eccentric, short-fused and moody (like his father) or neurotic, wilful and manipulative (like his mother). Neither affected nor pretentious, he is more level-headed than Harry. Wills is more responsible. But he smokes cigarettes, anathema to both his parents, and enjoys a drink as does Dad, though Mum rarely took more than a sip of Chardonnay. He also moves on the fringes of an older set centred on Tom Parker Bowles, son of Camilla, of whom, according to the Palace line, he warmly approves.

But the palace does not approve of the company he keeps. Here we enter the grey area where the royals must be allowed, to the occasional despair of their courtiers, to behave as human beings. Throughout the Queen's 48-year reign, her press spokesmen have conceded one official 'wart': that she is an over-indulgent mother. When Prince Edward proposed his disastrous It's A Royal Knockout, for instance, and prescient advisers urged the Queen to talk him out of it, she is said to have taken the line: 'No, I can't. At least the boy's doing something.'

Charles appears to have become equally indulgent. When Tom Parker Bowles was caught in possession of drugs, quasi-stepfather Charles read him the riot act, to his real father's considerable annoyance. But there is no record of a similar rebuke to his son for mixing in such circles, or any apparent attempt to remove him from them. What, after all, would Camilla say?

William hero-worships 24-year-old Tom, but is said to be too 'sensible' to dabble, even in soft drugs, himself. The 'child-of-his-times' prince is nevertheless as worrying for the senior royals as he is entertaining (and endearing) for the nation. Which way will William jump? Will the Charles in him sober up and confront the responsibilities that go with his birth? Or will the Diana in him kick against the royal pricks and make him go his own rebellious way? Although he will not officially embark upon public life until his twenty-first birthday, and Charles will meanwhile continue to block unwelcome publicity through the stringent code of conduct issued to the press, even on matters of undoubted public interest, these are becoming urgent questions in Palace circles. (In one incident last year the Palace prevented the News of the World publishing pictures of William on holiday with friends in Cornwall. The friends were drinking, William was not.)

As the Queen enters her seventy-fifth year, her mother will turn 100 this summer. Might the younger Elizabeth live as long? Might Charles even die before his mother? Might the feistier backbenchers of a narrowly re-elected Labour Government prefer to consign the monarchy to the tourist-rich museum where it rationally belongs?

Might Wills himself, once exposed to the scepticism of his university generation, come round to this view? He did so in a scenario envisaged by playwright Peter Whelan (a recent guest, ironically, at Sandringham), whose 1996 Divine Right portrayed a reflective William making an incognito tour of the Midlands, canvassing views on the Crown. At its climactic secret rendezvous in a field near Sandringham, William tells Harry he's decided to pass, and let the monarchy die a natural death.

'But they want us, they need us,' pleads his stunned younger brother. 'That's just the point,' replies a sadder but wiser William. 'They shouldn't.'

The Boy

Full Name William Arthur Philip Louis Windsor.

Title HRH Prince William.

Born 21 June 1982 at 9.03pm, weighing 7lb 10oz at the Lindo wing of St Mary's Hospital, Paddington, London. Christened by the Archbishop of Canterbury at Buckingham Palace. Confirmed by the Bishop of London at St. George's Chapel in 1997.

Godparents Princess Alexandra, Lady Susan Hussey, Sir Laurens van der Post, King Constantine of Greece, Lord Romsey and the Duchess of Westminster. Godfather to Prince Konstantine Alexios, the son of Crown Prince and Crown Princess Pavlos of Greece.

Schools

1985-1987 Mrs Mynor's nursery school, West London.

1987-1990 Wetherby School, Kensington, London.

1990-1995 Ludgrove School, Wokingham.

1995-2000 Eton College, Windsor.

Qualifications

12 GCSE O levels, including grade A in English, History and languages, grade B in Maths and Science.

A-levels to be taken this summer Geography, Biology, History of Art.

School awards Sword of Honour as a first year CCF cadet. Captain of swimming.

Has applied to go to Edinburgh University, possibly after a gap year.

The Girls

First girlfriend Zara Simmonds, granddaughter of the Earl of Ranfurly. Spotted kissing at a London ball in 1996.

Girls he hangs out with Melissa Lilly, Olivia Buchanan Jardine, Lady Douglas-Home, Holly Branson, Davina Duckworth-Chad, Emilia d'Erlanger. His cousins Laura Fellowes and Lady Gabriella Windsor.

Pin-Ups Pamela Anderson, Baby Spice, Cindy Crawford, the Barbie Twins, Britney Spears.

According to the Act of Settlement of 1701, persons in direct line to succession may not marry a Roman Catholic. A divorced person may also present problems.

• This article was amended on 15 October 2010 to remove a name falsely linked to Prince William.

'If you hang out with him - considering the shit he has gone through - even right after it happened you wouldn't notice that anything had bothered him at all.' Not, perhaps, altogether healthy. But William has been trained from birth to wield the stiff upper Windsor lip which supposedly symbolises the hopes and dreams of a great nation, once a mighty empire, even if, in Tony Blair's supposedly 'modernised' Britain, this seems incongruous. But in these irritatingly democratic times, when hereditary peers are kicked out of Parliament after a mere 600 years, the monarchy's best hopes of even medium-term survival rest in the box-office appeal of this seemingly pleasant young innocent, with signs of both his mother's winning ways and his father's stultifying gravitas. At least Diana was around long enough to leave William memo ries more down-to-earth than the young Charles was ever allowed: queueing in Marks & Spencer to pay for his purchases, playing video games alongside children his own age in Piccadilly Circus, fast food at Planet Hollywood, fun days out at Thorpe Park, even sneaking under age into 18-certificate films (not to mention, of course, visiting the homeless). Weekends with Charles, meanwhile, consisted of what Diana called 'killing things' - hunting and shooting - plus tweedy charades and some racy under-age driving of Range Rovers around the royal estate amid hour upon hour of fatherless frolics with surrogate mum Tiggy Legge-Bourke. So which parent has left the stronger mark on William? Like Diana more than Charles, the student prince is a card-carrying fun lover who can party with the best of them. Friends joke that he lost his innocence somewhere in the Aegean last summer during his father's annual freebie cruise aboard Greek billionaire John Latsis's yacht. 'He likes women a lot,' one double-barrelled chum recently told America's Talk magazine. 'Yes, he's definitely a player.' Talk 's current issue mischievously pairs off the prince with a gallery of potential future Queens, from Princess Madeleine of Sweden and one Isabella Anstruther-Gough-Calthorpe to Holly Branson, Elizabeth Jagger and Madonna's three-year-old daughter Lourdes (well, Diana was five when Charles turned 18). 'He's never even met Isabella Anstruther-Gough-Calthorpe,' spluttered a pal. 'She'd like to meet him, though...' It is supposedly because of the comely 'Izzy' Winkler, a 22-year-old socialite studying philosophy at Edinburgh University, that William has set his academic sights on the Athens of the North rather than Oxbridge, like his father (and all recent male monarchs) before him. But this is a twenty-first-century prince who emails his fellow teen-star Britney Spears, admits to fancying Baby Spice and has even been seen 'snogging' the 25-year-old that mutual friends saucily refer to as his 'cousin', Emma Parker Bowles, niece of his father's long-time consort Camilla. 'Nothing much came of it,' his chum told Talk. 'But still, it's pretty good, to snog a 25-year-old when you're only 17.' Snogging - and much more - is high on the agenda of the gilded British youth among whom William moves: many a virginity is surrendered beneath the manicured bushes at house parties in the 'royal triangle' of rural Gloucestershire (close to his father's organic farm at Highgrove) or Norfolk (near granny's pile at Sandringham). Amid a fusillade of double-barrelled names, from Duckworth-Chad to Palmer-Tomkinson, horny young toffs with nicknames like Hoggins and Rollo love bandying tampon jokes while throwing bread rolls at their belles at the end of hedonistic days spent hunting, shooting, fishing, getting drunk and singing rugby songs. Much as he loves this world, and feels alarmingly at home in it, young William already shows a measure of the caution born of centuries of royal breeding. Like Charles more than Diana, he is said by friends to be 'wary', 'canny', 'not terribly experimental', reluctant to push the royal envelope further than eons of propriety allow. A chip off the old block, above all, in flaunting an indifference to hoi polloi - hunting to hounds, for instance, in defiance of public opinion, not to mention government policy - 'he doesn't,' according to one friend, 'give a toss what people think'. There have, meanwhile, been encouraging signs that the prince is human: an almighty row with his father, for instance, over the venue for his eighteenth birthday party. Charles favoured the deadly dull setting of Highgrove, whose new 7,000 sq-ft Orchid Room is more suited to earnest conferences about the environment than an all-night rave for Blighty's latest crop of black-tied Hooray Henrys and giggling, falling-out-of-their-party-frocks neo-Sloanes. The party animal in William wanted a London nightclub. But he had to learn an early lesson, which is ominous for his future, by swallowing a compromise in the shape of a semi-stately thrash at Windsor Castle, courtesy of his grandmother, with the oldsters retiring tactfully at midnight to let the young things rave on. Another early lesson might be a caution that the party falls right in the middle of his A-levels when he should be revising. William has already shown his capacity for raving (in the strictly ballroom sense) at last summer's Cartier polo lunch, where he held court as a guest of his 26-year-old chum Edward van Cutsem, son of the couple closest to Charles and Camilla. In wraparound sunglasses and navy blue blazer with gold buttons - 'a little Eurotrash,' according to fashion guru Daisy Garnett, 'but, hell, it worked' - Wills apparently spent most of lunch romancing Victoria Aitken, daughter of Jonathan, the former Tory Minister who was jailed for perjury. So hard did Victoria laugh at her future king's jokes that she looked, to one watching journalist, 'like she might swallow his head'. Breaking all the royal rules, William had not told the Palace, nor its press office, nor indeed his father of his plans to attend the lunch. 'What are you doing here?' the Queen asked him in surprise, barely recognising her favourite grandson behind his wraparounds. William was blasé. 'Why should he tell the Palace about everything he does?' mused a friend. 'He doesn't. He does what he wants and that's the end of it.' Not for long. At the Cartier lunch, Wills may be the racy prince who mixes with a louche, witless set of drug-dabbling friends. Otherwise, as royals go, he is conventionally privileged, and disturbingly at ease with it all. How many other British 17-year-olds have their own car, flash apartment (a set of rooms at St James's Palace) and a Coutts gold card? In his last year at Eton he is reported (again like his father) to be 'no more than averagely bright', taking A-levels in biology, geography and history of art which will decide his university place, according to Buckingham Palace 'strictly on merit'. Although a fine shot (which runs in the family, despite his mother's loathing for blood sports) and a keen swimmer (as was Diana), he is not otherwise as sporty, least of all on horseback, as most of his royal cousins and forebears. William does not seem to be eccentric, short-fused and moody (like his father) or neurotic, wilful and manipulative (like his mother). Neither affected nor pretentious, he is more level-headed than Harry. Wills is more responsible. But he smokes cigarettes, anathema to both his parents, and enjoys a drink as does Dad, though Mum rarely took more than a sip of Chardonnay. He also moves on the fringes of an older set centred on Tom Parker Bowles, son of Camilla, of whom, according to the Palace line, he warmly approves. But the palace does not approve of the company he keeps. Here we enter the grey area where the royals must be allowed, to the occasional despair of their courtiers, to behave as human beings. Throughout the Queen's 48-year reign, her press spokesmen have conceded one official 'wart': that she is an over-indulgent mother. When Prince Edward proposed his disastrous It's A Royal Knockout, for instance, and prescient advisers urged the Queen to talk him out of it, she is said to have taken the line: 'No, I can't. At least the boy's doing something.' Charles appears to have become equally indulgent. When Tom Parker Bowles was caught in possession of drugs, quasi-stepfather Charles read him the riot act, to his real father's considerable annoyance. But there is no record of a similar rebuke to his son for mixing in such circles, or any apparent attempt to remove him from them. What, after all, would Camilla say? William hero-worships 24-year-old Tom, but is said to be too 'sensible' to dabble, even in soft drugs, himself. The 'child-of-his-times' prince is nevertheless as worrying for the senior royals as he is entertaining (and endearing) for the nation. Which way will William jump? Will the Charles in him sober up and confront the responsibilities that go with his birth? Or will the Diana in him kick against the royal pricks and make him go his own rebellious way? Although he will not officially embark upon public life until his twenty-first birthday, and Charles will meanwhile continue to block unwelcome publicity through the stringent code of conduct issued to the press, even on matters of undoubted public interest, these are becoming urgent questions in Palace circles. (In one incident last year the Palace prevented the News of the World publishing pictures of William on holiday with friends in Cornwall. The friends were drinking, William was not.) As the Queen enters her seventy-fifth year, her mother will turn 100 this summer. Might the younger Elizabeth live as long? Might Charles even die before his mother? Might the feistier backbenchers of a narrowly re-elected Labour Government prefer to consign the monarchy to the tourist-rich museum where it rationally belongs? Might Wills himself, once exposed to the scepticism of his university generation, come round to this view? He did so in a scenario envisaged by playwright Peter Whelan (a recent guest, ironically, at Sandringham), whose 1996 Divine Right portrayed a reflective William making an incognito tour of the Midlands, canvassing views on the Crown. At its climactic secret rendezvous in a field near Sandringham, William tells Harry he's decided to pass, and let the monarchy die a natural death. 'But they want us, they need us,' pleads his stunned younger brother. 'That's just the point,' replies a sadder but wiser William. 'They shouldn't.' The Boy Full Name William Arthur Philip Louis Windsor. Title HRH Prince William. Born 21 June 1982 at 9.03pm, weighing 7lb 10oz at the Lindo wing of St Mary's Hospital, Paddington, London. Christened by the Archbishop of Canterbury at Buckingham Palace. Confirmed by the Bishop of London at St. George's Chapel in 1997. Godparents Princess Alexandra, Lady Susan Hussey, Sir Laurens van der Post, King Constantine of Greece, Lord Romsey and the Duchess of Westminster. Godfather to Prince Konstantine Alexios, the son of Crown Prince and Crown Princess Pavlos of Greece. Schools 1985-1987 Mrs Mynor's nursery school, West London. 1987-1990 Wetherby School, Kensington, London. 1990-1995 Ludgrove School, Wokingham. 1995-2000 Eton College, Windsor. Qualifications 12 GCSE O levels, including grade A in English, History and languages, grade B in Maths and Science. A-levels to be taken this summer Geography, Biology, History of Art. School awards Sword of Honour as a first year CCF cadet. Captain of swimming. Has applied to go to Edinburgh University, possibly after a gap year. The Girls First girlfriend Zara Simmonds, granddaughter of the Earl of Ranfurly. Spotted kissing at a London ball in 1996. Girls he hangs out with Melissa Lilly, Olivia Buchanan Jardine, Lady Douglas-Home, Holly Branson, Davina Duckworth-Chad, Emilia d'Erlanger. His cousins Laura Fellowes and Lady Gabriella Windsor. Pin-Ups Pamela Anderson, Baby Spice, Cindy Crawford, the Barbie Twins, Britney Spears. According to the Act of Settlement of 1701, persons in direct line to succession may not marry a Roman Catholic. A divorced person may also present problems. • This article was amended on 15 October 2010 to remove a name falsely linked to Prince William.

webTitle: Fewer irises, but still too many gondolas...

fields.headline: Fewer irises, but still too many gondolas...
fields.standfirst: If the daubers, both professional and amateur, are out in force, it must be the Summer Show
fields.trailText: Two gold stars for the Royal Academy Summer Show this year. First Charles Saatchi buys a painting by an octogenarian academician, even before the doors are officially opened. Then Frank Stella, the American laureate of abstract art, declares that he would rather show at the RA summer jumble any day than in the gloom of Tate Modern
fields.body:
Royal Academy Summer Show

Dali Universe County Hall, London

Two gold stars for the Royal Academy Summer Show this year. First Charles Saatchi buys a painting by an octogenarian academician, even before the doors are officially opened. Then Frank Stella, the American laureate of abstract art, declares that he would rather show at the RA summer jumble any day than in the gloom of Tate Modern. Since Frank Stella is currently on show in both places, this is no small proclamation.

A surprising purchase and a startling claim: something must have changed at the Royal Academy.

Has it? Hardly. The annual pro-am fixture remains largely the same. There are fewer apples, irises and Provençal landscapes than last year, but there are more violins and gondolas. Celebrity gets a greater billing, with images of Tracey Emin, Ian Dury, Ken Livingstone and more than one shrine to the late James Dean. History no longer figures, with the exception of Frederick Gore's facsimile of the front page of an Evening Standard during the Kosovo crisis, as newly acquired by Charles Saatchi.

Nobody expects to encounter any of Saatchi's BritArt in this show. Nor is it ever likely if this year's senior hanger, sounding like a Trollope curate in the catalogue, really believes that by 'reaching out a helping hand' he can gather in a harvest of 'pictures' - of all things - from the YBAs in their East End studios.

Far more surprising is the miserable ratio of Older British Artists to their international peers. Freud, Riley and Auerbach never show, but every summer sees a faithful turn-out from Baselitz, Kiefer and Twombly.

One Bridget Riley would have made up for the entire showing of honorary academicians this year. The first gallery is hung with an off-cut Baselitz, a melancholy but minor Kiefer and a Cy Twombly sketch that looks like a memo to himself, dashed off in some distracted moment back in 1985. Balthus's latest Lolita, legs parted on a four-poster bed, is as underpowered as you might expect from this frail, nonagenarian artist. Jasper Johns hasn't bother to submit anything at all; only Antoni Tapies's weird, updated Osiris commands any visual impact.

Several of these artists were shortlisted for the 1999 Wollaston Award - more money than the Turner - won last year by David Hockney. Frank Stella now has the gallery in which Hockney attempted to summarise the Grand Canyon in multi-panel diagrams of blistering red and orange.

Stella is after something less substantial - the smoke that unfurls from a cigar. Computerised, multiplied and manipulated, these whorls ripple across two 20ft abstracts in Day-Glo colours and form the frozen undulations of three giant sculptures. On canvas, the idea dwindles into pattern. But the sculptures, welded out of trashed steel, look like mythical beasts, rampant and eerily new.

Stella must surely win the Wollaston this year: he hasn't the slightest competition from the shortlist. But there are other fine works, most of them by non-academicians such as Celia Paul and Tai-Shan Schierenberg, both hidden in the congested print-room. If the hanging judges were really after the young, they wouldn't bury such artists while giving Sir Eduardo Paolozzi's outsize wooden trainset - yet another of his magniloquent toys - unavoidable prominence in the forecourt. Equally, if they really prized the democratic openness of the Summer Show, they wouldn't hang every junior, outsider or amateur eight-deep in the main gallery like so much wallpaper. Peter Blake says he did this to make us 'giggle a bit'. How his words give him away.

Salvador Dali: Avida Dollars - that was the anagram André Breton coined for his former surrealist colleague when Dali began to recycle himself for cash in the late 1940s. The jibe proved prophetic. Even after Dali's death, there was enough surplus to fill three separate museums. Now there is a fourth, the Dali Universe, which has just opened at County Hall between the Aquarium and the London Eye.

The Dali Universe is the ghost train at this funfair: an inky black tunnel, theatrically lit, filled with skeletons and haunted by the hysterical voice of the long-dead Dali. There are 500 works, mostly watercolours and prints from the Sixties, but some from the Eighties when there was a suspicious superfluity of Dali multiples washing around. Dali jumps out himself, multiplied in photographs - dressed as the Pope, lounging on the Mae West sofa, next to Velázquez's portrait of Philip IV, from which he borrowed his famous antennal moustache.

If you want to see the early showpieces - Dali called them 'hand-painted dream photographs' - you'll have to go further along the Thames to Tate Modern. The Dali Universe has a lobster telephone, an early mannequin in feather wig and baguette hat and the eye-popping backcloth that Dali designed for Hitchcock's Spellbound. But mainly it offers the spectacle of Dali reprising his own trademarks - the crutch, the melting watch, the burning giraffe, the nail-free crucifixion - in everything from posters to monolithic bronzes. In this racket, nobody could ever out-merchandise Dali.

The great advantage of seeing Dali so thinly spread, so over-extended, is that all his sources become fully apparent. Over and again, you see the style he lifted from Meissonier, the motifs he got from Bosch, Arcimboldo and Velázquez, the notions he took from the books he illustrated: Dante, Lautréamont, the Bible, Freud. The show even includes Dali's scrapbook of borrowed masterpieces and all the Goya prints which he impotently defaced with his own crutches and soft clocks. Above them hang the untouched originals: a full set of Goya etchings. You need no other reason to visit the Dali Universe.

webTitle: My son hates me being pregnant, just because I'm 42

fields.headline: My son hates me being pregnant, just because I'm 42
fields.trailText: At the ripe old age of 42, I find myself pregnant again. My husband is 45 and we already have two children: a 16-year-old girl and a 14-year-old boy. After the initial shock, we became used to the idea and are looking forward to the birth.
fields.body:
At the ripe old age of 42, I find myself pregnant again. My husband is 45 and we already have two children: a 16-year-old girl and a 14-year-old boy. After the initial shock, we became used to the idea and are looking forward to the birth. Our daughter is delighted and has been very supportive but our son is very 'cross' with us. He has let us know that he thinks 'it is disgusting' to have a baby 'at our age' and has been generally sulky and uncooperative. His attitude is starting to upset me. Is his reaction normal? And what can we do to help him accept and love his new brother or sister?

A.S. South London

Yes, his reaction is quite normal and is influenced particularly by his age, his gender and his position in the family.

There are at least two elements to his hostility. First is that he resents being replaced as the youngest and most cosseted member of the family group, especially as he has long felt secure in that position.

In small-sized human families, the problem is seldom insuperable or serious. At 14 your son is nearly ready to spread his wings, and a tiny infant with needs so totally different won't present a threat for long.

The second factor in his antipathy is his sexual awareness, which will be in hormonal spate. By his perception, sexual adventures are areas of risk, a prerogative of the young. He probably really does imagine that this is something exhausted, ancient people relinquish in their mid-twenties. It has an aura of the forbidden, the dark and the sinful, a function that seems light-years away from his respectable, middle-aged parents.

By the same logical misconception, he will not (again subconsciously) associate sex with the baby that will eventually appear, so the second source of his anger will subside soon enough in a welter of domesticity. It is almost certain that he will be enchanted by the new arrival, so it's important to prepare the way for a complete turnaround in his attitude, without him losing face.

To this end, you should try to ignore his present negative vibes; neither being tight-lipped or overly-reassuring. Divest them altogether of tense associations.

Hang loose and accept he needs a bit more space. For instance, if you and your daughter want to go out shopping for prams and nappies, you could say: 'Son, you won't want to come. We're having lunch out, but you'll manage to look after yourself, won't you?'

At the same time, his father might take him away for some masculine pursuit such as a day's fishing. Such times for gender-bonding are healthy and reinforce the family ties.

Your son is at an age where he's changing and developing at the gallop, progressively becoming independent yet still clutching at his roots. He'll need to be reassured that his place in the home, both spatially and metaphorically, won't be usurped. With that security, his new sibling will be well received.

Readers' Replies

I have a lot of sympathy for you, as will any parent of a teenage boy who is sulky and unco-operative. I think you need to get to the bottom of what is really causing his anger, before assuming that it is the prospect of being supplanted by a new baby that is causing him anguish.

This could very well be true of a younger child, but at 14 your son is beginning to move away from you, anyway. I suspect that the baby is less of a problem for him than the horrible realisation that his parents are actually still having sex.

I'm sure that it is perfectly normal for your son to be like this. Teenage boys rarely need an excuse to be cross with their parents - it does seem to come with the territory.

The prospect of a new baby has merely given your son a focus for all that teenage angst. Reassuring him about the baby may not be the issue; educating him to the reality of life might be of more use.

Maybe he feels so disgusted with you and your husband that he can't talk to you about this. Does he get on with his older sister? It might be useful for her to talk to him about it. At 16, she's old enough to cope with the reality, but young enough to know what he is going through.

P.V. of Surrey

Next week's dilemma is from J.R. of Ruislip

My husband and I have a six-year-old son and a three-year-old daughter. I have never smacked or disciplined either of my children.

However, my husband believes in corporal punishment and treats our son particularly harshly. Recently, the situation seems to have become worse, generally resulting in our son being smacked for every mistake or act of clumsiness.

I have threatened my husband that I will take the children away because the home situation is becoming a battleground and the children are frightened to sit at the dinner table with their father in case they do something as trivial as knocking the salt pot over.

My husband was ill-treated when he was a child and he is prone to bouts of depression. The children are not being abused, but I am concerned they will end up hating their father.

Write to Observer Review or email margaret.cook@observer.co.uk. Views on each week's problem to reach us by Wednesday. Margaret Cook writes for Woman's Journa l

Teenage boys rarely need an excuse to be cross with their parents - it does seem to come with the territory. The prospect of a new baby has merely given your son a focus for all that teenage angst. Reassuring him about the baby may not be the issue; educating him to the reality of life might be of more use. Maybe he feels so disgusted with you and your husband that he can't talk to you about this. Does he get on with his older sister? It might be useful for her to talk to him about it. At 16, she's old enough to cope with the reality, but young enough to know what he is going through. P.V. of Surrey Next week's dilemma is from J.R. of Ruislip My husband and I have a six-year-old son and a three-year-old daughter. I have never smacked or disciplined either of my children. However, my husband believes in corporal punishment and treats our son particularly harshly. Recently, the situation seems to have become worse, generally resulting in our son being smacked for every mistake or act of clumsiness. I have threatened my husband that I will take the children away because the home situation is becoming a battleground and the children are frightened to sit at the dinner table with their father in case they do something as trivial as knocking the salt pot over. My husband was ill-treated when he was a child and he is prone to bouts of depression. The children are not being abused, but I am concerned they will end up hating their father. Write to Observer Review or email margaret.cook@observer.co.uk. Views on each week's problem to reach us by Wednesday. Margaret Cook writes for Woman's Journa l

fields.headline: An ounce of prevention...
fields.standfirst: Save pain and money by with gentler therapies that can nip a health problem in the bud, says  Neasa MacErlean
fields.trailText: Save pain and money by with gentler therapies that can nip a health problem in the bud, says Neasa MacErlean.
fields.body:
One in five workers has taken time off in the past year because of back pain. And four out of five occasionally suffer from aches and pains or worse, according to the public service trade union Unison.

For many people, the physical difficulties lead to emotional and financial problems too, but much of this hardship is unnecessary.

Prevention - the solution Unison is urging on the Government - could cost as little as £20, and save you years of pain and perhaps even thousands of pounds in lost income if you have to give up your job. The major problem is that the National Health Service focuses primarily on treating illness and injury - but does relatively little to prevent problems arising in the first place. Going to an osteopath can help you to spot the stresses and strains your body is undergoing years before they start to impair the quality of your life.

Other alternative therapists, including hypnotherapists, acupuncturists and masseurs, also place a strong emphasis on prevention. So if you want to see one, how much will it cost? Can you get discounts? And can you ever get this kind of treatment for free? The answer to the last two questions is yes.

The starting point to finding an alternative therapist is the relevant professional body or ruling council. The British Acupuncture Council (BAC), for instance, will send you a free list of practitioners in your area. One of the potential problems with complementary medicine is that practitioners are unregulated in many fields. While the BAA monitors its 2,000 members carefully, insisting that all have at least two years' full-time experience, anyone can call themselves an acupuncturist.

Members of a reputable body will be required to take out professional indemnity insurance - usually covering claims of up to £2 million if their treatment does you damage. You should ask to see their indemnity policy. You may reason that you are highly unlikely to make a claim against it, but the fact that they have a policy in place suggests that they have a professional approach to running their business.

You will also see therapists listed in the Yellow Pages - or you may follow up a recommendation from a friend.

The BAA suggests that people ring up a few local practitioners to compare their approaches - and their prices. As a rough guide, prices are likely to be £50-£60 for the first session. This could last more than an hour because, unlike conventional medical advisers, they will want to make a general, holistic, assessment of you first. Subsequent sessions are likely to last between 40 minutes and an hour, and will usually cost somewhere between £20 and £40.

Fees to see an osteopath are similar - typically £25-£30 per session, according to the General Osteopathic Council (GOC). This body sends out free lists of local practitioners. Osteopaths have only just become subject to new regulations. Since May 9, anyone calling themselves an osteopath has to be registered with the GOC. It currently lists about 1,800 members, with another 900 applications in the pipeline.

Intense price competition is not a feature of the alternative therapy world.

'Most of our members don't want to turn someone away because they cannot afford it,' says Ann Collins of the GOC. 'Ask an osteopath why they are in the profession and they'll usually say it's because they want to help people.'

Osteopaths, psychotherapists, chiropracters and other therapists appear to be far less motivated by money than their colleagues in mainstream medicine. They earn far less than dentists and solicitors - and the cost to clients is far less.

London-based osteopath John Fudge is typical of many alternative practitioners. He charges £25 for a session lasting between 40 and 60 minutes in his Finsbury Park practice. But he works a couple of days a week in a group practice of seven osteopaths, an acupuncturist and two massage therapists. This is located in the more affluent Winchmore Hill. His fee there is £30. He says: 'In a lot of smaller practices, you get sessions that last 40 minutes to an hour. But in practices where there is a receptionist, it's more likely to be half an hour. And it'll probably be a bit more expensive.'

Most therapists will consider reduced fees to people on low incomes. 'If anyone asks for a concession, I almost always give it,' says Fudge. 'I give £5 off to OAPs, people who are out of work and students.'

But even if you do not fall into one of these categories, practitioners are often sympathetic. Psychotherapists - who sometimes see clients over a period of years - often refrain from putting the price up with inflation if they think a client is struggling with the cost. And they are often open to negotiation if a regular client feels hard up.

There are other possible avenues for those who cannot afford to pay. Some doctors will now refer patients to alternative therapists. Some surgeries are bringing in alternative therapists to practise alongside the doctors. About 40 per cent of GP surgeries now give some access to complementary medicine, according to De Montfort University.

Free or cut-price treatment is available through the therapists' training schools - although these tend to be concentrated in London. Free treatment is available through the seven BAA-approved colleges in England: three are in London and the others are in York, Warwickshire, West Sussex and Reading.

There is another possibility for those who want a free massage. Employers are increasingly allowing their office-bound workers to get a massage at work. This would typically cost £10-£20 for a 10-20 minute session in London - but could be half the price elsewhere. You often find that a masseur or (more usually) masseuse will give a free massage to the person who organises an afternoon's session for the workplace.

People who have private medical insurance will sometimes find that this covers some forms of alternative therapy. Medical insurer OHRA covers six alternative treatments - including homeopathy, osteopathy and medical herbalism - on its main policies. Policyholders can 'self-refer' instead of going through a GP, but they can only do this if they have a specific complaint. Medical insurers have yet to get to grips with preventative medicine. Even so, OHRA is very satisfied with the way policyholders make use of the alternative options.

One person with a whiplash injury, for instance, would see an orthopaedic consultant and a physiotherapist if they opted for traditional medicine. They could also be prescribed drugs. Another person would prefer to visit a chiropractor. 'There's no doubt that the alternative route is the less expensive,' says OHRA spokeswoman Hazel Berrill. Typical initial costs, she says, would be £60-£80 to see an orthopaedic specialist, but £30-£45 to see a chiropractor.

But in the long run, medical insurers have a strong interest in getting people on their books who keep themselves healthy and who go in for preventative treatment.

'Alternative therapists used to be viewed as quacks,' says Kevin Morgan of adviser Litecastle. 'But increasingly they are coming into the mainstream. The issue of prevention will become more important. I am sure that more lifestyle bonus points will be built into medical cover contracts.'

Fudge makes a strong argument for even the fit and healthy to make a preventative visit to an osteopath: 'You can save yourself a huge amount of grief. If your posture is bad, for instance, it can lead to all sorts of problems - digestive problems, breathing disorders, even poor circulation in the hands. Doctors understand this but they can't prescribe prevention. They only prescribe when you're ill. They don't have the time to say: "Come back next month and I'll see how your posture is." So most people aren't aware anything is wrong until their back goes or there is some other problem.'

 British Acupuncture Council: 020 8735 0400 or www.acupuncture.org.uk. General Osteopathic Council: 020 7357 6655 or www.osteopathy.org.uk.

fields.headline: Building on old foundations
fields.standfirst: Traditional Victorian terraces are well-liked and ideal for family life, so let's have more.   Graham Norwood reports
fields.trailText: Traditional Victorian terraces are well-liked and ideal for family life, so let's have more. Graham Norwood reports.
fields.body:
Marcia Road is right up John Prescott's street. It is a set of homes being built on a brownfield site in Southwark, south London, in a traditional terrace design and aimed at attracting people with children to an area with few cheap family homes. This is what the Deputy Prime Minister wants for south-east England.

But there's a twist. Marcia Road is a replica of the same street first constructed, in the same place, in 1880. The original 68 houses on Marcia Road were built by the local authority in what was then the relatively prosperous Bermondsey docks area of south London.

They were missed by German bombers during the Second World War and were narrowly avoided by the town planners who destroyed much of the area in the Sixties and Seventies when they erected tower blocks in sur rounding streets. But by the Nineties most of the houses had been converted into flats, reflecting the reluctance of many families to live in what was becoming a characteristically difficult inner-city area. Age had taken its toll and maintenance bills for Marcia Road were rising at the same time as funding for Southwark Council's housing repairs were being cut. In 1998 the authority put the entire street up for sale.

Southwark had numerous developers interested in the street, but Galliard Homes outbid the others - the council won't reveal the price paid, but prior to the sale it said it was hoping for £2 million.

'Before the project got under way, four or five residents who had bought their homes under the Right To Buy scheme sold them back to the council,' according to Southwark spokesman Matt Grainger.

Galliard soon realised it would be cheaper to rebuild than to refurbish. 'We had hoped to keep them, but it became obvious they would cost too much to renovate,' says sales and marketing manager Madeleine Flower.

'We wanted to keep the look of the street exactly as it had been. It was a nice Victorian road, so we decided to rebuild the frontages with all their original detail, to fit in with the surroundings and because people like these sorts of properties,' she says.

The new Marcia Road is, from the outside, a replica of the old one in weathered London stone and period detail above windows and front doors. Only four houses are complete so far, with the remaining 64 to be finished over the next 12 months.

Once inside a finished home, the twenty-first century kicks in. Each house has four bedrooms plus reception rooms arranged over three floors, plus a small back garden. Different properties offer various first-floor study or dressing room options.

The prices are distinctly modern, too, with the new 68 houses ranging from £275,000 to £300,000 for one at the end of the terrace. But the properties will be almost on top of London Underground's new Ber-mondsey Tube station on the Jubilee Line extension, making the houses attractive for investors wanting a good capital return.

Non-Londoners may recoil at paying so much for a Victorian-sized house, but a three-bedroom Georgian townhouse and roof garden in nearby Southwark Bridge Road is going for £395,000 and a purpose-built two-bedroom apartment with views over the Thames is selling at a cool £450,000.

Back in the eighteen-eighjties the properties would have housed dock labourers and their large families - possibly more than one family per house, even before the conversions into flats. Rents to the council would have been under one shilling per week per property - about 5p.

'Now we're attracting a mix of people, according to Madeleine Flower. 'It's mostly families of course, because of the bedrooms, but there are also some people working in the City who want a house with plenty of space for much the same price as a flat. And there's lots of interest from people working at Guy's hospital,' she says.

The trend towards conversion, or rebuilding as original on brownfield sites, is likely to grow in this century, according to the National House Building Council.

'The Government has sent out a strong message to the industry that sustainable development means building on brownfield sites,' according to NHBC press officer Adrian Murrell.

'Historically, the last century saw British city centres undergo a decline in population as people fled urban areas for the suburbs. We may be beginning to see a gradual reversal of this exodus, as urban living regains its attractiveness and people decide that cities are exciting places in which to live,' he says.

'Conversions throughout the UK are currently taking place at the rate of 16,000 properties per year. The theme of regeneration is here to stay for the foreseeable future,' Murrell insists.

 Galliard Homes: 020 7620 1500; National House Building Council: 01494 434477.
