fields.headline: House call
fields.standfirst: No appointments, no waiting, speedy diagnosis and prescription - online doctors are flourishing. But are they safe, asks Wendy Moore
fields.trailText: No appointments, no waiting, speedy diagnosis and prescription - online doctors are flourishing. But are they safe?
fields.body:
Maria Rankine, who leads a busy working life as a quality auditor for the British Standards Institution, rarely visits her own doctor - she is seldom ill. So when a runny nose and blocked ears lingered for several weeks when she was due to fly to the US recently, she did not relish waiting for a GP's appointment. Instead she emailed her symptoms to e-med, the internet medical service, and within four hours an online doctor had diagnosed middle-ear congestion and recommended some nasal decongestants. By the weekend, she was fit to fly. 'I got the advice I wanted without leaving my house,' she says.

Francesco Coppola, a City broker who lives in south-west London, has also just signed up with e-med. 'I think it is how a doctor should be - the doctor of the future,' he says. 'I don't have the time to get out of work and wait my turn. It is too slow.' Online medical consultation is already big business in the US. Browse the American-based health websites and you can buy any medical commodity from prescription-only drugs like Viagra and Prozac, to personal advice from doctors - the 'virtual house call', as one site puts it - and even online psychotherapy.

Now e-medicine has crossed the Atlantic - much to the consternation of leading doctors. Websites are popping up to offer one-to-one, clinical advice from doctors, nurses, pharmacists, naturopaths and sex therapists. Services vary hugely in what they offer, ranging from the equivalent of a medical agony aunt, who may or may not choose to answer your question, to live, two-way chat with a doctor via email. Doctors and nurses who work online are qualified in the usual way, but alternative therapy on the net is no less a grey area than in real life.

Even the government is getting in on the act. Its health website, NHS Direct Online, launched by Tony Blair in December, attracts about 150,000 hits a day. Such sites are clearly meeting a demand from people too busy, too lazy, too anxious or too embarrassed to discuss their medical complaint with their own GP.

Dr Julian Eden, 38, who left his job as an NHS GP last year to launch e-med, agrees. 'This is what people need. It is consumer-led medicine,' he says. For an annual £20 fee, plus £15 for each consultation, he offers not only to diagnose your ailment but also to prescribe treatment and even refer you for tests or specialist opinion, all by email. He is e-med's main practitioner, assisted by a panel of doctors dotted around the country. But while e-med is one of several UK websites now advertising online consultation, he claims his service is unique. Few, if any, other websites undertake definitive diagnosis or prescribing, and some respond to a medical query by suggesting that the patient pose the question in the site's chatroom or check in its archives. This, argues Dr Eden, is tantamount to a GP telling patients to ask around in the waiting room for advice or to sift through a pile of medical records. Most health websites are also peppered with disclaimers, and warn visitors to see their own doctor if symptoms are serious.

Such caution is no doubt prompted by growing concern in the medical profession that diagnosis by email is potentially dangerous. The General Medical Council, which polices standards of all UK doctors, no matter what medium they use, has warned that online consulting and prescribing - without a physical examination, when the patient is not already known to the doctor, and where there is little opportunity to monitor treatment - may 'seriously compromise standards of care'.

But Dr Eden is convinced that online diagnosis is safe. The vast majority of patients aged 18 to 45 - the age bracket of most of his clients - do not need a physical examination, he says, although he speaks to patients by telephone or invites them to his surgery in Battersea, south London, for an examination, when unsure. Maria Rankine had already visited him in person for her diagnosis of middle-ear congestion.

New members fill in a form detailing their medical history, which is kept in a separate, secure system. When they want advice, they complete a 'symptom checker' by email. Dr Eden replies within four hours. Prescriptions may be emailed to an online pharmacist - he has a link with the Allcures website, which delivers medication to your door - or to the chemist nearest the patient's home or workplace (although for legal reasons he has to post a signed prescription, too).

Almost all of his 400 patients are professionals reluctant to take time off work to visit their GP with a simple ailment they know needs a prescription-only drug. But Dr Eden also caters for travellers who are struck ill in remote areas and prefer to check into a cybercafé and email a British GP than risk visiting a local hospital where facilities may be basic, at best. He can suggest drugs available over the counter (many of which might be available only on prescription here), or recommend a hospital visit or even returning home.

Indeed, Dr Eden, a compulsive traveller, says that the idea for e-med hit him when he was dangerously ill with cerebral malaria and stranded in Ouagadougou, in Burkina Faso, western Africa, with no access to reliable medical advice. 'I swore to myself there must be something better,' he says. In the not-too-distant future, Eden believes, most consultations could be online, with people using WAP mobile phones, which can browse the internet, to seek email advice, and doctors using webcam technology to examine patients.

Colleagues in the NHS are unconvinced. While accepting that cybermedicine is probably unstoppable, they are alarmed at the risks of online diagnosis. 'We think it is potentially very dangerous,' says Dr Paul Cundy, who chairs the IT committee of the British Medical Association, and is himself a GP, in Wimbledon. 'One of the skills of a GP is to pick up things in a consultation. You can do that on the telephone, but it is not possible online.'

Medical information sent via email may not be secure, he argues, while at the same time the doctor cannot be sure of the patient's identity. The online patient may be a hypochondriac who has already been refused medication by their own GP. Dr Neil Bacon, who runs doctors.net, the medical internet community where doctors talk to each other, agrees. 'An awful lot of doctors have concerns that you cannot do proper diagnosis over the net,' he says. Something that may seem trivial to a patient, like a headache or a cough, could be a symptom of something serious, such as a stroke or TB, he warns. Alternatively, the doctor may always err on the safe side and refer patients for unnecessary tests.

While there is clearly a future for online medicine - email could prove invaluable for repeat prescriptions or to clarify information from a consultation - its application will always be limited, he believes. 'The vast majority of patients like the fact they are going to see a doctor.'

Other doctors offering online medical advice are also wary of taking e-consultations to extremes. Dr Dan Rutherford, medical director of NetDoctor, one of the biggest UK health sites, says: 'Strictly speaking, the word "diagnosis" is inappropriate for the internet.' His site's Ask the Doctor service concentrates on general rather than personal queries, while visitors can also seek advice on sexual difficulties from the site's sex therapists, husband-and-wife team Christine Webber and David Delvin. 'In 10 years' time, online diagnosis may well be commonplace,' says Dr Rutherford, but in the meantime NetDoctor is treading cautiously.

Dr Raffi Assadourian, one of five GPs behind the UK website Britmed.com, takes a similar view. 'If anyone ever claims they can diagnose someone over the internet, it is not possible,' he says. NHS Direct Online provides a similar service. Online medical advice

Where to go for consultation

e-med (www.e-med.co.uk). Private medical 24-hour service offering diagnosis, prescription and referral by email. Annual fee £20 plus £15 per consultation, with response in four hours.

Britmed.com (www.britmed.co.uk). This site offers consultations - but not diagnoses or prescriptions - from British GPs for £23 (soon to be £18) per consultation. Responses are placed in a locked postbox on the website within 48 hours.

Instead she emailed her symptoms to e-med, the internet medical service, and within four hours an online doctor had diagnosed middle-ear congestion and recommended some nasal decongestants. By the weekend, she was fit to fly. 'I got the advice I wanted without leaving my house,' she says. Francesco Coppola, a City broker who lives in south-west London, has also just signed up with e-med. 'I think it is how a doctor should be - the doctor of the future,' he says. 'I don't have the time to get out of work and wait my turn. It is too slow.' Online medical consultation is already big business in the US. Browse the American-based health websites and you can buy any medical commodity from prescription-only drugs like Viagra and Prozac, to personal advice from doctors - the 'virtual house call', as one site puts it - and even online psychotherapy. Now e-medicine has crossed the Atlantic - much to the consternation of leading doctors. Websites are popping up to offer one-to-one, clinical advice from doctors, nurses, pharmacists, naturopaths and sex therapists. Services vary hugely in what they offer, ranging from the equivalent of a medical agony aunt, who may or may not choose to answer your question, to live, two-way chat with a doctor via email. Its health website, NHS Direct Online, launched by Tony Blair in December, attracts about 150,000 hits a day. He is e-med's main practitioner, assisted by a panel of doctors dotted around the country. Few, if any, other websites undertake definitive diagnosis or prescribing, and some respond to a medical query by suggesting that the patient pose the question in the site's chatroom or check in its archives. This, argues Dr Eden, is tantamount to a GP telling patients to ask around in the waiting room for advice or to sift through a pile of medical records. fields.headline: The height of style
fields.standfirst: When artist Wallace bought his beloved Camberwell home, he had high hopes for the ceilings. Tamsin Blanchard reports
fields.trailText: When artist Wallace bought his beloved Camberwell home, he had high hopes for the ceilings. Tamsin Blanchard reports
fields.body:
How could I refuse? The phone call came out of the blue, and the voice on the other end was most insistent that I go and have a look at his stepfather's home. 'It's the ceilings', he was saying. 'They're incredible. He's painted them all himself. No, he can't send you some pictures. You have to see them in the flesh.' So off I set to leafy Camberwell in south London, in search of one man's own private Sistine Chapel.

Wallace, an artist, lives on the ground floor and basement of one of those fine Georgian terraces that you wonder how anybody possibly affords. With trepidation, I step inside, not quite sure what to expect. The ceilings could be masterful works of art. But I envisage kitsch cherubs with angel's wings, flying from corner to corner. I fix a smile, expecting the worst. Wallace seems friendly enough, and shows me into a light, sunny room with a long table in the middle. The window looks out on to the most glorious leafy garden, meandering into the distance. And while Wallace makes coffee, I dare to glance up at the ceiling. This is not what I expected. It is white. No cherubs. Not an angel wing in sight. But it's not exactly plain. The cornicing is all original - intricately detailed and perfectly formed. It would be a crime to paint this ceiling anything but white.

It took Wallace - it's his surname, but that's what most people call him - the best part of a year to restore his dining-room ceiling, and clean away layers of paint that have accumulated over time. It almost drove him mad. Life seemed too short to restore the rest of the ceilings, so Wallace decided to build new ceilings on top of the old ones. 'The design is partly to do with how they are made,' says Wallace. 'I had to deal with the weight on my own.'

He started with the kitchen, building a simple ceiling with tongue-and-grooved planks of wood, slotted together. And then things began to get a little more elaborate. In the bedroom, there are blue rag-worked panels, supported by a latticework of red wood. The ceiling is beautifully crafted, with a hint of a Japanese aesthetic. In the hall is a brick-red ceiling with mossy green supports. They have a 30s look, and a touch of the Arts and Crafts movement. Wallace says he was inspired by the work of American architect Louis Sullivan, and the Chicago Library. The idea was to build new ceilings without destroying what was already there. 'The original ceilings are intact,' he says. 'If someone didn't like what I've done, they could take them down and restore what is underneath.'

Wallace has a long history with the house. He first moved into the fine terraced Regency crescent in 1967, when he rented a flat on the first floor. He also rented the basement as a studio. Then, in the 70s, he moved out to live around the corner and jumped at the chance to buy the ground floor and his beloved studio when it went on the market in 1986. He remembers paying '90-something'. This summer, however, the house will go back on the market after Wallace has finished 'tarting it up a little' - offers in the region of £450,000. With or without the ceilings, it's been a good investment. Indeed, Wallace, who is now 60, says 'it's instead of a pension'. He intends to move to Dorset, where he will continue to paint and use the profits to support himself. 'It's a shame I can't keep the place,' he says. 'But you get older and don't have the money.'

The house was converted into flats in the early 20th century, and has not changed much since then. A dark hallway leads to the dining room and kitchen, then on to Wallace's office and his bedroom - the one with the red and blue ceiling. The kitchen is at the back of the house, looking out over the gardens. It is clad in wood panelling - all Wallace's own work. Leaning on a wall between the dining room and kitchen is a giant's toothbrush, a maquette for a sculpture by the artist's friend and tutor from his days at Camberwell College of Arts, David Troostwyk. Most of the other art on the walls is Wallace's own. There are word paintings and his most recent, ongoing series of eclipse paintings, which he started before the solar eclipse of last year.

Downstairs, past the bathroom which is also clad in wood panelling - this time, ingeniously recycled from old school desks - is the painter's studio. He has done a lot of work on the basement. 'When I first started here it was grim. I wired it up and put some lights in.' These days, the studio is spacious and airy, a huge room at the front filled with half-finished canvases and hospital lights used for working through the night. At the back is Wallace's workshop, where he builds his ceilings and cuts his wood, and a room which leads out to a spiral staircase up to the garden. As part of his 'tarting-up' process, Wallace has laid some pea gravel outside and put some plants out, as well as adding a new toilet to a small utility room down there. It is still rough and raw in the basement, but there is original wood-block flooring and it is a perfect shell to build on.

Back upstairs, Wallace is musing on his ceilings again. The hallway works particularly well, with its decorative leaf motif finishing each end of the wooden slats. He's proud of his handiwork. 'I think it looks good. I'd like to copy the ceiling pattern onto the floor. You could easily do it.' He eyes up the floors, his mind working overtime. It looks as though whoever buys the house when it goes on the market this summer will be living with Wallace's art long after he has moved to Dorset.

fields.headline: Life support
fields.standfirst: Author and former aide to John Major, Michael Dobbs knew his life would never be the same after the Tory defeat of 1997. But his brother Peter and a common interest in genealogy brought him back from the brink
fields.trailText: Author and former aide to John Major, Michael Dobbs knew his life would never be the same after the Tory defeat of 1997. But his brother Peter and a common interest in genealogy brought him back from the brink.
fields.body:
Michael Dobbs We grew up in Hertford, in a working-class family. There was always a struggle for money. There were four of us children. I remember our mother sold our piano, I later discovered, to buy our Christmas presents. In many respects Peter and I are chalk and cheese: in some ways you couldn't find brothers with fewer abilities in common. When we were young we loathed one another. Being five years older, he was always leaving school as I was starting. On my first day, the teacher picked me up by the ear and dragged me around the classroom, ranting, 'Look what we've got here, another Dobbs!' I never imagined that we'd be close. He left home at 16, and has spent the past 35 years living in Canada, so I didn't see him for years and years.

Peter Dobbs Michael and I had a passing relationship. I was the black sheep of the family, always in trouble. I didn't achieve much at school, unlike Michael. I didn't do as well as my father expected me to. I never related to my father at all. I left when I was 22, to bum around the world. I ended up on the west coast of Vancouver Island and have been there for 33 years. I restore old English cars, old Jaguars and Austins. I've always been fixing things.

In the early 80s, Michael had been collating family history. He sent me what he'd found and it sparked my interest, and even though I had no family within 8,000 miles, it made me think and I kind of missed my family. I thought all the work he was doing was like searching for an old car: I can search for days in old barns for my cars. Our common interest in genealogy was something we were able to build our relationship with.

MD While Peter was in Canada, I was at Downing Street when Margaret Thatcher stepped across the threshold in 1975 and for nearly 25 years I was immersed in politics. Then I worked as an aide to John Major. But it was clear things were going horribly wrong. I was becoming disillusioned with the whole lifestyle and the party, it was affecting everything that I did. The evening of the 1997 election was the single most painful night of my life. Politics isn't a job, it's a lifestyle, a career, a social life. I realised that all was lost and wasted. I didn't want to talk to anybody. I wanted to go away and lick my wounds and forget about the world.

Peter started to phone weekly from Canada. We never used to talk to each other, and had a relationship which was often very difficult, but he was just there. He'd call, with the frying pan sizzling in the background, and tell me what a wonderful breakfast he was having, which helped me think about other things. I was depressed and pretty miserable. I went through a couple of very bad years. I kept asking, so what's the rest of my life going to be? I had no intention of wandering around as a failed political hack.

Fortunately, I've had writing to fall back on [House of Cards and To Play the King were adapted for television]. Throughout it all Peter kept checking on me. Because he's family and he was away, it was easier to relate to him than a person on the spot. He acted as a safety valve, making sure I was getting through it, which I only realised with hindsight.

PD I had been through similar changes in my life. When you've been in something for 25 years, and you have to take another path, it can be pretty scary. It's good to have a sounding board, someone you can trust. My life now has so little stress in it, and I'd hear him on the other end of the phone recalling his frantic week. I had been trying to nail him down for over a year to take a trip together together. Finally I ended up coming over and we went to Ireland, grave-hunting, meeting wonderful Irish people, and discovering things about the Dobbs family. We know they arrived in Ireland in 1650, but from where we don't yet know.

Once you start asking questions, you realise you are a link in a long chain and it becomes interesting to find out what those other links are. We only knew one of our grandparents, and we discovered everything we had been told about them was a pack of lies. Our maternal grandfather, we were told, died. The truth is that when my mother was a baby, he left them in terrible circumstances, with no money and back rent owing. There was a lot of anger and shame. Our mother wouldn't talk about it.

She also had a half brother who was another great source of mystery. He was deaf and dumb and badly treated as a child. He is still alive and for a very long time we have been deciding whether to contact him or not. On the one hand, it might be of great relief to him to find he has family, or, at his old age, it might cause him pain. There are so many fractured emotions. Our father never talked very much about his family, either. These days we share all our secrets, everything is open.

 Michael Dobbs's new novel, Whispers of Betrayal, is published by HarperCollins at £9.99

Because he's family and he was away, it was easier to relate to him than a person on the spot. He acted as a safety valve, making sure I was getting through it, which I only realised with hindsight. PD I had been through similar changes in my life. When you've been in something for 25 years, and you have to take another path, it can be pretty scary. It's good to have a sounding board, someone you can trust. My life now has so little stress in it, and I'd hear him on the other end of the phone recalling his frantic week. I had been trying to nail him down for over a year to take a trip together together. Finally I ended up coming over and we went to Ireland, grave-hunting, meeting wonderful Irish people, and discovering things about the Dobbs family. We know they arrived in Ireland in 1650, but from where we don't yet know. Once you start asking questions, you realise you are a link in a long chain and it becomes interesting to find out what those other links are. We only knew one of our grandparents, and we discovered everything we had been told about them was a pack of lies. Our maternal grandfather, we were told, died. The truth is that when my mother was a baby, he left them in terrible circumstances, with no money and back rent owing. There was a lot of anger and shame. Our mother wouldn't talk about it. She also had a half brother who was another great source of mystery. He was deaf and dumb and badly treated as a child. He is still alive and for a very long time we have been deciding whether to contact him or not. On the one hand, it might be of great relief to him to find he has family, or, at his old age, it might cause him pain. There are so many fractured emotions. Our father never talked very much about his family, either. These days we share all our secrets, everything is open.  Michael Dobbs's new novel, Whispers of Betrayal, is published by HarperCollins at £9.99

fields.headline: Stress? What stress...
fields.trailText: David Walden gained an insight into the issues faced by people in retirement during his work as director of Age Concern in Hampshire. Now, 61 this week, he is going through the experience himself.
fields.body:
David Walden gained an insight into the issues faced by people in retirement during his work as director of Age Concern in Hampshire. Now, 61 this week, he is going through the experience himself.

'There is a lot more involved than money', he has decided already. Relationships may need to be reassessed. 'A lot of people don't realise that they have been in a part-time marriage before.'

Yet most pre-retirement courses concentrate solely on financial issues, particularly invest ing the lump sums people generally receive with their pensions, says David. He is expressing his views in a book, although he is often too busy to write. He does part-time consultancy work and sits on the board of a housing association. He has also joined a health club. 'I never seem to have any time to do anything, but everyone says that about retirement.'

Physically, he feels much better than he did while working full time. 'I am much less stressed,' he says.

It has been easier than expected for he and his wife Avril to live on less. He retired on a pension of half his final salary in local government before joining Age Concern. They 'don't live high off the hog', but deny themselves nothing and can afford holidays abroad.

It is older pensioners who are in difficulty because they are less likely to have good private pensions, he says. David welcomes the Government fuel payments but would prefer them to go to those on lower incomes.

He has £60,000 saved and enjoys looking after it. 'I have chunks in bonds and some on instant access.'

fields.headline: Four of the best...
fields.standfirst: ...places to buy the ultimate kitchen gizmos
fields.trailText: ...places to buy the ultimate kitchen gizmos.
fields.body:
The dividing line between usefulness and gimmickry in the kitchen is a tricky and often personal matter. I would never buy an egg poacher or a machine for making popcorn, although doubtless some people swear by them. One of my favourite kitchen catalogues, precisely because of its mix of gadgetry and practical ideas, is Lakeland Limited (Alexandra Buildings, Windermere, Cumbria LA23 1BQ, 015394 88100; www.lakelandlimited.com). It sells such oddities as a tomato slicer (what's wrong with a knife?), a whistling bain-marie (doesn't say which tune), and a selection of Delia's favourites', as well as useful Kilner-type preserving jars (£11.95 for six 1-litre jars, plus £2 for 10 replacement rings), and a very handy item I remember from my granny's kitchen: a beaded, lacy food cover (two sizes, £32.95 and £8.95) to drape over bowls and trays of drinks to keep out insects. I am also taken by 'the ultimate in non-stick liners' made from reinforced cotton: heat resistant, it can be cut to any shape and will withstand 'five years or more of constant use'. It is designed for baking, but can also be used to fry eggs.

A similar combination of wacky and functional ideas pervades Nisbets (Freepost BS 4675, Bristol BS32 4FA, 01454 855 555; www.nisbets.co.uk). Geared largely to the catering trade, it sells black-and-white Gary Rhodes-style check trousers, industrial-strength blenders, and an 80-piece 'garnishing set' for sculpting, carving, cutting and decorating, the entire stock of which I am tempted to buy up and destroy so that I never have to come across the results in a restaurant ever again. But it also sells an indispensable cast-iron frying pan (£13.50), big stockpots holding up to 88 pints (from £40 to £140), and stainless-steel-lined copper pans (not much change from £100).

La Cuisiniere (87e/f Northcote Road, London SW11, 020 7223 4409; www.la-cuisiniere.co.uk) might try and sell you a timer on a rope, to remind you in the bath or on the train that you left a cake in the oven, as well as a fondue set: the small one for chocolate at £15.95, plus six forks at £6.50, might have its uses. Fine and coarse Microplane graters (£18 each) are ace at zesting lemons, puréeing garlic, grating chocolate or hard cheese and shredding coconut. A companion to the padded wine cooler is the Therm au Rouge wine warmer (£9.99): the heat from a short boil is retained in the gel-filled sleeve and transferred to a bottle, to bring it from cellar to room temperature in five to 10 minutes.

When it comes to knives, David Mellor (4 Sloane Square, London SW1; 020 7730 4259) is something of a specialist, dealing in the Japanese-inspired Global range (£30 to £70) and classic Sabatiers (mostly £20 to £30).

Other useful addresses are Peter Maturi (84-86 Vicar Lane, Leeds, West Yorks; 0113 245 3887), The Professional Cookware Company (Freepost SWC1836, Cheltenham, GL50 3ZZ; 08700 707 172), Divertimenti (45 Wigmore Street, London W1; 020 7935 0689), and Cucina Direct (PO Box 6611, London SW15; 020 8246 4300).

Jim Ainsworth is editor of The Good Food Guide

fields.headline: Handle with care
fields.standfirst: Why mangoes are like a woman's breasts
fields.trailText: Why mangoes are like a woman's breasts.
fields.body:
If you ever find yourself stuck for conversation with an Indian, just casually mention mangoes. It will act like a charm, for I have never yet met one who does not adore them with a passion. This obsession may seem odd to the uninitiated, especially if you have grappled with large South American mangoes, but try just one of the myriad sweet fibreless varieties from the Indian subcontinent and you will immediately understand.

'The best mango is the Alphonso,' states Vineet Bhatia, head chef of Zaika in Fulham Road, London. Shaped like a plump, blushing yellow comma, its matt skin hides an aromatic yellow flesh that is utterly delicious. 'They are ripe when they release a fragrance near their stem and yield slightly on being pressed near the top,' he explains. 'We used to eat them in our courtyard in Bombay, whole basketfuls, washed down with ice cold, sweet lassis.' I sense his longing to rush back, just so that he can eat them in the searing heat.

Such decadence is only possible here, if you visit an Asian supermarket. They are sold in handy fridge-sized boxes, although they should only be chilled just before eating. Boxes vary in size and can contain anywhere between six and 12 mangoes, snugly cushioned in shredded paper to retain their warmth. Depending on availability, they can cost between 50p and £1 each. Always inspect the contents before buying as quality can vary. If stocks are low and the mangoes look wrinkly, wait until the next order is due.

Eating mangoes is a messy business and should not be undertaken in public, let alone in good clothes as its juice will stream down your hands, elbows and chin. Never eat a mango with knife and fork, it is verging on the barbarous, and you cannot possibly appreciate it fully. Everyone has their own method of tackling this sensual fruit. 'You should gently massage the mango like a woman's breast, so that the fruit becomes more juicy,' recommends Vineet Bhatia, 'then peel back the skin and gradually suck the flesh from both the skin and the stone.' I prefer to simply cut the flesh, unskinned and unmolested, away from the stone in four segments. The two larger quarters are cut in half lengthways, allowing you to easily prise the flesh away with your teeth. It is the skin which enhances the mango's taste.

Alphonsos are coming to the end of their season, but according to Avnish Malde, commercial manager for Wealmoor, tropical fruit growers and importers for the supermarkets, you can console yourself with several other good fibreless Indian varieties. The highly coloured, slightly less fragrant Kesar mango, for example, appears in June. Or you could try a close cousin to the Alphonso, the bright yellow, delicate tasting Banganpali mango which is available throughout May and June. You will even be able to buy them in Waitrose this June. By July, you will find equally sweet, fibreless Pakistani varieties replacing the Indian imports, allowing mango addicts to indulge their passion for one more month.

 Zaika, 257-259 Fulham Road, London SW3 (020 7351 7823)

fields.headline: Second opinion
fields.standfirst: Every country recommends a daily intake of nutrients. As the US raises its levels again, we ask: are ours too low?
fields.trailText: Every country recommends a daily intake of nutrients. As the US raises its levels again, we ask: are ours too low?
fields.body:
NO: Judy Buttriss of the British Nutrition Foundation

'The recommended daily nutrient intakes for healthy people in this country are set at levels consistent with current scientific knowledge. Yes, the Americans have higher levels than we do for many nutrients, but as every country's scientists use different methodology to identify the recommendations, discrepancies will occur. What's more, the levels are population-specific. It's increasingly clear that genetic factors determine how well our bodies use nutrients (and therefore how much they need to stay healthy).

Current recommendations apply to someone eating a well-balanced diet. While one or two studies may show that high levels of nutrients help some conditions, this does not constitute conclusive proof. Nutrients can help your health, but they can also harm it if taken in excess. Until we understand at what point the balance shifts, the foundation believes the recommended intakes are about right. At particular times in our lives we may need higher levels of certain nutrients, but for the general population, eating the recommended amounts of nutrients every day through our diet is an easy way to ensure good health.

YES: Stephen Terrass of Solgar, a supplement company

As far as vitamins are concerned, I think the government's current recommended nutrient levels (RDAs) are an injustice to the British public. In today's society, a good state of health is no longer good enough. Research proves we can do more for our bodies and the government should be advising us of that.

The RDAs for vitamins are, at best, relevant to preventing diseases that are virtually non-existent in Britain such as scurvy, rickets and beriberi. Yet there is scientific evidence showing that certain nutrients can help protect against diseases that either kill or debilitate a large percentage of the population, including heart disease and cancer - but this can only be accomplished with levels far exceeding the RDA.

I don't know why the authorities won't change things. Perhaps it's easier to stick with something that exists. There's also the fact that if the government recommended higher levels, it would need to subsidise lower income families to reach them. But whatever the reason, keeping the levels low is doing a disservice to people who want to boost their health.

fields.headline: Just kidding
fields.standfirst: Jay Rayner's trip to Levant in London didn't live up to expectations. The setting was lovely, the service was exemplary, but the food got his goat
fields.trailText: Jay Rayner's trip to Levant in London didn't live up to expectations. The setting was lovely, the service was exemplary, but the food got his goat
fields.body:
For a while now, I have been trying to work out exactly what it is that matters when it comes to setting up a new restaurant. Not what matters to me, mind. I might like crème brlée but I can't expect it on every menu. No, what matters to those who are in the business of trying to recoup the major investment (these days rarely less than £1.5m) that, like a hungry diner, a serious new establishment can so easily swallow.

Take, for example, Levant, a new place on London's Wigmore Street specialising in the food of North Africa and the Middle East. Or, should I say, a new venture in an old place, which has had a bit of a makeover. The makeover has been successful, the basement room transformed by the use of clever lighting and 10 shades of caramel into something both soothing and inviting. The staff are exemplary, if a little toothachingly beautiful for my liking.

The wine list is sensible and not grossly overpriced. The cocktails are great, the music is not obtrusive and the bowls of olives, pickled radishes and cucumbers are as you would wish them to be.

The problem, and I am sure you are ahead of me by now, is the food. It is not even all the food. As I say, there are the olives and great pieces of pillowy flat bread. There were also terrific dips to scoop away while perusing the menu: a subtle taramasalata, a sturdy hummus, and the best examples of baba ghanoush that I've ever tasted.

The problem was with the other stuff we ordered from the kitchen. Part of the problem stems, I think, from the concept. Levant is an attempt to take the North African restaurant up-market, away from the crimson and cobalt blue souk fantasies that usually attend such exercises.

The chef, Michael Smith, is, as his name suggests, rather less than Levantine, and he has therefore had to learn the vocabulary and grammar of the food he is to cook. As a result, there is something awfully good-mannered about it, as if a fear of serious spicing has overcome the kitchen. It's like belly dancing without enough belly. What's the point?

There were six of us at our table, so we were able to give the menu a good work over. A salad of baby broad beans with mint and yoghurt was a perfect example of the problem: it was light and fresh but it lacked any zing. Almond-crusted deep-fried squid with lemon and parsley was an interesting idea, but, again, lacked the lushness that a plate of freshly fried calamari can deliver.

The problem was more pronounced in the main courses. Braised, spiced lamb with potatoes and chickpeas was an unobtrusive example of the sort of stew you could get at any taverna. Lemon-marinated, spatchcock poussin suffered the double whammy of tasteless poussin and not enough lemon.

The slow-cooked roast kid was one of the fattiest pieces of meat I've ever had, though the meat that lurked beneath the duvets of white fat was sweet and fibrous. The kitchen may respond that this is simply the authentic way of serving roast kid, but that doesn't hold, given that so many of the other dishes were so inauthentic. You can't have it both ways. The puddings we tried - a walnut baklava, lemon semolina cake with lemon syrup and, particularly, almond- stuffed honey dates with clotted cream - were the best things ordered from the menu.

Perhaps the food is subservient to the decor, the service, the concept, the buzz. Perhaps I'm a fool to make a fuss, but I don't think so. The fact is I can forgive a restaurant almost anything if it gives me great things to eat. That is the point of going there. Isn't it?  Levant, Jason Court, 76 Wigmore Street, London W1 (020 7224 1111). Dinner for two, including service and wine, £90. Jay Rayner can be contacted at jay.rayner@observer.co.uk

fields.headline: Flying doctor
fields.standfirst: Don't arrive feeling tired, irritable and bloated - these simple steps ensure you'll touch down with nothing to declare
fields.trailText: Don't arrive feeling tired, irritable and bloated - these simple steps ensure you'll touch down with nothing to declare.
fields.body:
Flying economy can be bad for your health: you could end up with a blood clot, suffer from fainting fits and become irritable and anxious. So says Farrol Kahn, of the Aviation Health Institute.

Passengers who travel business or first class - probably on expenses - may benefit from more generous seating and better food, but most of us feel far from refreshed when we arrive at our destinations. The long list of flying-related complaints includes feeling over tired, tetchy and bloated (shoes, for example, feeling tight on swollen feet), as well as being plagued by headaches and indigestion. Indeed, a reader's letter recently recited precisely these problems and asked if food can help to alleviate jet lag and minimise body trauma in flight and afterwards.

It will probably come as no surprise that alcohol is the first target. Not only does booze appear to be a significant cause of 'air rage', but alcohol's other negative effects on the body are magnified when it is consumed at altitude, which explains why you may both feel drunk faster than usual and suffer from a horrendous hangover on arrival. Its dehydrating action causes your skin to dry out, your head to ache and your energy levels to crash. In addition, a tipple imbibed on an empty stomach can increase your appetite: not only may you feel powerless to resist nibbling on nuts and crisps, but once your main meal arrives, you may still feel ravenous. Because most flyers eat purely out of boredom, the last thing you need is for alcohol to increase this temptation.

Most frequent flyers support the argument that if you refrain from alcohol and hydrate your body with water (either still or fizzy, although some people find that drinking fizzy water while flying causes their stomachs to bloat), you'll feel more refreshed when you land. Aim to drink two small glasses of water every hour and stick to a maximum of a couple of cups of tea or coffee, because excess caffeine can also dehydrate the body, causing fluctuating moods, sensitive digestion and headaches. If you're a well-organised traveller, tuck a few herbal teabags in your hand luggage (camomile encourages sleep, while mint aids the digestion). If you're feeling peckish, a caffeine-free drink can also serve as an appetite-questioner: are you feeling hungry because you're genuinely in need of nourishment or because you're bored?

You are probably familiar with the in-flight tendency of feet and hands to swell. This most commonly occurs as a result of a temporary imbalance in the level of salt (sodium) in your blood, and consuming salty foods, such as crisps, nuts and olives, makes matters worse. Potassium, on the other hand, helps to correct this imbalance and reduces fluid retention, so while on board, try to boost your intake of potassium-rich foods, including fresh fruit and vegetables such as bananas and tomatoes, or fresh fruit juices, like orange. This doesn't mean that you should eat nothing but raw food while you're flying, just that you should ask for grapes or an apple to accompany cheese, for example. Fruit also slowly releases energy-giving sugar, along with some fibre, into the body, thereby keeping the digestive system active. Even dried fruits, which can easily be stowed in a travel bag, can serve as a good inflight nibble.

Eating something healthy every few hours reduces the likelihood of inflight indigestion, particularly if you have a weakness such as a hiatus hernia, an acidic stomach, an ulcer or intestinal bloating, all of which can be exacerbated by the increase in cabin pressure. The digestive system generally finds it hard to digest fatty, spicy or overly sweet foods, which is not helped by the way many airline-catering companies dowse their food in sauces. A pressurised gut responds well to simply cooked chicken or fish (if it's served with a rich sauce, scrape off as much as possible), pasta or a sandwich without mayonnaise.

Eating to influence how your body feels is one of the most important things that you can do when flying. Pasta, potatoes and other starchy foods can induce soporific feelings to help lull your body to sleep or to relax. Because high-fibre starches, such as wholegrain toast, rolls or crispbreads, provide your body with a sustaining energy boost, they can constitute a healthy inflight breakfast, particularly when eaten with fruit. Although croissants and Danish pastries may provide instant gratification, because they contain high levels of fat and sugar, you won't feel satiated for long and may be tempted to devour more food on arrival.

If your body is calling out for a substantial, energising brunch or lunch, try to include some protein-rich foods - smoked salmon, scrambled eggs or lean charcuterie - in your meal. Opting for protein can also be helpful when you're flying westward and gaining hours, because protein energises you rather than making you feel sleepy. Ideally, accompany the protein source with some fibre (perhaps a wholegrain roll), or follow it with fruit. You could also pack a small nutritional first-aid kit, including a bottle of echinacea tincture, which will boost your immune system, helping it to ward off the bacteria and viruses circulating around the cabin. (The recommended dose is typically in the region of either a 500mg capsule or tablet or three-quarters to one teaspoon of tincture dissolved in a small amount of water, taken three times a day.) If you suffer from stomach or bowel bloating, try taking acidophilus pills (the recommended dose is usually about 20mg a day), preferably with a little yogurt, or if this isn't available, some still water. All in all, when packing your suitcase, remember that packing the right nutrients into your body will result in a healthy glow that will far outshine your suntan.

 Jane Clarke is a state-registered dietician and author of The Bodyfoods series of books

fields.headline: True colours
fields.standfirst: While Jackson Pollock and the New York abstract expressionists were in full throttle, Helen Frankenthaler was quietly changing the face of modern painting. As a new exhibition reintroduces her work to a British audience, Sir Anthony Caro salutes an artist who puts others in the shade
fields.trailText: While Jackson Pollock and the New York abstract expressionists were in full throttle, Helen Frankenthaler was quietly changing the face of modern painting. As a new exhibition reintroduces her work to a British audience, Sir Anthony Caro salutes an artist who puts others in the shade
fields.body:
Helen Frankenthaler's close contemporaries included Pollock, the sculptor David Smith, the writer Clement Greenberg and the painter Robert Motherwell, whom she married. Her technique of pouring thinned paint directly on to huge unprimed canvasses - colour staining - was taken up by her better-known contemporaries Morris Louis and Kenneth Noland. Now 71, of all the women on the American art scene today she is probably the most recognised and celebrated, yet in this country, unlike her peers, she is barely represented. Here, sculptor Sir Anthony Caro, friend of Frankenthaler's for 40 years, talks about the woman and her work

I went to America in 1959 on a travel scholarship and when I was in New York I visited a critic called Doré Ashton. Who should be there but Helen and her husband, the painter Bob Motherwell? They offered me a lift to my hotel, so we went uptown together and, on the way, they said: 'You must be lonesome here, you don't know anybody. We'll give a party for you.' That's how friendly they were. They gave a wonderful party. I was sitting next to the film star Hedy Lamarr, which was a surprise. The sculptor David Smith was there and the painter Franz Kline. It was amazing to come in as a young man not knowing anybody and find that tremendously welcoming attitude.

We didn't talk about our work then, but in 1963 I went back for two years with my wife, the painter Sheila Girling, and my two sons, to teach at Bennington College in Vermont, where Helen had been a student. At the weekends a lot of practising artists were around. I got to know her better then, but it wasn't until she divorced Bob in 1971 that I really got to know her as a person and to talk about art. She had been very close to Clement Greenberg years before and we all used to meet often at Kenneth Noland's farm.

Jules Olitski - another painter - Noland, Helen and I were all going in the same direction really. Coming from Britain and meeting those artists in New York was a knockout. They weren't hamstrung by history, which I think we were in England. In America they were saying, 'We've got to push the boundaries.' They were very open to experiment, especially with new materials, and they worked on a grand scale, buying canvas by the roll, which I had never seen before. We went to each other's studios and discussed and criticised each other's work. It was completely different from what I had known. In England, one had little contact with other artists' studios, except of course at the sculpture department at St Martin's School of Art, where I was teaching.

Olitski, Noland, Helen and I shared a whole aesthetic. Trying to be direct, not let a lot of technical stuff get in the way. I think that's why I turned to steel. Because it isn't cast, you don't have to make a great big armature before you start. Paintings like Helen's Mountains and Sea are very direct. They are painted on the unprimed canvas, using the acrylic very thinly: bang - there it is. It's a big painting but it's painted like a watercolour. That sort of directness is something that I share with her - trying to get your feelings to come straight through without a lot of barriers. Noland used to talk about one-shot painting - it comes out of abstract expressionism and Pollock.

Helen's language is paint. It seems to come straight from her. She's a tremendous natural painter, and that's not an easy thing to pass on. People who want to really enjoy the quality of the paint and the paper, letting go a bit, they've been influenced by her. She's not an ideas painter, she's a painter's painter. That's very unfashionable at the moment and that's probably why she's not mentioned as much as she should be. Nevertheless, she is very well known in the US and her work does travel, but I think the English are rather frightened of things that are sensual and appeal to the gut. We like to be bit more cerebral, harder. We seem to have to have reasons for everything.

There's a direct lead-in to her hand. That's the big thing - she talks a lot about the wrist, the hand. She is able to put something down and that's it. It's an incredible thing to be so sure that you don't fiddle. And she gets it right - that's what's incredible.

I regularly visit America, and once I said to Helen that she should come and work in England some time, in my sculpture studio. Suddenly I got a letter saying, 'How about in three weeks' time?' That was in 1972. She worked in my studio here in Camden [north London]. She'd work full days for two or three weeks and was incredibly direct. Her eye is terrific. There's a confidence about her work. The sculptures she made have scarcely ever been seen publicly and are remarkable.

Helen then invited me to go and make paintings in her studio in New York. I said, 'No, I'm not a painter.' My wife is the painter and I've always said, 'You do the paintings and I'll do the sculpture.' But Helen said, 'No, you've got to come to the studio.' So I went to New York and stayed in the Wales Hotel, which was little more than a doss- house uptown. I walked into to her studio on the first day and she said, 'Here is your assistant, there are your paints and your rolls of canvas. It's all yours' - amazingly generous. I said, 'Helen, I thought you'd be working here, too.' She came in occasionally and, when she did, she was wonderful. She would focus on the weak or strong areas and, with her outside eye, could direct me to the heart of the paintings. I hated making pictures, actually. In the end I cut them up and made them into collages - like sculpture!

In the 80s, we started the Triangle Workshop in the US for British, American and Canadian artists and Helen used to come every year to do a criticism. People looked forward to her visits. You could really talk about art with her. She is neglected compared to her contemporaries. I don't know if it has anything to do with her being a woman. She never wanted to be thought of as 'a woman artist': she has always expected her art to be judged on equal terms.

She often sends a note saying: 'Missing you both, how are you, what are you doing?' When I was last in New York I had dinner with her and her husband, Stephen DuBrul. I owe her a phone call because she hasn't been well. Hopefully she'll be able to come over for the Bernard Jacobson show.

It's a difficult time for Helen because you tend to look at her work and say it's beautiful, and these days that's against the fashion. It's a pity. It would be a terrible shame if the art goes out of art - and she's a real artist.

 An exhibition of recent works on paper by Helen Frankenthaler is at the Bernard Jacobson Gallery, 14a Clifford Street, London W1 (020 7495 8575) until 28 June From an interview with the artist by Julia Brown in After Mountains and Sea: Frankenthaler 1956-59 (Guggenheim Museum Publications)

fields.headline: Midsummer murder
fields.standfirst: It's the stuff of nightmares. You're being mugged, three teenagers approach, but instead of helping you, they join the attack. And then they decide to kill you.
fields.trailText: It's the stuff of nightmares. You're being mugged, three teenagers approach, but instead of helping you, they join the attack. And then they decide to kill you.
fields.body:
Two days before midsummer last year, as a red dawn was nudging the City skyline, Timothy Baxter and his old friend Gabriel Cornish strolled from Tottenham Court Road down to Charing Cross and up the steps of Hungerford Bridge. They were both 24 and had known each other since early childhood. They had been brought up at the Sheen school in Putney and had gone on to Richmond College. They had kept in touch during their years at university and later, as they had started their careers. They were friends.

That evening, after Baxter had spent an hour or so clattering about on his skateboard in the concrete caverns of the South Bank, they had walked into the West End for a drink at a bar in Leicester Square, before joining a group of friends to go clubbing in Charing Cross Road. Both men were at the beginning of their adult lives; Cornish was starting a career in the music business and had taken a job in sound engineering after completing a course at the south London College of Music. Baxter had read philosophy at Manchester University and was due to enrol at law school in the coming September.

Neither was flush and that evening they had eked out their drinks while they sat and relaxed in that aimless way students have. Then, happy and relaxed, chatting and oblivious to their surroundings, they decided to walk back to Baxter's mother's home on the South Bank. It was a warm night and the river was quiet. One or two late-night taxis cruised up and down the Embankment and, up river, lorries loaded with fruit and vegetables rolled across the bridges and into the market at Nine Elms. In those moments before the dawn of a summer day, London was at its most placid.

At the same time as Baxter and Cornish stepped on to the north end of Hungerford Bridge, three men, Sonni Reid, John Riches and a 14-year-old boy who we must refer to as Juvenile A, had swung out of the Waterloo Embankment and on to the southern end of the bridge where it joins the walkways of the Royal Festival Hall.

Reid, high on alcohol and cannabis, was 18 and homeless; Riches, 6'4" and 21 years old, had been making his living by casually stealing whatever he could get his hands on. The juvenile, the third member of the pack, was experienced in the ways of the street. He had form - theft, assault and attempted burglary and an attitude loaded with contempt for everyone he met.

None of the three had been clubbing or sitting chatting with friends, their educational accomplishments were minimal and they had few loyalties - other than to themselves. They were as at home in the London night as Cornish and Baxter were not and their hunting ground, which they had come to know like the backs of their hands, was the fertile alleyways and streets of London's Theatreland and the Thames Embankment.

As Baxter and Cornish reached the centre of the narrow metal span which runs alongside the train tracks from Charing Cross station to the South Bank, three more figures followed them on to the bridge from the north. They were a girl of 16 [Juvenile C] and a 17-year-old [Juvenile B] - a short, thick-set boy from Woolwich. They were in the company of Cameron Cyrus, a loose-limbed and imposing 6'3" 19-year-old.

So it was as if the fates had conspired to lead two young men, with their lives before them, smiling into the jaws of danger. As Baxter and Cornish met the first trio in the middle of the bridge, the two young men were confronted and attacked. Baxter was carrying his skateboard, a prized possession, but had no money to speak of.

'You've got the wrong people,' he said. 'We have nothing, leave us alone.' A few moments later, Cyrus and his two companions appeared. Cornish turned to them, pleading for help. The request fell on deaf ears. Their attackers took the skateboard and threw it over the parapet; then they took Baxter's glasses and threw them over as well.

Nobody will ever know exactly what happened on Hungerford Bridge that night. After discovering that Baxter and Cornish were telling the truth and that neither man had any money, some of the group attacked them. They beat them to the ground and then they kicked them in the face and stamped on their heads. We know that Cornish was attacked by Juvenile A, who had demanded the silver chain from his wrist. 'I refused to give it to him,' Cornish said later. 'It was a present from my parents.' But A attacked him and in minutes Cornish and Baxter were lying bleeding on the metal footway of the bridge.

Juvenile A then encouraged the others to take the two men and throw them into the river. They lifted Baxter, walked him to the parapet and dropped him into the Thames, which was in full flood. Then they did the same to Cornish. It was as if they perpetrated this sort of crime every day of the year. Beat someone up and, when you've finished, throw them away. Because if they're dead, they can't do anything about it.

There was no surveillance on the bridge, but all six seemed to realise that they could be picked up by the cameras as soon as they left it. After returning to the South Bank, Reid, Riches and Juvenile A decided to separate from the group and walked away on their own, returning to the north. Their work was not over for the night and within a few minutes they had robbed another young man, Matthew Reynolds, as he stood watching the sunrise on the Embankment. Riches and the juvenile had started to assault Reynolds but were dissuaded by Reid.

Terrorised and angry, Reynolds had given up his wallet and a cigarette lighter and had then been left alone. After the three had left, on their way to Leicester Square, he went to the police and reported what had happened.

Other pedestrians, alarmed at the aggressive behaviour of the three, also reported them and a patrol car eventually tracked them down in St Martin's Court, off Charing Cross Road, where Reid was amusing himself by doing press-ups on the pavement. Within an hour, the three youths were in custody at Charing Cross police station.

The arrest was just another incident in a long and lively night of assaults, thefts, robberies, rapes and false alarms. After an hour in the cells, Reid, Riches and their young companion were processed and brought out of the custody suite on the ground floor of Charing Cross and into the fetid, claustrophobic interview rooms. Reynolds had made a statement and the three suspects were questioned about it individually without requesting the presence of a solicitor. In interview, Riches immediately blurted out that 'something had happened on the bridge' and the police had their first intimation that there had been a serious incident.

Both boys had been concussed at the time they hit the river. Baxter had been badly beaten and never regained consciousness, but Cornish was more fortunate and the water seemed to have revived him. He can recollect little of what happened but, in a chilling moment during the subsequent trial, he described a vague memory in which he saw his friend standing on the river bank and waving. The image seems to have been a spur to his return to consciousness and to have helped to raise him from his concussion and give him some sort of control over his actions. He remembered seeing Big Ben as he drifted past and discovering that he was clutching his friend's rucksack, which gave him enough buoyancy to keep afloat.

He was drifting on the tide and quickly reached Vauxhall Bridge, over half a mile up river from Charing Cross. He had tried three times to swim to the side, but was pushed back to the centre of the stream by the current. He started to shout and, for the first time that night, events began to go his way. He was spotted in the middle of the river and was finally pulled out by two off-duty police officers who threw him a life belt and dragged him to the bank. Taken to St Thomas's Hospital suffering from hypothermia and concussion, he was able to tell the police that his friend was also in the river.

The River Police began a search, but it took more than 24 hours for the Thames to give up its victim. The police eventually found him lying drowned among the driftwood on a mud bank beneath the Oxo Tower. He had never regained consciousness and his body had been washed up and down the river on the tide. It was only then that the police knew for certain that a murder had been committed.

The police investigation was given to the Central London Serious Crimes Group and was put under the command of Detective Chief Inspector Dave Shipperlee. He is one of a breed of successful modern policemen - neat, efficient, painstaking and remorseless. On his office notice board is a complex flow chart showing the intricacies of a murder investigation and the rules which must be followed by the police. Above it, half a dozen inquiry posters are pinned in a line.

There was an inevitability about the progress of the police. The lonely walkways of the South Bank and the streets around Theatreland are bristling with CCTV cameras and, armed with information from Cornish, Shipperlee commandeered all the relevant CCTV film from the South Bank and Charing Cross and began to analyse it. 'This may sound straightforward,' he said, 'but the police have only one facility for examining surveillance film - our laboratory at Denmark Hill, which is always very busy. Because Charing Cross station belongs to Railtrack, they turned to the British Transport Police for help. It took a long time to analyse the material.

The six had split up and swapped clothes to alter their appearances, and Cyrus had done his best to avoid the cameras. But their efforts were half-hearted, as if they didn't really believe they had committed a terrible crime. The girl, Juvenile C, is seen holding hands and pecking her young companion's cheek as they leave the bridge. Cyrus and the two juveniles can be seen laughing and relaxed as they arrive at Waterloo Station at 4.45am and disappear on to a platform to catch an early-morning train back to south London. 'We knew who we wanted within a fortnight,' said Shipperlee, 'and then it was just a matter of old-fashioned policing.'

The trial started in November and lasted for six months. The accused, three of whom were under 18, were no more than children - albeit children who had been present when a murder had taken place and who had either colluded in it or failed to do anything to prevent it. They were charged on a number of counts, the most serious of which were the murder of Timothy Baxter and the attempted murder of Gabriel Cornish.

fields.headline: Alternatives
fields.standfirst: Tibetan medicine in Chelsea, post-traumatic-stress therapy and beating bad backs
fields.trailText: Tibetan medicine in Chelsea, post-traumatic-stress therapy and beating bad backs.
fields.body:
Your body
Last week, the Eden Medical Centre opened in London's King's Road. It aims to blend a Tibetan form of medicine, Dur Bon, with Western conventional and complementary systems. New Zealand born Christopher Hansard, its 42-year-old medical director, says he was chosen at the age of four by his Tibetan teacher for this vocation and was trained for 23 years in ancient medical arts. Dur Bon has much in common with Chinese and Ayurvedic systems, though it seems to be more physiologically based. Subtle variations of the pulse are understood to indicate ailments. I experienced how effective this can be when I was treated for a kidney-related infection by a Chinese herbal practitioner some years ago. Acupuncture is part of Dur Bon, although it is based on 121,000 neural channels instead of the meridians of the Chinese system. Hansard also uses herbal medicine, which he calls 'Tibetan drugs'. Dur Bon also incorporates observation: the patient's body language, speech habits and breathing rhythms are all taken into account, since emotions and thought patterns are said to affect physical wellbeing. Hansard claims remarkable results, including saving lives in emergencies. He is now hoping for clinical trials to be held. An initial consultation at Eden, including a full diagnosis, is £95; subsequent treatments cost £45 an hour.

Your mind
Professor Charles Figley of Florida State University's psychology department co-ordinated post-traumatic care for the survivors of the 1995 Oklahoma bombing. Among the 'power therapies' which he identified as being beneficial was the Thought Field Therapy (TFT) system, devised by Roger Callahan, a psychiatrist. The patient assesses their levels of distress - anger, fear, numbness, grief, etc - on a scale of 0 to 10. They are taught to tap or press pressure points in their face, chest or hands, which are drawn from acupuncture or shiatsu. This is thought to bring negative thoughts or emotions to the surface. Again the patient assesses their level of distress. When it reaches 1 or 0, the process is complete. Callahan claims that TFT successfully eliminates obsessive and compulsive behaviour patterns. Some might argue that TFT only works because it follows the procedures of acupressure. But the added ingredient of assessment reminds me of the Buddhist concept of mindfulness, in which you 'detach' from your thoughts and emotions by watching them. With practice, it can bring stability, harmony and peace - invaluable qualities in post-traumatic care.

Your questions
Some time ago, I was diagnosed as having sciatica in my back. The problem has resurfaced. Should I ask my GP for a screening? Mrs M Hanna, London Certainly see your GP, and ask for an MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging) scan of the lumbar spine region. You may be referred to the orthopaedic or neurosurgery unit of your local hospital. It would also be advisable to consult an osteopath, and take the scan for them to examine. One mineral-derived remedy often recommended by homeopaths for relieving sciatic pain is causticum. Always consult a professional homeopath before using any remedy (call the Society of Homeopaths on 01604 621 400). For a local osteopath, call the General Osteopathic Council (020 7357 6655).

 Enquiries to Richard Lawrence c/o Life Magazine, The Observer , 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, or alternatives@richardlawrence.co.uk.

Acupuncture is part of Dur Bon, although it is based on 121,000 neural channels instead of the meridians of the Chinese system. Hansard also uses herbal medicine, which he calls 'Tibetan drugs'. Dur Bon also incorporates observation: the patient's body language, speech habits and breathing rhythms are all taken into account, since emotions and thought patterns are said to affect physical wellbeing. Hansard claims remarkable results, including saving lives in emergencies. He is now hoping for clinical trials to be held. An initial consultation at Eden, including a full diagnosis, is £95; subsequent treatments cost £45 an hour. Your mind Professor Charles Figley of Florida State University's psychology department co-ordinated post-traumatic care for the survivors of the 1995 Oklahoma bombing. Among the 'power therapies' which he identified as being beneficial was the Thought Field Therapy (TFT) system, devised by Roger Callahan, a psychiatrist. The patient assesses their levels of distress - anger, fear, numbness, grief, etc - on a scale of 0 to 10. They are taught to tap or press pressure points in their face, chest or hands, which are drawn from acupuncture or shiatsu. This is thought to bring negative thoughts or emotions to the surface. Again the patient assesses their level of distress. When it reaches 1 or 0, the process is complete. Callahan claims that TFT successfully eliminates obsessive and compulsive behaviour patterns. Some might argue that TFT only works because it follows the procedures of acupressure. But the added ingredient of assessment reminds me of the Buddhist concept of mindfulness, in which you 'detach' from your thoughts and emotions by watching them. With practice, it can bring stability, harmony and peace - invaluable qualities in post-traumatic care. Your questions Some time ago, I was diagnosed as having sciatica in my back. The problem has resurfaced. Should I ask my GP for a screening? Mrs M Hanna, London Certainly see your GP, and ask for an MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging) scan of the lumbar spine region. You may be referred to the orthopaedic or neurosurgery unit of your local hospital. It would also be advisable to consult an osteopath, and take the scan for them to examine. One mineral-derived remedy often recommended by homeopaths for relieving sciatic pain is causticum.
