webTitle: Back to where I once belonged

fields.headline: Back to where I once belonged
fields.standfirst: Esther Freud, author of the autobiographical Hideous Kinky, explains why the ghosts of her childhood return to haunt her latest novel, a dark tale of domestic horror
fields.trailText: Esther Freud, author of the autobiographical Hideous Kinky, explains why the ghosts of her childhood return to haunt her latest novel, a dark tale of domestic horror.
fields.body:
'Yearning', she says. 'As a child I was always full of yearning.' For a home, stability, a settled sense of love; for children of her own (from the age of three, she used to dream up names for the son and daughter she wanted: Lancelot and Eloise were favoured). Now, in her mid-thirties, Esther Freud has found all these things - though the son and daughter are called Albie and Anna. Yet, still the novels that she writes are full of that sense of longing. I can think of no other writer who is so haunted by childhood, and who so authentically and unpatronisingly shows what it is like to be young, helpless, eager, vulnerable, resilient, awash with inarticulate needs.

Esther Freud, who was in her twenties when her first novel, the autobiographical Hideous Kinky, was published, has had from the very beginning her own charismatic voice: candid, lucid, unflashy, with a freshness and a sweetness about it. Much like her own voice when you meet her, light-timbred, fluent. Or her face - small, mobile, interested, with huge murk-green eyes. Which is only one side of the story, of course, for the sunshine and sanity she presents is the pleasant surface that lies over darker things. This is only to be expected from her background. Her father is the disturbing painter Lucian Freud. Her great-grandfather is Sigmund. Her sister is Bella Freud the designer; her cousins include Emma and Matthew Freud; her uncle is Clement.

She remembers picking up a copy of Time Out once, intrigued by the cover line, '100 Things We Love to Hate', only to find that one of them was 'anyone called Freud'. She has numerous half-siblings, some discovered only recently. She led a peripatetic girlhood, dragged off to Morocco after her hippy mother, wearing a red silk kaftan and longing for an acrylic jumper, breathing in exotic spices and dreaming of cornflakes. Family history breathes down her neck. Her name tags her. Her childhood dogs her. She grew up feeling that her life was extraordinary, while she herself was quite ordinary. This tension - between excitement and security; safety and adventure - tightens all of her fiction.

Her latest book, The Wild, is about step-families. 'I have always known I would write about extended families,' she says, sitting in a café near Hampstead Heath, drinking tea and apple juice. Single father William - teacher by day, and in his spare time handyman, woodcutter, cook, singer and dancer, organiser of domestic adventures, insister upon cheerfulness - has three daughters. Single mother Francine, with her children Tess and Jake, rents rooms from him. We know at once that this is not a story of happy families, for the opening pages describe a violent scene towards which the rest of the novel then works its way, and which fills its pages with dread. Scenes that are ostensibly cheerful fall into the shadows. A starting point for The Wild was, says Esther Freud, a sentence: 'We are living in a really brilliant house' - very spooky when the reader knows from the beginning that the house is also a house of domestic horror. Another starting point was the character of Tess, nine years old, needy, clumsy, diligent, hopeful, imaginative, plain. She wets her bed, night after night: her shameful secret. She writes bright letters to her absent father. She adores William, spaniel-like. 'He fills up her entire vision,' says Esther Freud, 'while William, he has all sorts of things in his life, and right out of the corner of his eye, every so often, he'll glimpse her small figure.'

She loves him with a passion; he scarcely notices her, and when he does it is with irritation. William, who provides the other main narrative point of view, is a sinister version of the New Man, except his creator has some sympathy for him: 'There's a certain kind of man I hate - the one who makes himself king of a very small kingdom. I know William's a monster. But I didn't want to write a didactic book. And I also know what it's like to be alone in a house full of children. Everyone howling. You can't escape. He wants to be this perfect father.' Instead he becomes like the leader of a cult where everyone has to smile and be happy.

Esther Freud is candid about using the events of her own life and the life of her extended family in her novels - Hideous Kinky was followed by Peerless Flats and Gaglow. 'I am amazed how ruthless I am,' she says. 'I don't think of myself like that. But if it works, I feel compelled by it. I tell myself I'll worry later. People go "God! I would have waited until everyone concerned was dead". But I can't wait.'

As a child, she was always telling stories (just like Tess does in The Wild), and she says that she has always 'hoarded' her past, anxious that she would forget it before she wrote it down and turned it into a narrative, her fictional version. 'My secrets and fears were so huge,' she says. She plucks a memory from her store for me, one that has stayed with her. 'I was seven, maybe eight, and was on my way to Scotland to see a friend and on the way we stopped off to visit my father. He gave me a chocolate shoe, it was full of chocolates. I was SO delighted. I arrived in Scotland and unwrapped it and I suddenly remembered that I don't like chocolate. I kept it for years and years and couldn't eat it and couldn't throw it away and couldn't forget how much it hurt.' She gives a little chuckle at the self she was - and yet this chocolate shoe (which in The Wild becomes a chocolate pig that her absent father gives Tess) could stand as a kind of emblem of the way Esther Freud treats her past: never throwing it away, hoarding it, compelled by it.

Tess is a bed-wetter. Esther Freud used to wet the bed herself. She remembers it as 'a secret you hold on to and it takes over. It becomes this huge thing. There's the fear of being judged, being found out. I thought I was the only person in the world who wet my bed.' It's those things that stung and haunted her which then turn up in her novels.

'Writing freed me from the past,' she says. 'I think I used to live in the past, and in the future. I was strangely unconnected to the present. It showed in the way I was always locking myself out of the house, say, or I'd suddenly find I was on the underground on my way to Cockfosters, not the other line. In a way, when I wrote Hideous Kinky , I stopped having to think so much about the past. I had always worried that if I forgot it, then no one would know what had happened to us. I felt my past was what was interesting about me. I was invisible, really, and only my past made me special and glamorous. I would look in the mirror and see a normal-looking girl. My background didn't show in my face. I wanted to be different, at the same time that I so wanted to be the same as everyone else. I always felt I was watched as a child, and I was watching ourselves as well. I was making everything into a story as it happened.'

At the same time she felt herself freed from the past by writing it, she stopped worrying so much about her future by moving into it; taking possession of the life she wanted. 'I stopped acting (a profession which maybe always makes you feel a sense of yearning to be at the centre), and I wrote Hideous Kinky at about the same time as I met the right man,' she says. The right man is the fine actor David Morrissey. 'Now I'm in the family that I dreamed of all my life. I always, always wanted children and I was always scared I wouldn't have them. You know when you drop a coin in a fountain and make a wish? I would always wish for children. In fact, when I went to Legoland the other day and people were dropping coins in the fountain, I realised I didn't really have anything urgent to wish for any more. I'd like more children, but it wouldn't break my heart if I didn't, not like it would have broken my heart to not have any.'

So in a way, Esther Freud feels she has arrived at the place she has been longing for all her upturned life. 'Being married, having children, it hasn't changed me that much. It's more, "Oh yes, this is what I should be doing". I don't feel, my God, what has happened to my life, the way some women do when they have children. I don't feel as if I've lost my freedom - I didn't feel that free before. I didn't feel a young, free, this-is-my-life person. I was too busy waiting for the right man, the children. I was longing too much for my future. Now that I've got it, I feel more liberated. I feel more special to myself now. In a way, I feel younger than I did when I was young.' She adds quite simply: 'I'm just so happy.' (In fact, she was so very, very happy after the birth of Albie, that after five days she asked the midwife if she was still on drugs.)

Journalists who interview Esther Freud tend to call her 'composed'. More than once, people have compared her to a cat - and there is something enigmatic and graceful about her. She blinks and grins at this. 'I am very happy for people to think that. I've spent a long time practising.' She is, she says, a very private person - while plundering her private life for her stories. Confession only happens on the page. 'I never wanted people to know if I had a problem,' she says. 'Like my bed-wetting, all my secrets. I used to be amazed by girls at school who'd chat away about having abortions or whatever. Sometimes I would try to imitate that openness, but I just couldn't. Maybe I was worried, somehow, that if I told my secrets and fears they would become real - I would see in people's faces that I wasn't all right. But if no one knew, it may not be real.' As if things aren't real until they are turned into words, stories.

She remembers being at some strange party for the launch of a pen. There was a handwriting expert there, and she and some friends queued up to have their writing analysed. 'My heart was thumping so. I asked my friends, "Are you scared?" and they just looked at me. "Why on earth should we be scared?" But I was scared. I didn't know what he would find out about me. I don't know if I was worried he would find something out I did know and was ashamed of, or something I didn't even know myself. He looked at my writing and said, "You don't like people to know about you, do you?" "No!" I squeaked. "No!" I suppose I fear I will be discovered as a fraud. Maybe acting made me feel that - but I'm sure it comes from my childhood. All those secrets.'

Secrets are what she explores in her novels. She stands up to go, five foot three in her trainers, light-footed and slight. A girl with green eyes, a woman with her own voice.

fields.headline: From high earner  to highbrow
fields.standfirst: Demi Moore's provocative roles made her the best paid woman in Hollywood. But after the disaster of  G.I. Jane, she disappeared from the screen. Now, three years later, she's back in a low-budget film and wants to be taken seriously.  Mark Morris examines her unlikely second coming
fields.trailText: Demi Moore's provocative roles made her the best paid woman in Hollywood. But after the disaster of G.I. Jane, she disappeared from the screen. Now, three years later, she's back in a low-budget film and wants to be taken seriously. Mark Morris examines her unlikely second coming
fields.body:
It's been a long time since we saw Demi Moore. And it seems like longer, because for most of the Nineties she was inescapable, no matter where you hid. G.I. Jane, the last Demi Moore star vehicle, came out three years ago and was instantly notorious. There were think pieces about women in the military, Demi did one-armed push-ups on talk shows, the critics howled and there were was sheer incredulity at the fact that Demi actually shouts 'Suck my dick' in the movie.

But that was the Nineties for Moore. Even if you didn't see any of her films, you couldn't avoid her, or - more specifically - her body. Those Vanity Fair covers, the Disclosure poster, the stories of implants and her work-out regime. Then there were the spurious debates: the Indecent Proposal issue about whether any woman was worth $1 million for one night, or the Disclosure question about whether women sexually harassed men. Not to mention the marriage to Bruce, the kids, and the stories about their overblown lifestyle. Even her name, which we all had to learn to say with the unexpected stress. And all the while, her wages went up, until she was the best paid actress in the world.

And then it stopped. Maybe the ridicule that followed The Scarlet Letter, Striptease and G.I. Jane did it. Maybe she had just made enough money to take a break. Or maybe it was the final collapse of her marriage. Whatever the reason, after a surprisingly effective appearance in Woody Allen's Deconstructing Harry, she went away. Her return is a curious one, free of the headline-grabbing bombast that we've come to expect. It's easy enough to see what she saw in Passion Of Mind: she gets to play both of the main characters. One is a widow living quietly in rural France, the other is a Manhattan career woman. One of them is dreaming the life of the other: the question is which is dream and which is reality.

But the script - by Ron Bass, who wrote Rain Man and My Best Friend's Wedding - has been kicking around since 1985 when it was intended for Michelle Pfeiffer. These days Bass is so powerful that he was able to insist that his script couldn't be tampered with, even though he wasn't on set to help. The director Bass chose was Alain Berliner, whose debut, Ma Vie En Rose, a fantasy about a sexually confused little boy, won a Golden Globe for best foreign film. Moore's two leading men were hardly in the Michael Douglas bracket either: William Fitchner is an excellent character actor who normally plays bad guys, while Stellan Skarsg rd is a star in Scandinavia but not in Hollywood. The budget was $15 million, which would barely cover what Moore normally gets paid. But as anyone who has worked with slumming stars will tell you, it is not the money that causes problems. It's the working conditions. And so it was on Passion Of Mind, where it seemed that Moore's band of nannies and helpers wasn't much smaller than the crew itself. Berliner wasn't happy. He also had trouble with Moore's overly literal approach. 'Demi needs a lot of details,' he said. ' What created some misunderstandings is that the movie is like a dream - there's not always a logic.' Add the fact that the film sat on the shelf for nearly a year before finding a release date, and this is no triumphant comeback. But you can see what Moore was trying to do: scale back and make a film that would not be a target for critics.

But of course, it was Moore who had put herself in the firing line in the first place. If you're looking for answers in a childhood, Moore's seems to have them all. She was born Demetria Guynes in 1962 in the appropriately infamous town of Roswell, New Mexico. She says that her family moved 30 times when she was young. And yes, they were poor. The man she grew up thinking was her father turned out not to be: he committed suicide when she was 15. She had two operations to correct a crossed right eye. She left school at 16, got married at 18 to a 30-year-old rock musician. Legend has it that it was their next-door neighbour, Natassja Kinski, who encouraged Demi to act.

After some modelling - including some nude work - she got a part in General Hospital, then America's most popular daytime soap. Her new salary also allowed her to acquire a hefty coke habit, which lasted until she got her first big film role in St Elmo's Fire; director Joel Schumacher insisted that she go into rehab before playing a girl with a coke problem in the movie.

If you want to know how powerful Moore's combination of will power and luck has been, look at the rest of the cast of St Elmo's Fire . They were the hottest young stars around: Judd Nelson, Emilio Estevez, Rob Lowe, Andrew McCarthy and Ally Sheedy. Schumacher's overblown melodrama about a group of friends trying to come to grips with life after college was going to be their way out of teen movies into the big time. It might just be the definitive Eighties movie, complete with a bludgeoning, anthemic rock theme tune, Reaganite politics, coke and Rob Lowe playing the saxophone while wearing a bandanna. And perhaps because it was so firmly of its time, not to mention such a showcase of wretched overacting, only Moore would grow up to have an A-list career.

But at the time, Moore was as Brat Pack as you could get. She shared a histrionic acting technique with Nelson. She went out with Estevez. She starred with Lowe in About Last Night (1986), a crude adaptation of David Mamet's play Sexual Perversity In Chicago, notable mainly for just how long Moore manages to be naked. But she broke with the clique when she split from Estevez and married Moonlighting star Bruce Willis. Then he made Die Hard and surprised everyone by becoming an action star.

And then Demi got lucky too. Ghost was one of those hits nobody saw coming. It was only meant to be a medium-sized movie in every way, a quiet bit of slush. But it took off, and made Demi - shorn of her big hair for the new decade - famous when her contemporaries were fading. At which point, her talent for self-promotion took over when she posed, nude and pregnant, for the cover of Vanity Fair. No actor and magazine have ever been as entwined as Demi was with Vanity Fair. 'I'm sure there are a lot of people who think I'm a bitch,' she was willing to confess. As the decade went on, the hits (A Few Good Men, Indecent Proposal) mixed with the flops (The Butcher's Wife, Now And Then) but it wasn't until The Scarlet Letter (1995) that things seemed to be going wrong. Sure, the film was a disaster, a terrible idea from the start, but it was Moore, rather than director Roland Joffe or anyone else, who took the blame. The same happened with Striptease and G.I. Jane. It can't have helped that Moore was now getting paid more than any actress in history, at a time when the films just seemed worse and worse.

Striptease was the nadir: far from the public demanding nudity, people felt Moore was imposing her increasingly weird, muscle-bound body on them. Like Madonna's behaviour a few years earlier, Moore's exhibitionism seemed to be less to do with sex than a kind of Nietzschean feminism. As Janet Maslin in the New York Times put it: 'These scenes suggest not unfettered sexuality but gruelling hard work: prodigious efforts by costumer, choreographer, make-up squad, work-out coach, maybe even the Army Corps of Engineers.'

But Moore wasn't taking on board what the real criticisms were. 'There's this idea that if you take your clothes off, somehow you must have loose morals,' she said. 'There's still a negative attitude in our society towards women who use a strength that's inherent - their femininity - in any way that might be considered seductive.' Watching the film, seduction seemed the last thing on the agenda. But Striptease could have saved her. Far from being a Showgirls clone, it was based on a novel by the the satirical crime writer Carl Hiassen. The ups and downs of Demi

1983 Beat 1,000 other wannabes to get her screen break on long-running daytime soap General Hospital.

1984 Plays Michael Caine's daughter in dire sex comedy Blame It On Rio. First topless scene.

1985 Stars in defining Brat Pack movie St Elmo's Fire as a coke-snorting yuppie . Follows up with About Last Night.

1987 Marries Bruce Willis.

1990 Ghost is her first blockbuster. Good performance as the winsome, grieving widow in the sleeper hit of the year.

Jane, the last Demi Moore star vehicle, came out three years ago and was instantly notorious. There were think pieces about women in the military, Demi did one-armed push-ups on talk shows, the critics howled and there were was sheer incredulity at the fact that Demi actually shouts 'Suck my dick' in the movie. But that was the Nineties for Moore. Even if you didn't see any of her films, you couldn't avoid her, or - more specifically - her body. Those Vanity Fair covers, the Disclosure poster, the stories of implants and her work-out regime. Then there were the spurious debates: the Indecent Proposal issue about whether any woman was worth $1 million for one night, or the Disclosure question about whether women sexually harassed men. Not to mention the marriage to Bruce, the kids, and the stories about their overblown lifestyle. Even her name, which we all had to learn to say with the unexpected stress. And all the while, her wages went up, until she was the best paid actress in the world. And then it stopped. Maybe the ridicule that followed The Scarlet Letter, Striptease and G.I. Jane did it. Maybe she had just made enough money to take a break. Or maybe it was the final collapse of her marriage. Whatever the reason, after a surprisingly effective appearance in Woody Allen's Deconstructing Harry, she went away. Her return is a curious one, free of the headline-grabbing bombast that we've come to expect. It's easy enough to see what she saw in Passion Of Mind: she gets to play both of the main characters. One is a widow living quietly in rural France, the other is a Manhattan career woman. One of them is dreaming the life of the other: the question is which is dream and which is reality. But the script - by Ron Bass, who wrote Rain Man and My Best Friend's Wedding - has been kicking around since 1985 when it was intended for Michelle Pfeiffer. These days Bass is so powerful that he was able to insist that his script couldn't be tampered with, even though he wasn't on set to help. The director Bass chose was Alain Berliner, whose debut, Ma Vie En Rose, a fantasy about a sexually confused little boy, won a Golden Globe for best foreign film. Moore's two leading men were hardly in the Michael Douglas bracket either: William Fitchner is an excellent character actor who normally plays bad guys, while Stellan Skarsg rd is a star in Scandinavia but not in Hollywood. The budget was $15 million, which would barely cover what Moore normally gets paid. But as anyone who has worked with slumming stars will tell you, it is not the money that causes problems. It's the working conditions. And so it was on Passion Of Mind, where it seemed that Moore's band of nannies and helpers wasn't much smaller than the crew itself. Berliner wasn't happy. He also had trouble with Moore's overly literal approach. 'Demi needs a lot of details,' he said. ' What created some misunderstandings is that the movie is like a dream - there's not always a logic.' Add the fact that the film sat on the shelf for nearly a year before finding a release date, and this is no triumphant comeback. But you can see what Moore was trying to do: scale back and make a film that would not be a target for critics. But of course, it was Moore who had put herself in the firing line in the first place. If you're looking for answers in a childhood, Moore's seems to have them all. She was born Demetria Guynes in 1962 in the appropriately infamous town of Roswell, New Mexico. She says that her family moved 30 times when she was young. And yes, they were poor. The man she grew up thinking was her father turned out not to be: he committed suicide when she was 15. She had two operations to correct a crossed right eye. She left school at 16, got married at 18 to a 30-year-old rock musician. Legend has it that it was their next-door neighbour, Natassja Kinski, who encouraged Demi to act. After some modelling - including some nude work - she got a part in General Hospital, then America's most popular daytime soap. Her new salary also allowed her to acquire a hefty coke habit, which lasted until she got her first big film role in St Elmo's Fire; director Joel Schumacher insisted that she go into rehab before playing a girl with a coke problem in the movie. If you want to know how powerful Moore's combination of will power and luck has been, look at the rest of the cast of St Elmo's Fire . They were the hottest young stars around: Judd Nelson, Emilio Estevez, Rob Lowe, Andrew McCarthy and Ally Sheedy. Schumacher's overblown melodrama about a group of friends trying to come to grips with life after college was going to be their way out of teen movies into the big time. It might just be the definitive Eighties movie, complete with a bludgeoning, anthemic rock theme tune, Reaganite politics, coke and Rob Lowe playing the saxophone while wearing a bandanna. And perhaps because it was so firmly of its time, not to mention such a showcase of wretched overacting, only Moore would grow up to have an A-list career. But at the time, Moore was as Brat Pack as you could get. She shared a histrionic acting technique with Nelson. She went out with Estevez. She starred with Lowe in About Last Night (1986), a crude adaptation of David Mamet's play Sexual Perversity In Chicago, notable mainly for just how long Moore manages to be naked. But she broke with the clique when she split from Estevez and married Moonlighting star Bruce Willis. Then he made Die Hard and surprised everyone by becoming an action star. And then Demi got lucky too. Ghost was one of those hits nobody saw coming. It was only meant to be a medium-sized movie in every way, a quiet bit of slush. But it took off, and made Demi - shorn of her big hair for the new decade - famous when her contemporaries were fading. At which point, her talent for self-promotion took over when she posed, nude and pregnant, for the cover of Vanity Fair. No actor and magazine have ever been as entwined as Demi was with Vanity Fair. 'I'm sure there are a lot of people who think I'm a bitch,' she was willing to confess. As the decade went on, the hits (A Few Good Men, Indecent Proposal) mixed with the flops (The Butcher's Wife, Now And Then) but it wasn't until The Scarlet Letter (1995) that things seemed to be going wrong. Sure, the film was a disaster, a terrible idea from the start, but it was Moore, rather than director Roland Joffe or anyone else, who took the blame. The same happened with Striptease and G.I. Jane. It can't have helped that Moore was now getting paid more than any actress in history, at a time when the films just seemed worse and worse. Striptease was the nadir: far from the public demanding nudity, people felt Moore was imposing her increasingly weird, muscle-bound body on them. Like Madonna's behaviour a few years earlier, Moore's exhibitionism seemed to be less to do with sex than a kind of Nietzschean feminism. As Janet Maslin in the New York Times put it: 'These scenes suggest not unfettered sexuality but gruelling hard work: prodigious efforts by costumer, choreographer, make-up squad, work-out coach, maybe even the Army Corps of Engineers.' But Moore wasn't taking on board what the real criticisms were. 'There's this idea that if you take your clothes off, somehow you must have loose morals,' she said. webTitle: Bill's pint pulls in exhibition punters

fields.headline: Bill's pint pulls in exhibition punters
fields.standfirst: Textile show coup confirms Birmingham's status, says  Nick Mathiason
fields.trailText: Textile show coup confirms Birmingham's status, says Nick Mathiason
fields.body:
What a difference a pint makes. When US President Bill Clinton supped one outside Birmingham's International Convention Centre at the G8 Summit two years ago, Birmingham as a world conference location came of age.

The weather was glorious, Reclaim the Streets were contained, and the world's press seized on the image of the planet's most powerful politician casually downing a pint.

For the NEC Group, the public-private partnership be-tween Birmingham Council and the city's Chamber of Commerce which owns and manages the ICC, the National Indoor Arena, Symphony Hall and the UK's biggest exhibition centre, the NEC, Clinton's tipple proved to the world that Birmingham was not a dreary, metal-bashing town.

'OK, we might not be on a honeymoon couple's destination wish list,' conceded NEC Group chief executive Barry Cleverdon. 'But that day everything came together. And for those watching that Clinton image, it proved Birmingham is a great place which can deliver.'

Next year, it will be 25 years since the National Exhibition Centre opened. In that time, the conference and exhibition sector has become one of the most powerful drivers of the city's economy. Last year an independent study by KPMG concluded that activity at the NEC Group venues generated £711 million for the region - a 62 per cent increase from when similar research was done seven years ago.

For Birmingham, the conference and exhibition sector is now almost as significant as the once-mighty car industry. And Clinton's pint played its part in winning new business for the centre. After 21 years of trying, Birmingham's NEC has finally clinched the world's biggest peripatetic trade event, the International Textile Machinery Association show. It will run for 10 days in October 2003, with 150,000 visitors generating £291 million in this country.

Until recently, the NEC was too small for ITMA, which needs three weeks' preparation time. But after 24 years, the NEC has doubled in size to over 2 million sq ft of space. Thanks to this growth, turnover rose 28 per cent last year to £127 million. Seventy per cent of that comes directly from exhibitions.

It may be housed on a windswept, greenfield site in a series of unpreposessing characterless warehouses but the NEC is easily the country's leading exhibition hall, thanks mainly to its size and superior transport links.

Britain's motorway network serves the centre well, trains from all over the country run into Birmingham International while the airport is just over a mile away. Next year a shuttle train link will take visitors straight into the halls. The NEC hosts 200 exhibitions each year. At present only Earls Court Olympia, with 126, can compete.

But there is persistent speculation that the Morris family and venture capitalist Candover, which bought Earls Court and Olympia from P&O for £187m last year, may convert one of its two London halls into an office or residential development.

A decision on this is likely once the true impact of London's new exhibition hall, ExCeL in Docklands, is known. But already ExCeL looks as if it could provide serious competition to not only Earls Court but to the NEC as well. The Boat Show is moving away from Earls Court to ExCel in 2001. The West London exhibition halls have also lost the Garden and DIY shows.

But for the NEC, competition from its new Docklands rival is nothing to shy away from. Cleverdon, its chief executive, is pinning hope on expanding the NEC's conference catering arm to put it in a position to take on organising food and drink for major events in different centres.

To anyone who has fed on the NEC's rather lacklustre and overpriced food, this ambition may seem far-fetched. But it is understood that the NEC will shortly announce a deal with golf's Ryder Cup organisers to take responsibility for the next tournament at the Belfry in Warwickshire in 2001. It already organises the catering at Wentworth and Loch Lomond golf events. In addition, Cleverdon confirmed that the NEC Group is close to securing a series of deals which will see it take on the managements of various conference centres throughout the world.

The NEC is also inviting property companies to develop more of its 200-hectare site. Possibilities include a business park, more hotels or a leisure and restaurant complex.

Meanwhile, the National Indoor Arena, which has an 8,000-seat capacity, recently announced that it is to host the 2003 World Indoor Athletic Championship - the first time this has been held in Britain. It is also close to securing the World Badminton Championships for the second time.

The NEC Group has yet to make a pre-tax profit and is subsidised by the NEC complex. But it is convinced it will soon register profits. But where it has been invaluable is helping to put Birmingham on the corporate map.

Where the elite meet

Just how did Brum manage to tempt leaders of the world's eight most powerful industrialised nations to a city once regarded as an inhospitable eyesore?

The story goes back to Black Wednesday in October 1992. Following Britain's ignominious exit from the Exchange Rate Mechanism, top European Union Ministers urgently needed to stop an escalating currency crisis. The Foreign Office gave just 22 days' notice to the NEC that it was choosing its newly built International Convention Centre, which cost £180 million to construct, to host the event. Although the issues which sparked the summit were mostly resolved by the time the EU leaders met, Foreign Office officials were delighted with the centre's rapid response.

So four years later, the Foreign Office mandarins decided that the Western European Defence Organisation should go to Brum. Again there were no hitches, which enabled the ICC to get the big one - the G8. For the NEC the days leading up to the G8 meeting were frantic.

On the weekend prior to it, the ICC hosted the Eurovision Song Contest. Sets were struck on Sunday, with the Foreign Office moving in the next day. The next major international political event coming to Birmingham, CND take note, is the Nato Defence Ministers' Meeting this October.

webTitle: Why friends are the new family

fields.headline: Why friends are the new family
fields.standfirst: Group holidays
fields.trailText: Group holidays
fields.body:
Apparently the craze all started with that toe-curling celluloid tribute to British thespianism and jolly good fun, Peter's Friends . Stephen Fry and his chums take over a large English house for their hols and put on a play - the perfect antidote to the family holiday. You do the same things - long walks, picnics, roast lunches, embarrassing games - only with one major twist: you are there without your family. This makes the trip both instantly cool, and slightly naughty.

Family holidays can be such a bore, just Mum, Dad, the children and maybe Granny and Grandpa (useful for babysitting). Grown-up group holidays seem elegant and desirable because they are not forced; no one is insisting you go away together. Hey! You just love hanging out with your friends. It's so, well, so Friends . And if they have kids, then your kids will all love hanging out. It's a perfect deal, without even a whisper of the dreaded term 'family-friendly', which is, as every parent knows, an oxymoron.

Family holidays are meant to be disastrous; group holidays are supposed to be chic, largely because there is a competitive edge which never exists when you are chewing on the egg sandwiches with Mum and Dad. With your family, you get away from it all. With your friends, you take it with you. Everyone turns up as if for a Country Casuals contest, with people movers, stainless-steel barbies, and boxes of boules from the Conran Shop. Tartan rugs are whipped out from beautifully packed hampers; children are displayed sporting Petit Bateau sand-suits, while the adults open jars of chilled caviar.

I am ashamed to say I have experienced this particular zeitgeist. Several friends and I rented a cottage in Cornwall. Between us, we had the Mercedes hatchback. We had the tartan rug. We had the Conran boules. We even had Cherry, a hamster (courtesy of one of the children), with its own bespoke travelling box, no less. Then Rowley Leigh, chef supremo of Kensington Place, turned up in the cottage next door. Come lunchtime, the Leigh ensemble was perfectly and beautifully arranged around a woollen rug, tucking into langoustines and home-made mayonnaise. Everyone had mobile phones and was talking about Rowley's latest television series. We slunk off and played French cricket.

Of course, you could always really push the boat out and go for The Samling. The Samling is the ultimate for British group holidays. If it had been around in the 20s, Scott and Zelda Fitzgerald would have gone there. It is the sort of place which has you envisaging guest lists as soon as you flick through the brochure. First, we understand, this is a 'house in the country, and emphatically not a country-house hotel'. Fine. You can't just book one room. You book the whole shooting match. That is, 10 luxury suites, a barn, a dining room which seats 20, an al fresco hot tub overlooking Lake Windermere, and so on. And a conference centre, in case you miss the office. In case you do not, you can spend your time doing chic, adult things like riding or falconry. And there's a full catering and waiting crew. OK, so it is £3,000 for 24 hours, including the Champagne, but when you are booking into adult-holiday heaven, who minds? If you go with six couples, that ends up at about 250 quid each, which might just work out for Rowley's birthday do. You can even put on a play in the barn and turn into a quasi-Stephen Fry. You can take children, but I think I'd rather leave mine at home.

Of course, the group thing has been charging around English country homes for years. The upcoming Merchant Ivory movie The Golden Bowl, an adaptation of the Henry James novel, puts it into perfect historical perspective. Halfway through, we witness a torrid love scene between Uma Thurman and Jeremy Northam, who plays her son-in-law. Classic Edwardian country-house communal pranks abound: adults flying down staircases on tin trays, suggestive sing-songs around the piano, wistful walks in the herb garden. Not a child in sight to distract the grown-ups from the important business of flirting and deceit. Removed from the constraints of everyday life, city, and work, the adults let their hair down and their morals fly away. And what is a decent weekend away with your friends without either a) a sexual liaison, or b) a major row? Even if it is over something as basic as who is doing the washing up.

Television director Jill Marshall treats herself to at least one adult holiday a year. She says the group dynamic of friends and colleagues is utterly different from going away with relations. 'All their kids get on with ours, so that takes care of the children,' she says. 'We are left to have major discussions about what is happening in the world,' she says. 'It's rather like the days before you were a parent. Or a worker.'

So what are you waiting for? Choose five of your friends, and get going. Slum it low-brow and rent a tiny damp cottage in Devon. Go middle-bracket and get into the likes of English Country Cottages, or Landmark Trusts. Or go to The Samling - if you can afford it. Posh, Becks and their mates have apparently already been there.

Classic Edwardian country-house communal pranks abound: adults flying down staircases on tin trays, suggestive sing-songs around the piano, wistful walks in the herb garden. Not a child in sight to distract the grown-ups from the important business of flirting and deceit. Removed from the constraints of everyday life, city, and work, the adults let their hair down and their morals fly away. And what is a decent weekend away with your friends without either a) a sexual liaison, or b) a major row? Even if it is over something as basic as who is doing the washing up. Television director Jill Marshall treats herself to at least one adult holiday a year. She says the group dynamic of friends and colleagues is utterly different from going away with relations. 'All their kids get on with ours, so that takes care of the children,' she says. 'We are left to have major discussions about what is happening in the world,' she says. 'It's rather like the days before you were a parent. Or a worker.' So what are you waiting for? Choose five of your friends, and get going. Slum it low-brow and rent a tiny damp cottage in Devon. Go middle-bracket and get into the likes of English Country Cottages, or Landmark Trusts. Or go to The Samling - if you can afford it. Posh, Becks and their mates have apparently already been there.

webTitle: Currency rules - but it's not OK

fields.headline: Currency rules - but it's not OK
fields.standfirst: The euro: made in America by the father of Reaganomics as a tool to smash the power of governments
fields.trailText: The euro: made in America by the father of Reaganomics as a tool to smash the power of governments
fields.body:
Give me two good reasons why I should listen to some American tell me about the euro.

All right. Number One: We don't care. There's no emotional baggage here. Frankly, I couldn't care less whether the Queen's nose remains on your coinage or not.

Number Two: Americans invented the euro. And it's time you learnt why.

In 1970, Professor Robert Mundell, now at New York's Columbia University, proposed the 'Europa', based on his theory of optimal currency areas. It won him the Nobel Prize. On the Continent, Mundell is dubbed 'father of the euro'.

But in the US, he is best known for the other creation he spawned. To Americans, Mundell is 'father of Reaganomics', the supply-side monetarism and tear-down-the-government philosophy which is the heart, soul and agenda of the extreme free marketeers.

Mundell was, even more than Milton Friedman, their leader. 'Ronald Reagan would not have been elected President without Mundell's influence,' wrote the Wall Street Journal's Jude Wanniski.

Canadian-born Mundell is a clever and cohesive thinker. It would be impossible to accept one side of his coin - the euro - without accepting the flip side: supply-side economics. They're inseparable, like marriage and lies.

Let's begin with Mundell in his own words. 'They won't even let me have a toilet,' he told me last week. Mundell has bought a castle in Tuscany. (Like many supply-side economists, he created prosperity, at least for himself.)

His problem is that, to preserve the ancient structure, local officials won't let him simply rip out a couple of walls to put in a bath and WC. His point is this: 'Europe is over-regulated. Regulated to death.'

There's more than plumbing on Mundell's long list of bureaucratic bugaboos. 'It's very hard to fire workers in Europe,' he complains. To solve such problems, Mundell conceived the euro. 'It puts monetary policy out of the reach of politicians.'

Yet that does not seem the most direct route to eliminating government. Even defenders of monetary union argue that each nation will remain in control of fiscal policy.

Oh no they won't , says Mundell: 'Monetary discipline forces fiscal discipline on the politicians as well.' The Maastricht rules, the conditions for entering the euro - limiting annual deficits to 3 per cent of GDP and total debt outstanding to 60 per cent - leave little room for active government. As Mundell explains it, Maastricht limitations mean individual nations will have nothing left to entice inward investment except lower tax rates and de-regulation. Governments will compete by shrinking.

Wholesale privatisation is also, for Mundell, a predictable effect of monetary union. To meet the 60 per cent debt limitation, nations privatise infrastructure such as water or air traffic control. These asset sales don't affect the public's obligation to use these services, and the public still pays for them - but Maastricht is satisfied.

John Maynard Keynes wrote: 'Madmen in authority, who hear voices in the air, are distilling their frenzy from some academic scribbler a few years back.' Now, I would never suggest that Baroness (Shirley) Williams is either mad or in authority - nevertheless, as a fervent supporter of the euro, she could explain, I thought, why Britain and Greece meet the criteria for one of Mundell's optimal currency areas.

The Lib-Dem peer had studied at Mundell's school. She told me she'd 'read lots and lots' on the euro but not much 'before the last 20 years', so missed Mundell. (Actually, Mundell won the Nobel only last year for continuing work.) What of Britain as optimal mate for euroland? She spoke of European tax and budget policies, though they have not a thing to do with reasons to meld currencies.

I would not say that Professor Williams (she teaches at Harvard) was faking it, but it was clear there was no point asking her about the supply-side economics underpinning the euro's conception.

Williams did argue that 'tiny' Britain must seek shelter within a large currency area. She may have thought I had a hell of a lot of nerve, as an American suckled in one big currency, to suggest Britain float alone.

However, the US does not have a single currency, at least not in the Maastricht sense. We have at least 50 currencies. Each state, every little burg and hamlet, has its own tax and employment policy. That's what saved the US economy from Mundellian Reaganomics. What Reagan took away in federal funds, states and cities restored.

Recently, in my village outside New York, the fire department decided we needed a new fire house. The citizenry voted to issue bonds on Wall Street and tax ourselves to cover the debt. We didn't need Washington's approval. Neither the state nor the Almighty (Alan Greenspan) could stop us.

America's states and municipalities have never 'converged' in the manner required of Britain by Eurocrats. As a result, debts of America's governments and local authorities are easily double the Maastricht ceiling of 60 per cent of GDP. Yet the US economy is doing quite well, thank you. The American experience suggests that what Britain needs is not a lower rate of exchange with the D-mark, but a little more democracy.

I may seem to be drifting off the point by hauling in what is euphemistically called the UK's 'democratic deficit' (the attraction to autocracy) into discussion of the euro. But, as the TGWU's Bill Morris writes*, the risk of the euro is that it puts the economy 'outside democratic control'.

This is not the whacko fear of a Sun reader that some Brussels bureaucrat will bark humiliating orders at Gordon Brown. Rather, says Morris, Britain's government 'could - if it so wished - ameliorate unemployment'. But monetary union 'removes that power to nowhere'.

Morris underscores the point that no one is ultimately in charge of the euro. Rather, Britain's economy will be ruled by the 3 per cent rule, the 60 per cent debt rule and the European Central Bank's 2 per cent inflation target. This is the dream of Mundell's monetarist circle - an economy run on automatic, by the monster in the box, a set of rules impervious to democratic forces - which will dictate policy long after they are gone and their theories are discredited.

Euro boosters think of monetary union as an an exchange mechanism to rival the Yankee dollar. But that was never the key concern of the euro's North American inventors. Indeed, it is a supply-side axiom that a nation cannot gain long-term competitive advantage by altering the exchange rate any more than nations can alter the weather by switching from Celsius to Fahrenheit.

But what about the loss of jobs at Rover's Longbridge and Ford's Dagenham? Mundell's collaborator, Art Laffer, told me: 'If exchange rates made a difference, all cars would be made in Moscow.'

For supply-side economists, terms of trade are a sideshow. The real goal of the Mundell Reaganauts, like all revolutionaries, is to smash the state, in this case through Maastricht-driven tax cuts, state spending caps, privatisations and deregulation of labour markets (and plumbing).

In this, they share a little with left-wing supporters of the euro. England's sharpest long-term strategist is Ken Livingstone. His long-term ambition is, he suggests, to demolish capitalism. How interesting that when the mayor called for rapid entry into the euro - presumably step one toward his ultimate goal - London's captains of commerce applauded. 'He understands us,' one banker said. I believe he does.

* Emu and the Democratic Deficit, Bill Morris: The Single European Currency In National Perspective (Macmillan).

webTitle: Brum's new modern father is no bore

fields.headline: Brum's new modern father is no bore
fields.standfirst: Nick Mathiason  talks to the city's new council leader about transforming the second city from concrete collar to jewel in the Midlands crown
fields.trailText: Nick Mathiason talks to the city's new council leader about transforming the second city from concrete collar to jewel in the Midlands crown
fields.body:
Maybe it takes an outsider to grab Birmingham by the throat and sort it out.

In the 1870s, Londoner Joseph Chamberlain cleared slums, built libraries and introduced a raft of social reforms to a city which was then the workshop of a thriving imperial nation.

Chamberlain, credited with being the father of modern Brum, pioneered a municipal can-do ethos which was replicated across the country.

Cut to the twenty first century and the unfortunately named Albert Bore, a short, effervescent Scotsman, is now at the city's helm and reviving that can-do municipal spirit with a vengeance.

Elected as council leader about a year ago, Bore, a 54-year-old former physics lecturer, believes that Birmingham must imitate the strategies that made Milan and Barcelona pivotal to their respective regions.

Direct local authority intervention is how Barcelona, in particular, rose from being a poor city to the economic Catalan powerhouse of today.

It sounds laughable that Brum, traditionally the most ridiculed conurbation in Britain, should aspire to the apex of continental sophistication. But the city has changed dramatically during the past 10 years. In the city centre, there is now Birmingham's first £1million home. Trendy London restaurants are testing the water and Christian Lacroix is opening there this autumn.

'Anyone who has been away from the city can't believe the changes,' said Alex Stephenson, chairman of Advantage West Midlands, the local regional development agency, and head of the Longbridge Taskforce.

For much of the Eighties, Bore saw the impotence of his city's council. 'We were too dependent on industrial jobs,' he recounted in his office, which still looks like a shrine to a municipal golden age. 'In the late Seventies to the mid-Eighties, 200,000 jobs were lost in Birmingham. In the same period, that matched the total lost in Scotland and Wales put together. It took the heart out of the city.'

Some might say that successive councillors and their planners did more damage to the city than the painful journey to what is now a serviced based economy. The city centre is notorious for being the most user-unfriendly in Britain.

To locals, the biggest bugbear is the inability to break through the 'concrete collar', a series of busy ring roads, which have effectively strangled any sense of civic pride.

As chair of the economic development commitee, Bore spent much of his municipal life working to break that grip. This project is half completed. Already, the city has buried one major arterial road 19 feet underground to enable people to walk from the International Convention Centre through to New Street without encountering any cars.

The Bullring - the grisly concrete shopping centre accessible only through a series of subterranean walkways - will also soon be demolished after years of wrangling.

The council has brokered an £850 million deal which means that almost 2 million sq ft of new retail space will come to Birmingham in three phases by 2003.

With the city's future as a retail destination assured, Bore is now attempting to regenerate the Eastside section into an 'education zone', to be known as Millennium Point. Bulldozers razing the Mass House Circus roundabout next year will enable work to start on a massive 420-acre site which will see a children's education centre, a Science University and an engineering faculty.

Bore's vision is a themed inner city. To the south will be a heritage centre centring on the Custard Factory and Typhoo Wharf, although further details on this are sketchy. But the city is pressing ahead with plans to build Britain's tallest building on the site of Central Television's old offices.

Locals are sceptical about the site, known as Arena Central and owned jointly by the council and property developer Hampton Trust, ever getting off the ground. They say Hampton Trust has not got the resources to fund a 50-storey building.

When quizzed on this, Bore smiles enigmatically. 'We can control it,' he said.

The 2.3 million sq ft at Arena Central will aim to put together a mix of entertainment attractions, including a Las Vegas-style theatre restaurant, international film theatre, health and fitness centre, nightclubs and other restaurants. At its heart will be a central public plaza and water feature - capable of being frozen into a skating rink - protected by a glass dome. It is what Bore calls the final piece in the city's jigsaw.

webTitle: Oligarch? No, I'm just an oil magnate...

fields.headline: Oligarch? No, I'm just an oil magnate...
fields.standfirst: Russia's bad boy assures UK investors he's a safe bet.  Simon Pirani  reports
fields.trailText: Russia's bad boy assures UK investors he's a safe bet. Simon Pirani reports
fields.body:
The bad boy of Russian business was at the Dorchester hotel in London last week for an image makeover. Multimillionaire Mikhail Khodorkovsky was in town to tell an Investing in Russia conference that his oil company, Yukos, has put its poor corporate governance record behind it, and will soon issue internationally-traded shares (level 1 ADRs).

Yukos, Russia's second-biggest oil producer returned to the Moscow stock market - which delisted it a year ago for regulatory offences - just in time for the visit.

It is not just Yukos's record, or the spectacular crash in 1998 of Khodorkovsky's bank, Menatep, that have made him controversial. It is the belief, held by most Russians, that he belongs to a tiny group of 'oligarchs' who made their vast fortunes at the country's expense and wield tremendous political influence .

Khodorkovsky said he only wished the belief about political influence was true. 'It makes me weep when Boris Berezovsky [the car-sales-to-oil-to-media magnate, perceived as the most powerful oligarch] talks about this group of people having 100 per cent political influence. If we had just 10 per cent of the political influence that Berezovsky claims, we would never have allowed the government to impose the unbearable tax burden on business that it has.'

Shortly before Vladimir Putin was elected, Berezovsky claimed the oligarchs controlled Russian politics and the new President could not change that. But Khodorkovsky insists that Berezovsky is an exception: a politician-turned-businessman. The other oligarchs - such as himself, Vladimir Potanin, media mogul Vladimir Gusinsky, and banking-to-metals tycoon Mikhail Fridman - have political influence that is 'more visible than that of Western businessmen, but, unfortunately, less effective'.

He added: 'I really don't see the difference, politically, between Yukos and General Motors. Both have about 2 per cent of [their country's] GDP. Both lobby in parliament for their interests. Both propagandise in the press.'

James Fenkner, strategist at Troika Dialog, Russia's largest investment bank, agrees that the other oligarchs are 'not as omnipotent as Berezovsky', but says Khodorkovsky's wishes have an interesting habit of turning into government action. Fenkner cites as an example the appointment last year of Viktor Kaliuzhny, a former Yukos employee, as Energy Minister, and his subsequent dismissal after Khodorkovsky expressed displeasure.

Khodorkovsky's main theme on his London visit - the need to reduce the tax burden on Russian business - coincides neatly with Putin's only clearly-stated economic policy. And the oil baron concurs with the former KGB spy in the Kremlin on the latter's moves to curtail the power of Russia's regional governors.

Thirty-six-year-old Khodorkovsky's indignation at claims he has undue political influence is matched by his anger at suggestions that his wealth was ill-gotten. 'If a young American built a $30 million company in the space of three years, he would be applauded. If a young Russian does it, people say he could not have done without the help of the Communist Party.'

Those three years of Khodorkovsky's early success were also the last three of the Soviet Union. He started in business in 1987, as a 23-year-old student at the Moscow Chemical Technology Institute and a member of the Communist youth organisation.

Khodorkovsky founded Menatep bank in 1989 and it grew rapidly, sprouting Rosprom, an investment company managing more than 100 industrial enterprises. By 1995, Menatep was well positioned to take advantage of the notorious loans-for-shares scheme, under which banks that lent money to the cash-strapped government got state assets at bargain prices in return.

International opinion held that state property was plundered. An International Monetary Fund analysis reckoned the oil assets went for less than one-tenth of their value. An analysis by two World Bank officials said favoured banks used state cash to fund bids, and concluded that 'any one of the major oil companies sold via a transparent, international tender would have yielded far more revenue than all the loans-for-shares auctions combined'.

Menatep bought Yukos for what critics say was an absurdly low price. Khodorkovsky said: 'Yes, the price was low - $400m - but I was taking on $3 billion of debt. In east Germany they sold such companies for $1.'

Under Khodorkovsky, Yukos pioneered the controversial transfer pricing system, under which his Moscow-based holding company buys oil from its production subsidiaries at fabulous discounts - currently $1.50 a barrel, a twentieth of the world price and a fifth of the domestic price - and resells it. This concentrates wealth in the holding company, weakens minority shareholders, and avoids tax.

Khodorkovsky was robustly unapologetic. ' As long as the tax regime is unjust, I will try to find a way round it.'

His worst problems stemmed from the Russian financial crash of 1998; Yukos kept up payments on $1bn of international loans but Menatep lost heavily on Russian treasury bonds and collapsed. Menatep defaulted on loans from three western banks - Daiwa, Standard and West Merchant - for which it had used Yukos stock as collateral.

The banks took a 31.9 per cent holding in Yukos, but then found that some of the company's assets had been transferred to offshore funds, presumed to be linked to Yukos management, on a repurchase agreement. At the same time, minority shareholdings in Yukos's production subsidiaries were being diluted.

Russia's securities regulator launched an investiga tion. Two of the three Western banks pulled out. Yukos's reputation was severely damaged.

'I sat down with representatives of the three banks and explained the situation,' said Khodorkovsky. 'I assured them that they would retain seats on the board. Unfortunately two of the three decided to sell their holdings.'

The banks that withdrew did so under the pressure of 'propaganda' by Kenneth Dart, the US investor who fought a legal battle over his rights as a shareholder in Yukos subsidiaries, Khodorkovsky believes. He pointed out: 'The company that I head, Yukos, takes its responsibilities. It has never failed to pay its debts and never diluted shareholders. At my own insistence, as a major shareholder, Yukos is committed to paying off all of Menatep's creditors.'

While Yukos's victories in the courts implied that it had not broken the law, 'it has cer tainly violated shareholders' rights,' Fenkner of Troika said. 'There is a credibility gap. Of all the corporate governance abuses in Russia in 1999 - and there were plenty -Yukos probably provided the best example.'

Fenkner acknowledges that the fabulous potential of Yukos's assets may convince Western institutions to give Khodorkovsky the benefit of the doubt. And Khodorkovsky is sure that once the tax burden on Yukos is reduced and its finances improve as a result, he will attract investors to fund expansion.

He could not have chosen a better place than London to relaunch himself. The authoritarian gravedigger of human rights in Chechnya, Vladimir Putin, used a visit to Tony Blair in April to make himself appear dignified and statesmanlike. Building trust in a shrewd and eloquent young oil baron should be a comparatively simple task.

Khodorkovsky said he only wished the belief about political influence was true. 'It makes me weep when Boris Berezovsky [the car-sales-to-oil-to-media magnate, perceived as the most powerful oligarch] talks about this group of people having 100 per cent political influence. If we had just 10 per cent of the political influence that Berezovsky claims, we would never have allowed the government to impose the unbearable tax burden on business that it has.' Shortly before Vladimir Putin was elected, Berezovsky claimed the oligarchs controlled Russian politics and the new President could not change that. But Khodorkovsky insists that Berezovsky is an exception: a politician-turned-businessman. The other oligarchs - such as himself, Vladimir Potanin, media mogul Vladimir Gusinsky, and banking-to-metals tycoon Mikhail Fridman - have political influence that is 'more visible than that of Western businessmen, but, unfortunately, less effective'. He added: 'I really don't see the difference, politically, between Yukos and General Motors. Both have about 2 per cent of [their country's] GDP. Both lobby in parliament for their interests. Both propagandise in the press.' James Fenkner, strategist at Troika Dialog, Russia's largest investment bank, agrees that the other oligarchs are 'not as omnipotent as Berezovsky', but says Khodorkovsky's wishes have an interesting habit of turning into government action. Fenkner cites as an example the appointment last year of Viktor Kaliuzhny, a former Yukos employee, as Energy Minister, and his subsequent dismissal after Khodorkovsky expressed displeasure. Khodorkovsky's main theme on his London visit - the need to reduce the tax burden on Russian business - coincides neatly with Putin's only clearly-stated economic policy. And the oil baron concurs with the former KGB spy in the Kremlin on the latter's moves to curtail the power of Russia's regional governors. Thirty-six-year-old Khodorkovsky's indignation at claims he has undue political influence is matched by his anger at suggestions that his wealth was ill-gotten. 'If a young American built a $30 million company in the space of three years, he would be applauded. If a young Russian does it, people say he could not have done without the help of the Communist Party.' Those three years of Khodorkovsky's early success were also the last three of the Soviet Union. He started in business in 1987, as a 23-year-old student at the Moscow Chemical Technology Institute and a member of the Communist youth organisation. Khodorkovsky founded Menatep bank in 1989 and it grew rapidly, sprouting Rosprom, an investment company managing more than 100 industrial enterprises. By 1995, Menatep was well positioned to take advantage of the notorious loans-for-shares scheme, under which banks that lent money to the cash-strapped government got state assets at bargain prices in return. International opinion held that state property was plundered. An International Monetary Fund analysis reckoned the oil assets went for less than one-tenth of their value. An analysis by two World Bank officials said favoured banks used state cash to fund bids, and concluded that 'any one of the major oil companies sold via a transparent, international tender would have yielded far more revenue than all the loans-for-shares auctions combined'. Menatep bought Yukos for what critics say was an absurdly low price. Khodorkovsky said: 'Yes, the price was low - $400m - but I was taking on $3 billion of debt. In east Germany they sold such companies for $1.' Under Khodorkovsky, Yukos pioneered the controversial transfer pricing system, under which his Moscow-based holding company buys oil from its production subsidiaries at fabulous discounts - currently $1.50 a barrel, a twentieth of the world price and a fifth of the domestic price - and resells it. This concentrates wealth in the holding company, weakens minority shareholders, and avoids tax. Khodorkovsky was robustly unapologetic. ' As long as the tax regime is unjust, I will try to find a way round it.' His worst problems stemmed from the Russian financial crash of 1998; Yukos kept up payments on $1bn of international loans but Menatep lost heavily on Russian treasury bonds and collapsed. Menatep defaulted on loans from three western banks - Daiwa, Standard and West Merchant - for which it had used Yukos stock as collateral. The banks took a 31.9 per cent holding in Yukos, but then found that some of the company's assets had been transferred to offshore funds, presumed to be linked to Yukos management, on a repurchase agreement. At the same time, minority shareholdings in Yukos's production subsidiaries were being diluted. Russia's securities regulator launched an investiga tion. Two of the three Western banks pulled out. Yukos's reputation was severely damaged. 'I sat down with representatives of the three banks and explained the situation,' said Khodorkovsky. 'I assured them that they would retain seats on the board. Unfortunately two of the three decided to sell their holdings.' The banks that withdrew did so under the pressure of 'propaganda' by Kenneth Dart, the US investor who fought a legal battle over his rights as a shareholder in Yukos subsidiaries, Khodorkovsky believes. He pointed out: 'The company that I head, Yukos, takes its responsibilities. It has never failed to pay its debts and never diluted shareholders. At my own insistence, as a major shareholder, Yukos is committed to paying off all of Menatep's creditors.' While Yukos's victories in the courts implied that it had not broken the law, 'it has cer tainly violated shareholders' rights,' Fenkner of Troika said. 'There is a credibility gap. Of all the corporate governance abuses in Russia in 1999 - and there were plenty -Yukos probably provided the best example.' Fenkner acknowledges that the fabulous potential of Yukos's assets may convince Western institutions to give Khodorkovsky the benefit of the doubt. And Khodorkovsky is sure that once the tax burden on Yukos is reduced and its finances improve as a result, he will attract investors to fund expansion. He could not have chosen a better place than London to relaunch himself. The authoritarian gravedigger of human rights in Chechnya, Vladimir Putin, used a visit to Tony Blair in April to make himself appear dignified and statesmanlike. Building trust in a shrewd and eloquent young oil baron should be a comparatively simple task.

fields.headline: Stockwatch
fields.trailText: BT | BAA | Peel Holdings
fields.body:
Bite off BT
Whither BT? This question gets asked ever more urgently in the telecoms sector these days. Last week was no exception. While Vodafone was rubbing its hands, having sold off Orange for a hefty premium, BT looked in danger of becoming the Miss Havisham of telecoms.

Chuck in Oftel's ruling last Friday that BT would have to start selling wholesale unmetered internet packages to anyone who wants them and the incumbent operator looks to be in a pretty pickle. Starved of partners abroad, its margins being eroded at home, the company's share price has slumped from a high of nearly 1,500p at the start of the year to bottom out at 880p last month.

Since then its price has put on a bit of a spurt, but nothing to gladden investors' hearts. But it's not all doom and gloom. The effect of BT's recent decision to separate into six discrete divisions still has to trickle through. BT has also secured a £16 billion loan facility, so shopping for 3G licences should not be too much of a concern. And, given its success, its Cellnet Genie internet service should float before long.

Even on a sum-of-the-parts basis, analysts at JP Morgan argue BT is worth around 1,322p a share, a 35 per cent upside to the company's current value. Buy.

Skies look clearer
The scrapping of duty free left BAA (the former British Airports Authority) shares in freefall last year.

Full-year results are tomorrow, and the signs are that BAA might finally take off again following last year's crash landing.

Retail space now focuses more on quality than price and has been increased. Arrivals outlets have been created. Passenger volume in April was 10 per cent up on last year.

Questions linger over planning permission for Heathrow Terminal 5. And BAA began legal action against Eurotunnel last week following attempts to renegotiate its 15-year contract to run retail operations.

Watch out for a shift in strategy, focusing on growth from consultancy and management of airports rather than the riskier business of retail.

The key consideration is how well the company has fought back from the retail woes caused by the abolition of duty free. Good news on that front would rank BAA as a marginal buy.

Shifting foundations
Shareholder dissatisfaction with the property sector has been welling up for years. Despite healthy fundamentals - strong tenant demand, a good investment market and not too many empty offices - shares have been trading at an average of 25 per cent discount to net assets.

But the camel's back was truly broken last week with three key announcements. First MEPC agreed with Hermes and US fund GE Capital to go private.

Then Peel Holdings, owner of the massive Trafford Centre, announced it is to buy back 10 per cent of its stock. And Nick Leslau's Prestbury Group said it was selling its property and returning cash to shareholders.

At the heart of the problem is the City's distrust of the sector. A re-rating is not on the agenda. After MEPC's decision to go private, investors will be betting on who will follow. Rule out the sector's two giants - British Land and Land Securities. British Land is too heavily weighted in the City, where rental growth is static. Land Securities' interests are too diverse.

The best bet is central London property specialist Benchmark. As most of its holdings are in London's West End, where demand is forcing rents up to record levels, investors are unlikely to lose. This year, Benchmark shares have gained from a 52 week low of 178.5p. Its Friday night close of 225.5p is 23p off its year high of 248.5p. Buy.

webTitle: Sainsbury remains off the shopping list

fields.headline: Sainsbury remains off the shopping list
fields.trailText: Throg Street
fields.body:
Bargain hunters may find themselves in the unlikely environs of J Sainsbury this week, noting that it has a low-price offer on its shares. The effect of Sir Peter Davis's 'kitchen sink' results presentation was to send the shares spiralling downwards from 341p to 305p on the day of the results.

The shares finished the week at 286p, down on the highs of 580p they reached in October 1998, but not yet down to the 249p depths plumbed in March this year. Pre-tax profits were equally dismal, with a 23 per cent drop, to £580 million. The supermarket is now committed to spending a further £900m refurbishing its stores this year.

Davis offered little in the way of comfort: his description of the company's underinvestment would have depressed even the most doughty supporter. We know that the trustee who holds the cards in terms of the family shareholding, Judith Portrait, appointed a merchant bank, DKB, at the turn of the year to help her decide what was the best course of action for the family shareholding.

One can easily imagine that they are still chewing their pencils over this particular conundrum: is Sainsbury's saleable?

At the moment it would appear to be highly unlikely - no buyer would want to pay much of a premium, even at the shares' currently miserable level, because of the level of investment needed to compete with the vigorous Tesco and Walmart-backed Asda.

Then there is the issue of who would be prepared to take on the competition issues any purchaser from inside the industry would face. Although its mix of properties would be easier for another retailer to take over than, for instance, those of Marks & Spencer, it is hard to imagine a domestic buyer willing to take the pain for long enough to see the gain in what is a perilously competitive business.

Reversing what he described as years of underinvestment, Davis is taking the right step forward, but even he must be doubtful whether he is ever going to be able to restore Sainsbury to the market leader spot - a place the store lost to Tesco in the annus horribilis of 1997. It is also wise for Davis to avoid the disposal of either its US chain, Shaws, or DIY superstores Homebase: nothing would be worse than providing proof that buyers in the market are far and few between and none are currently keen to splash cash on a retail basket-case.

For investors wanting to see a quick return on their investments Sainsbury is still very much on the avoid list - remember those investors who piled into Marks & Spencer after the shares dipped below 400p on the grounds that an upturn was inevitable?

For those currently holding shares, the losses are now so steep that the idea of cutting them is probably untenable. Some analysts are advising a switch into a more palatable takeover target, such as Safeway, which is one possible option.

But as for the investors who like to buy into a dip - remember that just because something is a bargain does not mean it is cheap. Carry on avoiding.

Back BSkyB as a walkover
Here we are, stranded between the FA Cup and the beginning of the next season, with only Euro 2000 for company. But for BSkyB, the season never closes. At the moment it is embroiled, along with Britain's other TV players, in the next round of Premier League bidding for rights. The fear has been that the satellite broadcaster will end up saddled with an enormous burden of costs for the rights, which would plunge it further into loss.

But ABN Amro last week added BSkyB to its 'buy' list, on the grounds that overpayment fears had been exaggerated and that the broadcaster was likely to hang on to the key sporting rights at a reasonable cost. This may be so, though it is difficult to imagine how ABN Amro knows the mind of the Premier League, when it doesn't seem to know its own.

However, while the levels that BSkyB reached earlier in the year - upwards of 2,500p a share - were clearly ridiculous, there is now more reason to be positive about the prospects for the pay-TV broadcaster.

Its digital switchover, after a shaky and expensive start, now appears to be going great guns: demand seems to be outstripping supply, given the disgruntled number of people having to wait for the dish men to come.

More encouragingly, digital homes are showing signs of being willing to spend more per household on their services - especially pay-per-view films.

But more significant than all of these factors is the encouraging lack of competition BSkyB is facing. Digital cable was a truly threatening opponent - unlike the pale OnDigital, which has its merits but offers a very pared-down service compared with Sky - but it has failed to materialise.

Whether this was caused by consolidation in the domestic cable industry over the past two years, or by the decade of poor service culture that preceded it is unclear, but the fact remains that to all intents and purposes, Sky is benefiting from the inability of cable to move its customers to a digital service.

Whatever happens to the football rights, any ambitious pay-per-view plans or greatly increased coverage will have to use Sky as a carrier.

Chief executive Tony Ball's enthusiasm for seeing the company expand its non-sports programming, although staying firmly focused on its sporting core, is also encouraging. And, thanks to the most pallid of challenges from cable, it is able to continue to build its brand as a 'must have' while competitors, even armed with football, appear a long way off the pace.

ABN Amro's assessment that 1,370p represents fair value - and possibly even a floor in the shares - has some merit. And for those of a gambling frame of mind, it may be more exciting to buy before the Premiership rights outcome is announced in the next month.
