webTitle: Realistic and ruthless as the clock ticks away

fields.headline: Realistic and ruthless as the clock ticks away
fields.standfirst: Diary of a dotcom
fields.trailText: Diary of a dotcom
fields.body:
The story so far. Flametree which is creating an Internet portal 'to help working women balance their lives', is gearing up for its imminent launch. Having secured £1 million in backing, the company has moved into offices in London's Victoria and is busy recruiting staff to help develop its site.

Thursday 8am

Flametree founders Jayne Buxton and Rosemary Leith are holding a conference call with their web design agency. Such is the pace of activity at the moment that the pair hold two conference calls a day.

Unfortunately Callum, the site's chief designer, is nowhere to be found. Someone suggests emailing him. There is a look of horror on the face of the founders when they hear his address is at 'squat.com'.

Despite Callum's no-show, things are moving along nicely. More than 60 per cent of the content has been loaded on to the site, and the BBC wants to make a fly-on-the-wall-documentary about the company (back off, we was here first).

Last week the company invited its 'friends of Flametree' to drop in, sip a glass of wine, play with the site and give their verdicts. 'Overall we were just bowled over,' Buxton recalls. 'It was fantastic feedback. The look and feel of the site came out really well. One woman said "you've really got soul here".'

The plan is to turn the 'friends' into evangelists for the site. They will help spread the Flametree gospel by word of mouth and email. The advertising industry even has a term for this low-cost PR: 'viral marketing'.

However, certain areas where the site could be improved did come to light.

'We need to draw people into it better - really handhold and direct and choreograph someone's visit,' Buxton says. 'Things that we think are simple on the website are not simple. For example, we want people to email their favourite items to a friend. We know how to do that, but a lot of people don't. You need a foolproof explanation saying "click on this". That usability advice can be really helpful.'

The pair now believe their decision not to use 'Flash' technology on their website, which takes a long time to download, has been vindicated. 'When you're clicking on the site and your child's having a nap you don't have time to download. Your free time's over by the time you do,' Leith says.

The pair are also pleased that they chose to use a server based in the UK, over near Canary Wharf. If they had chosen to rent one in the US it would have been cheaper, but 'there is no substitute for proximity in being able to crisis-manage', Buxton says.

Likewise, by renting the largest server available, they believe there should be no future traffic complications caused by constant upgrades.

One thing that emerged was the enthusiasm the site's users have for its online user forums. Flametree sees the forums as crucial because they help to build a sense of community - helping users to interact with each other - something that makes the site different from a conventional online magazine.

Ideally the company would have its own branded set of forums for the launch, but this does not look possible. Instead, the plan is to go initially for an off-the-shelf package, which will allow for less customisation.

Chris, who arrived from Canada last week as the company's content and technical manager, is charged with making the web designers and the editorial teams sing from the same hymn sheet.

He is sanguine about having to use this software package rather than the custom-made solution: 'There is no such thing as an ideal world.' He seems ruthlessly committed to making things run on time. 'Anything beyond 48 hours for functionality and we're not necessarily that far ahead,' he bellows into a speakerphone.

Having hit the one-month-old milestone, Flametree, now with seven full-time employees, is too big for its office. But Leith is confident that the landlord will agree to their moving into a larger office in the next couple of weeks.

For now the staff have to make do like sardines, crushed together between walls papered with 'to do' lists.

webTitle: Adding up the mobile phone bill

fields.headline: Adding up the mobile phone bill
fields.standfirst: With the cost of building new networks climbing in the billions, big is definitely beautiful, says  Jamie Doward
fields.trailText: With the cost of building new networks climbing in the billions, big is definitely beautiful, says Jamie Doward
fields.body:
One is a maverick who flunked out of a Canadian university and promotes the benefits of colonic irrigation; the other is a former young Conservative with a reputation for being an audacious dealmaker who loves the thwack of leather on willow.

But, despite their differences, Hans Snook, chief executive of Orange, and Chris Gent, his opposite number at Vodafone Air Touch, are united in one aim. Both want to sell you mobile phones. How they go about it will have a profound impact.

On the way the City views the value of their businesses - important for investors who have grown rich backing telecoms firms.

On the way it will spark further consolidation in the wireless telecoms sector - important when it comes to the level of competition in the market.

And on the way we use our mobile handsets in the future.

Vodafone's decision to sell Orange to France Télécom last week, in a £31 billion deal, means Europe now has two competing mobile telecoms powerhouses. Orange, injected into France Télécom's portfolio of mobile phone assets, expects to have 30 million subscribers across 16 countries by the end of this year. Vodafone, following its acquisition of Germany's Mannesmann (Orange's former owner) has 53 million subscribers in 25 countries worldwide.

And there's another potential giant: Deutsche Telekom. In addition to its native T-Mobile - with 11 mil lion subscribers - it also owns Britain's One2One, Max Mobil of Austria and joint ventures in the Czech Republic, Hungary, Poland, Russia and the Ukraine.

'If you looked at the UK wireless market two years ago there were the same four operators who are here now. But the big difference now is that three of them have been pumped up enormously,' says David Wilkins, principal analyst at research firm Analysys. 'All eyes are now on BT Cellnet which, analysts agree, needs to find some new partners fast if it is not to be left behind.'

That's partly because customers are becoming more international, expecting the same services from the same provider wherever they go.

The other force driving consolidation is the soaring costs of third-generation mobile phone systems: both the licences and the equipment needed to make them work. These '3G' networks can support wire-free internet services - opening the door to lucrative new revenue streams.

We can already see the first signs that data services are becoming important. In March last year, Vodafone subscribers received 15 million text messages using SMS technology - the 'paging' system available on most existing handsets. By March of this year, the figure had jumped to more than 140 million messages - reaching 43 per cent of customers. Data now represents 6 per cent of Vodafone's revenues. Imagine the traffic when new technology will allow us to send each other video clips or business presentations.

But such new technology does not come cheap. Britain's recent auction of 3G mobile phone licences might have made Gordon Brown think all his hogmanays had come at once - but it means big headaches for Gent and his competitors. Other countries, including Belgium, the Netherlands, Germany and Switzerland, saw how much the licences were worth to the operators and promptly decided to auction off their own radio spectrum. Some analysts now believe operators will have to pay in excess of £80bn to acquire 3G networks around the world.

This has serious implications for smaller players. Analysts at JP Morgan said recently that operators 'with a smaller footprint' - fewer subscribers - may be forced to consider 'alliances, joint ventures or possible consolidation' to match the advantages of scale delivered by companies such as Vodafone.

But what about the two giants? The City has been spooked by the high costs of 3G services. Vodafone's share price plunged as investors queried whether the company could afford to fulfil its global ambitions. Selling Orange brought a welcome respite as fears about Vodafone's debt levels subsided. The flotation of Verizon, its joint venture with Bell Atlantic in the US, coupled with the sale of some non-core assets which came with the Mannesmann takeover, will also help swell Vodafone's coffers.

Similarly, the new-look Orange - which will float for around £100bn within the next nine months - must also convince investors that it can afford the hefty prices 3G demands.

Some analysts continue to have reservations that the costs of 3G will be too high for operators to recoup their expenditure over the 20-year licences.

Signficantly, last week Gent muttered about Vodafone UK producing an IRR (internal rate of return) of at least 15 per cent on its 3G activities in the UK. To put that another way, Vodafone intends to earn 15 per cent more from 3G services than it will have to spend on developing and operating them.

This is no mean feat. 'Some of the modelling we've done shows that if a licence costs £2bn the company should be looking for a return of around 18 per cent. Go up to £4bn and you should look for a return of 13 per cent,' said Stephen Pentland, a partner at Spectrum Strategy Consultants.Vodafone paid nearly £6bn for its UK licence. 'The challenge for Vodafone is to justify paying that extra £2bn,' Pentland said. This argument will be reinforced following the impending German auction which, analysts predict, will fetch even higher prices.

An IRR of anything less than 15 per cent, analysts say, would send alarm bells ringing among Vodafone's investors who would look to switch into other stocks. Of course, given that no one really has a clue how big the wireless world will be, this figure might turn out to be embarrassingly conservative. But the question is how to exploit the opportunity.

Both Orange and Vodafone face problems. Vodafone has been tardy in rolling out wireless data services in comparison with Orange. 'Vodafone is still slow to get off the mark in WAP,' Pentland said. Indeed, just compare the SMS message volumes on the two companies' networks. Vodafone may have had 140 million SMS messages sent over its network in March - but this was dwarfed by Orange's 200 million. Vodafone also suffers from an image problem.

'Vodafone has a strong corporate brand but not a strong consumer brand,' Pentland said.

It's no surprise, therefore, that Orange will roll its brand out across Europe while Vodafone is left mithering about whether it should try to unite its diverse sweep of brands behind a single name.

This might not sound too important but the brand does have an effect on the bottom line. While Vodafone has a churn rate - the number of customers it loses - of nearly 30 per cent in the UK, Orange has half that, thanks largely to the strength of its brand.

Analysts at JP Morgan conclude: 'The overall performance of Orange in the first quarter of this year suggests that Vodafone may struggle to retain leadership of incremental market share this year.'

Orange, meanwhile, has its own problems. The French government owns a majority stake in France Télécom which raises questions about the company's autonomy. Snook built Orange around his own personal vision of the wireless future. Analysts question whether the company will now have the freedom to innovate that it had before. Ironing out such cultural differences will be Orange's key task.

Both companies will now look to capitalise on their positions by signing exclusive content and ecommerce revenue-sharing deals. As gatekeepers to the wireless internet, both Orange and Vodafone are in powerful positions. It is likely that Vodafone subscribers will have no choice but to use its European wireless portal - being developed with Vivendi - which will probably offer only those services provided by Vodafone's partners.

France Télécom, meanwhile, was in court last week - charged with preventing users from accessing its rivals' wireless internet services. This is a trick that Orange tried in the past. The giants are sharpening their knives. The great wireless internet carve up has begun.

fields.headline: Media diary
fields.trailText: Dyke's progress | C4 hits the language barrier
fields.body:
Don't hold your breath waiting for Jeff on the nine o'clock news
Despite indications to the contrary, Greg Dyke has not entirely forfeited expensive luxuries at the BBC. Gone, maybe, are the croissants, replaced by Mother's Pride toast (and no jam). Gone too are the company cars and chauffeurs - replaced by a secondhand Sunshine Variety Bus. But Greg is thinking big in terms of his hirings.

For instance he has supposedly decided that instead of an economics editor to replace Peter Jay when he retires, what the corporation needs is a business editor. Sensible enough. And he has a name in mind for that august post. It is one Jeff Randall, who we quite like here at media diary - despite his efforts to spoil our fun with his dodgy organ Sunday Business .

But as it is a rare vacancy that arises these days without Jeff's monicker being planted firmly in the frame, we suggest that the Beeb may have to go well beyond the £37,500 it routinely pays exalted reporting staff. Particularly as we hear reports that when Jeff's incentive package matures next year at Sunday Biz he has been saying he will 'plonk my fat arse on the hottest beach I can find'. Perhaps, then, he should be in the frame for John Simpson's job, too.

Making Michael blush
We believe we have found something that makes Michael Jackson, chief executive of 'Channel Swore', blush. Apart, of course, from our entirely unwarranted attack on his masculinity a couple of weeks ago, prompted by a curiously camp photo of him posing on an old fridge. Apparently, C4 has finally drawn the line. Following its programme 'A short history of the F word', the channel turned down a sequel, 'A short history of the C word'. This is apparently on the grounds that while the F word is generally acceptable for late-night broadcast, the C word isn't. Either that or it could be the Channel showing sensitivity after its own unfortunate recent history with the C word. Jacko's predecessor, Michael Grade, was furious when, in a subliminal nano-second, Chris Morris managed to insert the legend 'Grade is a c-' into his Brass Eye programme.

Catch another herring
Red Herring , the fabulously with-it e-zine, has been legally pursuing a tiny Scottish distillery - Inver House - for the branding of its newsletter The Red Herring, which is distributed to a mere 3,000 of the distillery's customers. Now the Inver House house journal is having to change its name, but media diary rang the ponytailed fops at Red Herring to ask why they hadn't done anything about the far more plagiaristic website, Red Herring.co.uk. 'What website?' they said. We await our legal finder's fee with interest.

Cause and effect?
We are alarmed to report that since Times columnist Joanna Coles announced her official support for Hillary Clinton in last Friday's paper, the First Lady's lead in the polls for the New York Senate seat has plummeted from 14 points to two. Could this be a coincidence?

webTitle: Sorry about United, Rupe. Will ITV do?

fields.headline: Sorry about United, Rupe. Will ITV do?
fields.trailText: On broadcast
fields.body:
Another week, another leak. No sooner has the privatisation of Channel 4 seemingly been knocked on the head, than we get another kite-flying exercise with well-informed suggestions that the Government is preparing to abolish media cross-ownership rules. In the run-up to the autumn communications White Paper, this one looks like a serious runner.

You can see the attractions. At the moment, any newspaper proprietor who owns more than 20 per cent of circulation is not allowed to own a terrestrial television station, which effectively bans Rupert Murdoch as well as Mirror Group Newspapers from getting into serious television (as opposed to the satellite stations which make pots of money from comparatively few subscribers).

There are, on the face of it, good political and industry reasons for scrapping any limits. It would be an olive branch to Murdoch in the run-up to the next election ('Sorry about Manchester United, Rupe, but help yourself to ITV instead'). And it would follow two much-touted pieces of conventional wisdom about the culture industries: that Britain needs a few big players to take on the international giants; and that it no longer makes sense to separate screen and print when you can receive your newspaper on the Internet, your favourite TV programmes on your mobile, and both of them on your fridge.

The political argument is impeccable, but both industry arguments are flawed. The British Big Player argument is as old as the first ITV merger, and has been trotted out regularly as the justification for progressive relaxations of ownership rules. Unfortunately, you could merge all the ITV companies with the BBC, throw in a cou ple of big independent production companies, and you'd still be dwarfed by the Time Warner-AOLs of this world.

Apart from which, no one has yet explained why we might want a British News International or Bertelsmann. Are their contributions to the world's cultural enrichment so memorable that we should be sacrificing our own carefully constructed regulatory structures to build a monolith? Are we so badly served by the output of our broadcasters that only some huge multi-national corporation nominally based in London will truly serve our audiences?

Then there's the convergence theory. Of course it's true that information can be reproduced in virtually any form on almost anything that moves. The funny thing is, an awful lot of people are still buying those old-fashioned paper things which you can fold up and stick in your pocket on the bus. If we are going to let the same people who publish them in large quantities also own the television channels which are still watched in even larger quantities, what happens to the pluralism which - most people still agree - is such an essential ingredient for a healthy democracy?

The convergists have an answer for this. It is called 'share of voice'. Yes, they say, we too believe that accumulating too much media con trol in the hands of a small élite is dangerous, but we have a cunning plan. All you have to do is add up newspaper circulation, TV viewing and radio listening - and presumably somewhere along the line make allowances for books, magazines, film studios and loud-hailers - and then come up with an impressive-looking league table. Choose your cut-off point for disqualification, and hey presto!

Funnily enough, something very similar was put together in 1995 by a consortium of media owners trying to get the cross-ownership rules relaxed. They made all sorts of complex calculations, downweighted radio by an arbitrary 50 per cent, and came up with a table which put - surprise, surprise - the BBC way ahead of the pack with a 19.7 per cent share of 'national voice' and News International in a rather pathetic second place with a mere 10.6 per cent. More grist to the mill of those who would divest Auntie of its inordinate power and influence.

It doesn't take an act of genius to understand the problem with this analysis. First, broadcasters cannot editorialise. They cannot campaign to keep Section 28, or send back scrounging asylum seekers, or to anoint Tony Blair as the greatest living human being on earth. Newspapers can be as biased and passionate as they want. Most are (and are much the better for it).

Second, it makes unproven assumptions about relative impact. There is no evidence that if the same number of people read an article and watch a TV programme with the same message, the impact will be identical - or that the impact on radio will be only half as much. Intuitively, it is nonsense. The 'share of voice' concept is rooted in a growing obsession with business expansion in the cultural industries, and the attempt to 'measure' diversity is a convenient democratic sticking plaster.

Some time in the distant future, screen and print might converge. Until they do, we should think very hard about allowing big newspaper moguls to be big television moguls as well.

Steve Barnett is senior lecturer in communications at the University of Westminster.

fields.headline: Resign? I'm right on track
fields.standfirst: Railtrack's Gerald Corbett sees hope amid crises, he tells  Joanna Walters
fields.trailText: Railtrack's Gerald Corbett sees hope amid crises, he tells Joanna Walters
fields.body:
Beleaguered Gerald Corbett has a panoramic view of London from his office on Floor 13 - lucky for some - of Railtrack House above Euston station.

From this great height and with a Marlboro Light in hand, he surveys St Paul's Cathedral, the London Eye and Tate Modern. But in corporate terms, the vantage point is an illusion. Corbett may to able to look out. But more importantly, the world is looking in. He says it's like living in a goldfish bowl.

The Government and a host of regulatory bodies are watching his every undulation. The City wants its dividends; the passengers want their trains to run on time. And since the Paddington disaster last October, Corbett has become a household name in Britain for all the wrong reasons.

Many people cannot believe he is still in his job, and not in prison. But Corbett is, for an emotional man, calm and determined. He has just persuaded the Government's 'rail enforcer', Sir Alastair Morton, not to smash Railtrack's monopoly on the network.

And now he is at the heart of the latest game between the Government, the train operators, Railtrack and the regulators - called 'show me the money'. The money being the estimated £52 billion it will take to deliver a shiny, new railway system over the next decade.

Corbett told The Observer last week: 'For the Government there is a key policy choice to be made. Does it want a railway over the next five years that grows by 25 per cent and brings billions in social benefits?

'Or do we have no growth, and continue with our Victorian infrastructure that is inferior to that of our continental competitors, while every year it takes 5 per cent longer to drive into London because of road congestion?'

To achieve the first option, the Government must put in more money, and regulator Tom Winsor must allow Railtrack to earn robust profits, Corbett says.

He reckons no single company could deliver the huge investments required - and particularly not Railtrack with a share price at half the level of a year ago impeding its ability to raise money in the market for capital investment.

Many observers believe that the depleted price has as much to do with Railtrack performing poorly while raking in vast profits as with Winsor cracking down on such behaviour and causing the City to take fright.

But it all stokes the controversy over the idea that the Government will have to pay if it wants a top railway.

Privatisation has clearly failed in some of its primary objectives, and the public believes Railtrack cannot be trusted with the taxpayer's penny.

The crisis surrounding the second stage of the project to upgrade the West Coast Mainline for 140mph trains, revealed by The Observer last week, is the starkest of illustrations that the Government risks throwing good money after bad. But Corbett pointed out without irony that the project was still 'on track', with just a slight 'funding' issue to be resolved. He is fighting his corner.

All the indications are that the Government will announce next month that it is putting extra funding into the industry - probably around £2bn a year, in addition to halting the decline in subsidies to the train operators. Much of this money will end up being spent by the same names in the industry that have attracted so much criticism since privatisation, with Railtrack at the top of the list.

But the Government hopes tighter regulation, more competition on certain contracts and Railtrack's protracted comeuppance will 'turn the oil tanker' towards greater efficiency, investment and performance on the network.

And much as many people would like Railtrack to be smashed up or renationalised, that is just not going to happen, Government sources have made clear.

Corbett insists not only that Railtrack is improving and will eventually win the public's confidence but also, as he first told The Observe r two months ago, he is no longer on the profit and shareholder agenda: his first priority is public service.

Morton had proposed taking the future expansion projects away from Railtrack, and even new maintenance contracting and plans to replace worn out infrastructure.

The company would be able to bid for such projects, but only in competition with the likes of Balfour Beatty, Taylor Woodrow, Bechtel and Jarvis. The idea was that this would make Railtrack more efficient and prevent calamities along the lines of the West Coast project, which suddenly more than doubled to £5.8bn.

fields.headline: 'One out, all out' fallout
fields.standfirst: American consultants and British lawyers are showing employers how to combat the drive for union recognition.  Oliver Morgan reports
fields.trailText: American consultants and British lawyers are showing employers how to combat the drive for union recognition. Oliver Morgan reports
fields.body:
It seemed an incongruous venue. When the law firm Eversheds held the London leg of its round Britain 'Trade Union Roadshow' last month, it chose the Ironmongers Hall - one of the venerable edifices built by the precursors to modern trade unions.

The meeting was timely - regulations in the 1999 Employment Relations Act take effect this week, reintroducing compulsory procedures for union recognition in the UK for the first time since the Eighties.

For the businesspeople gathered there to hear leading employment lawyers from America and Britain explain the new laws, the message was unambiguous.

'UK employers should view a union organisational effort as an economic heart attack,' Alan Lips, partner in the Labour and Employment group at leading US firm Taft Stettinius and Hollister warned. He added: 'Organised labour unions are philosophically dedicated to coercing employers into economic partnership with them.'

In common with other UK law firms, Eversheds has been busily preparing a union resistance practice - or union-busting as it is called in the US - in anticipation of the new laws, which mean unions are recognised for collective bargaining purposes.

Unions have been monitoring events, and point to leading City firms such as Nabarro Nathanson as well as nationwide practices such as Eversheds and Dibb Lupton Allsop which have been anticipating an increase in business as the laws take effect.

Eversheds' preparations appear to have been particularly carefully planned. The firm has made contacts with leading US consultants, who advise management on tactics to win recognition battles using videos and other 'persuasive' techniques.

One of these, Houston-based PTI Labor Research, has visited London to advise on several occasions. It is planning to open its own London office this summer.

And it has courted US lawyers such as Lips to prime UK companies on the 'dangers' they face - offering its own advice on 'importing the US experience'.

Lips used his Ironmonger's Hall presentation to outline the US experience of legal processes on union recognition (governed by laws since 1935) and draw lessons for the UK. He points out that laws in general - and the US Labor Management Relations Act of 1947 in particular - contributed to highly adversarial relations.

He states: 'The LMRA is designed to permit economic warfare between employers and unions in controlled set tings and on relatively equal grounds.' But he points out that despite the Act, unions are in decline in the US - from 37 per cent of private sector workers in 1960, to 9.4 per cent in 1999.

In the UK, he says 'some employers will undoubtedly be targets. If those employers are not getting this kind of training, they are not going to be prepared.'

In fact, big British unions have been playing down the confrontational potential in the Act. For example, the GMB manufacturing union says: 'The ideal would be that we don't reach that stage.'

And the AEEU emphasises partnership deals limiting industrial action in return for collaboration on pay, conditions and training.

But, as Lips explains, his experience in dealing with labour disputes in America tells him companies should be wary. 'I would expect unions to exercise the economic power that the legislation has given them, and that is nothing but an adversarial activity.' And he adds: 'That can lead to a strike. And if you have a strike it is about as serious an economic event as can happen to a company.'

Lips warns that the UK legislation 'more favourably supports unions' organisational efforts than the labour law in the US'. He indicates that American union resistance techniques - which he links to the fact that union certification elections fell by 8.5 per cent in 1999 - could be employed in the UK.

The key is to gain the initiative before a union decides to initiate a ballot for recognition, triggering the legal process. After a ballot is called, an employer has to open premises to unions for campaigning, which can mean notice boards, and email and PA systems.

If a ballot is called, the campaign should be stepped up with the following messages: 'strikes are futile and fatal' and 'unions cost more than they are worth'. In the US, badges and baseball caps are used by management and unions in ballot campaigns.

Another crucial area is defining the 'bargaining unit' - a factory, group of workers or division of a company - which is balloting for recognition. Lips' advice to employers is to lobby hard the Central Arbitration committee, which rules on the definition of the bargaining unit. He says: 'Attempt to gerrymander the unit to include the most favourable votes. The union will.'

Eversheds is pushing US methods in the UK. Partner Martin Warren says that the firm will work with companies that want partnerships as well as those that want to keep unions out. For the lat ter, he suggests techniques such as pointing to the union general secretary's salary, and painting it as a high-cost organisation selling a service for a profit like a company.

The roadshows appear to have been successful. Lips has found that members of the UK subsidiaries of American companies attending the seminars - those invited included McDonald's, Dow Chemical, and Bristol Myers Squibb - have contacted him saying they want their US superiors to wake up to what is happening in the UK.

Owen Warnock, another partner with Eversheds, says that the firm has advised both UK companies and UK subsidiaries. It can also put clients in contact with US consultants, such as PTI Labor Research, for advice.

PTI partner Mildred Blowen says Eversheds has provided a useful entrance to the UK. 'One of the issues that is going to be big in the UK as it is in the US is what contribution trades unions make to lower productivity.'

Another partner, Stuart Keene, claims PTI has more than 1,000 clients in the US, many of them blue chip, and many are asking about their UK subsidiaries. He also says: 'We are working with several FTSE 100 companies to advise them on techniques.'

PTI will devise a video campaign reinforcing new messages each week, using video and compulsory 'captive meetings' of employees. Message include: union finances; how unions spend their money; how unions can make companies fail; the impact on personal finances of striking; and how good the company is.

Union reaction is predictable. 'We have heard that there are companies from the US trying to offer these services. They should bugger off back to the US,' said one union spokesman. But the TUC also points to figures showing membership up 0.6 per cent last year without the Act, and the number of recognition deals increasing.

The AEEU says partnership does work in the UK but it is clear that unions do have targets. There are old adversaries and scores to settle. The National Union of Journalists - which faced widespread derecognition in the Eighties - has a number of such struggles it believes the Act will help it win.

HIGH profile targets include News International, the Independent and Associated Newspapers, owner of the Daily Mail . General Secretary John Foster believes the Act will be a great help. But recognition struggles will be difficult - the unions still have to recruit 10 per cent of employees and demonstrate that at least a further 40 per cent will vote for recognition.

'It will be tough to get back, particularly in places like News International. But we're confident,' Foster says. But he is upbeat about recent voluntary recognition deals including with regional newspaper group Newsquest.

Jimmy Elsby, assistant general secretary of the Transport and General Workers, says that despite increased recognition deals in advance of the Act, there are T&G targets. 'American companies appear to be worse,' he says.

He points to a Motorola plant in East Kilbride, where union membership among the 2,000 workers jumped from a few to 400 within weeks following a dispute over part-time shift patterns. Motorola has refused to negotiate over recognition, says Elsby. 'We look forward to using the Act.' The T&G is also organising drivers for a ballot at the Robert Wiseman dairy group.

This law will help white- collar unions too. Unifi, the financial services union, has a longstanding dispute with HSBC about recognition for managers. The Act will help here. But it will do more than help unions get back into manufacturing and traditional service sectors. Unifi, like other service unions, is trying to recruit in growth areas of the new economy.

Call centres now employ 250,000, some 45 per cent of them in financial services. 'They are clearly a target for us. They are greenfield sites with no history of unions,' says Unifi's Dai Davies.

He points to Barclaycall, the phone banking side of Barclays, where a voluntary ballot found 87 per cent of those voting in favour of union recognition.

Companies and unions which can't get on will clearly use the Act ruthlessly, but one of the main problems the unions will face is squabbling among themselves.

Some are criticised for drumming up membership in companies where others have traditionally operated. Sometimes they are accused of signing 'sweetheart' deals with employers to increase membership. And employers will try to introduce tame staff associations to undermine demands for unions.

This has not passed the lawyers by. Martin Warren says: 'Whether the UK union movement can work together to exploit the opportunities undoubtedly offered to it by the Act remains to be seen.'

A clear warning from the lawyers that if the unions can be divided, they can be ruled, whatever the law says.

How ballots for recognition will work

Unions can ballot for recognition in all companies with more than 21 employees. Smaller companies are exempt. Recognition allows unions to represent employees in various areas, for example collective bargaining for pay and conditions, and representation in grievance procedures.

The process is triggered when a union applies for a ballot. Usually it will have been canvassing for members, so it can meet the requirements to show a 10 per cent membership within the bargaining unit - the group of workers to be covered by the recognition agreement - and that a further 50 per cent are likely to support recognition.

The employer has 10 days to respond. It can agree recognition straight away. If it does not there are 20 days for negotiation. If it still refuses, the Central Arbitration Committee is called in. First it will rule on the bargaining unit (BU). Employers could have an advantage here - the rules say that the bargaining unit must be compatible with 'effective management'.

There is a 20-day period for the employer and union to agree the BU. If at the end of that period there is no agreement, the committee will make a decision after another 10 days.

If the union can prove a majority of membership in that bargaining unit, then it gains recognition. If not, there is a ballot - either postal or at the workplace - within 20 days. Costs are shared.

If the union wins, there is automatic recognition. If it loses, it cannot re-apply for recognition within three years. The union must not only win 50 per cent in the ballot, but must have at least 40 per cent of the BU voting.

One final point is that the union must be able to prove that it is genuinely independent - it cannot be a stooge of the employer.

fields.headline: The bottom of the barrel
fields.standfirst: Enjoy that pint. High rents and higher beer costs mean the pub may not be there much longer, reports  Nick Mathiason
fields.trailText: Enjoy that pint. High rents and higher beer costs mean the pub may not be there much longer, reports Nick Mathiason
fields.body:
Britain's pub landlords are becoming a threatened species. Free houses - pubs owned outright by the licensee - are rare, and the number of tied pubs - owned by a brewery which restricts the sale of outside beers - is diminishing.

Managed pubs, owned by the chains, where as the name implies the manager is paid a salary, may have their own problems with wages and conditions but the latest threat is to tenanted pubs, those where the licensee pays rent and buys beer from the operator, keeping whatever profit is left.

Each month, according to the Campaign for Real Ale (Camra), 20 pubs close down. They are forced out by rent rises, low margins on beer sales, and by having to give half of their revenue from food and gaming machines to their landlords, the pub operating companies.

In rural areas, the picture is particularly bleak, thanks to dramatic downturns in British farming.

The plight of the landlord has worsened over the past 10 years - since the Beer Orders of 1989, under which the Government capped the amount of pubs any brewer could own and required breweries to allow landlords to sell a 'guest beer'. The idea was to introduce new competition.

While new entrants have indeed emerged, this tactic appears to have failed. There are 60,000 pubs in Britain, and over 10,000 of them are now owned by pub operating companies backed by City money.

These players are not bound by the 1989 Beer Orders and are eager to acquire more pubs. Two weeks ago Enterprise Inns - the largest quoted pub operator - snapped up 183 pubs from Whitbread for £119 million. It now owns more than 2,500 establishments. Enter prise and companies such as Japanese investment bank Nomura and Hugh Osmond's Punch Taverns ,which are the leading pub companies, now act as quasi-property firms, securitising the rent and beer sale incomes they receive from landlords.

In addition, pub operating companies can negotiate with breweries for significant discounts on barrels of beer, beer that they sell on to landlords at huge margins. In effect, an expensive middleman has been created. Most make additional revenue out of the landlords when they leave their premises, hitting them for huge dilapidation claims.

The situation has got so serious that earlier this year the Competition Commission reopened the Beer Orders inquiry. It is due to report this August, and those close to the inquiry indicate that it may force pub operating companies to reduce the price at which they sell beer to pubs.

For struggling landlords, this cannot come a moment too soon. According to the Brewers and Licensed Retailers Association, 1.3 million pints of beer are illegally imported each day. Minimum wages, increased business rates and EU directives on working conditions have also increased pub running costs.

If that were not enough, UK beer consumption is falling. The amount downed has fallen from 39.9 million barrels in 1989 to less than 36 million last year.

Britain's biggest brewers have now largely shunned pubs, preferring to focus on themed bars such as All Bar One and the Pitcher & Piano chain, where customers tend to drink higher-margin bottled beer and spirits.

The tactic has enticed more women into bars, but sceptics fear these establishments will have a limited life. 'They will be rebranded or sold off once their novelty fades,' said Iain Loe of Camra. 'Landlords are under more pressure than ever. Upward-only rent contracts and red tape are forcing many out.'

The Federation of Licensed Victuallers' Associations says that to survive, landlords need to develop legal and marketing skills. Indeed there are now vocational diplomas in running pubs.

Enterprise Inns chief executive Ted Tuppen, an accountant who, until forming his company in 1991, never ran a pub or brewing firm, said: 'The licensee is the person who makes the premises successful.' But for many surviving on wages of less than £12,000 a year, Tuppen's words are small beer.

As a pub landlord, Peter Lyons claims to have lost more than £50,000 - his entire redundancy pay from the power industry job he lost six years ago.

Lyons, aged 51, from Staffordshire, took on a pub with a history of failure but thought he could make it successful as it was in a prime location in a prosperous small town. After paying £600 to the owner, Enterprise Inns, for a weekend course, he began to suspect that the firm was after only one thing: his money. Initially, his rent was 'reasonable' since the previous tenant made a hash of the operation. But as trade picked up the rent doubled, and he found he had to buy beer exclusively from Enterprise. 'I could have bought it £90 a barrel cheaper,' he said.

Lyons, who spent thousands on internal repairs without any contribution from Enterprise, was losing money, so he decided to move to a country pub run by a different operator. But within months, Enterprise took it over as part of a £50 million deal. A similar scenario unfolded. Lyons now works in a hospital. His savings have gone.

Lister's rent hasn't changed, but beer from his pub operator costs the same nationwide. 'My punters haven't the same income as those in the South East,' he said. 'My margin on beer is minimal.'

fields.headline: Texan union-busters move in
fields.trailText: A firm of 'union-busting' American consultants is set to open offices in Britain to advise employers how to fight the union recognition laws which take effect this week.
fields.body:
A firm of 'union-busting' American consultants is set to open offices in Britain to advise employers how to fight the union recognition laws which take effect this week.

Texas-based PTI Labor Research claims it has been approached by a number of FTSE companies concerned about the recognition regulations in the Employment Rela tions Act. It is expected to be the first such practice to come to the UK, and plans to open London offices this summer.

John Monks, the TUC general secretary, said the presence of such firms threatened to undermine the fine balance between employers and unions which has been struck in the legislation.

Unions are concerned that this will be the first in a swathe of US consultants coming to this country to cash in on employer concerns over the new law.

The Act sets out procedures for balloting workers on whether they want to join trade unions if companies resist approaches by union officials. It has been the subject of three years of intense negotiation between the TUC and the Confederation of British Industry.

PTI, which advises more than 1,000 US companies, uses videos and compulsory 'captive meetings' to persuade staff to reject union membership in the run-up to ballots. It tells them about the 'high cost' of unions, the impact on personal finances of striking, the success of union-free companies, and the failure of unionised ones.

The company's website states: 'PTI Labor Research, Inc was established over 20 years ago to help management, labor attorneys and corporations respond to unions and union organising campaigns.'

It advertises its digital video technology and lists its most popular videos, which include one called 'Unions: just say no!'

Such firms are widespread in the US, and have contributed to far more antagonistic labour relations than in the UK, according to the AFL-CIO, the American equivalent of the TUC.

IPT partner F Stuart Keene told The Observer : 'We have ben approached by a number of UK companies in the FTSE index and we have been over to visit several times in advance of the Act being passed. Some time during the summer we are looking to get established in the UK, with an office in London.' He said he had made contact with UK law firm Eversheds.

Unions have been monitoring activities of UK law firms as well as US lawyers and consultants who may be planning to pick up business in the UK because of the Act.

The TUC says other US legal firms may beef up their practices in the UK, but that PTI will be the first union-busting consultancy to set up in this country.

Monks said: 'This blatant anti-union scaremongering is completely out of step with the current climate in British industrial relations.'

fields.headline: From rags to rescue packages
fields.trailText: The Government is expected to launch a rescue package for the beleaguered textiles industry this week, although it may amount to less than the car workers and miners received.
fields.body:
The Government is expected to launch a rescue package for the beleaguered textiles industry this week, although it may amount to less than the car workers and miners received.

The move is a key part of Trade and Industry Secretary Stephen Byers's attempt to wrest back the initiative on the crisis facing British manufacturing in the wake of the sale of Rover and as sterling remains high.

He is set to announce extra funding - suspected to amount to a meagre £5 million - for modernising and improving productivity in the thousands of companies that make up the 'old-economy' textiles sector.

Plans for a task force for textiles, aiming to offer retraining for workers who lose their jobs in the industry in a similar way to the Rover task force set up in March, are also expected from employment minister Tessa Jowell.

However, the challenges will be different because the impact is not focused on one site, as was the case at Longbridge.

The moves come in response to a report from the government-sponsored Textile and Clothing Strategy Group, which has investigated problems faced by the industry.

Textiles workers have taken a hammering over the past two years as sterling has risen on foreign exchanges. An estimated 70,000 jobs have been lost since 1997.

On Friday a further 300 redundancies were announced, with the closure of two woollen mills in Scotland by Dawson International. Last week it also emerged that Coats Viyella, once the star performer among textile companies on the stock market, was to be taken private.

Retailers have attempted to cut costs by switching production to low-cost overseas operations - resulting in companies such as Marks & Spencer, which had a longstanding 'buy British' policy, ending long-term relationships with manufacturers such as William Baird.

John Wilson, director-general of the Apparel and Textile Confederation and a member of the strategy group, said he anticipated that government funding would be channelled into education, training and information technology, as well as reskilling for those who had lost their jobs.

Wilson said that while swathes of the textile industry had been hit, Britain had designers at the top end of the market such as Vivienne Westwood and Alexander McQueen, who were among the best in the world.

One of the key challenges in the report was for companies to learn how British designers had added value to their products and brands and apply it to their businesses. Retailers also needed more discerning buying and marketing strategies.

A Department of Trade and Industry spokeswoman said Byers would be announcing financial assistance, but declined to say how much this would be.

webTitle: Top land firm Delancey set to go private

fields.headline: Top land firm Delancey set to go private
fields.trailText: Delancey Estates, the quoted George Soros-backed property vehicle, could be the next major real estate company to take itself private.
fields.body:
Delancey Estates, the quoted George Soros-backed property vehicle, could be the next major real estate company to take itself private.

Delancey, which is backed by £100 million of Soros's money, invested through Quantum Realty Fund and his family trust Tivadar, is currently trading at a discount to net asset value of nearly 30 per cent - a measure of the City's lack of interest in the sector.

This discount has prompted chief executive Jamie Ritblat to consider leaving the stock market.

Last week the property sector was thrown into turmoil after MEPC, the UK's third- largest real estate company, bowed to investors' long-running dissatisfaction with property shares and agreed to be taken private in a £3.49 billion cash deal.

'We've always said that we wouldn't sit around,' Ritblat told The Observer this weekend. 'The market's view on the sector doesn't seem to be willing to change. We're not going to rush into anything - but we are keeping our options open.'

One property analyst said: 'Jamie's way of investing isn't in vogue. He likes buying high-quality assets and holding them for the long term on long-term finance. Institutions prefer estates to be rapidly churned.'

Last Friday, Knutsford directors Nick Leslau and Nigel Wray confirmed they were to liquidate Prestbury, the property group they formed two years ago.

Leslau said his shareholders preferred cash to a 'highly illiquid and persistently discounted share price'. He added that he may now form a private company to manage the direct property investments of institutions.

webTitle: Ad giant seeks stake in Gunners

fields.headline: Ad giant seeks stake in Gunners
fields.trailText: One of the world's largest advertising and marketing groups has emerged as favourite to take a stake of nearly 10 per cent stake in Arsenal Football Club.
fields.body:
One of the world's largest advertising and marketing groups has emerged as favourite to take a stake of nearly 10 per cent stake in Arsenal Football Club.

Octagon, a subsidiary of global sport marketing and entertainment group Interpublic Group and run by high profile-advertising man Frank Lowe, is understood to be negotiating to buy into the North London Premier League club.

Granada, soon to demerge, is also said to be keen to buy into Arsenal, and OnDigital, jointly owned by Carlton and Granada, signalled an interest last March in buying a stake in the club, which recently appointed Keith Edelman, a former Carlton Communications executive, as managing director.

This appointment was interpreted as a sign that Arsenal is desperate to secure a media partner: it is the only major British club without one. Insiders say it has invited interested parties to tender for a stake. A proposed £400 million takeover by Carlton collapsed two years ago.

Arsenal, which has twice pulled off an FA Cup and League championship double, is set to leave its Highbury ground for a new state-of-the-art stadium nearby within three years. The relatively small size of the present ground, which holds only 38,000 fans, has left the club struggling to keep up with the revenues of some of its bigger rivals.

Its annual turnover, at £40m, is less than those of Newcastle, Chelsea and Liverpool, and less than half that of Manchester United. The club, controlled by David Dein and jeweller Danny Fiszman, is keen to attract a new shareholder to finance its move, which could cost up to £100m. Selling a 10 per cent stake to Octagon would yield close to £50m.

Octagon is already a leading player in football sponsorship consulting, TV rights sales and distribution. Last week, it spent £16.1m on a 49.9 per cent stake in German Bundesliga club Eintracht Frankfurt; it is the first overseas group to buy into German football. It already holds similar stakes in two Brazilian clubs and one in the US.

The Premier League is in the middle of a bidding war for its TV rights. The main 66-games-a-season live package of matches is thought to be a two-way contest between Sky and the NTL cable company. This contract could generate up to £1 billion for the clubs over three years.

fields.headline: Silverstone on grid for fightback
fields.trailText: The board of the British Racing Drivers' Club, which owns the Silverstone race track, will this week announce a radical plan to overhaul its archaic structure in a fightback against rival Brands Hatch. The move has angered some of the BRDC's 800 members, who fear it will weaken their control.
fields.body:
The board of the British Racing Drivers' Club, which owns the Silverstone race track, will this week announce a radical plan to overhaul its archaic structure in a fightback against rival Brands Hatch. The move has angered some of the BRDC's 800 members, who fear it will weaken their control.

Brands Hatch, bought by US media giant Interpublic last year for £120 million, has won the rights to stage the British Grand Prix from 2002 until 2007. The move was seen as a body blow to Silverstone and the BRDC. Now, in a bid to develop Silverstone's commercial potential, BRDC members will be asked at an extraordinary general meeting on Thursday to back the development of a new company, Silverstone Operations.

The company is to be headed by Silverstone boss Denys Rohan, who will take charge of negotiating its future commercial arrangements.

There have been doubts about whether Brands Hatch will be able to host a grand prix unless it is granted plan ning permission.

Brands Hatch has expressed an interest in leasing the track from Silverstone, and in the past has tried to buy the circuit. A group of BRDC rebels want to negotiate a deal for Brands Hatch to manage Silverstone.

However, The Observer has learnt that, based on the proxy votes submitted to the egm's organisers so far, the resolution to create the new company, and retain managerial control at Silverstone, will be given the green light.

webTitle: GTech sued for $3m by Czech lottery company

fields.headline: GTech sued for $3m by Czech lottery company
fields.trailText: US Lottery equipment maker GTech, which supplies ticket terminals to UK operator Camelot, is being sued for nearly $3 million by the company behind the Czech national lottery.
fields.body:
US Lottery equipment maker GTech, which supplies ticket terminals to UK operator Camelot, is being sued for nearly $3 million by the company behind the Czech national lottery.

The disclosure that the Czech operator, Sazka, has filed a legal action against the world's largest maker of the machinery follows revelations that the software supplied by GTech to Camelot was faulty. This caused almost 100,000 UK lottery winners to lose out on some of their winnings.

Sazka alleges that GTech did not fulfil an order for new terminals by an agreed date, was unable to eliminate a recurring error which saw the number 74 appear in a game featuring balls whose numbers ran from one to 49, and on one day this year failed to prevent thousands of terminals crashing during a technology changeover.

As a result, Sazka says it suffered a loss in revenue - and it wants damages.

Sazka also alleges that its contract with GTech expires two years earlier than the US company believes it does.

GTech maintains the Czech claims are without merit, and says it will defend itself vigorously.

The Czech operator's decision to file the lawsuit with the International Arbitral Centre of the Austrian Federal Economic Chamber of Commerce will intensify the focus on Camelot and its technology partner.

The UK Lottery Commission is scrutinising Camelot's bid to run the lottery when a new seven-year licence comes up for grabs in 2001. A rival consortium, the People's Lot tery, headed by Sir Richard Branson, wants to prise the game from Camelot, which has sold more than £14 billion worth of tickets.

As a result of the software glitches with its UK operations, GTech is to launch a worldwide review of its operations to see if the problem has occurred anywhere else. The company operates more than 80 lotteries worldwide.

Problems with the UK system came to light only after a former GTech engineer, David Armitage, blew the whistle. Armitage alleged the software glitch was identified in 1998, but GTech's managers could not decide how to fix it. Camelot said it became aware of the error only last month.

The US firm has pledged to refund all the winners who lost out, Camelot said.

fields.headline: Two men in a U-boat
fields.trailText: Peter Preston: The technical details are spot on, the inevitable leaks and creaks make you shiver in your seat
fields.body:
This is a week for the simple virtues: pace, professionalism, verve. It is what separates U-571 from the rest of a disconsolate pack - and thereby, perhaps, hangs a broader thesis. Hollywood, so far, has found two action blockbusters for 2000. One is Gladiator, the return of the Roman epic. The other is this Boy's Own yarn about Second World War submarine derring-do. Both have their special effects, but neither seeks to make a display of them. Old-fashioned adventure returns with an added punch. Movies can do what they do best naturally.

So, it's 1942 again and Hitler's U-boats, shielded by the uncrackable Enigma code, are sinking Allied convoys at will. But one German sub, the eponymous 571, gets cornered and badly damaged in mid-Atlantic. Its calls for help are intercepted back in the good old USA, though, and Captain Bill Paxton and crew are dispatched to pose as a Nazi rescue mission, seize the wounded sub and get hold of the vital Enigma code kit. You need no gift of prophesy to guess at the second hour of mayhem. The only question is who lives and who dies.

What's on offer? Not historical accuracy to events 'inspired' by the exploits of Brit (not Yankee) crews. This is a very contorted Enigma variation. Not any profound exploration of claustrophobia and fear 160 metres deep. Das Boot might never have existed. Not even gimcrack philosophy. Nobody soliloquises about the futility of war; nobody, indeed, suggests that such a thought would ripple the blandness of their minds. No, this is a movie of 40 years ago come back to find a modern audience - and Jonathan Mostow delivers with elan.

Mostow is one of the new, young directors who knows how to fire impact from standard scenarios. He showed that, a couple of years ago, in Breakdown (when a distraught Kurt Russell lost his wife in the desert inhabited by J.T. Walsh and other menacing flakes). He shows it again here - and his style is to seem to possess no style. The storytelling is always terse and clear. No little directorial flourishes or curlicues. Nothing gets lost in the gloom of the boat. Psychological complexity is how First Lieutenant Matthew McConaughey takes command and learns to be a man - but even that requires only 1.5 changes of facial expression. The rest of a cast mostly devoid of stars is asked to be athletic, drilled and virtually interchangeable. Only Harvey Keitel, as the gnarled Chief Klough, is out of the age range and treading oddly shallow water, in search, presumably, of an untaxing pay day.

It would be false to claim much for U-571 beyond a compulsive competence, but that is also no mean virtue. The technical details are spot on, the inevitable leaks and creaks make you shiver in your seat. Nearly two hours go by without let, hindrance or longueur. All those weeks as champion of the American box office, until Gladiator came, provide their own testimony - and maybe signal a movement back to Hollywood basics.Who needs bloated sci-fi when seven men in a U-boat can whip up so much of a storm. If Mostow is going to make a career out of new wine in old bottles, he might try a western next.

fields.headline: Paperback of the week
fields.trailText: The unofficial runner-up at last year's Booker Prize
fields.body:
Fasting, Feasting
Anita Desai
Vintage £6.99, pp228
Buy it at BOL

'If we could have chosen a runner-up, we would have given the runner-up award to Anita Desai,' Gerald Kaufman, chair of the judges, announced when J.M. Coetzee won the Booker Prize last year. But for Uma, the centre of our attention for much of Desai's quietly unforgettable runner-up, Fasting, Feasting, even small consolations are in short supply.

Uma is a Cinderella figure, kept at home to babysit, make lemonade and massage her mother's feet - only she isn't the one with the looks, either. While her pretty younger sister, Aruna, achieves a 'good' marriage and moves to the seafront in Bombay, and her little brother, Arun, is hothoused in preparation for university abroad, Uma - myopic, plain and not very bright - remains on the shelf, grows lumpen, grey and bitter alone with her parents, 'MamaPapa' - a two-headed monster of suffocating, middle-class Indian tradition who rule their small world from a swing on the veranda.

Fairy godmothers come and go; respect, spiritual nourishment and novelty are as fleeting as a flash of sun on the sacred river nearby. Desai writes in vignettes which accentuate the brevity of Uma's desperately sad-funny moments of respite: a drink of shandy one evening; a stolen phone call; the local convent's Christmas bazaar (her idea of heaven).

In eloquent contrast, part two of the novel follows Arun in the States, where life is so alien he 'knows nothing'. Here, he is repulsed by the amount of food crammed into 'gleaming white caves where ice secretly whispered to itself', although the all-American family he stays with are starving in a different way. 'But what is plenty? What is not?' wonders Arun. 'Can one tell the difference?'

fields.headline: Classicwatch
fields.trailText: It's been called the funniest English novel of the century and remains the best-loved of all Amis's books.
fields.body:
Lucky Jim
Kingsley Amis
Penguin Classics £6.99, pp251
Buy it at BOL

It's been called the funniest English novel of the century and remains the best-loved of all Amis's books. Jim Dixon, his hapless hero, is a reluctant lecturer at a provincial redbrick university (based, Amis later confessed, on University College, Leicester, at the time his friend Philip Larkin - to whom the novel is dedicated - was librarian there).

Jim's future in the department of Modern History is, unfortunately, in the hands of Professor Welch ('How had he become Professor of History, even in a place like this?') and Jim must therefore endeavour to make Welch like him. But his intense animosity towards Welch's 'bearded, pacifist, painting' son, Bertrand, and his desire for Bertrand's voluptuous girlfriend, Christine, conspire against him. And then there's his splendid lecture on 'Merrie England', delivered while riotously drunk...

This new edition, part of Penguin's sleek, new Modern Classics series, comes with an introduction by David Lodge which explains all you could want to know about its social and literary context. But Lucky Jim really needs no explanation; the humour is as sharp and brilliant as it was in 1954.

fields.headline: Audio
fields.trailText: John Lynch's soft delivery gives these tales a sheen of myth and wonder
fields.body:
Four Letters of Love; As it is in Heaven
Niall Williams
Read by John Lynch
Running time 3 hours; abridged
Macmillan Audio Books £8.99

In Four Letters of Love 'the plots of God and Love' enmesh and Nicholas is consumed by his love for Isabel, the three words 'I love you' flying around 'the rooftops of his mind like a madness'. Although they are destined for each other, Nicholas's four letters of love fail to reach Isabel and she marries someone else. But God's voice is heard through the magical Irish landscape, guiding Nicholas and uplifting people's everyday lives. Isabel's disabled brother is healed, and love works other miracles too.

Philip Griffin in As It Is In Heaven is dying of cancer and longs to join his beloved wife and daughter killed 15 years previously. But before he dies, he wants to play the 'Angel of Love' for his son, Stephen. A solitary schoolmaster, Stephen lives on Ireland's west coast where the teeth of the Atlantic bite off the roof tiles. It's a simple existence until he falls in love with Gabriella, an Italian musician who captures forever the vulnerable parts of his soul.

As It Is In Heaven combines the aching reality of love with a visionary force: Stephen sees love as the evidence of the 'ear of God' and feels that, however difficult it might be, he must follow Gabriella, his lodestar.

These stories in which characters, orchestrated by some higher force, are destined to love have a touch of heaven about them. John Lynch's soft, hushed Irish delivery captures it and lifts them into a realm of myth and wonder. It's difficult not to be entranced.

fields.headline: Paperbacks
fields.trailText: An accomplished novel exploring the boundary between alturism and self-fufilment plus When Dreams Travel, East of the Mountains, AJ Ayer: A Life and Josser
fields.body:
Your Father
Jonathan Myerson
Review £6.99, pp276
Buy it at BOL

Duncan, a junior Minister, is hugely beset by a double burden of impotence: politically, in his inability to effect real change, and physically, in his troubled marriage.

He travels to Russia, and in the plight of an impoverished laboratory sees a worthy cause, an opportunity finally to make a difference. But Myerson adds to this the shadow of Duncan's father, and it becomes increasingly difficult for Duncan to separate his desire to do good from his desire to live up to his father's expectations. The short chapters cut from one moral tangle to another, skilfully balancing the different sources of Duncan's complicated pain.

Myerson's accomplished second novel explores the hazy boundary between altruism and self-fulfilment, the weight of the past hidden even in our best intentions.

When Dreams Travel
Githa Hariharan
Picador £5.99, pp276
Buy it at BOL

Scheherazade, the great story-spinning survivor of A Thousand and One Nights, is dead. Hariharan's third novel follows the destinies of her husband, Shahryar and her sister, Dunyazad, as they come to terms with their bereavement.

Shahryar wants to build a lavish monument, but Dunyazad knows that she can only be faithful to the memory of her sister by telling and re-telling her story, by multiplying the fictions around her name.

Hariharan's elegant prose is suitably mesmeric, and the early parts of the novel are an intriguing blend of evocative description and deceptive dreamscape. But as Dunyazad and her slave-girl companion exchange stories in the second half of the novel, our expectations of spiralling complexity are curiously disappointed.

East of the Mountains
David Guterson
Bloomsbury £6.99, pp279
Buy it at BOL

When Dr Ben Givens is diagnosed with cancer of the colon, he decides to seek a 'neat, uncomplicated end' to his life by wandering into the wilds of Washington State and staging a hunting accident. But circumstances complicate his journey into the countryside of his birth, as he is distracted from his original goal.

Guterson's second novel sensitively portrays the troubled mind of a man meeting his end, describing a deer-hunting expedition of Ben's youth and the carnage in his memories of the Second World War with a harrowing weight of detail that anchors us in the physical world.

There are no comforting metaphysical solutions to Ben's bodily disintegration, and Guterson's novel is laudably unmelodramatic, precisely and humanely written.

AJ Ayer: A Life
Ben Rogers
Vintage £8.99, pp402
Buy it at BOL

A.J. Ayer was, after Bertrand Russell, arguably the most influential British philosopher of the twentieth century, and is remembered not only as an academic but also as a public figure. Left-liberal, egalitarian and atheistic, he made countless appearances on TV and radio, during which he displayed the incisive thinking and elegant wit that characterised his philosophical writings.

Ben Rogers has written a lucid and judicious account both of Ayer's philosophical development and his highly eventful personal life, an account which balances clear sympathy for Ayer with due attention to his defects. Despite his emotional coldness, vanity and total lack of fidelity to the women in his life, Ayer retains our interest throughout Ben Rogers's excellent biography.

In the words of Ayer's close friend, Isaiah Berlin, Ayer's 'mixture of sophistication and simplicity is very odd and attractive'.

Josser: The Secret Life of a Circus Girl
Nell Stroud
Virago £6.99, pp299
Buy it at BOL

After a family tragedy, Nell Stroud joined a succession of circuses, touring the forgotten spaces on the outskirts of Britain's towns. She was cautiously admitted to the tight-knit world of greasepaint and graft, but always remained a 'josser' - circus-speak for 'outsider'.

Part autobiographical sketch, part reportage on the declining circus world, Josser: the Secret Life of a Circus Girl gives us a clear account of the daily grind beyond the illusions of the show, the emotional and physical exhaustion endured for the sake of a few minutes of glory in the ring. Stroud's prose is measured but expressive, and beyond her own story lies a moving depiction of a form of entertainment on the brink of extinction.

webTitle: Sly, vicious, insane - he's the Iago of the West

fields.headline: Sly, vicious, insane - he's the Iago of the West
fields.standfirst: Britain's nastiest policeman returns in Bill James's latest while Val McDermid gets a little too close to reality to be believable and Donna Leon turns on the Italian style
fields.trailText: Britain's nastiest policeman returns in Bill James's latest while Val McDermid gets a little too close to reality to be believable and Donna Leon turns on the Italian style
fields.body:
Killing the Shadows
Val McDermid
HarperCollins £16.99, pp423

Kill Me
Bill James
Macmillan £16.99, pp267

Friends in High Places
Donna Leon
William Heinemann £15.99, pp250
Buy it at BOL

Given the vast number of mystery novels published each year, the idea that someone is killing off crime writers has a certain appeal - we could do with a little winnowing. That's the central premise of Val McDermid's taut new thriller Killing The Shadows, in which academic psychologist and geographical profiler Professor Fiona Cameron hunts down a serial killer working his way through a death list of mystery writers. The killer is targeting those crime writers who have turned psychological profilers into heroes. What makes him especially dangerous is the fact that his methods shatter all conventional views on the way serial killers operate. Cameron's search is given added urgency because her lover, Kit Martin, is a crime writer - and his name is on the list.

The geographical profiler carries her own baggage. Weighed down with guilt because her sister was the victim of killer who has never been caught, she is also, at the start of the novel, at odds with the Metropolitan police. She used to work with them until they ignored her recommendations and went ahead with a scheme to catch a killer that turned into an entrapment scandal.

Since The Mermaids Singing, McDermid's work has just got better and better, the pinnacle being last year's A Place of Execution - a tremendous piece of fiction, complex and haunting. Killing The Shadows, good as it is, isn't in that class. McDermid's books are always frighteningly convincing, but Killing The Shadows doesn't quite convince in the same way, I think because there is something too 'fictional' about the central conceit of somebody targeting crime writers.

And setting, as she does, her fictional mystery writers in the real world of UK crime writing, with its Crime Writers' Association and its Dagger Awards, paradoxically makes the novel less realistic. Even so, taken on its own terms, Killing The Shadows is an absorbing read, an entertaining showcase for McDermid's abundant talents. McDermid not quite at her peak is still head and shoulders above pretty much all of the competition.

It's easy to lose all decorum when talking about Bill James's Harpur and Iles police procedural series. British mystery writing's finest prose stylist writes with such verve and originality he transcends what can often be a stale mystery sub-genre to produce novels that are startling, achingly funny and sometimes wholly surreal. Kill Me is the seventeenth in the series and the immediate sequel to Eton Crop in which undercover cop Naomi Anstruther's operation among the local drug gangs ended in a bloodbath on the dockside floating restaurant, the Eton Boating Song. In fact, the last few novels in the series have been pretty much contiguous, continuing episodes in a three-way struggle among the police, the local drug barons and London gangsters trying to take over the lucrative drug trade in the unnamed West Country city.

In Kill Me the struggle continues. Although violence and fear are described convincingly and the plotting is precise, it is James's gift for characterisation and for describing - largely through dialogue - the interplay of the characters that make Kill Me and the rest of the series so enjoyable. Even the names of the characters are entertaining: Panicking Ralph, Lincoln W. Lincoln (aka Lovely Mover), Corporeal (the skinny Digby Lighthorn) for example. And he can nail a character with a detail: local villains Mansel Shale and Alfie Ivis are somehow more sinister because their tipple is gin and pep out of Brer Rabbit mugs.

Dominating all, however, is the relationship between DCS Colin Harpur and ACC Desmond Iles. Harpur and Iles are trapped in a hellish relationship of need and hatred. Each needs the other's skills to work effectively against the crooks. But Iles hates Harpur for having had an affair with his wife; Harpur is trying to keep Iles away from his underage daughter. And Harpur tries to shore up his Chief Constable, who is recovering from a breakdown, against Iles's constant undermining and baiting.

Iles is a character of Shakespearean dimensions: seemingly omnipotent, narcissistic, sly, vicious, lustful, quite possibly insane. James has a great gift for dialogue, especially three-way conversations in which each person follows their own train of thought rather than responding to what the others are saying. Although there is tension and there are powerful scenes of violence, Kill Me, as with the others in the series, is a comic novel of a high order in which the reader is constantly put off-balance not with plotting but with aspects of character and the sheer pleasure of the prose. Essential reading.

Donna Leon is finally getting the sales her entertaining series featuring the Venetian detective Commissario Brunetti warrants. As Michael Dibdin and Magdalen Nabb have discovered in their fiction, the corrupt nature of Italian bureaucracy provides a strong background for crime novels. Leon's books have the added richness of their setting: Venice, a city that is both beautiful and sinister. Friends in High Places is the ninth in the series and starts with an amusing notion - that Brunetti's apartment on the top floor of one of the city's oldest buildings has no planning permission and may therefore have to be pulled down.

Given that this is Italy, Brunetti's first reaction is to avoid official channels and see who he knows who can bring pressure to bear in the right quarters. Before he has got very far, however, the bureaucrat who first brought him the bad news rings him, fearful about some information he is going to pass on. He is then found dead after a fall from scaffolding.

Leon is a skilful plotter and the story quickly opens out as Brunetti's investigations take him into the dark side of Venetian life and the world of drug abuse and loan sharking. Brunetti is a nicely shaded creation, a moral man who is also all too human. Friends in High Places is a splendid read, clever and provoking.

 Peter Guttridge's latest satirical crime novel The Once and Future Con is out in paperback (Headline £5.99)
