British mystery writing's finest prose stylist writes with such verve and originality he transcends what can often be a stale mystery sub-genre to produce novels that are startling, achingly funny and sometimes wholly surreal. Kill Me is the seventeenth in the series and the immediate sequel to Eton Crop in which undercover cop Naomi Anstruther's operation among the local drug gangs ended in a bloodbath on the dockside floating restaurant, the Eton Boating Song. In fact, the last few novels in the series have been pretty much contiguous, continuing episodes in a three-way struggle among the police, the local drug barons and London gangsters trying to take over the lucrative drug trade in the unnamed West Country city. In Kill Me the struggle continues. Although violence and fear are described convincingly and the plotting is precise, it is James's gift for characterisation and for describing - largely through dialogue - the interplay of the characters that make Kill Me and the rest of the series so enjoyable. Even the names of the characters are entertaining: Panicking Ralph, Lincoln W. Lincoln (aka Lovely Mover), Corporeal (the skinny Digby Lighthorn) for example. And he can nail a character with a detail: local villains Mansel Shale and Alfie Ivis are somehow more sinister because their tipple is gin and pep out of Brer Rabbit mugs. Dominating all, however, is the relationship between DCS Colin Harpur and ACC Desmond Iles. Harpur and Iles are trapped in a hellish relationship of need and hatred. Each needs the other's skills to work effectively against the crooks. But Iles hates Harpur for having had an affair with his wife; Harpur is trying to keep Iles away from his underage daughter. And Harpur tries to shore up his Chief Constable, who is recovering from a breakdown, against Iles's constant undermining and baiting. Iles is a character of Shakespearean dimensions: seemingly omnipotent, narcissistic, sly, vicious, lustful, quite possibly insane. James has a great gift for dialogue, especially three-way conversations in which each person follows their own train of thought rather than responding to what the others are saying. Although there is tension and there are powerful scenes of violence, Kill Me, as with the others in the series, is a comic novel of a high order in which the reader is constantly put off-balance not with plotting but with aspects of character and the sheer pleasure of the prose. Essential reading. Donna Leon is finally getting the sales her entertaining series featuring the Venetian detective Commissario Brunetti warrants. As Michael Dibdin and Magdalen Nabb have discovered in their fiction, the corrupt nature of Italian bureaucracy provides a strong background for crime novels. Leon's books have the added richness of their setting: Venice, a city that is both beautiful and sinister. Friends in High Places is the ninth in the series and starts with an amusing notion - that Brunetti's apartment on the top floor of one of the city's oldest buildings has no planning permission and may therefore have to be pulled down. Given that this is Italy, Brunetti's first reaction is to avoid official channels and see who he knows who can bring pressure to bear in the right quarters. Before he has got very far, however, the bureaucrat who first brought him the bad news rings him, fearful about some information he is going to pass on. He is then found dead after a fall from scaffolding. Leon is a skilful plotter and the story quickly opens out as Brunetti's investigations take him into the dark side of Venetian life and the world of drug abuse and loan sharking. Brunetti is a nicely shaded creation, a moral man who is also all too human. Friends in High Places is a splendid read, clever and provoking.  Peter Guttridge's latest satirical crime novel The Once and Future Con is out in paperback (Headline £5.99)

fields.headline: Fantastical tsar trek
fields.standfirst: Historical fiction meets meticulous travelogue in Malcolm Bradbury's To the Hermitage
fields.trailText: Historical fiction meets meticulous travelogue in Malcolm Bradbury's To the Hermitage
fields.body:
To the Hermitage
Malcolm Bradbury
Picador £16, pp509

This book is one of those strange hybrids that exist at the borders of fact and fiction, creatures with the head of an essay and the hindquarters of a romance, say, or vice versa. The book describes itself as Malcolm Bradbury's sixth novel, although it could just as well be his ninth (if you include two novels for television and a novella) or not a novel at all.

The more you read it, the less novelish it seems to be. There is a preface in which the author puzzles over exactly what he has written: 'Shall we call it a story?' he asks. Well, if there is a story, it goes something like this: Denis Diderot, fantastical creature (head of philosopher, body of a playwright, short and curlies of a librarian) sells his collection of books - the raw material of his Encyclopaedia - to Catherine the Great, who promptly buys the man himself as an appendix to his own library, and carts off both to her Winter Palace. Two centuries later, a Bradbury-like author/narrator takes part in the Diderot Project. Part homage, part junket trip, the project brings together a group of wryly observed academics and sends them off to St Petersburg in the master's footsteps.

There isn't much more story than that, which is to say there isn't a great deal of story. To the Hermitage is a work of fiction in that much of it is imaginary, and for want of a better word you could call it a novel, but it doesn't really feel like one. Much of it reads like first-person travelogue. Large parts are immaculately researched historical fiction. There is a whole biography of Diderot written and then fictionalised, as well as vestigial sections of dramatic dialogue.

This is a delightful book. Bradbury clearly enjoyed its creation. He is a fine satirist, particularly of the academic world. At its best, his writing is very English, very funny, with a sweetly veiled cynicism. There is a disgust with liberal values, a frustration with foreign customs, but it is all hedged in an affectionate language more reminiscent of Michael Palin than Kingsley Amis.

There are dangers in writing at the borders of fact and fiction. It isn't only that the best novels are more truthful than any newspapery facts; Bradbury knows where he stands on this, and makes clear in his preface that he has fictionalised history wherever he feels it can be improved upon. But facts also take up a lot of room. Too much information can pull at a novel, stretch and thicken it. A good biographer should know everything and tell it; a good novelist should know everything and tell only the story it contains.

For all its wit and skill, To the Hermitage is a sprawling work, and you know it's going to sprawl several pages before you reach the opening line, somewhere between the author's preface and the two pages of epigrams. One of the trends in contemporary British fiction is for novels to be lean and perfectly formed, like catwalk models; every word should do the work of 10, as they do in poetry.

In this sense, To the Hermitage is deeply unfashionable. It is a heavy book, full of diversions and distractions. It moves at a magisterial pace (the ferry from Sweden to Russia leaves on page 90 and doesn't arrive until page 259). It becomes distracted by Descartes or the fall of the Soviet Union.

None of this is unpleasant, just very slow. 'Rambling' may not be much of a compliment, but this is high-quality rambling all the same. To the Hermitage is not the story by the direct route, but with endless diversions. Is it a story at all?

Maybe, maybe not, but it captures the character of Diderot as well as any story could hope to do.

fields.headline: The road to Auschwitz
fields.standfirst: Can Fritz Stern's study of the sciences in Germany, Einstein's German World, explain why the Holocaust happened?
fields.trailText: Can Fritz Stern's study of the sciences in Germany, Einstein's German World, explain why the Holocaust happened?
fields.body:
Einstein's German World
Fritz Stern
Allen Lane £20, pp352
Buy it at BOL

The topic of German-Jewish relations continues to exercise the labours of historians and sociologists. Recent fiction, notably in German, has been obsessed with the background to and after-life of the Holocaust. The opening of the Jewish Museum in Berlin, together with the interminable, acrimonious debate over a national memorial to Jewish victims, heightens attention, both German and international.

In no other nation, after their emancipation from the ghetto, did Jews experience a comparable flowing in the life of science and the intellect, in many branches of the arts and in the business world. In none was the end of co-existence more hideous and irreparable. What, in God's name - that cant phrase being so apposite - went wrong?

Fritz Stern has devoted a lifetime of thought, research and publication to this question. His studies of the role of Jewish finance in the construction of Bismarck's empire, his essays on the apocalyptic strains in German political theory and on the singular destiny of a major power which had entered so late into European affairs, are of the highest distinction. Related through his family to many of the seminal figures in German science and public affairs, Professor Stern has been an analyst and witness of exceptional authority.

In this collection of essays, reviews and addresses, the virtues of clarity, of humane poise, of extensive knowledge scrupulously enlisted, are manifest. A certain twilit sadness inevitably colours his backward look. How is one to balance, let alone relate, the splendour that was Goethe and Beethoven and Kant to the febrile, formidably creative climate of Weimar and the blackness that followed? Despite unquestionable prejudice and mundane discriminations, 'Einstein's German world was one in which Christians and Jews [or individuals of Jewish descent] lived and worked together'. What roads led to Auschwitz?

Rightly, Stern focuses on the exact and applied sciences. In numerous branches, in academic and applied research, in attributions of official reward, German science throughout the later nineteenth and early twentieth centuries came close to leading the civilised world. In this pre-eminence, the genius of Jewish scientists and the largesse of Jewish donors played a salient role. As Stern puts it: 'The wildly anti-Semitic kaiser had a weakness for rich Jews, and for his weakness he was vilified by rabid, incorruptible anti-Semites.' (The ironic equity of the sentence is wholly characteristic.)

The principal text in this gathering is a twofold portrayal of Fritz Haber and Albert Einstein. It is their complex, ultimately doomed relationship which epitomises that of Germany and its Jews. Haber was an organic chemist and biochemist of the very first rank. Endowed with devouring ambition and almost demonic capacities for hard work, he made a number of discoveries which did change history. The fixation of nitrogen from the air provided Germany with the ammoniac need for fertilisers, for high explosives and for poison gas during the First World War.

It was Haber, more than any other scientist, who cemented the decisive alliance between industry and research, between academic and laboratory-results of Nobel stature and their industrial application on a vast scale. Much of today's industrial-military complex, together with the entire concept of research and development in academic institutes, derives from Haber's rare combination of abstract insight, experimental virtuosity and managerial adroitness. The man paid a fearful price, losing his sons in successive wars to whose technological ferocity he had so prodigally contributed.

Haber's admiration for Einstein was boundless. Einstein, whose private complications Stern alludes to with illuminating tact, responded. But the matter of Germany came to divide them. Haber was, like so many converted Jews, a super-patriot, wholly devoted to German nationalism and ready, almost to the last moment, to allow even Hitlerism the benefit of the doubt. He strove to keep Einstein in a darkeningly anti-Semitic post-1918 Berlin.

Einstein's pacifism, his declared Zionist sympathies, were alien to Haber. Yet a common irony, unperceived, it would seem, by Fritz Stern, conjoins their two destinies. Haber's work on poison gas led to the Zyklon-B of the Nazi death-ovens. Einstein's identification of energy and mass led to Hiroshima. If the chemotherapy of Paul Ehrlich did, for a time, liberate human beings from syphilis, the discoveries of Haber and Einstein rendered the human condition distinctly more threatening.

In a hotly debated study, Daniel Goldhagen ruled that the Holocaust was endemic in the German character and in German history since the pogroms of the Middle Ages. Stern's review, reprinted here, shows the fallacy of the claim. French anti-Semitism was rife after the Dreyfus Affair; Jew-hatred in Austria was, continues to be, more rabid than any in Germany. None the less, Fritz Stern leaves unanswered Goldhagen's final question. With Soviet troops very near, German civilians, instead of begging forgiveness and seeking to flatter their new masters, continued to butcher Jews on their death-marches. Why? What is there in German sensibility which, however obliquely, underwrote Hitler's madness?

Fritz Stern's emphasis lies elsewhere. He looks to reconciliation both symbolic and substantive. He points to the proud record of (West) German democracy and social justice over more than half a century. Franco-German understanding and German-Polish relations are strong signs of hope. Breslau remains Stern's native ground. Einstein was far less forgiving. He did not set foot in Germany again.

fields.headline: Dangers on a train
fields.standfirst: Haruki Murakami describes the mundanity in the extraordinary in his account of the Tokyo gas attack, Underground
fields.trailText: Haruki Murakami describes the mundanity in the extraordinary in his account of the Tokyo gas attack, Underground
fields.body:
Underground
Haruki Murakami
Harvill Press £20, pp400

Koichi Sakata, a 50-year-old commuter, has a precisely ordered life. He leaves his home at 7am everyday, walks swiftly to the station to take the Sotestu Line to Yokohama (the exercise does his blood pressure good), then takes the Yokosuka line to Tokyo and the Marunouchi Line to Shinjukusanchome. He usually gets a seat.

Every noon, Sakata has a glass of milk for lunch, so every alternate day he stops off to buy two days' supply. On a milk-buying day, he travels in the third carriage on the train. By chance, that put him exactly where the deadly sarin gas was first released on to the Tokyo subway by members of the Aum cult on a spring morning in March of 1995.

It is the juxtaposition of the mundane and the insane that makes this such an odd little book. The bright yellow dustjacket features an anatomical diagram of a flayed torso overlaid with a Tokyo subway map. It's a strange image - half Sixties retro-chic and half sci-fi - and strikes the right tone for this disconcerting work.

Underground describes the gas attack - now one of the most famous episodes in the history of contemporary terrorism - from the perspective of both the victims - 12 died and thousands were seriously injured - and the killers. Haruki Murakami is fascinated by the banal details that make up everyday existence and by how that mundanity can open and close like a sea around the most extraordinary irruptions. The book is constructed around 43 interrogations of those involved in the attack.

At first, the level of detail jars. Murakami does little but transcribe his interviews and for readers used to novelists digesting material before regurgitating it, having it passed direct from mouth to mouth takes some getting used to. But gradually, as the characters make their entrances and exits, a slow, almost lazy, sense of dislocation steals over the reader. The memories of the survivors of the attack are oddly sharp. They remember the colour of the handkerchief tied to ambulance wing-mirrors or describe the sarin-soaked air as coloured 'a light pearl tinged with yellow'. The whole effect is weirdly beautiful.

The translation may help this oddly ethereal atmosphere Everybody speaks like characters from an absurdist play. People say things like: 'I'm a man in a hurry' and: 'I was always flirting with death' and: 'Work means you can't look the other way.'

There is no artifice or pretension in Underground. There is no need for cleverness. What Murakami describes happened to ordinary people in a frighteningly ordinary way. And it is all the more bizarre for that.

fields.headline: Saddle lore
fields.standfirst: Jane Smiley's new novel, Horse Heaven, goes inside the head of the horse but reveals more about the human psyche
fields.trailText: Jane Smiley's new novel, Horse Heaven, goes inside the head of the horse but reveals more about the human psyche
fields.body:
Horse Heaven
Jane Smiley
Faber £17.99, pp576

A novel about horses, more than 200,000 words long? Is Jane Smiley joking? Well, actually not, and it doesn't take long before the reader, submitting to a rare and confident spell cast by this marvellous novelist, starts to wonder why he ever thought it was a strange idea. Horses have a peculiar magic, of course; everyone knows the power they can wield over pre-adolescent girls, and has glimpsed a fragment of that almost erotic fascination in dozens of children's classics, from Black Beauty onwards.

In more literary works, horses have a unique series of meanings; they are prominent in the ancients, and have continued to have some kind of significance bound up with wisdom and nobility. Swift, of course, ends Gulliver's Travels in the land of the Houyhnhns, a sort of Surrey ruled by patient, virtuous horses - rather like a Stubbs painting of mares and foals brought to life. Plenty of people have been impatient with the final book of Gulliver's Travels; Randall Jarrell's character, Gertrude Johnson, 'felt a faint impulse to sweep the last piece off the board, to write an article exposing the Houyhnhns'.

But horses have gone on being a powerful symbol - more than that, a statement - of worldly wisdom and right living, and one of the many virtues of this engrossing book is how it restrains an innate temptation towards whimsy and anthropormorphism. Rather, it explores a whole world of human motivation and ambition within the context of horse dealing and racing. Horses, for most of the book, are the blank screen on which the human characters can project their own desires and wishes.

Only occasionally does Smiley go into the mind of a horse, with thrilling effect; it could be whimsical, but is always utterly truthful; it would be almost a blasphemy to mention The Horse Whisperer in the same context. There is, it is true, a psychic who reads the minds of horses, but so firm is Smiley's grip that it is not long before the reader is stilled and even moved by the vision of the animal's thoughts. But horses are seen as much as carriers of human values, freighted with considerations which mean nothing to them; many are as much economic facts as physical ones.

The costs of acquiring a horse are clearly set out, along with the assets of the buyer and how the money has been raised; prize money in racing is contemplated without embarrassment, as is the depreciation in value which a living horse inevitably incurs. When a character hocks her house - which has been appreciating steadily in value by 12 per cent per annum - for a horse which may at any second break a leg and become worthless, we know we are in the hands not just of a playful novelist who loves that little interchange of the letter - horse/ house - but a profoundly serious one who is concerned that we should know the facts of her world. Horse Heaven, in short, is written on the purest Marxist principles, and its author wants us to know the economic basis which underlies the slowly gathering action.

But if Smiley responds in an intellectual way to the business side of the horse world, the book's greatest virtue is in an unforgettably sensuous responsiveness. The physical presence of horses is conveyed with wonderful variety; Smiley has spent long months sitting in fields, watching them move, and her book loves to set down their movements, to write even the magical incantation of abstruse terminology. 'She had a whole new list of words that she sang voicelessly to herself: furlong, off the pace, sire, dam, yearling, gaskin, withers, hock, router, cannon bone, garden spot, long shot, favourite, girth, blinkers, fetlock, and, of course, filly.' Smiley also loves the thing, the movement, for which there are no words, to which her prose responds as quickly and definitely as iron filings to a magnet.

The equine world is the vehicle for perhaps as many as 15 small stories, involving different characters, which are brought together with grand architectural sureness. Horse Heaven covers the whole range of American society, from people with so much money they lie awake at night worrying about how to spend it, to cashiers at Wal-Mart. It satisfies almost every narrative hunger of the reader, from the furious confrontation and the race that ends in tragedy, to the fairy-tale flourish of a prince in a glittering carriage finding his beautiful princess working in a convenience store, before leading her out into a new world.

Smiley writes as relaxed people speak, and her characters speak as real people speak, two virtues which ought to be more common than they are in the contemporary American novel. She knows, as Dickens did, just when to be vulgar, and, more importantly, when not to be. Massive, thrillingly articulated, unfailingly intelligent and warmly humorous, Smiley's last two or three novels have been what Tom Wolfe's are popularly supposed to be (Horse Heaven is even better than Moo). She is the most perfect vindication of the realist novel, of the speaking voice. In her sensuous responsiveness to the facts of the world, her cool, amused, analytical gaze, she has started to look like the best living American novelist.

In more literary works, horses have a unique series of meanings; they are prominent in the ancients, and have continued to have some kind of significance bound up with wisdom and nobility. Swift, of course, ends Gulliver's Travels in the land of the Houyhnhns, a sort of Surrey ruled by patient, virtuous horses - rather like a Stubbs painting of mares and foals brought to life. Plenty of people have been impatient with the final book of Gulliver's Travels; Randall Jarrell's character, Gertrude Johnson, 'felt a faint impulse to sweep the last piece off the board, to write an article exposing the Houyhnhns'. But horses have gone on being a powerful symbol - more than that, a statement - of worldly wisdom and right living, and one of the many virtues of this engrossing book is how it restrains an innate temptation towards whimsy and anthropormorphism. Rather, it explores a whole world of human motivation and ambition within the context of horse dealing and racing. Horses, for most of the book, are the blank screen on which the human characters can project their own desires and wishes. Only occasionally does Smiley go into the mind of a horse, with thrilling effect; it could be whimsical, but is always utterly truthful; it would be almost a blasphemy to mention The Horse Whisperer in the same context. There is, it is true, a psychic who reads the minds of horses, but so firm is Smiley's grip that it is not long before the reader is stilled and even moved by the vision of the animal's thoughts. But horses are seen as much as carriers of human values, freighted with considerations which mean nothing to them; many are as much economic facts as physical ones. The costs of acquiring a horse are clearly set out, along with the assets of the buyer and how the money has been raised; prize money in racing is contemplated without embarrassment, as is the depreciation in value which a living horse inevitably incurs. When a character hocks her house - which has been appreciating steadily in value by 12 per cent per annum - for a horse which may at any second break a leg and become worthless, we know we are in the hands not just of a playful novelist who loves that little interchange of the letter - horse/ house - but a profoundly serious one who is concerned that we should know the facts of her world. Horse Heaven, in short, is written on the purest Marxist principles, and its author wants us to know the economic basis which underlies the slowly gathering action. But if Smiley responds in an intellectual way to the business side of the horse world, the book's greatest virtue is in an unforgettably sensuous responsiveness. The physical presence of horses is conveyed with wonderful variety; Smiley has spent long months sitting in fields, watching them move, and her book loves to set down their movements, to write even the magical incantation of abstruse terminology. 'She had a whole new list of words that she sang voicelessly to herself: furlong, off the pace, sire, dam, yearling, gaskin, withers, hock, router, cannon bone, garden spot, long shot, favourite, girth, blinkers, fetlock, and, of course, filly.' Smiley also loves the thing, the movement, for which there are no words, to which her prose responds as quickly and definitely as iron filings to a magnet. The equine world is the vehicle for perhaps as many as 15 small stories, involving different characters, which are brought together with grand architectural sureness. Horse Heaven covers the whole range of American society, from people with so much money they lie awake at night worrying about how to spend it, to cashiers at Wal-Mart. It satisfies almost every narrative hunger of the reader, from the furious confrontation and the race that ends in tragedy, to the fairy-tale flourish of a prince in a glittering carriage finding his beautiful princess working in a convenience store, before leading her out into a new world. Smiley writes as relaxed people speak, and her characters speak as real people speak, two virtues which ought to be more common than they are in the contemporary American novel. She knows, as Dickens did, just when to be vulgar, and, more importantly, when not to be. Massive, thrillingly articulated, unfailingly intelligent and warmly humorous, Smiley's last two or three novels have been what Tom Wolfe's are popularly supposed to be (Horse Heaven is even better than Moo). She is the most perfect vindication of the realist novel, of the speaking voice. In her sensuous responsiveness to the facts of the world, her cool, amused, analytical gaze, she has started to look like the best living American novelist.

webTitle: He betrayed Wilde. But that wasn't the worst thing Bosie did

fields.headline: He betrayed Wilde. But that wasn't the worst thing Bosie did
fields.standfirst: Douglas Murray's Bosie is a brave attempt at rehabilitation of a golden boy who played on his charm... until it ran out
fields.trailText: Douglas Murray's Bosie is a brave attempt at rehabilitation of a golden boy who played on his charm... until it ran out
fields.body:
Bosie: A Biography of Lord Alfred Douglas
Douglas Murray
Hodder & Stoughton £20, pp374

In 1895, as the storm clouds gathered over the already tempestuous affair between Oscar Wilde and Lord Alfred Douglas, Bosie's intemperate and quite possibly insane father, the Marquess of Queensberry, voiced the opinion that his son ought to have 'the shit kicked out of him'.

I'm afraid it's an idea which might occur more than once to the reader wading through incident after paranoid incident of hurt, reproach, libel suit and vicious sonnet in Bosie's life story, all employed by this 'golden boy' in the relentless pursuit of his own ends. Douglas Murray's rehabilitation of his subject is a brave attempt to redeem a character immured in the calumny of legend. Beloved of Wilde, betrayed by Wilde, betrayer of Wilde, Douglas was a man-boy who played on his charm until it ran out, then raged against Fate for that mortal fact.

After a colourful introduction to the 'black Douglases', Murray's well-researched account soon has us in the thick of the affair, and by telling it from Douglas's point of view, the author gives us an illuminating new angle, especially on Bosie's sexuality. An early experimenter with his own sex, Douglas came to Magdalen as the leader of 'the cause', a campaigner by default. Yet he would turn both straight and Catholic post-Wilde. Indeed, it increasingly seems as though it was both protagonists' heterosexuality which proved their downfall.

Bosie had the added burden of genetic instability to cope with. Murray reminds us what a monster the Marquess was. He was a vicious man who damned his family to misery. None more so than Alfred, although his other son, Percy, was described by his father as a 'sicked-up looking creature, as if he had come up the wrong way. When he was a child swathed in irons to hold him together it used to make me sick to look at him and think that he could be called my son.'

Murray's account of the familiar tragedy of Wilde's trials is well marshalled. He points out that when Bosie failed to make it into the dock to defend Wilde, the rest of his life would seem to have been a series of attempts - often in the courts - to make up for the fact. Most crucial of all is the time-bomb of Wilde's prison letter to Douglas, De Profundis, which was kept from Bosie by Wilde's 'devoted friend' Robbie Ross and which Murray correctly sees as Wilde's most 'destructive legacy' to Douglas.

Bosie became twisted up in his own past, his literary talent wastefully channelled into vituperative sonnets and magazines which seem to exist solely for the purposes of pursuing his campaigns against Robbie Ross, the Asquiths, Jews, and any other party by whom he felt wronged. This sometimes tiresome sequence of spats culminated in the infamous Pemberton Billing trial of 1918, when the protofascist MP Billing alleged the war effort was being undermined by sexual perverts in the highest positions of influence. Douglas, seizing the opportunity for revenge on Ross - and Wilde, by one remove - and encouraged by Billing in his mad conspiracy theories, took the stand to declare that Wilde was 'the greatest force of evil that has appeared in Europe during the last 350 years'.

But Douglas's public nadir came when Churchill sued him over wild allegations that he had taken part in a Jewish-financed conspiracy to have Kitchener 'murdered' in 1916; Douglas received a prison sentence. Murray depicts this as a turning-point in Douglas's life. Like Wilde, Douglas wrote an epic work whilst in prison - In Excelsis - which his biographer sees as a purging of his old obsessions, although with lines such as 'The leprous spawn of scattered Israel/Spends its contagion in your English blood', it merely repeated the kind of libels which had got Douglas into prison in the first place. Contorted in the fundamentalist pathology of the time, such accusations were little removed from those made by Billing's intellectual patron, Arnold White, that: 'Wilde, after death, was found to have a tumour on his brain, a fact that pointed to a hospital rather than Reading gaol'.

Yet Douglas did redeem himself in the Twenties and Thirties, repledging his name to Wilde's. Abandoned by his wife, his son in a mental hospital, slipping further into poverty, he was supported only by his undoubted Catholic faith and friends as disparate as Marie Stopes and Bernard Shaw. In a centennial year which threatens many more books on Wilde, Murray's book does a fine job of putting an irksome and faded legendary boy to bed.

 Philip Hoare's study of the Billing case, Wilde's Last Stand , is published by Duckworth

fields.headline: Sticks and stones
fields.trailText: As TS Eliot's Sweeney Agonistes puts it: 'I gotta use words when I talk to you.'
fields.body:
As TS Eliot's Sweeney Agonistes puts it: 'I gotta use words when I talk to you.' Words, finally, are all we've got. And if the right words are put in the right order, you can get away with almost anything.

Such is the theme of David and Hilary Crystal's Words on Words: Quotations about Language and Languages (The Penguin Press £18.99, pp 580), a unique anthology that celebrates the raw material of any good poem, or, indeed, any prose passage of consequence.

It's an enjoyable collection from two aptly-named professional linguists who know their onions and who have turned up, if you're interested in such matters, some unusual items as well as some old favourites:

'When I use a word,' Humpty Dumpty said, in a rather scornful tone, 'it means just what I choose it to mean - neither more or less.' 'The question is,' said Alice, 'whether you can make a word to mean so many different things.' 'The question is,' said Humpty Dumpty, 'which is to be master - that's all.'

Alongside plenty of Carroll and Dickens and Shakespeare, there are citations ranging from Douglas Adams to Darryl Zanuck on all manner of subjects, from the nature of language to the language of the media, grouped thematically.

The obvious criticism of this book is that if, for example, a fragment of a quotation is lodged in your mind you cannot, unless you happen to know the author, track it down from the index. In that respect, I greatly prefer Peter Kemp's wittier and more impressionistic Oxford Dictionary of Literary Quotations. But I am grateful for Words on Words. What it lacks in accessibility, it compensates for in thoroughness. It is not concise, but it does have a good section on 'brevity':

Ford Madox Ford: 'You cannot be absolutely dumb when you live with a person unless you are an inhabitant of the North of England or the State of Maine.'

Montaigne: 'It is a pity that intelligent men are so fond of brevity: by it their reputation is certainly worth all the more, but we are worth all the less.'

Words on Words also gives clues to the moral and cultural value of literature:

Ezra Pound: 'We are governed by words, the laws are graven in words, and literature is the sole means of keeping those words living and accurate.'

I am grateful to the Crystals for this, from a Vladimir Nabokov interview:

'I would be inclined to define a good poem of any length as a concentrate of good prose,with or without the addition of recurrent rhythm and rhyme. The magic of prosody may improve upon what we call prose by bringing out the full flavour of meaning, but in plain prose there are also certain rhythmic patterns, the music of precise phrasing, the beat of thought rendered by recurrent peculiarities of idiom and intonation. As in today's scientific classifications, there is a lot of overlapping in our concept of poetry and prose today. The bamboo bridge between them is the metaphor.'

robertmccrum@observer.co.uk

fields.headline: Look, no brains...
fields.standfirst: Susan Sontag has resisted the lure to write an intellectual novel a little too well with In America
fields.trailText: Susan Sontag has resisted the lure to write an intellectual novel a little too well with In America
fields.body:
In America
Susan Sontag
Jonathan Cape £16.99, pp387

Susan Sontag, it seems, never wanted to be the most intelligent woman in America. All the austere essay writing, the elegant forays into postmodernism, the effortless deconstruction of contemporary metaphors were apparently a distraction from her real ambition: to write breast-heaving historical romances.

Talking of In America in recent interviews, she has noted how, in the past, she allowed her 'insufferable moralism to kidnap her' and of how in her youth 'she couldn't resist the attention' afforded to her by her reputation for uncompromising intellectualism. Now, she says, she feels the freedom to pursue her real passions; and her real passions, on the evidence of this book, are for Victorian melodrama.

In The Volcano Lover, Sontag's last novel, a fictionalised account of Lord Nelson's affair with Emma Hamilton, she carried off her unironic tale of grand passions by giving it the apparatus of a smart inquiry into the nature of historical fiction: it set itself up as a page-turner which occasionally obliged its readers to examine the nature of page turning. She attempts something similar here, but her framing is more laboured and her story less affecting.

In America tells the true-ish adventures of a celebrated Polish stage actress of the 1870s, Maryna Zalezowska, who travels to the west of America with a retinue of friends and admirers, in search of emancipation, even Utopia. It has been published amid a minor storm in the States over Sontag's borrowings from the real-life career and memoirs of one Helena Modjeska. But the question of attribution of sources is a sideshow; the real mystery here is how such an accomplished writer could deliver such an unengaging book.

Sontag introduces us to her characters in 'Chapter Zero' by having a version of herself - a prolix nineteenth-century version - time-travel to eavesdrop on the group's fireside conversation as they begin to prepare to leave Krakow. Half-aware of the contrivance of this device, she pauses every now and then to offer schoolmarmy advice on how to read her novel: 'You may need to silence everything in your own room so you can hear the sounds of that other room inside your head,' she suggests helpfully, and goes on: 'Raucous or soft-mannered people may be sitting down to dinner, saying something you don't understand, let's hope not because the television is on, and full blast, but you'll catch the gist.'

The resulting gist, arguably best read with Supermarket Sweep full blast in the background, is a 25-page opening paragraph that drifts between self-analysis and the half-concocted intrigues that form the basis of the book. It reads a little like an introduction to Paint Your Wagon by Alain Robbe-Grillet: 'There are so many stories to tell,' she remarks of her chosen tale, after musing a little on her own Polish grandparents, her childhood and her grasp of Romance languages, 'it's hard to say why it's one rather than another, it must be because with this story you feel you can tell many stories, that there will be a necessity in it; I see I am explaining badly...' She may be apologetic for her tendentiousness, but she is tendentious all the same.

As a consequence, by the time an advance party of two sets sail for New York - after an unsuccessful dry-run at Utopia in the Tetras mountains - you share something of their sense of liberation. Charitably, it may have been Sontag's intention to mimic the claustrophobia of life in occupied Poland in 1875 in the opening to her novel; if so, it is a triumph - reading it, emigration seems like the only viable option. The escape is led by a lovelorn novelist Ryszard who has a crush on Maryna. On board the ship from Liverpool, he conducts unsuccessful flirtations; like his compatriots, he dreams of 'turning life into pure future'.

This future is dependent in large part on the theatrical whims of Maryna, who is the unofficial 'queen' of her small nest of admirers. You can see why Sontag, too, might have been attracted to the actress who is at the heart of her book; in some ways she seems a version of the writer's younger self. Maryna has her 'moral thermostat' permanently on high; she chides herself for being 'too fastidious' (just as Sontag, in an aside, urges herself to be less 'thinky'). 'Comedy,' Maryna says, in a rare moment of comedy, 'isn't thought to be my strong point.'

She is a great social improver. On reporting seeing the newly invented telephone for the first time at the Great Exposition in Philadelphia, Maryna writes home to explain how 'anyone can now have an Italian opera, a play of Shakespeare, a debate in the Congress, a sermon by their favourite preacher laid on like gas in one's own house. The possibilities for public instruction are unlimited...'

There are in this high-mindedness possibilities too for nice, distancing ironies and at first, when she reproduces Maryna's long letters home from America, it seems as though Sontag is quietly apeing a florid nineteenth-century Polish-English, a long-winded literary joke, but a joke all the same. As the novel progresses, however, and Maryna's diction proves virtually indistinguishable from the authorial voice, it dawns that Maryna is not meant as pastiche, but as a sympathetic heroine, and her travelogue is intended as a sentimental education.

There is lurking somewhere a parable of the founding of the American West, akin to one of Hawthorne's examinations of the original Plymouth colonies. Maryna sees herself as Rosalind in As You Like It and there are stagy debates on the nature of estrangement. But Arden in California is over almost before it begins, as the members of the commune fall predictable prey to what Sontag defines as 'the destructive nihilism of the desert' and they drift off towards San Francisco, where Maryna re-establishes herself as an actress.

In place of a sustained interrogation of the idea of the West, Sontag presents an involved love triangle or, rather, a love rectangle: Maryna is married to Bogdan and courted by Ryszard but ultimately in love only with the theatre. You can't help but sympathise with her choice. Bogdan is a repressed gay aristocrat with a fascination for manned flight. Ryszard, meanwhile, has a tendency to utter straight-faced chat-up lines such as: 'I've lived with your body in my mind so long. Your breasts, your thighs, your love cave - I can tell you about them.'

When this line in dubious flattery does eventually, and remarkably, give Ryszard access to the 'love cave' in question ('Let me kiss you, Maryna.' 'Don't.' 'So I will never hold you in my arms.' 'Never? Never! Who knows what that means?') you may well feel that he and Maryna deserve each other. More likely, though, you'll be past caring.

Ryszard, meanwhile, has a tendency to utter straight-faced chat-up lines such as: 'I've lived with your body in my mind so long. Your breasts, your thighs, your love cave - I can tell you about them.' When this line in dubious flattery does eventually, and remarkably, give Ryszard access to the 'love cave' in question ('Let me kiss you, Maryna.' 'Don't.' 'So I will never hold you in my arms.' 'Never? Never! Who knows what that means?') you may well feel that he and Maryna deserve each other. More likely, though, you'll be past caring.

fields.headline: Weary Windies struggle with form
fields.trailText: There is always a twist in the Brian Lara story. Out for one in the first innings, when he 'walked', he was held back last night in the second.
fields.body:
There is always a twist in the Brian Lara story. Out for one in the first innings, when he 'walked', he was held back last night in the second. Presumably the decision to send in Chanderpaul before him, when two wickets had gone down for 24, was his captain's; but since the star batsman's state of mind has been very much in the public domain recently, one can't help wondering.

The captain in this game is Sherwin Campbell, who has worries of his own. Out second ball in the first innings, he spent some time avoiding a 'pair', got off the mark with a push that went close to a fieldsman, clattered an emphatic boundary, and was then caught at third slip from an uncertain, half-forward nudge.

It was a second wicket for young Duncan Catterall, who in his first first-class game this season, had five wickets on Friday. At 45 for two when bad light ended play, the tourists have yet to wipe off a first innings deficit of 68. But although these may be awkward days for their batsmen, the bowlers won't have been too disconcerted to move almost overnight from a dry Test pitch in the Caribbean to classic English conditions.

An atmosphere that changed within seconds from the lightest of misty rain to the hint of pale sunshine, plus moisture in the pitch, must have been near to therapy for the weary fast men.

In the morning Nixon McLean and Corey Collymore enjoyed themselves against batsmen capable only of defending. They didn't try to bowl too short or too quick, and McLean in particular bowled a fine line to the left-handers.

It was to be almost an hour before a run was scored in front of the wicket, albeit it only a firm push to midwicket for two by Vikram Solanki. The England 'A' batsman, with scores of 98 and 161 in his last two championship matches, had to ride his luck. He had got off the mark to a ball that brushed his glove before evading the keeper's leg-side dive; and a cramped hook against McLean fell short of long leg.

In the meantime, Philip Weston, choosing the wrong opponents for a first-team return, played an indeterminate push that sent the ball at easy catching height to cover; Elliott Wilson was caught behind half-driving at a full length ball from Collymore; and the left-handed Paul Pollard got a ball that slanted and lifted so perfectly that the nick was greeted with the smallest of shouts.

Immediately after lunch off-spinner Chris Gale was given two overs and was expensive. Franklyn Rose then took over. He was making his first appearance of the day, following a scan on a bruised finger, but by now the initiative was marginally with the batsmen.

Against Collymore, Solanki had slashed an intended drive over the slips and in the same over found air with another. If there was a hint of pent-up frustration in a cover-drive against the same bowler this was also the stroke of the day as it fled the fence beneath the Ladies Pavilion. Considering his travails, a half-century containing eight fours, and reached in 98 balls, was a noteworthy achievement.

In the end he died by the sword, top-edging a hook. That was also the style of Driver's dismissal, after he had hit Mahendra Nagamootoo for two leg-side sixes.

The latter will not have been so pleased with his day: leg-spinners delivered flat, quick and erratically were not likely to achieve much on this sort of wicket.

webTitle: Is Snoop Doggy Dogg really a race warrior?

fields.headline: Is Snoop Doggy Dogg really a race warrior?
fields.standfirst: Or is 'race' almost extinct? as Paul Gilroy argues in Between Camps - by way of Montaigne and Missy Elliott
fields.trailText: Or is 'race' almost extinct? as Paul Gilroy argues in Between Camps - by way of Montaigne and Missy Elliott
fields.body:
Between Camps: Race, Identity and Nationalism at the End of the Colour Line
Paul Gilroy
Allen Lane £22.50, pp416
Buy it at BOL

Earlier this month, Jack Straw took part in a Sunday Times-sponsored debate in London on 'The Growing Threat of the Underclass'. The keynote speaker was the American social scientist Charles Murray, whose best known work, The Bell Curve (1994), manipulated recent genetics research to explain why so many African-Americans were on welfare. Ignoring such petty factors as poor schooling or lack of federal investment, he claimed that the problem lay with the IQ scores of black people which were lower than those of other ethnic groups. Their genes made them stupid. Why are they poor? Literally, it is 'cause they is black.

Pathologising black people on spurious evidence is nothing new. Imperialism could not have flourished without it. Kant, in his 'Observations on the Feeling of the Beautiful and the Sublime', approvingly quoted Hume's assertion that blacks were incapable of producing 'anything great in art or science or any other praiseworthy quality'. Fifty years earlier, Carolus Linnaeus, the Swedish botanist who first classified the natural world, had divided mankind into five categories which casually blurred moral and physical attributes: Europeans were 'gentle, acute, inventive' while Asiatics were 'severe, haughty, covetous' and Africans 'crafty, indolent, negligent'.

One of the goals of Between Camps is to look at the crafty and negligent ways in which various European writers have used - and also ignored - the category of 'race' in shaping their ideas about what it is to be modern or even human. Its author, Paul Gilroy, has been one of the consistently interesting thinkers in English academia over the past two decades. Sidestepping the post-structuralist quicksands into which so many of his contemporaries have sunk, he blends sociology, moral philosophy and cultural theory into a heady brew.

His work is distinguished not only by its breadth of reference (Lévinas freestyles with Li'l Kim, while Montaigne gets jiggy wit' Missy Elliott) or by its canny use of puns (Gilroy promotes notions of identity which stress routes rather than roots; it ain't where you're from, it's where you're at), but also by its Utopian vocabulary that invokes the 'yearning' of the disenfranchised peoples it discusses.

One of the startling claims Gilroy makes in his new book is that 'race' is on the verge of extinction. Scientists - though not those celebrated by Charles Murray - have not only shown that many disparate ethnic groups hail from the same genetic pool, but that individual tribes in Africa and elsewhere are far more genetically heterogeneous than previously suspected. Strangers among our 'own', newly-affianced to alien peoples - how much longer, asks Gilroy, can we deploy race as a conceptual category?

He also questions whether racial theories that have traditionally been founded on negrophobia make much sense now that blackness can 'signify vital prestige rather than abjection in a global info-tainment telesector'. Translated into English, this means that those videos of Puff Daddy flexing and showing out, which MTV spews forth, may help white people think of blacks in a new and positive light.

Or perhaps they won't. The Arsenal fans I recently saw on the Tube, interrupted their chorus of 'Spurs are on their way to Auschwitz' to kick a young African student into a bloody pulp. They didn't think their adoration of a black striker such as Nwankwo Kanu obliged them to treat non-football-playing Nigerians with any greater tolerance. Gilroy himself seems to realise this: analysis soon gives way to imprecation as he calls for liberation from 'all racialising and raciological thought, from raciological seeing, racialised thinking, and racialised thinking about thinking'.

A particularly fascinating feature of Between Camps is its attempt to draw parallels between black and Jewish experiences. This is an issue of some pertinence in the States, where despite the Jewish contribution to black American creativity (publishers such as Knopf were responsible for issuing the key works of the Harlem Renaissance during the 1920s) and political parity (they helped the civil rights movement of the 1950s and 1960s), Jews have long been regarded as enemies by, among others, the Nation of Islam. Gilroy, however, highlights their shared histories of mass extermination and argues that such sufferings undermine the triumphalist rhetoric of European modernity. He is interested by how these groups, exiled and dispersed both, have developed identities which are based on transmigration and diaspora rather than the litany of blood-soil-roots so often paeaned by nationalists.

Gilroy is also keen to attack the body fascist 'biopolitics' of much recent black popular culture. Soul and reggae artists of the past, he claims, tried to create a revolutionary consciousness in their listeners. Today's rappers are more interested in buffing, tattooing and draping their surly, dogmatically heterosexist bodies. In doing so, he suggests, they employ much of the iconography and jargon of pre-war fascism.

Gilroy's lunging analogies - one involves Snoop Doggy Dogg and a concentration camp - can be OTT. His prose is often clotted with the circumlocutions and apocalyptic terminology - ultranationalism, white supremacy - that is rife in revolution. The abolition of mortgage tax relief will affect the cultural and material prosperity of black people more than some obscure critical theorist's epistemological lacunae. None the less, Between Camps is worth reading. Its scope, its unfashionable commitment to 'planetary humanism', and its moral seriousness all make it an unusual and valuable work of cultural politics.

fields.headline: Taxation: hints and wrinkles
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Being over 65 can have its financial advantages. The system offers several tax breaks that are not available to younger taxpayers - but you have to know the rules.
fields.body:
Being over 65 can have its financial advantages. The system offers several tax breaks that are not available to younger taxpayers - but you have to know the rules.

Everyone gets a personal allowance of £4,385. This is the amount of taxable income you can receive before you start paying income tax. Married couples where one is 65 or over also qualify for the married couple's allowance, taking £200 off your tax bill.

Both of these can be increased by what are known as age allowances - although they depend on both age and income level. They operate in two age bands. For those aged 65-74, the personal allowance increases to £5,790, while at 75 and over it goes up to £6,050.

But these allowances are also governed by your income. This year, the income limit is £17,000. If your total taxable income is above that, the age allowances are reduced by £1 for every £2 of income over the limit. The following examples illustrate how the system works.

Harry is single, 66, with an income of £18,000 - £1,000 over the limit. He loses £500 of the age allowance, taking it to £5,290. On the other hand George, who is married, aged 66, has an income of £20,000 - putting him £3,000 over the limit. This wipes out all his extra £1,405 age allowance, so he can claim only the basic personal allowance of £4,385.

He still receives an increased married couple's allowance. Of his £3,000 'excess' income, £2,810 has been set against his personal allowance. That leaves only £190 to count against his married couple's allowance.

If you have income from investments, you may be able to change them to cut your tax bill by qualifying for the higher allowances. Individual savings accounts and national savings certificates both offer tax-free income. But you have to hold savings certificates for at least 12 months to start a regular encashment plan that will pay out tax free.

Although you can't put any more money into Peps and Tessas, you can draw the income - without it counting as taxable income.

There are several other types of investment which can provide income in a non-taxable form. If you have bought an annuity, the taxman treats part of each payment you get as capital, rather than income. It is not subject to income tax - and can be ignored when it comes to calculating your age allowances.

Single-premium life assurance bonds - often known as investment bonds - also offer tax-saving potential.There is no tax liability until the entire bond is cashed or matures, and you can withdraw a sum equal to 5 per cent of the original investment every year for up to 20 years. Again, this is a return of capital - not income - so you pay no tax and it does not count against allowances.

Another technique is for married couples to share their investments. Arthur, 72, has pensions of £16,500, and his savings in the building society pay £4,000 in interest net of tax.

His wife, Jane, 70, has a £3,000 pension. By transferring the building society account into Jane's name she will qualify for a tax repayment of £710.

In addition, Arthur's tax bill will be cut by £309.10 because he will qualify for an age allowance and a higher married couple's allowance. The simple step of transferring the building society interest from husband to wife saves them more than £19.50 per week.

Another option is to put investments into joint names. Where assets are held in joint names, husband and wife are each treated as entitled to an equal share of any income.

 The author is senior tax manager at accountant PricewaterhouseCoopers.

webTitle: Shelling out for Egg will be a gamble

fields.headline: Shelling out for Egg will be a gamble
fields.standfirst: Analysts are split over prospects for the internet bank, says  Neasa MacErlean. Can it outmanoeuvre its rivals?
fields.trailText: Analysts are split over prospects for the internet bank, says Neasa MacErlean. Can it outmanoeuvre its rivals?
fields.body:
Don't invest your life savings in Egg, the Prudential's internet wing, which is floated this month. Although it is seen as a very cleverly run business, the experts are divided on its future. There is no guarantee it will continue to sparkle in the way it has done during its first 18 months.

You have to be an Egg customer to be eligible to invest. The company is restricting the share offer to the 800,000 people who were customers on 22 February this year.

If you qualify and want to apply, you need to do it by midnight on Thursday. Controversy has attached to the fact that applications will only be accepted over the internet at the www.egg.com site. If you do not have net access at home, Egg recommends setting up a free email account with a provider such as Yahoo! Mail (www.yahoo.co.uk) or MSN Hotmail (www.hotmail.com).

Is it worth applying? Justin Urquhart-Stewart of Barclays stockbrokers is one of those who firmly says yes. 'I would fill up your egg carton,' he says.

'It has got fantastic backers, it is extremely well managed, it was first into its area of the market and it has shown an ability to cross-sell very effectively.'

Justin Modray of financial adviser Chase de Vere is one of those who gives it a maybe: 'People should certainly consider it - but it's relatively high risk. It is one of those companies which has poured a lot of money into a loss leader - by offering very good savings and loans rates.But its problem now is that it has to cut those savings rates to make money. A proportion of its customers are then likely to jump ship. I think it will struggle in the long term.'

Many people think the answer is no - including this City banking analyst: 'My gut feeling is that it is a company that is going to struggle to make much money in the long term. Goldmans [the 'global co-ordinator'] will ensure that the share price goes up for a couple of days - but in the longer run Egg will be playing in a very competitive market. If you are going to invest, sell on the first day.'

Investors have the option of applying for shares worth £200, £500 or £1,000. If the issue is oversubscribed, then share applications will be scaled down. If it is vastly oversubscribed, names will be put in a hat to decide who gets shares and who loses out. Applicants will be told by email if successful.

Shares will start to be traded on 12 June. Egg has said shares will be priced somewhere between 130 and 175p each. Urquhart-Stewart predicts the price will be at the high end of this range - and could go to 220p fairly quickly, partly because 'there will be a shortage of stock'. The share sale is only a partial flotation: the Pru is selling off only 18 per cent of Egg.

Urquhart-Stewart warns would-be investors against applying for only £200 of shares: 'I don't like holding shares of that amount. You get hit by commission when you come to sell them.' He means that most stockbrokers charge a minimum fee, no matter how small a number of shares you are selling, and this could eat up a lot of any profit.

Although it is seen as a very cleverly run business, the experts are divided on its future. There is no guarantee it will continue to sparkle in the way it has done during its first 18 months. webTitle: How to cope with being made a scapegoat

fields.headline: How to cope with being made a scapegoat
fields.trailText: Accept if inevitable, quickly decide which route to take and get out if can
fields.body:
1: Understand that less sophisticated societies have a need for scapegoats and sacrificial lambs. Robert Ayling clearly understood this when he was forced out as chair of the Millennium Dome last month. His approach - shrugging his shoulders, saying little and walking away - is one of the best ways to deal with this situation.

2: Accept, however, that there are two types of scapegoating. If you work in the murky worlds of politics or business, then you should not get upset if you come across unfairness. If you are a schemer yourself you will know that the 'blame frame' is just part of the terrain. If, however, you are the innocent victim of a miscarriage of justice then you may need to engage in serious warfare just to keep going.

3: Decide early on which route you are going to take. If you are going to go quietly, do it with grace. 'Almost invariably, the best thing to do is to shut up and retreat for six months,' says Brendan, a doyen of back-stabbing scenarios. 'Even people who think it is unfair can become embarrassed and will not thank you for saying you've been made a scapegoat.' Mayor Ken Livingstone, the recipient of much of Tony Blair's bile on Old Labour, has strained to appear serene and to avoid saying anything unpleasant about Blair.

4: Start plotting, if you feel so inclined, about how you can spread the blame to others. You have been rather remiss in letting yourself be scapegoated in the first place - by not maintaining your information systems with colleagues and by neglecting your popularity ratings. But you can get revenge. You may have evidence of other people's mistakes, for instance. The truly Machiavellian will anonymously leak damaging memos or get other pawns to stumble upon the incriminating documents. Appreciate that some of your tormentors will get their comeuppance: companies with blame cultures repeatedly go through the scapegoating ritual.

5: Consider finding a new job (if you have not lost your post already). For a start, you do not have the stomach for the nastier side of office politics. Secondly, the company could be going downhill in the long run. In their new book Difficult Conversations, the authors, members of Harvard University's Negotiation Team, conclude: 'Removing one player in a system is sometimes warranted. But the cost of doing so as a substitute for the hard work of examining the larger contribution system [looking at all the contributing factors] is often surprisingly high.'

fields.headline: How good is yours?
fields.standfirst: Pamela Atherton's guide to checking if your scheme is a winner or a loserMoney Unlimited
fields.trailText: Pamela Atherton's guide to checking if your pension scheme is a winner or a loser.
fields.body:
Pensions are one of our most important benefits as employees. Yet their mind-boggling complexity makes them one of the least understood. Most people don't know what sort of scheme they belong to, let alone how it compares with others.

Help is at hand, however. The latest survey by Union Pension Services, a trade union organisation which produces an annual comparison of UK schemes, looks at 250 plans to which, it says, two-thirds of occupational scheme members belong. And for the first time, it includes several money purchase plans, some of which are rated among the best.

The generous scheme for retired MPs, the Parliamentary Contributory Fund, is rated the best, followed by plans run by banks and other big businesses.

The survey's author, UPS director Bryn Davies, an actuary, gives each scheme an 'overall' percentage rating for the benefits provided, compared with an ideal or 'target' scheme. For the top 10, see the box below.

A second percentage figure shows the value of the all-important employer's contribution. This is called the 'net of [employee] contributions' ratio. Other ratings show how good individual schemes are for staff who stay in them until retirement, for those who leave early and for the low paid.

However, the survey is extremely controversial, not least because it ranks final salary schemes - which provide a pension based on a member's final salary at retirement and length of service, alongside money purchase, or 'defined contribution', schemes whose pensions are based on the level of annuity your fund can buy.

Members of money purchase scheme are at the mercy of annuity rates at retirement, so their pension pots tend to buy considerably less than those promised by final salary schemes. The high price of buying an annuity makes the gap between the benefits of the two types of pension grow ever wider.

This is why Bruce Moss of actuarial firm Towers Perrin dismisses the survey as fundamentally flawed: 'Davies is comparing two completely different types of pension. It is like comparing apples with pears. The conclusions he has reached are incorrect.'

That said, the survey is generally regarded as a useful comparator of final salary schemes, of which around 10 million people in the UK are members. In final salary or 'defined benefit' schemes, the level of contribution made by the employer is most important, so the most significant rating to look at in the survey is the 'net of [employee] contribution' percentage.

If you belong to a final salary scheme, you can make additional voluntary contributions. Lower-paid employees may be allowed to contribute to a stakeholder pension from next year. But the Government has yet to make a final decision on this

Under money purchase schemes, by contrast, the average level of employer contribution tends to be far lower than with final salary schemes. Most bosses pay only between 5 and 10 per cent of staff salaries into money purchase schemes compared with an average of 12 -15 per cent for a good final salary scheme.

 Copies of Pension Scheme Profiles can be purchased for £295 from Union Pensions Services, 10E Bedwardine Road, London SE19 3AY.

fields.headline: Growing old comfortably...
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Investment advice for your sixties, seventies and eighties.
fields.body:
Sixties

At this stage of your life, says Valerie Smart, senior tax manager at PricewaterhouseCoopers, the priority should be to reduce the risks you are taking with your investments.

So if you have ben dabbling in the dotcoms, now is the time to stop. You will need to seek safer investments, but the income from your accumulated savings may drop as a result.

Your priorities must switch from capital growth to income. Smart says: 'You might look for the same total return, but the mixture of income and growth would be different.'

For many pensioners, the temptation will be to leave everything on deposit. But the danger is that if you do this early in retirement, inflation erodes the value of the capital.

Most investment advisers counsel younger pensioners to spread their money between deposits and investments that will produce some capital growth so that the value of the total amount is maintained over the years.

Income on a portfolio such as this may be lower to begin with, but it has a better chance of rising to outstrip returns on deposits in the long term.

For people unaccustomed to stock market investment, investing now for income later can take a leap of faith. But, because retirement may last for many years, more pensioners will have to consider an investment strategy that includes some risk.

Fred Carr of stockbroker Carr Sheppards Crosthwaite recommends that nervous investors start by investing as little as £1,000 in a unit trust or investment trust - just to get used to the idea of taking some risk.

For people retiring on personal pensions and 'money purchase' company pensions, the early sixties are likely to bring them face to face with the paltry returns available now on annuities. It will come as a rude shock to discover that their fund of £100,000 will buy barely £8,000 a year of income - less for a woman.

Those with larger funds - some advisers suggest a minimum of £250,000 - can consider income drawdown plans, or phased retirement schemes, where money can remain invested in the stock market.

For those with smaller funds, the best option until recently has been simply to shop round for the best rate - income can vary by 20 per cent between the best and worst paying companies. Another option was to choose a with-profits annuity that might offer an increasing level of income in future. But insurance companies are trying to produce new types of annuity, and advisers have reacted enthusiastically to a new product launched last month by Canada Life, which allows investors to use part of their fund to buy an annuity giving guaranteed income for five years and leave the balance of the pension fund invested. After five years, options can reviewed again.

When taking your pension - be it money purchase or final salary - it is usually best to take the maximum tax-free cash available, because that money can go into investments such as Isas to produce tax-free income. If taken as pension, it will be taxed.

Better-off pensioners may want to start planning to avoid inheritance tax bills for the next generation. Those whose incomes are surplus to what they need to live on are permitted to give money away with no tax bill.

Simon Leney at solicitor and investment manager Cripps Harries Hall says: 'If you are 60 and had children in your twenties and thirties they will be 35 or 40 now, and may be earning reasonably well themselves.You could think about school fees planning for grandchildren. You could set up a trust to receive regular income and build up a pot for grandchildren.

But advisers counsel against being too eager to give away money. Carr says: 'It is sensible to defer any real planning until about one year after retirement, by which time you will have settled into your new way of life and have a realistic idea of your true budgetary needs.'

The sixties is also an age where it may still be economically viable to set up a nursing home fees insurance plan, although these are unaffordable for many people.

In the early years after retirement you may want to make the most of profits built up in your home. Lenders and financial institutions are launching products to meet this demand.

But consider whether it would be better in the long term to sell your property and release cash rather than giving up some of the capital; all such schemes require sharing at least some of the housing profits with a financial institution. For information on equity release for the elderly, contact Hinton & Wild on 020 8390 8166.

Seventies

When you reach your eighth decade, concerns about inheritance tax may come more sharply into focus. An increasing number of people will need to worry about this in future because of rising property prices. The average price of a property in London is £185,000; the maximum estate that can be passed on this year without being hit by an IHT bill (which would be at 40 per cent of the value of the estate) is £234,000.

'As you get older, your need for income reduces,' says Leney. You may be able to give more out of your income without lumbering the recipients with a bill.

Lump-sum gifts of capital will be tax-free as long as you survive seven years - and are taxed on a sliding scale if you die within that period.

PricewaterhouseCoopers' Smart warns that even now, giving away assets and income needs to be considered carefully. 'Look at how much you can afford to give away against the need to pay for long-term care.'

Smart says that for people in their seventies, age-related tax allowances become more relevant. Some investments help protect the allowances.

At this stage it may be sensible to start using up savings. The older you are, the more acceptable it is to see capital reduced to meet your needs.

If you want to secure your income for the future, it may be worth looking at purchased life annuities.

Your capital will be exchanged for a lifetime income; before your seventies, rates on annuities are too poor.

Eighties

Leney recommends that you keep your will up to date and make sure that your executors know about any special beneficiaries, such as adult children vulnerable because of illness or disability.

Your investments will need to concentrate on generating income, perhaps at the risk of capital erosion. Returns on annuities continue to improve as you get older.

State pensions at a glance

 The basic pension for a single person this year is £67.50 a week; or £40.40 for a wife (based on husband's NI contribution record) , £107.90 for a married couple (based on husband's contributions) and £135 for a married couple where both have paid full contributions.

 If the basic pension is your only income you may be entitled to income support to provide the Minimum Income Guarantee - £78.45 a week this year. If you have savings of more than £8,000 (£12,000 next year) you won't qualify.

 You may also receive the State Earnings Related Pension (Serps); amounts vary depending on your past earnings. Some people may also receive a Graduated Pension based on contributions on earnings between 1961 and 1975. Average payments work out at £2.50 a week.

fields.headline: Bosses step up cyber snooping
fields.standfirst: Wacky office emails may be a laugh but they could land you in trouble, writes  Nick Gillies
fields.trailText: Wacky office emails may be a laugh but they could land you in trouble, writes Nick Gillies
fields.body:
Email monitoring is the latest way employers have found to infuriate their staff. Catching out the odd bad apple should not be a source of such irritation to workers as it is. 'Little Hitlers'; 'Like 1984 made real: their systems don't work and they arrest the wrong man'; and 'I've seen many cases, but not one caught by email monitoring'. Those are phrases from managers and lawyers. They control the system: if they feel like that, what do its victims feel like?

And there are plenty of victims. A just-published survey by Industrial Relations Services suggests 77 per cent of employers now routinely check to see what websites have been visited by employees. Emails are monitored by 55 per cent of employers. The enhanced powers of MI5 to tap emails may also be suggesting to employers that the Government backs snooping on internet transmissions.

But what are employers monitoring, and how? The two problems are the volume of traffic, and how to write software to monitor it. Peter Norbury, employment specialist at law firm Eversheds, says: 'If people are doing 20 emails a day, how do you monitor it? I haven't had a case brought to me that originated with software monitoring.'

An urban legend in IT circles concerns the programmer who wrote a program which would automatically delete any email containing certain strings of letters. It did not occur to him to specify that there must be a space before and after the strings, and it was several days before his com pany noticed it was unable to communicate with its depot in Scunthorpe.

At this point it's tempting to dismiss email monitoring as a joke. But Phil Ryan, head of Information Security at Peapod UK, says: 'People are very naive about this. Someone from a civil liberties group said she'd undertaken a study of email and it was innocuous. She ought to see what comes over my desk.'

'John', the publisher of an online business news service, says: 'A colleague called me into his office and showed me a picture of a man and a cow in the James Herriot position.'

But it's not all recreational misuse. Norbury acted for a senior executive who was being undermined by emails sent out in her name by a subordinate. 'They didn't turn up on the email monitor because they were in a sort of code. These people know what they are doing. They use innocuous words.' She found out about it because a colleague showed her a circular adding: 'This doesn't sound like you.'

And employers are liable for what is published by their employees. This is why many firms put a disclaimer at the bottom. Email is a written communication, and is subject to the laws of libel.

'It is also worth bearing in mind that emails often contain copyright information,' says David Shepherd, editor of the Industrial Relations Services' Employment Trends bulletin, 'and also that email is as secure as a postcard: stored on a server, and constantly mis-routed'.

There are, clearly, good reasons for employers to restrict what their staff do on the net. But why are they so bad about it? 'Deborah', the marketing manager of a northern firm, recalls: 'Late one Friday a colleague sent me the filthiest joke I've ever seen. I sent him back one word - "fantastic!" Half an hour later I got a message saying, "Your email was not sent because it contained inappropriate language". I got caught! Not the man who sent it!'

This irritation with systems is widespread, and has an interesting origin. Geraldine Bear, a freelance consultant in 'workplace solutions' (setting up everything in a new workplace from desks to the right level of technology), says it relates to the culture. 'If you go to a consultancy like PriceWaterhouse where information is the culture, you find there is complete access. If you go to companies where information is seen as having no value you find a hierarchy of restrictions. I knew one woman who'd been invited to join a working party on new images of the workplace. She wanted to do an internet search for information, but she was told she wasn't senior enough, and then that she couldn't be trusted. It was denied on status, not need. It's gatekeepers again, acting like little Hitlers.'

And life is about to get more confusing. This October the Human Rights Act comes into force, and will presumably stop employers snooping on their employees. 'Presumably', because no one is clear yet what standards will be imposed. But it's clear from users that something which pays some attention to the dignity of workers would be appreciated.
