Emails are monitored by 55 per cent of employers. The enhanced powers of MI5 to tap emails may also be suggesting to employers that the Government backs snooping on internet transmissions. But what are employers monitoring, and how? The two problems are the volume of traffic, and how to write software to monitor it. Peter Norbury, employment specialist at law firm Eversheds, says: 'If people are doing 20 emails a day, how do you monitor it? I haven't had a case brought to me that originated with software monitoring.' An urban legend in IT circles concerns the programmer who wrote a program which would automatically delete any email containing certain strings of letters. It did not occur to him to specify that there must be a space before and after the strings, and it was several days before his com pany noticed it was unable to communicate with its depot in Scunthorpe. At this point it's tempting to dismiss email monitoring as a joke. But Phil Ryan, head of Information Security at Peapod UK, says: 'People are very naive about this. Someone from a civil liberties group said she'd undertaken a study of email and it was innocuous. She ought to see what comes over my desk.' 'John', the publisher of an online business news service, says: 'A colleague called me into his office and showed me a picture of a man and a cow in the James Herriot position.' But it's not all recreational misuse. Norbury acted for a senior executive who was being undermined by emails sent out in her name by a subordinate. 'They didn't turn up on the email monitor because they were in a sort of code. These people know what they are doing. They use innocuous words.' She found out about it because a colleague showed her a circular adding: 'This doesn't sound like you.' And employers are liable for what is published by their employees. This is why many firms put a disclaimer at the bottom. Email is a written communication, and is subject to the laws of libel. 'It is also worth bearing in mind that emails often contain copyright information,' says David Shepherd, editor of the Industrial Relations Services' Employment Trends bulletin, 'and also that email is as secure as a postcard: stored on a server, and constantly mis-routed'. There are, clearly, good reasons for employers to restrict what their staff do on the net. But why are they so bad about it? 'Deborah', the marketing manager of a northern firm, recalls: 'Late one Friday a colleague sent me the filthiest joke I've ever seen. I sent him back one word - "fantastic!" Half an hour later I got a message saying, "Your email was not sent because it contained inappropriate language". I got caught! Not the man who sent it!' This irritation with systems is widespread, and has an interesting origin. Geraldine Bear, a freelance consultant in 'workplace solutions' (setting up everything in a new workplace from desks to the right level of technology), says it relates to the culture. 'If you go to a consultancy like PriceWaterhouse where information is the culture, you find there is complete access. If you go to companies where information is seen as having no value you find a hierarchy of restrictions. I knew one woman who'd been invited to join a working party on new images of the workplace. She wanted to do an internet search for information, but she was told she wasn't senior enough, and then that she couldn't be trusted. It was denied on status, not need. It's gatekeepers again, acting like little Hitlers.' And life is about to get more confusing. This October the Human Rights Act comes into force, and will presumably stop employers snooping on their employees. 'Presumably', because no one is clear yet what standards will be imposed. But it's clear from users that something which pays some attention to the dignity of workers would be appreciated.

webTitle: Lost stars put Jupiter in eclipse

fields.headline: Lost stars put Jupiter in eclipse
fields.standfirst:
Advisers caution against putting new money in the group left reeling by a management walkout, says Jill Insley
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Advisers caution against putting new money in the group left reeling by a management walkout.
fields.body:
Investors in Jupiter Asset Management funds are being advised to stay calm following the sudden departure of Jupiter's founding chairman, John Duffield, and three company directors.

Duffield, a top name in the investment world, established Jupiter as a leading fund management group, with 750,000 customers and more than £13.5 billion under management. Although he was a hands-on chairman, actively involved in all aspects of the business, Jupiter and its German parent Commerzbank say the changes should not have any impact on the group's performance and philosophy.

Steve Glynn, head of retail marketing at Jupiter, says: 'Outside John Duffield himself, none of the individuals has any involvement in the day-to-day running of the fund management processes or have any influence over the investment philosophy. The group's philosophy and style will remain the same.'

Commerzbank has asked Edward Bonham Carter, chief investment officer, and Jonathan Carey, the group finance director, to take on the additional roles of joint chief executives. Together with Alan Miller, head of specialist funds, and Martin Schueller, head of international, they will form an executive committee responsible for day-to-day management of the group.

The upheaval comes just a few weeks after the resignation through ill health of William Littlewood, Jupiter's star manager. Littlewood has run the group's £1.6bn flagship fund for the last 10 years, but its performance has plummeted over the last year. Ranked second out of 82 funds in the equity income sector over five years, and seventh out of 87 over three, Jupiter Income fell to eighty-sixth position out of 95 funds over the last year.

Tony Nutt, who manages the £201m Jupiter High Income fund and £410m Dividend & Growth investment trust, has taken over management of Jupiter Income.

Independent financial advisers agree that investors should wait for the dust to settle before putting any new money into Jupiter funds.

Ian Millward of Chase de Vere Investments in Bath, whose firm has used Jupiter funds extensively over the last three or four years, says: 'We're not recommending that clients put new money into Jupiter funds, but those who have existing investments with the group should not panic.

'They should give us a ring in a week or perhaps a fortnight when the situation at Jupiter has become clearer.'

James Tew, the European head of research at Standard & Poor's Fund Research, an organisation that assesses the performance of fund managers on a quantitative and qualitative basis, says investors should wait two or three months to see how Jupiter settles down. Fund Research is waiting to find out more about the new management structure, the retention of fund managers, and any impact on investment strategy before deciding whether to re-rate Jupiter's funds.

However, Jason Hollands of London independent financial adviser Best Investment, believes that investors should think about moving their money elsewhere: 'Some of the retail fund managers have now had to assume new corporate responsibilities including two we recommend: Edward Bonham-Carter and Alan Millar. This can't be good news for the funds as they find themselves stretched at short notice. Promotions can create resentment from those overlooked. Clearly the atmosphere isn't great at Jupiter and further resignations can't be ruled out.

'Until the dust has settled it would be crazy to put further money with Jupiter. We think this could take a good six months. Our advice to existing investors is to consider a transfer out of Jupiter.'

He suggests Artemis UK Growth and Artemis UK Smaller Companies, funds managed by Apax Asset Management in Edinburgh - a group headed by ex-Jupiter managing director Jamie Campbell. Investors looking for an equity income alternative should consider Newton Income.

webTitle: The age of grey won't fade away

fields.headline: The age of grey won't fade away
fields.standfirst:
The elderly are taking power, says Maria Scott in the last of our guides to finances through the decades. Their rising numbers buy clout in the market - and in politics, too
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The elderly are taking power, says Maria Scott in the last of our guides to finances through the decades. Their rising numbers buy clout in the market - and in politics, too.
fields.body:
If the approach of a sixtieth birthday fills you with apprehension, think again. Life from retirement onwards is increasingly something to look forward to.

For a start, there is more of it. Thirty years ago, a new-born baby boy could not on average expect to live to celebrate his 70th birthday. A girl would live until a few months after her 75th birthday. But life expectancy is lengthening all the time: a man aged 60 now can expect to live until he is 84, and a woman until she is 88.

A hundred years ago the average life expectancy was barely half a century, yet now most of us can look forward to a good deal of life beyond work.

Older people can also expect to wield increasing political and economic clout. By 2030 there will be 35,000 people in Britain aged over 100, and already people of retirement age make up nearly 20 per cent of the population. Increasingly, they have more votes and higher spending power.

Over the past few weeks we have witnessed the acknowledgement by politicians that this group of the population is important in electoral terms. Labour and Conservatives alike are battling over which of them can win the confidence of pensioners, each launching set-piece packages aimed at improving the state deal for the elderly. The recent derisory increase in the basic state pension, of 75p a week, was blamed for Labour losses in the recent council elections.

The centenary birthday of the Queen Mother later this year is likely to focus attention on longevity, and the tributes to Sir John Gielgud, who died at 96 a fortnight ago, highlighted the huge amount of work he did in the second half of his life. For many people, the photographs of the sharp-boned young actor with the aquiline nose will have been unfamiliar. For the movie generation, Sir John's life started with his role as the haughty butler to Dudley Moore's character in the comedy film Arthur .

But life after 60 will bring challenges that were not faced by previous generations, including those who did live into old age. Increasingly we are also a nation of have and have-not pensioners.

For the haves, this is the first time that they have had to think seriously about investment, as lump sum payments from pensions and inheritances have been liberated. As David Walden, a former director of Age concern says: 'It is not difficult to acquire £100,000. Many pensioners of my age find themselves in the position of having that money in the bank.'

This means making complex investment decisions about the best way to protect or increase the capital, while not taking too great a risk with it.

Better-off pensioners can also be vulnerable to incompetent or unscrupulous advisers. The investment market has been cleaned up substantially in the past few years, but you still cannot afford to be complacent about choosing an investment firm to manage your money. Products designed to produce income need to be studied carefully to see how much of that income - especially among the higher paying products - is coming from erosion of your capital, now or in future. Some income-producing products can be among the most complex financial products on the market.

People retiring with personal pensions, or 'money purchase' employers' schemes, will be shocked at the poor value they seem to get from the annuities they are obliged to buy with their funds. But insurers are beginning to improve their annuity products. Pensioners will also find that they may have to deal with more complex tax issues than in the past because of new age-related allowances.

Some financial products , such as private medical insurance and travel cover, become more expensive after 60 because of the increased likelihood of claims. But other types of insurance, such as household cover, can become cheaper because older people take fewer risks with their property and claim less often than younger age groups. Saga, a specialist in products for older people, launched second-home insurance for the over-50s last week, claiming to offer wider cover and lower prices than any rival policy. Adviser and insurance broker Berry Birch & Noble launches a new venture on 10 June called 50 Plus Insurance, offering household cover at discounts of 10 per cent.

Many have-nots, however, find the state benefits system so complex or distasteful that nearly a million of them do not claim for the pension top-ups - through income support - that they are entitled to.

Many older people fear losing their homes to pay for nursing care. Questions about this are among the most frequent put to the charity Age Concern.

Simon Leney, of solicitor and investment manager Cripps Harries Hall, says clients of his in their sixties and seventies, often find retirement more enjoyable than the last decades of work. Living is cheaper, you can take less expensive off-peak holidays, and people in this age group 'are more relaxed about the need to keep up with their peers'.

Leney sees lots of spry, cheery 80-year-olds: getting even older has its consolations, he says. 'When you are in your nineties you can be as rude as you like and behave as outrageously as you like.'

webTitle: Out of the office, but on the case

fields.headline: Out of the office, but on the case
fields.standfirst: Cultural barriers are impeding more effective use of net working, says  Richard Scase
fields.trailText: Cultural barriers are impeding more effective use of net working, says Richard Scase
fields.body:
Internet technologies have the capacity to revolutionise work practices, in terms of both where and how we work.

This is certainly so for the rapidly growing sector of knowledge workers who no longer strictly need to commute daily to their employer's premises.

But the barriers to realising the potential offered by these technologies are not technical but cultural and managerial. Only when these change will it be possible to reduce traffic congestion, urban pollution and the stresses associated with working in large, alienating office environments.

Of course, this is not to say that offices will disappear and allow everyone to work remotely. Many jobs do not allow it. Equally, most people do not want to work from home full-time. The high rate of divorce is a clear indication that home is not heaven for a very large number of men and women.

But what is becoming ever more evident is that as the economy becomes more dependent on knowledge-based services of one sort or another, it is no longer necessary for those who add value through the exercise of their intellectual, professional and expert skills to spend long hours every day working in offices. Britain already has the longest working hours of any country in Europe. In too many companies, personal prestige is gained by being first in the car park in the morning and last out at night.

It is the culture of management which sustains this increasingly redundant work pattern: a long-hours culture which, as data collected at the University of Essex shows, creates ill health and a pattern that restricts the career opportunities of women because of their conflicting domestic demands.

In too many companies, there is a persisting belief that long hours equal employee commitment and that employees are not to be trusted to work unsupervised. In some sectors this trend is becoming stronger. Even in some universities there is now a 'clocking in' culture so that academics are forced to commute to work to switch on their PCs to write their books.

The internet renders all this unnecessary. Work processes can be distributed and managed just as effectively by networking colleagues working remotely as by having them all in the same building. So, too, can quality and quantity of employee output. Internet technologies offer companies the opportunity to break down their bureaucratic, hierarchical structures and operate flexibly and virtually. So why are UK examples so rare? Apart from one or two major companies such as BT, few have introduced strategies for this kind of evolution - in contrast with, for example, firms in Scandinavia. Why is it that British companies are so reluctant to change their working practices?

To bring about changes would require a revolution in the nature of the employment relationship. There has to be a shift from employee conformity to internalised commitment. What does this mean and how can it be achieved?

One of the major forces driving the design of the modern corporation has been attempts by management to impose conformity on their staff. The origins of the factory system and the introduction of assembly-line technology were inspired by this motive. Management and technology dictated the hours, the pace and the quality of work.

This feature of British manufacturing was once its great strength. A compliant labour force permitted goods to be produced competitively and cost-effectively. But the legacy has become dysfunctional. Even if work tasks no longer need to be done in one place, employees in large sectors of the economy are still expected to come in to work in a reliable and predictable manner. In the internet economy, the practice is perpetuated by the prejudice of managers. Why? Because they fear losing control and the onset of organisational anarchy. This is particularly the case among middle managers who are accountable to their bosses for the performance of their staff. But cultures of compliance mean that staff will only do what is expected of them.

They withhold their creativity. And creativity is the source of corporate innovation. The outcome is businesses that lose their competitive advantage because of lack of innovation and poor customer service. What is the corporate response? The kneejerk reaction is to tighten the control procedures so that low trust and conformity are reinforced. This is what is happening today in swathes of the economyfrom universities and traditional professional firms to manufacturing, retailing and service companies. Yet high-performance organisations should be destroying employee conformity and generating internalised commitment. This is how dotcom companies operate.

For employees to be committed, they need to be empowered. For empowerment, they need access to information and to be engaged in decision-making processes. They need to have a stake in the profits of the business. And, instead of corporate management, they require leadership. This was a feature of Richard Branson's companies in the early days as it still is today of Microsoft. These changes become urgent as the British economy becomes more dependent upon internet technology, information services and the creative industries as sources of future employment growth.

The internet offers something more than cost reduc tions through downsizing and flexible home working. It is a creative force, allowing people to work in ways and places where they feel most motivated. This is why writers 'escape' to hideaways to work while rock artists 'get it together in the country'. If corporate managers were intent on making their businesses truly innovative, they would allow their staff to do the same.

But how would most of our bosses respond if told: 'See you in a couple of weeks, I'm off to the sun because I must get that tender document completed by the end of the month'? Until their response is positive neither the internet nor employees will fulfil their potential.

 Richard Scase is the author of Britain in 2010 (Capstone Publishing) and professor of management at the University of Kent at Canterbury.

webTitle: Atherton free from pain in rain

fields.headline: Atherton free from pain in rain
fields.trailText: Michael Atherton must wait a little longer for his 14th test century. Unbeaten on 96 at close of play on Thursday, he spent much of yesterday ambling round the dressing room, with occasional appearances on the rustic balcony, after the second day was rained off.
fields.body:
So Michael Atherton must wait a little longer for his 14th test century. Unbeaten on 96 at close of play on Thursday, he spent much of yesterday ambling round the dressing room, with occasional appearances on the rustic balcony.

If he looked wistful, then bet your life he was not remotely anxious: Atherton has been there before and done it, never more so than at Trent Bridge where he has scored four pre vious test centuries and, with one more, will equal Denis Compton's ground record.

Good memories and the psychological boost they bring are as essential a part of the sportsman's armoury as good technique. Atherton's career would seem to be entering a new phase, not just post captaincy but post back trauma.

Two winters ago in Australia he was in trouble consistently because his immobility left him unable to sway away from well directed bouncers and he was forced to take them on instead. If not pain free, he is unencumbered now, which is all he asks. So the confidence, and with it the scores, are beginning to return.

After the wettest April on record and the soggiest of Mays, June has not got off to the brightest of starts. Rain began to fall mid-morning and washed in at intervals through the day. Just once the numerous covers were hoovered clear of water and removed from the ground.

Play, it was announced, would begin at 20 minutes to two, as it had on the first day. But the rain returned, the covers went back on and, despite the tireless efforts of the groundstaff, who sweep the water away, watch it return and then go through the same process again without batting an eyelid, the ground remained sodden and unplayable.

The umpires Merv Kitchen and Dave Orchard made their final inspection at five o'clock, consulted both captains and at 5.25pm play was abandoned. The 6,000 spectators who had remained optimistically in place throughout the day will get their money back.

They may have been unlucky not to get any play, for the last total wash-out on this ground was 21 tests ago, on August 14, 1967, the fourth day of England's match with Pakistan. In the 21 previous to that, since the first played on the ground against Australia in 1930, there were nine blank days. The weather must be getting better.
fields.bodyText: So Michael Atherton must wait a little longer for his 14th test century. Unbeaten on 96 at close of play on Thursday, he spent much of yesterday ambling round the dressing room, with occasional appearances on the rustic balcony. If he looked wistful, then bet your life he was not remotely anxious: Atherton has been there before and done it, never more so than at Trent Bridge where he has scored four pre vious test centuries and, with one more, will equal Denis Compton's ground record. Good memories and the psychological boost they bring are as essential a part of the sportsman's armoury as good technique. Atherton's career would seem to be entering a new phase, not just post captaincy but post back trauma. Two winters ago in Australia he was in trouble consistently because his immobility left him unable to sway away from well directed bouncers and he was forced to take them on instead. If not pain free, he is unencumbered now, which is all he asks. So the confidence, and with it the scores, are beginning to return. After the wettest April on record and the soggiest of Mays, June has not got off to the brightest of starts. Rain began to fall mid-morning and washed in at intervals through the day. Just once the numerous covers were hoovered clear of water and removed from the ground. Play, it was announced, would begin at 20 minutes to two, as it had on the first day. But the rain returned, the covers went back on and, despite the tireless efforts of the groundstaff, who sweep the water away, watch it return and then go through the same process again without batting an eyelid, the ground remained sodden and unplayable. The umpires Merv Kitchen and Dave Orchard made their final inspection at five o'clock, consulted both captains and at 5.25pm play was abandoned. The 6,000 spectators who had remained optimistically in place throughout the day will get their money back. They may have been unlucky not to get any play, for the last total wash-out on this ground was 21 tests ago, on August 14, 1967, the fourth day of England's match with Pakistan. In the 21 previous to that, since the first played on the ground against Australia in 1930, there were nine blank days. The weather must be getting better.

webTitle: Wasim Akram loses his TV job

fields.headline: Wasim Akram loses his TV job
fields.trailText: Wasim Akram has been dropped from Channel 4's commentary team for this summer's West Indies test series because of the damage to his reputation caused by the Pakistan judicial inquiry into match-rigging.
fields.body:
Wasim Akram has been dropped from Channel 4's commentary team for this summer's West Indies test series because of the damage to his reputation caused by the Pakistan judicial inquiry into match-rigging.

Although Wasim avoided a life ban, the Qayyum Report concluded that his reputation had been "sullied" and that the evidence had "cast doubts upon his integrity".

Justice Malik Mohammad Qayyum further ordered that he should not captain Pakistan again, fined him £3,500 and recommended that his financial affairs should be further investigated.

Scrutiny of the report soon persuaded Channel 4 that its credibility would be damaged by the retention of Wasim as a commentator while the match-fixing furore dominates cricket's agenda.

Once Pakistan's final test against West Indies in Antigua had been concluded - with, intriguingly, the best bowling figures of Wasim's test career - Wasim was persuaded that his only course of action was to stand down.

"With further investigations ongoing into match-fixing allegations in a number of test-playing countries, the issue is set to dominate the cricketing agenda throughout the summer," a Channel 4 statement said last night.

"Channel 4 does not wish to compromise its ability to cover fully and fairly an issue of such fundamental importance to the game, nor does the channel wish to distract attention from this summer's West Indies series.

"After consultations with Channel 4, Wasim Akram has decided that it would be inappropriate to be part of the commentary team this summer and has asked to be released from his contract in order to concentrate on his playing career."

He will spend the summer playing for Aston Unity in the Birmingham League.

Qayyum imposed a life ban on Salim Malik and levied fines on eight players as the match-rigging scandal finally claimed its first high-profile victims.

Crucial to the judgment upon Wasim was the withdrawal of a sworn affidavit by Ata-ur-Rehman, who had accused him of involvement in a bookmaker's scam during a one-day international at Christchurch in 1994.

Channel 4, meanwhile, is hoping to outbid Sky TV in the race for exclusive use of technology that could eventually be used by international umpires to determine lbw decisions.

Hawk-Eye, which can track a cricket ball to within 5mm in under two seconds, is part of a new wave of technological inventions that could leave such recent innovations as Channel 4's red zone and Sky's blue zone redundant.

The England and Wales Cricket Board is monitoring extensive trials this summer of Hawk-Eye, which has been developed by Dr Paul Hawkins, of the Siemens-owned Roke Manor Research.

Hawkins, who has played minor counties cricket for Buckinghamshire, insists that Hawk-Eye, an offshoot of medical and military research, need not undermine the umpires' role but could equip them with the rapid information they need to retain their on-field authority.

"The advantage of this invention is that the decision need not be made by a television umpire," he said. "The big problem about technological aids is the endless delays. In this case, the on-field umpire could be furnished almost immediately with vital information - such as where the ball pitched and whether it struck the pad in line with the stumps - by either a pager or a television screen."

webTitle: Tudor puts his hand up for a rise

fields.headline: Tudor puts his hand up for a rise
fields.standfirst: Surrey 333  Hampshire 207-8
fields.trailText: Surrey 333 Hampshire 207-8
fields.body:
As the ball soared over the square-leg boundary, Alex Tudor stood stock still in his follow-through, freezing the shot as if posing for the paparazzi. "One of these days Surrey are going to realise I'm wasted at No10," the gesture exclaimed, defying contradiction.

In propelling his side to respectability yesterday morning, Tudor collected an unbeaten 64 off 68 balls with strokes as authentic (mostly) as they were thrilling.

It swelled his season's average to 142 - he has been dismissed but once - and confirmed that his match-winning 99 not out for England at Edgbaston last July was as freakish as a snowstorm in Alaska. His omission from the list of contractees remains, as Groucho Marx once put it, a travesty of a travesty.

Inevitably, following the rain earlier in the week, the pitch resembled an over-cooked souffle, bad news for those anticipating a masterclass in artful dodgery. Saqlain Mushtaq waited 20 overs for his first wicket and Shane Warne managed only one in 30 before winding up the home innings with his sole delivery yesterday. Warne, who craves firm tracks, has yet to encounter one, which at least partly explains his modest returns.

Another factor, of course, has been the Hampshire batting order, for whom brittle would be a compliment, implying as it does a vestige of strength. Subtract Giles White's resilient, occasionally decorative 96 and Adrian Aymes's cussed 44, and the rest of the top seven here aggregated 25 - par for the course.

Crucial as it was in averting the follow-on, the fifth-wicket pair's stand of 78 was only Hampshire's fourth half-century stand this term, two of them for the ninth wicket, none of which has managed to complete the full Monty. Even when you have one of Wisden's five cricketers of the century at your beck and call, it helps to give him a few runs to play with.

Preying on shaky psyches and mislaid techniques was that evergreen toiler Martin Bicknell, whose two test outings represent arguably the greatest miscarriage of justice since Gloucestershire's Charlie Parker ended his career with 3,278 first-class victims and one token cap. The excuse in his case was a refusal to tug forelock; there have been no such alibis for Bicknell, though he may well curse the day Mrs Fraser gave birth to little Angus.

All three of his wickets here, each caught by slips or keeper, were a product of exemplary line and length leavened with a soupcon of outswing, in contrast to the recipe initially followed by Tudor, whose appreciable pace was spoilt by too many four-balls. Having Derek Kenway missed twice off successive balls by Mark Butcher - both stiff asks - did little for his humour, though revenge was swift as Ally Brown swooped at third slip.

As the light faded Tudor returned to have Aymes poking to gully, then ripped an inswinger through Warne, enhancing the champions' prospects of a belated first win. The west London Sobers? Don't rule it out.

webTitle: Satan stalks the catering and ground staffs

fields.headline: Satan stalks the catering and ground staffs
fields.trailText: Dave Podmore is not singing in the rain.
fields.body:
Obviously, I've got nothing but sympathy for Athers being stuck on 96 for 24 hours. Dave Podmore is no stranger to the nervous 90s, be it runs conceded in a bowling spell or miles per hour through a speed trap. But the way I see it, as a cricketer you only spend about 1% of your time trying to hit the ball, throw it, catch it, whatever - so there's absolutely no point getting yourself steamed up about it.

Having said that, it would be wrong of me not to accept my share of the blame for the delay in Athers getting to his ton. Like the former South African skipper, it's time to make a full and frank confession. Hansie Cronje fingered Satan for bringing about his downfall and causing him to take his eyes off Jesus.

Pod blames the Thai fishcakes in the Trent Bridge media centre. They were disappearing so fast I had to jump up from my seat behind the bowler's arm, causing Athers to take his eyes off Guy Whittall. After which Iron Mike went back into his shell and has stayed there ever since.

Apart from that, I've had a great time with the press boys, who, to be honest, I haven't always had much time for in the past. Having learned a bit about their lifestyle - eg blowing up a Marigold washing-up glove to look like a cow's udder, then putting it on your head just like county cricketers do - I realise I may have been a bit narrow-minded about the media.

To see one of them fill out a blank restaurant bill for 40 people is to appreciate the true craftsmanship of the wordsmith.

And the press get messed about just as much as the players by the powers that be. In view of the prevailing conditions yesterday, a few of us decided to spend a sporting afternoon 100 yards up the river at Nottingham races. No sooner had we piled into the cabs than an announcement comes over the PA that play would be starting at 1.40.

So it's as you were and back upstairs to the media centre, only to find we've missed the free lasagne, apart from the black bits in the corner of the tin. And there's Bumble Lloyd smacking his chops when he was supposed to be out in the signing caravan shifting piles of his book.

A decision on play isn't made till well after the last race, leaving us nothing to do with the time but watch Countdown and compare the tunes on our mobiles. Sometimes I wonder if these ground authorities care about sport at all - if you ask me Satan's got at them too.

But as I say, I could see myself quite happily donning the laminated media pass after I retire. I have to face the fact that I've only got another half-dozen odd playing seasons left, and won't always be driving a car with "Dave Podmore" in big red italic letters running down the sides and a fluorescent bat on the bonnet.

And it's got to be better than working as a Trent Bridge groundsman. They had the moppers going at 8 o'clock yesterday morning, and when they got all the Scrumpy Jack up from the hospitality suite carpets it was time to start on the outfield.

Still I'll say this for the rain. It kept the place clear of all those hordes of kids in their kwik cricket T-shirts who rush around with bats and balls getting under everybody's feet. Bloody little hooligans - can't they go and find a couple of lamp posts?

fields.headline: Round-up
fields.trailText: Essex, languishing at the wrong end of the Second Division, will be praying for blue skies over Ilford when they wake this morning on the verge of their first Championship win of the summer.
fields.body:
Essex, languishing at the wrong end of the Second Division, will be praying for blue skies over Ilford when they wake this morning on the verge of their first Championship win of the summer.

They enter the final day needing 56 for victory over Northamptonshire with six wickets left. Facing a target of 226, they closed last night at 170 for four with Darren Robinson unbeaten on 70.

Essex had been 47 for three after a superb spell from Devon Malcolm, who took all three for nine runs in seven overs. But Robinson then shared a 119 stand with his captain Ronnie Irani, who contributed his second half-century of the match.

Earlier Ricky Anderson, who took 50 wickets in his debut season last year, followed up his six wickets in the first innings with five for 77 in the second as the visitors, 203 for four overnight, were bowled out for 327.

Sussex, who have not won since beating Essex in the Benson and Hedges Cup at Chelmsford five weeks ago, are on the verge of victory at Hove, where Glamorgan faltered in their second innings after an opening stand of 80 between Matthew Elliott and Steve James.

Facing a deficit of 278, Matthew Maynard's men ended the third day on 242 for six. The former Middlesex spinner Umer Rashid took two wickets after earlier completing his second successive half-century.

The joint leaders Warwickshire endured a dismal, rain-shortened day at Edgbaston. The team with the most batting bonus points in the country ended on 104 for nine and did not even have to face Shoaib Akhtar, missing from the Nottinghamshire attack with a side strain. David Millns took three wickets.

For Middlesex the erstwhile England hopeful Richard Johnson led the way as Gloucestershire were bowled out for 242 at Lord's, setting the hosts 298 for victory. Johnson took four wickets to add to five in the first innings. Middlesex are 39 without loss.

Only 18 overs were possible on the third day of Yorkshire's First Division game against Leicestershire at Headingley, which now looks condemned to a draw.

The sides meet again in the National League tomorrow, when Michael Vaughan hopes to make his comeback for Yorkshire. His England team-mate Craig White, however, has a knee injury.

There was no play at Old Trafford but bad news for Lancashire whose opening bowler Peter Martin will not play again for at least six weeks after it was confirmed that he sustained a fractured and dislocated right thumb against Derbyshire .

Pakistan went some way towards banishing uncomfortable memories of defeat by Bangladesh in last year's World Cup by thrashing international cricket's minnows to the tune of 233 runs in their opening Asia Cup match in Dhaka yesterday.

Pakistan made 320 for three and then shot out Bangladesh for 87. Imran Nazir and Yousuf Youhana both scored 80 and Inzamam-ul-Haq an unbeaten 75.

Sri Lanka, the holders and probable finalists after two wins, had their cricket board resign en masse for the second time in three months yesterday over differences with the sports minister S B Dissanayake.

fields.headline: Ealham escapes chain gang
fields.standfirst: Kent 177 & 237-9 dec Durham 81 & 44-2
fields.trailText: Kent 177 & 237-9 dec Durham 81 & 44-2
fields.body:
There was an exultant jangling of civic chains to accompany Kent's third-day resurgence. At the mid-afternoon count, 17 of the county's mayors had arrived in their finery to applaud in regional allegiance as they ate their strawberries and cream. They had outnumbered by one the number of wickets that fell during the sodden stupor of the previous day.

The ground staff had miraculously made play possible for this coveted festival match but everyone privately agreed it could never really be a first-class track after being underwater. And as the ball stayed cruelly low, the lbws multiplied alarmingly - with David Constant narrowly ahead of Ray Julian.

By yesterday, however, Kent had worked a transformation. They were even able to declare on 237 for nine, leaving Durham a daunting total of 334.

The overdue policy for Kent was to attack, though it might mean living with danger. Alan Wells went for a bold shot or two. He lofted over extra cover, first bounce to the boundary; next ball, impatient to repeat his indulgence, he changed his mind too late and lobbed a catch to mid-off. By lunch Kent were 123 for seven: Mark Ealham and Matthew Fleming knew what was required. Between them they changed the course of the contest.

With intelligent batting they bucked the game's trends with a stand of 95 before the Kent captain poked an unlikely return catch to Nicky Phillips, seemingly surprised by some bounce. That was perhaps the most decisive partnership, though Min Patel's with Ealham was almost as valuable. In a sparky innings, Patel pulled Phillips for the match's only six.

Ealham remained in charge for just over four hours, relishing the chance to show those sturdy square-cuts while doing his best to wrest the initiative from tiring bowlers. Durham's hopes were receding by the over. They looked deficient of effective bowling options. The slow bowlers found a little turn; things were by now easier at the crease.

Durham's response was not encouraging. Martin Saggers, a better bowler than in his Durham days, had Jon Lewis leg before. Kent were crowding the bat for Patel and David Fulton tumbled at silly-point to dismiss Jimmy Daley. It is hard to see what, apart from the rain, can save Durham.

webTitle: Anti-climax as Taxi picks up Lara

fields.headline: Anti-climax as Taxi picks up Lara
fields.standfirst: West Indians 164 Worcestershire 4-0
fields.trailText: West Indians 164 Worcestershire 4-0
fields.body:
There should be an ironic award for bowlers who spoil everything; the Eric Hollies Trophy, perhaps. Yesterday it would have been won by Kabir Ali. As WG Grace might have said, they came to watch Brian Lara bat, not Kabir bowl. But Lara batted for just 10 minutes and faced only four balls while scoring a single run.

It was not even a good ball. Kabir, just 19 from Birmingham, fired one down the legside and Lara, following it round, fine-glanced it to the wicketkeeper Steven Rhodes and walked before the umpire could give his decision.

The West Indies tour of England was only 17 minutes old but already spectators were looking at their watches and wondering what to do next. Then it rained. But those who remained enjoyed seeing Worcestershire get the better of their jet-lagged opponents, bowling them out in 62.2 overs.

It is five months since Lara played test cricket and four months since he played any cricket at all. There is little time for him to find his famous form before the first test starts in Birmingham on June 15. After Worcester they play Glamorgan at Cardiff and Zimbabwe at Arundel.

Kabir, known as "Kabi" and inevitably "Taxi", must think this bowling business is rather easy. He made his Worcestershire debut at the end of last season, took wickets and is playing here in place of a batsman, Graeme Hick.

He said last night: "I was well pleased with that dismissal. It was a dream to get the big man out himself. I had a feeling in my mind that I might just do it. It will be in my head for a long time."

Kabir opened the bowling and with his second ball bowled the acting captain Sherwin Campbell, who shouldered arms. The other test opener, Adrian Griffith, was then lbw to Duncan Catterall in the fourth over, and Lara must have thought he was batting for Warwickshire again as he hurried down the pavilion steps. He played just one scoring shot, a glanced single.

When Lara fell the West Indians were 15 for three. But in view of the fact that they were still rubbing the sleep from their eyes, having flown in from Antigua in the early hours of Wednesday morning and after a hard series against Pakistan, it was a wonder they managed to find their way to the crease. The conditions, dark and damp - the middle two hours were lost to rain - with a soft pitch, were hardly familiar to their younger players, either.

At the end of the day the most successful bowler was not Kabir but Catterall, who returned figures of four for 50, including a burst of three in 20 balls near the end.

The most dogged resistance came from Chris Gayle (38) and Mahendra Nagamootoo (37), but the most attractive strokes were from the young Guyana right-hander Ramnaresh Sarwan (27), who definitely looks a star of the future.

At the end of the day the most successful bowler was not Kabir but Catterall, who returned figures of four for 50, including a burst of three in 20 balls near the end. The most dogged resistance came from Chris Gayle (38) and Mahendra Nagamootoo (37), but the most attractive strokes were from the young Guyana right-hander Ramnaresh Sarwan (27), who definitely looks a star of the future.

webTitle: Germany's bond is back but Bierhoff remains on the rocks

fields.headline: Germany's bond is back but Bierhoff remains on the rocks
fields.trailText: German striker Olivier Bierhoff is slated much the same way Alan Shearer was at the start of last season. Only now it's just a week before Euro 2000.
fields.body:
Somewhere in Europe there's a multi-million-pound striker and national team captain struggling to justify his automatic selection for Euro 2000. Sound familiar? Thought so. Only for Alan Shearer of a few months back read Oliver Bierhoff this morning.

Once the source of hope for Germany's future, Bierhoff is now seen by many as a figure who belongs in the past. His last goal for his country came 610 minutes ago against Northern Ireland last September. A poll released on Thursday on the German website Sport1.de showed that the Milan player is regarded by the public as the weakest of the five strikers in Germany's squad.

The national coach Erich Ribbeck seems to disagree, though Bierhoff still has good reason to hope history repeats itself when he plays against the Czech Republic tonight.

At Wembley four years ago he scored twice against the Czechs to win Euro 96. This evening's match in Nuremberg may only be a friendly but Bierhoff can sense the importance. "I need a goal," he said, "no matter what it looks like."

Bierhoff scored 11 times in Serie A last season and was subjected to fierce criticism at times. Such attacks have been commonplace throughout his career, continuing even as his 20 goals led Milan to the 1999 scudetto . His admirers in Germany point out that the service he receives in the national side has been far from ideal.

Germany's recent form has certainly been uninspired but there was an optimistic feel at their training camp in Mallorca last week. Real Mallorca were beaten 4-0 in a warm-up match and the internal squabbling seemed to be gone.

"The players have got clear heads again," said Ribbeck, who has ignored calls for his resignation. The Bayern Munich midfielder Mehmet Scholl confirmed the change in mood as preparations for the games against Portugal, Romania and England continued.

"I'm much more optimistic for the European Championship than I was before the training camp," he said. "The atmosphere is even nearly better than before Euro 96. We had our doubts then, too."

The Czech Republic, who won all 10 of their qualifying games, should offer a good guide to Germany's health. The Czechs learned yesterday that Holland, their opening opponents at Euro 2000, expect Edgar Davids to have recovered from an operation on an ingrowing toenail in time for their June 11 encounter.

Roger Moore, a man who as James Bond became used to dealing with more serious problems than ingrowing toenails, is expected to be among a packed crowd in Ljubljana today for Slovenia's final warm-up match against Saudi Arabia.

The Slovenian FA has agreed to donate a percentage of the gate receipts to the Slovenian National Committee for Unicef and Moore will be there in his capacity as a Unicef ambassador. The game is Slovenia's first since the end of April, when they lost 3-2 in France after going 2-0 ahead.

Spain face a tough test in Sweden today. Their confident-sounding coach Jose Antonio Camacho has also organised a friendly in Luxembourg on Wednesday and asked his squad to relax ahead of the main event.

"It is important for the players now to show the same enjoyment that they have in training this past week," he said. "They've done very well here and I'm not worried about anything."

Norway, Spain's opening opponents in Rotterdam on June 13, take on Italy this afternoon hoping for a psychological boost. "If we perform well the players will gain confidence," said their coach Nils Johan Semb. "That is important to bring to the first game."

More than £100m is expected to be staked on Euro 2000 with the United Kingdom betting industry, beating by about £20m the amount placed during France 98.

webTitle: Diamonds for trumps and Macca dummy

fields.headline: Diamonds for trumps and Macca dummy
fields.trailText: Lacey says teams win international tournaments because of the quality of their players rather than the way they play. It is the players who make successful systems, not the other way round.
fields.body:
The Maltese falcon turned out to be a fake, much to the chagrin of Peter Lorre and Sidney Greenstreet, not to mention Humphrey Bogart's sardonic amusement. Similarly Kevin Keegan is about to find out whether his England team are made of gold or lead.

As he relaxes briefly in the Mediterranean sun Keegan knows he is a week away from discovering whether he is likely to become the nation's hero or, to use Bogey's idiom, just another fall guy, someone to give to the pops.

Already the mass media are amassing, critical knives newly honed, freshly minted metaphors poised for action. Keegan cannot be lampooned as a turnip should England fail; that is Graham Taylor's copyright. A tulip, perhaps.

No wonder the England coach seemed edgy when he announced his squad of 22 for Euro 2000 late on Wednesday. "You can be doom merchants," he chided the assembled hacks, "which some of you are very, very good at."

If anything, the majority of the reports on England's 2-0 victory over Ukraine earlier that evening erred on the side of optimism. Even those who had been straining at the leash to get in the first bite at the England coach's ankles were wagging their tails.

Certainly Keegan's switch from 4-4-2 to playing three at the back with five in midfield produced greater attacking fluency compared to the more rigid performance in last Saturday's 1-1 draw with Brazil. But it did not settle the arguments about what pattern England should adopt against Portugal on Monday week.

Systems will always be contentious but are only part of the argument. Teams win international tournaments because of the quality of their players rather than the way they play. It is the players who make successful systems, not the other way round.

England did not win the World Cup in 1966 just because Alf Ramsey did away with conventional wingers and employed Bobby Charlton in a central role behind the front runners. In fact, for their opening two games of that tournament Ramsey had first John Connelly on the left wing, then Terry Paine on the right.

Ramsey's genius lay in a readiness to adapt which, by the final against West Germany, found Alan Ball and Martin Peters working the flanks and tucking in to defend as wing-halves, Charlton prepared to subjugate his own attacking instincts so long as Franz Beckenbauer kept him company, and Geoff Hurst winning lasting fame after nearly missing the World Cup because he had shown poor control on a bumpy pitch in Copenhagen shortly before it began.

Would that Keegan could enjoy some of Ramsey's options. On England's only previous visit to Malta, for a European Championship qualifier in 1971, Colin Harvey, then part of an outstanding midfield threesome at Everton, won what was to be his only international cap. Howard Kendall, who with Ball completed the trio, never played for England.

Ball was capped 72 times and it seems reasonable to assume the modern equivalents of Harvey and Kendall would win more than one cap between them. At least in Paul Scholes Keegan has a midfielder with something of all three about him, in addition to the goalscoring instincts of David Platt and the drive of Bryan Robson.

Perhaps Keegan is deeper than most would imagine. Maybe his sudden enthusiasm for making Steve McManaman the centre of the universe is a cunning ploy to divert the attention away from Scholes.

Certainly it looked that way at Wembley on Wednesday night. McManaman's influence was as peripheral as it will always be when he is tethered to the left wing, while Scholes caused the Ukrainians far more problems through the middle.

However Keegan decides to play it in Euro 2000, the success of his team will depend in part on the amount of freedom Scholes is given. Against Brazil he was told not to get on his bike but play a holding role. Against Ukraine he worked in tandem with Robbie Fowler and the effect was electric.

Then there is the catalyst, Nick Barmby, who on Wednesday replaced Scholes for the last 17 minutes and immediately provided the element of surprise which has been so rare in England's football since Michael Owen sped past Argentina's defenders in St Etienne two years ago.

One school of thought argues that Keegan should consider playing Owen alone up front with Scholes, Fowler or Barmby tucking in behind. Certainly the England coach will have to reorganise his attack once Alan Shearer has retired from internationals after Euro 2000.

Or it may be before then. Against Brazil and Ukraine the England captain was keen and alert, playing an essential part in the three goals scored by England in those games. When it comes to alternative strikers, however, Keegan is better off than most of his Euro 2000 rivals and has already made it clear he would be prepared to drop Shearer if necessary.

Equally Shearer has made few bones about his preference for Emile Heskey as a partner up front. After Heskey's galumphing, artless intervention on Wednesday that is a sobering thought. So is the image of high balls being pumped towards the pair against defences able to cope with this sort of thing in their sleep. Either way there must be more to England's game than Beckham's crosses.

A personal feeling is that Keegan should start with Shearer and Owen and use Scholes in close support as an attacking midfielder, while Paul Ince drops anchor in front of a back four. In other words a diamond which need not be for ever but might turn out to be Scholes's best friend.

fields.headline: Barmby overtakes on the left
fields.standfirst: Everton forward can claim England's problem position
fields.trailText: David Lacey reckons the Everton forward can claim England's problem position.
fields.body:
The European Championship is unlikely to be won on a playing field in Malta but for a number of England players today's match in the National Stadium at Ta' Qali may have a significance lasting a little longer than this evening's flight home.

For Nick Barmby, starting an England match for the first time in four years, there will be the chance to make a late challenge for the problematical position on the left. David Beckham will have an opportunity to maintain the rich vein of form he showed against Brazil and Ukraine.

Kevin Phillips, Alan Shearer's fourth partner in three games, will hope to begin reproducing at international level the prolific scoring habits that have already survived promotion from First Division to Premiership. As for Shearer himself, the England captain received a public reminder from Kevin Keegan yesterday that there was more to leading an attack than just putting the ball into the net.

It is even clearer that the impact Barmby made as a substitute in the 2-0 victory over Ukraine at Wembley on Wednesday, when he replaced Paul Scholes with just over 15 minutes remaining, has given the Everton player an opportunity of being in the starting line-up against Portugal in Eindhoven on Monday week.

"Nick Barmby thoroughly deserves the chance he will get against Malta," Keegan said. "The players know where the opportunities lie. There is still the odd place where a player will have a chance to stake a claim and one of these is on the left side."

The England coach believes that reverting to a 4-4-2 formation, which will have Dennis Wise and Paul Scholes in central midfield as well as the back line that played against Brazil, will give Barmby the ideal setting to continue his late dash for selection in Euro 2000.

"He picked up the pace of the game from the first second. He looked like he was a player on a mission," said Keegan.

Beckham has nothing to prove to Keegan except perhaps a wider expression of the talents he can bring to the European Championship. He is an automatic choice, a stark contrast to the situation he was in during the 1998 World Cup under Glenn Hoddle.

The then England coach left Beckham out of the opening match against Tunisia. When Beckham did appear it was as a substitute for the injured Paul Ince against Romania and two games later his World Cup ended with the red card against Argentina.

Now Beckham is playing as well as he has ever done for his country and will go into a major tournament knowing that Keegan has no doubts about his ability to influence matches. "But it's still more a case of working for the team and making sure we win," Beckham explained yesterday.

Keegan used Beckham as a right wing-back but this did not impede his role as an attacker. "Playing wing-back is hard work because I spend a lot of the time getting back," Beckham admitted, "yet I still went forward a lot and got in quite a few crosses. I'm now confident in any formation."

Beckham has warmed to Keegan's player-friendly style and is not alone. "There's a definite im provement in the team spirit compared to 1998," he reflected. "There is more togetherness now between the players and the management.

"This comes from the manager. It shows around the camp, on the training pitch and in the games. It also shows the respect the players have got for the manager.

Player-friendly

"He keeps things simple and you don't have to complicate it with the players we've got in the squad. That's the big thing the manager gets across.

"We've got three hard games in the first stage but if we perform well on the day we've got a very good chance."

Beckham's fitness and form are crucial to England's hopes of making significant progress in Euro 2000. As much goes for Shearer although the nagging thought persists that for the English lion of Euro 96 this could turn out to be one championship too many.

Shearer looked sharp against Brazil and Ukraine and made important contributions to each of the goals scored by England. Yet Keegan felt it necessary yesterday to remind his captain of the need to remember the full duties of office.

"It's always nice to score goals," Keegan said, "but I think it's more important that Alan leads the line well. I said to him after the first half against Ukraine that he could have held the ball up better. Both he and Robbie Fowler could have done so. There are still things Alan Shearer needs to do, basic things, before we start talking about scoring goals."

That said, a combination of two of the Premiership's most potent strikers, with Fowler due to come on after half-time, should bring England some goals worth talking about this afternoon. Not that the Maltese are the pushovers they used to be.

England will be asked to break down a tight-marking sweeper system that recent visiting teams have found difficult to penetrate. After Northern Ireland played here in March Neil Lennon complained that Malta "kicked us all over the pitch".

It is clear that a match arranged to mark the centenary of the Malta FA, and one which England hope will secure the Maltese vote on the Fifa executive when the hosts for the 2006 World Cup are decided next month, will be a little harder than kissing babies. But it could also help lessen the chance of England's European Championship ambitions being still-born.

Malta (1-3-3-1-2) : Barry; Buttigieg; Spiteri, Dimech, Chetcuti; Turner, Brincat, Carabott; Busutil; Mifsud, Nwoko.

fields.headline: Cheers and fears
fields.standfirst: On the eve of Euro 2000,  Donald McRae heads for the places where history will be made - and finds the Dutch in raptures, the Belgians in despair.
fields.trailText: On the eve of Euro 2000, Donald McRae heads for the places where history will be made - and finds the Dutch in raptures, the Belgians in despair.
fields.body:
Grand Place, Brussels

A week tonight, on the edge of a Belgian square the size of a football pitch, Paul-David Hollander will reach for his first batch of 5,000 plastic glasses and start praying. As the new co-owner of a bar called Petit Paon, the Little Peacock, Hollander's prayer will be laced with hope and fear.

At exactly 8.45pm local time, just as darkness spreads across the city centre, the beery hum will deepen into a roar as Euro 2000 finally begins in Brussels. Yet, for Hollander, there is personal relief that next Saturday's opening match between Belgium and Sweden will mark a low-key start compared to the fevered nights ahead.

"We can prepare ourselves for good business and maybe just a little trouble," the 24-year-old suggests. "We'll get a lot of Swedish fans in the square - and maybe even some Belgians. But it will be much busier when the other countries arrive. And, of course, the English are different. They drink the biggest jugs of beer."

Once England have played Portugal in Eindhoven on June 12, their travelling army will descend on Brussels. Grand Place, fringed by huge outdoor bars and side-streets crammed with restaurants, will mark the drinking point for thousands of fans who use Brussels as a base during England's two remaining group matches in the small town of Charleroi - a 40-minute train journey away.

German supporters will also move into Brussels a week on Tuesday, ready for their potentially decisive clash against England two weeks tonight. They will be followed by Turkish fans. The stark ingredients for violence are obvious.

Even when it is empty, it is not difficult to imagine Grand Place as a battleground. It is likely that a mass outbreak of fighting will reel down the adjoining lanes - such as rue Chair et Pain. Apart from Hollander's little bar, the rest of that pretty if touristy street is lined with 35 restaurants.

Competition is fierce. It is impossible to walk down rue Chair et Pain and escape the smiling enticement of each new greeter. He points to his own eye-catching display of seafood and fruit on crushed ice and says "hello" with such seductive determination you fear the words "big boy" creeping up in breathless pursuit of your custom.

Until they start smashing through the exotic pyramids of food, a mildly inter esting exchange might unfold between the hoolie-mobs of Euro 2000 and those desperately grinning doormen. Yet a far more disturbing image sees gangs of men cracking each other's heads open against the loose cobble-stoned paving.

"But maybe," Hollander nods hopefully, "the fans will stay happy and we will make money." Hollander's commercial ambitions spring from his memory of the night three months ago when Grand Place turned orange. "I'd just bought this bar when Belgium played Holland. The square outside was full of Dutch fans. So many of them came here after the match that I had to keep my hand on the beer pump until four in the morning. Maybe we will have more great nights like that . . ."

Stade Communal, Charleroi

The stadium rises suddenly out of the rainy mist. Its steep red banks climb at such a sharp angle that, staring upwards, a temporary third tier looks more like a vertical wall of seats. The dizzying sight is deepened by the fact that the Stade Communal is hemmed in on three sides by different apartment blocks.

Only a narrow road seems to have prevented the constructors from setting the newly redeveloped ground flush against the wall of each bricked building. This is not some kind of compact and soaring homage to the study of claustrophobia and vertigo in Belgium. The truth is more basic.

There is not enough land on this particular site to build a conventional stadium with a 30,000 capacity for Euro 2000. Without the option of spreading outwards and rising at a more gradual gradient, the designers have aimed straight upwards and pulled off a dubious trick in squeezing 22,000 backless bucket seats into such a constricted space. They have heightened the danger by adding a top layer of 8,000 seats which will be removed after England's final group match against Romania.

The view from row 21 of level three provides an undeniably panoramic view. Yet if anyone is injured in this matchstick-like upper tier, mountain-rescue teams will have to be brought in - and hopefully not those crack units from the Belgian lowlands. When they recently conducted an emergency drill in an empty stadium, it took 20 minutes for a mock-victim to be rescued. How they would cope when confronted with a terrified throng in the event of a stadium disaster is more unsettling.

The threat to those in the lowest sections is equally severe. Spectators in the front row will be less than a foot from the perimeter fencing. The fatal lessons of Hillsborough have been ignored. There will be no escape on to the pitch for anyone pushed up against the two-metre high metal barrier by an avalanche of falling bodies.

Raymond Hens, the cigar-chomping head of stadium security, dismisses such anxiety. His permanent position as the director of prisons in Charleroi may explain his bluff tough-guy persona. Yet he appears strangely naive when addressing the recent history of footballing tragedy. "I don't see us having any problem here," Hens argues. "We tested the stadium in an international match like this and everything was OK."

The fact that Hens should use a midweek friendly between Belgium and Portugal as some kind of security yardstick for a European Championship match between England and Germany would be laughable if it were not so hazardous. "I understand English fans," Hens protests. "They live for football matches against Germany. It is lovely. Yes, sometimes there is also trouble. But we have German fans on one side and English on the other. Up on the third level there will only be neutrals. So we have no problems there. Kevin Keegan says our ground is like the Stadium of Light."

The Stade Communal is more like Euro 2000's definitive Stadium of Darkness - a point which has been made repeatedly by both Belgian politicians and policemen. Yet many people in Charleroi endorse Uefa's blunt refusal to move the match to Brussels. Jean-Yves Roquet is one of the more interesting voices. An unmissable 24-stone optician who runs his own business from the centre of town, Roquet is both a footballing sophisticate and man so friendly he only has to hear a few words of English to offer an impromptu tour of his beloved Charleroi.

"A lot of people fear Euro 2000," Roquet concedes. "But then people like me are so proud the biggest group match is taking place in our town. It's very exciting." Roquet managed to buy 40 tickets for various Euro 2000 matches on the internet - including half a dozen for both England games in Charleroi.

While emphatic that he and his friends will use at least four tickets for June 17, he admits that, like many others, he will sell his spare pair to English or German fans. The idea of a "neutral zone" is shattered by such an inevitable revelation.

As a ticket-holder for the tragic European Cup final at Heysel in 1985, Roquet stresses the need to make a "responsible" black-market sale. "My Heysel ticket is still at home," he says. "It's a reminder. My father died the day before that match and so I did not go. But we cannot forget. That's why this tournament is so important to Belgian football. We cannot afford another disaster."

In an attempt to end our day in Charleroi on a more upbeat note, Roquet sweeps through town in search of Philippe Albert. It does not takes long to find Charleroi's favourite son in a bar not far from the Stade Communal. "Newcastle always reminded me of a bigger version of Charleroi," Albert suggests. "This is an industrial town but it is so friendly. I always tell everyone it is a fascinating place."

Within minutes there is sudden confirmation that Charleroi is indeed more than a boring little Belgian town. A local resident, infuriated by Belgium's 60% tax rate, has just set fire to his car. He then storms into the tax office and shoots three people, holding a further five hostage. As Charleroi swarms with machine-gun wielding policemen, a full-scale siege seems as good a time as any to head for Holland.

"Charleroi is not normally this exciting," its enormous optician murmured. "I just hope it's more boring when England and Germany arrive."

Travelling through Belgium and Holland by train, the flatlands blur convincingly. For once, Euro 2000's marketing slogan of Football Without Frontiers seems more apt than vacuous. Yet the perennial threat of hooliganism forced a debate this week in both countries over the possible reintroduction of border controls.

For now, however, the most distinct boundary is one of mood. If Belgium seems drizzly and apprehensive in its approach to Euro 2000, Holland is ablaze with colourful exuberance. Even if the adjoining towns initially look remarkably similar, each stop at a new station displays an increasing flash of orange and the gathering chatter in Dutch of a likely victory.

Once you pass Arnhem and then meander into the countryside near Hoenderloo, the quiet returns. The tranquility is deepest in the woods and secluded grounds of the hotel where the Dutch squad will set up camp once they return from Zurich on Monday. The expectations of a nation still stand out brightly in the surrounding silence.

"Oranje success" is spelt out in a gigantic flower-bed. "These are the first words the Dutch team will see when they arrive," Arlette Gilbert smiles serenely. As the sales manager of the Golden Tulip as well as the main organiser of training camp facilities, Gilbert exudes the sleek charm and confidence which seems to characterise the official Dutch promotion of Euro 2000.

"We are very hopeful of 'orange success'," she murmurs, "but it is also important that we create the right kind of environment for the team. One of my responsibilities is to control the daily media gatherings. As we move towards the final we expect around 450 reporters a day. We will look after the press, but the team comes first."

The Golden Tulip specialises in pampering professional footballers - with Barcelona being one of many leading European clubs to regularly use the complex as a training base. Yet there is more than pure business at work in the meticulous year of planning which, Gilbert says, "has taken into account every single aspect of our next four weeks. We've pulled out all stops for the team in orange."

Gilbert conducts a mini-tour of the chalet-style house "where Frank Rijkaard will live for the next month and plan his campaign", as well as the players' individual rooms, each with "its own patio and English garden". There is also the perfect training pitch, with a surface superior to that which England and Germany will play on in Charleroi, a volleyball court and the deep blue swimming pool - once you've escaped the gym, the treatment room and the video-analysis lounge.

The only problem for a national footballing psyche which traditionally thrives on training camp bust-ups would appear to be the myriad of boardrooms offering ample opportunity for rival groups to plot the next twist in an enduring power struggle. Even this hugely entertaining Dutch quirk has, at least for now, been subsumed in a seemingly effortless drive towards "oranje success".

Oranjeloo (Orange Town)

Who needs Edgar Davids or Clarence Seedorf to go on strike when Holland have already given us the surreal suburban genius of Oranjeloo?

"We are only a very small community of 1,700 people in Hoenderloo," explains Jan Wolffensperger, the nominal head of the village, "and our idea is a simple one. There can be no greater honour than to have the Dutch team based just outside Hoenderloo. We met with Co Adriaanse who has just been appointed the new coach of Ajax, and he suggested we change our name to Oranjeloo.

"So throughout Euro 2000 the town will only be referred to as Oranjeloo. At the same time we have decided to turn the town orange. Come, I will show you . . ."

To jump on an orange tandem in the company of big Jan, who has slipped on his Euro 2000 clogs specially for the occasion, and cycle through Oranjeloo on a summer afternoon is to disappear into an incredible world. If David Lynch had discovered Dutch football first he might have made, rather than Blue Velvet, a deeply strange film called Orange Town.

As we drift beneath fluttering orange bunting and past houses draped in orange decorations, smiling families step out into their sunlit gardens to wave and shout "Hup, hup, Holland!"

Wim Barten and his wife Riek calmly welcome us into a home which has been converted into the Jaap Stam Bar. Their front garden may have been taken over by a flowered shrine to Euro 2000 but, next to the front door, a life-sized cardboard cut-out of Dennis Bergkamp serving drinks behind Jaap's bar is more eye-catching. Bottles of Dennis Beer glint on the counter.

Around the corner, in a garden belonging to Sandra Renata, the July 2 final of Euro 2000 is already underway - as Holland play France in Rotterdam. The pitch is 12ft by 8ft and all 22 players are three inches tall. Miniature sponsor boards from businesses around the village line the edge of the field while, at night, the foot-high floodlights illuminate a final set to last an entire month.

Even at the level of Subutteo in Oranjeloo, you can pick out the individual stars of Euro 2000 - and it has be said that the Dutch look as if they can pull off a motionless swagger at will. Nicolas Anelka, in contrast, is even more miserable in Orange Town than he was in either north London or Madrid. Thierry Henry is stuck in the mud. Emmanuel Petit has lost his pony-tail. Fabien Barthez, just in from Manchester, is scratching his head at the sight of the Dutch on permanent attack.

A couple of times a day the people of Oranjeloo move the Dutch players around - just to prove that Holland are a far more fluid outfit than the statuesque world cup holders.

There is only one cloud in Oranjeloo. Partick Kluivert is missing. The chief suspect is Sandra Renata's black Labrador - Joy. They have not quite printed the shock headline of Dog Eats Kluivert in fear of an even more distressing truth: Joy Buries Kluivert Alive.

Yet, as Jan Wolffensperger insists, "Kluivert or no Kluivert, we will still win this game! "There is sudden urgency on the touchline. Even the man-sized dummy of Frank Rijkaard seems to twitch in his suit and tie as Sandra drops the ball at Marc Overmars's feet.

"Bergkamp is waiting to score the winning goal in Rotterdam," Jan croons, "and here comes the centre . . ." But here comes Joy, swooping in on Overmars like Tony Adams in disguise. And there goes Overmars, swallowed up by the jaws of fate. Joy for Joy; despair for Holland.

Except, a week before Euro 2000, it's still possible to give a black dog a red card in Oranjeloo. Overmars is returned safely to the left wing, the ball at his feet, and the longest championship in history awaits another winning Euro 2000 goal from Dennis Bergkamp. After, all in Orange Town, far more than Brussels, they're ready and drooling.
