On a more facetious note, it has been said that there are only two credible degree classes, a first and a third - anything in between smacks of mediocrity. Though perhaps this isn't something to suggest to your interviewer. For those with genuine ability and determination to recover, a third can be a positive longer term experience causing only temporary difficulties. There are graduates in finance, management, law and elsewhere who have not allowed their chequered academic careers to impede their progress. People like Auden, Barnaby and Spedding serve to demonstrate that a graduate with a third class degree is not necessarily a third class graduate. If you don't remember anything else.... A poor degree result need only be a short-term setback provided you have the resilience, stamina and suitable strategy to claw your way back. It may be a long haul, but remember that it's you who will decide how far you can go, not your degree result, and don't let anyone else tell you otherwise.

webTitle: Summer time and the leaving is easy if you go to the show

fields.headline: Summer time and the leaving is easy if you go to the show
fields.standfirst: It's a fair way to find your first job
fields.trailText: It's a fair way to find your first job
fields.body:
Let's start with the philosophical bit. Choice is good but you can have too much of it. If you're picking a mobile and don't make the right choice, tough, but if you're picking a career the wrong choice is total meltdown time.

So where do you begin? If you aren't one of those dreary types who's got everything lined up already, time gets short as summer rolls in and you want a salary cheque by September.

Yes, you can use the internet for a job search, and careers experts say it's worth doing as a back stop, but it's all a bit hit and miss zapping round the websites. How will you ever know what you've missed ?

And, say the experts, you should take a look through job ads in the press - specialist publications for the career you fancy are the obvious place to look so you know who's who and what they have to offer.

But in the end, graduate fairs still come out best as a job hunting ground, because, like sex, both parties know what they are there for. If you have spent the last 12 months studying for your degree, with time out for those little things called exams, you are likely to be one of the thousands of people who are having to panic now and get themselves along to a summer jobs fair.

These started back in the 60s as a mopping up operation for graduates who failed during the milk round, but now they are a major source of job opportunities.

"Employers come back year after year," says Anne-Marie Martin, director of the University of London's Careers Service. "They spend a lot of money so they must find it worthwhile. And it's worthwhile from a student's point of view because they get jobs."

London's is the last of the summer fairs on June 28 and 29 and it's a big bash with 168 exhibitors. Anyone with a degree can go. It's at the Business Design centre in Islington and the organisers say that at least 12,000 people come through the doors each year.

"Those who are well prepared and have researched the companies and are clued up and make their pitch will do very well at fairs," says Martin. "But there is always that 1% who haven't done anything at all and just wander in with no idea of what the employer wants."

What you want the employer to want is you. They bring along their personnel - or human resource -team to see you in person and give you a chance to meet them.

Martin adds: "Some employers treat fairs as a primary interview and some students won't make it past first base."

Those who do will be invited for a more formal interview at the company's premises and everything goes from there. There are urban myths about companies who make job offers on the spot, but this doesn't happen in reality, says Manchester University's employment liaison officer Jan Hewitt.

Manchester's summer graduate fair is another two-day event,on June 21 and 22, held in the Armitage Centre at the Firs Athletic ground. It claims to have ousted London for top slot with 180 exhibitors this year. Unlike London, Manchester makes it a condition of agreement with employers that they do have jobs to offer when they sign up.

Birmingham is another biggie on June 16 and 17 at the NEC. Free coach transport from a number of UK cities is available.

Some exhibitors use fairs to raise their own profiles and hand out information, some use fairs as a vetting procedure while others treat it as a first interview and expect you to fill out an application form and do all that sort of stuff.

London has some add-on attractions to take the grief out of the process. There are seminars and presentations, experts to clock your CV and give you advice as well as cybercafes for you to check out company websites. Manchester will have experts to help with your application forms and interview techniques.

"The advantage of a fair is that you have a chance to talk to a potential employer and to sell yourself," says Martin. Even better, if you aren't that sure about what career you want, graduate fairs can give you ideas.

"There's a serendipity element to fairs," adds Martin. "You might be in a long queue for one company and wander off to something that looks a bit interesting and find it suits you better than the first one. Graduate fairs are like a series of shop windows."

So you might come back with something you didn't set out for in the first place. The experts tell you to put job stereotypes to the back of your mind. You don't know until you find out. IT is a growth area, but for a lot of people it's just one long groan. Nobody wants to be a nerd. It's only when you talk to IT companies that you will discover that they desperately need creative types for all those sexy new websites. And then there's new media as well.

The sort of companies you can expect to find at graduate fairs range from household names to complete unknowns - to you that is. At Manchester you can meet people from the Carphone Warehouse, Andersen Consulting, the government's Defence Evaluation and Research Agency, McDonald's, The Guardian (of course) John Lewis, Morgan Stanley Dean Whitter, Rolls Royce, Scottish Power and the Royal Marines among many many more.

London has some of the same big names plus the Metropolitan Police, ASDA, Barclaycard,Waitrose, Pizza Express, Tesco, Shell International, the Foreign and Commonwealth Office, Alternative Network Ltd and Dow Jones International Ltd.

Whatever you are going for, it's also time to smarten up, get that suit on, take the ring out of your eyebrow (you can keep the one through your navel) and strut your stuff. By July somebody will be paying you for your stunning personality and megawatt brain.

 Birmingham: 0800 856 2492 and www.gradjobs.co.uk
 Manchester: 0161 275 2828 and www.netwise.ac.uk
 London: 0800 252 183 and www.careers.lon/ac/uk

fields.headline: Cool companies: No 34 Equant
fields.trailText: Don't bother to look Equant up in the dictionary; it will not be there. And unless you are one of the chosen few with an Oxbridge degree you are unlikely to know that a quant is the long pole used to propel a boat on a river. However, anyone who gets on to the career path at this firm is well on the road to becoming a quant, too - as in a highly paid computer specialist.
fields.body:
Don't bother to look Equant up in the dictionary; it will not be there. And unless you are one of the chosen few with an Oxbridge degree you are unlikely to know that a quant is the long pole used to propel a boat on a river. However, anyone who gets on to the career path at this firm is well on the road to becoming a quant, too - as in a highly paid computer specialist.

Equant - or as it is known in the trade, the best kept secret in telecommunications - is a leading global supplier of 'mission-critical' deep technology communications solutions. It has a presence in more than 220 countries and deploys network integration and application skills using data, voice and internet technology. It also provides network design and integration services, equipment installation, maintenance and support services and software development.

The convergence between computing, broadcasting and telecommunications is generating demand for new services which integrate the domains of the desktop, the local area network and the wide area network. Equant's research and development division investigates the changing trends and technological advances presented to the telecommunications industry.

Atlanta-based Equant's origins date back to 1949, when Sita was formed by major airline companies from all over the globe to provide communications and data processing services to the air transport industry. The acronym loosely stands for "state-of-the-art infotech in aviation". A not-for-profit co-operative, Sita developed the network principally to meet the needs of its member organisations.

In the late 80s, increasing deregulation prompted Sita to evaluate opportunities to develop the network's commercial potential and over the years, Equant was born and floated on the New York and Paris Stock Exchanges.

Sticking to its roots, the firm recently helped Lufthansa (left), which was keen to take advantage of the emerging electronic distribution channels. The German airline chose Equant to provide its multimedia server, one of the most advanced distribution solutions of its kind used by any airline.

Equant maintains a strong commitment to working practice that is team-oriented, fast-paced and fosters entrepreneurial spirit in its workforce. It particularly welcomes graduate trainees with competence in any foreign language. They are encouraged to participate in all stages of the software development, from requirement analysis, design, coding and testing to documentation and end user training. This, says Equant, gives them well-rounded skills which lead to early responsibility and the choice of project management, technical consultancy or sales and marketing career paths.

 Send applications to Human Resources, EAS, Weyside Park, Godalming, Surrey GU7 1XE.

webTitle: The personal touch will help you launch your career

fields.headline: The personal touch will help you launch your career
fields.standfirst: Resist the temptation to mass produce covering letters
fields.trailText: Resist the temptation to mass produce covering letters
fields.body:
If you're just rolling out of your finals, ready to begin your job hunt armed with nothing more than a CV and a generic cover letter addressed to 'Personnel' or 'To whom it may concern', you've got to ask yourself one question: "Do I feel lucky?" Well, do you?

PC faxing and email capabilities have made bulk employment queries too tempting. So if your answer is "Yes" or "With my qualifications, I don't need luck," it might benefit you to know that most of these personnel people - who may (or may not) be concerned about your job query - don't take too kindly to generic job application letters.

When they have to read 300 applications for one job, the last thing they want to see is a badly photocopied one. They want to see the most specific information you can give them.

If you're still not convinced that you need a separate cover letter for every company you wish to apply to, ask yourself another question: Do you actually read with interest or even open the junk mail you receive, which is addressed to 'The resident' or 'The occupant'?

Now that you're convinced, the following ten steps should help you prepare a strong and targeted cover letter, guaranteed to let recruiting managers know you're sincere and focused.

1) Copy the letterhead used on your CV at the top of the letter. Sometimes multiple page submissions get separated. This will ensure that if your CV is misplaced, the employer will have backup information regarding your address and telephone number.

2) Address the letter to a specific person, and include their title. Finding a personal contact in the company is crucial to your chances of success - a person to write to rather than just addressing the letter to the employment department. Generic job letters suggest you have very little interest in the organisation or its needs.

Some personnel officers receive up to 10,000 CVs in a year, so the least you can do is take the time to call the company and find out what their names is. Personnel managers admit that sometimes it's best to send a copy of your CV and cover letter to the manager of the position you are interested in. It's likely this person will have some say, if not the final say regarding whether you are considered, and ultimately hired.

3) List the title of the job and how you learned about it in the introductory paragraph. If you were referred by someone, use their name. If you don't know anything about the positions the company has to offer, the best thing you can do is ask to learn something about them. You'll come across a lot more positively than those people simply asking for jobs.

4) Be positive. "Put yourself in the position of the recruiter who receives hundreds of speculative letters every week," says Simon Howard, author of Creating a successful CV (Dorling Kindersley). "Try opening your letter with a positive statement. In order to get the reader's attention, it can be a good ploy to start with 'you' or 'your'. For example, 'Your company has an impressive reputation in the field of...' or 'You are one of a very few employers...'. The letter needs to describe the key aspects of your CV succintly and say why the recruiter should be interested in you. You must make a clear proposition and leave the reader in no doubt of your career objective."

5) In the body paragraphs, let the person know you've researched their company and use bullet statements to prove you have what it takes to do the specific job they have available.

6) Write in your own words. Make sure that your letter sounds like you, not like something out of a book. Your covering letter should be an accurate reflection of your personality. Employers are looking for knowledge, enthusiasm, and focus.

7) Keep it short. Keep it simple and clean - not cluttered. Use no more than seven lines, and preferably five or fewer, per paragraph. Vary the sentence length. None of the sentences should be very long, but you don't want a staccato stream of very short sentences. One page is the maximum for letters.

8) Close with a courteous 'thank you', but include a statement which leaves you open for a follow-up by phone.

9) If you can't find any information about the company, the next best thing to do is ask for it. Requesting an in-house newsletter or annual report shows sincerity and interest.

10) Proofread your letter for errors and tone before you send it. Job applicants are frequently deselected because of spelling, typing or grammatical mistakes.

webTitle: How to... join the family business

fields.headline: How to... join the family business
fields.standfirst: Success is all relative
fields.trailText: Success is all relative
fields.body:
To join or not to join, that is the first question. The second is when to join. What am I referring to? Joining the family business. It seems like a good idea - working with people you know, assured career path (hopefully), no need to worry about careers and applying for jobs and, more importantly, keeping the family stake in the business. And for those who decide not to join, at least they will always have the option.

But is it better to join the family business straight from university? After all, if you're sure that's what you want, why waste time working elsewhere? Or is it better to get work experience in the big wide world first?

Working in her father's manufacturing company during the school holidays and at weekends convinced Satbir Billen that she did not want to go into the family business. "I enjoyed working there but I saw the hard work that was needed, the long, unsociable hours, the setbacks and the stress. I also saw the good things - but I had no illusions," she explains.

After completing her degree in biotechnology, Satbir worked as a purification scientist, followed by a couple of years in public relations. Satbir's views about working in the family business have changed since working in PR.

"I realised that to be successful in your career, even if you're working for somebody else, you still have to work the long hours and deal with stress. That's when I started to re-think my views about working for yourself: at least my father has reaped the rewards from being his own boss," she adds.

"My brother, Jatinder Singh Bhaura, joined the family business straight from university but he decided to leave after two and a half years. He felt that because it was our father's company, he would never get the recognition he deserved and his successes would not be recognised as his own. He went to work for another company for a year.

"However, he has now realised that working for himself is what he wants to do and he has started his own company. When my father retires, he will see if he can try and run both companies," she says. So according to Satbir, working outside the family business helps you decide whether or not it's right for you.

Ben Williams, an Edinburgh-based chartered corporate psychologist, agrees that it's rarely a good idea for graduates to go straight from university into the family business. He says that graduates who do "may get resentment from other people in the business who feel that they don't have the experience or ability for the jobs that they are doing".

Mr Williams advises graduates to work in the outside world before joining the family business so that they can "learn how to fail and make mistakes". "If graduates entering family businesses bring outside work experience, they have something to offer other than the fact that they are related to the owner," he explains.

This is borne out by Simon Lees Jones, a surveyor, who joined the family business, JW Lees & Co, a brewery, after working elsewhere for several years. "The family business is run by my father and uncle and they have a policy that before any family member joins the business they have to have worked outside the business for at least five years. This is so that we can make our own mistakes and have something valuable to offer the business," he says.

Simon is now property director of the family business, his brother is sales and marketing director and his two cousins also work in the business. "When I joined the family business I had to do every job including the menial ones like cleaning and delivery. This gave me a good all-round knowledge of the business and helped me to get to know everyone. The workers now respect our dedication to the business," he explains. Simon and the second generation of Lees Jones are leading the expansion and development of the family business.

If you don't remember anything else....

1. Get some work experience in the outside world before joining the family business.

2. When you join the family business - don't take advantage of your situation or expect any favours.

3. Do every job in the business to give you a good overall understanding of it.

4. Remember that you may have to work harder than employees who are not related, to prove yourself.

5. If there are family disputes, try not to bring them into the workplace.

 The organisation Family Enterprise produces reports, books and runs seminars for family businesses. Their website is at www.familyenterprise.org or you can call them on 0141 331 3125.

Simon is now property director of the family business, his brother is sales and marketing director and his two cousins also work in the business. "When I joined the family business I had to do every job including the menial ones like cleaning and delivery. This gave me a good all-round knowledge of the business and helped me to get to know everyone. The workers now respect our dedication to the business," he explains. Simon and the second generation of Lees Jones are leading the expansion and development of the family business. If you don't remember anything else.... 1. Get some work experience in the outside world before joining the family business. 2. When you join the family business - don't take advantage of your situation or expect any favours. 3. Do every job in the business to give you a good overall understanding of it. 4. Remember that you may have to work harder than employees who are not related, to prove yourself. 5. If there are family disputes, try not to bring them into the workplace.  The organisation Family Enterprise produces reports, books and runs seminars for family businesses. Their website is at www.familyenterprise.org or you can call them on 0141 331 3125.

webTitle: Open all hours: how job shops help students and employers

fields.headline: Open all hours: how job shops help students and employers
fields.standfirst: New service bypasses milk round
fields.trailText: New service bypasses milk round
fields.body:
Wanted - bright, literate, numerate young people of graduate quality willing to work either part-time or seasonally in a wide variety of demanding and responsible positions. Could lead to a full-time contract."

This in essence is the attraction of job shops to both students and employers. Run by many but not yet all universities, this relatively new service offers students flexible hours, an income, and CV-boosting work experience, while employers gain access to a highly intelligent, well-motivated temporary workforce.

"Job shops are academia's realistic response to the fact that students do work," says Andrew Jackson, who manages the new student employment service at City University in London. "The job shop allows the university to limit the number of hours advertised to 15 per week during term-time, to make sure employers are paying minimum wage, and to match the opportunities with the sort of work registered students have asked for."

To employers however, one of the great advantages of using a job shop is the fact that it allows them to trial students for future full-time employment, bypassing the considerable costs of the milk-round altogether.

"Trying out students on a look-see basis is right at the heart of our recruitment policy," says Donald Clark, chief executive of Epic Group, a company involved in e-government, e-business and e-learning. "In the last two years, out of 12 students given placements, five have gone on to work with us full-time."

"The primary aim of student employment services is to help students to graduate," says John Sander, head of the student employment service at Sussex University, one of the country's oldest job shops. "This is done by providing them both with some income and with commercial experience which ideally should be career-related. However, there can be no doubt that this service is a new way for students and employers to get together to consider post-university opportunities."

"Employers are definitely aware of the advantage of coming to us to get to students earlier," agrees Olwen Duncan, manager of the student employment service at Edinburgh University, who points to the fact that because job shops often deal with first-year students, small to medium-sized employers are reaching them virtually straight from school. And it is this size of firm that has most to gain, because they allow them to scoop off some of the cream before it gets sucked up by the giants of the milk-round.

Jean Rainy-Brown is private client director of Mackay, Stewart and Brown, a small firm of independent financial advisors based in Edinburgh. "We advertise at the university for someone to work over the summer," she says, "essentially to cover other staff holidays. But we also have the advantage of knowing that we are advertising to a pool of high achievers.

"If they like us and we like them, that could extend into part-time work in the following year, and possibly a permanent position after graduation. We have found two full-time advisers that way and it has saved us time and money over other recruitment methods."

The fact that smaller companies have a lot to gain from using job shops as a trial for new employees does not mean that blue chip names ignore them. They do, and a large student population may be instrumental in their decision to relocate offices. However, this type of highly branded organisation is often shy about admitting to using students in anything but administrative roles because the public still has a negative perception of student employees.

But the point at which student employment services may show their greatest potential is in the new software businesses which, in their early days, do not have the financial strength to commit to full-time contracts, but which still require a highly educated workforce.

"In the first year of trading it offered us great flexibility," says Alberto Schiannini of Babel, a new company which checks the foreign language versions of market- leading interactive entertainment products. "Students are educated, literate and in the same age group as the consumer, but they want limited hours or very seasonal work. This combination is unbeatable in our fast-moving environment. I would never consider finding anyone through the milk-round, it's too slow."

One of the biggest problems for job shops is that those seeking vacation work in one university's catchment area are often students who attend other universities. And as job shops are funded by individual universities, there is no financial incentive to help a competitor's students find work. This is a problem that employers are also keen to find a solution to.

"The biggest difficulty is the fact that an employer like us has to deal with individual universities and sometimes even individual faculties," says David Clark of Epic Group. "We are trying to persuade the government that what is needed is a nationwide website."

If this were to prove feasible, then job shops may yet change the face of graduate recruitment completely.

fields.headline: Chelsea bring £15m striker into fold
fields.standfirst: Football Unlimited
fields.trailText: After the bitter disappointment of being left out of Holland's squad for Euro 2000, Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink had reason to celebrate yesterday when he completed a record-equalling £15m move from Atletico Madrid to Chelsea.
fields.body:
After the bitter disappointment of being left out of Holland's squad for Euro 2000, Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink had reason to celebrate yesterday when he completed a record-equalling £15m move from Atletico Madrid to Chelsea.

The deal makes him the joint most expensive player bought by a British club, matching the fee Newcastle spent on Alan Shearer in 1996. Given that Hasselbaink cost half as much again as Chris Sutton, the fans will expect a corresponding return of Premiership goals, leaving him needing one and a half.

After signing a five-year contract, the 28-year-old reflected that the move had come a year late. "When I left Leeds I had an offer from Chelsea," he said. "I wanted to come here but Leeds didn't want to let me go to another English club, so I had to leave to Atletico."

Better late than never, Gianluca Vialli hopes. His attempts to win the title have faltered to a large degree because of his failure to find a 20-goal striker. Tore Andre Flo and Gus Poyet were the joint top-scorers last season with 10; Gianfranco Zola led the way the year before with 13.

The manager hopes Hasselbaink, who scored 16 and 18 Premiership goals in his two seasons at Elland Road, will succeed where Sutton failed. The Dutchman scored 24 league goals for relegated Atletico - half the team's total - and more than 30 in all.

His arrival on a deal believed to be worth £40,000 a week after tax is likely to trigger the departure of at least one striker from Stamford Bridge.

Zola has said he hopes Chelsea will give him "the opportunity to leave" and is considering an offer to return to Napoli. That may hinge on whether the club win promotion. They are second in Serie B with two games left.

George Weah is unlikely to stay after his spell on loan from Milan, and Sutton hardly looks to have a future at the club. Even Flo acknowledged: "It is about time that Chelsea sell one striker. We are now too many."

The Norwegian claims he is being pursued by the Spanish champions Deportivo La Coruna but insisted: "As long as Chelsea want to keep me I would like to stay."

Jamie Redknapp faces yet more surgery on the problematic knee that ruled him out of the England reckoning for Euro 2000, and yesterday he was informed that it may be six months before he is restored to full health.

Leeds are considering a £2.3m bid from Manchester City for Alf Inge Haaland.

Celtic's director of football Kenny Dalglish has maintained that he will not be leaving the club following the appointment of Martin O'Neill as manager. "That's my spell as interim manager over. I'll be moving back to my original position," Dalglish said. "As for Martin O'Neill, I wish everything that he wishes for himself."

Crystal Palace, landlords to Charlton and Wimbledon in recent years, may find themselves tenants next season having opened negotiations with Gillingham over a possible ground share at Priestfield.

Talks between Jerry Lim, who is fronting a consortium attempting to buy the First Division club, and the former Palace chairman Ron Noades, whose company owns the freehold to Selhurst Park, will continue next week.

Lim is pushing for a new 10-year licence or a re-negotiation of the lease as the current one prohibits an outside company building on the ground, quashing his plans to transform Palace's home of 76 years into a leisure complex.

"The new owners will obviously not want to develop the stadium just for the benefit of their landlords," said the Palace chairman Peter Morley. "If the negotiations break down then the club needs a fall-back position and that would be to ground share."

Darlington will have a point deducted next season if their fans re-offend after the attack on Shrewsbury's goalkeeper Paul Edwards at Feethams in April. The decision came after the club pleaded guilty, at a Football Association crowd control commission, to a charge of failing to control their spectators.

Fifa's president Sepp Blatter has scrapped his plan to stage the World Cup every two years. "I have put the idea into a safe and I have lost the combination to that safe," he said. "Let it stay there in peace."

fields.headline: Levant, London
fields.standfirst: Levant attracts all the movers and shakers, but is it any good? By Matthew Fort
fields.trailText: Levant attracts all the movers and shakers, but is it any good? By Matthew Fort
fields.body:
Address: Levant, London
Something was most definitely up. The place was awash with critics, chefs, distinguished food writers and chroniclers of the social scene. Why, even I was in the company of Blossom, the distinguished restaurant commentator of our sister newspaper, The Observer, his wife, my wife, and two immensely informed eaters from America. I began to wonder if there was anyone dining in Levant that night who was what you might call a non-interested party. We all sat at our tables, wondering how the others were getting on, and how they'd express their experience in print.

The last time I had been to Levant, it hadn't been Levant at all, but Oceana, a restaurant of some ambition, style and substance that never quite hacked it in the public affections. That was then. Levant is now. The basement area has been modified, simplified and made immeasurably sophisticated and elegant. The London passion for things North African has moved on from the colour, swirl and dash of the carpet stalls of the souk to something more reminiscent of the austere beauty of the desert itself.

Food, too, has moved on (if those are the words), to what is claimed is a kind of modified Middle Eastern cooking - the Levant is defined generally as "the eastern Mediterranean and its shores" (Chambers). The chef is definitely British. Having said that, the breads, pickles, moutabal, taramasalata, muhammra and the hummus, which were delivered to our table by a young man of rare charm, could have been distinctly and deliciously straight from a table in Jerusalem.

From there on in it would seem the level of direct inspiration seemed to fluctuate. Clearly, the intention is not to produce "authentic" food of the Levant, which is just as well, as I am not in a position to comment learnedly on matters of authenticity. My grilled sardines, for example, could as well have been multi-purpose Mediterranean as from the coast between Tizi Ouzou and Beirut. They were as large as small herrings and notably well-cooked, but not remotely nationalised by any one culinary culture.

Being six around the table, we gave the menu a pretty good run-through - some squid, coated, the menu said, in almonds, a nice conceit I thought; a ravioli lookalike called manti stuffed with chard and feta; braised spiced lamb with potatoes and chickpeas; roasted sea bass with red pepper and walnut sauce; a poussin ditto; roast kid; lamb kebab; spinach salad; rocket salad; and then, in the pudding department baklava, lemon semolina cake, almond-stuffed dates with clotted cream, and poached dried fruits with vanilla ice cream.

I'd better say right off that it was a fairly disappointing experience, all told. It wasn't that the food was bad, or even badly cooked, but it lacked oomph, it lacked zip and zest, and, above all, it lacked spice. Spice, it seems to me, lies at the heart of Middle Eastern cooking: the dextrous use of turmeric, cumin, cinnamon, saffron, coriander, chilli and all the rest are, in many cases, what distinguishes the Lebanese version of a dish from the Syrian, or the Syrian from the Moroccan. Of the pointed, piquant use of spice there was no trace as far as I was concerned. It may be said, with some fairness, that I was beginning to show the symptoms of the Mother of All Colds, but I patiently questioned my fellows at the table, all of whom have more sensitive palates than I anyway, and they were equally baffled on the spice front.

I have no particular beef with the reinvention of the cooking of whatever country, just so long as the finished article cries "Eat me!" in a commanding fashion. The food at Levant did not. For instance, my stew of lamb and chickpeas was a pleasant enough proto-peasant stew, but without distinguishing characteristics. The sea bream and the grilled poussin came in for a similar low level of enthusiasm. The manti were decent enough, but the pasta envelope was of the heavy-duty variety.

While some dishes could have done with a touch more of the warm south, others could have done with less. If you are going to make a virtue of non-authenticity, then you have the excuse to trim a little fat off the roast kid. Obviously, if you are beside a wadi in the desert such refinements of butchery may get overlooked. You're not going to waste a good chunk of nice, wholesome fat under those circumstances. In Marylebone, London, it is another matter, however. The amount of fat was excessive. (To be fair, the majestic Jonathan Meades, dining at another table, embraced the notion of fat wholeheartedly. The kid had been fatty, he agreed, "but it was very good fat".) And the blanched spinach salad with pine kernels was simply inedible - bitter, claggy and beastly.

The puddings were greeted with a little more praise, and so they should be, but they weren't enough in themselves to restore the sense of well-being that good dining should generate. This sense of blighted hope was intensified by a bill that reached £293, but it turned out that that was all our own fault. Two bottles of imperious Chteau Musar at £28.50 each, two bottles of an impish Cassis at £26.00 each, plus another £35 on sundry other tipples before and during meant that booze accounted for roughly half the bill - £144.50 (and before you get huffy about the sum spent on that front, I'd remind you that we were entertaining eminent guests). So that left £148.86 on food, or a shade under £25 a head, which isn't nearly as bad as the original total suggests. Indeed, by London standards, it would be more than reasonable if only the food had been as assured and as soothing as the service and decor.

fields.headline: Cabinet split over spending tactics
fields.standfirst:
Chancellor Brown accused of breaking review agreement by playing big number politics
New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: A cabinet battle has broken out over tactics in the coming spending review with some ministers furious that their colleagues are briefing that public services are to receive a multibillion boost.
fields.body:
A cabinet battle has broken out over tactics in the coming spending review with some ministers furious that their colleagues are briefing that public services are to receive a multibillion boost.

They have been exasperated by headlines this week proclaiming that overall spending will rise by £40bn in the third year, while capital spending on transport could rise by as much as £140bn over 10 years.

Some ministers believe the public is now cynical about government promises of extra cash and privately warned yesterday that disillusionment with Labour will only deepen if ministers raise expectations of huge increases in next month's three-year spending review. They say that previous tactics of accumulating annual rises in order to arrive at an artificially boosted total had backfired.

"We are now doing the exact opposite of what we agreed we would do, which was to talk about money for investment," said one minister.

Anger is being directed at the chancellor Gordon Brown with critics claiming he is playing a very hard game in private while letting his team brief that he will permit big spending increases in the third year of the spending review.

There is special tension developing between the industry secretary Stephen Byers and Mr Brown.

It is understood that the chancellor, already at odds with Mr Byers over the single currency and the minimum wage, has rejected the Department of Trade and Industry's spending bid.

Mr Byers, after a difficult two months, is seeking a political rehabilitation, but is said to be angered at his treatment by the chancellor.

Tensions are also rising over the bids being tabled by the education secretary David Blunkett for higher education spending.

Although it is expected that education will get big overall rises in 2003-4, the third year of the spending review period, education officials are warning that ministers plan to cut the amount of money given for each university student by up to 3% - although the total is likely to rise because of the increase in the number of students. Any cut in spending per student would represent a substantial worsening of the present position.

The Treasury is insisting such cuts are necessary to take account of the overall expansion of places. The government has set a target of an extra 100,000 students in higher education, including many more mature students.

It is also understood that the Home Office is still battling to get a big enough rise to accommodate an increase in police numbers. One cabinet minister said yesterday: "The review was supposed to be about modernisation and investment, but all the headlines are about telephone number spending increases. We need to dampen down expectations. People are not in the mood to hear about these kinds of numbers. We are in danger of forgetting every lesson we learnt from the previous spending review".

Briefing on figures is believed to be coming from both the Treasury and from ministers eager to proclaim their personal triumphs in their negotiations with the Treasury.

It is understood that Mr Byers is taking a special interest in the presentation of the figures in the spending review. He and other modernisers are determined to ensure they are presented in the traditional annualised form, rather than accumulated year on year to give an unduly bloated figure.

Mr Byers' officials say he has been told that in the previous spending review in 1998, Mr Blunkett, the then health secretary Frank Dobson and some Treasury civil servants protested over the presentation of £40bn increases for health and education. The Treasury reached this figure by accumulating each annual rise.

fields.headline: Dagenham protest will disrupt Ford
fields.standfirst: Special report: Ford at Dagenham
fields.trailText: Ford's British car operations face serious disruption in the late summer and early autumn as its workforce prepare for industrial action in protest at the US group's decision to end car production at the Dagenham plant from early 2002 with the loss of 1,900 jobs.
fields.body:
Ford's British car operations face serious disruption in the late summer and early autumn as its workforce prepare for industrial action in protest at the US group's decision to end car production at the Dagenham plant from early 2002 with the loss of 1,900 jobs.

More than 50 senior union officials on the Ford joint negotiating committee, representing industrial and white-collar staff, voted unanimously this week to resist plans to remove assembly work from Dagenham when production of the Fiesta ends and transfer it to Cologne.

The unions are planning mass meetings at Ford's British plants before the end of July when an earlier planned exodus of 1,500 Dagenham employees, all of whom have volunteered for redundancy, is due to be complete.

Many, if not most, have already left. But union officials insisted yesterday that the remaining workers will have signalled their intention to stay at the east London plant, and it is understood they will call ballots for industrial action there and at other plants.

The US car group's costcutting programme is designed to staunch substantial losses in its European business, and yesterday Wolfgang Reitzle, head of Ford's premier automotive group, confirmed that he would initiate a "radical restructuring" at Land Rover, bought last week from BMW for £1.86bn.

Tony Woodley, chief car negotiator for the TGWU transport union, said of the Dagen ham plans: "The agreement that was struck in 1997 with [Ford president] Jac Nasser to put new investment and a new model into Dagenham stands. The agreement is identical in words, content and commitment to that struck one week later in Cologne. There is only one difference: theirs is legally binding and ours is a gentlemen's agreement - so we should stop behaving like gentlemen."

Mr Woodley said the commitment stood even though Ford had tried to sugar the pill with the promise of expanded engine production at Dagenham, with the creation of 400 jobs. "That was already part of our 1997 agreement," he said.

Unions, meanwhile, stepped up demands for talks with Mr Reitzle about Land Rover's future, including prospects for its 13,000 employees, concentrated in Solihull.

Mr Reitzle said Land Rover, which lost around €60m (£37m) last year, had "an absolutely uncompetitive cost base," partly because many of its components were sourced in sterling, and a problem with productivity. He said it was too early to estimate any job losses.

Mr Woodley said: "As far as the workforce is concerned there is no problem with employment because Solihull is an efficient plant with relatively new products."

Union concerns centre on the powertrain operation, which employs 2,000 people making gearboxes, axles and transmissions.

webTitle: Sinn Fein bans flags on Coronation Day

fields.headline: Sinn Fein bans flags on Coronation Day
fields.standfirst:
Mandelson concessions on policing adds to Unionist fury
Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Sinn Fein ministers Martin McGuinness and Bairbre de Brun caused controversy yesterday by ordering the departments of education and health not to fly the union flag.
fields.body:
Sinn Fein ministers Martin McGuinness and Bairbre de Brun caused controversy yesterday by ordering the departments of education and health not to fly the union flag.

Unionists opposed to the Good Friday agreement seized on their move, claiming that the first minister, David Trimble, had misled his ruling Ulster Unionist party council in insisting the flags issue had been successfully resolved. It voted narrowly last weekend to rejoin government.

They also pointed to comments yesterday by the Northern Ireland secretary, Peter Mandelson, on the policing bill as evidence that he would backtrack on reassurances given to Mr Trimble. Mr Mandelson said he would consider SDLP amendments ahead of Tuesday's second reading.

Nationalists claim the proposed legislation has diluted EU commissioner Chris Patten's recommendations on RUC reform in 44 areas. It is understood Mr Mandelson will accept a strengthening of the police board's power. It is to include two Sinn Fein representatives, if the party chooses to take up its places.

Seamus Mallon, the deputy first minister and deputy SDLP leader, is forwarding several amendments to the bill, and Mr Mandelson praised his work yesterday.

Sinn Fein was also calling for a return to Mr Patten's proposals, and warned again that the IRA's offer to allow weapons inspectors access to some of its dumps was on condition the Patten plan would be implemented in full.

Government sources feared that Sinn Fein, which has previously said the Patten plan was too little, was complaining as an excuse for the IRA to drag its feet; there will be problems if Cyril Ramaphosa, the ex-African National Congress secretary general, and Martti Ahtisaari, the former Finnish president, fail to gain access to the first dump this month.

Mr McGuinness, minister for education, and Ms de Brun, health minister, issued the flag directive to their departmental officials for yesterday's Coronation Day, one of 13 days when the Union flag is meant to fly over government buildings in Northern Ireland.

The power-sharing executive, which met for the first time on Thursday, was unable to resolve the issue. Ulster Unionists rejected a Sinn Fein proposal to fly the Irish tricolour alongside. The next flag day is a week today, the Duke of Edinburgh's birthday.

In the run-up to last week's vote, Mr Mandelson took the power to decided on the issue but he refuses to do so until the executive and the 108-member assembly try to find a solution. He is expected eventually to rule the union flag must fly, and called the row row unnecessary. Mr McGuinness urged politicians to "grow up" over flags, appealing to Ulster Unionists to recognise nationalist sensitivities.

Michael McGimpsey, Ulster Unionist minister for culture, said refusal to allow the flag to fly was to deny the consent principle.

Ian Paisley, leader of the Democratic Unionist Party, opposed to the agreement, said: "Sinn Fein is unfit to be in office, and the Ulster Unionists are unfit to negotiate on behalf of unionism. It is far from clear they will be a satisfactory res olution. While Ulster Unionists bend over backwards to pander to Sinn Fein-IRA, it is clear that Sinn Fein-IRA shows contempt for British culture and the Ulster Unionist interpretation of the Belfast agreement."

The DUP's Nigel Dodds, minister for social development, underlined the shaky start to restored devolution this week, saying he would refuse to attend a ministerial meeting with Mr Trimble and Mr Mallon on Monday.

They had summoned Mr Dodds and fellow DUP member Peter Robinson, minister for regional development, to explain their party's plan to revolve the ministries through its assembly team; the DUP has said its tactics aimed at wrecking the agreement.

Mr Dodds said: "I challenge David Trimble: if he is unhappy, let him put down a motion and vote us out of office. I'm not answerable in any shape or form to the Ulster Unionist leader or the SDLP deputy leader. I have many engagements on Monday."

The army began to fulfill promises on demilitarisation announced after the IRA offer last month. It began to strip look-out positions on flats in two republican areas of Belfast. Engineers were also beginning to demolish bases at Cloghogue near Newry, Co Down, and at Cookstown, Co Tyrone.

fields.headline: Movers
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: The rebound hi-tech shares ended the week in style as the Techmark, which dipped below 3,000 points two weeks ago, closed more than 8% higher at 3,634.95.
fields.body:
The rebound hi-tech shares ended the week in style as the Techmark, which dipped below 3,000 points two weeks ago, closed more than 8% higher at 3,634.95.

The increase was fuelled by higher unemployment figures in the US which eased fears of an interest rate rise. The Nasdaq index in New York was also trading sharply higher mid-session.

Some of the better performers in the Square Mile included micro-chip designer Arm Holdings , which rose 72p to 692p, Celltech which was 85p better at £10.17, and Baltimore Technologies, which added 69.5p to 398p.

Dealers noted that private investors appeared to be coming back but said institutions were unlikely to underpin a genuine revival in the short term.

For some though the popularity was sending share values to highs not seen for the past four weeks. Geo Interactive Media climbed nearly 40% to 870p.

The improvement was welcome news for the technology firms which have lately changed the face of the main index and were threatened with dropping out again after the briefest of tenures. The quarterly review of the FTSE constituents is in the coming week. The FTSE 100 was also caught in the wake of the hi-tech turnaround and surged 155.9 points to 6,626.4.

Other strong performers included Logica , 172p higher at £20.25 and telecommunications business Kingston Communications , which was marked up 50p to 660p.

Freeserve , the internet service provider whose parent company put it up for sale nudged 12p higher to 548.5p giving it a value of £5.4bn.

Wall Street also had a benign effect on the likes of Reuters , which closed 16% higher at £11.90.

Away from technology stocks, British Airways made a 28p gain to 393p, however, the price is still half what it was two years ago.

A brokers note from West LB Panmure changing its stance on Sainsbury to neutral from underperform gave the group a 17p filip to 286p.

McBride which makes many of the own-label products on supermarket shelves was not so fortunate. It warned of a sales slowdown and saw its shares dip 1p to 79.5p.

The switch back to new economy shares knocked British Aerospace back 18p to 400p, British American Tobacco down 13p to 370p and drinks group Diageo down 18p at 557p.

webTitle: Search for enemies in super class war

fields.headline: Search for enemies in super class war
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: After nearly four years of embracing its traditional opponents, Labour is now in search of enemies.
fields.body:
After nearly four years of embracing its traditional opponents, Labour is now in search of enemies.

Unlike Lady Thatcher, Tony Blair is disinclined to seek out his "enemies within", preferring to create a broad coalition. But, perhaps in response to William Hague's new populism, Labour is in search of opponents of its desire for an open meritocratic society - although senior strategists are uncertain how far to push the argument that Britain remains class-bound.

Gordon Brown in particular - with his speech attacking Oxbridge elitism - has taken the party back to the position Mr Blair adopted at last year's Labour conference, when the prime minister attacked the "forces of conservatism", targeting fox hunters, supporters of General Pinochet and unelected peers.

Mr Blair may be nervous about reducing his "big tent", but a fortnight ago the Downing Street strategic communications unit was advising ministers to attack the top 10% in society who appeared immune to boom and bust.

Influential voices in Downing Street include Andrew Adonis, policy adviser on constitutional matters and education, who co-wrote The Super Class, a book that could be seen as a bible for the current attack on privilege.

Oxbridge has dominated the row over elitism over the past two weeks, but it is possible to establish likely future government targets.

The legal profession

Mr Brown instructed the Office of Fair Trading in the March Budget to "look at the rules which restrict entry to certain professions, and legal restrictions on the ability of individuals who do not have specified qualifications from offering certain services".

The Lord Chancellor, Lord Irvine, chivvied by backbench MPs such as Andrew Dismore and more discreetly by the Home Office, has been looking at the judicial appointments system. Sir Leonard Peach, the former chairman of the the public appointments commission, was appointed last summer to look at senior judges, none of whom come from the state sector. In December he recommended the government appoint a judicial appointments commissioner.

Lord Irvine has tried to counter criticism of secret soundings in the appoint ments system by listing people who are normally likely to be consulted.

"Irvine is doing a lot to reform the criminal and civil justice system, but he is only tinkering with the legal professions," said Mr Dismore. "The judiciary is an elite, class-based and self-perpetuating, and it is impossible to break in."

Venture Capitalists

Mr Brown appointed Paul Myners, chairman of Gartmore (and non-executive chairman of Guardian Media Group), to look at how institutional investors make their decisions, how their results are reported and the incentive effects of the methods used to assess fund performance. Mr Brown believes City investors are not risk takers and need a mix of carrot and stick to perform better.

Managers

In the Budget Mr Brown announced he was appointing Sir Anthony Cleaver, chairman of AEA Technology, to create a new council for excellence in management and leadership. Reporting in March next year, it will examine issues of management competence, training and appointment. It is expected to question whether British managers come from as broad a social range as their workforce.

Banks

Sir Don Cruickshank, who was appointed by the chancellor to look into banking monopolies, found anti-competitive practices in money transmission services, which increase charges to consumers, add to business costs and stifle innovation. Bankers remain easy targets, especially in view of rural branch closures.

NHS consultants

In his book Mr Adonis highlighted NHS consultants as a key constituent of the "new super class". He wrote: "The NHS has its own branch of the super class: the elite of hospital consultants, mainly London-based, who combine NHS practice with lucrative private work under their euphemistically termed 'maximum part-time' contracts.

"Even without private practice, some 250 consultants earn more than £100,000 a year from the NHS alone."

In 1993 three-quarters of applicants to medical school had professional parents; only 1.1 per cent had unskilled parents. One in five medical students has a doctor as a parent.

Mr Adonis pointed out the the audit commission, the public sector watchdog, has criticised contractual arrangements for consultants, finding many hospital managers have little idea how many hours their consultants devote to the NHS. Health secretary Alan Milburn is negotiating over these contracts.

Oxbridge

Mr Adonis has been at the helm of the attack on Oxbridge, describing it in his book as the apex of privilege.

webTitle: Methodists urged to aid ex-sex offenders

fields.headline: Methodists urged to aid ex-sex offenders
fields.standfirst: Religion in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: The Methodist Church is set to defy the "demonising media" and public opinion by advising members to offer help to sex offenders rather than shunning them.
fields.body:
The Methodist Church is set to defy the "demonising media" and public opinion by advising members to offer help to sex offenders rather than shunning them.

A report to be considered by the Methodists' annual conference in Huddersfield this month will ask them to banish the image of sex offenders as men in dirty macs and instead offer a role in the church to them and their families.

In some circumstances, the report suggests informing only a select few churchgoers of a sex offender's identity - keeping it secret from the main congregation.

The report says: "What does the sex offender need? Acceptance, love, a place to worship and join in fellowship, comrades for the journey, and people who accept him as he is and commit themselves to supporting him in his attempt to live a new life."

The church's working party which drew up the report suggests that although former offenders should not expect unconditional forgiveness or be allowed to hold any church office, they should be accepted and treated with respect.

The move is likely to stir controversy at a time when paedophiles are in some cases hounded out of communities.

It suggests offenders should be made known to a select and discreet group within any chapel, and be encouraged to pray and seek divine forgiveness.

The working group chairman is Dick Jones, a minister in Nottingham and former president of the Methodist Conference. He said: "We were concerned to get away from the idea that these are peculiar people in dirty macs. These are probably the most extensive guidelines drawn up by any church."

Some 13% of ministers said they were aware of offenders in their current appointment, rising to 25 % in North Wales and 20% in north-west London.

A Home Office study in 1995 suggested that 10% of sex offenders are convicted of a similar offence within five years and 22% are convicted of either a sexual or violent offence within the same period.

The report suggests that a quarter of sex offenders attend church regularly, compared with 8% of the population as a whole. It says: "They need constant support from other people to help them rebuild and conduct their lives in a way which manages the thoughts, feelings, behaviours and situations which in the past have moved them towards offending."

Forgiveness did not mean wiping the slate clean or forgetting the offence: "If God does this, then God is promoting an unreal world in which history has to be constantly rewritten and in which offended persons are expected to ignore the traumas and injuries they have suffered ... the great story of the Old Testament is not like this."

The report warns that churches should not, as sometimes happens, expect victims immediately to forgive their abusers, saying that would be "pastorally unwise, grievously insensitive and unrealistic".

webTitle: Telekom chief reticent about designs on Freeserve

fields.headline: Telekom chief reticent about designs on Freeserve
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Deutsche Telekom's chief executive, Ron Sommer, was keeping plans for further expansion in the UK firmly under wraps yesterday, shrugging off reports that the German telecoms group has its sights set on Freeserve.
fields.body:
Deutsche Telekom's chief executive, Ron Sommer, was keeping plans for further expansion in the UK firmly under wraps yesterday, shrugging off reports that the German telecoms group has its sights set on Freeserve.

Although Mr Sommer declined to comment on whether he was looking at Freeserve or even Cable & Wireless - describing reports of possible bids as "speculation" - he said that when Deutsche Telekom did have a target in mind it set a limit to the amount it was prepared to pay and "if that limit is passed there's no deal".

He added: "I am so happy there is so much speculation so no one knows what we are really doing."

Mr Sommer was in London to promote the third public offering of shares in his company. The sale of some 200m shares - worth €12bn at the current price - is billed as the first global retail offer, with shares available to small investors in the UK, Japan, Canada and the US. British investors will be able to take part through Crest Depository Interests - securities held and settled through the British system which represent an entitlement to Deutsche Telekom shares. Use of CDI will allow UK investors to buy shares and receive dividends in sterling.

Investors can apply for a minimum of 25 shares - there is no maximum - and for those who apply by June 9 there is a €3 a share price discount. For those who hold the shares until the end of next year, there is a one-for-10 bonus issue. The prospectus for UK investors can be obtained from HSBC Investment Bank.

"This is a ground-breaking offer - the first global retail offer," Mr Sommer said. In total the offer was open to some 800m potential investors and feedback from the UK was "very positive". The shares on offer are being sold by KfW - an arm of the German government - and are the first sales by the state since Deutsche Telekom was privatised.

Though the recently floated internet business, T-Online, and Deutsche Telekom's mobile phone business - which will be brought to the stockmarket later this year - are regarded as the jewels in the crown, Mr Sommer insists that the fixed line business offers plenty of growth potential.

Deutsche invested heavily in the fixed line operation during the mid-90s and is offering customers an increasing array of services and options which generate higher revenues.

The offer price has not yet been fixed but will be determined by the market price when the offer closes later this month. Last night Deutsche Telekom shares were changing hands at €72.35, up 5.6% on the day.

fields.headline: Letters from Belsen
fields.standfirst:
Esther Mossel, aged 5, and
her family were among more
than 110,000 Dutch Jews
sent to Nazi concentration
camps. Her story, told by
Ann Pasternak Slater, and
notes exchanged with her
family in the camp, are a
poignant account of life in
hell
fields.trailText: It is 1944. Esther Mossel is walking with her father, holding his hand high above her head. She is six years old. There are many people lying about. They are all naked. She asks him, "Why are they sunbathing?"
fields.body:
It is 1944. Esther Mossel is walking with her father, holding his hand high above her head. She is six years old. There are many people lying about. They are all naked. She asks him, "Why are they sunbathing?"

Her elder sister had been a sickly child, and long before they were sent to Bergen-Belsen, Esther could remember her lying bare under a sun-ray lamp, to get well again.

Esther's father, Joseph, known as Yo, was a schoolmaster in Alkmaar, near the Dutch village of Heiloo where they lived. Her mother, Else, had trained as a lawyer. Esther's brother Ben was nine years older than her; her sister Yett seven years older. Yo and Else were Zionists and had set up the Jewish Kehila, or community, in Alkmaar. They were well-respected there. Hitler invaded Holland between May 10 and May 15, 1940 and the Mossels tried to escape at once to England. But the ports were already closed and they were forbidden to leave. With the co-operation of the Dutch police, the Germans had access to all registration - births, marriages, deaths, the electoral roll - so that every Jewish family could be easily located. A total of 105,000 Dutch Jews died in the Holocaust.

Later that year, Jewish government employees and schoolteachers were stripped of their posts. Then Jewish children had to leave the state schools. For a year, Yo taught his son Ben, and Ben's friend Marjan Drukker, at home. On May 3 1942 came the edict forcing all Jews to wear the Star of David and, shortly after, all Dutch Jews were ordered to move to Amsterdam.

The Mossels were fortunate enough to have an aunt there. They took one floor of her large house, Plantage Middellaan 3, opposite the Schouwburg Theatre. The Hortis and Artis (the botanical gardens, and the zoo) were just round the corner. It should have been a good place for children - if all public amenities had not been closed to the Jews. And the Schouwburg had turned into a collection-point as they were rounded up.

The enforced displacement of the Jews to Amsterdam undid much of the accurate registration the German occupation had inherited. Although officially now concentrated in the city, it was possible for many families to go into hiding in rural Holland, or to foster their younger children in Aryan families. The Mossel's maid, Annie Duyfetter, remembers Esther being left with her in the country. Esther always insisted on wearing a hat: her parents must have impressed on her that she shouldn't uncover her head - her dark hair could have given her away among the predominantly blonde rural Dutch.

One day she and Annie were crossing a bridge when the wife of a local Nazi collaborator stopped them, saying: "I know you have a Jewish child in your house." Annie firmly claimed the little girl by her side was her niece from the south of Holland, but soon Esther was sent back to her parents.

Fostering was perilous for both children and hosts. Marjan Drukker, Ben's friend, who had studied with Yo the year before, went into hiding with her parents. They were taken in by a Dutch farmer, Piet Kleibroek, of Warmenhuizen. They were betrayed and not one of either family survived.

The Resistance placed each member of the family with a different host. Meyer, Yo's youngest brother, was taken in by watchmaker Kasperten Boom, 77, a devout Christian, in Haarlem. Meyer was hidden with his family in Ten Boom's watch shop at Barteljorisstraat 19, from May 1943 till February 1944, when they too were betrayed. Meyer and some of the others managed to stay hidden in an attic and after three days were moved to Friesland. Ten Boom died after two weeks' interrogation. His two daughters were sent to concentration camps: only one survived.

Many children were moved from home to home secretly, by night. There are records of children passing through up to 26 hiding places. (After the war, legal battles were fought over 1,854 children; 1,540 were returned to single surviving parents; 87 were given to guardians; 365 children were never returned to their surviving Jewish families.)

When the Mossels arrived in Amsterdam in May 1942, Yo began teaching maths at a school set up by the Jewish Council. It was a sad school because the children kept disappearing - a few into hiding, the vast majority to the camps. The streets were being cleared house by house. Informers were paid 6 or 7 guilders a head - about £50 today.

By the end of October, Yo's third brother Aaron, with his wife and their children, had also been rounded up. His second brother Jacques, with his wife and three children, was gone by the spring of 1943. On May 26 1943, the bell rang at Plantage Middellaan 3 for an insolently long time. Yo opened the door. A Dutch civilian in a brown suit and two Dutch policemen were standing there. They came in and sat down at the table while the family collected their belongings together. They had already packed. Esther remembers being dressed in multiple layers of clothing. She does not remember being frightened.

They were deported by train to Westerbork, which had originally been established by the Dutch in 1938 as a reception camp for Jewish refugees from Germany. Conditions were relatively good, if crowded. By the beginning of 1942 there were some 1,600 prisoners. By the end of the year more barracks were built to house another 10,000 Jews and Gypsies.

The camp was well-organised. There was a theatre, where Jewish artistes performed for the benefit of captors and prisoners. There was a social life. The children were kept busy - Esther remembers making origami and singing Jewish songs in a children's choir. Yo taught Hebrew, even though it was forbidden.

Every Monday, a list of names would be read out, of those to be deported by train the following day for unknown destinations in the east. There was an atmosphere of dread. The whole week centred on the Monday roll-call: no-one wanted to leave. 107,000 Jewish prisoners were deported from Westerbork between July 1942 and April 1945, chiefly to Sobibor and Auschwitz. 5,000 survived.

THE Mossels' turn came on January 11, 1944, when they were sent with 1,032 other Jews to Bergen-Belsen. It had been in operation since March 1943. Supposedly a preferential camp, the prisoners were not initially made to work, and forced labour was only partially introduced from 1944. The camp was divided into separate sections, including one for the Dutch - the Sternlager, in which prisoners wore their own clothes with the Star of David. This also contained an Infectiebarak, or isolation hospital, set behind barbed wire, which was run by Dr Siegfried Emmering (a survivor of the camps who lived to his nineties). Here Esther's sister Yett spent most of her time ill with tuberculosis. Jewish prisoners served as nurses in the hospital. They probably had no medicine, but slightly better food and cleaner conditions.

Yo's brother Zadok, with his wife and two daughters, had also come from Westerbork by the same train, as did Joshua Birnbaum and his wife, Hennie, and six children. At Westerbork, Joshua had created an orphanage. In Bergen-Belsen, Esther was often looked after by the Birnbaums - she remembers them shaving off her hair to get rid of the ubiquitous lice, and burning her infested clothes.

She also remembers having a brown coat, a small blue blanket which was her comforter, and a little bag in which she kept her belongings. Among these was a cotton-reel with which she did French knitting, using wool the grown-ups unravelled from worn-out clothes. She made yarmulkes (the Jewish skull-cap), and plaited reins to play at horses with the other children.

Esther has a vivid memory of a group of very religious young Tunisian boys with peyess (the ritually uncut sidelocks). The children would refuse to eat camp food that was not kosher. That left them little but bread and water. They used to walk round the camp singing a song of rejoicing, so constantly that Esther can sing it to this day. They died of starvation very quickly.

She remembers the long hours spent in appel [roll-call] in lines of five, being counted by the guards. Some were kind but others were brutal, particularly a woman guard nicknamed De Griet, who used to beat the prisoners viciously. One witness records her attacking Ben. Once when Else flung out some dirty water from cleaning the barrack, she was caught by De Griet and thrown into the bunker - thick walled, concrete, and very cold - for three days without food or water. At the end of that time Esther remembers others pointing Else out, telling her, "That's your mother". Esther couldn't get near. She was very sad for her - she looked so far away, like a person already in another world.

Towards the end of the war conditions deteriorated fast as Bergen-Belsen received thousands of prisoners from other concentration camps. Between December 1944 and March 1945, when the Germans retreated, the camp population rose from 15,000 to 41,000. About 50,000 concentration camp prisoners and 30-50,000 prisoners of war died in Bergen-Belsen, of whom 35,000 died from starvation, epidemics and exhaustion in the camp's last months between January and April 1945.

In 1945 the feast of Passover came unusually early, on March 29. Esther was at that time quartered with the Birnbaum family, who secretly baked Matzos and told her about the liberation of Jews from Egyptian slavery. Less than a week later, Esther stood by her mother's bedside on the lowest bunk. Else was very weak and thin. Esther remembers her skin hanging from her legs. Ben was standing by his mother's head, Yett at her feet. Ben said, "Does Esther know?"

It was then that Esther learned her father had died on the first day of Pesach. That moment also proved to be the children's leave-taking from their mother. The next day the children and another 2,000 prisoners were put on a train at Celle. The adults had little doubt they were being taken to be exterminated. Those too ill to move, like Else Mossel, were left in the camp.

For 13 days the train shuttled south and north between the German defence and the closing pincers of the Russian and Allied fronts. The train came to be known to the Dutch as De Dodentrein, the train of the dead. Between April 10 and April 22 alone, 139 died - many of the bodies were buried by the side of the railway tracks. Esther's childish memories, however, are very different. At Celle station she was re-united with her sister in a wagon set aside for the sick. There were seats and it was not as overcrowded as the rest of the train. She could lie and sleep. Out of the window above her she could see trees.

There were many air-raids. Lying on the railway-embankment beside a young German soldier, she was surprised to see how pale and frightened he was. And one early morning, she remembers a man standing in the wagon doorway with a beautiful live cockerel in his arms. Later that day the Russians found them. It was April 25, 1945. They were not far from the village of Tröbitz.

Another 28 dead were taken out of the train and in Tröbitz they continued to die. But for Esther it is a time of happy memories. Oom Zadok and Tante Annie, Yo's brother and wife, were there with their two children. Together with Ben and Yettie they lived in a house that had one German woman upstairs. Annie begged three matches, failed to light the large stove with one, succeeded with the second, and kept it burning till their departure many months later.

She found a block of compressed tea in the larder and used it for barter. There was rhubarb growing in the fields which she cooked with rations of sweetened milk. They all made themselves sick with a tin of greasy meat from the larder. The children ran wild. Ben stole the Russian commandant's bicycle, and from a tree overlooking the bedroom watched a Russian soldier making love to the woman upstairs. Esther gorged herself on unripe fruit. Her seventh birthday was on July 24. Her aunt made a cake with the letter E in blackberries from the hedgerows of Tröbitz. At the end of August the Russians transported two truckloads of Dutch survivors home. Annie still had her third match with her.

And one early morning, she remembers a man standing in the wagon doorway with a beautiful live cockerel in his arms. Later that day the Russians found them. It was April 25, 1945. They were not far from the village of Tröbitz. Another 28 dead were taken out of the train and in Tröbitz they continued to die. But for Esther it is a time of happy memories. Oom Zadok and Tante Annie, Yo's brother and wife, were there with their two children. Together with Ben and Yettie they lived in a house that had one German woman upstairs. Annie begged three matches, failed to light the large stove with one, succeeded with the second, and kept it burning till their departure many months later. She found a block of compressed tea in the larder and used it for barter. There was rhubarb growing in the fields which she cooked with rations of sweetened milk. They all made themselves sick with a tin of greasy meat from the larder. The children ran wild. Ben stole the Russian commandant's bicycle, and from a tree overlooking the bedroom watched a Russian soldier making love to the woman upstairs. Esther gorged herself on unripe fruit. Her seventh birthday was on July 24. Her aunt made a cake with the letter E in blackberries from the hedgerows of Tröbitz. At the end of August the Russians transported two truckloads of Dutch survivors home. Annie still had her third match with her.

Contrary to the implication in a column headed People Power?, page 24, June 1, Ted Heath did not win the 1975 referendum on Europe. The prime minister was Harold Wilson, although it was Mr Heath's government which took Britain into Europe, the decision that the referendum was called to approve.

Our piece about Tom Waits in Paris, page 4 of today's Saturday Review, spells his name wrongly throughout. All the references to him insert an e in his surname, as does the blurb on the front of the Saturday Review. Many apologies.

fields.headline: Written off
fields.trailText: •  Diane Stokes (Letters, June 2) confuses the term "cult". While Star Trek fans frequently overinflate the qualities of their favourite TV programme, they don't sign up to a set of religious dogmas.
fields.body:
 Diane Stokes (Letters, June 2) confuses the term "cult". While Star Trek fans frequently overinflate the qualities of their favourite TV programme, they don't sign up to a set of religious dogmas. Many Trekkers are as passionate critics of the show's weaknesses as they are admirers of its strengths. In contrast, forgetting conspiracy- theory rumours about Scientology, it must be emotionally difficult to consider that the man who founded your religion is an fact an awful writer. The film is unlikely to be watched by the science-fiction audience, most of whom are aware that the novel Battlefield Earth is embarrassingly inferior to Hubbard's earlier, inventive, fiction for John W Campbell's magazines.

Andy Sawyer
Science fiction librarian, Liverpool University library
A.P.Sawyer@liverpool.ac.uk
