fields.headline: Drug deaths bug 'spreading'
fields.standfirst: Drugs in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: A mystery infection linked to drug injection by heroin addicts is thought to have spread to England and Wales and claimed seven more victims, public health officials confirmed last night.
fields.body:
A mystery infection linked to drug injection by heroin addicts is thought to have spread to England and Wales and claimed seven more victims, public health officials confirmed last night.

The deaths are being examined for links with serious outbreaks of the condition in Scotland and the Irish Republic where 18 users of the drug have died and 22 are seriously ill.

The location of the latest deaths is not being disclosed until postmortem tests have been completed and double-checked, but doctors said that the symptoms are closely matched. Noel Gill of the public health laboratory service said that a further seven English and Welsh drug-users were ill with the condition and were also being tested.

"This does give cause for concern," he said. "What has been happening in Glasgow and Dublin is unusual. We are still looking at the cases in England and Wales and it will be five or six days before we know whether the cases are linked, but they do seem to have common factors."

An American expert on epidemics and infection has been drafted into a government team which is working on continuous, 24-hour shifts to isolate the bacterium involved in the infection, which appears to strike when needles are used on muscles or under the skin, instead of directly into veins. Jai Lingappa has been seconded to Glasgow by the US centre for disease control and prevention in Atlanta, Georgia, which has also been sent tissue from Scottish and Irish victims.

The spread of effects via large internal abcesses is rapid and culminates in an attack on the heart, kidneys and liver. Once the vital organs have been reached, treatment is useless.

The power and speed of the infection led to initial theories last week that outbreaks in Glasgow, Aberdeen, Dublin and Counties Wicklow and Kildare were caused by anthrax. But the emergence of a new and unknown bug was confirmed after tests on the first victims.

Health officials in other European countries have been alerted and customs and excise are co-operating in checks on consignments of drugs from the Indian sub-continent which may have been tainted.

Doctors said earlier this week that they were involved in a race against time to prevent the infection spreading from limited areas in Scotland and the Irish Republic.

webTitle: Women's groups fail to block visa for Tyson

fields.headline: Women's groups fail to block visa for Tyson
fields.standfirst: Boxing: special report
fields.trailText: Women's groups have vowed to intensify their protests over boxer Mike Tyson despite the failure of a legal move to block his arrival in the UK.
fields.body:
Women's groups have vowed to intensify their protests over boxer Mike Tyson despite the failure of a legal move to block his arrival in the UK.

At the Court of Session in Edinburgh yesterday a judge dismissed a petition by the Glasgow Rape Crisis Centre to overturn home secretary Jack Straw's decision to grant Tyson, a convicted rapist, entry clearance to the UK so he can fight at Glasgow's Hampden Park on June 24. It is the second time a women's group has failed to keep the boxer out of the UK. The judge, Lord Clarke, said he would give his reasons at a later date.

Representatives of the centre said they would continue to protest. A joint women's group had been set up in Glasgow and was planning "creative direct action" up to and including the fight.

"We are obviously very disappointed the petition was refused," said Sandy Brindley, spokeswoman for the centre. "But we still feel it was a very worthwhile process to go through in terms of challenging the decision and the message we saw underlying it, that economic considerations were given more weight that the trauma suffered by women."

She said they had been concerned by reports there may be a third Tyson fight planned: "If it did seem to be getting the go-ahead, I hope women's groups and survivors of sexual violence will have a part in that process."

In court, the women had argued that Mr Straw's decision to allow the boxer in was flawed by procedural impropriety: he had heard representations in private from Tyson supporters on May 3, and had been duty bound to hear from opponents of the fight. They also claimed that they had a "reasonable concern" that granting a convicted rapist leave to enter might diminish the gravity of the crime in the eyes of the Scottish public, and particularly in the eyes of male boxing fans.

Counsel for the centre, Susan O'Brien QC, said the home secretary had not been required to hear representations from anybody before reaching a decision, but having chosen to hear from the Tyson camp, he had made an exceptional case. "Mr Straw did not have to exercise his discretion the way he did. Having chosen to hear representations on behalf of the applicant, and being fully aware of the issues involved and aware that people wanted to make representations, it was not a fair decision to deny the petitioners and others the right to be heard."

Counsel for the home secretary, Colin Tyre QC, argued that Mr Straw had no legal obligation to solicit outside views before taking a decision, but he had taken into account the public views that had been expressed when it emerged Tyson was hoping to come.

He also argued the centre had no special right to challenge the decision: "Despite the fact that the petitioners have great involvement with violence against women, it can't be said that that gives them an interest in relation to an immigration application."

Paul Cullen QC, for Frank Warren, the promoter, told the court that if the fight were stopped, there would be serious financial implications and major inconvenience for Mr Warren and others. He said 30,000 tickets had been sold at an average £100, and TV rights had been licensed around the world. Cancellation, he said, "would be extremely damaging for the reputation of the UK, and Glasgow in particular, as a stage for international sporting events".

Granting Tyson a visa has caused outrage amongst politicians in Scotland since immigration is not a devolved matter, and the Scottish parliament was not consulted. It falls to Glasgow city council to decide next week whether to grant an entertainments licence for the event.

Last night Mr Warren was "absolutely delighted". It was the second time pressure groups had tried and failed to hinder Tyson promotions through the courts, he said. "While we had sympathy for the causes the groups support, they must now realise that there are better ways of achieving their goals than using Mike Tyson as their punchbag."

webTitle: Sierra Leone army mobilises for new push

fields.headline: Sierra Leone army mobilises for new push
fields.standfirst: Sierra Leone: special report
fields.trailText: Sierra Leonean army and militia units are striving to restore the momentum of their advance into territory held by the Revolutionary United Front, after being forced to retreat earlier this week from the town of Lunsar, 70 miles north-east of the capital.
fields.body:
Sierra Leonean army and militia units are striving to restore the momentum of their advance into territory held by the Revolutionary United Front, after being forced to retreat earlier this week from the town of Lunsar, 70 miles north-east of the capital.

The capture of Lunsar, represented the first government seizure of long-held RUF territory - as opposed to the retaking of land through which the rebels had advanced recently to threaten the capital, Freetown. But Lunsar was lost again when rebels counter-attacked, using captured UN weapons.

Both sides now appear to have withdrawn from the area, the government forces moving back to positions near a bridge over the Rokel river.

According to the UN, aerial reconnaissance showed the town to be empty early yesterday. Frank Tabor Bassie, a militia commander just back from the front, said that the rebels' use of an armoured car and heavy machine guns captured from the UN forces had tipped the balance in Lunsar after a five-hour fight on Tuesday night.

At their base in Freetown, the pro-government Kamojars (hunters), as the militia are known, were sending fresh units up the road toward the front yesterday, as well as ammunition and food supplies. The army also confirmed that a fresh effort to take Lunsar was underway.

The deputy minister of defence, Hinga Norman, said: "A no mans land has opened up between the two sides, and now it's a matter of who gets back in there first."

The taking of Lunsar encouraged those who believe that the government's forces have the capacity in the coming weeks and months to fight through many more miles of territory, taking five or six more towns on the way, and finally dislodging the RUF from the diamond areas in the east of the country.

There are even plans to try to cut the RUF supply lines by an attack from the south on the key east-west road, as well as by pushing along it from Lunsar. Such ambitions, which some outside observers believe are unrealistic, will certainly have to be put aside until Lunsar's fate is decided. The seesaw over the town suggests that both sides may be suffering from fatigue and supply failure.

There may also be an element of diplomatic signalling, the RUF perhaps indicating that it is ready to return to the de facto zone of control it had before but will resist any incursion. That would not be acceptable to the government in Freetown.

Yet a restoration of the ceasefire, which amounts to much the same thing, is one of the objectives which west African governments agreed would be desirable at a recent meeting of their regional association, the Economic Community of West African States. A committee appointed by Ecowas to look into the breakdown of the ceasefire and seek its restoration is due in Freetown next week.

A team ordered to examine the performance of the UN mission in Sierra Leone in the difficult weeks after UN troops were taken hostage and their equipment seized will be questioning UN officers, both civilian and military, in the next few days.

Although such assessments are a normal part of UN procedure, it is not normal to dispatch one at such an early stage, in the middle of a crisis.

The question of responsibility for the feeble response to the first RUF hostage-takings will presumably be a key issue, as will the question of an expansion or reinterpretation of the mandate of the UN force.

 Relatives and friends of the Reuters journalist Kurt Schork, who was killed in an ambush in Sierra Leone last month, gathered for a memorial service in Washington yesterday. In a message, the UN secretary general, Kofi Annan, said his death had left "a great void in the world of journalism", and added: "It should encourage all of us to do more and do better for those innocent men and women caught in conflict, whose stories Kurt Schork lived to tell."

webTitle: Palestinians feel the heat as police enforce beach apartheid

fields.headline: Palestinians feel the heat as police enforce beach apartheid
fields.standfirst:
With peace looming, Israel is keen to establish areas for Jews only

Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: In these early days of a sweltering summer, the long palm-dotted beaches of Tel Aviv are a natural escape. But if you are a Palestinian, a family day out can mean a night in jail.
fields.body:
In these early days of a sweltering summer, the long palm-dotted beaches of Tel Aviv are a natural escape. But if you are a Palestinian, a family day out can mean a night in jail.

As Israeli Jews were unfolding their deckchairs yesterday morning to begin a weekend of lolling on the sand, the Tel Aviv police were out in force, detaining dozens of Palestinian day trippers, and scaring away many more in a zealous enforcement of beach apartheid.

The operation to create Jewish-only beaches began four weeks ago, and has been rigorously pursued every Friday since then. Last week more than 1,100 Palestinians were detained, including children on school trips. Ten Israeli coach drivers face charges under the security act.

One east Jerusalem family's day at the seaside ended in tears and a fog of exhaust fumes at 10am yesterday when the police confiscated their car, marooning them with their picnic basket on a traffic island in a busy avenue.

The family, who were afraid to give their names, have the legal right to travel anywhere in Israel. But when police officers hauled them over for the customary questioning of every Palestinian who dares to visit the beaches, they discovered that the father owed 91,000 shekels in back taxes on his shop.

They seized his car and put his wife and two teenage children under armed guard until a relative could arrive to ferry them home.

"Officially, they cannot prohibit us from coming here," said the father. "But they are determined to harass us even if we do have legal rights. They just do not want us to be happy."

Since the early days of the peace process, Israel has kept Palestinians penned into the stifling and crowded confines of the West Bank and Gaza by imposing a permit regime to shut out all but those workers who perform jobs considered too lowly for Jews. In turn, Israeli Jews are barred from visiting Gaza, although they can travel freely in the West Bank.

Now, with the date for a final settlement looming, Israel is trying to affect the complete separation of Palestinians and Jews.

In the Pisgat Ze'ev area of Jerusalem, the police routinely stop Palestinian children playing in the park. In the central Israeli town of Ranana, the council recently banned non-residents from visiting the amusement park, to keep out Palestinian tourists. In the occupied territories there are no recreation facilities.

In Tel Aviv the pretext is security. A police spokesman said they were simply enforcing the permit regime, intended to stop the entry of potential terrorists to Israel.

But three Gazans who arrived at the beach with permits yesterday were brusquely told to leave the busier sections patronised by Jews and swim in the rocky and rubbish-encrusted bay near the twin city of Jaffa, which has an Arab majority.

And off they meekly went. Other Palestinians do not leave so easily. In a strange game of beach roulette, some of the people arrested yesterday said they had been thrown out earlier but were determined to keep on coming.

"They said it was illegal for us to come here," said Firas, a computer science student at al-Quds University in Jerusalem.

Arriving with seven friends in matching New York Yankee baseball caps, they were arrested near the dolphinarium before they could even set foot on the sand.

"But this is so unfair. The Israelis come to Jericho, they come to Ramallah, they come to Nablus. Nobody stops them. But we cannot go to the beach."

fields.headline: Branch line
fields.trailText: Despite John O'Farrell's unkind column (May 31), Railtrack has invested in infrastructure. At Reading station there's a brand new barrier to make access to the platforms more difficult; up on the cross-bridge there are new screens that show no information whatsoever.
fields.body:
Despite John O'Farrell's unkind column (May 31), Railtrack has invested in infrastructure. At Reading station there's a brand new barrier to make access to the platforms more difficult; up on the cross-bridge there are new screens that show no information whatsoever (the old screens were removed, presumably, because they worked); there is in any case no screen anywhere that lists arriving trains, only departures; there is no trolley stand near the taxi rank; and if you want to buy any ticket but the most basic you must visit the Travel Shop, which closes long before the rest of the station and often at unscheduled hours. webTitle: UK braced for chaos after blast

fields.headline: UK braced for chaos after blast
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: London is preparing for a summer of disruption after senior security sources warned yesterday that dissident republican groups could try to cause maximum chaos across mainland Britain and police urged members of the public to be vigilant.
fields.body:
London is preparing for a summer of disruption after senior security sources warned yesterday that dissident republican groups could try to cause maximum chaos across mainland Britain and police urged members of the public to be vigilant.

The alert came as a bomb threat was phoned in to City of London police, causing the evacuation of offices in the Bishopsgate area of the financial district and the closure of Liverpool Street station for three hours. The call was a hoax but caused disturbance to businesses and commuters and traffic congestion.

As officers from Scotland Yard's anti-terrorist branch began analysing debris from the high explosive device planted under Hammersmith Bridge, it emerged that ministers have assumed that a London-based cell of the Real IRA has been established.

Ministers and security sources do not believe that the cell yet has the capacity to create serious damage in the capital but they do believe that the Real IRA is working closely with the Continuity IRA. While the two splinter groups number no more than 100 members and political supporters, it is believed they have the capacity to cause disruption.

The groups are not believed to have the ability to create long-term physical damage either to the capital or the peace process. Ministers accept, however, that one strike such as that at Hammersmith Bridge will give the dissident republicans the political and military credibility to cause "real chaos" through further false alarms and bomb hoaxes.

The blast on Hammersmith Bridge triggered a number of hoax calls including warnings that a device had been planted in the Dartford Tunnel in Kent, a part of the M25 orbital motorway, causing it to be closed for 35 minutes.

"There will be a lot of phone calls and warnings designed to cause maximum damage," the source said, adding that this could happen for weeks.

Police are trying to trace two taxi drivers who dropped off passengers near Hammersmith bridge before the explosion. Witnesses told police that two black taxis dropped off two passengers on the south side of the bridge, where the device was planted. The first was dropped off at 2.45am and the second at about 3.40am. The bomb went off at about 4.30am.

Security in the capital has been stepped up as police last night confirmed the device comprised between 1kg and 2kg (2-4lb) of high explosive.

The government and security service remain certain, at this stage, that none of the activity is being licenced by the IRA itself. Ministers added that it was important that the public remained calm and that nothing was done to dramatise or sensationalise events.

Deputy Assistant Commissioner Alan Fry, the head of Scotland Yard's anti-terrorist branch, said: "I ask people that if they see a suspect package, to contact us on 999." He added there would be more high visibility policing in London in the wake of the bomb.

The Bishopsgate hoax saw emergency services cordoning off the heart of the City. Officers with sniffer dogs carried out an extensive search.

Bishopsgate was bombed by the IRA in 1993, leaving one person dead, 44 injured and 130 buildings damaged. Hammersmith Bridge has been targeted twice before by terrorists, most recently in 1996 when the most powerful Semtex bomb ever used by the IRA on the mainland failed to go off.

Tracking down the supposed new British-based cell will, according to sources, depend on the ability of the British security services and the Garda to inflitrate the dissident republican group and on the ability of the group itself to recruit from outside the known pool of sympathisers.

Ministers believe the security services have been instructed to call in or track all known supporters of the dissident groups. They do not believe that many figures operate on the mainland who are unknown to the police or MI5.

fields.headline: Swinging in the wind
fields.trailText: Interesting that the only issue for the managers of the Liverpool night club Cream over their accepted serious drug problem, including people pushing drugs on site, was whether or not to renew their licence (Report, May 31).
fields.body:
 Interesting that the only issue for the managers of the Liverpool night club Cream over their accepted serious drug problem, including people pushing drugs on site, was whether or not to renew their licence (Report, May 31). For John Brook and I, running Wintercomfort's day centre for the homeless in Cambridge, with a similar but seemingly much lesser problem, the situation resulted in prosecution and jail. I wonder why?
Ruth Wyner
Highpoint Prison

 Woody Herman, whose recording of Louis Jordan's song is probably the best known, always used Caldonia in print, although both Cal'donia and Cal'donya have appeared elsewhere (Letters, June 2). This multiplicity may arise from the possibility that Jordan did not write out the song himself. He was heard jamming by Ralph Burns, Herman's arranger, who then wrote down the first 12 bars and the 8-bar tag. In view of the historical derivation, Cal'donia might be considered the best of the three versions.
George Kitchin
Penrith, Cumbria

 We have become familiar with the use of Wales as a handy measure of geographical area, but it is less convenient when one has to deal with something which is only, say, 0.02 times the size of Wales. It is therefore a relief to see that the size of Monaco has now been accepted as a suitable smaller standard unit (Will Expo become Germany's dome? June 2). But how many Monacos are there to a Wales?
Colin Campbell
Basingstoke, Hants
colin@campbell.datanet.co.uk

 Re the flags in Northern Ireland controversy (Unionists join forces, June 2): a black flag at half mast in memory of the dead would seem most appropriate.
Ruth Cartwright
Stuart Mann Rayleigh, Essex

webTitle: Please don't be afraid of the bears

fields.headline: Please don't be afraid of the bears
fields.trailText: Few can have failed to observe the massive volatility that is bedevilling global stock markets.What pundits have to explain is the core cause of this volatility. A glance at the daily stock market summaries in the financial press can be revealing.
fields.body:
Few can have failed to observe the massive volatility that is bedevilling global stock markets.What pundits have to explain is the core cause of this volatility. A glance at the daily stock market summaries in the financial press can be revealing. Most of the quoted strategists are bearish in their recommendations. However, when strategists who cover Europe are bearish about their markets largely because of their views of the US we generally become distinctly bullish.

Call it contrarian or bloody-minded, but we can see little in the US market to be running scared of. Those who take the opposing view generally cite one of three issues: US interest rates, overspending by the US consumer or the dollar.

In the wake of the recent half-point increase in US rates, many have said that the Federal Reserve has abandoned its gradualist approach to raising rates. Indeed, the futures market is pricing in a 50 basis point increase in Fed funds at the June 28 meeting.

Yes, some of the recent data has shown rising inflationary pressures in the economy. For instance, the Employment Cost Index (the broadest measure of the price of workers) is running at its highest level in 10 years.

However, the measures of inflation remain very subdued. The latest release showed core inflation decreasing from 2.4% to 2.2% - hardly the stuff of central bank nightmares. Inflationary expectations remain firmly under control. All the survey evidence points to headline inflation of 2.5% to 3% by the end of the year.

One common way of assessing the appropriateness of the Fed's policy stance is to use the Taylor rule. This simply relates interest rates to the current level of inflation and the output gap. In order to calculate the size of the output gap we need a guesstimate of the potential growth rate of the economy.

There is a growing consen sus that the information technology revolution has raised the trend rate of growth of the US economy. Since 1995, that economy has expanded by an annual average of close to 4%, seemingly without inflationary consequences. A relatively uncontroversial call would be to say the US economy is capable of growing around 3.5%.

Plugging this number and current inflation into the Taylor rule shows that, contrary to the bears' opinions, Fed funds are at the correct level for the present environment.

The second fear factor that seems to play on investors' minds is the potential impact of a US stock market crash, especially on consumption. Some have even gone as far as to speculate that it would result in a recession.

The argument runs as follows: The Fed estimates that for every dollar the US stock market rises, 3-7 cents is spent. Imagine that process in reverse. Say the market fell 20%; that translates into a drop in household wealth of at least $4 trillion. Given such a decline in wealth, consumption could fall by some $120bn-$200bn, a fall of 1.5 to 2% of GDP.

OK, that is a pretty horrid scenario. But it ignores one crucial piece of evidence. The accompanying chart shows the ratio of consumers' spending to their wealth. It has declined significantly, from an average of 26% in the 1980s to a mere 19% now.

The rise in wealth triggered by the stock market gains of the past 10 years has met with a more muted response from consumers than ever before. In effect, consumers are operating as if the US stock market were 20 to 30% lower than it actually is. The simple truth is that consumers aren't and never have been irrationally exuberant.

A dollar collapse is the third and final fear factor. The US is borrowing about $1bn a day from the rest of the world. What happens when overseas investors stop funding the US consumption habit? The dollar would collapse, imported inflation soar, bond yields rise dramatically, and consumption and investment would suffer a major setback, plunging the US economy into a recession.

However, applying the "Krugman test" to the greenback shows it is sustainable at current real interest rate differentials. The test essentially comes down to a race between improvement in the trade deficit (as the currency declines) against the increasing burden of interest payments on external debt. Don't worry about the details but take solace that stories of the impending collapse of the dollar are nothing more than the pipedreams of bears.

The investors' darkest nightmares can be mitigated by delving behind the rabble-rousing rhetoric and looking at the facts. The US market is not about to collapse, nor are other global equity markets.

James Montier is global strategist at Old Mutual Securities

fields.headline: Thorntons profit meltdown continues
fields.trailText: The Easter bunny was lazy this year, so chocolate shop chain Thorntons yesterday issued a profits warning - the third this year - driving its shares to new lows.
fields.body:
The Easter bunny was lazy this year, so chocolate shop chain Thorntons yesterday issued a profits warning - the third this year - driving its shares to new lows.

The company, whose previous chief executive departed suddenly in March, admitted that overstocking of Easter eggs had left it with £1.4m of such seasonal stock.

Peter Burdon, the new chief executive, said that while the retailer had achieved "good" sales figures at Easter it had been a mistake to put more stock in the stores to try to boost turnover.

While sales to children were strong, attempts to entice an older audience with compact discs and eggs failed. While like-for-like sales over Mother's Day and Easter increased by 9% and 6% respectively over the same period last year, overstocking hit its margins.

Mr Burdon, who took the helm in May, admitted that the reduction in the profits forecast for the year to £5m was a disappointment. However, Thorntons, still 32% owned by the founding family, would not need to lay off staff or shut any of the stores opened rapidly in recent years, one of the causes of its current predicament.

Instead, he said, the group would refocus existing and new products, tighten its organisation and introduce new incentive structures for staff.

The shares, which only two years ago were trading at 290p, ended 11% lower at 93.5p.

webTitle: Loophole specialists salute great tax war

fields.headline: Loophole specialists salute great tax war
fields.standfirst: Chancellor leads by example
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown may have succeeded in stifling the clamour over his Budget changes to tax rules for multinationals by agreeing to postpone implementation for nine months, but Chris Gent's threat - idle or not - to relocate Vodafone AirTouch abroad unless the chancellor backs down demonstrates that the consultation process will be a tough one.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown may have succeeded in stifling the clamour over his Budget changes to tax rules for multinationals by agreeing to postpone implementation for nine months, but Chris Gent's threat - idle or not - to relocate Vodafone AirTouch abroad unless the chancellor backs down demonstrates that the consultation process will be a tough one.

It is not immediately clear, however, what precisely Mr Gent is railing against. The received wisdom is that Vodafone AirTouch and dozens of other multinationals are upset by the Treasury's plans to clamp down on the so-called mixer companies used by multinationals to minimise their taxable international earnings before they enter Britain.

But according to some sources sitting in the ether between Whitehall and the City, Vodafone AirTouch's real beef is over proposed changes to things called controlled foreign companies, or CFCs.

CFCs are a grey and complex area and, like the effect of their namesake on the ozone layer, there is an endless technical debate on their impact on the world's financial system.

In simple terms, their use involves channelling domestically earned profits offshore into a subsidiary specifically to avoid paying UK tax.

Exemptions exist for companies that are able to demonstrate they have a legitimate business reason for sending money offshore - the so-called motive test - but the chancellor understandably wants to crackdown on any misuse of the system.

There is, of course, no evidence that Vodafone AirTouch has been doing anything untoward.

It may have some extremely valid concerns regarding the Treasury's proposals. But whatever happens, it is clear that disputes between big business and national governments over tax can only intensify from here.

With new technology making capital increasingly mobile, countries belonging to the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development are panicking. Individual governments, unable to retain the most talented international accounting expertise, face an uneven battle with all those loophole specialists enjoying spectacular remuneration packages at the big accountancy firms.

Governments know they have to band together to try to shift the weight of advantage away from offshore financial centres and back towards the major economies, leading to discussions over the introduction of sanctions against tax havens unless they fall into line and agree to open their financial systems to inquiries by foreign tax authorities seeking to track down lost revenue.

For the exercise to succeed, however, OECD countries recognise that they must first put their own houses in order to avoid the charge of double standards. With his proposals on mixers and CFCs, Mr Brown is simply leading by example - and other European nations, notably Ireland, should recognise as much.

All cashed out Is cash no longer king? Not if the institutional response to recent hostile bids for Blue Circle and Wickes is any guide. Yesterday, the venture capitalists behind do-it-yourself chain Focus Do-It-All had to admit that the £327m on offer for its competitor was just not tempting enough. The snub comes just a month after Lafarge, the French building materials group, failed to grab Blue Circle despite laying £3.65bn in readies on the table. That was the first substantive all-cash bid for a British company to fail in 15 years.
Lafarge and Focus have one thing in common: their timing proved abysmal. Their early bids were pitched low.

They looked outrageously opportunistic - and the opportunity disappeared when the dot.com bubble deflated and investors, albeit in a small way, shunted their attention back to the old economy sectors where goods are actually produced and sold.

But in the case of Focus-Wickes in particular, the phalanx of advisers leading the attack - Deutsche Bank, ING Barings and Cazenove -will know that they cannot simply blame a change in market circumstances.

Throughout the bid process there was a sense that their tactics were just a little too aggressive. Fund managers felt they were being strong-armed. There was also a clear hint of desperation a week ago, when the Focus camp declared that it would hang on to the near-30% stake it had bought in Wickes, whatever the outcome of the bid.

The predator may well make a return on this stake since it is widely expected that Bill Grimey, the chief executive credited with reweaving the Wickes' basketcase after the discovering of accounting irregularities three years ago, will at some point forge a merger with J Sainsbury's Homebase.

Sadly for Bill Archer at Focus, his company is not going to be leading the consolidation in the sector that everyone knows is inevitable.

webTitle: Preyed on and fearful, Fiji's ethnic Indians get set for new exodus

fields.headline: Preyed on and fearful, Fiji's ethnic Indians get set for new exodus
fields.standfirst: The Fiji coup: special report
fields.trailText: James Chandra believes there is only one way to break the oppressive fear, tension and nerves that have gripped his life since indigenous Fijians launched a coup against the ethnic Indian-led government on May 19. An ethnic Indian farmer, he feels he has to get out of Fiji.
fields.byline: John Aglionby  in Vunicivicivi, Naitasiri province
fields.body:
James Chandra believes there is only one way to break the oppressive fear, tension and nerves that have gripped his life since indigenous Fijians launched a coup against the ethnic Indian-led government on May 19. An ethnic Indian farmer, he feels he has to get out of Fiji.

"This area is very dangerous, no one wants to stay here," he said. As he spoke he gazed at his fields in the Rewe river valley that supporters of the coup leader, George Speight, have plundered to feed the rebels camped inside the parliament compound in the capital Suva, an hour's drive away.

"If any country will take us, we will be very happy to go. I think almost all Indians want to leave. There is nothing left for us here."

He is not exaggerating. His 9.3-hectare (23-acre) smallholding, which 10 days ago was full of the country's staple root vegetable, dalo, is bare. His two horses and two cattle have disappeared, his house has been trashed and his savings have been stolen.

Most of his neighbours have similar stories. "We are all afraid," said Abdul Gani, who lives behind locked iron gates with seven other families. "If we could go, we would."

More than 70,000 Indians left Fiji after the last coup in 1987, because of the oppression. Most of the 320,000 that remain are struggling to survive as poor farmers, not yet able to shake off the yoke of their ancestors, who were brought from India by the British at the end of the 19th century to work as indentured labourers on sugar plantations.

"They were meant to stay only five to 10 years but the British refused to let them leave," said John Ali, an ethnic Indian government minister before the latest coup, and one of only five hostages to have been released by the rebels.

Mr Speight confirmed yesterday that he hoped to free the remaining 30-odd hostages before "final talks" on Monday with the country's military commanders and tribal chiefs to settle the political crisis.

Mr Ali believes that the ethnic Indian community is being victimised because of its relative prosperity, acquired through hard work, as well as its unexpected success in the last general election in 1999.

"As petrol and water do not mix, so Fijian culture and commerce do not mix. They are two different things," he said.

Indigenous Fijians paint a very different picture of the racial struggle. Many agree with Mr Speight's claims that the ethnic Indian prime minister, Mahendra Chaudhry, was scheming to allow Indians, who make up 44% of the 780,000 population, to take over their land.

"I don't agree with Speight's methods because they are criminal," Manasa Vakaravia, an indigenous Fijian farmer, said. "But I agree with what he is fighting for. Chaudhry wanted to take what is rightfully ours, and had to be stopped."

Mr Vakaravia and his friends have been to Suva several times to give moral support to the rebels in the parliament.

Mr Speight and some of his followers are younger generation chiefs disgruntled with the long-established hierarchical structure of the tribes, whose leaders still retain many feudal powers in their individual fiefdoms.

Fiji consists of 14 geographical provinces and simultaneously three confederacies, divided along tribal lines. While in many areas there are racial divisions, there are also provinces where indigenous Fijians and Indians live side by side harmoniously.

The coup has exposed these sources of tension and exacerbated them. Now leaders of the Indian community are demanding international intervention to save them.

"If the west claims to advocate universal human rights, how can it just sit back?" Mr Ali asked. "Unless we get help, the Indian community will die an unnatural death. We will suffocate and die."

A western businessman who has lived in Fiji for several years said: "What we are finding is that with all the overlapping and competing interest groups, there is a massive power vacuum. People are unsure who their first loyalty should be to; their race, their chief or their neighbours. Solving the immediate political crisis is not going to change that."

fields.headline: Unilever to raise Bestfoods bid
fields.trailText: Unilever, the Anglo-Dutch consumer goods group, is expected to try to break the deadlock this weekend over its $18.8bn takeover proposal for US food company Bestfoods.
fields.body:
Unilever, the Anglo-Dutch consumer goods group, is expected to try to break the deadlock this weekend over its $18.8bn takeover proposal for US food company Bestfoods.

Sources close to Unilever said it was prepared to offer more than $70 a share for Bestfoods. The target company categorically rejected a $66-a-share offer a month ago and has refused to talk to Unilever about any deal.

Frustrated with the stale mate and concerned that Bestfoods' talks with other potential merger partners might make headway, Unilever is prepared to bid against its own offer, pushing up the price to $20bn.

Since Niall Fitzgerald, Unilever's chairman, first contacted Dick Shoemate, head of New Jersey-based Bestfoods, a month ago there has been one attempt at communication between the two sides.

Bestfoods, which makes Knorr soup and Hellman's mayonnaise, is understood to has talked to several potential partners about a merger, with Bestfoods as buyer rather than seller. One company insider last night said that discussions were at a "delicate stage".

The group is understood to have talked with Diageo, the British consumer goods group, about buying Pillsbury, its US operation, as well as with Campbell Soup.

However, an alternative deal could meet objections from Bestfoods' shareholders, several of whom would be happy to see a Unilever deal.

webTitle: US carriers cosy up as BA eyes KLM

fields.headline: US carriers cosy up as BA eyes KLM
fields.trailText: The world's second largest air carrier, American Airlines, was last night said to be pressing for a merger with Northwest, the fourth largest carrier in the United States.
fields.byline: Jane Martinson  in New York and  Keith Harper
fields.body:
The world's second largest air carrier, American Airlines, was last night said to be pressing for a merger with Northwest, the fourth largest carrier in the United States.

Well-placed sources within both companies suggested that merger talks were on, confirming developments on both sides of the Atlantic.

The reports started in Minneapolis, headquarters of Northwest, although both companies would neither confirm nor deny the reports involving talks between Don Carty, chief executive of American, and John Dasburg, chief executive of Northwest.

The story began to emerge after analysts said that they expected a new grouping following the announcement of the buy-out of US Airways last week by United Airlines, the world's largest airline.

Shares in Northwest were up 20%, while American's fell by $1 to just over $28.

Greg Overman, spokesman for the Allied Pilots' Associattion, said that an American Airlines board meeting had taken place this week, but a possible deal had not been mentioned.

As well as flying to more than 150 cities worldwide, Northwest owns 13.5% of Continental, a small rival. American serves 180 cities overseas and has an extensive alliance with KLM, the Dutch carrier.

Once United set its sights on US Airways, analysts had been waiting for a round of consolidation in the industry.

In addition to a Northwest-American deal, analysts said a merger between Delta Air Lines and Continental Airlines might be a marriage waiting to happen.

A deal between Northwest and Texas-based American could face a host of obstacles, similar to those that may block the deal between United and US Airways, namely combining their workforces and their huge information technology networks.

For the deal to get regulatory approval, Northwest would also have to sell off its 13.5% equity holding and 51% voting stake in Continental.

The American Airlines-Northwest deal could have implications for British Airways which has been trying unsuccessfully to forge a link with AA for the past four years.

Bob Ayling, BA's recently sacked chief executive, spent a large part of his career at BA attempting to bring about the deal.

But both he and Mr Carty were thwarted by other large American carriers and by the regulatory authorities in both the UK and America.

BA now has a new chief executive in Rod Eddington, who is trying to strengthen its operational base. Relations between BA and American Airlines remain cordial, but BA is concentrating on a link up closer to home.

It is talking with KLM, in a move which would make it the biggest national carrier in Europe, providing it with a dual base at Heathrow and Schipol, near Amsterdam.

Air France and the Spanish national carrier, Iberia, are also said to be involved in closer links.

BA has a small stake in Iberia, showing the gradual interlocking of many of the large airlines.

webTitle: Exit  Rank sells Florida theme parks stake

fields.headline: Exit  Rank sells Florida theme parks stake
fields.trailText: Leisure group Rank has agreed to sell its 50% stake in the Florida theme park, Universal Studios Escape, to Blackstone Capital Partners, a US private equity firm, for £185m.
fields.body:
Leisure group Rank has agreed to sell its 50% stake in the Florida theme park, Universal Studios Escape, to Blackstone Capital Partners, a US private equity firm, for £185m.

Rank might reap a further £50m from the sale, conditional upon Blackstone achieving a return on its investment expected to be set at about 30%.

Analysts were unimpressed by Rank's exit from the complex,which comprises two theme parks, Universal Studios Florida and Islands of the Adventure (pictured), and a dining and entertainment centre.

The City had expected Rank's stake to fetch more than £400m, given it has a book valuation of £332m. In 1999 Rank reported a £2m loss on Universal Studios Escape, then jointly owned with Seagram.

The theme parks opened in May 1999.

Mike Smith, Rank's chief executive, said: "We are pleased to have reached this initial agreement with Blackstone, secured with the co-operation of our partners. However, there are still a number of conditions to be met which means that we still need to temper our expectations."

Those conditions include agreement from the banks which lent £1.1bn to Rank and Seagram.

Cash from the deal will be used to reduce Rank's debt, which totals almost £850m.

webTitle: P&O goes cruising for a bruising

fields.headline: P&O goes cruising for a bruising
fields.trailText: The stock market, rather than the high seas, sunk cruise and ports operator P&O yesterday after investors took fright at revenue projections for its cruise arm.
fields.body:
The stock market, rather than the high seas, sunk cruise and ports operator P&O yesterday after investors took fright at revenue projections for its cruise arm.

Executives warned that additional capacity and a competitive American market would hit revenue yields for its cruises operation, which it plans to spin off as a separate company in October.

However, P&O director Peter Smith insisted the reaction - which took 11% of the value of the shares - was overdone and said the statement was "nothing remotely approaching a profits warning".

While analysts said they were preparing to reduce their profits forecasts for the business, Mr Smith said they had failed to take account of P&O's attempts to keep costs under control.

The statement issued to the stock exchange yesterday morning showed that operating profit in its P&O Princess cruises operation had increased by 4% to $60m (£40m), even though fuel prices had risen by $9m, in the first three months of the year.

P&O, which is in the throes of taking over Festival Cruises, is increasing its capacity to capitalise upon a growing appetite among younger people for cruises. Earlier this year it suffered the embarrassment of failing to complete the inaugural voyage of Aurora but the vessel alone will increase P&O cruise capacity by 37%.

The group insisted yesterday that despite the additional space for passengers, bookings were going well.

Mr Smith acknowledged that the prices of cruises had fallen back slightly from higher levels of 1998 and 1999.

Analysts said the stock market reaction was based on concern that the rise in capacity would continue to erode prices. There was also some anxiety that any slowdown in demand in the US would also hurt potential profits.

Shares in P&O, which controls 70% of the global cruise market, ended at 640p, losing some of the gains registered in the previous two weeks.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Microsoft, the software group that has put Seattle on the global map, was forced to deny yesterday that it had contemplated leaving the US for Canada.
fields.body:
Microsoft stays loyal to Seattle

Microsoft, the software group that has put Seattle on the global map, was forced to deny yesterday that it had contemplated leaving the US for Canada.

A BBC report suggested that authorities in British Columbia, 100 miles north of Microsoft headquarters, had tried to entice the company to move over the border and avoid ramifications of its long-running anti-monopoly fight with the US government.

Ricardo Adame of Microsoft issued a "100% denial". He said that no executive had "ever had any thought or any conversations whatsoever" about moving out of the US. "It is a US company, it is part of the engine of the new economy in the US and we strongly believe in the US judicial system."
BAA sues Eurotunnel

BAA is suing Eurotunnel for losses it has suffered under a contract to run shops at the two Channel tunnel terminals, Folkestone and Calais. It has lost £10m since it signed the 15-year contract with Eurotunnel last July.

It is seeking damages in the high court for "misrepresentation and for breach of warranty".

Eurotunnel's managing director of shuttle services, Bill Dix, denied the claim, saying his firm would make a counter-claim for breach of contract. He said that in the past nine months, Eurotunnel's share of the market was 54%, an increase on the previous year. "This is the best answer to BAA's allegations," he said.

Wickes fends off predator

DIY group Wickes successfully defended its independence against hostile bidder Focus-Do-it-All after the bid lapsed yesterday with just 35.6% of shareholders supporting FDIA's offer.

Wickes shares closed at 390p, below the 430p offer price which valued Wickes at £327m. Dawson shuts woollens plant Textiles group Dawson International shut its loss-making woollen yarn business Laidlaw & Fairgrieve yesterday with 290 job losses after failing over two years to find a buyer for it. Closure of the woollens business follows a long list of disposals as part of a restructuring begun when chief executive Paul Munn joined Dawson three years ago. The group has quit five of its divisions including Pringle of Scotland and its American thermal underwear business to concentrate on the cashmere market, of which it controls 20%. Laidlaw & Fairgrieve incurred a loss of £2m last year and is expected to deliver a similar result this financial year.
Star TV scraps Hong Kong pact

The Star TV unit of Rupert Murdoch's News Corp and Cable & Wireless HKT yesterday abandoned plans for an ambitious TV and internet joint venture.

"We have come to a mutual and amicable decision to part ways," the companies said in a joint statement.

The announcement confirms speculation that the pact was doomed after News Corp earlier this year backed a losing bid for C&W HKT.

The venture would have delivered Star programmes over C&W HKT's broadband network in Hong Kong, one of the most advanced in the world.

webTitle: Mugabe land seizures force hundreds of farm owners to flee

fields.headline: Mugabe land seizures force hundreds of farm owners to flee
fields.standfirst: Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: Hundreds of Zimbabwe's white farmers prepared to leave their land yesterday following Robert Mugabe's announcement of the seizure of 804 mostly white-owned farms for the resettlement of poor black farmers.
fields.body:
Hundreds of Zimbabwe's white farmers prepared to leave their land yesterday following Robert Mugabe's announcement of the seizure of 804 mostly white-owned farms for the resettlement of poor black farmers.

"I don't know how to even begin leaving my farm," said Jim Sinclair, a white farmer faced with eviction by early next month. "I had reckoned it would take five months to wind up the farm, not a few weeks."

He said he feared an increase in lawlessness. "This gives carte blanche to anybody who wants to move onto the farms. Some of them are armed."

Five white farmers have been killed since Mr Mugabe's supporters began invading farms three months ago.

In 1980, as president of the Commercial Farmers Union, he encouraged white farmers to continue under majority rule. Now Mr Sinclair sees little hope for Zimbabwe's large-scale farming. "This will tear the heart out of commercial agriculture," he said. "It's the beginning of the end of the economy of this country."

Other farming families have begun packing up valuables in fear that their property will be invaded immediately.

"Our biggest fear is that there will be an influx onto the farms by people who are just going to go shopping for land, livestock and equipment," said Colin Cloete, a CFU official. The group is setting up a programme to help farmers relocate their families, protect farm workers, move household goods and livestock.

An extraordinary government gazette was published yesterday announcing the confiscations. Some of the farms involved are owned by black Africans, most of whom are critics of Mr Mugabe.

Mr Mugabe's action will enable his government to take possession of farms covering nearly 2m hectares (5m acres), by the time of the election on June 24 and 25.

"The president has called for a fast-track kind of resettlement with no elaborate infrastructure," said Vincent Kwenda, the director of land resettlement. But critics claim that without redevelopment only subsistence farming will be possible on seized land.

People will be moved onto the farms by the end of June, despite the fact that the farm owners have 30 days to lodge legal objections to the confiscations. The new land legislation, written by Mr Mugabe and enacted last week, gives farmers few grounds to contest the seizures.

Far from praising Mr Mugabe's move, many black Zimbabweans are dismissing it as an election ploy that will be disastrous for the country's long-term stability.

"It is an election gimmick which will result in environmental damage and will speed up our economic decline," said John Makumbe, a political science lecturer at the University of Zimbabwe.

"The people will not get adequate infrastructure, financial support or training to cultivate the land productively. It is unfortunate that Mugabe is so scared of losing power that he will damage the environment and the economy just to stay in office."

The new legislation states that Britain is obliged to pay for the land seized from the African people during the colonial period. If Britain does not pay, states the law, then the Zimbabwe government is authorised to seize the land without paying compensation.

The British government had earmarked £37m for much-needed land reform in Zimbabwe, but Mr Mugabe's current land grab will not qualify for the funds.

"Land reform in Zimbabwe can only really succeed if it is transparent and legal," said the British high commissioner, Peter Longworth, yesterday.

"We have always said we are prepared to participate in such a plan. We are aware, as are many others, that well managed land reform is an important factor for social stability."

Other international donors are expected to shun Mr Mugabe's hurried land expropriations. Officials from the United Nations Development Programme and the president of South Africa, Thabo Mbeki, have attempted in recent days to broker a compromise deal to raise international funds to pay for the white-owned farms. But Mr Mugabe rejected the imposition of any conditions on how the land reform should be carried out.

The economic effects of Mr Mugabe's hasty land resettlement are expected to be disastrous. The properties confiscated comprise nearly a quarter of the country's large-scale farms. Zimbabwe's commercial farming sector provides 40% of the country's export earnings and is the largest single employer, supporting 2m.

The seizures could also trigger a failure of Zimbabwe's commercial banks which have lent more than £431m to the farming sector.

The Foreign Office minister, Peter Hain, last night described a visit to Zimbabwe today by the shadow foreign secretary, Francis Maude, as "irresponsible" given the country's present volatility.

"Our biggest fear is that there will be an influx onto the farms by people who are just going to go shopping for land, livestock and equipment," said Colin Cloete, a CFU official. The group is setting up a programme to help farmers relocate their families, protect farm workers, move household goods and livestock. An extraordinary government gazette was published yesterday announcing the confiscations. Some of the farms involved are owned by black Africans, most of whom are critics of Mr Mugabe. Mr Mugabe's action will enable his government to take possession of farms covering nearly 2m hectares (5m acres), by the time of the election on June 24 and 25. "The president has called for a fast-track kind of resettlement with no elaborate infrastructure," said Vincent Kwenda, the director of land resettlement. But critics claim that without redevelopment only subsistence farming will be possible on seized land. People will be moved onto the farms by the end of June, despite the fact that the farm owners have 30 days to lodge legal objections to the confiscations. The new land legislation, written by Mr Mugabe and enacted last week, gives farmers few grounds to contest the seizures. Far from praising Mr Mugabe's move, many black Zimbabweans are dismissing it as an election ploy that will be disastrous for the country's long-term stability. "It is an election gimmick which will result in environmental damage and will speed up our economic decline," said John Makumbe, a political science lecturer at the University of Zimbabwe. "The people will not get adequate infrastructure, financial support or training to cultivate the land productively. It is unfortunate that Mugabe is so scared of losing power that he will damage the environment and the economy just to stay in office." The new legislation states that Britain is obliged to pay for the land seized from the African people during the colonial period. If Britain does not pay, states the law, then the Zimbabwe government is authorised to seize the land without paying compensation. The British government had earmarked £37m for much-needed land reform in Zimbabwe, but Mr Mugabe's current land grab will not qualify for the funds. "Land reform in Zimbabwe can only really succeed if it is transparent and legal," said the British high commissioner, Peter Longworth, yesterday. "We have always said we are prepared to participate in such a plan. We are aware, as are many others, that well managed land reform is an important factor for social stability." Other international donors are expected to shun Mr Mugabe's hurried land expropriations. Officials from the United Nations Development Programme and the president of South Africa, Thabo Mbeki, have attempted in recent days to broker a compromise deal to raise international funds to pay for the white-owned farms. But Mr Mugabe rejected the imposition of any conditions on how the land reform should be carried out. The economic effects of Mr Mugabe's hasty land resettlement are expected to be disastrous. The properties confiscated comprise nearly a quarter of the country's large-scale farms. Zimbabwe's commercial farming sector provides 40% of the country's export earnings and is the largest single employer, supporting 2m. The seizures could also trigger a failure of Zimbabwe's commercial banks which have lent more than £431m to the farming sector. The Foreign Office minister, Peter Hain, last night described a visit to Zimbabwe today by the shadow foreign secretary, Francis Maude, as "irresponsible" given the country's present volatility.

webTitle: Europe urged to protect Cornish pasties

fields.headline: Europe urged to protect Cornish pasties
fields.trailText: The Cornish are a proud people - proud of their history, proud of their countryside, proud of their rugby players, and above all proud of their pasties.
fields.body:
The Cornish are a proud people - proud of their history, proud of their countryside, proud of their rugby players, and above all proud of their pasties.

For years the county's many pasty makers have seethed as up-country bakers have routinely attached the label "cornish" to what they consider are inferior products.

But now they are fighting back. Even if they cannot always agree on the ingredients of what one leading manufacturer has dubbed "the original convenience food", they are turning to Europe to help protect what is widely acknowledged to be one of Cornwall's most important industries.

Provided they can demonstrate the "cultural significance" of a food that once formed the staple diet of cornish tin miners, trading standards officers hope they will be able to persuade European law makers to give the county's pasties the same protected status granted to products such as Rutland beer and Newcastle brown ale.

The Cornish pasty campaign aims to build on Cornwall's success in persuading the EU to prohibit anyone describing their clotted cream as Cornish unless it is manufactured there.

Sympathetic government officials in London have warned, however, that the pasty's application is likely to be a more complicated affair because the raw ingredients do not always come from within the county and there is no agreement on its definitive recipe or shape.

Consumer watchdogs are now calling on Cornish people to help them in compiling a comprehensive history of the food, so as to help in supporting their case.

Liz Carveth, Cornwall's trading standards marketing officer, said the application would need to show that the pasty is a uniquely Cornish invention that is an essential to the local economy.

"We are not trying to stop anyone calling a pasty a pasty," she said yesterday.

"But if they are going to call it a Cornish pasty let's make sure it is made here in Cornwall."

The pasty is said to date back hundreds of years, and became well known as the staple food of the county's "tinners".

Today, more than 3m pasties are produced in Cornwall every week.

With an annual turnover of £150m, the industry supports some 3,000 jobs in processing and manufacturing.

webTitle: Author claims Hitler halted tanks when map showed swamp

fields.headline: Author claims Hitler halted tanks when map showed swamp
fields.trailText: The "miracle" of Dunkirk happened only because Hitler was thrown into panic by a geological map, according to evidence in a book published today.
fields.body:
The "miracle" of Dunkirk happened only because Hitler was thrown into panic by a geological map, according to evidence in a book published today.

The map convinced him that his crack tank regiments would be trapped in waterlogged, low-lying fields near Dunkirk if he let them advance to annihilate the retreating allies.

So he halted their advance for two and a half days - giving the British and French armies time to organise defences and start evacuating their troops to fight on future battlefronts. In the view of many historians, this pause lost him the second world war

In fact, the land was dry and safe for tanks during this period. "They could have got through and inflicted immense damage on us," the book's author, the military historian Martin Marix Evans, said yesterday.

Hitler's frontline panzer corps commanders, who had observers close to the terrain, were "left speechless" by the order, issued in Berlin.

Almost as soon as Hitler rescinded the command, rain began to fall. It lasted three days. This made the fields genuinely impassable, allowing the evacuation to be completed despite Luftwaffe attacks.

The book, The Fall of France, claims to be the first to publish and to discuss the official German army geological maps and handbooks used by Hitler and his headquarters staff. The documents are also analysed in a military journal* issued by Mr Marix Evans's publisher.

Hitler's notorious "halt" order on May 24, 1940, is seen as one of the central unsolved mysteries of the war. He later gave the terrain of Flanders as his reason. He is known to have been haunted by memories of Flanders mud as a soldier in the first world war.

But his army's master of mechanised warfare, Heinz Guderian - the tank general who desperately wanted to advance on Dunkirk - dismissed this explanation as "a poor one".

Most historians have assumed that Hitler's excuse was a cover for other motives. Favourite theories are that:

He had promised the glory of destroying the Dunkirk evacuation to Herman Göring, head of the Luftwaffe;

He believed a display of mercy towards the British expeditionary force on the beaches would pave the way for a peace treaty with Winston Churchill's government, giving him mastery over Europe without a long war. This is known as the Golden Bridge theory.

The map, in documents titled Military and Geographical Descriptions of France, appears to be the first evidence that Hitler had solid reasons for his qualms. Compiled only five months before the evacuation, it was the main German army manual used until 1944.

Mr Marix Evans paid £40 in a Welsh antiquarian bookshop for a copy captured by a British soldier during the liberation of France in 1944. "Clearly it circulated widely in Hitler's army," the author said. Yet it is not mentioned in the official British army or Royal Navy histories of the operation.

Copies of the map exist in the Bundesrat war archive at Koblenz, Germany, and in the Imperial War Museum, London. But neither archive could trace any requests from scholars to study it.

"I can say with confidence that the map has been neglected," said Mr Marix Evans.

 The Fall of France - Act With Daring. Osprey Military Books, Wellingborough, Northants NN8 4ZA, £19.99. *Osprey Military Journal, available from 01933 443863, £4.95.

webTitle: Formaldehyde off the menu in Hirst's new departure

fields.headline: Formaldehyde off the menu in Hirst's new departure
fields.trailText: Damien Hirst, the man who made an art form out of pickling cows and sheep in formaldehyde, is about to turn his hand to dead marine life.
fields.body:
Damien Hirst, the man who made an art form out of pickling cows and sheep in formaldehyde, is about to turn his hand to dead marine life.

The artist is understood to have completed the purchase of a large harbourside property in the north Devon resort of Ilfracombe with a view to opening a fish restaurant there.

Locals hope it could do for the Victorian seaside town what the TV chef Rick Stein has done for the fishing village of Padstow in neighbouring Cornwall.

Hirst, who has a home in north Devon, has been looking to open a restaurant in the area for some time.

Following months of speculation he is now reported to have acquired the former White Hart pub in the old harbour area of the town in a deal involving around £200,000.

Hirst's business partner, Simon Browne, said yesterday that the venture was still in its early stages. But the intention was to open a bar restaurant.

"I have been keeping an eye open for the right spot over the years. We love Ilfracombe and we hope that if we invest in one small part of the town it will help to revitalise the whole harbour."

Planning officials at North Devon district council have yet to receive a planning application from the new owners to change the imposing property from its recent residential use into a restaurant. But the proposal seems unlikely to meet with opposition within Ilfracombe itself.

The town, population 11,000, relies heavily on the tourist trade and a celebrity venture of this kind could only prove an additional attraction.

"We are certainly not lacking in restaurants, but my own view is that anything that brings more people into the town has got to be good for Ilfracombe," the town's mayor, Bill Hedges, said yesterday.

webTitle: Flotilla regroups for last voyage into legend

fields.headline: Flotilla regroups for last voyage into legend
fields.standfirst: Boats that helped evacuate 338,000 troops in 1940 return to Dunkirk to honour the spirit that revitalised a beleaguered nation
fields.trailText: Sixty years on from their finest hour, a flotilla of small boats yesterday made their passage across the English Channel in a pilgrimage to Dunkirk, honouring those who evacuated 338,000 British troops.
fields.byline: Vikram Dodd  aboard HMS Somerset, Dunkirk
fields.body:
Sixty years on from their finest hour, a flotilla of small boats yesterday made their passage across the English Channel in a pilgrimage to Dunkirk, honouring those who evacuated 338,000 British troops.

The vessels came to commemorate what Winston Churchill called "a miracle of deliverance", when the cream of the British army, trapped on the beaches, were saved from capture by the Nazis.

Just after 9.15am the first of 61 small boats eased out of Dover harbour. As they emerged they were set against a horizon dominated by the undulating white cliffs of Dover. As it was 60 years ago, the weather was near perfect for sailing and the wind moderate. The crests of the low, greenish-brown waves were turned silver by a warm late-spring sun.

Among the hundreds watching the departure was Dunkirk veteran Bill Hinchliff, 81, who was rescued from the French sands after three days trapped by incessant enemy fire.

Bearing witness yesterday brought back the horror that left only 60 of his battalion of 908 young men alive. "It was the most scared I've ever been in my life. We were under enemy fire all the time, being shelled with Stukas coming down. I was petrified by the noise of them.

"We just buried ourselves in the sand. We couldn't go in the basements of the houses because there were the dead bodies of troops in there."

After this anniversary, the Dunkirk Veterans' Association, defeated by ageing, will wind itself up. That fact added poignancy to yesterday's graceful commemoration by the Dunkirk little ships of the role that they played in rescuing so many.

Eight hundred craft, some barely 30ft long, were involved in Operation Dynamo, which it was hoped would save at best 45,000 troops. Some carried soldiers all the way back, avoiding heavy enemy fire and minefields, but most ferried troops off the beaches to larger ships anchored further off shore. Their role was invaluable.

The former TV presenter Raymond Baxter, 78, is honorary admiral of the Association of Dunkirk Little Ships, which masterminded the commemoration. Yesterday was his seventh voyage of pilgrimage to Dunkirk, which is held every five years. The first was in 1965.

Sixty years ago his motor yacht, L'Orage, ferried bloody troops, 34 at a time, off the beaches and to safety. He said: "It's a celebration of one of the two turning points of modern world history, the other one being D-Day. If Operation Dynamo had been a disaster it's highly probable that Britain would have sued for peace."

Sailing towards Dunkirk yesterday, as 60 years ago, were yachts, motor cruisers, barges and a cockle boat. All flew the defaced flag of St George, which vessels involved in the rescue earned, on which the Dunkirk coat of arms sits in the middle of the Red Cross of St George.

Little ships
One vessel was more than 100 years old, another sat barely 2ft out of the water. It was this flotilla of wood, glue and nails that played a role so much greater than the sum of its parts in preserving this island in an hour rich only with darkness.

Some boats nearly failed to make the pilgrimage. Shrapnel was discovered in the hull of Firefly when it was being repaired. Four years ago the Southern Queen was a day away from being put on a bonfire, such was its disrepair, when Phil Hammond rescued it to stop "another part of our history being destroyed".

Since then he has restored the craft estimated to have saved 1,000 troops, spending more than £10,000 to join yesterday's convoy. It went back into the water only 10 days ago.

During the voyage Mr Hammond, 57, said: "Coming across has been so emotional. I am very elated we could be part of the celebrations, but there is also a lump in my throat about what happened 60 years ago. We've been on board living history today."

From a few hundred yards away these dots of history in the channel were guarded by HMS Somerset. It was needed, as to reach Dunkirk from Dover the flotilla had to cross shipping lanes in one of the busiest maritime areas in the world.

They sailed at between four and six knots. Most tankers, which dwarf them, dropped anchor and stayed out of the convoy's way as a mark of respect. The flotilla at times stretched 1.9 miles long, becoming more compact when the danger from other vessels was at its greatest.

HMS Somerset, a type 23 frigate, also ferried over Admiral Robert Timbrell, 80. As a 20-year-old acting sub-lieutenant he captained the yacht Llanthony, which with five Scottish trawlers saved 900 troops. The day before setting out he had been in naval school.

Mr Timbrell had hoped to be reunited with the yacht, owned in 1940 by Lord Astor, but bad weather prevented it from reaching Dover in time.

But watching the armada sailing across the channel yesterday brought back to him memories from the last century, of dead troops floating off Dunkirk, of the three trips he made in darkness at the wheel of his vessel. In the chaos, he, like other captains, had to decide how best to effect the rescue.

Mr Timbrell, a Canadian from Nova Scotia, said that his role in the rescue was his finest hour. "The Dunkirk evacuation for a 20-year-old acting sub-lieutenant, who dare I say successfully lifted 900 troops, was a major event in my life."

Halfway across the channel the RAF paid its own tribute to the heroism of the little ships.

Lone Spitfire
The blue sky was pierced by a lone Spitfire coming out of the sun, which flew over the convoy as low as mast height. Sixty years ago that was how close German fighter planes were getting.

After six hours, the first of the 61 vessels reached Dunkirk to waiting crowds.

The cruiseboat Papillon limped in on one engine after its starboard engine failed two miles from Dunkirk. Its owner, Ian Gilbert, 49, an avionics engineer, spent £20,000 to join this ride. It was a small price to pay, he said, to honour those who ensured liberty. "The boat is a unique part of our heritage. It's a living symbol of the Dunkirk spirit."

He added: "It is not just about commemorating troops being evacuated from Dunkirk, but that people were prepared to sacrifice huge amounts, including their lives, for the freedom of Britain.

"It's commemorating that selflessness and the ability of my 12-year-old son to grow up in a peaceful world. That's why it's important for the memory to be kept alive."

Soon the baton of remembering the little ships' heroism at Dunkirk will pass to a new generation, to hold or not as the brightness of memory allows.

fields.headline: Landing a place at Oxford
fields.trailText:
Magdalen College, Oxford has not always been as elitist as Gordon Brown makes out. A long time ago the college offered me a place even though I was a working-class boy from a state school. However, the dons did ask me one awkward question. The interview apparently over, I was in the process of leaving the room when one of their number called out: "Just one last question. Does your family still own the land around Sedgemoor?" My truthful but am biguous answer was, "No, Sir."
It seems the offer that they made me was based on the charitable notion that I came from a rich family which had fallen on hard times. On this basis I turned it down.

Brian Sedgemore MP

 Terence Conran (Letters, June 1) may have served on a university council for many years, but he clearly doesn't understand the first thing about academic life if he thinks universities close outside term. Serious research - on which vibrant teaching and a healthy society depend - can only be done when one is able to give it undivided attention for a sustained period of time. That is what vacations are for. If undergraduates were present on campus all the year round (many postgraduates already are), a way would have to be found to release academic staff from their teaching commitments for part of it. Otherwise the Lauras of the future would follow her abroad in search of the intellectual stimulation and sense of excitement that comes from studying under those who are engaged in shaping the contours of their discipline. That is the hallmark of a true university education.

Anthony Arnull
University of Birmingham
arnulla@law.bham.ac.uk

A long time ago the college offered me a place even though I was a working-class boy from a state school. However, the dons did ask me one awkward question. The interview apparently over, I was in the process of leaving the room when one of their number called out: "Just one last question. Does your family still own the land around Sedgemoor?" My truthful but am biguous answer was, "No, Sir." It seems the offer that they made me was based on the charitable notion that I came from a rich family which had fallen on hard times. On this basis I turned it down. Brian Sedgemore MP  Terence Conran (Letters, June 1) may have served on a university council for many years, but he clearly doesn't understand the first thing about academic life if he thinks universities close outside term. Serious research - on which vibrant teaching and a healthy society depend - can only be done when one is able to give it undivided attention for a sustained period of time. That is what vacations are for. If undergraduates were present on campus all the year round (many postgraduates already are), a way would have to be found to release academic staff from their teaching commitments for part of it. Otherwise the Lauras of the future would follow her abroad in search of the intellectual stimulation and sense of excitement that comes from studying under those who are engaged in shaping the contours of their discipline. That is the hallmark of a true university education. Anthony Arnull University of Birmingham arnulla@law.bham.ac.uk

webTitle: Who steals my name... may make a tidy sum in cyberspace

fields.headline: Who steals my name... may make a tidy sum in cyberspace
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: How much are the letters of the alphabet worth and who owns them? Unlike the radio spectrum (parts of which were auctioned off for £22.5bn earlier this year), no one owns them and they are worth nothing. Unless, of course, you bundle them up in a way that bottles the zeitgeist and then register the result with the authorities which control names used on the internet.
fields.body:
How much are the letters of the alphabet worth and who owns them? Unlike the radio spectrum (parts of which were auctioned off for £22.5bn earlier this year), no one owns them and they are worth nothing. Unless, of course, you bundle them up in a way that bottles the zeitgeist and then register the result with the authorities which control names used on the internet. Peter Littke, a businessman from Bookham, Surrey, has just turned down £4.4m for the name e-buy.com that he bought a year ago for £63. We are used to seeing brand names -like Coca-Cola - being valued in tens of billions of pounds. But the companies owning them have taken decades to build a global reputation that prompts customers to order a Coke rather than one of its rivals as an almost Pavlovian response. In this case the paradigm is being reversed: they are trying to buy a brand off the shelf so that the business can be injected at a later date.

What is surprising in these circum stances is why such quintessentially e-commerce names like e-buy.com - and ebuy.com which Mr Littke also owns - were still available only a year ago when the purchases were made. Since then there has been an eruption of cybersquatting during which the names of famous people, not to mention the whole of Manchester United's first team, have been registered by fortune-seeking speculators. Jeanette Winterson, the author, recently won a landmark ruling against a squatter who had registered her name, but it is not clear whether other victims will be as successful.

Even after all this publicity, no one among Whitehall's finest spin doctors thought to register the name Leoblair.com before an outsider, one David N George, got there first. But then Alastair Campbell, the prince of spin himself, was not quick enough off the mark to register alastaircampbell.com. Britain's slowness to keep up with the culture of the internet knows no bounds.
