fields.headline: Not to travel is better
fields.trailText: Dea Birkett's article (Trouble in the paradise industry, June 1) is a travesty. It fails to mention any of the real arguments surrounding tourism in Burma, and the boycott of Lonely Planet publications.
fields.body:
Dea Birkett's article (Trouble in the paradise industry, June 1) is a travesty. It fails to mention any of the real arguments surrounding tourism in Burma, and the boycott of Lonely Planet publications.

For those who are interested in the arguments, as opposed to an emotional response about the sanctity of travel, here they are: the development of tourism in Burma is directly linked to mass human rights abuses. Income generated through tourism is helping sustain one of the most brutal military regimes in the world.

For these reasons, Burma's elected representative, led by Nobel Peace laureate Aung San Suu Kyi, are asking people not to visit. Lonely Planet's promotion of tourism to Burma and the inaccuracies in the current guide concerning problems in Burma, have left pro-democracy activists with no choice but to boycott their publications. Rather than allow tourists to make up their minds, Lonely Planet's guide misinforms them and then makes it clear that it believes the positives outweigh the negatives.

Birkett and Lonely Planet are doing the junta's work by absurdly describing as totalitarian a campaign that informs people of the issues and then gives them the choice to buy or not to buy Lonely Planet publications. The last word should be left to Aung San Suu Kyi, leader of the party elected by Burma's people: "Burma will be here for many years, so tell your friends to visit us later. Visiting now is tantamount to condoning the regime."

Dr Sein Win,
Prime minister, Burmese government in exile
John Pilger
Glenys Kinnock MEP

fields.headline: The ghosts of '68
fields.trailText: I was intrigued to read that, according to a secret intelligence, report "it is generally known" that I had attended an international conference on Vietnam convened by the SDS in Berlin in February 1968 (Student rebels were 'frighteningly radical', May 31). If only life was so much fun and secret reports always so entertaining.
fields.body:
I was intrigued to read that, according to a secret intelligence, report "it is generally known" that I had attended an international conference on Vietnam convened by the SDS in Berlin in February 1968 (Student rebels were 'frighteningly radical', May 31). If only life was so much fun and secret reports always so entertaining. I can recall clearly an overnight trip to Norfolk where I addressed the local vicar and six people in a church hall in Lowestoft. I don't recall that any of them had links with the Fourth International - perhaps they were the secret contacts with Rudi Dutschke? But personally I have still never travelled to Berlin.

The problem with a secret service and secret reports is that they enable people of limited vision to invent a world of actions and motivations without ever having to justify them to those affected. Does the term "secret intelligence report" indicate that the report is secret, or, as appears more likely, that the intelligence is not only a secret but a complete mystery?
David Robinson Wellington
New Zealand
david.robinson@vuw.ac.nz

 I was proud to be a "frighteningly radical" Young Liberal at the Grosvenor Square demonstration against the Vietnam War in 1968. It wasn't just the appalling loss of young life in a pointless war we were protesting against: it was our own smug, complacent and inequitable society here in Britain. The violence was undoubtedly provoked by mounted police trampling non-violent demonstrators, including young women. History is so easily rewritten. Today we have a society which is even more smug, complacent and inequitable. Clearly, we need to reintroduce into our national politics some of that "frighteningly radical" spirit from the 60s.
Richard Denton-White
Portland, Dorset

 I was surprised at your characterisation of Herbert Marcuse's philosophy as "nihilistic". In One Dimensional Man, Marcuse points out that man in this modern, capitalist, technocratic society has a tendency to develop only one dimension of his potential: his material or economic side. This, he suggests, is both unnecessary and tragic, since man has a much greater complementary potential to develop, namely, his spiritual, artistic or soulful side. The first dimension, he admits, makes human and social existence possible, but the other, he states, makes life worth living. I fail to see what is "nihilistic" about such a philosophy - even today. On the contrary, it is profoundly liberating and relevant.
Stephen Douglas
Cambridge
ssd22@cam.ac.uk

webTitle: Payout for farmers in GM seeds blunder

fields.headline: Payout for farmers in GM seeds blunder
fields.standfirst: GM food: special report
fields.trailText: Hundreds of farmers who unwittingly sowed crops from seed contaminated by genetically modified material will get compensation running into millions of pounds, the company involved in the fiasco announced yesterday.
fields.body:
Hundreds of farmers who unwittingly sowed crops from seed contaminated by genetically modified material will get compensation running into millions of pounds, the company involved in the fiasco announced yesterday.

Advanta Seeds UK bowed to mounting political pressure and threats of legal action by setting up independent panels to determine financial packages to cover for losses suffered by farmers and seed merchants.

It denied any liability for the mistake, which has already resulted in some food being made from tainted crops harvested last year, as the company and its international associates announced a Europe-wide deal after similar, smaller-scale, incidents in Sweden, France and Germany.

The money will only go to farmers who have had to destroy their crops of oilseed rape this year - about 400 in Britain alone. More than 11,600 acres are thought to have been affected, although twice that acreage of crops was grown and sold last year.

Advanta agreed a face-saving formula with Nick Brown, the agriculture minister, and government officials at a meeting on Thursday. It presented proposals for what it called a "fair and equitable" compensation package to distributors and farmers yesterday.

"To ensure fairness and consistency, independent agricultural advisers, professional loss adjusters and the farmers' unions of England and Scotland will be asked to propose the final settlement," it said.

This process is expected to take a few weeks and will probably result in a series of standard compensation schemes depending on acreage, financial arrangements and the intended destination of the crop into food processing or industrial use.

The company said yesterday that it expected the settlements would cost "a substantial sum" but its solution would be quicker than dealing with farmers individually.

"Advanta is making this gesture not because of any liability but because it has always, and continues, to put the interests of its merchants and their farmer customers first."

Mike Ruthven, general manager of Advanta Seeds UK, said: "So far as we are concerned, the position has not changed. We have not broken any law that we are aware of and we acted properly." Slightly fewer farmers are now thought to have been affected by the crisis than the 500 to 600 originally estimated.

Ben Gill, president of the National Farmers' Union, gave a cautious welcome. "We will not be fully satisfied with the outcome until we know the full details of the settlement."

The government has been severely embarrassed by the international furore surrounding the mistake, which the company blames on cross-pollination of its conventional crop seed by GM material on the Canadian plains two years ago. Although Mr Brown last week advised farmers to destroy the crops, he admitted he had no legal powers to order them do so. But there was no market for the crops once the contamination was revealed.

The Ministry of Agriculture last night said: "Anything that can bring a speedy resolution has to be welcomed." But it stressed the deal was a matter for Advanta and farmers.

The government has had to rush through new procedures for random testing of imported seeds but is resisting pressure from seed companies to agree that conventional seed could be contaminated by up to 1% GM material.

Compensation paid in Britain alone may total more than £2m through seed, planting, destruction and loss of contracts for food or industrial uses, although the European Union did allow final planting dates to be extended so that farmers could qualify for subsidies with another sowing of uncontaminated seed.

webTitle: Drunk on the joy of poetry

fields.headline: Drunk on the joy of poetry
fields.trailText: I will always have fond memories of the character-forming period I spent working alongside Barry MacSweeney at the Folkestone Herald in the late 70s (Message in a bottle, G2, June 1). That was in the days when newspapers treasured their eccentrics rather than sacked them.
fields.body:
I will always have fond memories of the character-forming period I spent working alongside Barry MacSweeney at the Folkestone Herald in the late 70s (Message in a bottle, G2, June 1). That was in the days when newspapers treasured their eccentrics rather than sacked them. Barry, as news editor, was a true one-off, and his love of sharp-dressing was highly evident. One week he announced that he had "gone punk" and arrived at work wearing ludicrously tight drainpipe trousers and a jacket covered in safety pins. A few days later he was talking about joining the Young Farmers and sporting a three-piece tweed ensemble.

His "country" phase included buying a pregnant pig which he christened Garbo. He then ordered a horrified junior reporter to act as midwife. For three days the wretched hack slept in an outhouse alongside the expectant sow and with much relief was eventually able to report it managed to give birth without outside interference. Barry, of course, spent those three days safely at work, his desk cluttered with his usual bizarre array of paperwork, including perhaps the latest letter from Allen Ginsberg and a copy of the minutes of Lyminge parish council.

For the unwitting, he could be dangerous to work with, as I discovered when I spent a night with him covering the 1979 general election. Barry brought copious quantities of booze and dope to be consumed while we waited for the result of the local count. Half an hour before the vital interviews with the candidates, he slumped unconscious on to his desk, leaving me to stumble off into the night to talk to the politicians. Somehow a reasonable front page emerged.
Jeremy Miles
Boscombe East, Dorset jmiles@lds.co.uk

 Though affectionate and deeply felt, Gordon Burn's homage tends to dwell on the alcoholism, referring to the poems primarily to illustrate the illness rather than illuminate the work. I saw MacSweeney back in his 60s heyday and again towards the end of last year. Both times he was the worse for drink: the first occasion being joyously hedonistic; the last, intensely tragic. On neither occasion did his inebriated state prevent the splendour and magnificence of his words from coming through. It is to be hoped that his untimely death will stimulate a genuine reassessment of this important, brave and undervalued poet.
John Harvey
Ebbw Vale, Gwent
slowdancer@mellotone.co.uk

webTitle: Their future is still with Orange

fields.headline: Their future is still with Orange
fields.standfirst:
Interview Hans Snook and Graham Howe, chief and deputy chief executive, Orange
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Interview Hans Snook and Graham Howe, chief and deputy chief executive, Orange
fields.body:
Hans Snook is almost too easy a target for lampooning. There he sits in his feng shui'd office with moustache, receding rockabilly hairdo and black Nehru shirt with an Orange motif in the middle that makes him look faintly like a vicar, joking about his fondness for colonic irrigation.

I am sure it must be here somewhere. Either a mug or a sticker on his computer bearing the old saw: "You don't have to be mad to work here ..." - and without the slightest hint of irony.

Snook's studied eccentricity is stamped on the image of the mobile telephone company which he has run since it launched in 1994. He literally wears his offbeat personality on his sleeve - those funky Orange cufflinks - his office has a large fishtank and some aria or other is blasting out when I arrive.

Snook, though, clearly has his talents, not least one for survival. In the past few weeks he and his senior management team, led by Orange's deputy chief executive and finance director Graham Howe, have managed to emerge from three changes in ownership at the helm of a larger, stronger, independent company.

Serendipity's part

The revival of fortunes has been an astonishing turnaround. Just eight months ago Orange was bought for some £20bn by the German telecommunications and engineering company, Mannesmann, and Snook's hangdog expression at the presentation of the deal was enough to say he was none too happy.

Snook the showman did not like play ing second fiddle to the rather dull Mannesmann chief executive, Klaus Esser.

Snook, 52, says that serendipity has always played a large part in his life - and it was certainly good fortune that his larger British competitor Vodafone then bid for Mannesmann and won what had become an ugly takeover battle.

Regulators demanded the subsequent divestment of Orange, and along came France Telecom with an offer of £26bn - certainly one that was too good to refuse.

If all goes according to plan, France Telecom's mobile businesses will be bundled in with Orange, and the combined operation will be refloated on the London, Paris and New York stock markets with Snook and his management team in the driving seat.

The combined business will have around 20m subscribers, with 6m in Britain, 10m in France and the remainder in start-ups or joint ventures throughout Europe, Hong Kong and Israel.

Snook concedes that if Vodafone had not intervened he would no longer be at Mannesmann. Cynically, he could afford not to be - that tendency to rely on good fortune paid off doubly in the Mannesmann acquisition, which converted to hard cash some £45m worth of share options and long term incentives that Snook had in place.

When Orange is floated once again - and a likely date for that is early next year - Snook and Howe will no doubt be awarded a fresh tranche of options which will swell their bank accounts further.

"With France Telecom we had a brief courtship; we're now engaged and we are going to be married," Snook says in his mid-Atlantic accent.

"With Mannesmann it was more of a shotgun wedding. It was very unlikley that we could have stayed part of Mannesmann."

It was clear in the rapidly consolidating telecommunications market as long as a year ago that something had to happen to Orange. Its weaker British competitor, One2One, had just been snapped up by Deutsche Telekom and Orange had the choice of either making an acquisition or becoming the target of a predator itself.

Snook recalls: "At the time we were very close to buying E-Plus [the German mobile telephone company], so our board was ready for growth.

"They understood Germany and even Hutchison [Orange's then largest shareholder] was ready to dilute. Mannesmann then came in to talk to us. If we had done E-Plus it would have put a bit of a stretch on our financial resources. It would have been the right thing to do, and our shares would have rocketed.

"But look at the conditions of the Mannesmann offer: they were offering cash and shares. It was a good price and our shareholders wouldn't have had to worry about increased debt. Mannesmann had promised something similar to what France Telecom have indicated, but Klaus was not able to deliver those elements simply because the management structure in Germany didn't allow it."

It also quickly became apparent that Snook and Esser were singing from different song sheets. "We would actually give different answers on the platform - even though we had an agreed position; with Michel Bon, who runs France Telecom, we have an agreed position and we tell the same story." Esser, he adds, misjudged just how much Vodafone needed to do a deal with Mannesmann in order to retain its own independence.

With typical self-assurance, he suggests that the Germans underplayed the Orange card during the hostile bid process.

Likely contender

Snook was clear that he would not be lured into another deal unless it was on his own terms. Advisers to the company made it plain during the negotiations with France Telecom that, unless their demands were met, he and his management team would quit. Orange had wanted a demerger from Vodafone rather than being put up for sale.

"My concern was that Chris Gent [Vodafone's chief executive] would have liked to have sold Orange to a weaker competitor, and sucked a lot of cash out of that competitor and made it even weaker.

"Hopefully it would also be to a competitor that we didn't like, so a lot of senior management would leave. It would have been a triple win for Vodafone and I said that can't be allowed to happen, and if that does happen we are going to walk.

"We wanted a company that was public again. We knew we would have to move very, very fast and use the currency of our shares to either acquire companies after that, merge with companies or find a strategic investor - all we've done is reverse that position and got France Telecom in as a strategic shareholder up front, and when we float now we will be a much larger company."

Howe adds that the company could possibly do its next deal ahead of flotation. Finnish mobile telephone company Sonera, KPN of Holland, and Bell South and MCI Worldcom from the US are mentioned as candidates.

"Because of our circumstances we know all these companies extremely well now, and if there is something possible we remain the more likely contender. We know who our management team would fit with and who our vision is aligned with. This won't be the end of the road."

They shrug off any suggestions of possible culture clashes with France Telecom, which after all is still half owned by the French government. Its mobile business, which trades as Itineris, was- Snook says - born in competition and shares all the same entrepreneurial, youthful characteristics as Orange.

Snook is often dubbed a visionary and his enthusiasm for the future development of mobile phone technology is admittedly infectious. One of his favourite fancies is an ear stud or lapel badge that will not only be a communications device but help to organise the wearer's life, reminding them of appointments and so on.

Snook waxes lyrical about a hologram on his desk and says the company is investigating ways of using the technology which comes from a New York-based firm. Why not, for instance, have holographic projections of the management team at roadshows instead of the real thing? Unsurprisingly he cannot leave his phone alone and in between chomping on a toothpick he repeatedly checks his handset for incoming text messages.

Snook refutes the suggestion that Orange follows the cult of his personality. Howe, dressed in a white version of Snook's eyebrow-raising corporate shirt, could have been deliberately trotted out to present the team and underline that this is not a one-man show. "Hans's eccentricities are his alone," Howe adds. "We are not all into colonic irrigation."

Corporate cult

However, the intense admiration for Snook among colleagues and advisers means that many of his traits are repeated, without much charm, among others in the company.

His favoured phrases - one is "wirefree future" - are used with depressing regularity. Press conferences are arranged on cramped double-decker buses painted orange (what a jape!) because the company likes to do things differently. Staff at Orange do not call you on their mobile phones, they call you on their "Orange", but do not appreciate jibes suggesting they verge on the Moonie-like.

webTitle: Church left fuming as Russians put their faith in prophets and pyramids

fields.headline: Church left fuming as Russians put their faith in prophets and pyramids
fields.standfirst: Russia: special report
fields.trailText: The prophet on the phone wanted to know if I'd heard the news. Much more importantly, did I know what it portended? On both counts I pleaded ignorance.
fields.body:
The prophet on the phone wanted to know if I'd heard the news. Much more importantly, did I know what it portended? On both counts I pleaded ignorance.

"Are you a believer?" asked Sergei Trubetskoy.

"Mmm, not sure really."

"Oh never mind, you've got plenty of time. You'll realise sooner or later. But the crows. You know about the crows, don't you?"

"Sorry?"

Exasperated by a British newspaper's ignorance of the biggest news out of Britain in years, the prophet went on: "Look, the crows are fleeing England. You must take this seriously. This is a catastrophe. A terrible disaster is about to befall England."

It's high season for the Russian capital's disaster-mongers. These millennial times mean that the seers, soothsayers and shamans are having a field day predicting the future to a populace wearied by the present and burdened by the past.

There are "telly therapy" sessions where members of the public gather round their sets for bouts of mass faithhealing or national seances. There are giant pyramids - positive energy magnets - built on fields outside the city. There are more than 100 "schools" and "academies" initiating witches and wizards in the arcana of white, black and "grey" magic. All for a decent fee, of course.

There are the tarot-card dealers and palm reading machines, and the newspapers which wage circulation battles with the help of astrological charts forecasting everything from the next Kremlin intrigues to your prospects for a better sex life.

But if the booming trade in superstition and the occult is supposed to offer some comfort in the face of the unremitting hardship of the average Muscovite's lot, something has gone wrong.

A Moscow paper has just published a "coded calendar" for 2000, an alphabet of what to expect in the months ahead. There are no reasons to be cheerful, unless you're leaving the country fast.

A is for high-casualty terrorist attacks (three next month, one in August), B is for major fires (two this month, three next), D is for floods, earthquakes and the like (stay away in September), G is for epidemics or mass poisoning (beware October), and so on.

From Orthodox mysticism to Siberian shamanism to peasant fatalism, the attachment to auguries and divination is deep-rooted here. The rationalism and atheism of the communists made little difference. Indeed, Dzhuna Davitashvili gained a reputation for exerting magical powers over politburo wives when Leonid Brezhnev ran the Kremlin in the 1970s.

And Boris Yeltsin had his celebrated "Kremlin Merlin", General Georgy Rogozin, who helped to run his boss's security service as a KGB veteran while dabbling in the occult on the side and declaring himself an expert in "paranormal phenomena".

Before making a career as an MP, Anatoly Kashpirovsky was perestroika's most prominent quack, starring as a TV faithhealer three times a week in the 1980s.

Keen to monopolise the mystery business and manipulate the emotions that go with it, the Russian Orthodox church denounces the occult's proponents as merchants of "diabolic inspiration".

But a large part of the explanation for the appeal of the quacks, mystery-mongers, and soothsayers lies in the failure of the state, the church and social institutions to do their jobs.

If a Russian soldier is missing in action in Chechnya and the authorities are doing nothing to trace him, a desperate mother turns to a seer for help in locating her son. If unaffordable bribes mean that your child can't get the hospital treatment it needs, you might reach for the nearest faithhealer.

And if you're trapped with a husband who's unfaithful and beats you, you might just go for the traditional treatment of finding the right old woman to put a spell on him.

webTitle: Chechen rebels up ante on eve of Clinton visit

fields.headline: Chechen rebels up ante on eve of Clinton visit
fields.standfirst: Crisis in Chechnya: special report
fields.trailText: Rebels in Chechnya attacked the nerve centre of Russian forces yesterday, as the most graphic report to come out of the war offered strong evidence of what appears to be the worst single massacre of civilians by Moscow's forces.
fields.body:
Rebels in Chechnya attacked the nerve centre of Russian forces yesterday, as the most graphic report to come out of the war offered strong evidence of what appears to be the worst single massacre of civilians by Moscow's forces.

The Russian military warned that the rebels were bracing for a major offensive on Grozny after they rocketed the army's headquarters in the destroyed capital of the breakaway republic.

Russian sources confirmed what was the most concerted attack in Grozny since its capture by Russia in February. The rebels claimed that 15 Russians were killed, but Moscow said only two of its men were wounded.

As the guerrillas upped the ante, Human Rights Watch issued a report yesterday on a Russian rampage in a Grozny suburb on February 5 in which at least 62 people were killed in cold blood. The report was released to coincide with President Bill Clinton's arrival in Moscow today for his first summit with the Russian president, Vladimir Putin.

The New York-based group's report contains 38 pages of chilling testimony which provides compelling evidence of the massacre. The victims included a one-year-old boy, an 82-year-old woman, and a woman who was eight months pregnant.

"The massacre, a war crime, took place in the midst of a sweep operation several days after Russian forces seized Grozny," Human Rights Watch said. "Some killings were accompanied by demands for money or jewellery, serving as a pretext for execution if the amount was insufficient. Others were killed for lack of identity papers.

"However, most of the killings were entirely arbitrary. Several witnesses stated that the soldiers forcibly removed the victims' gold teeth or stole jewellery from corpses."

Moscow denied reports of the atrocities when they first surfaced in February and described them as a "provocation", although Mr Putin this week promised European Union leaders that all allegations of human rights abuses in Chechnya would be thoroughly investigated.

While military prosecutors have repeatedly derided the reports, the Russian civilian prosecutor's office in Grozny is investigating the massacre.

A certificate from the office says that "on February 5, 2000, a mass murder of civilians took place during a passport inspection by sub-units of the defence ministry and interior ministry of the Russian federation".

The report by Human Rights Watch is based on interviews with more than 35 witnesses of the massacre or relatives of the victims. It lists the names and ages of 62 people confirmed killed in the suburbs of Aldi and Chernorechiye, and of another 19 unconfirmed dead.

"The conscripts said they had an order to kill everyone," said one resident of Aldi.

"As the soldiers spread through Aldi they engaged in an orgy of killing, arson and rape," Human Rights Watch said. "In perpetrating the massacre at Aldi, Russian forces unquestionably committed war crimes or a grave breach of Russia's obligations under the Geneva conventions."

Asiat Chaadayevo, a nurse from Aldi, told of discovering the body of a woman named Kaipa, whose nine-year-old daughter survived the rampage. "I entered the yard. I saw Kaipa's body lying by the gates, almost cut in two, face down in a pool of blood. She was on her knees, bent over. The left part of her head was smashed. The bullet wounds were in an arc on her left side. The body almost split in two when I tried to lift it."

Numerous witness spoke of rape, looting and torching of houses the same day. A man said he saw five of the most prosperous houses in Aldi being burned. Another resident said: "Soldiers pointed at the burning houses and said, 'We will destroy all of Chechnya this way. You see your city? We'll flatten Chechnya'."

Another man described the looting three days later. "In the afternoon they came to my house at 116 Voronezhskaya Street. They looted everything... They took the TV, my tape player, my wife's kitchen appliances, vases, anything they liked. They took my brother's things as well."

Human Rights Watch believes the killers were interior ministry riot police units from St Petersburg and Ryazan.

webTitle: Dome may fail to reach reduced target

fields.headline: Dome may fail to reach reduced target
fields.standfirst: The Millennium Dome: special report
fields.trailText: The Millennium Dome is facing a struggle to meet even its revised target figure of 7m visitors, according to attendance figures for May published yesterday.
fields.body:
The Millennium Dome is facing a struggle to meet even its revised target figure of 7m visitors, according to attendance figures for May published yesterday.

The New Millennium Experience Company, which runs the attraction, said just over 500,000 people visited the site last month, with an average 16,200 people passing through the turnstiles every day.

The dome needs to attract an average of more than 20,000 people every day to reach the target which was brought down last month from a break-even figure of 10m visitors.

When the £758m attraction opened to the public in January, the NMEC hoped to draw 12m people over the year.

Last month's disappointing attendance figures - the worst since January - come after the NMEC was forced to seek a cash lifeline from the Millennium Commission, which has already given more than £500m to the beleaguered attraction.

However, Pierre-Yves Gerbeau, the NMEC's chief executive, was yesterday upbeat about the the dome's prospects of meeting its revised target. "We are well on our way to achieving our new, realistic, target of 7m visitors," said Mr Gerbeau, who believes figures will be boosted by an influx of tourists and schoolchildren over the summer.

He added: "By any standards the dome is clearly an overwhelming success both in terms of visitor numbers and the positive feedback from those who visit."

At last month's crisis meeting the lottery commission granted £29m lottery money to the dome on the condition that Bob Ayling, the NMEC chairman resigned. Last Wednesday, Mr Ayling was replaced by David Quarmby, chairman of the British Tourist Authority and Docklands Light Railway.

Under plans to save money, many of the 5,500 staff could lose their jobs, and executive salaries and perks are likely to be cut. The dome has now scrapped its 11pm late-night opening on Fridays, Saturdays and Bank Holidays. It is open from 9am to 8pm each day with half-price £10 tickets available on the doors after 4pm.

To reach the target of 7m visitors, the dome will need to attract just under 145,000 visitors a week or more than 632,000 a month.

Until the end of May, the dome attracted an average of 17,045 visitors a day which worked out at just under 515,000 a month. The best month for the dome so far has been April when 579,333 visited. The numbers were boosted by the Easter holidays.

The NMEC said yesterday that the attraction, in Greenwich, south-east London, will next week beat last year's attendance figure for the most popular charging attraction in Britain. Alton Towers theme park in Staffordshire attracted 2.65m people.

To the end of May, 2,573,803 people had visited the dome, but the figure includes thousands of schoolchildren who have been let in free.

webTitle: Cash-strapped Lakes looks for host of sponsors

fields.headline: Cash-strapped Lakes looks for host of sponsors
fields.standfirst: Countryside in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: A startling version of William Wordsworth's beloved Lake District may emerge next week, stretching from the crags of Weetabix Scafell to Sparkling Windermere - a version that could be brought to you exclusively by, for example, the makers of Perrier water.
fields.body:
A startling version of William Wordsworth's beloved Lake District may emerge next week, stretching from the crags of Weetabix Scafell to Sparkling Windermere - a version that could be brought to you exclusively by, for example, the makers of Perrier water.

A corporate version of the famous landscape has been conjured up by fundraisers in the Lake District national park authority, which is hobbled by budget deficits and a squeeze on government funding.

Charged with coming up with bright ideas, park officer Chris Fancy has devised a sponsor's dream list of mountains and lakes - plus humbler, though probably more practical, features such as park rangers and their jeeps. The authority's finance committee will be encouraged to develop the theme with imaginative matchings: a range of possibilities, for example, could be discussed with Boots or Walkers Crisps - though as yet none of the above firms has been approached.

The concept paper tabled for the committee includes internationally known landmarks such as the peaks Skiddaw, Helvellyn and Great Gable, and the major lakes from Ullswater in the east to Wastwater, conveniently close to British Nuclear Fuels' Sellafield plant. Other highly marketable sites could include the "host of golden daffodil" fields around Grasmere, and childhood haunts of the Fair Maid of Buttermere.

"It's very early days at the moment," said Mike Ashton of the park authority, dodging in and out of the Lake District information tent at the rainswept Holker Hall garden festival. "They are just ideas, but we are open and accountable, and we like to have our ideas in public to get people thinking."

Thoughts were immediate from Cumbrian amenity societies, which view the prospect of pension funds fighting over the rights to the Old Man of Coniston with alarm. Ian Brodie of the Friends of the Lake District said: "We understand that the park is short of money, but this is a dangerous path to go down.

"What if the park took money from a mobile phone company which then used its generosity as an argument at planning inquiries into sticking up transmission masts in the Lake District? We can also see a lot of money for lawyers, not the Lakes, if a company starts arguing that Helvellyn or Derwentwater is its brand name because it has paid for it."

The committee, which meets on Tuesday, is likely to sanction only a modest start to a Corporate Lakes, on the lines of a local bootmakers' £1 a pair donation which has just raised £55,000 for footpath repairs. Mr Ashton said: "That sort of sponsorship is very welcome when we need £5m for path repairs and our budget for them this year is £40,000."

Similar gentle ploys may be explored with Wall's for drystone restoration, or the airports company BAA for sheepfold maintenance. But overt branding would be ruled out. Mr Ashton said: "Signage is not part of our thinking, and we are the planning authority which decides on signs."

A credit card donation scheme is likely to get approval, as is discreet sponsorship of the park authority's website. Elsewhere in the world of e-commerce, the influence in the Lakes heritage of Wordsworth's sister, Dorothy, could provide other openings - for dot.coms.

Pain of some who tried to gain

April 1999 Former agriculture minister John Gummer castigates firms for sponsoring only 12 of 300 threatened animal and plant species, with £1m of the £1.5m raised going to one species, the otter. The other lucky species included the Tesco skylark, the Norsk Hydro water vole, the Thames Water depressed river mussel and the Glaxo Wellcome medicinal leech

March 1999 Maryland state in the US abandons its sponsor-a-highway clean up scheme as the only legal way to stop an attempt by the Ku Klux Klan to pay for litter clearing in Anne Arundel county

August 1998 Friends of the Earth attacks the "cynical public relations" of British Nuclear Fuels funding boy scouts with £30,000 in exchange for the company symbol on the Scout Association scientist badge

June 1997 The Police Federation castigates multi-firm sponsorship of patrol cars, including labels from Harrods, Newcastle Breweries and Thresher's off-licence chain, for making them "resemble Grand Prix racing cars"

March 1996 The Royal Mail Wood at Airton in the Yorkshire Dales becomes the country's first sponsored wood, amid quips that the trees will be recognisable by coming into leaf late

fields.headline: Wreckers at work
fields.standfirst: The extremes have aims in common
fields.trailText: It is still not certain, and should not be taken for granted, that the bomb on Hammersmith bridge in the early hours of Thursday morning was put there by rejectionist republicans. Such obvious assumptions about culpability have proved wrong before.
fields.body:
It is still not certain, and should not be taken for granted, that the bomb on Hammersmith bridge in the early hours of Thursday morning was put there by rejectionist republicans. Such obvious assumptions about culpability have proved wrong before. Certainly it fits with the pattern which had been predicted - that the Real and Continuity IRAs would try to destabilise the resumed proceedings of the Northern Ireland executive and assembly. And it might seem specifically calculated to put the Sinn Fein leadership on the spot. Would they condemn an episode so closely similar to what the IRA had done in the past? If they did, that might deepen disillusion in republican heartlands and feed that sense of betrayal needed to swell the ranks of the unreconciled. If they did not, David Trimble's predicament in keeping the Ulster Unionist show on the road would be made that much more difficult.

Dr Ian Paisley's Democratic Unionists do not stick bombs to bridges. Their intentions, though, have a lot in common with those of republican rejectionists. They want to wreck the process. They are seeking to do so now by disrupting the operations of the new Northern Ireland government. They have hit on this notion partly to resolve their party's internal difficulties: some, like Dr Paisley himself, wanted to stay out of government; others, like his deputy Peter Robinson, a minister in the original executive and by all accounts a good one, wanted to go back to work. The intention now is that DUP ministers should take up their offices and then resign, making way for others, a tactic they would then repeat ad nauseam. There is an irony here: the DUP having spurned the chance to make its contribution to establishing the new institutions now seeks to exploit them for its own political ends. There is also a deep-dyed cynicism, of the kind often warned against in churches.

In each case - the presumed, violent tactics of republican rejection and the non-violent but malevolent tactics of Dr Paisley - the response has to be the same. The general will of people in Northern Ireland is behind the agreement, the assembly and the executive. Those who wish to destroy them, at either end of the spectrum, are the minority who must be resisted. Equally to be resisted is the tendency to undermine them by picking an issue likely to inflame sentiment against them - a tactic practised at times even by those who still support the process.

The spat about flying flags over government buildings is one example. The issue is far from trivial in a province where symbolism means so much. Nor is there any solution so obvious that men and women of good will can be chivied to muster behind it. Fly the tricolour alongside the Union flag and there's a sense of equivalence which goes beyond anything in the agreement. Fly the Union flag alone and republicans see it as an emblem of continuing unionist dominance rather than of the new and different political entity which has now been created. This is one of many problems best debated within the new institutions themselves, just as David Trimble suggested yesterday. If, as seems all too possible, no consensus is found, then it will be up to the Northern Ireland secretary, Peter Mandelson, to exercise the ingenuity for which he is famous. This is the kind of issue - there will be many more - which seems certain to steam the assembly up, but must not be allowed to bring it down. Which puts it in the same class as bombs on Hammersmith bridge and the manoeuvres of Dr Paisley's party.

fields.headline: Such men are dangerous
fields.standfirst: The rogue consultant has got off lightly
fields.trailText: Senior management was negligent and complacent. People who could have raised the alarm failed to do so, out of inertia, out of fear, or simply because, in the world which they moved in, the consultant was god.
fields.body:
Senior management was negligent and complacent. People who could have raised the alarm failed to do so, out of inertia, out of fear, or simply because, in the world which they moved in, the consultant was god. All are allotted appropriate blame in the fair and judicious report by Jean Ritchie QC on the case of the Kent consultant gynaecologist who left such a trail of misery behind him until he was finally sacked. But as the report also says: "Rodney Ledward bears the greatest responsibility for the failures in his practice."

The full truth of his disastrous reign in south Kent cannot even now be established. Not all his victims will have come forward: some are still too embarrassed to talk about the problems, like incontinence, with which they were left by his botching. The number of his victims probably runs into hundreds. In six cases, husbands blame him for the deaths of their wives. Not all the evidence which came before the Ritchie inquiry was hostile. Some patients recorded their gratitude for what he had done for them. Some pupils saluted his exceptional teaching skills. Some colleagues still say he was scapegoated. But all that fades when compared with the dreadful cata logue of Mr Ledward's malpractices: the apparently unnecessary operations on private patients; the equally needless hysterectomies for women in their twenties; the constant pressure on NHS patients to switch to his private practice; the frantic pace he worked at; the occasions when he turned up for operations apparently the worse for drink. And the blunders, the perforations of bladder and bowels - far more in a matter of years than a competent consultant could be expected to cause in a lifetime.

There are people serving substantial prison sentences for inflicting less misery, pain and bodily harm than he did. Though he never admitted as much, and does not now, he must have known the risks he was running and the permanent damage he was doing to patients. It was not in the remit of the Ritchie inquiry, but on the face of this evidence it is hard to see why - unless his health would preclude it - there has been no sign yet of criminal proceedings. He has lost his career, and the secretary of state is urgently considering his NHS pension, but even the loss of that seems a quite inadequate price for what he has done. Medicine was too lenient with Mr Ledward. The law should not make the same error.

webTitle: Anglican church in Canada says it faces bankruptcy from child abuse claims

fields.headline: Anglican church in Canada says it faces bankruptcy from child abuse claims
fields.trailText: The Anglican church in Canada is braced for bankruptcy, submerged by claims for damages for the alleged sexual abuse of native Canadians in its children's homes amounting to C$2bn (about £900m).
fields.body:
The Anglican church in Canada is braced for bankruptcy, submerged by claims for damages for the alleged sexual abuse of native Canadians in its children's homes amounting to C$2bn (about £900m).

Legal fees are rapidly eating into its reserves of C$10m, and attempts to persuade the government to bail it out have so far been unsuccessful. The government has even more cases of its own to deal with.

The church's 26 residential homes, some of which had been operating since the 1820s, were closed in 1969, and church leaders have been apologising ever since for the way they were run as part of a heartless attempt to assimilate tribal youngsters into white culture by removing them from their families and training them in the white man's ways.

This seems to have included not only emotional and physical abuse and neglect but also frequent sexual assaults.

In a statement read out at church services this week, the Primate of Canada, the Most Rev Michael Peers, admitted that the church would not be able to survive in its current form.

"We are faced with litigation so costly as to change radically our structures and our life as a national church," he said. "The legacy of the schools has been deeply wounding. We have an obligation and a will born of our desire to be just, to account for past injustice."

The revelations of the spartan and loveless conditions in the homes and the traumas suffered by the children who were forced into them mirror similar allegations involving schools and homes run by churches across the world, from Ireland to Australia.

The archbishop first admitted the Anglican church's culpability in an emotional statement to an Indian convention seven years ago.

Angry Indians walked out as he said: "I am sorry more than I can say that we were part of a system which took you and your children away from home and family, tried to remake you in our image, taking from you your language and the signs of your identity... that in our schools so many were abused physically, sexually, culturally and emotionally."

The Canadian Anglican Journal, which carried a long report on the affair last month, quoted one of the first to receive a settlement, Ben Pratt of the Gordon Indian reserve at Punnichy, in Saskatchewan.

Mr Pratt said: "It's not like the money will make me happy or make me feel better, but I might as well get something for what those bastards did to me.

"Around here it's called arse money. It's supposed to be dirty."

Mr Pratt is said to have received C$46,000 compensation for being repeatedly raped from the age of seven by William Starr, director of the residential home on the reservation in the 1960s, and later administrator of the school.

Mr Starr was convicted in 1993 of sexually assaulting 10 boys under 14 between 1968 and 1984.

At least 7,000 Indians have lodged cases, mostly against the government, although 1,600 of them cite the church as a co-defendant. The church's legal costs topped C$1.5m last year and already exceed C$150,000 this year.

Duncan Wallace, bishop of the Saskatchewan diocese of Qu'Appelle, told the journal: "If just 20 of the cases the church faces go the way the first one did, we will be bankrupt, there's no doubt about it."

At the church's national executive council last month, Archbishop Peers said: "There are those who say this is God's judgement that the church has lost its way.

"Maybe so, but the people being judged are from generations earlier... if bankruptcy becomes inevitable, we really are called to be the body of Christ Dead.

"Absolutely dead. And just as absolutely destined to rise."

fields.headline: News in brief
fields.trailText: Bomb damages Microsoft office
fields.body:
Bomb damages Microsoft office

An explosion in the courtyard of the South African offices of Microsoft in Johannesburg yesterday shattered windows but caused no injuries.

Four security guards were the only people in the building at the time. Reuters, Johannesburg

Nato cleared of war crimes

The chief UN war crimes prosecutor said yesterday there was no basis for a UN investigation into allegations that Nato committed war crimes during its air campaign in Yugoslavia.

"Although some mistakes were made by Nato, I am very satisfied there was no deliberate targeting of civilians or unlawful military targets," said Carla del Ponte. AP, United Nations

Blast kills eight in Kashmir

Eight people were killed and 11 wounded yesterday when a bomb went off near a religious gathering north of Srinagar in Kashmir.

Police said one of the wounded was a Kashmiri Shi'ite religious leader and ex-housing minister, Moulvi Iftikhar Hussain Ansari. Reuters, Srinagar

Exiled Aceh rebel murdered

An exiled leader of the Aceh rebel movement was killed in a restaurant in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, on Thursday, hours before a ceasefire between the separatists and Indonesian forces was due to begin.

The Free Aceh Movement blamed Teuku Don Zulfahri's murder on the Indonesian armed forces. The army rejected the claim. AP, Kuala Lumpur

Turkish ex-PM faces trial

A Turkish parliamentary committee yesterday voted to send Mesut Yilmaz, a former prime minister, before the supreme court to face charges of giving away state-owned land.

Mr Yilmaz's Motherland party is a junior partner in a three-party coalition. His case must still be reviewed by parliament before he can be tried. AP, Ankara

Swiss return Roman pottery

Switzerland has returned to Italy 3,000 pieces of Roman jewellery, statuary and pottery illegally excavated and smuggled across the border.

The items, seized by the Swiss authorities in 1995 and blocked since then by a wrangle over legal jurisdiction, are insured for 20m Swiss francs (£8m)but are probably worth far more. AP, Berne

Axe murderer 'kills again'

A woman freed from a prison psychiatric ward after serving four years for murdering her son with an axe has been accused of using an axe to kill her husband in a pig sty at their farm near Kalambaka, Greek police said yesterday.

Sotiria Loutriotis, 61, was undergoing psychiatric evaluation. AP, Kalambaka

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
Hepatitis scare for patients
Hundreds of patients operated on by a surgeon over the past five years are being asked to undergo tests after it emerged he is carrying the hepatitis C virus. Nearly 750 people who underwent surgery at the Selly Oak and Queen Elizabeth hospitals in Birmingham have been contacted. The surgeon, who has not been named, was not aware he had the virus.
fields.body:
Hepatitis scare for patients
Hundreds of patients operated on by a surgeon over the past five years are being asked to undergo tests after it emerged he is carrying the hepatitis C virus. Nearly 750 people who underwent surgery at the Selly Oak and Queen Elizabeth hospitals in Birmingham have been contacted. The surgeon, who has not been named, was not aware he had the virus.

Nuclear firm's £40,000 fine
British Nuclear Fuels Limited was yesterday fined £40,000 and ordered to pay £35,000 in costs for its sixth breach of health and safety at its Sellafield plant in the past decade. The case followed a spillage of 1,500 gallons of pressurised nitric acid at the Cumbria plant in March last year which caused damage estimated at £750,000 to equipment, and left three people slightly injured.

Castaways 'no' to Dodgy stunt
Pop group Dodgy, which turned up on Taransay in the Western Isles wanting to perform for the 35 members of the BBC's £2.4m Castaway project, was refused permission to play and ordered off the island. A BBC spokeswoman said: "That was exactly the kind of thing the castaways came to the island to avoid".

Health minister apologises
Health minister John Denham is to apologise to one of his Southampton constituents after he sent a letter about the NHS to her dead daughter. Jodie-Marie Bennett, 11, died 15 months ago at Southampton general hospital after surgery.

Pokemon attack on boy, 8
An eight-year-old boy was threatened with a flick-knife and beaten by a child about four years older who tried to steal his Pokemon cards. Lewis Parsons was attacked close to his home in Aldershot, Hampshire.

Headless man still a mystery
Detectives have released another computer-generated image of a man found decapitated in a park in Rednal, Birmingham, on Monday. They think he was aged about 30 and could have been a refugee, possibly from eastern Europe.

fields.headline: Arrest in Moro case
fields.trailText: French police in Corsica yesterday arrested a suspected former leader of the Italian Red Brigades who was wanted in connection with the assassination of the former Italian prime minister Aldo Moro more than 20 years ago, a police source said.
fields.body:
French police in Corsica yesterday arrested a suspected former leader of the Italian Red Brigades who was wanted in connection with the assassination of the former Italian prime minister Aldo Moro more than 20 years ago, a police source said.

Alvaro Loiacono, 50, was seized on a crowded beach in L'Ile Rousse, in the north of the island. He was said to have offered no resistance.

The police source said Mr Loiacono was suspected of being a senior figure in the far-left Red Brigades guerrilla movement, which was responsible for a string of murders and kidnappings in Italy in the 1970s and 1980s.

Besides the murder of Moro, who was kidnapped and shot dead in 1978, he was wanted in connection with at least nine other murders, including that of an Italian magistrate and five police officers.

The police source said that Loiacono had recently arrived in Corsica from Switzerland, and was travelling under a Swiss passport, using his mother's surname.

webTitle: US moves to freeze drug barons' profits

fields.headline: US moves to freeze drug barons' profits
fields.trailText: For the first time, the White House yesterday designated a "dirty dozen" kingpins of the international drugs trade, freezing their US assets and putting any companies which assist them under notice that they face millions of dollars in fines and other penalties.
fields.body:
For the first time, the White House yesterday designated a "dirty dozen" kingpins of the international drugs trade, freezing their US assets and putting any companies which assist them under notice that they face millions of dollars in fines and other penalties.

All 12 of the drugs bosses named by the Clinton administration yesterday are familiar enough figures in the global smuggling economy but there are doubts about the extent to which any of them currently has significant assets inside the US.

The move's primary significance is as part of a renewed attempt by the US to target a network of businesses and individuals who can be linked to the so-called "kingpins" with a range of tough economic sanctions.

The 12 were named in a letter sent by President Bill Clinton to the US Congress under the terms of the 1999 Drug Kingpin Designation Act, which establishes a global sanctions regime aimed against major international traffickers and their networks.

Six of the 12 are Mexicans, some of whom are already under arrest in their home country. The remaining six include two from south-east Asia, both currently based in Burma, two from the Caribbean and two who are on the run in Nigeria.

"This dirty dozen are at the start of a growing process which targets the bad guys rather than continuing with nation-to-nation head-butting," said a congressional aide to one of the drafters of the legislation.

The new law has been criticised by American civil liberties campaigners who warn that there is no effective redress for anyone who is wrongly designated under the act.

Mexico has also complained that the act could be used as part of a political campaign against Mexican immigrants in the US.

The Mexicans listed by Mr Clinton include two sets of brothers: the Tijuana-based Ramon and Benjamin Arellano-Felix, who run one of the most notoriously violent drugs operations in the Americas, and Jose de Jesus and Luis Ignacio Amezcua-Contreras, who control a Mexican-based metamphetamine cartel. Ramon Arellano-Felix is also currently on the FBI's "10 most wanted" list.

Rafael Caro Quintero, who is currently in prison in Mexico, and Vicente Carillo Fuentes, the head of the Juarez drugs cartel, complete the Mexican section of the White House kingpin list.

Also on the list are Chang Chi-Fu, more widely known as Khun Sa, and Wei Hsueh-Kang, both of whom are dominant figures in the south-east Asian drugs world and who both currently operate unhindered in Burma.

Oluwole and Abeni Ogungbuyi are Nigerians who fled from the US more than a decade ago following their arrest on charges of smuggling heroin.

The other two kingpins are Noel "Zambo" Heath and Glenroy "Bobo" Matthew, who come from St Kitts-Nevis and who are both wanted for extradition to the US on drugs charges which relate to their roles in Colombian cocaine cartels.

The principal aim of the designation of the 12 suspects is to target US or US-owned banks and businesses which can be linked to the kingpins' operations. Under the Kingpin Act, these companies face fines of up to $10m (£6.6m), with individuals liable for prison sentences of up to 30 years.

A list of such businesses must be published later this year by the US treasury department under the terms of the new law.

"This action underscores our determination to do everything possible to fight drug traffickers, undermine their operations and end the suffering that the trade in illegal drugs inflicts on Americans and people around the world," the presidential press secretary, Joe Lockhart, said in a statement.

"If this tool didn't exist, even if you were under indictment you could do business with a bank. You cannot do that now," said Senator Paul Coverdell, a Georgia Republican who was one of the two principal authors of the law, along with Senator Dianne Feinstein, a California Democrat.

"We now have improved tools to deny these criminals their illicit profits and track them down, no matter where they may hide," the White House drugs "tsar", General Barry McCaffrey, said.

Leaders of the 'dirty dozen'

Wei Hsueh-Kang Believed to be in hiding in Burma, the Chinese-born Wei, also known as Prasit Chivinnitipanya, is head of the United Wa State Army, the most powerful heroin smuggling organisation in south-east Asia. Sentenced to death in his absence in Thailand in 1987, he has a $2m US price on his head.

Chang Chi-Fu, also known as Khun Sa, the veteran drug baron and former leader of the Shan United Army now lives unhindered in Rangoon, having 'surrendered' to the Burmese regime in 1996. He controls an international heroin smuggling network, whose profits are laundered through the Burmese economy.

Ramon Arellano-Felix, who with his brother Benjamin, was also on yesterday's White House list. The 35-year-old Arellano-Felix leads the powerful and violent Mexican-based Tijuana cartel and is wanted for cocaine trafficking. The US government has issued a $2m reward for his capture.

fields.headline: Norris mugged for his £9,000 Rolex
fields.trailText: Steve Norris's conspicuous love of the finer things in life earned him some unwanted attention yesterday when a teenager snatched a £9,000 Rolex from his wrist.
fields.body:
Steve Norris's conspicuous love of the finer things in life earned him some unwanted attention yesterday when a teenager snatched a £9,000 Rolex from his wrist.

The former Conservative transport minister, and London mayoral contender, was stepping out of his Bentley in Buckhurst Hill, Essex, when the mugger pounced.

He was not seriously hurt in the robbery, but a spokesman said he had owned the watch for between 15 and 20 years and it had sentimental value.

Aides had suggested Mr Norris tuck the watch away before a photo shoot for his mayoral campaign, but he insisted on making it visible, declaring: "I'm proud of it," the spokesman recalled.

Mr Norris said yesterday: "It was all over in a matter of seconds and I have lost a posses sion I valued very highly, but I am none the worse for wear and life goes on."

Mr Norris had been in Buckhurst Hill for a business meeting and was just getting out of his Bentley when a car pulled up and a teenager jumped out, ran towards him and pulled the watch from his wrist.

He was robbed outside a boutique called Personal Touch.

Mr Norris had no time to react, the spokesman said: "Steve is not a shrinking violet, and he is a big fellow, but the kid used the element of surprise."

The 55-year-old former Epping Forest MP felt he had escaped lightly compared with some victims of violent street attacks, the spokesman added.

Mr Norris is the latest in a line of high-profile figures to have their Rolexes stolen. Victims have included the ex-topless model Jilly Johnson and actress Britt Ekland.

webTitle: Renegade spy to give himself up in return for tribunal hearing

fields.headline: Renegade spy to give himself up in return for tribunal hearing
fields.trailText: Richard Tomlinson, the former MI6 officer, is prepared to return to Britain to face trial for his alleged breaches of the Official Secrets Act provided he is first allowed to present his case for unfair dismissal to an industrial tribunal.
fields.body:
Richard Tomlinson, the former MI6 officer, is prepared to return to Britain to face trial for his alleged breaches of the Official Secrets Act provided he is first allowed to present his case for unfair dismissal to an industrial tribunal.

Speaking in the Adriatic resort of Rimini, Mr Tomlinson said his lawyers have made a formal offer to the British authorities in the hope that he will be allowed to clear his name before an impartial appeals tribunal. The development follows recent reports that MI5 whistleblower David Shayler is also ready to return from France to face trial on similar charges.

Mr Tomlinson has been locked in a bitter battle with his former employers since being dismissed in 1995. He spent six months in prison for sending a book synopsis to an Australian publisher and is suspected of having published the names of 116 alleged MI6 officers on the internet. Mr Tomlinson said he hoped the dispute could be resolved through negotiation, but remains committed to obtaining redress.

"I regret the whole thing, but I felt I had no other choice but to do it this way," he told the Guardian. "Former employees have a lifetime duty of confidentiality. I would support that if MI6 gave a lifetime commitment to fair treatment. If they allowed me to take my case to a tribunal you would never hear my name again."

Mr Tomlinson is still indignant that he was sacked after three and a half years as a probationer in the intelligence service. The former spy, who served in Moscow and the Balkans, said he was given no warning and no credible reason for his dismissal. "I feel a sense of injustice every waking minute and a sense of frustration that I can't bring this to the negotiating table."

His main objective now is to prove to the world that his dismissal was both "breathtakingly arrogant" and unfair. "That to me is worth everything. It's an important part of my psychological makeup. Being sacked unreasonably is a tremendous impediment to getting on with my life."

His efforts have included attempts to publish his memoirs in Australia and threats to post a damaging exposé of MI6 on the internet, but not, Mr Tomlinson insisted, the publication of the 116 MI6 officers' names. That list, he said, was probably published by MI6 itself to get him expelled from Switzerland.

Mr Tomlinson, who has joint British and New Zealand citizenship, is negotiating with a Moscow publisher for a book on his experience of being hounded around Europe over the past five years. The latest episode came on May 18 when Italian police accompanied by two British Special Branch officers raided his apartment in Rimini and took personal papers and computer equipment.

"They forgot to bring a bag, so they took one of my suitcases and a blanket, which doesn't even belong to me," he said. "They took everything electronic, even my stereo. The only thing they didn't take was the TV - perhaps because it wouldn't fit into my suitcase. It was really very amateurish."

The intelligence service needs to modernise its management practices, institute an impartial appeals process and radically reform its secrecy regime to equip itself for the post-cold war world, he said.

webTitle: Clinton faces European flak for 'son of star wars'

fields.headline: Clinton faces European flak for 'son of star wars'
fields.standfirst: President's farewell tour marred by row over US missile shield
fields.trailText: Bill Clinton's valedictory European tour was marred yesterday by blunt public criticism that US plans to develop a controversial missile defence system could rekindle a global arms race and weaken Nato.
fields.byline: Tony Paterson  in Berlin, Ian Black  in Brussels and Ian Traynor  in Moscow
fields.body:
Bill Clinton's valedictory European tour was marred yesterday by blunt public criticism that US plans to develop a controversial missile defence system could rekindle a global arms race and weaken Nato.

The US president was in Aachen to receive the coveted International Charlemagne prize for European Unity but behind the compliments there was rising anger at plans for the so-called "son of star wars" scheme - a defence shield designed to protect the US from nuclear missiles.

"Of course, it is the sovereign right of our American allies to make the decision which they regard as necessary for their external security," the German chancellor Gerhard Schröder said, after the two leaders discussed the issue on Thursday. "However, as this issue could have an impact far beyond the United States, it is in the alliance's interest to deal with it in a spirit of friendship."

Earlier this week the French president, Jacques Chirac, issued a similarly candid warning, asking: "How do you convince [nations] to stop piling up new arms when more powerful countries say it's necessary to develop technologies that put hard-won strategic balances into question?"

The comments added to a rising chorus of concern from the US's European allies.

Mr Clinton can also expect to encounter concern in Moscow today when he meets the Russian president, Vladimir Putin, for the first time - but there were signs last night that an agreement could be reached.

Mr Clinton's European tour, which ends in Ukraine, is expected to be his last before the presidential elections in November, unless he re-visits Northern Ireland.

Earlier this week, at the biennial US-EU summit in Lisbon, he sidestepped unresolved transatlantic trade disputes over hormone-treated beef, bananas, and tax subsidies to promise worried Europeans that the controversial missile technology could be shared with "civilised nations".

Washington says the multibillion dollar defence system is needed to shoot down rockets fired by rogue states such as Iraq and North Korea.

Returning yesterday to European fears of US domination, Mr Clinton pledged to strengthen the transatlantic bond many believe has frayed in the post-cold war period.

But Mr Schröder stressed the importance of fledgling European defence efforts. These worry the US, which fears that complex EU arrangements will never produce a credible military force and may undermine Nato.

Many Europeans feel that last year's Kosovo crisis underlined the urgency of creating autonomous defence forces, though more progress has been made on building bureaucratic structures than fighting capabilities.

Mr Chirac also called for EU governments to push ahead with plans to create a 60,000-strong mobile force.

In Moscow, meanwhile, Mr Putin told NBC television that the countries could develop the proposed missile shield together. While it remains unclear whether the US is prepared to share its interception technology, the Russian leader hinted that such an arrangement might produce a compromise.

"Such mechanisms are possible if we pool our efforts towards neutralising the threats against the US, Russia, our allies, and Europe in general," Mr Putin said. "We have such proposals and we intend to discuss them with President Clinton."

Signalling his good intentions in his Aachen speech, the US president urged Europeans to try to make Russia welcome. "No doors can be sealed shut to Russia, not Nato's, not those of the European Union," he said.

The EU's other task was to "de-Balkanise" the south-east of Europe and make it a full part of a united continent.

Mr Clinton was the first American president to receive the Charlemagne prize, which has previously been awarded to Sir Winston Churchill, Konrad Adenauer and Tony Blair.

fields.headline: A Country Diary
fields.standfirst: North Pembrokshire
fields.trailText: A group of volunteers was walking through the sand dunes behind Newport beach picking up any rubbish. From the corner of my eye I saw one of those elasticated wire straps you use to keep things firm on your bicycle carrier. Leaning over   to grasp it I suddenly saw that it was watching me. I'd almost turmoiled with an adder, or more powerfully, a viper, from its Latin name vipera berus.
fields.body:
A group of volunteers was walking through the sand dunes behind Newport beach picking up any rubbish. From the corner of my eye I saw one of those elasticated wire straps you use to keep things firm on your bicycle carrier. Leaning over to grasp it I suddenly saw that it was watching me. I'd almost turmoiled with an adder, or more powerfully, a viper, from its Latin name vipera berus.

It was enjoying the warm sunshine on top of the marram grass. The main colour was a delicate soft grey with a strong dark brown zig-zag. We looked at each other before I quietly retreated. Its scales were lying like roof tiles on its body. Underneath, like our fingernails, is the skin with its nerves and blood vessels. Too pretentious to say, as DH Lawrence writes in Snake, "I felt so honoured", but I did.

And in the garden I saw a beautiful demoiselle preparing herself for life. She must have come from the stream that runs down the side. The air was busy with red and blue damselflies, but they'd all come out of the pond. The beautiful demoiselle - what a name! - needs running water. She'd honoured our hedge for her filling out.

Another astonishment was provided by a great tit on the terrace during breakfast. It was behaving oddly round a flower pot. A quick stab at the ground was immediately followed by one wing stretching with the tail wrapped towards it whilst the beak probed its oxter. All this was done with an air of detached concentration, as if the bird were in a trance and somehow compelled to circle the pot stabbing and poking, stretching and bending.

After it flew off I found the small ants hustling around the pot. It was the first time I'd seen such a small bird "anting". fields.bodyText: A group of volunteers was walking through the sand dunes behind Newport beach picking up any rubbish. From the corner of my eye I saw one of those elasticated wire straps you use to keep things firm on your bicycle carrier. Leaning over to grasp it I suddenly saw that it was watching me. I'd almost turmoiled with an adder, or more powerfully, a viper, from its Latin name vipera berus. It was enjoying the warm sunshine on top of the marram grass. The main colour was a delicate soft grey with a strong dark brown zig-zag. We looked at each other before I quietly retreated. Its scales were lying like roof tiles on its body. Underneath, like our fingernails, is the skin with its nerves and blood vessels. Too pretentious to say, as DH Lawrence writes in Snake, "I felt so honoured", but I did. And in the garden I saw a beautiful demoiselle preparing herself for life. She must have come from the stream that runs down the side. The air was busy with red and blue damselflies, but they'd all come out of the pond. The beautiful demoiselle - what a name! - needs running water. She'd honoured our hedge for her filling out. webTitle: Mountain roads, hairpin bends and no speed limit: this is biker heaven

fields.headline: Mountain roads, hairpin bends and no speed limit: this is biker heaven
fields.standfirst: Motorcyclists from all over the world still flock to the Isle of Man for their yearly joust with death
fields.trailText: Motorcyclists from all over the world still flock to the Isle of Man for their yearly joust with death
fields.body:
We pulled hard out of Ramsey in third, feeling the nudge in the back as we hit the slope of May Hill. No fog; that was waiting higher up the mountain: visibility 30 yards maximum, they said. A lean to the left and to the right; then on to Stella Maris and throttle back for the great Hairpin, 150 degrees of twist and rise.

Up to the fields, the golden gorse, the glimpse of the sea. On to the wide sweep to Gooseneck, where we parked the Fiesta, used the Portaloo and watched a host of red, purple, lime green and occasionally pink Hondas, Suzukis and Kawasakis disappear over the slopes of Snaefell towards Douglas.

We car drivers, whose eyes flicker nervously in wing mirrors during TT fortnight on the Isle of Man, were yesterday dismissed as bumbling numpties by a Scottish biker and others who swarm here to do what they cannot do anywhere else: ride as fast as they like on public roads.

Down by the grandstand where races start and finish in this, the 93rd year of burning rubber and blaring exhausts, the Scotsman and his friends, some bleary after the night before, emerge to begin one of the Isle of Man TT's great rites: wandering, looking, smoking. And talking about bikes.

Across from the grandstand and its results board is a large cemetery, with a crematorium like a mosque. Some bikers park outside its gates but do not glance inside, fearing perhaps a grim reminder of what can happen if you lose it on a bend up by Black Hut or Kate's Cottage.

But soon there will be three funerals of three bikers who were killed this week during practices on the 37-mile twisting mountain circuit on which bikes reach speeds of more than 130mph.

Racing proper does not start until today and more riders may die; the grim tally of fatalities since racing began in 1907 could soon top 200. Someone soon is bound to call for a ban. But the bikers will have none of it.

And neither it seems will sports minister Kate Hoey, who will today ride the full circuit on the back of a bike. "It's always a tragedy when someone dies in a sports event and no one is more concerned about that than the people who run the sports," she said.

"All sports are risky and some are more risky than others. This is one of the biggest road races in the world. My father came in 1938 and he told me how exciting it was. I've always wanted to come.

Deborah Christie, 29, a manager for a haulage company, is making her eighth trip from Aberdeenshire, this time with her mighty red Yamaha R1 1000.

"No one has the right to say we shouldn't do this any more. Everyone knows the dangers when they come. Everyone who comes does so at at his or her own free will. I'll keep coming back."

Ms Christie, who bought her own bike five years ago when she got fed up with sitting on the back, will not be out tomorrow for the one-way free-for-all known as Mad Sunday when everyone can have a go.

"It's just a little too much for me," she admits. Not that she's afraid of hitting 140mph up on the mountain. "It's just a brilliant buzz. This is the only place in the British Isles where you can do these speeds legally. I get the feeling that I have to take the bike in front - and then the bike in front of that."

She loves the companionship, the camaraderie. "As a biker, you can go up to a complete stranger and they'll talk to you. You don't get that with cars - you can't just go up to a stranger and blather away. It's a unique lifestyle."

Just so, says Peter Christian from Leicestershire and a regular for almost 50 years: "I've touched 120mph in my time."

Just so, agrees Lord Jopling, the former Tory chief whip and owner of a Yamaha FJ 1200: "People go mountaineering and dive to great depths. People do all manner of dangerous things. It is part of human nature to take risks."

Around the circuit they have doctors and ambulances; back in Douglas there is a helicopter on the rugby ground and another on standby.

"Although one worries greatly about safety, one has to accept that a circuit on closed public roads can never be as safe as on a short specialist circuit," admits Neil Hanson, clerk to the TT course. "Riders have to accept that and make up their minds what sort of racing they want to take part in."

There is much admiration for Mirko Bonetti, who has spent five days travelling from Milan on his slightly tweaked veteran Vespa 50: light blue with gearstick, TT flag and not much room for luggage.

"All the way on that?" asks an astonished English leatherman. "I am a lover of old bikes," explains Mirko, his nose peeling with autoroute sunburn. "This is the capital of the races in the world. All the racing here has always been a big attraction. So why not come?"

Rudi Anderegg, 52, on his third visit from his home near Zurich, is relishing a most unSwiss freedom. "We have many mountain roads but they are very strict in Switzerland - no faster than 80kms an hour. Plenty of check-ups and fines.

"I started late and bought my first bike only 10 years ago. Safety is the main thing. If you concentrate, it's OK."

Down on the prom, an extremely bent Honda lies propped up by a lamp-post with a contributions box on its seat and a note reading, "Please help fix me."

As sympathetic riders dropped in a few quid, a friend of the rider says: "He has a broken leg, broken arm, fractured pelvis and possibly a punctured spleen. But the engine's OK."

Road tolls: High cost of racing

Since their inception in 1907, 199 people have been killed in the Isle of Man TT races.

These are the number of participants killed in both the TT races and the Manx Grand Prix during the worst years for casualties since 1960:

1961

1991

1996

webTitle: Widow leaves £5m to buy art for Britain

fields.headline: Widow leaves £5m to buy art for Britain
fields.trailText: A widow who died childless has left shares and property worth more than £5m to an art charity, the National Art Collections Fund, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
A widow who died childless has left shares and property worth more than £5m to an art charity, the National Art Collections Fund, it emerged yesterday.

Brenda Knapp's bequest is the biggest in the fund's history. It will be used to help British public collections acquire sought-after works.

The charity said Mrs Knapp, who died last October aged 95, was not the first in her family to remember art in her will. Her brother George Washington Fox left a large sum to the fund on his death in 1985.

Born Brenda Ulrica Washington, Mrs Knapp married accountant Hubert Knapp in 1938. After being widowed in 1978, Mrs Knapp became "something of a recluse", but remained on friendly terms with her neighbours in Kingston Hill, Surrey, and spent her time tending her garden.

She joined the art charity as a life member in 1986, and was always determined to "save art" for the country. She spent the last 10 years of her life in a nursing home.

She was a keen supporter of many charities and developed a considerable knowledge of art history. After her death a three-foot high pile of art catalogues and magazines was found beside her bed.

Sir Nicholas Goodison, chairman of the art fund, said yesterday: "Brenda Knapp's extraordinary bequest means that her love of art will live on.

"Mrs Knapp was adamant that works of art should not leave the country because there was not enough money in the public purse, and her bequest will go a long way towards ensuring that money will be available for galleries and museums to purchase works of art that may otherwise be lost to the public."
