webTitle: £1,000 to shoot a ruddy randy duck

fields.headline: £1,000 to shoot a ruddy randy duck
fields.trailText: The ruddy duck could go down as the most expensive duck in history - and it is too small to be considered worth eating.
fields.body:
The ruddy duck could go down as the most expensive duck in history - and it is too small to be considered worth eating.

The ruddy, condemned to die because of its sexual prowess, is costing the taxpayer £1,000 a bird to exterminate. The Department of Environment has been carrying out a cull of the frisky birds in order to stop them flying south to mate with an endangered Spanish white-headed duck.

But next week officials will be forced to admit the remarkable cost of the venture. The elusive ruddy is proving anything but a sitting duck - marksmen hired to shoot it on its nest have only managed to kill 800 in a year, when the target was 4,000. The cost so far is £840,000.

The first batch of sharpshooters hired to destroy the females and thus reduce the population baulked at killing them while they were protecting their eggs.

When the killing finally got going last year after a tougher breed of hunters was hired by the department, the ducks often proved too quick off the mark. They were reported diving under water and swimming into the reeds.

The department last night said: "We have two more years at this experiment. It is too early to say its a failure."

Culling has begun again this year with marksmen looking for birds to shoot on their nests. Some organisations, notably the Royal Society for the Protection of Birds, support the killing, but many wildlife groups protest.

Ursula Bates, of Solihull Animal Aid, said: "The Spanish argue they don't want to mix the species but what does it matter whether a duck has a white head or not? The ducks look almost the same, other than that. Who are we to play God?"

Ruddy ducks originate from North America. They were brought to Europe by Sir Peter Scott, who founded the Slimbridge Wildlife Trust in Gloucestershire.

Some escaped from an enclosure and have since been breeding in Britain and elsewhere in Europe.

The RSPB believes the ruddy ducks have brought the white headed duck to the brink of extinction "because ruddy ducks fly out to Spain and compete with the males. They are very vigorous and successful in the mating game. We certainly do not enjoy the idea of a cull, but if the only option available is an unpleasant one, it should still be carried out."

webTitle: Hospital suffers bitter legacy of organ scandal

fields.headline: Hospital suffers bitter legacy of organ scandal
fields.standfirst:
Strain is telling on staff as they pick up the pieces at Alder Hey, its reputation shattered by retention of children's organs without consent

The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: For some parents it is the rocking horse logo that angers them. Its prominent position on letters from Alder Hey hospital informing them that their children's organs have been harvested does little to ease their grief. Others have focused their rage on the hospital itself and have rounded on the staff.
fields.body:
For some parents it is the rocking horse logo that angers them. Its prominent position on letters from Alder Hey hospital informing them that their children's organs have been harvested does little to ease their grief. Others have focused their rage on the hospital itself and have rounded on the staff.

Eight months after it emerged that the organs of 893 children were removed and retained without their parents' consent, Europe's biggest children's hospital is still struggling to come to terms with the crisis. The bright cartoon murals that decorate the corridors and wards of the Liverpool complex belie a darker mood among staff and parents.

Eddie Allen was camped outside the wrought-iron gates of the hospital for about eight days last month after he found out that many of his daughter's organs had been kept. Kathleen, 18 months, died there almost 10 years ago after heart surgery. He was protesting at the behaviour of the pathologist, Dick van Velzen, who was responsible for harvesting organs.

For the first few days Mr Allen slept on the pavement, but when the weather turned colder his supporters gave him a tent. Other parents placed flowers next to the tent, turning the pavement into a makeshift shrine.

"I have three other daughters," he said. "If, God forbid, any of them fell ill I would not hesitate in bringing them to Alder Hey for treatment because the nursing and medical staff treated us very well. But it is the actions of the pathologist that I have a problem with."

Not all parents are so pragmatic. Denise Foy, whose baby son Nicky's organs were retained when he died after heart surgery in 1990, said: "I would travel a long way to avoid taking any of my children to Alder Hey."

Last month she discovered that most of her son's organs had been kept, after initially being given a much shorter list of organs. "It has taken eight months after we first asked the hospital which organs had been retained for us to get the full list," she said. "Our family has been absolutely devastated by what has happened. There was hardly anything left of him when we buried him."

The hospital's family liaison unit has borne the brunt of the parents' anger. Sue Chapman, one of its staff, has had dozens of parents in her office demanding answers. "I worked on the helpline from the day the story broke in September until Christmas, and it got to the point where I didn't want to open my door any more to speak to anyone," she said.

"I had one man in my office pulling the leaves off one of my plants because he was so angry about what had happened to his child. I told him that I couldn't help him if he stood there shouting, and eventually he calmed down."

She said it was impossible for staff not to have been affected by the stories they heard. "Some people have dropped out from the helpline after a couple of weeks because they can't handle it."

Chris Doyle, an advanced nurse practitioner with 18 years' experience at Alder Hey, lasted a month before she dropped out. Twice she had to break the news to parents that their children's organs had been retained. "It was probably one of the most distressing things I have ever had to do," she said. "I realised that it was something I couldn't go on doing.

"It really upsets me when parents say they hate this place. There is so much good going on that seems to have been forgotten about. I am sure the parents cannot be critical of the nursing or medical care that their children have received here."

She said staff needed to put the organ retention issue behind them and concentrate on the positive work being done.

Tony Bell, acting chief executive, and Judith Greensmith, new chairman of the hospital trust, are picking up the pieces left by the previous management. Mr Bell said the controversy had led to an increase in stress-related illness among staff. Morale had also been hit.

"The hospital found itself in the middle of a major incident, and the issues seemed to get worse and worse," he said. "The temptation was to try to close down the incident and control it, and that is when the parents felt they were being distanced from the hospital.

"The staff who have been dealing with the relatives feel traumatised by what they have gone through - it has affected everyone one way or another. We have had members of staff who have had children who died at the hospital or who have relatives who have been touched by the tragedy."

Ms Greensmith said: "I do not think we are going to get this sorted out quickly. But we hope that once the inquiry is over and, hopefully, the parents get the answers they require, we will be able to put this behind us."

Other parents have nothing but praise for the medical care their children have received at Alder Hey. Dorothy Dickenson, from the Wirral, has been bring ing her severely disabled son Colin for treatment for 15 years. "When I first heard about organ retention I thought it was horrendous, and I felt very sad for the parents involved," she said. "But it has not put me off bringing my son here, as the care we receive is superb."

Ian Peart, consultant cardiologist, said that though many parents had been told that hearts were kept for research, staff had not known that other organs were being retained. "There was never any intention to deceive any of the families," he said.

Consultants now had a much more detailed understanding of the anatomy and morphology of a congenitally malformed heart. Ten years ago the death rate for heart surgery was 16.4%, but by 1998-99 it had fallen to 3.6%.

For some consultants, the impact of the scandal has been far reaching. Barry Pizer, who works in the cramped oncology department, had hoped that work would begin on a multi-million pound unit this year, but it has been delayed because of a £1.5m funding shortfall.

"Because of the issues relating to the inquiry, fundraising has tailed off, and it is very frustrating for doctors and nurses," he said. "We just want to create the best environment and provide the best facilities for patients that we can."

"But it has not put me off bringing my son here, as the care we receive is superb." Ian Peart, consultant cardiologist, said that though many parents had been told that hearts were kept for research, staff had not known that other organs were being retained. "There was never any intention to deceive any of the families," he said. Consultants now had a much more detailed understanding of the anatomy and morphology of a congenitally malformed heart. Ten years ago the death rate for heart surgery was 16.4%, but by 1998-99 it had fallen to 3.6%. For some consultants, the impact of the scandal has been far reaching. Barry Pizer, who works in the cramped oncology department, had hoped that work would begin on a multi-million pound unit this year, but it has been delayed because of a £1.5m funding shortfall. "Because of the issues relating to the inquiry, fundraising has tailed off, and it is very frustrating for doctors and nurses," he said. "We just want to create the best environment and provide the best facilities for patients that we can."

fields.headline: Knife-edge issue for French justice
fields.standfirst: The justice minister is pondering the release of the murderer who consigned the guillotine to history
fields.trailText: Outside the courthouse in Troyes, on a January day in 1977, a placard-waving crowd was screaming at the windows: "Death! Death to the bastard!"
fields.body:
Outside the courthouse in Troyes, on a January day in 1977, a placard-waving crowd was screaming at the windows: "Death! Death to the bastard!"

Inside, a wild-eyed young lawyer on the verge of tears was screaming at the jury.

"You, and you alone, have the right of life or death," he cried.

"If you decide to kill Patrick Henry, it is each of you that I will see before me tomorrow morning, at dawn. I will say to myself that it is you, you alone, who decided. Do not add to the death of a child that of a young man."

Twenty-three years after the trial that led France to abolish the guillotine, the justice minister, Elisabeth Guigou, began considering whether the child murderer saved from death by that lawyer's inspired pleading should be freed from jail.

"It is", she admitted, "one of the most difficult decisions I have ever faced. All the expert opinions I have now received are positive. But this man killed a child."

Few cases have divided France like that of Patrick Henry, who abducted Philippe Bertrand, seven, from outside his primary school in the village of Pont-Sainte-Marie on January 30 1976.

He strangled him, took the body to a room he had rented under a false name in nearby Troyes, wrapped it in a blanket and stuffed it under the bed.

Henry, a local man with a couple of previous convictions for cheque forgeries and a minor traffic accident, was arrested as a possible suspect within days. A bespectacled, blond-haired young man of 22, a keen Sunday fisherman, he turned out to have helped energetically in the manhunt for little Philippe and was soon released.

Then, as national hysteria grew steadily with the continuing failure to find any trace of the boy, Henry appeared on a popular television chat show to declare firmly that, in his view, "People who kidnap children deserve death."

He had protested too much: on February 17 the police discovered the rented room. Henry was captured while trying to escape over the roof.

It emerged that Henry had called Philippe's parents less than an hour after the kidnapping to demand a million francs in ransom - for a little boy who was already dead.

The uproar in Troyes and throughout France was immense. Letters poured in to the police, the court, the mayor of Troyes, calling for "the monster" to be "starved to death", "tortured before his execution", "strangled with the same cord he used to kill Philippe".

The then justice minister, Michel Poniatowski, expressed the hope that justice would be "swift, and brutal".

Henry's chosen lawyer, Jean Berner, refused to represent him. A second withdrew after receiving threats to his life. The third, Robert Badinter, was still tortured by the memory of watching, four years previously, two of his clients die "from the blade that slices a living being in two".

Mr Badinter put the death penalty rather than his guilty client on trial. His courtroom performance is seen today - as it was by almost every observer at the time - as having dealt the death penalty an ultimately fatal blow.

Although two other murderers were executed, in February and September 1977, they were the last to be sentenced to death in France.

In 1981, four years after saving Henry's life, Mr Badinter returned to centre stage as justice minister. His first major act was to abolish the death penalty.

"You will not regret your decision," Henry told the shellshocked judge who relayed to him the jury's refusal to impose the death sentence. By all accounts, he has kept his word: now 46, he has gained his baccalaureat, a maths degree and an advanced computer programming qualification during his years in prison.

He has founded a small company, employing fellow prisoners, to develop software for schools. He is guaranteed a job in the field if he is released. He has passed half a dozen successive parole boards with flying colours, and his psychologists' reports are favourable.

But Ms Guigou, perhaps unsurprisingly, is hesitating. Next year, thanks to one of her own laws, the decision to free life prisoners will be taken out of the hands of the justice minister and given to a specialist tribunal.

This one though is hers and, as Mr Badinter might have said, hers alone. Philippe Bertrand's parents have already said they do not want their son's murderer freed. Public opinion appears to back them, albeit by a slender margin. Against that Ms Guigou must weight her personal belief in the possibility that even the most savage criminal can reform.

It will not be an easy call.

fields.headline: Ministers blamed for power crisis
fields.standfirst: Britain's nuclear industry: special report
fields.trailText: The nuclear industry is being driven close to bankruptcy and the development of renewable energy sources is being stalled by government determination to drive down electricity prices.
fields.body:
The nuclear industry is being driven close to bankruptcy and the development of renewable energy sources is being stalled by government determination to drive down electricity prices.

A last-ditch attempt to save both industries will be made this month when the House of Lords debates the utilities bill which was designed to improve competition in the electricity industry but will probably kill off parts of it.

The idea is to make electricity producers bid for the right to supply the national grid, with the lowest tender winning.

With the price of gas so low new gas stations can bid at as little as 1.9p a kilowatt hour, compared with the previous average price of 2.5p.

British Energy, the privatised nuclear giant, cannot produce electricity at that price from any of its nine stations. It will make a loss on every transaction or have to shut its reactors. The company, which has seen its share price tumble, is making every cut it can to survive.

The renewables industry, previously thought to be poised for takeoff, is also shelving plans for off-shore wind farms and bio-mass plants.

A scheme to build a factory in Scotland to make wind turbines by Vestas, the world's biggest turbine manufacturer, has been put on hold and will be abandoned unless the government changes tack. The government is permitted by the European commission to subsidise renewables for five years to get the industry off the ground.

The government originally planned to make it compulsory for electricity distribution companies to buy 10% of all the electricity they sold from renewable sources and planned to impose penalties on those companies that did not comply. But because renewable energy is so expensive, companies may find it sometimes preferable to pay those penalties than buy green electricity.

Critics describe the Department of Trade and Industry as "an adventure playground for young Thatcherite economists." Attempts in the Commons to safeguard the government's 10% target for renewables by including it in the bill were voted down before Easter and the industry thinks it will be impossible to reach.

Silvan Robinson, chairman of British Biogen, was hoping to build power stations using fast growing wood. The Ministry of Agriculture had earmarked £30m to help farmers to get started but he would not be able to build the plants without a guaranteed market snatched away by the bill.

Britain has 50% of the potential wind energy in Europe that could be converted by turbines into electricity but has only installed 5% of Europe's windmills.

A spokesman for the Department of Trade and Industry acknowledged there were problems both for the nuclear industry and renewables but said the bill was designed to make companies more competitive.

British Energy is trying to renegotiate reprocessing contracts with British Nuclear Fuels to cut its costs for dealing with spent nuclear fuel by two thirds, and has shut its visitor centres.

A spokesman said: "We have got our unit prices down but not as fast as the market has tumbled."

fields.headline: Dot.com name owner rejects £4.4m offer
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: What's in a name? Millions of pounds, apparently, if you register a lucrative domain name on the internet.
fields.body:
What's in a name? Millions of pounds, apparently, if you register a lucrative domain name on the internet.

Peter Littke, a businessman, has turned down a £4.4m offer for e-buy.com, the name he registered three years ago for $100 (£63). It is the second offer he has rejected from the Californian company of the same name.

Domain names can be registered on a first-come, first-served basis for as little as £30 a year.

Mr Littke, from Bookham, Surrey, decided that he could make more money by using the name for his own project, to be launched in September, even though "it felt like a lottery win".

He said: "It was a very tempting offer, but I have been working for three and a half years on a different concept, whereby e-buy.com only forms part of it. I had to say no because we are too far down the road."

But there is a flip side to the name goldrush. Jeanette Winterson, the Whitbread prize-winning novelist, won a legal battle for her name last month. Her name and those of 130 other novelists had been registered as domain names by Mark Hogarth, a Cambridge University academic, in the hope of selling them back at a big profit, a process known as cybersquatting. But an intellectual property tribunal ruled last month that Mr Hogarth had acted in bad faith.

Other companies have paid a high price for names. Halifax paid £600,000 for If.com, the brand of its new internet banking service. BAA claimed that a cyberpirate demanded £2m for Baa.com, a site devoted to all things woolly.

fields.headline: Joan Tough
fields.standfirst: Educating the primary teachers
fields.trailText: Joan Tough, who has died aged 82, started her career as a primary schoolteacher and went on to become one of the leading figures in primary education. As a university teacher, author, and a speaker with an international reputation, she influenced countless teachers, offering them insights into how children learn and how they might be best educated.
fields.body:
Joan Tough, who has died aged 82, started her career as a primary schoolteacher and went on to become one of the leading figures in primary education. As a university teacher, author, and a speaker with an international reputation, she influenced countless teachers, offering them insights into how children learn and how they might be best educated.

Joan was born in Manchester - her father was the correspondent in France of the Manchester Guardian - but lived most of her life in the Bingley area of Yorkshire. She attended Bingley Grammar School and trained as a teacher at Goldsmiths College and at the Froebel Institute in London.

She taught in several Yorkshire primary schools before becoming a headteacher and then a lecturer at Margaret MacMillan College in Bradford. In 1965, she was appointed to Leeds University's Institute of Education to research and contribute to a post-experience course in education.

Her first main research project, a longitudinal study of the language development of more than 60 West Riding children, set out among other things to examine the effect of nursery education on the children's subsequent progress. It revealed aspects of children's use of language and a range of skills that could have implications for their learning at home and at school.

These are discussed in her first book, Focus on Meaning (1973), and later in The Development of Meaning (1977). In 1970 Joan became director of the advanced course of study for the year-long diploma in primary education at Leeds University. She was awarded her PhD in 1971.

In the early 1970s, she carried out a feasibility study to discover how research into children's language skills might help teachers' effectiveness in schools. As a re sult, in 1973 the Schools Council communication skills in early childhood project was set up at Leeds University, with Joan as the director. She was one of the first to attract outside funding to support educational research. The work involved 90 groups of teachers and the help of advisers in many local education authorities. Joan and her small team in Leeds began designing materials to help teachers develop the necessary skills.

The first Schools Council publication, Listening to Children Talking, was published in 1976, followed by Talking and Learning in 1977. These were guides to be used by individual teachers and were also the basis for group discussion and workshop sessions. A series of videotapes and discussion notes were also published. In 1976 the project was extended to cover the 7-13 age range, and in 1978 a further extension focused on the special needs of children with moderate learning difficulties. As a result, Talk for Teaching and Learning (1979) was followed by A Place for Talk (1981).

The final phase of the project, from 1981 to 1983, focused on helping children acquire English as a second or additional language, and Talk Two was published in 1985. The books and workshop materials had an immediate impact. Ideas were presented clearly; suggestions were based on experience. The many examples and transcripts in the books, as well as the excerpts on videotape, illustrated how teachers could develop skills and put them into practice.

The Schools Council remit was to work with teachers in England, Wales and Northern Ireland, but eventually courses were held for teachers and teacher-educators from abroad. Joan was a fine speaker and she always made an impressive contribution to the conferences, seminars and symposia, which took her all over the world. A chance holiday encounter with a woman in Nepal in the early 1990s revealed that she had attended one of Joan's courses at Leeds and was now working with the women in her village to put her ideas into practice.

In 1979 Joan was awarded the CBE; she retired in 1983, but continued to write, lecture and travel professionally until 1986. She was a city councillor in Bradford for 12 years until 1999, being a member of a number of education committees. At the time of her death, she was chair of the Bradford early years partnership and heavily involved in the city's outdoor education centres.

Joan was remarkable for her energy and her ability to get things done, but she also enjoyed her family and friends, her home and her garden. She and her husband Alec were warm and hospitable. Alec died in 1987.

Joan is survived by their two sons and a daughter.

Yvonne Avice Dorothy Joan Tough, educationalist, born January 20 1918; died May 10 2000

fields.headline: Underside
fields.trailText: Tremendous news from the battle against road congestion. "Across Britain nearly 250 people plan to scrap their car this Sunday in exchange for an annual bus pass," trumpets First Group, the public transport operator
fields.body:
 Tremendous news from the battle against road congestion. "Across Britain nearly 250 people plan to scrap their car this Sunday in exchange for an annual bus pass," trumpets First Group, the public transport operator. Don't you love the "nearly"? Actually, the figure for those participating in this well-meaning but ineffectual "swap your banger for a bus" offer is 242, but "more are signing every day". All right, so let's round it off to 250 and assume the rate of progress is maintained every month. With 22m cars on the road, it'll take only 3,500 years to halve traffic volumes.

 Things fall apart (1): Elsewhere in the public transport sphere, the Tube, liberated by Ken Livingstone's coup from even a thin veneer of customer service, is reverting rapidly to type. Wednesday morning and the shock workers of Europe's financial capital flooded into mighty Euston only to learn that its underground station had been closed because of overcrowding. The wage slaves were advised to try Euston Square or Warren Street. The latter was also closed because of overcrowding but a notice advised "customers" to give Euston a go. Memo to Tube bosses: can we please have the upside of this time-machine trip (the pub on Sloane Square station, smoking carriages, proper red trains...)?

 Things fall apart (2): Tuesday morning was no time to become a victim to fraud or embezzlement. Enemy action - or possibly a gremlin - knocked out the entire telephone system at Serious Fraud Office HQ in Elm Street, London, with even callers to Mama Doc's ultra-hush private line being told by a robotic phone company voice that no connection was possible. Contact was restored around lunchtime but disruption had been minimal because key personnel had taken advantage of the fact Tuesday was a "civil service privilege day". Sorry? Whatever happened to "we never sleep"? Anyone have Sam Spade's mobile number?

 From beyond the grave, the Action Bank lives on as if nothing had changed. NatWest customers have just found themselves in receipt of a letter asking them to fill in a questionnaire about standards of service from NatWest. The missive is signed by Tim Jones, chief executive of retail banking. Doubtless it was another head of retail banking, also called Tim Jones, who left NatWest shortly after Royal Bank of Scotland's successful takeover in March. Coming soon: the District Bank customer satisfaction survey.

 On the satisfaction theme, Bayer, the venerable German medicines group, is going into battle against the anti-impotence drug Viagra with its own "erectile dysfunction treatment", Vardenafil. Presumably impotence medicines, as with 1950s nuclear bombers, have to have names beginning with V. Bayer expects to earn about £bn a year from this little potion, possibly as a result of synergies with another famous Bayer product, aspirin. Male customers can overcome their impotence and the women in their life can cure their headaches.

 Elsewhere in the world of, er, adult relationships, distressing news for fans of the father of the modern market economy, Friedrich Hayek. We fed the great man's name into the computer and awaited a stack of useful information, courtesy of the web. Sad to say, the first eight places under "Hayek" have been bagged by someone called Salma Hayek, whose internet sites claim to specialise in material of the no-clothes-on variety. His/her idea of the "road to serfdom" is rather different from that of the late professor, whose own page is a sorry number nine. We clicked no further on the Salma front for fear of alerting the Gary Glitter investigation team. Far more wholesome is "retired Judge Carolyn J Hayek", of Washington State, who "performs weddings throughout the Puget Sound area".

 Finally, Bank of England governor Eddie George's grace and favour pad in New Change, near St Paul's Cathedral, is threatened by the modern mania for cost effectiveness, we hear. The lease on the flat - scene of many a drama, not least Mr George's hasty return from a skiing trip in February 1995 to try to salvage something from the Barings debacle - may be terminated, it seems. What is the Bank boss to do - become a Big Issue salesman?

The missive is signed by Tim Jones, chief executive of retail banking. Doubtless it was another head of retail banking, also called Tim Jones, who left NatWest shortly after Royal Bank of Scotland's successful takeover in March. Coming soon: the District Bank customer satisfaction survey.  On the satisfaction theme, Bayer, the venerable German medicines group, is going into battle against the anti-impotence drug Viagra with its own "erectile dysfunction treatment", Vardenafil. Presumably impotence medicines, as with 1950s nuclear bombers, have to have names beginning with V. Bayer expects to earn about £bn a year from this little potion, possibly as a result of synergies with another famous Bayer product, aspirin. Male customers can overcome their impotence and the women in their life can cure their headaches.  Elsewhere in the world of, er, adult relationships, distressing news for fans of the father of the modern market economy, Friedrich Hayek. We fed the great man's name into the computer and awaited a stack of useful information, courtesy of the web. Sad to say, the first eight places under "Hayek" have been bagged by someone called Salma Hayek, whose internet sites claim to specialise in material of the no-clothes-on variety. His/her idea of the "road to serfdom" is rather different from that of the late professor, whose own page is a sorry number nine. We clicked no further on the Salma front for fear of alerting the Gary Glitter investigation team. Far more wholesome is "retired Judge Carolyn J Hayek", of Washington State, who "performs weddings throughout the Puget Sound area".  Finally, Bank of England governor Eddie George's grace and favour pad in New Change, near St Paul's Cathedral, is threatened by the modern mania for cost effectiveness, we hear. The lease on the flat - scene of many a drama, not least Mr George's hasty return from a skiing trip in February 1995 to try to salvage something from the Barings debacle - may be terminated, it seems. What is the Bank boss to do - become a Big Issue salesman?

fields.headline: Picture of a pioneer
fields.standfirst: Brand values Kodak
fields.trailText: Kodak, one of the most famous brand names in the world, has no meaning. It is a random selection of letters, with no hidden significance.
fields.body:
Kodak, one of the most famous brand names in the world, has no meaning. It is a random selection of letters, with no hidden significance.

George Eastman wanted a simple brand name for his new photographic products. He decided that a short word beginning and ending in K, a letter he liked, would do. He then randomly chose intervening letters until he arrived at a word which looked good. So Kodak was born and registered in 1888.

Eastman himself was born in 1854 at Waterville, New York. His father was a nurseryman who sold his business to set up a commercial college in Rochester, also in New York.

But Eastman's father died young, and Eastman was forced to leave school at 14 to find a job to help support his mother and two sisters, one of whom was handicapped.

His first job was as a lowly paid messenger at an insurance firm. He later studied accounting in his spare time. His diligence paid off and he was taken on as a clerk at a local bank for $15 (then about £3) a week.

His life was to change after he planned to make a photographic record of a holiday in Santo Domingo. He bought the necessary equipment - a huge camera, a heavy tripod, chemicals, tanks and a tent for preparing the wet glass plates - but never took the holiday.

He began to experiment to make photography easier. Wet plate photography was a tremendous palaver and photographers were just beginning to use plates coated with gelatin emulsions which remained sensitive when dry.

Eastman made his first dry plates using a formula he had seen in a British magazine. He developed his own formula and began to sell dry plates to other photographers in 1880.

His business almost collapsed when a batch of plates he sold turned out to be duds. The cost of replacing them all free of charge nearly tipped the company into bankruptcy. But the company managed to salvage its reputation and gain a new partner, businessman Henry Strong. The change in its fortunes came when Eastman started to produce roll film and the camera to use it.

Eastman realised that simple equipment would make photography accessible to the public. He launched the Kodak camera in 1888 with the slogan "you push the button, we do the rest". By 1896 Kodak had sold 100,000 cameras and was making 400 miles of film and photographic paper a month.

Photography took off as a popular hobby four years later when Kodak launched its first $1 Brownie box camera. The Instamatic camera, with its cartridge-loading film, was intro duced in 1963 and more than 50m had been sold by 1970.

Transparent roll film opened the way for the movie industry. Kodak launched the first specially coated film for movie cameras in 1896.

Cine cameras and films for the amateur market followed in 1923, as did a variety of still camera film sizes. The latest of these was the Advanced Photo System, developed by a number of photographic companies, including Kodak, and launched in 1996. APS film has a strip running through it which enabled information about each shot, including its shape, to be stored electronically for use during processing. Kodak moved further into the electronic era with digital cameras and its PhotoCD system for storing images.

George Eastman gave away his fortune, mainly to universities and educational bodies including London's Eastman Dental Hospital and Institute in Grays Inn Road. He committed suicide at the age of 77 as his active life was curtailed by a progressive illness.

There are very few photographs of him. The man who created snapshot photography - and one of America's largest companies - preferred to remain behind the camera.

fields.headline: Tito Puente
fields.standfirst: Bandleader and instrumentalist who became a worldwide ambassador for Latin jazz
fields.trailText: Tito Puente, who has died aged 77, was known as the king of Latin jazz, El Rey del Timbal, "Mambo King" or simply 'El Rey'. The greatest ambassador for Latin music in the 20th century, his impassioned style of Latin jazz, his high-energy drumming and delicate vibraphone playing attracted adoring audiences for decades in countries as far removed from Latin America as China and Japan, Russia and the UK.
fields.body:
Tito Puente, who has died aged 77, was known as the king of Latin jazz, El Rey del Timbal, "Mambo King" or simply 'El Rey'. The greatest ambassador for Latin music in the 20th century, his impassioned style of Latin jazz, his high-energy drumming and delicate vibraphone playing attracted adoring audiences for decades in countries as far removed from Latin America as China and Japan, Russia and the UK. In home territories in South America and the Spanish-speaking Caribbean, his reputation was summed up by his singing partner of nearly 50 years, the queen to his king, Celia Cruz: "Our world is in mourning because one of the souls of Latin music has died."

Puente had never contemplated retirement. In February this year, he received his fifth Grammy - for the Mambo Birdland album - and was recently honoured by the US government on a postage stamp. His last concert in April was in San Juan, Puerto Rico.

Puente was a musician's musician, a composer, arranger and bandleader, and a showman. He had a childlike delight at jokes and teasing, and realised very early on the significance of giving a performance more than just musical. In the late 30s, while playing with the band of Cuban singer Machito, he dragged his timbales drum kit to the front of the stage and never went back into the shadows. From then on, his solos were instantly a star attraction.

Ernesto 'Tito' Puente Jr, the son of a factory foreman, was born and raised in New York, though he spent a few years as a child with his family in Puerto Rico and remained devoted to the island and its culture for life. His music education - on piano - began in Manhattan, spurred on by his mother, who would secretly take 25 cents for the class from his father's coat pocket. With his younger sister Annie, he took up dancing, slick and neat as he would be all his life, and as he boasted later, one of the few bandleaders who could actually dance.

As a teenager, he played timbales and piano in several Latin bands around town, and was heard by the newly arrived Cuban pianist and bandleader, José Curbelo. Joining up with Curbelo, Puente learned about band-leading and business before moving on to play with Machito, who was creating the template for Afro-Cuban jazz with his partner Mario Bauza.

Puente's career was interrupted by the war - he served in the US Marines - but on his return he studied composition at the Juilliard School of Music and emerged to found his first band, the Picadilly Boys. By then, many Cuban musicians were in town, bringing with them an infectious and highly syncopated new dance called the Mambo; Puente was hooked. Within a couple of years, he was drawing vast crowds with performances in the Mecca of the dance, the Palladium Ballroom on 52nd Street, just along from the world famous bebop jazz club, Birdland.

For Puente this was an opportunity to see at close quarters the arrangements of musicians such as Stan Kenton and Dizzy Gillespie, who also shared a passion for Cuban music. Thus began Puente's long connection with the American jazz scene, and the foundations were laid for some brilliant collaborations on future records.

In his comprehensive biography, Tito Puente and the Making of Latin Music, Steven Loza compares Puente's significance in American music to that of Louis Armstrong and Duke Ellington. The 1997 tribute album Commemorating Tito Puente, 50 Years of Swing offers 50 tracks from all stages of his career, beginning with his first successful recording Que no, que no! in 1946, sung by his future rival for the title of Mambo King, Tito Rodriguez. As revealed on this fondly conceived box set, his range of musical styles and collaborators was exceptional: from the raucous brassy Americanised versions of Cuban rumbas, mambos and chachachas to Latin-jazz encounters with the leaders of the genre (Ray Baretto, Mongo Santamaria, pianists Charlie Palmieri, Hilton Ruiz and Michel Camilo) and also members of the American camp, George Shearing, Lionel Hampton, Woody Herman, and fellow vibraphonist Cal Tjader, to New York's more recent commercial salsa.

The 1999 tribute song, El Cien (The Hundred - to commemorate his 100th album), is a textural delight, a flash-past of the most significant voices of salsa in the past few decades, including, of course, Celia Cruz, the most significant Latin singer of the century.

Puente drew each new generation of musicians into the fold. His genuine interest in them and their ideas kept his own music fresh. Through his Tito Puente Foundation, he enabled poor Hispanic musicians to attend music college. By the 90s, he had become a mentor and unlikely icon for many young Latin hiphop crossover producers and musicians, including his son, the percussionist Tito Jr.

Puente did not always approve of new trends and commercially motivated salsa; he certainly didn't feel any compulsion to praise them or conform to the car-chase, big band merengues which dominated the charts in the late 80s. He said - in a rare flash of irritation - that he would sooner stop playing than have to play them. But he was open to serious, committed changes, especially at the jazz end of the Latin music spectrum.

Puente's repertoire of Latin jazz and salsa includes more than 100 albums and scores of singles. Individual songs are known worldwide and reappear in new guises. He reclaimed the timeless Oye Como Va from Carlos Santana who sowed the seeds of today's interest in Latin music when he gave it the electric Latin rock treatment at the Woodstock Festival in the 60s.

Since then, the non-Latin population and America's mainstream media have woken up to his presence among them (a secret privately enjoyed in the Latino communities). His music became increasingly desirable and was used in film soundtracks and signature tunes (his friend Bill Crosby adopted a Puente song as his show's signature tune and appeared frequently on stage with him at the famous "Latin Meets Jazz" nights at New York's Village Gate club). In the movie of The Mambo Kings, Puente played a musician playing at the Palladium in the mambo heyday.

In 1981, Puente visited London with his Latin Jazz Sextet - a streamlined, tight, inventive outfit which took the city by surprise. Backstage, Puente said he was amazed at the reaction and couldn't wait to come back. In 1984, he returned with his full band and Celia Cruz out front; it was an unforgettable night. This country's love affair with salsa was confirmed.

Puente's death marks a new century in Latin music, but one which is grounded entirely in his music - and his mischievous and passionate personality.

He is survived by his wife, Margie, two sons and a daughter.

 Ernesto (Tito) Anthony Puente, musician, born April 20 1923; died May 31 2000

webTitle: Japanese sober up to alcohol threat

fields.headline: Japanese sober up to alcohol threat
fields.trailText: Japanese in search of a late-night beer got a nasty surprise this week when off-licences imposed a voluntary ban on selling alcohol from vending machines. The prohibition is a response to a public clamour against growing alcoholism and under-age drinking.
fields.body:
Japanese in search of a late-night beer got a nasty surprise this week when off-licences imposed a voluntary ban on selling alcohol from vending machines. The prohibition is a response to a public clamour against growing alcoholism and under-age drinking.

Vending machines dispensing alcohol have been one of the most distinctive features of the modern Japanese landscape. Conveniently located and easy to use, they usually offer bottles of whisky, sake and wine, as well as a range of beers in cans as big as two litres.

On Wednesday night their owners began restocking them with cans of juice, green tea and other popular soft drinks.

The All Japan Alcohol Merchants' Association estimated that up to 70% of the 170,000 machines were closed or restocked. Owners in some areas were given a dispensation because they rely heavily on the machines.

Many people going home late at night were disappointed that they could not buy a cold beer from their usual source.

"I didn't know the ban started today," one lamented. "I agree with the reasons, but I must admit I'll miss them, especially on a hot summer night like this. Now I'll have to walk to the all-night convenience store for a coldie."

The Japanese are fond of their vending machines, which sell everything from fresh flowers to sex aids.

The merchants' association agreed as long ago as 1994 to do something about illegal purchases of alcohol by the under-20s, but attempts to introduce a smart-card system to check the age of customers came to nothing.

Rising adult drunkenness has added to the pressure: it is not uncommon to see smartly dressed men staggering along railway platforms or asleep in the gutter, and the media have focused on "kitchen drinkers" - alcoholic housewives.

By itself, the vending machine ban is unlikely to have much of an impact: 24-hour convenience stores, which are almost as numerous as beer machines, often sell beer through the night, and beer and sake are available at station kiosks and takeaways.

Off-licence owners want shops which sell to under-age drinkers to be penalised.

webTitle: Ex-champion boxer Duran prepares to fight at 48

fields.headline: Ex-champion boxer Duran prepares to fight at 48
fields.trailText: Entering the fifth decade of your chosen career you might reasonably expect life to get a little easier. But after 33 years at the top of his profession, the veteran Panama boxer Roberto "Hands of Stone" Duran is preparing to wind on the bandages for another night of tough manual work.
fields.body:
Entering the fifth decade of your chosen career you might reasonably expect life to get a little easier. But after 33 years at the top of his profession, the veteran Panama boxer Roberto "Hands of Stone" Duran is preparing to wind on the bandages for another night of tough manual work.

Duran, 48, who made his professional debut as a lightweight in the Caribbean city of Colon in 1968, is preparing to meet the San Francisco-based Pat Lawlor for the second time on June 16, in a clash for the vacant National Boxing Association super-middleweight crown in Panama City.

The fight, dubbed by the local promoter, Star Boxing Productions, as "the battle of five decades", is set to extend Duran's 117-fight career into a record fifth decade, and could garner him a further world title in a record fifth weight division.

"It's not going to be easy, but I've trained hard for it. Lawlor owes me and I'm going to make him pay," Duran said last week, adding that it would be his final outing before a home town crowd. "The most important thing is for the Panamanian people to enjoy the title shot, as it's been many years since I fought here."

Meanwhile Duran's 23-year-old daughter, Irichelle, has been forced to pull out of her bout before tomorrow night's world title fight between Mickey Cantwell and South Africa's Zolani Petelo in Ashford, Kent.

She was due to take on Newcastle bus driver Audrey Guthrie, but failed the British Boxing Board of Control's medical requirements because she was running a temperature.

Her father learned his aggressive two-fisted style in the tough streets of Panama City's El Chorrillo district in the 1950s and 1960s and won his first world title at Madison Square Garden in 1972 when he stopped Ken Buchanan in the 13th round for the World Boxing Association (WBA) lightweight belt.

Successfully defending the title 12 times over the next seven years, the Panamanian brawler stepped up a division to beat Sugar Ray Leonard on points for the World Boxing Council welterweight belt in 1980. Further championship belts followed against light-middleweight Davey Moore in 1983 and middleweight Iran Barkley in a 1989 upset.

But while his close contemporary Leonard lofts divots on the fairways of the US pro-celebrity golf circuit, and his former opponent Marvin Hagler plays the villain in Italian films, Duran has carried on slugging it out in a remorseless sport that makes no special case for loved old timers.

In the decade after the glory years of the 1980s, the increasingly out of shape ex-champion lost to Lawlor in the sixth round of their 1991 clash and was stopped in three rounds by William Joppy in a failed bid to win the WBA middleweight title in 1998. In his only outing since then he lost on points to the little-rated Argentine fighter Omar Gonzalez.

Nevertheless, early whispers from the training camp suggest that Duran is pulling out all the stops to beat Lawlor in front of a roaring home town crowd at the capital city's New Panama gymnasium. Relocating to Panama City from his former Miami training camp, Duran has teamed up with the veteran trainer Nestor Quinones to prepare for the 12-round clash.

Quinones, who has known the former champion since he earned a few cents shining shoes and selling newspapers in El Chorrillo in the 60s, has imposed a harsh daily training regime of road and bag work, topped off with eight rounds of sparring in a cinder block gym in the capital's San Miguelito district.

With two weeks until the fight, Duran is within a few pounds of the 168lb (12 stone) weight limit, and his regular sparring partner, Giovanni Duran - no relation - said he is fast returning to form. "Strength never leaves you. He hits hard with both hands, and with every pound that he loses he's getting stronger and faster."

Also casting a critical eye over Duran's preparations is Maria Toto, Panama's only woman boxing trainer, who has coached five hopefuls to national titles over the past two decades. Sitting in the sweltering low-roofed gym, her voice turns to gravel as she articulates the fervent hopes of the partisan Panamanian crowd: "This bout has more importance because he's fighting in front of his own people. He's never lost in Panama City before, and he's not going to lose now."

But while his close contemporary Leonard lofts divots on the fairways of the US pro-celebrity golf circuit, and his former opponent Marvin Hagler plays the villain in Italian films, Duran has carried on slugging it out in a remorseless sport that makes no special case for loved old timers. In the decade after the glory years of the 1980s, the increasingly out of shape ex-champion lost to Lawlor in the sixth round of their 1991 clash and was stopped in three rounds by William Joppy in a failed bid to win the WBA middleweight title in 1998. In his only outing since then he lost on points to the little-rated Argentine fighter Omar Gonzalez. Nevertheless, early whispers from the training camp suggest that Duran is pulling out all the stops to beat Lawlor in front of a roaring home town crowd at the capital city's New Panama gymnasium. Relocating to Panama City from his former Miami training camp, Duran has teamed up with the veteran trainer Nestor Quinones to prepare for the 12-round clash. Quinones, who has known the former champion since he earned a few cents shining shoes and selling newspapers in El Chorrillo in the 60s, has imposed a harsh daily training regime of road and bag work, topped off with eight rounds of sparring in a cinder block gym in the capital's San Miguelito district. With two weeks until the fight, Duran is within a few pounds of the 168lb (12 stone) weight limit, and his regular sparring partner, Giovanni Duran - no relation - said he is fast returning to form. "Strength never leaves you. He hits hard with both hands, and with every pound that he loses he's getting stronger and faster." Also casting a critical eye over Duran's preparations is Maria Toto, Panama's only woman boxing trainer, who has coached five hopefuls to national titles over the past two decades. Sitting in the sweltering low-roofed gym, her voice turns to gravel as she articulates the fervent hopes of the partisan Panamanian crowd: "This bout has more importance because he's fighting in front of his own people. He's never lost in Panama City before, and he's not going to lose now."

fields.headline: Apartheid killers granted amnesty
fields.trailText: South Africa's Truth and Reconciliation Commission yesterday granted an amnesty to an apartheid death squad commander, Eugene de Kock, and other former policemen responsible for killing 14 people from 1983 to 1991.
fields.body:
South Africa's Truth and Reconciliation Commission yesterday granted an amnesty to an apartheid death squad commander, Eugene de Kock, and other former policemen responsible for killing 14 people from 1983 to 1991.

Among the victims was Zweli Nyanda, a commander in the armed wing of the African National Congress and the brother of the current head of South Africa's armed forces, General Siphiwe Nyanda.

Police general Johann Coetzee was also granted an amnesty for conspiring to kill members of an ANC unit and the murder of three anti-apartheid activists in Swaziland in December 1986.

De Kock - a former colonel who headed the Vlakplaas unit that tortured and executed anti-apartheid activists - is serving two life terms plus 212 years in prison for a range of crimes including murder. He has applied for amnesty for more than 100 crimes.

His lawyer, Schalk Hugo, said the amnesties were not related to the two life sentences De Kock was serving.

Zweli Nyanda was one of the highest-profile ANC members to fall victim to De Kock's hit squad. In his book A Long Night's Damage, De Kock called Mr Nyanda "a charismatic leader and a thorn in the flesh of the security police". AP, Johannesburg.

webTitle: Bronte society in turmoil as plot thickens

fields.headline: Bronte society in turmoil as plot thickens
fields.trailText: One of Britain's oldest literary societies faces uproar at its annual meeting today over a charity commission investigation and the unexplained suspension of its director.
fields.body:
One of Britain's oldest literary societies faces uproar at its annual meeting today over a charity commission investigation and the unexplained suspension of its director.

Members of the Bronte Society will challenge the ruling council over fears of bankruptcy at the celebrated Parsonage Museum in Haworth, West Yorkshire, where the legacy of Charlotte, Emily and Anne has been a source of turmoil for a decade.

The society has been warned by charity commission auditors that its financial problems are "most urgent and pressing" after successive annual deficits of more than £70,000 that have eaten into capital reserves.

Members will also protest at what one yesterday called "getting the mushroom treatment over the director's suspension - being kept in the dark and fed on you know what".

The society's difficulties involve a series of subplots worthy of the Bronte sisters, following a furore eight years ago over a planned underground extension of the parsonage financed by an anonymous gift of £1m.

The donation was withdrawn after bitter divisions between the society's 3,000 members and the voting-out of the old council that had fostered the scheme. "The new arrivals presented themselves as the 'listening council' but I'm afraid that they seem to have made exactly the same mistakes," said Kathy Geldard, a vice-president of the society and its former honorary secretary.

"Because the old council were bound to confidentiality by the would-be benefactor, they were caught in the trap of seeming to be secretive. Now things seem to have gone the same way again."

Director Mike Hill resigned last month after a two-months suspension, with no comment from either side on what lay behind what the society called "a private internal matter." Respected in the northern arts world, Mr Hill is thought to have ruffled some society feathers by cooperating in a local newspaper's April Fool joke last year, praising a fictitious plan for a 30-acre Bronte theme park as "welcome, because the parsonage needs livening up".

Once Britain's second literary shrine after Stratford-upon-Avon, the former home of the Brontes in the Pennine village of Haworth has seen visitor numbers drop from 200,000 10 years ago to 80,000 last year. The loss in income has worsened the squeeze on resources, with some 20 staff to be paid and regular maintenance bills for the historic building.

The charity commission report specifies that "from information available, it is clear that on present trends the charity will not survive for very many years".

The commission's audit also warns that the 21-member council of trustees may be too large and unwieldy to make critical decisions effectively.

The council chairman, Margaret McCarthy, was travelling to Haworth from her London home yesterday and was not available for comment. But she said earlier: "In 100 years' time the Bronte Society will be as strong as we are now and people will still be able to visit the beautiful Bronte Parsonage Museum."

fields.headline: Weight loss aid 'mainly water'
fields.trailText: A businessman made nearly £900,000 in a year by selling a slimming aid that boasted of a revolutionary approach to weight loss, but was little more than flavoured water.
fields.body:
A businessman made nearly £900,000 in a year by selling a slimming aid that boasted of a revolutionary approach to weight loss, but was little more than flavoured water.

The bottled drink Calorad, sold in £55 packages, would help slimmers to lose weight and build lean body muscle while they slept, it was claimed. In fact, it was made up of cheap ingredients with no proven effect on weight loss or muscle gain.

John Dallas, general manager of a company that imported the Canadian-made slimmers' aid, was fined £10,000 under the Trades Descriptions Act and ordered to pay £1,800 costs at Teesside crown court on Thursday.

In advertising literature sent out with the 500ml bottles, customers were told how Calorad produced "beneficial results" in 86% of people who used it over three months.

North Yorkshire trading standards office launched the prosecution after the drink was tested during routine checks on claims by slimming product companies.

Dallas, 55, whose company Essentially Yours Industries UK is based at Queenslie Industrial Estate, Glasgow, admitted making a false claim under the 1968 Trades Descriptions Act.

Alexander Cameron, counsel for Essentially Yours, said the slimming product "has had very positive responses from people up and down the country".

The literature describing Calorad to customers has been withdrawn as a result of the court action. But the product is still being sold to the public, and trading standards officers in North Yorkshire have alerted colleagues nationwide.

Judge Peter Fox said he was satisfied Dallas had not set out to mislead the public.

Stuart Pudney, head of North Yorkshire trading standards, said after the case: "Preying on people who are desperate to lose weight is a particularly despicable practice."

webTitle: Luxembourg gunman was frustrated, violent loner

fields.headline: Luxembourg gunman was frustrated, violent loner
fields.trailText: Neji Bejaoui, the gunman who took some 40 children hostage at a Luxembourg day care centre, was harbouring a grudge against the authorities, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
Neji Bejaoui, the gunman who took some 40 children hostage at a Luxembourg day care centre, was harbouring a grudge against the authorities, it emerged yesterday.

A bitter, volatile loner with a long history of mental illness, he had suffered a series of personal and professional failures which had driven him over the edge.

His dramatic decision to take the children - aged from one to eight years - hostage was motivated by his inability to accept that he had lost custody of his own two children.

In an interview given to local radio before police marksmen shot him twice in the head on Thursday, his bitterness boiled over: "I can't bear life any more and I can't face people. I swear on my mother's head that I love children, but they took my children away and I have taken the children of others. It's tit for tat."

It was the "aggressive behaviour" of the unemployed Tunisian, who was recovering in hospital last night, that had prompted social services to put his son and daughter in a home for almost a year and a half in 1994.

He never recovered from the setback and blamed the staff at the creche in the small town of Wasserbillig, which his daughter used to attend, for informing the authorities of his behaviour.

A cafe owner in the neighbouring village of Manternach, where Bejaoui lived with his Luxembourgeoise wife before they were separated, said: "They took the kids away because he hit them and he hit his wife. He is a violent man. They also took them away because they weren't fed properly. He never worked and had financial problems," he said, asking not to be named.

Bejaoui lived in a run-down but imposing house in a rather shabby area before splitting up with his wife. Neighbours say he could often be seen in the garden lifting weights or sparring in boxing gloves.

A martial arts and fitness fanatic, he dreamed of setting up his own business supplying bodyguards to nightclubs and politicians.

His hope was never realised, however, and the psychiatrist he visited on and off for around seven years issued him with a medical certificate declaring him unfit for work.

As the tense standoff with the Luxembourg police limped to its dramatic denouement this week, Bejaoui struggled to tell the world's media who he was. He described himself as "a bodyguard, a private investigator and black belt kickboxer". The reality was rather different.

Prone to bouts of violence and deeply frustrated, Bejaoui has never held down a job for any length of time. A government statement yesterday said he had a history of violence and had been convicted of assault in 1998. It claimed he was "very unstable" and described him as an attention-seeking paranoiac.

Largely unemployed since 1993, he worked as a bodyguard and private detective for only brief periods. The statement listed his profession as a pastry chef.

Bejaoui admitted that his working life was a disaster. "I have been seeing a shrink for seven years now. I did this [took the children hostage at gunpoint] because of cold and hunger. I am ill and I can't work any more," he told the radio station.

He had little contact with the people in the village where he lived and despite residing in Luxembourg since 1982 did not speak the language. In 1996 neighbours watched in horror as he chased his wife through the streets of Manternach with a knife in his hand. Local people say they were openly wary of approaching him.

Friends encouraged him to concentrate on his sporting interests in the hope that he would find some kind of mental peace, but he slipped into a pattern of depressive and aggressive behaviour.

However, a friend of his children said he spent much of his time asleep, getting up only to take medication, and that he was "a kind man and fairly normal".

His brother-in-law, Jos Dueren, said: "He's not as bad as you might think. In any case, he is not a violent man."

Bejaoui was yesterday recovering despite the fact that he was shot in the head at almost point blank range.

Reports that police disguised as reporters had shot him using a gun concealed in a camera could still not be confirmed, but the authorities did admit that detectives disguised as a camera crew had lured him into the open.

The International Federation of Journalists condemned the ploy as unethical.

fields.headline: Square deal
fields.standfirst: £4m campaign to restore historic gardens
fields.trailText: London's forgotten squares have been left to rot unloved for nearly 60 years, according to English Heritage, which today launches a campaign to save them.
fields.body:
London's forgotten squares have been left to rot unloved for nearly 60 years, according to English Heritage, which today launches a campaign to save them.

Most of the 600 historic gardens in the capital have not recovered from the battering they took in the second world war when Winston Churchill ordered their iron railings to be ripped out and smelted down for the war effort.

But few of the railings or the ornate seats and benches that followed them into the furnaces were made into tanks or guns.

English Heritage estimates that at least £4m is need to restore the squares most at risk. Spokesman Drew Bennellick said for half a century London had turned its back on its squares. "Some of them haven't been really looked at since the war and are now very sad indeed."

English Heritage is pledging £200,000 over the next three years to the campaign, and hopes this will kickstart councils and private sponsors into restoration work.

fields.headline: Sword attacker sent to hospital
fields.trailText: An unemployed computer expert who made a "ferocious and sustained" attack with a samurai sword on worshippers at a south London church was yesterday ordered to be detained indefinitely in a secure hospital.
fields.body:
An unemployed computer expert who made a "ferocious and sustained" attack with a samurai sword on worshippers at a south London church was yesterday ordered to be detained indefinitely in a secure hospital.

A jury at the Old Bailey took just 10 minutes to find Eden Strang, 26, not guilty by reason of insanity on charges of attempted murder and assault after hearing he was in the grip of extreme paranoid schizophrenia.

Eleven churchgoers were left seriously injured when Strang burst naked into the Sunday morning service at St Andrew's Roman Catholic Church in Thornton Heath last November after hearing voices telling him the worshippers were demons in human form.

Psychiatrist Jonathan Vince told the court that Strang had probably been mentally ill for seven years and believed he could communicate with God through his computer.

But his paranoid schizophrenia had gone largely unnoticed and he had failed to receive medical treatment.

Dr Vince said Strang's illness had developed to such a degree that there was nothing else in his mind than that the whole world was full of demons out to destroy him and his family.

He said it was "quite extraordinary" to find someone in a state of that disorder. "He suffered from a defect in reasoning as a direct result of the disease of mind.

"I believe he was not able to appreciate what he was doing was wrong either morally or legally. He thought he and his family would be apocalyptically destroyed."

Strang's victims suffered lasting injuries after he lashed out at them with the 3ft sword.

Paul Chilton lost part of his hand and suffered permanent damage to his jaw when Strang attacked him. He spent seven hours on the operating table, and needed 40 pints of blood and 100 stitches to his face.

Parish priest John O'Toole said after the hearing that he believed the court's decision was just.

"The mood of the parish is that he needs treatment, not punishment."

webTitle: EU allies seek to halt rights charter

fields.headline: EU allies seek to halt rights charter
fields.trailText: Britain is building alliances with at least four other EU member states to block a legally binding charter of fundamental rights that would be written into a new treaty at the end of the year.
fields.body:
Britain is building alliances with at least four other EU member states to block a legally binding charter of fundamental rights that would be written into a new treaty at the end of the year.

With the Tories on the attack over alleged government acquiescence in an embryonic "constitution" for the EU, it emerged yesterday that there is wide opposition to the maximalist version of the project.

Sweden, Finland, Ireland and Spain all share Britain's determination to resist calls for a charter that includes new social and economic rights, diplomats said. Several other small countries have reservations, too.

Lord Goldsmith, Tony Blair's representative on the committee drafting the document, insisted in a BBC interview that the government would "get anything removed that goes beyond existing rights as recognised in the United Kingdom."

Britain's main worry is that France, taking over the EU's rotating presidency on July 1, will push for a charter with new social rights, guaranteeing maximum working hours, worker consultation and trade union membership.

The German chancellor, Gerhard Schröder, wants a legally binding document, but is said to be much less keen on the social dimension.

Italy, Greece and possibly federalist-minded Belgium are the keenest supporters of the charter and want it incorporated into a proposed treaty of Nice in December.

The European commission also backs a strong and legally binding charter. But it has no say in the actual decision to draw up a new treaty.

The government had originally hoped to get away with nothing more than a pledge card listing existing rights in an accessible way.

Apart from the Conservatives, the CBI opposes the charter on the grounds that it would impose new costs on British industry. The TUC sees it as a possible means of strengthening employment relations law.

Mr Blair is confident that he can find enough allies to make opposition comfortable. But the timing is bad because it coincides with important talks on EU institutional reform and the still unresolved issue of the withholding tax on cross-border savings.

Eurosceptics are also seizing on strong Franco-German determination to step up the role of the 11 EU member states that have already adopted the single currency, in a way that would underline Britain's exclusion.

Francis Maude, the shadow foreign secretary, yesterday returned to the attack on the government. He told BBC radio's Today programme: "There are two irreconcilable views on this. The government is doing its usual thing of saying, 'Don't worry, chaps, it's perfectly harmless, just a bit of window-dressing, nothing to worry about.'

"And yet you've got people on the continent who say this is the beginning of a written constitution for the European Union, that it is a fundamental building for the single European superstate. They can't both be right."

webTitle: Backbencher urges Blair to rule out 2001 poll

fields.headline: Backbencher urges Blair to rule out 2001 poll
fields.trailText: A senior Labour backbencher yesterday became the first MP to call on Tony Blair publicly to reject an election next year, saying the public would be mystified if the government did not run its full term.
fields.body:
A senior Labour backbencher yesterday became the first MP to call on Tony Blair publicly to reject an election next year, saying the public would be mystified if the government did not run its full term.

Tony Wright, the MP for Cannock Chase and chairman of the Commons public administration select committee, said last night: "I hope the prime minister will kill off all speculation about an early election by saying that he intends the parliament to run its full term.

"We have a big majority and we rightly keep saying how long it takes to deliver the benefits of the programmes we are putting in place. Not only is the prospect of endless speculation about election dates a complete turnoff, the electorate would simply not understand if the government held an election before it has served its full term."

There has been widespread assumption that the election will be held next May, at the same time as county council elections. But senior Labour figures insist no detailed work has yet been done on election timing. It is possible that the government will wait until May 2002.

Mr Wright's warning came as senior figures in the engineering union sounded a sceptical note over suggestions Mr Blair is willing to strike a deal with Liberal Democrat leader Charles Kennedy on electoral reform, under which both will back the alternative vote.

That would be a deep disappointment to Lord Jenkins of Hillhead, who published an official report last year recommending a form of top-up voting system designed to give a more proportional result.

The AV system requires voters to name their candidates in order of preference, with the first candidate to get more than 50% winning.

Liberal Democrat and Labour electoral reformers say it fails to produce a proportional result, but some Liberal Democrats claim it is the only system that will win the support of the Labour party.

But the Amalgamated Engineering and Electrical Union, leading party sponsors of the First Past the Post Campaign, were hostile to the deal last night. Political officer Tom Mann said: "AV is known to punish the losers hard and does not create the consensus politics that some want."

fields.headline: Heads 'deserve £100,000 salaries'
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Headteachers brought in to turn around failing schools should be awarded executive pay deals of £100,000 or more, a teaching union leader said yesterday.
fields.body:
Headteachers brought in to turn around failing schools should be awarded executive pay deals of £100,000 or more, a teaching union leader said yesterday.

David Hart, general secretary of the National Association of Head Teachers, called for packages including company cars, private health insurance, performance bonuses and MBA courses as part of an across-the-board improvement in heads' pay and conditions.

"People may laugh at £100,000 salaries. But some schools are no laughing matter," Mr Hart told delegates at the NAHT's annual conference in Jersey.

"I am not talking about private-sector excesses. If successful heads can be found to take up the challenge and win, the life chances of thousands of pupils will have been radically changed."

David Blunkett, the education secretary, said on March 1 the government was prepared to offer £100,000 to a pool of "super heads" to take over overall management of groups of up to five poor-performing schools. A set of schools in Nottingham is a likely candidate.

But Mr Hart said heads in charge of individual "fresh start" schools deserved similar deals. The pay ceiling for state secondary heads is £76,000, although a handful benefit from clauses enabling them to earn more. Most were in the £50,00 to £60,000 range, he said.

Primary heads could earn up to £50,000 but most earned between £30,000 and £40,000, Mr Hart said. But the union would not rest until most primary heads earned £40,000 to £50,000, and most secondary heads £60,000 to £80,000.

"Salary levels send a message," the union leader told delegates. "They tell the outside world the value placed on you, the leaders of schools.

"Why should not the head of a 1,000-pupil school earn £40,000? Why should not the head of a 2,000-pupil school receive some £80,000?

He went on: "You are holding down posts which are just as, if not more, responsible than better-paid jobs in other walks of life."

He said research by the business consultants Hays Management had endorsed the union's view that secondary heads dealing with budgets of about £2.5m and 1,000 pupils should be earning around £80,000.

Mr Blunkett's proposal this week to wrench away local authorities' power over heads' budgets was another reason to boost headteachers' pay, Mr Hart said.

A spokesman for the education department said pay deals of £100,000 for the "super heads" had been "mooted" but no final decision had been made.

In his keynote address, Mr Hart accused Ofsted of aiding and abetting division in education by putting more schools at risk of going into special measures, and through the creation of a new category of under-achieving, or "coasting", schools.

webTitle: NUT lifts threat of strike over pay linked to results

fields.headline: NUT lifts threat of strike over pay linked to results
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The leadership of the National Union of Teachers lifted the threat of a one-day strike yesterday over performance-related pay in a snub to its own conference delegates.
fields.body:
The leadership of the National Union of Teachers lifted the threat of a one-day strike yesterday over performance-related pay in a snub to its own conference delegates.

The NUT, the largest teaching union, rejected a vote by delegates at its conference in Harrogate at Easter to hold a ballot on strike action.

But yesterday the union's alternative to the strike - to launch a joint campaign with another union against the government's plan - immediately hit the rocks.

A spat developed between the union and its would-be partner the National Association of Schoolmasters/Union of Women Teachers.

Nigel de Gruchy, general secretary of the NAS/UWT, demanded an apology from his NUT counterpart, Doug McAvoy, for what he called an "outrageous accusation in his conference report that we were supporting the government on performance-related pay".

Mr de Gruchy said: "There is no question of us giving consideration to a joint campaign unless he retracts that statement and issues an apology."

Mr McAvoy had announced yesterday that a joint meeting would be held with the NAS/UWT on Tuesday, the day after the deadline for applications by classroom teachers for performance-related pay.

Delegates at the conference had voted by a 60-40 majority to hold a ballot. But the executive believed the rank and file membership would vote no in a ballot.

A survey of members produced a 30% response rate and only three out of five participating wanted a strike. A legal challenge in Wales to performance-related pay may also be successful.

The NUT's executive said other teacher unions had made it clear the NUT would be isolated if it went on strike. "Division in the profession and the probability that a significant number of NUT members would vote no would allow the government to claim that only a minority of teachers opposed performance-related pay."

The government is promising classroom teachers with no extra duties, earning £23,958, at the top of their pay scale, an extra £2,001 from September. Eventually their pay could increase to £30,108 on the new threshold. The NUT has recommended its members apply for the offer although it opposes it on principle.

David Hart, general secretary of the National Association of Head Teachers, welcomed the NUT executive's "very wise decision".

But in his speech to the NAHT's conference in Jersey, he attacked the "depressing message" sent out by the NUT conference. Heads of department had to have a role in assessing the performance of teachers under them, he said.

"To engage in behaviour they would deplore in their own pupils, to insult their own senior members by talking about snooping on fellow teachers as a description of threshold assessment, to refuse to debate professionally, gives an image which damages the standing of the profession," Mr Hart said.
