webTitle: Who put the harm in Harmondsworth?

fields.headline: Who put the harm in Harmondsworth?
fields.trailText: The Wissey Foulness Went and Quin. It's enough to make you burst your banks.
fields.body:
Would the obliteration of Harmondsworth be a suitable subject for more than mere local outrage? When I read this week that runway-hungry Heathrow had been dreaming of an expansion which would do in both Harmondsworth and its neighbour Sipson, I registered only limited distress. To me, Harmondsworth had never meant anything more than the HQ of Penguin Books. This week, that perception was drastically changed. When I looked the place up in an ancient copy of David Piper's wonderful Companion Guide to London, I discovered that a field in the vicinity had become the last resting place of the old Waterloo bridge, built in 1817, at which time someone described it as "a colossal monument worthy of Sesostris and the Caesars". When it was taken down in the 1930s, its 70,000 tons of granite, craigeth, bramley, blue pennant and york stone were exiled to Middlesex (as it then was) and redeployed for use in ornamental fireplaces.

But then I consulted another fine work of topography, Nairn's London, by the great Ian Nairn. What he wrote sent me hurtling westwards: "An astonishing village, only half a mile from London airport's runways: a tiny green with too many rose bushes on it, two village pubs and a simple village church...." What thrilled him most was Harmondsworth great barn, behind the church, probably 15th century, 190 feet long, with inside, "12 great luminous bays, timber-framed, with no attempt to make the beams Gothic, and all the more memorable for that."

Nairn was there in the 1960s, but there's still the pleasant triangular green, still the two pubs, still the untroubled church, and still the mighty barn (though I did not get into it), now in the hands of English Heritage. (For a fuller description of Harmondsworth, try AW Harris's website - ). On the basis of a brief inspection, Smallweed feels the time has come for a slogan. Here it is:

KEEP THE HARM OUT OF HARMONDSWORTH

You can cut that line out if you like, and stick it on your rear windscreen.

 Returning to Britain last Sunday from blessed Italy, Smallweed noted with exquisite alarm that some of the green fields of Sussex had turned a horrible brown. Was this something to do, perhaps, with genetic modification? Or a new agricultural subsidy cooked up in Brussels? Apparently not. The news that evening explained that the Uck had broken its banks; also something they called the Tizzy. The Uck I knew, having been to Uckfield; but where was the Tizzy? Hours of research turned up the Teise, which rises near Tunbridge Wells and later divides into two, each half eventually merging into the Beult. I blame the actress Elizabeth Hurley, who has given the world the idea that you get yourself known by bursting your banks. Now everyone is at it, and apparently waterways too. I guess that the Uck and the Teise saw in last week's rain a matchless opportunity to get thenselves into the media by a nifty bit of bank-bursting. And now that their ploy has succeeded, I fear the practice may spread.

 Even for internet users, a full list of English rivers is hard to obtain. But an hour or two with a map reveals a host of rivers unknown to many, and until now largely unknown to Smallweed. The Ant, for instance, and the Can and the Len. The Quarm and the Quin (there is also a Quoich, but that is in Scotland). The Wissey. You may have heard of the Yare, which flows into the sea near Great Yarmouth; but what of the Yar, which flows into Brading Harbour on the Isle of Wight? Or the Nar, on which, unsurprisingly, Narborough stands (that is Narborough, Norfolk, of course, not Narborough, Leicestershire) on its way to meet the sea at King's Lynn.

There is also a Yarty, not to mention no fewer than seven Yeos. In days of yore there was even a Yore but that has become the Ure. There's a Seven, as well as a Severn; a Sow (Stafford is on the Sow) and a Sowe, which ennobles Coventry. I never knew either that Nuneaton, hitherto famous merely for producing George Eliot and Larry Grayson, stands on the banks of the Anker. There's a Hodder , rising in the forest of Bowland,though no Stoughton, and a Went, but no Came - though of course there's a Cam, which is also both at some time the Rhee and the Granta.

There's a river Skirfare in the north of Yorkshire and a river Foulness in its east; a Bela, a Biss, a Cock, and a Pang. There are even two Eaus, in Lincolnshire: the Great and the Long, which adorn Saltfleet and Saltfleetby. The Great even flows through one of the Theddlethorpes. I hope public spirited people will devote their weekends to visiting some of these rivers and reading this column to them. They will then believe they are famous and have no need to break their banks.

 In this space two weeks ago I addressed my visiting pest, the pedant, as "chummy." A reader writes to inquire if I have any connection with Drogheda, the only place to his knowledge where the term is in common use. I find this astonishing. I had always thought the term was the stuff of daily banter from Lerwick to Looe and from Lurgan to Liskeard. I have no connection with Drogheda and have never set foot in the place, though I do know two things about it. (1) It isn't pronounced as spelled, but is made to rhyme, more or less, with embroider. (2) There used to be a peer of this name, who was big in culture.

A rural psychiatrist writes : It is also an anagram of hog-dread, a condiction which afflicted the Shropshire peasantry between the years 1771 and 1803.

Smallweed responds with cringing reverence : But of course. That explains everything.

webTitle: Stop Dorset's switch from cream teas to chrome tedium

fields.headline: Stop Dorset's switch from cream teas to chrome tedium
fields.trailText: Lunching in Cerne Abbas... | On the beauty myth
fields.body:
We're just back from a quick two days in a B&B in Dorset, which remains one of the nicest southern counties, possibly because no motorways go there. The scenery is bewilderingly lovely since it changes entirely every 100 yards, many of the villages are gorgeous, and the place is full of fabulous pubs whose signs indicate their desperation for you to sample their local ales and fresh seafood.

Yet the council appears to have decided that there is no vista which cannot be improved by a caravan park, so as you're walking along a vertiginous cliff top, the sun sparkling on the foaming sea, gulls wheeling below you, Portland Bill shining in the distance, you suddenly come upon what might be an aerial view of the H-blocks of the Maze prison.

Something else which continues to puzzle me is why petrol companies seem to have a complete dispensation from planning permission. Take Burton Bradstock, a village which looks as if it's copied from an Olde English jigsaw puzzle box, with flower -festooned thatched cottages from which you half expect to see a hedgehog in a pinny emerge with a basket of pegs. In the Anchor my son and I played bar skittles under the tutelage of a kindly gap-toothed and bearded local. It was idyllic. But just at the edge of the village is a hideous Texaco station, all huge red signs and today's prices in letters large enough to be read from Lyme Regis.

Why is this? Is the assumption that motorists will drive for hours to immerse themselves in rustic beauty, but are too blind to see a filling station? If they can read the handwritten signs in windows saying: "Dainty cream teas" surely they can spot "Texaco" or "Esso" in letters less than three feet high?

 Lunching in Cerne Abbas, under the great priapic giant, I read about how Radio 1 had just sacked Andy Kershaw, one of the most thoughtful, enterprising and humane broadcasters in the country. (Now there's a scandal Gordon Brown should worry about; I bet his Rochdale accent didn't help him.) On the way home, our daughter wanted the same station on the radio.

We caught Chris Moyles, a man who makes Tony Blackburn sound like Professor Joad. It was drivel. You wanted to wipe the radio with a Kleenex. There was a long discussion about Denise van Outen's breasts. There was a shorter chat about how Mr Moyles (or a sidekick) wanted to see that appalling film in which All Saints appear naked.

He and his friends had a vocabulary slightly larger than an intelligent chimp, though possibly smaller than some of the smarter dolphins. Things they approved of were "nice", "good", "great" or, if really admirable, "the canine testicles". As they droned on and on about nothing, saying nothing, filling up the empty airwaves with a greater vacuum, each record came as an intense but regrettably short relief.

 Like Douglas Adams, the late Paul Jennings had a game in which he gave British place-names their real definitions, as opposed to the drearier ones propounded by etymologists (why does everything turn out to mean "settlement", or occasionally "settlement by the oak trees"?). To Jennings, Leeds meant "a horse's nostrils". Erith was what a philanderer did, as in the old phrase, "man erith, woman morpeth". There was headstrong, as in "none of your bovey tracey ways here, miss!"

Jennings must have loved Dorset, where the true meaning of most village names leaps out at you, hardly requiring translation at all. Gussage St Michael, for instance, is clearly a pair of chain store knickers. When you have a hangover, you feel Duntish. Beer Hackett is an alcoholic scribbler who wrote the hard-hitting "'Swelp Me, Guv" column in the old News of the World. Catsgore was the place where the forbidden sport of cat-fighting was practised till Cromwell threatened to hang the organisers. Birdsmoorgate was a tremendous scandal involving a Bishop's Caudle and a shady doctor named Poxwell.

Many are colourful euphemisms. Up Sydling, for example: any lady of pleasure (or Plush) would know exactly what regular customers - such as Toller Porcorum, the libidinous rector, and the squire's son Haselby Pluckett (betrothed to the lovely but innocent Intrinseca) - had in mind, and were prepared to pay for handsomely.

 "I like a woman you can give a good 'ug to," my old English master used to say at school, during one of his occasional animadversions on the nature of marriage and relationships. I suspect most males would agree with him, as would the BMA, worried this week about young women suffering from eating disorders.

It's a measure of how little women actually care what men think of them that any should wish to be thin and waif-like. Most of us chaps like some flesh on the ribs. I'd guess that 90 per cent of men fancy Sophie Dahl more than Kate Moss. As for Jodie Kidd, just looking at her makes you feel like a paedophile. But the fashion industry decrees otherwise. I'm quite certain that this is no masculine plot, though it may have something to do with the large number of gays who employ the models.

While men's magazines have beautiful women on the cover, women's magazines have beautiful women on the cover too, usually looking rather different from the buxom persons who appear in FHM, Loaded and the rest. The fact is that most women are concerned about winning the admiration of other women. Men's wishes and desires are largely an irrelevance. There's nothing wrong with this, but we ought to be clear that's what it's about.

 A friend of mine called the other day to say that his daughter, who is the same age as Laura Spence and has precisely the same qualifications, applied at the same time for the same course at Magdalen, Oxford, and similarly failed to get in. The difference is that she went to a very well-known public school. "I suppose we could have argued that they were prejudiced against her because of that, but we just shrugged and went on till we found her a place somewhere else," he said.

Really talented people like Laura Spence and my friend's daughter will always find a first-rate education. We've always been terrific at educating the elite in this country, which is why we have several of the world's finest universities. What we have never yet figured out is how to educate the everyone else.

By using a warped mockery of the democratic system, Brian Souter, (who is chairman of the multi-million pound company which runs my local rail service), has managed to stir up popular hatred against a small and already oppressed minority. It's a familiar pattern in European history. Mr Souter's populist campaign might well make life more unpleasant for Scottish gays. But at least nobody will ever accuse him of making the trains run on time.
fields.bodyText: We're just back from a quick two days in a B&B in Dorset, which remains one of the nicest southern counties, possibly because no motorways go there. The scenery is bewilderingly lovely since it changes entirely every 100 yards, many of the villages are gorgeous, and the place is full of fabulous pubs whose signs indicate their desperation for you to sample their local ales and fresh seafood. Yet the council appears to have decided that there is no vista which cannot be improved by a caravan park, so as you're walking along a vertiginous cliff top, the sun sparkling on the foaming sea, gulls wheeling below you, Portland Bill shining in the distance, you suddenly come upon what might be an aerial view of the H-blocks of the Maze prison. Something else which continues to puzzle me is why petrol companies seem to have a complete dispensation from planning permission. Take Burton Bradstock, a village which looks as if it's copied from an Olde English jigsaw puzzle box, with flower -festooned thatched cottages from which you half expect to see a hedgehog in a pinny emerge with a basket of pegs. In the Anchor my son and I played bar skittles under the tutelage of a kindly gap-toothed and bearded local. It was idyllic. But just at the edge of the village is a hideous Texaco station, all huge red signs and today's prices in letters large enough to be read from Lyme Regis. Why is this? Is the assumption that motorists will drive for hours to immerse themselves in rustic beauty, but are too blind to see a filling station? If they can read the handwritten signs in windows saying: "Dainty cream teas" surely they can spot "Texaco" or "Esso" in letters less than three feet high?  Lunching in Cerne Abbas, under the great priapic giant, I read about how Radio 1 had just sacked Andy Kershaw, one of the most thoughtful, enterprising and humane broadcasters in the country. (Now there's a scandal Gordon Brown should worry about; I bet his Rochdale accent didn't help him.) On the way home, our daughter wanted the same station on the radio. We caught Chris Moyles, a man who makes Tony Blackburn sound like Professor Joad. It was drivel. You wanted to wipe the radio with a Kleenex. There was a long discussion about Denise van Outen's breasts. There was a shorter chat about how Mr Moyles (or a sidekick) wanted to see that appalling film in which All Saints appear naked. He and his friends had a vocabulary slightly larger than an intelligent chimp, though possibly smaller than some of the smarter dolphins. Things they approved of were "nice", "good", "great" or, if really admirable, "the canine testicles". As they droned on and on about nothing, saying nothing, filling up the empty airwaves with a greater vacuum, each record came as an intense but regrettably short relief.  Like Douglas Adams, the late Paul Jennings had a game in which he gave British place-names their real definitions, as opposed to the drearier ones propounded by etymologists (why does everything turn out to mean "settlement", or occasionally "settlement by the oak trees"?). To Jennings, Leeds meant "a horse's nostrils". Erith was what a philanderer did, as in the old phrase, "man erith, woman morpeth". There was headstrong, as in "none of your bovey tracey ways here, miss!" webTitle: Parky will go on chatting for ever

fields.headline: Parky will go on chatting for ever
fields.trailText: The Talk Show Story (BBC1) was presented by Michael Parkinson. It also featured Michael Parkinson as one of the guests. At several points Michael Parkinson was interviewed by an unseen figure just over the cameraman's left shoulder. Who was that interviewer? I think you can guess. But what will happen to the talk show when Parky dies? You needn't worry. As Clive Anderson revealed, steps have been taken to ensure that the singular penetrative style of whatever it is he does will survive. Even after a nuclear holocaust, commissioning editors have organised things so that Parky and his swivel chair will still be around.
fields.body:
The Talk Show Story (BBC1) was presented by Michael Parkinson. It also featured Michael Parkinson as one of the guests. At several points Michael Parkinson was interviewed by an unseen figure just over the cameraman's left shoulder. Who was that interviewer? I think you can guess. But what will happen to the talk show when Parky dies? You needn't worry. As Clive Anderson revealed, steps have been taken to ensure that the singular penetrative style of whatever it is he does will survive. Even after a nuclear holocaust, commissioning editors have organised things so that Parky and his swivel chair will still be around.

Admittedly, in some of the worst-case scenarios contemplated by the head of light entertainment and techno johnnies from the MoD, there will be no guests, but that need not be an insuperable problem, as this show amply demonstrated. This was a time to wheel out those old clips that we have come to know and be irritated by - Grace Jones hitting Russell Harty, Muhammad Ali waxing lyrical, black and white Americans in thick spectacles making jokes that only American studio audiences, to whom humour was then rationed as part of the government response to postwar austerities, could find funny.

Astoundingly - though perhaps they can remedy this in next week's episode - there was no time for Rod Hull and Emu's attack on dear old Parky, which was a great shame. To my mind, they should have shown it, alongside the clip of the time Rod and Emu met Snoop Doggy Dogg on The Word. While Mark Lamarr wound up the show, Snoop, intolerant of this bird handler's hardly sublimated hostility, chucked Emu in the corner and, with an angry expression, rested one gangsta rapper's foot on Rod Hull's neck.

What is this thing called talk? Surely the British variant of talk is called chat and was exported, with some success, by Alan Partridge to France, where he set up a fortress of chat, or chteau. (I am at this moment putting my right index finger on my nose and pointing with my left finger at my in-house drummer, who is halfway through a neat roll.)

What is most distressing about the chat/talk show is that Alan Partridge and Mrs Merton satirised it into oblivion here and The Larry Sanders Show did the same in the US, but still Graham Norton and Conan O'Brien dragged the thing back. Which is proof enough for me not only that satire does not work but also that there is no benevolent, interventionist God.

Some historians maintain that the chat/talk show started in Holland, where it is still known as the prat show. By the time Steve Allen started the Tonight show on NBC, the whole thing had become much cuter. When Allen interviewed Erroll Flynn, for instance, both were dressed as swashbucklers and traded blows as they swapped inanities. "I understand you have been doing quite a bit of travelling recently," said Allen, with a wild thrust. "Well, yes," parried Flynn. "I have been in Spain."

Which reminds me of a funny joke. Erroll Flynn got on the Central Line during the rush hour the other day, shirt open to the waist, sword alert in his sword hand. "Excuse me. Where does this train go to?" he asked a fellow traveller. "Ongar, monsieur!" said the fellow, raising his sword. "Ongar!"

But surely the Allen-Errol interaction shows the direction in which the chat show must develop if it is to hold our interest. Fewer guests, perhaps, but more weapons. Imagine if interviewer and interviewee were equipped not merely with swords, but with shotguns and live ammunition? Charlton Heston might well become a much more exciting prospect as an interviewee, particularly if he lost his temper with Des O'Connor.

Imagine, further, that once the interactive possibilities of the medium are properly exploited, with the simple push of a button Freddie Starr need never darken our screens again. This is the kind of attainable entertainment future that our so-called public service broadcasters are too lily-livered to contemplate. Instead they are content to show us clips from old programmes and pass them off as prime-time entertainment. Enough of this television reviewing. When Jack Paar, TV's first talk show superstar, retired on air, he told the audience: "There must be better ways of making a living than this. You have been peachy to me always." Sentiments that I echo, but for the fact that not one of you has been peachy. For which much thanks.

fields.headline: Ready, aim, misfire
fields.standfirst: The Royal Armouries' art exhibition has plenty of guns but little power, writes  Adrian Searle
fields.trailText: The Royal Armouries' art exhibition has plenty of guns but little power, writes Adrian Searle
fields.body:
The Royal Armouries has an image problem. It is difficult to have a museum of weapons, of arms and armour, without it appearing to glorify war and death. There are plenty of people who revel in the hardware, who get a kick out of all this stuff. I find the place grim and chilling.

For the past couple of years the Royal Armouries has been collecting and commissioning art as a corrective to this Boy's Own world of militaria, and an exhibition of the aquisitions, Warning Shots, opens today. The typography of the title - italics and caps -may be forced, the bullet-point issues clunking ("Popular Culture - violence as portrayed by the mass media"; and "The impact of real or imagined violence on innocence and the child") but the message is clear enough. Violence is bad.

The exhibition is a roll-call of modern manners and strategems. In a nasty little video Chicago artist Tony Tasset gets himself shot in the chest again and again. He stands against a white wall and a shot rings out; he is thrown back and slides bloodily down the wall, smearing the whiplash cascades of red which have erupted around him. Called Squib, the work utilises movie techniques to simulate getting wacked, rubbed out, ventilated by a gun. It is unpleasant, but you watch all the same, over and over, to spot the mechanics of the stunt. This is a made-for -TV death.

Across the gallery hangs a big colour photograph by Israeli artist Ori Gersht, a real shot of a wall in Bosnia. It is a pretty picture of an ochre painted wall in slanting sunshine, a spiral staircase climbing to a door in the middle of the picture. It is travel brochure stuff, except that the wall is pocked with bullet-holes, picked-out in the raking light. Nothing is actually happening, but there's menace here all the same.

The catalogue (overdesigned, mendacious and uncertain how to pitch itself) talks about scars on the landscape bearing witness to psychological damage. It is difficult to disagree, or to escape the cliches. There's a hand-wringing element to all this, as though the artists were being used as sticking-plasters.

The late Andrea Fisher's photograph - taken from a media photograph of a dead girl on the ground in Bosnia, is cropped to show a bit of her head, her hand clutching a purse, her hairband among the fallen leaves on the pavement. A real hairband, just like the girl's, sits on a plinth nearby. This, I think, is about the only instance where the trace of a victim appears in the whole museum. It is the more telling for its utter ordinariness.

Originally, Christine Borland's installation The Quickening, The Lightening, The Crowning was intended to be placed inside the Armouries' permanent displays. Her museum cabinets, filled with a selection of guns handed in after the massacre at Dunblane, and leather-covered babies' skulls and maternal pelvises (used as demonstration models in hospital training), with a soundtrack that mixes foetal heartbeats and gunshots, would have been fitted seamlessly among all the other weaponry and with the Robert Hardy commentaries that waft through the halls. It is a brave commission but it would have been braver to insinuate it among the other displays. That would give the gun-club visitors something to think about.

Somewhere along the line, Warning Shots tries to cover too many bases, and pays lip service to too many issues. Faisal Abdu'allah's big photo-screenprints of a scary, gun-toting kid dressed in gangster-rap uniform don't really tell us anything much except that you don't want to meet this guy. Where's the deconstruction, I ask, where's the critique?

Finally, future wars. Up in the collection is a speculative display of the weapons of the future, including a life-sized space cadet with a giant laser weapon, with a spoof label telling us about some war in a distant part of the galaxy. Gary Perkins has picked up the idea in his miniature, push-button activated model of a scene from The War of the Worlds. Toy tanks and cars are under attack from crustaceous Martian war machines in a little smoke-filled box on trestles. Push the buttons and laser guns flash, while sound effects from toy space-guns movies enliven the scene. On a little monitor, you can watch the events as though seated in a car stranded in the battle. The kids will love it.

But Orson Welles's panic-inducing 1938 radio version of HG Wells's story is still unbeatable. Welles managed to close the gap between the real and the fictional, and inadvertently tapped into real fears. Somehow, very little here has much actual affect. That's the trouble with this show, and perhaps with most art: it is cordoned-off, cauterised; it has had the firing pin removed.

 Warning Shots till September 3 at the Royal Armouries, Leeds LS10 1LT (0113 220 1999, or visit: www.warningshots.org.uk

fields.headline: The last word on   Excellence
fields.standfirst: Uncritical egalitarianism poses a threat to excellence, seen by democratic man as an easily removable cause of envy and exclusion. -  Alexis de Tocqueville
fields.trailText: Uncritical egalitarianism poses a threat to excellence, seen by democratic man as an easily removable cause of envy and exclusion. - Alexis de Tocqueville
fields.body:
When Matthew Arnold wrote Culture and Anarchy over 100 years ago, he gave expression to the ideal of excellence in the fostering of culture, by describing it as "getting to know, on all the matters that most concern us, the best which has been thought and said in the world, and, through this knowledge, turning a stream of fresh and free thought upon our stock notions and habits".

Arnold was an inspector of schools, and a champion of higher education, and he believed in excellence in education as the way not only to staff the economy, important though that is, but to produce an enculturated society which will live up to the ideal in Aristotle's dictum: "we educate ourselves in order to make noble use of our leisure."

From China to France every country that is or aspires to be developed has an elite educational stratum, aimed at taking the most gifted students and giving them the best intellectual training possible. In China this is done from an early age, with special schools for the brightest children. In France the system of Hautes Ecoles - superior universities, entry to which is fiercely competitive - cream the highest-flying minds and subject them to a rigorous discipline. The aim in all cases is to enhance the best in order to gain the highest quality in science, engineering, law, national administration, medicine and the arts.

Few could object to the rationale behind this, save those for whom universal mediocrity is a price worth paying for social equality. But there is a danger to which meritocratic means to the cultivation of excellence - or what should be solely such - falls prey. It is if, after the establishment of the means, merit by itself ceases to be enough, and money and influence become additional criteria. In many, perhaps most, countries in the world money and influence are the determiners of social advancement, even where meritocratic criteria still apply too: in America you need money to gain social advantages, in China it helps to be a party member.

Until recently the United Kingdom was one of the few countries where educational excellence was available on grounds purely of merit, despite the fact that the superior education provided by private schools ensured that plutocratic influences interfered with meritocratic ones, in this case by purchasing meritocratic advantages. This remains the case, although to a much reduced extent than formerly.

But recent changes mean that the money barrier has been reintroduced: university students now have to pay fees, and will soon be paying more. They do so either by borrowing or by relying on parents. Starting life in debt or expense, even for supposed greater rewards later, is a disincentive, and is felt especially by the already least advantaged. It is therefore an irony that a government which is reintroducing a money obstacle, and with it a serious derogation from merit as the sole criterion, should focus on influence, under the disguise of the "old school tie" - a much diminished and ever-diminishing factor - as a political ploy. If it were not a cheap opinion-poll trick, it would be troubling evidence of ignorance or unintelligence.

It is easy for popular newspapers and populist politicians to make pejorative use of the term "elite," but they are just as quick to complain if doctors, teachers, or sportsmen playing for national sides, fail our highest expectations - if, in short, they are not elite after all.

Although there are few if any true democracies in the world - most dispensations claiming that name are elective oligarchies - the democratic spirit nevertheless invests western life, both for good and ill. The good resides in the pressure to treat everyone fairly, the ill resides in the pressure to make everyone alike.

This latter is a levelling tendency, a downward thrust, which dislikes excellence because it raises mountains where the negative-democratic spirit wishes to see only plains. But democracy should not aim to reduce people and their achievements to a common denominator; it should aim to raise them, ambitiously and dramatically, as close as possible to an ideal.

Excellence in every sphere should be held out as the target, fostered and encouraged wherever found by an effort of the social will: which means, among other things, by having institutions, especially of learning, which are the finest and most demanding of their kind. A society which resents excellence is a society in trouble. What good does it do us if we hold back the best to make the rest feel better? We would not dream of doing so in football, and we would be alarmed if we thought we did it in medicine.

There is a crucial point here. It is that doing and being the best takes real effort. America's Camelot president, John F. Kennedy, was blessed in his speech-writers, one of whom wrote a memorable peroration on why America wished to put a man on the moon (the real reason was to show that America had a bigger rocket than the Soviets): we will do it, said the text of the speech, not because it is easy, but because it is hard; and doing hard things makes you better. That is what excellence is for: it is for striving towards the highest standards, and moving mankind forward thereby.

But recent changes mean that the money barrier has been reintroduced: university students now have to pay fees, and will soon be paying more. They do so either by borrowing or by relying on parents. Starting life in debt or expense, even for supposed greater rewards later, is a disincentive, and is felt especially by the already least advantaged. It is therefore an irony that a government which is reintroducing a money obstacle, and with it a serious derogation from merit as the sole criterion, should focus on influence, under the disguise of the "old school tie" - a much diminished and ever-diminishing factor - as a political ploy. If it were not a cheap opinion-poll trick, it would be troubling evidence of ignorance or unintelligence. It is easy for popular newspapers and populist politicians to make pejorative use of the term "elite," but they are just as quick to complain if doctors, teachers, or sportsmen playing for national sides, fail our highest expectations - if, in short, they are not elite after all. Although there are few if any true democracies in the world - most dispensations claiming that name are elective oligarchies - the democratic spirit nevertheless invests western life, both for good and ill. The good resides in the pressure to treat everyone fairly, the ill resides in the pressure to make everyone alike. This latter is a levelling tendency, a downward thrust, which dislikes excellence because it raises mountains where the negative-democratic spirit wishes to see only plains. But democracy should not aim to reduce people and their achievements to a common denominator; it should aim to raise them, ambitiously and dramatically, as close as possible to an ideal. Excellence in every sphere should be held out as the target, fostered and encouraged wherever found by an effort of the social will: which means, among other things, by having institutions, especially of learning, which are the finest and most demanding of their kind. A society which resents excellence is a society in trouble. What good does it do us if we hold back the best to make the rest feel better? We would not dream of doing so in football, and we would be alarmed if we thought we did it in medicine. There is a crucial point here. It is that doing and being the best takes real effort. America's Camelot president, John F. Kennedy, was blessed in his speech-writers, one of whom wrote a memorable peroration on why America wished to put a man on the moon (the real reason was to show that America had a bigger rocket than the Soviets): we will do it, said the text of the speech, not because it is easy, but because it is hard; and doing hard things makes you better. That is what excellence is for: it is for striving towards the highest standards, and moving mankind forward thereby.

fields.headline: Splitting hares
fields.standfirst: The readers' editor on... a question of attribution
fields.trailText: The readers' editor on... a question of attribution
fields.body:
Give me a moment to catch my breath. I have spent quite a long time this week in the entirely pleasurable pursuit of a hare, a hare started by one of our columnists on Tuesday. By the way - while I am panting - the Concise Oxford Dictionary says, very mildly, that the expression "start a hare" means "raise a topic of conversation"; but Brewer's Dictionary of Phrase and Fable (revised edition, 1981) comes closer to the real meaning, in my opinion, by adding the usually relevant word "irrelevant" to the definition. The hare in this sense is a relative of the red herring.

The column on Tuesday was about crime and punishment and it finished like this: "...it doesn't matter a hoot how beastly you intend to be to villains if you don't collar them first. Mrs Beeton formulated the first law of criminology, albeit in a different context: 'First catch your hare'."

This brought an immediate email from a reader who said, "Actually, she didn't." Nowhere in the admirable works of Isabella Beeton, he maintained, is anything remotely similar to be found. Certainly there is nothing like it in the undated (perhaps 1930s) edition of Mrs Beeton's Family Cookery that I have before me, although she has a great deal to say about hares. She tells me, not how to catch one, but how, when they are in season from September to March, to select from the market a good, young one ("The ears are tender and easily torn"); advises me to hang it for about a week (depending on the weather) and not to paunch [disembowel] it until required for cooking.

She tells me how to skin it - by hanging it from a hook so that both hands may be employed in the task. She instructs me in the preparation of jugged hare - a recipe that Auntie Win used on the farm at Hockliffe in my childhood - and gives the recipes for a wide variety of other hare-y dishes. But nowhere does she remind me that I must first catch the hare before I can cook it.

So who did say it? Here is Brewer again: "First catch your hare. This direction is generally attributed to Hannah Glasse, habit-maker to the Prince of Wales, and author of The Art of Cookery made Plain and Easy (1747). Her actual directions are, 'Take your Hare when it is cas'd, [cased] and make a pudding ...etc' To 'case' means to take off the skin..."

The Oxford English Dictionary says, rather playfully, "First catch your hare (ie as the first step to cooking him): a direction jestingly [my italics] ascribed to Mrs Glasse's Cookery Book [1747], but of much more recent origin."

The Dictionary of National Biography, which says (correctly) that Mrs Glasse was the habit maker to the Princess - not the Prince - of Wales, fails to enlighten us: "The attribution to Mrs Glasse of the proverb 'First catch your hare' has occasioned some discussion. The proverb is not found in her Art of Cookery, but her words, 'Take your hare when it is cased' may have suggested it."

It should be said, perhaps, that simple instructions such as this (don't try to cook it with the skin on) were more Mrs Glasse's cup of tea than Mrs Beeton's. As Mrs Glasse herself said, "If I have not wrote in the polite Stile I hope I shall be forgiven; for my Intention is to instruct the lower Sort." Do not be confused by the title of a recent edition of Mrs Glasse's book: First Catch Your Hare (details below). The book dismisses as a myth the attachment of the phrase to Mrs Glasse.

Brewer asserts, " 'First catch your hare,' is a very old phrase..." then it points to a passage in "the 13th century Bracton". This is the work of the jurist Henry de Bracton, De legibus et consuetudinibus Angliae (On the Laws and Customs of England). But what Bracton says, as Brewer concedes, is "It is commonly said that you must first catch your deer, when it is caught, skin it." Obviously we are not having that: a deer is not a hare.

No, we come back to the OED's contention that the phrase is of much more recent origin than the mid-18th century of Mrs Glasse's book. The OED finds a reference in Thackeray's The Rose and the Ring, 1855: " 'A soldier, Prince, must needs obey his orders: mine are . . . to seize wherever I should light upon him.' 'First catch your hare!' exclaimed his Royal Highness." It also notes this reference from the Times, August 25 1858: "Bitter experience has taught us not to cook our hare before we have caught it."

Both references are, in any case, before the appearance of Mrs Beeton's Book of Household Management, published in parts from 1859 to 1861 when it appeared for the first time in book form.

The hare is still running and I doubt we shall ever catch it.

 First Catch Your Hare: The Art of Cookery made Plain and Easy by Hannah Glasse, a facsimile of the first edition with essays by Jennifer Stead and Priscilla Bain, Prospect Books £27.50. fields.headline: Battle and the sexes
fields.standfirst: 'I don't think it would be any fairer to pit women against men in battle than to have them play tennis against each other at Wimbledon'
fields.trailText: 'I don't think it would be any fairer to pit women against men in battle than to have them play tennis against each other at Wimbledon'
fields.body:
On the very day that the Observer reported on its front page that the army is to train women soldiers for combat roles, ITV broadcast the first 90-minute instalment of a two-part drama about a woman officer in the British Army. It was appropriately called Rough Treatment, for the woman was brutally raped in a shower room by two fellow officers when they caught her making love with another officer. The officer she liked behaved almost as badly as the rapists by running away from the scene, leaving her to her fate, and then lying in court to get them acquitted. The second part of the drama, broadcast on Monday, was about the woman's fearsome revenge on these three repulsive men, two of whom had been expelled from their regiment in disgrace and were now doing rather well in business.

Typically of British television dramas, Rough Treatment had a rotten script and a thoroughly unconvincing plot. But if it was doing anything, it seemed to be making a strong case against women being in the army at all. Even before the rape, the heroine's treatment by her male colleagues was far worse than any woman would have to bear in any other profession. She was resented for her soldierly courage and initiative, and therefore accused of just "playing" at being a soldier. She was referred to as "a stuck-up bitch" when she rejected sexual advances, and as "a silly little tart" when she succumbed to them. Still, on she soldiered, full of pride in her regiment and determination to succeed, slogging her guts out against all the odds, only to be rewarded with a double rape and an end to her military career.

I don't think any woman wanting to join the army would pursue the idea any further after seeing this television film. But there are many women in the army already, and the question now is whether they should be allowed to brandish bayonets in the front line, just as their male comrades do. The Ministry of Defence has now decided to challenge the traditional wisdom of the armed services, that women should not engage in hand-to-hand fighting. It is putting them through a series of trials this year to test their strength, courage and psychological aptitude for the bloody work of combat. According to the Observer, they will be tested in both mixed-gender and all-women units to see how they fare. One aim is to study how men react to the presence of women on the battlefield. Then, within 12 months, a committee of experts will produce a report for the ministry entitled A Study Of Combat Effectiveness And Gender.

If there are women seeking equal rights with men to kill and to be killed, I commend them for their courage, but I don't think it would be any fairer to pit women against men in battle than to have men and women play tennis against each other at Wimbledon. If women are to form their own combat units in the British army, there should be a new international convention to ensure that the enemy units they face should also be composed of women. Another option would be to leave all combat entirely to women, with each side committing itself in advance to accept the outcome without sending any men into battle. That would at least be fair, and it might also make war a little less brutal.

At Wimbledon, of course, they also have the mixed doubles championship, and there are going to be the mixed-gender tests as part of this year's military trials. Considering all the fuss that was made about homosexuals in the armed services in the past, when military chiefs argued that their very presence threatened team discipline, I am surprised that this point hasn't yet been made with regard to women. Certainly, in Rough Treatment, the actress Daniela Nardini completely shattered team morale. Gay men and women are now welcome in the armed forces after winning a series of discrimination cases at the European Court of Human Rights, and the official line has become that they do not threaten team discipline unless they engage in overt displays of affection - the same principle that is applied to heterosexuals.

But what of anti-gay prejudice in the ranks? This is likely to be a problem. Certainly it is a serious one in the US, where Private Barry Winchell was last year battered to death by a fellow private at an army base in Tennessee because he was thought to be gay. But was he? His lover was a nightclub performer called Calpernia Addams, a man who was in the process of becoming a woman. It may be that he loved her not as a man, but as the woman she/he wanted to be. Meanwhile, gay-rights activists have turned Barry Winchell into a martyr for their cause, but in doing so have had to insist that Calpernia is a man, which has caused her/him enormous distress. These gender issues are unbearably complicated.

webTitle: One of our audiences is missing

fields.headline: One of our audiences is missing
fields.standfirst: How do you empty the Albert Hall? Book the Royal Opera.  Stephen Moss is confused
fields.trailText: How do you empty the Albert Hall? Book the Royal Opera. Stephen Moss is confused
fields.body:
Here is a puzzle. We whinge endlessly (and quite justifiably) about the Royal Opera House's outrageous ticket prices, yet when, in a laudable act of theatrical democracy, the opera company leaves its rarefied home, cuts its prices, and makes its superb production of Wagner's most accessible opera available to a far wider audience than usual, no one turns up. The Albert Hall was so empty for Die Meistersinger that, as I sprawled in the arena just in front of the stage, at times I felt that the stellar cast was performing just for me.

Either Covent Garden's marketing department has been falling down on the job - ticket sales were only 18% of capacity, according to one report - or the British public needs its collective head examined. This was a dream evening.

Meistersinger is long, of course, starting at 5pm, finishing at 10.30pm; but it is not long in the way that Siegfried, say, is long. It fizzes along at breakneck speed: it is Wagner in comic mode (showing that, if he felt like it, he could outwit Rossini) and the music is flawless. Wagner would have hated the notion of showstoppers, but this opera is full of them - the famous overture, whose majestic theme underpins the entire work, the prize song, the great quintet. The ultimate compliment to the music is that after a while the Albert Hall's noisy air conditioning ceased to matter.

This was a semi-staged production, with the costumed singers performing on an apron stage in front of the orchestra and chorus, but we were in no way short-changed. If anything, singers coming down the long flights of steps on either side of the stage, the chorus filing in and out behind the orchestra, and conductor Bernard Haitink having to half-turn to cue singers kept everyone on their toes, adding a welcome edginess to proceedings. When Beckmesser (the splendidly cod-villainous Thomas Allen) jumped off stage after losing the Eva-vision Song Contest and sprinted through the arena, it summed up both the passion of the performance and the absence of bodies in the hall (he had to vault over only one surprised middle-aged woman).

John Tomlinson was magnificent as Sachs - heroic, knowing, yet a touch too self-regarding; Gert Henning-Jensen brought boundless energy to the role of his apprentice, David; and Robert Dean Smith was ideal as Walther, the suitor who has to apply for membership of the wacky band of Meistersingers. He eventually gets in but, despite Sachs's queasily nationalistic outpouring, never looks as if he quite believes in the imperishability of German art (the last five minutes of Meistersinger and its effect on Hitler's mindset would merit further analysis). This, though, was a truly imperishable occasion, a great night at the opera, and I fear you missed it.

fields.headline: Depressing news: Radio 2 is cool
fields.trailText: Wave riding
fields.body:
How can you tell when you are getting old? This is how: get in the car, fiddle with the radio, and see how long you can endure each station. After a barrage of shouting over Britney Spears and mobile phone ads, you'll find Fleetwood Mac. "Wow, this is actually quite good." The Mac finish and Terry Wogan (Terry Wogan!) calmly announces, "You're listening to Radio 2."

We, the prematurely old, have no radio home. As pop consumerism gets younger and bands become more throwaway (heard of Northern Line and Sweet FA? Don't worry, they were last month), the process of falling out of touch seems to be accelerating. People in their late 20s and early 30s, once still within pop's catchment area, are now considered pensionable. This leaves a huge uncatered-for audience, which is where Radio 2 - once the broadcasting equivalent of stale biscuits and the Stannah Stairlift - comes in.

Jim Moir, ex-head of light entertainment at BBC TV, who took over as controller of Radio 2 in 1996, has made it his mission to target young wrinklies like me. His first job was to build on the cult potential of Radio 2's heartland shows (even - gulp - Ken Bruce), identifying the crossover cool of what Radio 2 was already doing: Tony Bennett specials and easy listening through the night (exactly the sort of music then played at trendy London clubs like Indigo). The next stage was to pepper the schedule with young-wrinkly icons: Paul Merton, selecting his classic comedy archive (a clever move to keep both old and new audiences happy); then, on Saturday mornings, Jonathan Ross, a washed-up 80s know-all who magically reinvented himself as the professionally out-of-touch man, knowingly unable to name a single modern record on Never Mind the Buzzcocks.

The result is a bizarrely radical station. The paunchy, past-it cool of people like "Whispering" Bob Harris and Wogan, with his Flan O'Brien surrealism and resolutely unfashionable music, make Radio 2 far more subversive and cutting-edge than Radio 1, with its force-fed I'm-down-with-the-kids-daddy-o trendiness.

There is a basic rule at work here. Nothing is cool if someone older tells you it is. Last week I chanced upon Chris Evans's breakfast show on Virgin. Evans told a story about his departure from Radio 1. "I was called in to see Matthew Bannister [controller of Radio 1]. 'You're out of control. If you were me, what would you do?' " "Well," Evans replied. "I'd sack me." A week later, he did. Andy Kershaw, the world music stalwart at Radio 1, has just suffered the same fate (though in his case, the sacking was more straightforward - take a holiday, don't come back). Kershaw is rumoured to have been offered a job at Radio 2 (as has Simon Mayo). His arrival would cement, depressingly for me, the fact that I am now officially a Radio 2 listener. It wouldn't even be an ironic thing any more. I'd simply be there. Here was a DJ whom I grew up with. In sacking him, Radio 1 is saying that da kidz don't want to know about the Senegalese nose-flute revolution any more (not even at three in the morning). He no longer fits Radio 1's branding as the largin' it rave station for that gold-dust 16- to 24-year-old audience. And neither (thank God) do I.

Flicking across the dial in my car, I soon realise why Classic FM and Heart FM have already cleaned up with young wrinklies. The commercial war between identikit stations is fierce: at the Sony awards, someone from Kiss FM's award-winning morning show snubbed Sara Cox of Radio 1, who responded by asking Kiss presenter Bam Bam to "suck my cock".

Young wrinklies are not served by such stations and have so far made do with whatever else was around. Now they are becoming a target audience as niche and definable as the 16- to 24-year-olds. There's a danger, however, that in skewing itself self-consciously towards knowing fogeyish-ness, Radio 2 may ruin its appeal. Namely, that it had an appeal in the first place. Sitting slap bang in the middle of the YW demographic, I should be a prime target for the Jonathan Ross show on Radio 2. But weirdly enough, I have started listening to Chris Evans. You just can't explain these things, least of all to yourself.

After a barrage of shouting over Britney Spears and mobile phone ads, you'll find Fleetwood Mac. "Wow, this is actually quite good." The Mac finish and Terry Wogan (Terry Wogan!) calmly announces, "You're listening to Radio 2." We, the prematurely old, have no radio home. As pop consumerism gets younger and bands become more throwaway (heard of Northern Line and Sweet FA? Don't worry, they were last month), the process of falling out of touch seems to be accelerating. People in their late 20s and early 30s, once still within pop's catchment area, are now considered pensionable. This leaves a huge uncatered-for audience, which is where Radio 2 - once the broadcasting equivalent of stale biscuits and the Stannah Stairlift - comes in. Jim Moir, ex-head of light entertainment at BBC TV, who took over as controller of Radio 2 in 1996, has made it his mission to target young wrinklies like me. His first job was to build on the cult potential of Radio 2's heartland shows (even - gulp - Ken Bruce), identifying the crossover cool of what Radio 2 was already doing: Tony Bennett specials and easy listening through the night (exactly the sort of music then played at trendy London clubs like Indigo). The next stage was to pepper the schedule with young-wrinkly icons: Paul Merton, selecting his classic comedy archive (a clever move to keep both old and new audiences happy); then, on Saturday mornings, Jonathan Ross, a washed-up 80s know-all who magically reinvented himself as the professionally out-of-touch man, knowingly unable to name a single modern record on Never Mind the Buzzcocks. The result is a bizarrely radical station. The paunchy, past-it cool of people like "Whispering" Bob Harris and Wogan, with his Flan O'Brien surrealism and resolutely unfashionable music, make Radio 2 far more subversive and cutting-edge than Radio 1, with its force-fed I'm-down-with-the-kids-daddy-o trendiness. There is a basic rule at work here. Nothing is cool if someone older tells you it is. Last week I chanced upon Chris Evans's breakfast show on Virgin. Evans told a story about his departure from Radio 1. "I was called in to see Matthew Bannister [controller of Radio 1]. 'You're out of control. If you were me, what would you do?' " "Well," Evans replied. "I'd sack me." A week later, he did. Andy Kershaw, the world music stalwart at Radio 1, has just suffered the same fate (though in his case, the sacking was more straightforward - take a holiday, don't come back). Kershaw is rumoured to have been offered a job at Radio 2 (as has Simon Mayo). His arrival would cement, depressingly for me, the fact that I am now officially a Radio 2 listener. It wouldn't even be an ironic thing any more. I'd simply be there. Here was a DJ whom I grew up with. In sacking him, Radio 1 is saying that da kidz don't want to know about the Senegalese nose-flute revolution any more (not even at three in the morning). He no longer fits Radio 1's branding as the largin' it rave station for that gold-dust 16- to 24-year-old audience. And neither (thank God) do I. Flicking across the dial in my car, I soon realise why Classic FM and Heart FM have already cleaned up with young wrinklies. The commercial war between identikit stations is fierce: at the Sony awards, someone from Kiss FM's award-winning morning show snubbed Sara Cox of Radio 1, who responded by asking Kiss presenter Bam Bam to "suck my cock". Young wrinklies are not served by such stations and have so far made do with whatever else was around. Now they are becoming a target audience as niche and definable as the 16- to 24-year-olds. There's a danger, however, that in skewing itself self-consciously towards knowing fogeyish-ness, Radio 2 may ruin its appeal. Namely, that it had an appeal in the first place. Sitting slap bang in the middle of the YW demographic, I should be a prime target for the Jonathan Ross show on Radio 2. But weirdly enough, I have started listening to Chris Evans. You just can't explain these things, least of all to yourself.

webTitle: He's a poet, a crooner, and the creature under the bridge

fields.headline: He's a poet, a crooner, and the creature under the bridge
fields.standfirst: Tom Cox experiences the weird allure of Tom Waites, live in Paris
fields.trailText: Tom Cox experiences the weird allure of Tom Waites, live in Paris
fields.body:
We are complete numbskulls to believe it's true, of course, but there's a brief moment at the Rex in Paris when several thousand of us think that we just may have been given Tom Waites's phone number.

"You've got my number, give me a call," rumbles Tom on I'll Shoot the Moon. "It's 2-7-9-4-6-8-2-3." A surreptitious rustle for pens can be detected. "Have you got that? That's 6-17-29-34-68-19-23, OK? 4-6-6-6-3-7-8-10-19-2-34." OK, Tom, you fooled us. For a moment, we were stupid enough to think that the primitive, cadaverous crypto-world you come from has means of electronic communication.

The unique thing about Waites is that, despite his obvious self-awareness, he probably doesn't think that a song like I'll Shoot the Moon, from 1993's discordant, seldom-heard album The Black Rider, is the least bit rancid, fetid or exotic. When Waites gnarls through a deformed ballad like this he's probably thinking of himself as a fallen diva, the proverbial fat lady singing; not the Plasticine-complexioned, beatnik Worzel Gummidge blues man that we see before us.

This is why Waites will always be so much stranger than disciples such as Beck and Gomez: he's an extraterrestrial attempting to establish himself as a human - not the opposite. The one-armed dwarfs and rain dogs he grunts about aren't just apparitions from an overactive imagination; they are the people he plays poker with in the dimly lit back room of his local bar.

Plenty of people have modelled themselves on Waites - Elvis Costello is sitting in the audience, doing his dishevelled best to mimic Tom's craggy suit and porkpie hat - but Waites has never slunk along in anyone's shadow. Well, a handful of people perhaps, but most of them have probably been dead for half a century, and, thanks to an overruling peculiarity in his genetic makeup, it's physically impossible for Waites to sound like he's imitating. He handles his instruments like he's just found them buried in Mississippi marshland and plays them like he's leading a revolution for the People of the Ground.

This whole procedure - a set lasting more than two hours, trailed by five encores - is easy for Waites now. Even the lookalikes and freaks who believe they understand him best know they will never really comprehend him, so they go into raptures at everything he does and says. He talks about his death worries and offers "creaming" as an alternative to cremation and burial; the audience roars, observing the incongruity of his concerns, coming as they do from someone as immortal and ungodly as Waites. "I know you guys - you want the hits!" he says, and the audience roars, in the knowledge that there's no such thing as a populist Waites set.

The songs Waites wrenches out of the earth from the classic Swordfishtrombones and Rain Dogs albums neglect the odd rancid rudiment - Jockey Full of Bourbon misses the extra percussion of whipped flesh, Tango Til They're Sore hasn't got the bit that sounds like crates of ale toppling down cellar stairs - and remind you just how well those albums work as cohesive mood pieces, but Waites's back-up men are skilled enough to give him space to wallow and wheeze in his own time: the accompaniment is simultaneously stripped-down and lush.

The songs mutate slightly but are uniformly timeless, Waites slobbing around in self-created luxury to revisit any moment of his 30-year career without making it sound like revivalism. He has avoided the detrimental effects of ageing on his music by being born part scarecrow, part poet, part crooner and part the creature that your mum used to tell you about that lived under the humpback bridge.

It all feels more special because it takes place in a Parisian cinema with an artificial skyline and upholstery that appears not to have been replaced since 1956, yet still looks and feels immaculate. But that's because Waites won't accept anything less than the best. He's not being a prima donna; he's being logical. He hasn't played in Britain since 1987 because Britain doesn't have a venue that's weird enough for him. Waites at Wembley Arena would be as inappropriate as Catatonia at the Coconut Lounge. More artists should be this true to their natural gifts, and ingenious enough to turn their natural disadvantages into intriguing idiosyncrasies. As far as ageless, wise, Yoda-like figures who represent all the benefits of God and Satan rolled into one go, Waites is about as sexy and self-assured as they come.

He finishes with Time, which presents the inconceivably poignant spectacle of a gremlin trying his very best to sum up the multi-formed sadness of humanity in three minutes. It features that great line about the rain sounding "like a round of applause". Stepping out into the damp Paris night a few moments later, what the rain really feels like is the thing that greets you after you've spent two hours in an underworld cauldron and washes you back to mundanity.

fields.headline: Double vision
fields.standfirst: You live together, you have kids together... and you run a business together. Can your marriage take the strain? Charlotte Abrahams meets three design-world husband-and-wife teams, to find out how it's done
fields.trailText: You live together, you have kids together... and you run a business together. Can your marriage take the strain? Charlotte Abrahams meets three design-world husband-and-wife teams, to find out how it's done
fields.body:
My husband and I work in offices 10 miles apart and in totally different industries. That's how we like it. Out to work, home to play. Private life and personal life firmly separated. That is the secret of success in both arenas - or so we thought. But, having talked to three couples, all of whom run highly successful design-retail businesses (and marriages, too, it appears), I see that the rules of separation that we consider so crucial to a happy relationship and satisfying career aren't always necessary.

Judging from these people, the reason couples become business partners seems to have more to do with expediency than rigorous planning. One decides to fulfill his/her ambition to go it alone, and the other finds spously support soon leads to full-time involvement.

Andrew Purves, one half of the couple who set up the smart contemporary furniture emporium Purves & Purves, certainly has no romantic illusions about shared vision. "I think quite often couples end up working together because, for one partner or the other, it's cheap labour." he says. "You've got one household but double the input." (Pauline Purves, who has given her financial skills and buyer's eye cheaply from the start, takes this put-down very well.)

Ros Sacher is similarly realistic. When her husband Jerry left Marks and Spencer to set up the all-American lifestyle shop Jerry's Home Store, she soon realised that, as it was going to take over his life, she'd better join the work-force, too. The position of public-relations officer was an obvious choice. "Jerry comes back and unpacks his samples on the carpet," she says, "so I see the stuff and, because he talks about it a lot, I know what's going on. I think that, in a small business, when you're very busy it would be difficult to brief a PR company to do the job. Also, we do have three children, so this is ideal. I can work from home and it can be as full- or as part-time as I want it to be."

Phil Webb can sympathise. Not that long ago his wife, Victoria Suffield, seemed happy enough running an eclectic interiors shop - The Hambledon Gallery, in Blandford, Dorset - with her mother, while he did consultancy work from home. Then she decided "it would be a laugh" to put together a mail-order catalogue as a sideline that she could run out of the back of the shop. He should have spotted the danger signs and got himself a full-time job in the city. Within a year, the "pet project" had grown unmanageably large. Victoria was still very committed to the shop and didn't want to give it up, so either the catalogue, House, had to be shelved (life-long row fodder, or what?) or Phil had to give up consultancy and buckle down, too. Four years on, Phil is running the mail-order side from the barn in the garden while Victoria, who is also responsible for styling the catalogue and all the buying, is based at the new shop, The Hambledon, in Winchester.

So how does it work? How do they all manage the pressures and irritations of shared work on top of the pressures and irritations of marriage and family life?

Physical separation seems to be vital - none of these three couples actually works in the same place, if they can help it - as does a clearly defined job description. Ros Sacher does the PR and that's all. Victoria Suffield expects Phil to respect her buying and styling decisions, and in return keeps out of all matters relating to mail order. Pauline Purves sticks to the marketing and fights a natural instinct to interfere with matters on the shop floor - and she doesn't find it easy: "Because we set up this business together, I feel really passionate about it and I find it very difficult to walk into the shop and not view it like my own sitting room. I'd like to be able to do this or that. But I mustn't do it because there is a management team."

That's very laudable, adult behaviour, of course, but (and I'm hoping for some row revelations here) surely the fact that the marketing manager or buyer or managing director is also a spouse means professional conventions are sometimes forgotten in the heat of the moment? Surely sometimes one half of the team behaves in an irrational, domestic manner rather than a cool, professional one? Not at House or Jerry's Home Store, apparently - or at least, if they do, the Webb/Suffields and the Sachers are keeping quiet. The Purveses are a bit more forthcoming, admitting that occasionally they do have heated discussions that are "a little more honest" than they might be if they weren't married. But that's a far as they'll go. It's harmony all the way - apparently.

Assuming that they can all keep petty disagreements about whose turn it is to do the shopping out of their working lives, can they keep work out of their private lives?

On this one, two out of three couples fall down. Andrew Purves claims to have no trouble switching off when he comes home, and Pauline says they rarely talk about the business at all. But Ros and Jerry and Phil and Victoria admit that work knows no boundaries. "The problem is," says Jerry, "that we are a business that trades 363 days a year. Over the weekend, the stores ring their figures through to the house, and I visit the stores every weekend. It's a pressure of time, and I know it drives Ros mad, but sometimes the only time you have to discuss things is in the evening or at the weekend."

It's the same with Webb and Suffield. They have a rule that they don't discuss work while the kids are awake, and that they don't work at the weekend, but in practice it doesn't quite work. The mail-order office is in the garden, so they can hear the phone ring if they're outside, and, while Phil may not actually answer it over the weekend, he does sneak in to collect the messages. "Work never goes away," Victoria says, "and I do resent it in a way. I love it, but I would also like to have a normal life."

So what about benefits? Flexibility seems to be the biggest one. With at least a part of each business based at home, working and looking after a family (they all have three children) is relatively straightforward.

And then there are the shopping opportunities. Jerry Sacher spent the entire interview lying in one of the two Jerry's Home Store leather recliners that furnish the study/ children's room (this may be a large house in a smart and fashionable bit of London, but it is very much a family home); and when I arrived, we had coffee around a large, zinc-topped table that I have often lusted over in the shop.

You can play spot-the-stock in the Purves' incredibly light, three-storey apartment, too - although here you can also see the downside of working with furniture. "At some stage, we're going to buy a sofa," Andrew says, surveying their almost-minimal sitting/dining room, "but the idea of choosing something..." The thought of shopping in his leisure time is so awful that he can't even finish the sentence. For now, they sit around the table (damaged stock on loan from the shop until they buy one of their own) or on the floor.

I couldn't see much House stock in Phil and Victoria's rustic-with-an-urban-twist home (although from the dining-room window I spotted several hundred packing cases, debris from a delivery of their best-selling stone balls). But, apparently, you can see quite a lot of their furniture at the shops. Their dining table, for example, has been at the Winchester site since it opened - but, no, it's not for sale. "I would do anything for money," laughs Victoria, "but I won't sell the table."

So would they recommend this working-marriage thing? Interestingly, no one quite answers the question but, judging from the success of their businesses, it must have something going for it - even if it is, as Mr Purves says, just high- quality labour for a minimal wage

Jerry's Home Store, 020-7581 0909 for branches

House, 01725 552549 (www.housemailorder.co.uk)

fields.headline: The questionnaire
fields.standfirst: Rebecca Callard
fields.trailText: Rebecca Callard
fields.body:
Rebecca Callard was born in Leeds in 1975, the daughter of actress Beverley Callard. As a child, she appeared in the TV series, The Borrowers. Grown-up, she earned acclaim for her role in Band Of Gold, and starred in Sunburn. Her voice features in The Miracle Maker, an animated film about the life of Jesus.

What is your idea of perfect happiness?
Gathering all the people I love on the island of Paros, dancing and sipping cool beers together.

What is your greatest fear?
Spiders.

What is the trait you most deplore in yourself?
I'm scatty, I lose things all the time.

What is the trait you most deplore in others?
Disloyalty.

What is your greatest extravagance?
Skincare - you can never have too many wrinkle creams.

Where would you like to live?
Sometimes Japan, sometimes New York, sometimes Paros.

What do you most dislike about your appearance?
My height - I'd like to be five inches taller (and blonde).

What is your most unappealing habit?
I'm impatient at times.

What is your favourite smell?
Christmas.

What is your favourite word?
Pickle.

What or who is the greatest love of your life?
My mum.

Which living person do you most despise?
I try not to despise anyone - but Roy Chubby Brown is really pushing me.

Have you ever said 'I love you' and not meant it?
No.

What is your greatest regret?
Not learning to drive.

When and where were you happiest?
On holiday with my family in 1998, our first holiday together - we just ate and laughed.

How do you relax?
A hot bath, meditation, a good romantic comedy, being smothered in face-pack.

What would your motto be?
Face the fear, and do it anyway.

What keeps you awake at night?
Clubbing.

How would you like to be remembered?
With an enormous statue in Trafalgar Square - I think there's room.

What is the most important lesson life has taught you?
We're not here long enough to mess around.

Grown-up, she earned acclaim for her role in Band Of Gold, and starred in Sunburn. Her voice features in The Miracle Maker, an animated film about the life of Jesus. What is your idea of perfect happiness? Gathering all the people I love on the island of Paros, dancing and sipping cool beers together. What is your greatest fear? Spiders. What is the trait you most deplore in yourself? I'm scatty, I lose things all the time. What is the trait you most deplore in others? Disloyalty. What is your greatest extravagance? Skincare - you can never have too many wrinkle creams. Where would you like to live? Sometimes Japan, sometimes New York, sometimes Paros. What do you most dislike about your appearance? My height - I'd like to be five inches taller (and blonde). What is your most unappealing habit? I'm impatient at times. What is your favourite smell? Christmas. What is your favourite word? Pickle. What or who is the greatest love of your life? My mum. Which living person do you most despise? I try not to despise anyone - but Roy Chubby Brown is really pushing me. Have you ever said 'I love you' and not meant it? No. What is your greatest regret? Not learning to drive. When and where were you happiest? On holiday with my family in 1998, our first holiday together - we just ate and laughed. How do you relax? A hot bath, meditation, a good romantic comedy, being smothered in face-pack. What would your motto be? Face the fear, and do it anyway. What keeps you awake at night? Clubbing. How would you like to be remembered? With an enormous statue in Trafalgar Square - I think there's room. What is the most important lesson life has taught you? We're not here long enough to mess around.

fields.headline: Dulcie Domum: Zen Livingstone
fields.standfirst: 'Try to conceal my horror at being mistaken for an octogenarian's sister'
fields.trailText: 'Try to conceal my horror at being mistaken for an octogenarian's sister'
fields.body:
I have but three ambitions this week: to design my Zen garden, to mend the three sick vacuum cleaners and to redecorate my bedroom. Someone once painted it brown, and now I crave something light but shadowy, like the faintly phosphorescent miasma of ghostlike distemper - the colour of the folds of an Elizabethan ruff in a portrait that needs professional cleaning. I hope they can get behind that concept down at Do-It-All.

First, though, the three sick vacuum cleaners - like characters in some updated fairy-tale. Ring VacVet, secretly hoping that Aunt's old upright will need putting down. The VacVet is a charming, middle-aged man with impeccable manners who takes our sick vacs away tenderly in his van. They look forlorn and shocked in the sunlight. Oh God! Thank God we could never afford to send them away to boarding school.

Two seconds after the VacVet van has left, I make a futile attempt to get to grips with the concept of crêpes, and drop a bag of flour on the kitchen floor. The bag explodes, coating everything with a fine film of white. However, discover belatedly that the use-by date was back in the last century, so perhaps Fate stepped in to protect us from weevils. Attempt to sweep up flour and create dust-storm worthy of the Sahara. Only suction available would be box of straws, so do the decent thing and escape out into the back garden.

Aunt is digging at far end with a tray of dahlias at her side - just where I was planning to have the bamboo screen and statue of the Buddha. Not sure if aunt sympathetic to Zen. I, however, am going overboard about all things oriental - except, of course, stir-fried spaniel. Have noticed recently that everyone else is going oriental, too, especially Ken Livingstone. His cheekbones seem to have widened and his eyes narrowed. I expect soon he will change his name to Zen Livingstone.

Halfway down the garden, hesitate. Let the aunt have her fun. Why not dahlias in Buddhist garden? Saw picture of the Dalai Lama recently wearing saffron robes and looking a bit like a dahlia himself. In fact, he's almost an anagram of a dahlia, which must be a sign.

"Hello! Isn't it a lovely day?" voice from adjoining garden - of large Victorian house, widely reputed to be brothel. Peer through hole in hedge and detect cheerful, middle-aged woman wearing high-heels and smoking cigarette. The Madame, presumably - "I'm Maureen - pleased to meetchoo!" Introduce myself and agree about weather. Aunt approaches. "Maureen, this is Elspeth."

"Pleased to meetchoo, dear. Are you sisters? There's a definite likeness."

"Ah, no. Elspeth is my husband's aunt."

Try to conceal my horror at being mistaken for an octogenarian's sister, and express admiration of Maureen's garden. "Oh, we 'ave some lovely barbecues," she confides. "You must come over."

"I've hearrrd that you rrrun a therrrapy centrrre !" gushes aunt. Maureen nods. "Do you do massage, dearrr ?" Maureen says they do. "I'd be grrrateful if one of yourrr therrrapists could have a crrrack at my lumbago!" cries aunt. Maureen looks apprehensive.

"My main masseuse is on 'oliday at the moment," she apologises. "But I fink they do 'ave a physioferapist down at the elf centre."

"Ah, but it would be so much morrre convenient to be able to get it next doorrr! " cries aunt. Maureen smiles faintly. Luckily, a cloud covers the sun and we agree it is getting too chilly to be standing about.

In kitchen, Harriet is making popcorn. "Mum!" she cries. "Your hair an' your face are, like, todally white!" Recall episode with the flour. Rush to looking-glass. I look 70. On the other hand, the hint of ageing skin through the film of white particles is just the effect I want for my bedroom walls. Tempted to drive to DIY store and request paint to match my cheeks, but decide to endure cup of tea with aunt, as it is my duty to find reason why she should abandon her plan to penetrate brothel next door and demand relief.

The Zen garden will have to wait. I am, however, forming a plan to go round to Maureen's and ask to borrow her vacuum cleaner.
