fields.headline: Superplonk
fields.trailText: The average score for each of the wines that follows is, to be utterly precise, 17.2 points out of 20. Readers often ask why are there never any 20-pointers, or even 19-ers in this column, and my response is that, for a bottle to be so perfect, it must be an extremely luscious, complex wine at its peak of maturity. And which high-street retailer or supermarket sells such wines? I tasted only one 20-point wine last year, a 1982 Sori San Lorenzo Barbaresco by Angelo Gaja, priced at £160, and available only from Volvona & Crolla in Edinburgh (a city that is more the Milan of the north than the soi-disant Athens), and I confess I finished the whole bottle over several long and very heady hours.
fields.body:
The average score for each of the wines that follows is, to be utterly precise, 17.2 points out of 20. Readers often ask why are there never any 20-pointers, or even 19-ers in this column, and my response is that, for a bottle to be so perfect, it must be an extremely luscious, complex wine at its peak of maturity. And which high-street retailer or supermarket sells such wines? I tasted only one 20-point wine last year, a 1982 Sori San Lorenzo Barbaresco by Angelo Gaja, priced at £160, and available only from Volvona & Crolla in Edinburgh (a city that is more the Milan of the north than the soi-disant Athens), and I confess I finished the whole bottle over several long and very heady hours.

For £160, you can buy 32 bottles of Valdivieso Barrel Selection Merlot 1998, from Chile, and enjoy several weeks' splendid tippling. This wine, like all those in this week's column, is available at Majestic Wine Warehouses, a company that more than one reader has beefed about due to its inflexible policy of selling only by the case or mixed case. Nevertheless, on the basis of the price and quality of certain of its bottles, Majestic can peddle a bargain as shrewdly as any. This merlot is wonderful, happy juice, parading leather, tannins, blackberries and plums, a hint of cinnamon, and a lingering finish. It rates 17 points and costs £5.99 per bottle (as part of a mixed case of other wines), but if you buy two or more bottles you can pick it up for £4.99.

Pirramimma Cabernet Sauvignon 1998 (17 points, £7.99, or £6.99 for two bottles or more), from Australia, is intensely concentrated and deep, and has a lushly textured tightness that opens up deliberately and deliciously with stunning tannins. Pirramimma Petit Verdot 1997 (17 points, £8.99, or £7.99 for two bottles or more) really races over the tastebuds, sweeping all before it as it does so. It has a sullen spiciness at first, then the huge tannins arrive, and it's one long torrent of richness and depth.

Chteau Flauguergues Cteaux du Languedoc 1998 (17.5 points, £6.99, or £5.99 for two bottles or more) is very elegant. The tannins and the fruit are deliciously melded and softened one into the other, and the finish is inspired. This is a very serious yet fun-to-drink wine. Chteau Trignon Ctes du Rhne Villages Sablet Ramillades 1998 (17.5 points, £6.49, or £5.99 for two bottles or more), meanwhile, has absolutely compelling richness and beautifully earthy tannins. The quintessence of elegant rusticity, it's a compelling performer from nose to throat: teasing, taut and tenacious. Domaine de Rodes Syrah Vin de Pays d'Oc 1998 (16.5 points, £3.99, or £3.49 for two bottles or more) has rousing richness, layered, earthy fruit and offers stunning value at the two-bottle price.

Mas de Bressades Cabernet Syrah Vin de Pays du Gard 1998 (17 points, £6.99, or £6.49 for two bottles or more) presents irreproachable tannins linked to thrusting hedgerow fruitiness. Marvellous old world/new world marriage of styles (ie, softness and ripeness with character and backbone). Mas de Bressades Cuvée Excellence Costières de Nmes 1998 (17.5 points, £6.99, or £6.49 for two bottles or more) has more eagerness on the finish than its cab/syrah brother, a tighter texture and a slightly more lingering, individual finish.

Even more individuality is in evidence with Aglianico del Vulture 1997 (18 points, £9.99), from Basilicata in southern Italy. It is a mineral-tinged treat, combining concentrated ripeness and the unique tang of the grape and the region. It is an altogether beautiful, confident, stunning mouthful. As is Valpolicella Classico Superiore Domini Veneti 1996 (17 points, £6.99) The individuality stays the sane side of eccentricity while offering spice, cherries, leather, sweet blackberries, soft tannins and a hint of prune.

Also from Italy, and to round things off on a high note, is Capitel Monte Olmi Amarone Tedeschi 1995 (17.5 points, £18.49), which is a lot of money, but for a lot of wine. It is an outstandingly joyously quaffable wine of coal-mine depth yet dainty-finishing richness. It combines fennel, spiced plums, blackberries and savoury tannins. Available in very limited quantities at all branches, it is a wine for a special occasion.

webTitle: In the realm of the scented

fields.headline: In the realm of the scented
fields.standfirst: The early bird, says Christopher Lloyd, catches the best of nature's fragrance. In those first hours of daylight, scents range from flowery perfume to incense, stewed apple and even fruit salad
fields.trailText: The early bird, says Christopher Lloyd, catches the best of nature's fragrance. In those first hours of daylight, scents range from flowery perfume to incense, stewed apple and even fruit salad
fields.body:
May included a lot of what gardeners call good growing weather - that is, warm and humid. The day would start with thick, heavy mist, and 7am was (and will for weeks remain) ideal for going into the garden.

At that time, scents are heaviest on the air. You move from the orbit of one to the next, with scarcely a break between. Take, for instance, the incense rose, Rosa primula , which smells exactly of that. A few years ago, Fergus moved it from where it wasn't doing very well to where it is now extremely happy, but that happens to be eight or so metres from the nearest path, so it's become hard to catch a whiff of it. This morning, however, it was with me strongly, distance notwithstanding.

Our sweet briars (and they self-sow pretty freely) are more helpfully placed, scent-wise, though ready to grab you by the clothes or scalp as you sidle past. Their scent is of stewed apples. If you prune them pretty hard each year, they will be making new growth right through the summer and into autumn, and it is the young foliage that gives off the strongest aroma. The way to prune is to remove every year the previous year's flowered/fruited growth - whole branches of it - leaving the long, unbranched young wands to do the flowering and fruiting for the coming season. (Beware the armature of prickles, as this is exceedingly vicious.) The hips are brilliant scarlet and look scintillating if sited next to the plumes of pampas grass.

All elaeagnus have tiny but wonderfully-scented flowers. Some of them, such as the evergreen E. x ebbingei, flower in autumn, but deciduous kinds do so in late spring. E. angustifolia will make a beautiful little silver-leaved tree (like the weeping pear, but without the weeping habit), if pleased. It likes a continental climate - hot summers and cold winters.

This is related to the elaeagnus that is now called 'Quicksilver' (once 'Caspica'), which makes a large shrub (the size is easily controlled by pruning) with brightly silvered, oval leaves. It is usually grown just for its foliage, but also bears tiny, pale-yellow, fragrant flowers in late May. This blooms about two weeks after E. umbellatus, which is exceedingly prolific in flower and scents a large part of my garden, downwind. It makes a big shrub; the young foliage is pale green. Plant it in the background somewhere, as it is dullish for much of the year.

For the second half of May (in the south), Azara serrata is a great asset against a sunny wall, though allowed to bulge forwards. It is quite bulky (good near to a blue, evergreen ceanothus) but not entirely hardy. The poufs of bright yellow flowers are showy and smell strongly of fruit salad on the air; it has glossy, evergreen leaves.

May-flowering, deciduous azaleas are well known for their powerful pong, which can be almost too strong and pervasive in quantity. I would rather visit a garden in which they abound than grow them myself. But there are other, more restrainedly fragrant azaleas, such as the June-flowering Rhododendron occidentale and, another welcome late one, R. arborescens.

Rhododendrons can be under- and interplanted with lilies-of-the-valley, which will make a carpet with their characteristic foliage, each shoot having one pair of leaves. They like moisture and a leafy, organic soil. Although tolerant of quite deep shade, they flower much more freely where some sun can reach them. The wild lily-of-the-valley is not in general cultivation, and has unnecessarily small flowers for garden purposes. On the other hand, just to be difficult, I find 'Fortin's Giant' a bit vulgar and self-advertising. Var. rosea is a dirty and ineffective pink that appeals to some. 'Variegata' has longitudinal yellow stripes on its leaves, and they are charming although, unfortunately, large areas of a colony will revert to plain green and the flowers are as small as the wildings'.

One way or another, the typical C. majalis, as grown in all our gardens (you can surely beg some from a friend), is the best to have. If grown near to paving, it will run between the cracks, which is delightful if you don't tread on them. Should there be a few stray blue forget-me-nots around, that is better still.

I have never had lilies-of-the-valley in such quantities as to be able to sniff them on the air (I have experienced this elsewhere), but they are ideal for pulling (not picking, let alone cutting; just pull each stem cleanly out of its socket) and enjoying at close range indoors.

The climbing honeysuckle season starts in earliest May, Lonicera caprifolium being one of the most precocious. It is a charmer, though pale in colouring. It is sometimes difficult to find the right place for yet another climber. In the case of honeysuckles, you could do worse than grow one (or more) as an open-ground shrub, without providing it with support. No objection whatever will be raised to this treatment. Or, give it the pole treatment and grow it up a strong pole of convenient length, rising among and above the contents of a mixed border.

If you have plenty of space, you might spare a thought for L. rupicola var. syringantha (2m), which makes a large, fairly unruly, though easily controlled, non-climbing shrub, with clusters of tubular, rosy-mauve flowers, very well scented. After its main early-summer flowering, it will continue to produce some blossom right through to autumn

fields.headline: The net addict
fields.trailText: www.martinamis.albion.edu and surfing for real
fields.body:
While retouching my Ipanema-style bikini wax, Marika (who grooms one or two hirsute but influential grande-dames in publishing) mentioned some literary gossip. Apparently, Kingsley Amis's bitterness in old age was because he was convinced he was the love child of couturier Sir Hardy Amies and Wallis Simpson, but his surname had been shortened to conceal the scandal. Judging from his serialised autobiography, Martin's life seems riddled with equally strange twists, though I couldn t find anything about this in www.martinamis.albion.edu, and the book's too long for me to read.

I needed Marika because Ricky, who is a keen surfer, had asked me to go with him to Perranporth for the weekend. I d never surfed before, but I was delighted to discover that I am a natural. Jem H, another ace surfer we met there who looks like a Greek god (pity Ricky was with me), turned out to be a twin soul. He told me about good sites: www.surfstation.co.uk, www.meto.govt.uk, and www.fnmoc.navy.mil

On Sunday morning, intoxicated with love, I ran to the beach, climbed on my board and caught those magic waves gold-flecked by the rising sun. Feeling free as a cloud, I threw away my minuscule bikini and rode the tide, then I went back to the hostel and woke Ricky...

Later, while exchanging sweet whispers, he said that webcams are sited in Perranporth. The image of gorgeous me riding the waves stark naked was there in cyberspace for all to see! Thank God Marika had done a superb job.

Many of you have sent emails to congratulate me on this site, but some have had trouble finding it. The net is like the world: everything starts in the US. I'm told it's only a matter of time before all servers and search engines realise that Tanya is available to all.

fields.headline: How to shave
fields.trailText: One of the reasons so many men go through the appalling rigmarole of shaving every morning is because not shaving would inevitably lead to the appalling rigmarole of being a man with a beard.
fields.body:
One of the reasons so many men go through the appalling rigmarole of shaving every morning is because not shaving would inevitably lead to the appalling rigmarole of being a man with a beard. Because shaving is not one of life's most uplifting activities, some men don't bother for a couple of days and go for the stubble look. The impression they think they're giving is that of a rough, tough man from the prairies. The impression they're actually giving is lazy little skanker for whose partners a kiss is like having a Black & Decker sander pressed to your face.

Shavers can get all sorts of gels, oils and creams. Oils are good, because you can see where you're going, but they're also slippery, so that before you know it, your ear will be quietly bleeding on the floor.

Those creamy lathers, applied by badger-bristle brushes, are great for doing it like your father did it, but if there's one species who should be keeping their bristles its badgers. Gels are good because they go a long way - generally over nearby curtains, as they tend to be sold in highly pressurised canisters.

Why anyone ever used a cut-throat razor is an absolute mystery - it's like driving a 'hit-tree' car, or 'make-baby' condom. Disposable razors are so called because they take up a huge proportion of your disposable income. These razors have two, three or even four blades on the same head, and claim to cut so close that you actually expose your jawbone. What they don't tell you is that you can get the same effect by doing two more strokes with your simple one-bladed razor.

To keep the skin taut when shaving, you have to pull a range of faces, any one of which would have got you a thick ear if you had pulled them as a child.

Men are always slightly disappointed by how few shaves they get from an average razor. It's gives a fantastic first shave, but the next one feels like a rusty hacksaw blade. What has happened in the interim is that your beloved has shaved both legs with it, which in shaving terms is the equivalent of deforesting the Amazon.

If someone threw aftershave in your face in the street, you would rightly have them for assault with a deadly weapon, but up and down the country bathrooms are full of the screams of agony of men splashing raw alcohol on to their tender, bleeding faces. The alternative is to put on a soothing moisturiser with extract of ylang ylang. But if you're going to undermine your manhood to that extent, you might as well grow a beard.

fields.headline: The joy of text
fields.standfirst: Who'd have thought it: the big boom in mobile-phone use is not the spoken word but  written messages. And, says Richard Benson, it's transforming the way we interact
fields.trailText: Who'd have thought it: the big boom in mobile-phone use is not the spoken word but  written messages. And, says Richard Benson, it's transforming the way we interact
fields.body:
Beep-beep, beep-beep. Beep-beep. In February this year, Sophie Oliveira, a 28-year-old TV researcher from Leeds, goes to watch a London performance by De La Guarda, the Argentine theatre company-cum-circus show that is said to "challenge the boundaries between audience and performer".

During the show, a male performer walks into the audience and asks to borrow her mobile phone. She agrees. He makes a call, and then hands the phone back to her. Sophie, curious but apprehensive, sends a text message saying "Who is this?" to the number he's just dialled. The reply comes after the show, when she's in the pub; it consists, somewhat unhelpfully, of the words "alright u tart?!" It turns out to be the De La Guarda man; he'd called his own phone when he borrowed hers to store her number.

"how do u knw I'm a TART?" types Sophie, who is up for a laugh.

"i cn sense it frm here. I like that in a woman" replies the, er, charmer.

"hmmm... what else do u like in a woman?" she taps - at which point I must draw a discreet veil over an exchange that went from textual to sexual into the small hours.

"Yes, I suppose you could call it text-sex," says Sophie, laughing. "Actually, he did try to call me twice during it, but I just switched him off - I wouldn't have wanted to speak to him. Text-messaging is really different from talking... it's a completely different thing. Messages have got that kind of flirty thing..."

Beep-beep. In April, Mr Balil Patel, an IT consultant from Preston, thinks of an answer to a problem that has long vexed British Muslims. The problem concerns the sun; Muslims pray to Mecca when the sun rises and sets, but in Britain it's hard to tell when that happens, because there are few muezzins to alert you to it, it's often too cloudy to see the sun yourself, and you have a busy modern schedule to distract you. Mr Patel checks the sunset time in the morning paper, sets up a group-send on his mobile's messaging function, then, every evening, sends a warning text-message to his friends just before sundown.

Beep-beep. During the campaigning for Zimbabwe's constitutional referendum in February, mobile-phone users opposed to Robert Mugabe send a "VOTE NO" text message to groups of random numbers. This is one of the few ways to get the anti-Mugabe message across in a mass medium, because opposition parties are little reported or misrepresented in state-controlled newspapers and television. After the referendum, Strive Masiyiwa, the chief executive of Zimbabwe's largest mobile phone network, has to employ bodyguards after he is attacked several times by Mugabe supporters.

Beep-beep-beep-beep-beep-beep-beep-beep. People who work in the mobile-phone industry are well-used to high levels of demand for their services, but they have never seen anything like the figures for text-messaging. From an initial total of 40 million in January 1999 - the first month that British users could send them from one network to another - the number of dinky, digital messages of up to 160 characters sent in the UK had risen to 360 million by this April, and May's figure is expected to top 500 million.

In other countries, the figures are even higher: the Italians currently send twice the number of text messages that we do, and the Germans three times. The earth's population as a whole sent three billion text messages in December 1999 alone - the last month for which figures are available - and industry observers expect that figure to reach 10 billion by the end of this year.

Those observers don't really know who is sending the messages, or what they're sending them for, but they estimate that 10% are work-related (managers telling their travelling salesmen about stock prices, for example, or engineers letting their warehouses know they're running low on components), while the other 90% are the titchy, thumbed-in and beamed-out bulletins, broadsides and billets-doux sent by the rest of us.

The people at the companies that make the phones or run the networks are excited, bewildered, or both; none of them even imagined text messages becoming this popular, and a few thought they wouldn't catch on at all. Indeed, off the record, some people from the networks will tell you that they underestimated the demand so badly that they can't increase broadcast-capacity fast enough to keep up; they'll tell you that this is why your phone has been flashing those brain-bothering "network busy" messages so often in the past 18 months.

They tend to explain the appeal in terms of practicality. Nokia's UK business development manager, Mark Squires, thinks it has got a lot to do with cost (you can send a text message anywhere for a trip-to-a-70s-sweetshop-sized 10p), and with what he calls the "control factor" (as in, you get to read it if, and when, you want).

Ericsson's senior product manager, Colin Ellis, agrees. He also points out that they have made mobile communications accessible to the deaf for the first time, and adds that the popularity "is also down to them being so discreet and personal; no one need know when you're sending or reading a text message, even if you're in a meeting. And you don't have to use the manual to learn how to do it. We've realised that however good a service is, if people have to read the manual in order to use it, it won't happen."

But there seems to be something more than practicality about the appeal of text messaging: something that gives them that brown-paper-packages-tied-up-with-string quality, and qualifies them for life's range of small, good things. Text messages are like little sugar-rushes of contact, postcards for the people's cyberspace, the real reason God gave us both thumbs and the capacity for language (alright, alright, I know).

What explains it is vague, and hard to pin down; part of it must be that they seem sent to solve so many of our modern manners-conundrums. Such as: what to do when you want to ask someone something without getting sucked into the pleasantries-and-gossip-vortex? Or when you're on the bus and can't wait, but wish to avoid "I'M ON THE BUS"-syndrome? Or when you wish to ensure that the forgetful friend you're phoning has the directions to your house written down correctly? There's also the way they pander to the deep-rooted, but rarely acknowledged, human love of making up stupid languages ("Gr8 2 CU", etc). And, of course, there's that "kind of flirty thing".

It is not only anecdotal evidence that suggests people have created a new kind of non-contact foreplay with text-messaging. Last year, 44% of mobile-phone users questioned in a survey for Nokia said that text messages meant they told their partner they loved them more often; 53% used it to apologise after rows; and a saucy 18% suggested they might, ahem, "make love" later that evening.

From different research, Orange has found that 64% of its customers think that text messages are "a good way to flirt with people they'd like to know better". Now, of course, both companies could just be talking up small surveys - it's a good story, after all - but Nokia has acted on its findings, compiling lists of ready-made romantic messages to be stored in phones, thus saving users the effort of making up their own (yes, I know, I know - tell them). And most mobile users will tell you that they like getting it in writing, particularly in those tricky early stages of a relationship.

It is, perhaps, surprising that they appeal to men as much as women, given the former's poor reputation regarding regular declarations of affection. As Mark Squires says, in a strange moment of man-to-man intimacy with me at the Mobile Expo 2000 show in Birmingham's NEC, "Somehow, you can say stuff like 'I love you' easier, can't you? A lot of men can't say it to their girlfriends because it makes them feel... soppy. But they can send it on text message. Men like this just the same as women. There haven't been many things like that, but we do find that, with the modern communications technology market, you can't look for those old divisions and values."

It might only be because it combines the love letter with gadgetry, but the text message does appear to have encouraged men to write and call more; and, in this respect, it might just be carrying on the good work of its telephonic ancestors. Some commentators in the past have credited the universal adoption of the telephone with making men more willing to talk about their emotions. The emotionally inarticulate apparently find it easier to talk about their feelings if their friend is on the other end of a phone line, while they're in a room on their own; and being able to type it out and send it via radio masts now seems to be helping them feel positively at one with themselves and the world. Beep-beep, mate.

Text-messaging's proper name is Short Message Service (commonly referred to as SMS), and you have the European Union to thank for it. In the early 80s, the EU's telephones department rather presciently decided that it needed a system that would work across all its national boundaries, and persuaded engineers from each member-country's major phone company to invent it. Despite the vast comedic potential of this arrangement, the engineers had, by 1992, created a form of radio communication called the Global System for Mobile Communication, or GSM.

Because some of the engineers had heard of the internet, and thought that people might want to send messages to it with their phones, they built into the system a facility that allowed users to send a bit of text. The first SMS was sent from a PC to a mobile phone on the Vodafone network in Britain in early 1992, but its development seems to have been something of a just-in-case measure - the GSM engineers didn't even bother to work out how to return messages until after GSM had been put into operation in Europe in the early 90s.

In Britain, SMS initially attracted little interest from the networks but, as the competition between them increased, they began half-heartedly promoting text-messaging as an added-value teaser to existing services. Because they would allow it only within their own network, however, it was next-to-useless for most people. The networks now say that technical hitches and difficulties with commercial agreements held them up in making it possible to text-message between them, but you get the impression that few people working there at the time thought SMS would be popular with the public. Some will admit that, originally, they thought mainly of using it to send information to their customers; a public predilection for sending silly 160-letter letters to each other wasn't the sort of "projection" that came up at strategy meetings.

In Britain, Orange, Cellnet, Vodafone and Mercury One2One finally made it possible to use SMS across different networks in January 1999. Through winter and early spring, take-up was healthy but, in comparison with what was to come, unremarkable - 40 million a month between January and April.

Then something started to happen that took the people at the networks by surprise. Pay-as-you-go mobile vouchers, which obviated the need for credit checks and direct debits from bank accounts, were bringing mobile phones to mass-ownership among under-18-year-olds, and for them text-messaging was ideal and instinctive. It was far cheaper than calling; it had a novelty value; it felt natural to a generation that had grown up with email, and you could use it when you weren't supposed to be sending messages, thus annoying adults and teachers alike (text-messaging in schools is now creating a dilemma for teachers; parents insist their children carry phones for personal safety, but the children use them for surreptitious digital-note-sending in lessons. Many schools ban them from desks during lessons, and one private school in Berkshire has just instituted a fine system for anyone caught texting in teaching-time).

With pre-pay customers averaging three times more SMS-ing than others, the figures began to rise steeply, hitting 271 million in December. All the networks now agree that the youth market was the "key driver" in popularising SMS, and make deeply appreciative statements about "young people" and their "non-technophobia".

"We're going to see lots of SMS services becoming available," says Colin Ellis. "It's all about the art of the possible. And because youth is all about pushing boundaries and experiment, young people are experts at the art of the possible."

There used to be a joke in the industry that young people became so fond of SMS because, when they were in nightclubs, say, they found it easier to send and read a message than to hear someone speak. Then someone noticed that there really was a rise in use between 10pm and 2am on Friday and Saturday nights; they're still wondering about that.

Whatever; however much, or little, text-messaging is being done on and around the dancefloor, it is clear that it has permeated British youth culture in, it has to be said, some fairly mirth-prompting ways. Pirate radio station DJs in London, for example, can be heard appealing over the airwaves for missives from the "Text Message Crew" (and, indeed, "The Email Massive"). Details of illegal squat parties are messaged through to caller groups. It was no surprise at all to find Orange sponsoring the 20th anniversary issue of The Face magazine in May this year, and registering its presence in the form of a 12-screen text message (from "The Big O") printed on a page.

It's all very well bowing to the youth market but, of course, admitting that the kids know what's going on is just the modern, cool way of admitting that you haven't a clue. The truth is that we're in unmapped territory here, and no one knows what people will do with their mobeys. Everyone can see there's a lot of potential for mobile phones, but the industry is realising - partly because the text-message boom took it by surprise - that the psychology of mobile-phone use is unpredictable, and any commercial exploitation of SMS will have to take into account our, well, feelings towards them. From the little research that has been done, we know that we have a more personal, closer reaction to text messages received on a phone than to email on our PC, for example. And that people who message a lot feel unpopular (or, perhaps, suffer "phoneliness") if they don't receive any for a while, and will start sending until they get a response.

On the other hand, my own research suggests that we don't like strangers invading our personal phone-space. In one week, I sent out 70 messages to numbers chosen at random. The messages were varied: a formal one ("Hello. This is a msg sent at random by R Benson, a journalist writing abt txt msgs for the Guardian. If you would like to be interviewed abt txt msgs, pls reply"); a jovial one, sent with a fictitious young friend (Hi!! We're messing about with our phone, we're sending msgs 2 people we don't know to see who's there! Pls reply, love rich and emma); a somewhat embarrassing sci-fi one ("Is there anybody out there?" - well, I thought that might catch an X-Files fan, or something); and a simple one ("Hello stranger"). I got just one reply, to a "Hello stranger". It seemed encouraging at the time, and I thought it might be rather interesting to interview a stranger via text message for this article; but unfortunately, our encounter amounted to the following:

Me: "Hello stranger"

Them (after 10 minutes): "Well hello to you to" (sic)

Me: "Thank u! I've been sending msgs 2 strangers to see how long t wd take to get a reply. u r the 1st! don't worry - I am sane. Richard"

Them (after 24 hours): "Who are you"?

Me: "My name is Richard Benson. I am a journalist writing a story about text messages. Would you like to be interviewed by text message for the story? It would be anonymous; no need to give names, etc. What do you think?"

Them: Nothing

Me (after 24 hours): "Umm, is that a 'no', then?"

Them: Nothing.

And that was it. My conclusions: a) I am no better at chatting people up than I was at 15, b) text-messaging is probably not a good medium for meeting new friends, or for direct marketing, because c) although mobiles are good for concealing one's location and identity, it's still a bit spooky to get messages from someone you don't know.

Nevertheless, you probably will be swapping them with strangers soon, because of technology that will allow you to buy things, look things up, and have information sent to you in text-message form. Cellnet's Genie service (which has signed up Balil Patel's mobile minaret) and a company called Sonera Zed are already working in this area (and if you don't think that sounds interesting, you should check their websites: they're good). You can already send graphics, and some networks will supply text-message Christmas cards this year, but that's nothing. In Finland, where the technology is more advanced, you can send a text message to a vending machine, which will deliver, say, a soft drink and put the charge on your phone bill; or order a plane ticket, which comes in the form of a text message, so all you have to do at the check-in desk is show your phone. You'll only have this until 2005, though; by then, "more advanced data services" and permanently open internet connections will probably edge it out.

Will they have any lasting influence on us? Cd vwls dspr frm th lng'ge altgthr? Or could we end up with a two-tier language system, in which everyday English wd b abbreviated, + cd include numbers + l8rs 2gthr? History offers an interesting parallel that suggests that the answers to these questions could be a partial "ys".

In the 18th century, a major programme of road-building led to improved transport and mail services throughout England. At the same time, developments in technology made it cheaper to manufacture printing presses, and they became more widely available. As a consequence, more people were able to travel, there was a new, widespread interest in printed communications, and letter-writing became increasingly popular; it even inspired a new literary genre in the epistolary novel, of which Samuel Richardson's Pamela remains the best-known example. All this had a direct impact on language, and the way people used it. The conventions of letter-writing (addresses in the top corners, Dear Sirs and Madams, and so on) were established, for example, and dictionaries were created to standardise spellings between different areas of the country.

As the infamous media guru Marshall McLuhan pointed out, changing forms of communication tend to change the way we talk. Sometimes - see the blokes-and-phones theory - they can change the way we act and think, too. It's impossible to know what effect emails and text messages will have on us, but it is clear that they have instigated the biggest boom in "letter" writing for 200 years; and while we don't, yet, have a text-message novel, the tight, subject-less sentences and the reproduced emails in Bridget Jones' Diary have at least a touch of the digital missives.

Mike Short, the chairman of the GSM Association's Mobile Data Taskforce, believes that text-messaging is part of a epoch-defining shift in the way we communicate with one another, a "move from a verbal to a visual culture", as he puts it. That seems a rather grand claim to make on its behalf, but then, if you're not sure what's happening, you might as well try to sound excited about it.

The rest of us don't know so much about that, but will carry on using SMS because, of all the clever services and bits of information the techies find to give us, our favourites are the ones that let us talk to each other and make each other laugh. And because, as all good text-maniacs know, when you're dialling, the whole world :-)s with you. Beep-beep

Nokia's UK business development manager, Mark Squires, thinks it has got a lot to do with cost (you can send a text message anywhere for a trip-to-a-70s-sweetshop-sized 10p), and with what he calls the "control factor" (as in, you get to read it if, and when, you want). Ericsson's senior product manager, Colin Ellis, agrees. He also points out that they have made mobile communications accessible to the deaf for the first time, and adds that the popularity "is also down to them being so discreet and personal; no one need know when you're sending or reading a text message, even if you're in a meeting. And you don't have to use the manual to learn how to do it. We've realised that however good a service is, if people have to read the manual in order to use it, it won't happen." But there seems to be something more than practicality about the appeal of text messaging: something that gives them that brown-paper-packages-tied-up-with-string quality, and qualifies them for life's range of small, good things. Text messages are like little sugar-rushes of contact, postcards for the people's cyberspace, the real reason God gave us both thumbs and the capacity for language (alright, alright, I know). What explains it is vague, and hard to pin down; part of it must be that they seem sent to solve so many of our modern manners-conundrums. Such as: what to do when you want to ask someone something without getting sucked into the pleasantries-and-gossip-vortex? Or when you're on the bus and can't wait, but wish to avoid "I'M ON THE BUS"-syndrome? Or when you wish to ensure that the forgetful friend you're phoning has the directions to your house written down correctly? There's also the way they pander to the deep-rooted, but rarely acknowledged, human love of making up stupid languages ("Gr8 2 CU", etc). And, of course, there's that "kind of flirty thing". It is not only anecdotal evidence that suggests people have created a new kind of non-contact foreplay with text-messaging. Last year, 44% of mobile-phone users questioned in a survey for Nokia said that text messages meant they told their partner they loved them more often; 53% used it to apologise after rows; and a saucy 18% suggested they might, ahem, "make love" later that evening. From different research, Orange has found that 64% of its customers think that text messages are "a good way to flirt with people they'd like to know better". Now, of course, both companies could just be talking up small surveys - it's a good story, after all - but Nokia has acted on its findings, compiling lists of ready-made romantic messages to be stored in phones, thus saving users the effort of making up their own (yes, I know, I know - tell them). And most mobile users will tell you that they like getting it in writing, particularly in those tricky early stages of a relationship. It is, perhaps, surprising that they appeal to men as much as women, given the former's poor reputation regarding regular declarations of affection. As Mark Squires says, in a strange moment of man-to-man intimacy with me at the Mobile Expo 2000 show in Birmingham's NEC, "Somehow, you can say stuff like 'I love you' easier, can't you? A lot of men can't say it to their girlfriends because it makes them feel... soppy. But they can send it on text message. Men like this just the same as women. There haven't been many things like that, but we do find that, with the modern communications technology market, you can't look for those old divisions and values." It might only be because it combines the love letter with gadgetry, but the text message does appear to have encouraged men to write and call more; and, in this respect, it might just be carrying on the good work of its telephonic ancestors. Some commentators in the past have credited the universal adoption of the telephone with making men more willing to talk about their emotions. The emotionally inarticulate apparently find it easier to talk about their feelings if their friend is on the other end of a phone line, while they're in a room on their own; and being able to type it out and send it via radio masts now seems to be helping them feel positively at one with themselves and the world. Beep-beep, mate. Text-messaging's proper name is Short Message Service (commonly referred to as SMS), and you have the European Union to thank for it. In the early 80s, the EU's telephones department rather presciently decided that it needed a system that would work across all its national boundaries, and persuaded engineers from each member-country's major phone company to invent it. Despite the vast comedic potential of this arrangement, the engineers had, by 1992, created a form of radio communication called the Global System for Mobile Communication, or GSM. Because some of the engineers had heard of the internet, and thought that people might want to send messages to it with their phones, they built into the system a facility that allowed users to send a bit of text. The first SMS was sent from a PC to a mobile phone on the Vodafone network in Britain in early 1992, but its development seems to have been something of a just-in-case measure - the GSM engineers didn't even bother to work out how to return messages until after GSM had been put into operation in Europe in the early 90s. In Britain, SMS initially attracted little interest from the networks but, as the competition between them increased, they began half-heartedly promoting text-messaging as an added-value teaser to existing services. Because they would allow it only within their own network, however, it was next-to-useless for most people. The networks now say that technical hitches and difficulties with commercial agreements held them up in making it possible to text-message between them, but you get the impression that few people working there at the time thought SMS would be popular with the public. Some will admit that, originally, they thought mainly of using it to send information to their customers; a public predilection for sending silly 160-letter letters to each other wasn't the sort of "projection" that came up at strategy meetings. In Britain, Orange, Cellnet, Vodafone and Mercury One2One finally made it possible to use SMS across different networks in January 1999. Through winter and early spring, take-up was healthy but, in comparison with what was to come, unremarkable - 40 million a month between January and April. Then something started to happen that took the people at the networks by surprise. Pay-as-you-go mobile vouchers, which obviated the need for credit checks and direct debits from bank accounts, were bringing mobile phones to mass-ownership among under-18-year-olds, and for them text-messaging was ideal and instinctive. It was far cheaper than calling; it had a novelty value; it felt natural to a generation that had grown up with email, and you could use it when you weren't supposed to be sending messages, thus annoying adults and teachers alike (text-messaging in schools is now creating a dilemma for teachers; parents insist their children carry phones for personal safety, but the children use them for surreptitious digital-note-sending in lessons. Many schools ban them from desks during lessons, and one private school in Berkshire has just instituted a fine system for anyone caught texting in teaching-time). With pre-pay customers averaging three times more SMS-ing than others, the figures began to rise steeply, hitting 271 million in December. All the networks now agree that the youth market was the "key driver" in popularising SMS, and make deeply appreciative statements about "young people" and their "non-technophobia". "We're going to see lots of SMS services becoming available," says Colin Ellis. "It's all about the art of the possible. And because youth is all about pushing boundaries and experiment, young people are experts at the art of the possible." There used to be a joke in the industry that young people became so fond of SMS because, when they were in nightclubs, say, they found it easier to send and read a message than to hear someone speak. Then someone noticed that there really was a rise in use between 10pm and 2am on Friday and Saturday nights; they're still wondering about that. Whatever; however much, or little, text-messaging is being done on and around the dancefloor, it is clear that it has permeated British youth culture in, it has to be said, some fairly mirth-prompting ways. Pirate radio station DJs in London, for example, can be heard appealing over the airwaves for missives from the "Text Message Crew" (and, indeed, "The Email Massive"). Details of illegal squat parties are messaged through to caller groups. It was no surprise at all to find Orange sponsoring the 20th anniversary issue of The Face magazine in May this year, and registering its presence in the form of a 12-screen text message (from "The Big O") printed on a page. It's all very well bowing to the youth market but, of course, admitting that the kids know what's going on is just the modern, cool way of admitting that you haven't a clue. The truth is that we're in unmapped territory here, and no one knows what people will do with their mobeys. Everyone can see there's a lot of potential for mobile phones, but the industry is realising - partly because the text-message boom took it by surprise - that the psychology of mobile-phone use is unpredictable, and any commercial exploitation of SMS will have to take into account our, well, feelings towards them. From the little research that has been done, we know that we have a more personal, closer reaction to text messages received on a phone than to email on our PC, for example. And that people who message a lot feel unpopular (or, perhaps, suffer "phoneliness") if they don't receive any for a while, and will start sending until they get a response. On the other hand, my own research suggests that we don't like strangers invading our personal phone-space. In one week, I sent out 70 messages to numbers chosen at random. The messages were varied: a formal one ("Hello. This is a msg sent at random by R Benson, a journalist writing abt txt msgs for the Guardian. If you would like to be interviewed abt txt msgs, pls reply"); a jovial one, sent with a fictitious young friend (Hi!! We're messing about with our phone, we're sending msgs 2 people we don't know to see who's there! Pls reply, love rich and emma); a somewhat embarrassing sci-fi one ("Is there anybody out there?" - well, I thought that might catch an X-Files fan, or something); and a simple one ("Hello stranger"). I got just one reply, to a "Hello stranger". It seemed encouraging at the time, and I thought it might be rather interesting to interview a stranger via text message for this article; but unfortunately, our encounter amounted to the following: Me: "Hello stranger" Them (after 10 minutes): "Well hello to you to" (sic) Me: "Thank u! I've been sending msgs 2 strangers to see how long t wd take to get a reply. u r the 1st! don't worry - I am sane. Richard" Them (after 24 hours): "Who are you"? Me: "My name is Richard Benson. I am a journalist writing a story about text messages. Would you like to be interviewed by text message for the story? It would be anonymous; no need to give names, etc. What do you think?" Them: Nothing Me (after 24 hours): "Umm, is that a 'no', then?" Them: Nothing. And that was it. My conclusions: a) I am no better at chatting people up than I was at 15, b) text-messaging is probably not a good medium for meeting new friends, or for direct marketing, because c) although mobiles are good for concealing one's location and identity, it's still a bit spooky to get messages from someone you don't know. Nevertheless, you probably will be swapping them with strangers soon, because of technology that will allow you to buy things, look things up, and have information sent to you in text-message form. Cellnet's Genie service (which has signed up Balil Patel's mobile minaret) and a company called Sonera Zed are already working in this area (and if you don't think that sounds interesting, you should check their websites: they're good). You can already send graphics, and some networks will supply text-message Christmas cards this year, but that's nothing. In Finland, where the technology is more advanced, you can send a text message to a vending machine, which will deliver, say, a soft drink and put the charge on your phone bill; or order a plane ticket, which comes in the form of a text message, so all you have to do at the check-in desk is show your phone. You'll only have this until 2005, though; by then, "more advanced data services" and permanently open internet connections will probably edge it out. Will they have any lasting influence on us? Cd vwls dspr frm th lng'ge altgthr? Or could we end up with a two-tier language system, in which everyday English wd b abbreviated, + cd include numbers + l8rs 2gthr? History offers an interesting parallel that suggests that the answers to these questions could be a partial "ys". In the 18th century, a major programme of road-building led to improved transport and mail services throughout England. At the same time, developments in technology made it cheaper to manufacture printing presses, and they became more widely available. As a consequence, more people were able to travel, there was a new, widespread interest in printed communications, and letter-writing became increasingly popular; it even inspired a new literary genre in the epistolary novel, of which Samuel Richardson's Pamela remains the best-known example. All this had a direct impact on language, and the way people used it. The conventions of letter-writing (addresses in the top corners, Dear Sirs and Madams, and so on) were established, for example, and dictionaries were created to standardise spellings between different areas of the country. As the infamous media guru Marshall McLuhan pointed out, changing forms of communication tend to change the way we talk. Sometimes - see the blokes-and-phones theory - they can change the way we act and think, too. It's impossible to know what effect emails and text messages will have on us, but it is clear that they have instigated the biggest boom in "letter" writing for 200 years; and while we don't, yet, have a text-message novel, the tight, subject-less sentences and the reproduced emails in Bridget Jones' Diary have at least a touch of the digital missives. Mike Short, the chairman of the GSM Association's Mobile Data Taskforce, believes that text-messaging is part of a epoch-defining shift in the way we communicate with one another, a "move from a verbal to a visual culture", as he puts it. That seems a rather grand claim to make on its behalf, but then, if you're not sure what's happening, you might as well try to sound excited about it. The rest of us don't know so much about that, but will carry on using SMS because, of all the clever services and bits of information the techies find to give us, our favourites are the ones that let us talk to each other and make each other laugh. And because, as all good text-maniacs know, when you're dialling, the whole world :-)s with you. Beep-beep

fields.headline: The knowledge
fields.standfirst: Bud you like: artichoke
fields.trailText: Bud you like: artichoke
fields.body:
The subject
Flowerbud of Cynara scolymus , member of the thistle family - and it looks the part. God knows why anyone first dared eat one. Dimensions: from clementine-sized morsel to grapefruit-sized beast. Etymology: from the Arabic al-karsufa .

The basics
In artichoke-land, size matters. You're most likely to find big globes, whose probable origin is France or Italy. A good one has tightly-packed scales (the leafy things), tender at the tips, with no trace of brown.

The details
To cook: trim the stalk and snap off the small scales. Boil in plenty of salted water (around 30 minutes), covered with a lid that's a bit smaller than the pot, so as to weigh down the globes and keep them submerged. Eat the base of the scales (scrape with lower incisors) and the base (heart) only. The tiny thistles (collectively called the choke) that sprout from the base are inedible. Natural partners: vinaigrette or lemon juice. Really small specimens can be sautéed or grilled; true infants can be eaten raw. Big globes can be barbecued, if you have more care and patience than The Knowledge can muster. Incidentally: nothing to do with Jerusalem artichokes. Incidentally: used to make an Italian apéritif called Cynar, regarded (in Italy) as having medicinal properties. Incidentally: too late to attend this year's Artichoke festival in Castroville, California, where Marilyn Monroe was crowned 'Artichoke Queen' in 1949.

Where to buy
Big globes: greengrocers and some supermarkets. Smaller artichokes: don't hold your breath, unless you have a swanky greengrocer at hand - although Waitrose is selling (for a couple of weeks more) tasty little 'petit artichokes' grown experimentally in the UK. With careful handling, they're a treat.

The easy way out
This is it. Restaurants do many swanky things with artichokes, and The Knowledge implores you to leave swanking to them. Artichoke hearts in brine or oil? Useful larder items, but no substitute. Artichoke as medicine? Try Cynara, recommended by its makers as a cure for bloating.

fields.headline: Make mine a...
fields.standfirst: Wyborowa
fields.trailText: Wyborowa
fields.body: A wyberwhat? A vee-bor-over . The emphasis is on the last two syllables. But even if you get the pronunciation right, the barman probably won't have a clue what you're on about, unless you're propping up a bar such as the new Purple Bar at the Sanderson hotel in London, where it's the house vodka. Part of its appeal - other than that it actually tastes of something - is that it isn't advertised; and the unreconstructed retro packaging makes it the tipple of choice for literary anti-heroes. Connoisseurs know that it's the biggest-selling vodka in Poland, made from rye, and that wyborowa means 'excellent' in Polish. And that you should drink it straight from the freezer, or as a Polish martini (Krupnik, Wyborowa and apple juice). So who drinks it (apart, of course, from hard-drinking Poles and literati)? Very Cool People, apparently, who drive Jensen Interceptors, drink Illy caffé and read Nabokov and Simone de Beauvoir. If that sounds like your ticket, head for a good independent or Oddbins (RRP £13.99).

fields.headline: Dear Weekend
fields.trailText:
Finally, an article about someone who does not have a 'normal' sexual lifestyle, yet the emphasis is on their intelligence - Susan Sontag has been someone I've admired over the years, ever since I read On Photography 20 years ago (Finding Fact From Fiction, May 27). I despair when the only concern that the media has about certain personalities is their 'gayness'. The only thing that separates 'gays' from 'straights' are our stupid archaic laws!
Lola Flash
London E1

Lola Flash
London E1

Thank you to Dr Tanya Garrett (Dear Weekend, May 27) for questioning the use of the pictures that accompanied the article on Andrea Dworkin. I, too, was puzzled by their purpose. Unfortunately, the only lasting impression I was left with was of Ms Dworkin's physical appearance. The article on Susan Sontag contained a reference to her physical attributes: 'Sontag was, and remains . . . a beauty.' But there was no such reference in the Dworkin article. Perhaps if the subject of Ms Dworkin's appearance had been addressed, the photographs of her would not have had such a powerful impact. As it was, they served only to become a major feature of the article, considering the close-ups used.
Miss Deborah Gilshan
Fulwood, Preston

I beg to differ with Dr Tanya Garrett. I saw the portraits of Andrea Dworkin as giving her the same coverage as any other person in a Weekend main feature. Not publishing her photograph would have been akin to body fascism. It's time we got away from only picturing females if they are young and beautiful, and from assuming that the male image is always going to be superior, even when old and unattractive.
Annie Conroy
Chelmsford, Essex

So John Beardsmore disapproves of the Guardian giving 'free publicity' to right-wing fascists (Dear Weekend, May 27)? I suppose he'd rather the far right quietly nurtured itself in some sleepy backwater while he slept peacefully in his bed, oblivious to their activities. I hadn't heard of Nick Griffin, either, and am ashamed for having become so removed from the reality of such things. Innocence is bliss. Don't shoot the messenger, John.
Mike Freeman
Brittas, Co Kilkenny, Eire

In his interview, Nick Griffin asserts that 'people are born different'. He is right. Some people are born and grow up to become intolerant, ignorant bigots, while others are born and grow up to become tolerant of people of different races and religions.
Name and address witheld

Keep Ahdaf Soueif (May 27). It was a pleasure to read a column by a genuine person with a real life rather than the self-obsessed Julie Burchill. Instead of attempting to shock, Soueif reflects.
Ruth Henningham
calaquendi@lineone.net

Julie please come back. I can't bear it without you on Saturday mornings. With you, I (a black British woman) am accustomed to feeling included in this society, while being entertained, informed and sometimes shocked. Ahdaf Soueif and all this 'toasties' rubbish was offensive, even ridiculous, but not presented as such. We are not in Cairo, and the NF do not make distinctions in Great Britain.
Yvonne Witter
London SE21

fields.headline: Planet of the japes
fields.standfirst: His intergalactic guide to life, the universe and everything was an instant bestseller. But dogged by writer's block, he moved to California and has now turned his attention to endangered species and a new dot.com project.  Nicholas Wroe  reports
fields.trailText: His intergalactic guide to life, the universe and everything was an instant bestseller. But dogged by writer's block, he moved to California and has now turned his attention to endangered species and a new dot.com project. Nicholas Wroe reports
fields.body:
Soon after The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy was published in 1979, Douglas Adams was invited to sign copies at a small science fiction bookshop in Soho. As he drove there some sort of demonstration slowed his progress. "There was a traffic jam and crowds of people everywhere," he recalls. It wasn't until he had pushed his way inside that Adams realised the crowds were there for him. Next day his publisher called to say he was number one in the Sunday Times best seller list and his life changed forever. "It was like being helicoptered to the top of Mount Everest," he says, "or having an orgasm without the foreplay."

Hitchhiker had already been a cult radio show and went on both television and the stage. It expanded into four more books that sold over 14m copies world-wide. There were records and computer games and now, after 20 years of Hollywood prevarication, it is as close as it's ever been to becoming a movie.

The story itself begins on earth with mild-mannered suburbanite Arthur Dent trying to stop the council demolishing his house to build a bypass. It moves into space when his friend, Ford Prefect - some have seen him as Virgil to Dent's Dante - reveals himself as a representative of the planet Betelgeuse and informs Arthur that the earth itself is about to be demolished to make way for a hyperspace express route. They hitch a ride on a Vogon spaceship and begin to use the guide itself; a usually reliable repository of all knowledge about life, the universe and everything.

Adams's creativity and idiosyncratic intergalactic humour have had a pervasive cultural influence. The phrase "hitchhiker's guide to..." quickly became common parlance and there have been numerous copycat spoof sci-fi books and TV series. His Babel fish - a small fish you can place in your ear to translate any speech into your own language - has been adopted as the name of a translation device on an internet search engine. He followed up his success with several other novels as well as a television programme, book and CD-rom on endangered species. He has founded a dot.com company, H2G2, that has recently taken the idea of the guide full circle by launching a service that promises real information on life, the universe and everything via your mobile phone.

Much of his wealth seems to have been spent fuelling his passion for technology but he has never really been the nerdy science-fiction type. He is relaxed, gregarious and a solidly built 2m tall. In fact, he has more the air of those English public schoolboys who became rock stars in the 1970s; he once did play guitar on stage at Earls Court with his mates Pink Floyd. In a nicely flash touch, instead of producing a passport-size photo of his daughter out of his wallet, he opens up his impressively powerful laptop, where, after a bit of fiddling about, Polly Adams, aged five, appears in pop video spoof featuring a cameo appearance by another mate, John Cleese.

So this is what his life turned into; money, A-list friends, and nice toys. Looking at the bare facts of his cv - boarding school, Cambridge Footlights and the BBC - it seems at first sight no surprise. But his has not been an entirely straightforward journey along well-worn establishment tracks.

Douglas Noel Adams was born in Cambridge in 1952. One of his many stock gags is that he was DNA in Cambridge nine months before Crick and Watson made their discovery. His mother, Janet, was a nurse at Addenbrooke's hospital and his father, Christopher, had been a teacher; he went on to became a postgraduate theology student, probation officer, and finally a management consultant, which was "a very, very peculiar move", claims Adams. "Anyone who knew my father will tell you that management was not something he knew very much about."

The family were "fairly hard up" and left Cambridge six months after Douglas was born to live in various homes on the fringes of east London. When Adams he was five his parents divorced. "It's amazing the degree to which children treat their own lives as normal," he says. "But of course it was difficult. My parents divorced when it wasn't remotely as common as it is now, and to be honest I have scant memory of anything before I was five. I don't think it was a great time, one way or another."

After the break-up Douglas and his younger sister went with their mother to Brentwood in Essex where she ran a hostel for sick animals. He called it Doctor Which." Many years later Adams did write scripts for Doctor Who. He describes Halford as an inspirational teacher who is still a support. And even now, when I have a dark night of the soul as a writer and think that I can't do this anymore, the thing that I reach for is not the fact that I have had best-sellers or huge advances. It is the fact that Frank Halford once gave me 10 out of 10, and at some fundamental level I must be able to do it."
