fields.headline: Intimate escapes
fields.standfirst: Anita Desai extends her range in Diamond Dust and Other Stories
fields.trailText: Anita Desai extends her range in Diamond Dust and Other Stories
fields.body:
Diamond Dust and Other Stories
Anita Desai
Chatto & Windus, £14.99, 207pp

This wittily observed short-story collection is Anita Desai's first book since Fasting, Feasting, the novel for which she was named runner-up to JM Coetzee in last year's Booker prize. Both books reveal an abiding impulse to dissect what Desai once called "the web of [family] relationships, sticky and sweet, clinging and trapping". But while these stories slyly take a scalpel to family ties that stifle as much as they sustain, they extend her range in intriguing directions, charting not only bitter confinement but also heady escape.

Fasting, Feasting (now a Vintage paperback) casts a coolly ironic gaze at parallel symptoms of dysfunction erupting in provincial India and suburban America, from bride-burning to bulimia. Food is central, whether scarce and meanly rationed in a middle-class Indian home, or abundant yet rejected in the New England of eating disorders and obsessive keep-fit.

The stories in Diamond Dust range across not two but three continents, tracking people on the move - whether exiled from India or Mexico to US campuses (where Desai has taught for years) or fleeing sweltering summers for the relief of Himalayan hills or the Cornish seaside. While mother figures ply long-departed sons with "favourite" childhood foods in vain attempts to rekindle waning bonds, gulfs of incomprehension and resentment open up as the migrants are transformed by their journeys.

"Winterscape", like Fasting, Feasting, contrasts the strength of familial ties in north America and India, as Rakesh's "two mothers" visit him and his pregnant wife Beth in Toronto. Although Beth chafes against this invasion of "two foreigners" from her husband's past in Punjab, she gradually gains insight into the love that made Anu gift her own son to her widowed, childless sister Asha, Rakesh's mother and aunt swapping places. In "Tepoztlan", a nephew's return from Texas to a Mexican mountain village where "ageing daughters looked after aged parents" stirs an old claustrophobia, driving him to flee again a household of bitter complaint, "shrouded and still" as an empty parrot's cage. "Ah, the gringo", the locals mutter sarcastically.

Amid exquisite descriptions of nature and evocation of atmosphere are the violence and rapacity that characteristically break the calm surface of Desai's fiction. In "Royalty", a leech-like character exploits the hospitality of friends, while in the title story a civil servant heads for tragedy over his fondness for his "badmash" pet dog, Diamond. There is also comedy, as in the story where a family bound for Simla gets stuck in a traffic jam, which may be no more than a ruse to deliver captive business to the myriad roadside vendors who materialise out of the dust.

In one of the finest and most moving stories, "Underground", the focus shifts from a couple motoring in Cornwall to a widower, Bob, whom they disturb when they seek a room at his guest house. Their knock triggers memories of buying the hotel with his dying wife, and of his previous job in Iraq, where he found "his voice raised, loudly, like a caricature, a cartoon of a British colonial" at the enticing vision of a close-knit local family that excluded him.

The final and most satisfying story in this collection returns to the subject of Desai's earliest fiction: the lone or isolated woman in India and the ambivalence of independence. In "The Rooftop Dwellers", Moyna, testing her wings as a "working woman in the metropolis", joins a Delhi community of single lodgers in adjacent barsatis or rooftop rooms. Her new landlords raise their eyes from mythological TV epics only to narrow them disapprovingly at their lodger ("too young, too pretty, too unattached"), yet her spirits lift as she savours a new freedom in her rooftop "palace", shaded by the canopy of a parrot-filled pipal tree.

The tone marks a shift from Desai's previous fiction, which has tended to count the high price to women of claiming such freedoms. While Moyna's shunning of the shelter of family does subject her to the scrutiny and exploitation of landlords, gropers on buses, a lewd gallery of rooftop onlookers and an insolent servant boy who blasts out tapes he has stolen from her, the final note is one of triumph. While Fasting, Feasting ultimately affirms the comfort and endurance of family ties - however constraining - here the epiphany is one of escape. It is as though, training her eyes on a later generation of women than her own, Desai is finally able to celebrate a widening of the frontiers.

fields.headline: God knows
fields.standfirst: The narratives that E L Doctorow weaves around the millenial musings redeem City of God
fields.trailText: The narratives that E L Doctorow weaves around the millenial musings redeem City of God
fields.body:
City of God
E L Doctorow
Little, Brown, £15.99, 272pp
Buy it at BOL

When the altar cross goes missing from his episcopal church only to reappear on the roof of the synagogue of Evolutionary Judaism, the Reverend Dr Thomas Pemberton (known as Pem) sees it as a sign. For a long time unsure of his faith, especially regarding the Christian response to the Holocaust and the fact that the Mesopotamian creation myths significantly pre-date the Bible, Pem makes a move towards conversion, and his decision is compounded when he falls in love with Sarah, the widow of Rabbi Gruen.

Behind a portentous title that loudly hails a book of big themes and no little irony, Doctorow contrives a montage of letters, interviews, emails and sermons, some of which investigate the arguments for and against the existence of God. Others wonder if we can redefine God so that he is more apparent in this age of scepticism. And what happens if you lose your faith, like Pem, and stray from the path to the city of God?

Alternating between fiction and non-fiction, Doctorow also proffers lengthy disquisitions on the philosophy of language and the nature of the universe: is physics an attempt to rediscover, empirically, the lost path to God? He relates each subject to the creative process with a wearisome self-reflexivity: if God is the author, can the author be God?

These ideas aren't new. A fragmented, secular society struggling for identity and faith - hasn't this condition been gleefully spelled out on the idiot-boards of postmodernity for years? Do we need to be talked through it yet again?

Thankfully, the book is redeemed by the two fictional narratives which weave their way around the conjecture. There is Pem's tale, as he stumbles towards Judaism and Sarah's love, and there is the extraordinary story of Sarah's father, who, with enormous courage and guile, survived the Vilnius ghetto of the second world war. These sections are by far the most convincing and humane, and go a long way towards addressing one of the novel's main concerns: how we can reclaim our humanity after a century of genocide.

The ghetto story is itself a fictional reworking of events as written by another character, who shows Sarah a proof for her comments. By bringing in another writer, Doctorow creates a more successful dynamic between text and counter-text, fiction and history, memory and its endless revisions.

fields.headline: Gale force
fields.standfirst: Stephen Moss  on stormy weather and natural disasters in The Weather Factor, Floods, Famines and Emperors and Fire from the Mountain
fields.trailText: Stephen Moss on stormy weather and natural disasters in The Weather Factor, Floods, Famines and Emperors and Fire from the Mountain
fields.body:
The Weather Factor
Erik Durschmied
Hodder & Stoughton, £14.99,
Buy it at BOL

Floods, Famines and Emperors: El Nino and the Fate of Civilisations
Brian Fagan
Pimlico, £12.50, 304pp
Buy it at BOL

Fire from the Mountain
Polly Pattullo
Constable, £9.99, 218pp
Buy it at BOL

For want of a nail, the battle was lost, as the old saying goes. Or an umbrella, perhaps. Few historians would dispute that key moments in the past have been influenced by the weather. Bannockburn, the Spanish Armada and D-day could all have had very different outcomes, but for a sudden downpour, an unexpected storm and poor weather forecasting by Hitler's strategic command.

For Erik Durschmied, author of The Weather Factor, downpours, tempests and avalanches are the very stuff of history. From Noah's Flood to the Vietnam War, he argues that sudden and unexpected meteorological calamities and our failure to predict them have changed the results of battles, leading indirectly to the fall of civilisations. The fact that the Biblical flood was caused by a geological fault, or that events in southeast Asia might have been influenced by American foreign policy, does not deter him: it's all the fault of Michael Fish and his predecessors.

Durschmied is a former war correspondent, and it shows. Nowadays, his "I flew in with the Red Devils" style is out of fashion in war reporting, so he has turned to the next best thing: the violence of the elements. This is a tabloid view of history, and in the tradition of the best newshounds comes complete with direct quotes. But was Durschmied really there when, on September 11, AD9, two Roman legionnaires whispered their fears to each other? I think not.

In the last chapter, "Owning the Weather in 2025", Durschmied finally loses his tenuous grip on reality. He claims that war 21st-century style will be a "geophysical conflict", complete with floods, storms and earthquakes artificially induced by scientists in the Pentagon and Kremlin. This is not popular science but science fiction - only without the science.

In Floods, Famines and Emperors, Brian Fagan also takes an "if only" view of world history. However, by confining himself to a specific phenomenon he has produced a far more convincing account. El Nino is a periodic event during which upwellings of warm water in the Pacific give rise to savage storms, resulting in a huge rise in rainfall over some parts of the world and unexpected droughts in others.

Fagan puts the current El Nino in a historical perspective, from the collapse of the Maya civilisation in Mexico to the 22nd century BC, when a great drought threatened to destroy the Egyptians. During years of plenty, the pharaohs had had the foresight to increase crop yields and store food; if only modern governments were so far-sighted. The account of recent El Ninos is one of greed, misallocated resources and the exploitation of land for short-term gain. The message may not be new, but it still bears repeating: we have learned nothing from history.

The same lesson can be learned from Fire from the Mountain by Polly Pattullo, which tells of the effects of volcanic eruption on Montserrat. Until recently, if we had any image of Montserrat at all, it was of a sun-drenched island in a calm blue sea. Then, on the morning of June 25 1997, after almost two years of rumblings, the Soufriere Hills volcano finally blew its top. The next day, Montserrat and its people were front-page news.

Pattullo traces the events leading up to the final eruption and its consequences. Although more than two thirds of the island's inhabitants left the area following the first stirrings of the volcano in 1995, many stayed put. Nineteen people died in the eruption, a relatively small number compared to other recent disasters. What kept Montserrat in the headlines was the bungling of the British government, and in particular the remarks of the secretary of state for overseas development, Clare Short. It was she who complained that the island's government wanted so much money, "it will be golden elephants next". Under any circumstances this would have been a serious gaffe. At a time when the volcano looked as though it was about to erupt again, it was a truly monumental one.

Silver linings are few and far between, but this terrible event did bring forth a collection of songs, poetry and prose, including these lines by Howard Fergus: "But volcano is boss man, only one in its class, man..." A well-wrought miniature is often worth more than a sprawling canvas, a sonnet more revealing than a 1,000-page potboiler. So if you really want to find out about the way natural events can shape the course of history, read Fire from the Mountain.

fields.headline: Shields stops speaking
fields.trailText: No more bookfests for the Canadian novelist, plus will Zadie Smith get her teeth into the Orange Prize? Will she even show up?
fields.body:
 News reaches us from the Hay Festival about the imminent retirement from public life of one of the book world's most amiable figures. The Canadian novelist Carol Shields used her appearance at the annual mudfest to announce that she will no longer be making any appearances at festivals, signings, "platforms" or any other bookchat shindigs. After signing copies of her work (no doubt for a few canny first edition hunters) Shields had a characteristically arch way of describing her experiences of the last few years: "I drifted into the 'speaking' business, enjoyed it, met interesting people and am delighted I'm never going to do it again."

 Is Zadie "White Teeth" Smith the shoo-in for the Orange Prize that she seems? Possibly. But the Loafer hears that one judge is saying "over my dead body" and thumping the table. All will be revealed at a gala prizegiving at the Victoria & Albert Museum on Tuesday. But Smith won't be there in any case, as she is embarking on a whirlwind tour of the US.

 One past no-shower has relented though. J M Coetzee, otherwise engaged at the Booker ceremony, will, say the organisers, be in London on June 26 to pick up his £10,000 Commonwealth Writers Prize. And he'll meet the Queen too.

fields.headline: Fear and waiting
fields.standfirst: William Goldman serves up another helping of silver-screen gossip in Which Lie Did I Tell?
fields.trailText: William Goldman serves up another helping of silver-screen gossip in Which Lie Did I Tell?
fields.body:
Which Lie Did I Tell? More Adventures in the Screen Trade
William Goldman
Bloomsbury, £16.99, 384pp
Buy it at BOL

A Hollywood film script, when all is said and done, is just a set of instructions for assembly - with pitfalls and humiliations, some of which have already been documented by screenwriter William Goldman in Adventures in the Screen Trade (1983). Now he has produced a sequel, something he berates as the pits of the Hollywood system, without acknowledging that this book is exactly that: a repeat of a proven formula, part gossip, part master class, part autobiography (interestingly ghastly), with a recycling of choice Goldman scenes and analysis of favourites by others.

Writers exist in Hollywood to be bullied, to be fired and not to get thanked. Belonging to the cheapest end of the process, they have no place to hide. Agents can trick up their jobs with the martial strategies of oriental warlords, but writers, like ideas, are there to be kicked around, and however good their efforts they invariably end up being abused by executives. Any script getting made depends less on quality than chance alignments of agents and stars, grace and favour, the marketplace or any other number of random factors. As Goldman points out, it is a business in which in the end nobody knows anything.

Scriptwriting may be assembly, but it is also involves endless speculative configurations. This explains the industry's conservative and repetitive nature, which translates into the primary Hollywood states of fear and waiting. By the most reverent, the art of screenwriting is regarded as somewhere between alchemy and surgery, with the highest praise reserved for the legendary script doctors who command fabulous sums to fix broken scripts (often just amounting to a late application of common sense).

A multimillion-dollar analysis industry has grown up over the last 20 years, dedicated to showing how a script works through a jargon of plot points, character arcs, backstories, hooks and the twiddly bits that make a film light up in an audience's heads. One of this book's better jokes has Goldman being asked by a keen student, "Do you always begin your second theme by page 17?"

Goldman takes a writer's standard thin-skinned view of Hollywood, mainly by doing what Faulkner did, which was not to live there. His two most famous scripts were for films very much of their time, Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid (1969), a cutesy alternative to Peckinpah's West, and All the President's Men (1976), both of which won him Oscars. There was a cooling period around Adventures in the Screen Trade, possibly related to the book, for then as now Goldman hit out at obvious targets: the rudeness, stupidity and vanities of Hollywood. When treated with straightforward professional courtesy (by Clint Eastwood), he practically slobbers with gratitude.

After four decades, Goldman, contrary to his own dictum, does know a thing or two about the screen trade, especially about nuts and bolts problems. The big problem here is the prose, which raises the question, can the man write and not annoy? After the open white spaces of his screenplays, his bunched-up writing is not a pretty sight, being neurotic, skittery and too dependent on expletives. When not being assailed by the podium delivery he favours, the reader is ambushed by a dreadful faux-mateyness, described by Elmore Leonard in his puff as Goldman's "over-lunch" voice - suggesting that lunch may best be skipped.

More Adventures in the Screen Trade William Goldman Bloomsbury, £16.99, 384pp Buy it at BOL A Hollywood film script, when all is said and done, is just a set of instructions for assembly - with pitfalls and humiliations, some of which have already been documented by screenwriter William Goldman in Adventures in the Screen Trade (1983). Agents can trick up their jobs with the martial strategies of oriental warlords, but writers, like ideas, are there to be kicked around, and however good their efforts they invariably end up being abused by executives. fields.headline: The menacing decade
fields.standfirst: From the Wall Street crash to Hitler's triumph...  Piers Brendon enters the shadow of the 1930s in The Dark Valley
fields.trailText: From the Wall Street crash to Hitler's triumph... Piers Brendon enters the shadow of the 1930s in The Dark Valley
fields.body:
The Dark Valley: A Panorama of the 1930s
Piers Brendon
Jonathan Cape, £25, 880pp
Buy it at BOL

On New Year's Eve 1899 the German Social Democratic Party organised a glittering ball to celebrate the new century. The party had grown in mighty bounds to become the largest democratic political organisation on earth. The ball attracted all sides, the right wing represented by Edward Bernstein and the revolutionary wing by Rosa Luxemburg. The mood of the evening was triumphalist: the party was about to emerge into the century of great hope. Whatever the means of change, whether through parliament or revolution, it seemed obvious to all the guests that nothing could stop the relentless progress of social democracy and the benefits which it would shower on the whole human race.

Less than a decade and a half later, the great hope disintegrated into unimaginable despair. The first world war, supported by the German social democrats and the British Labour Party, consigned millions of the young men of Europe to the charnel house. For a brief moment after the war, some of the optimism of that eve-of-century ball returned, only to be plunged into gloom in the 1930s, "the dark valley". The great hope vanished and in its place came slump, fascism, another war and the Holocaust. The rest of the century was haunted by the howling ghosts of the dark valley: every rise in unemployment, every attack on racial minorities, every slippage on the stock exchange, every censored broadcast sent out tremors of apprehension that what happened in the 30s might be coming again.

Globalisation is usually presented as a modern phenomenon. The outstanding contribution of Piers Brendon's history is his presentation of the 30s as a decade in which each apparently independent part of the world depended on the others. The slump and the depression set off by the Wall Street crash in 1929 quickly enveloped Britain, France, Germany, Italy and Japan.

Brendon fits the story of what happened in each of these nations into an international pattern. Seasoned democracies such as the US, Britain and France, whose governments had won the war, somehow managed to survive the economic blizzard, but the effect on Germany, Japan and Italy was to replace democracy with a crazed fascist militarism which speedily degenerated into racist terror and imperialist aggression.

In Spain, the elected government was toppled after a long and ferocious civil war set off by a fascist rebellion. As they drowned in what seemed an unstoppable right-wing tide, millions of victims and their sympathisers cast hopeful eyes towards what they were led to believe was a new socialist dawn in Russia. In fact the new dawn was by that stage a grotesque hoax, kept alive by merciless and mendacious propaganda.

A consistent theme in this book is that official mendacity was common to all countries, whether or not their governments depended on votes. Everywhere those in power laid hold of the means of informing people - and informed them in terms opposite to the truth. In this process there was very little to choose between, for instance, the war propaganda of the Japanese government and British ministers' assumption that the purpose of the BBC and almost all the free press was to state and argue the ministers' case.

Brendon tells his story kaleidoscopically, alternating his chapters country by country. Somehow he manages to get through his vast panorama without a moment's dullness; his characters come to life in a flurry of detail about their appearances and habits. He never takes refuge in blandness, the usual retreat of boring historians.

And there is no comfort here for the mass of increasingly fashionable historians who surmise that there may, after all, have been something to be said for Hitler or Franco or Mussolini or Hoover or Chamberlain or Ramsay MacDonald. In Brendon's view, MacDonald's socialism was "like Harris tweed in Bavaria"; his "cut the dole" policy in 1931 was based on "penalising the indigent for the failures of the opulent". Lord Plymouth, who headed the British government's non-intervention committee for Spain, was a "patrician nincompoop", Ward Price of the Daily Mail "an odious toady". The young king Edward VIII "sympathised with the poor but associated with the rich"; the French foreign minister Georges Bonnet had "the courage of his own lack of conviction" and Randolph Churchill was "not fit to be allowed out in private". Although Brendon is the keeper of the Churchill archives at Cambridge, he is by no means sycophantic towards Randolph's celebrated father, Winston, who, he reminds us, was tremendously impressed by Italian fascism and by extremist militarism in Japan.

But the strength of this book does not depend on such insights into its characters, nor on the flashes of literary criticism, for instance of George Orwell, Ernest Hemingway and Louis MacNeice. Rather, great chunks of this history rest on unfashionable opinions. The "most fundamental cause" of the great crash in the US, for instance, was "financial inequalities". Republican Spain was smothered "by the poisonous tendrils of Stalinism". And the key to understanding Stalin was not his association with the Russian revolution but his obsession with eradicating every vestige of that revolution in order, as Brendon puts it, "to destroy every shred of left-wing opposition". All these ideas shed new light into the gloomiest recesses of the dark valley.

There are times when the author's obsession with detail distracts him from the central issues. The biggest question of all about the 30s is surely "could Hitler have been stopped?" Brendon explains how much his chancellorship owed to chance and intrigue. In the November 1932 elections only weeks previously, the Nazis lost 2m votes, and even after Hitler became chancellor, the electorate refused him the endorsement he confidently expected. He got the constitutional majority he needed by the subtle device of imprisoning all the elected communist deputies. But what Brendon almost completely ignores is the response of the communists and social democrats to the rise of fascism.

Though their combined vote and their influence in the country was substantially greater than those of the Nazis, both sides - especially the communists - rigidly refused to form a united front against the fascists. The communists, who at one stage were getting 6m votes, renamed the social democrats "social fascists". So great was the sectarian divide in those crucial months before the deluge that the communists preferred even to link up and stage strikes with the fascists rather than campaign in the country and in the factories for a unified force against fascism. "After Hitler, our turn" was the boast of the communist leader Ernst Thalmann.

After Hitler, as it happened, communists and social democrats were at last united - in the concentration camps. Brendon's refusal even to ask the question whether and how Hitler could have been stopped is reflected elsewhere in his book - for instance over the growth of fascism in Italy or the failure of the Popular Front government in France to go to the aid of republican Spain. Brendon might reply that his job is to tell history as it was, not as it might have been. But at least one of the virtues of such an authoritative and moving account is to arm us against any repetition of similar horrors in the future.

fields.headline: Evening classes
fields.standfirst: Ann Bermingham tells the story of amateur art in Learning to Draw
fields.trailText: Ann Bermingham tells the story of amateur art in Learning to Draw
fields.body:
Learning to Draw: Studies in the Cultural History of a Polite and Useful Art
Ann Bermingham
Paul Mellon Centre for Studies in British Art/Yale University Press, £50, 304pp
Buy it at BOL

Drawing and painting remain as persistent and popular as the British commitment to dogs and gardening (they probably satisfy similar needs). But although amateur art-making is supported by an entire infrastructure of how-to-do-it books and mags, classes and art-material suppliers, it has remained resolutely marginalised - the object of complacent sneers by the art establishment and the press.

Now American art historian Ann Bermingham has provided a fascinating and complex analysis of amateur drawing as a cultural production reflective of larger social phenomena. Ironically, she suggests in Learning to Draw: Studies in the Cultural History of a Polite and Useful Art that it can no longer be thought of as a social practice, yet one welcomes the book as an essential cornerstone in the construction of a new discipline which investigates drawing as both practice and discourse.

Learning to Draw traces the way drawing defined differences between individuals and groups and helped to constitute the idea of "the individual" in changing English society between the 16th and 19th centuries. It does so through the structural framework of Foucault, Habermas, gender politics and psychoanalysis, which can sometimes make for rather convoluted arguments.

Bermingham focuses her discussion of the courtly art of the 16th and 17th centuries around the notion of sprezzatura, nonchalant grace, as defined by Baldassare Castiglione in his book The Courtier (translated into English in 1561). Radically, she suggests that the representational practices of drawing and painting were models for the performative fiction of courtiership - itself a disguised mode of political agency - and examines these ideas within the absolutist politics of the English court.

Sprezzatura, Bermingham argues, prizes masculine grace and virtue and displaces the negative aspects of "dissimulation" on to women. She relates this trope of displacement to Elizabeth I's simultaneous concerns with controlling productions of her image and the suppression of aspects of her own body. This idea is extremely interesting, but the notion of sprezzatura is curious in relation to the laboured miniatures of Nicholas Hilliard, with their jewelled detail and stiff and hieratic poses. Graceful sprightliness is a more convincing attribute of Sir Anthony van Dyck, and Bermingham digresses from her discussion of drawing in the Stuart period for a close reading of his painting "Charles I Hunting" (circa 1635).

Drawing was the private amateur pastime of the aristocratic connoisseurs or "virtuosi" attached to the court of Charles I. In the unsettled economic climate leading up to the Civil War, class distinctions were fluid and virtuosity was powerfully coded as a social signifier, requiring wealth, knowledge and sensibility. Bermingham contrasts this with a post-Civil War society in which the new virtuosity depended on intellectual attainments as much as wealth, encountered in many of the founding members of the Royal Society such as Sir Christopher Wren. Drawing, she proposes, served the development of empirical natural science.

Very much at home in the 18th century, Bermingham discusses the role of landscape drawing in constructions of national identity and class. Boldly defining the landscapes of "sense, sensibility and sensation" rather than topographic, picturesque and naturalistic, she focuses on the moral, political and social values of types of landscape within the ideology of the aesthetic. The introduction of drawing into military schools, for example, happened at a time when there were military and agricultural imperatives for accurate maps. Meanwhile, the proliferation of drawing manuals which emphasised a repertoire of "touches" and differentiated strokes for varied foliage and tree shapes constituted an ideology of "sensation", of which Constable's Stour Valley landscapes are the supreme records.

In the early 19th century, an era of feminised amateurism, aristocratic and middle-class girls were taught by a new class of peripatetic drawing masters, among them some artists of merit. Academician Angelica Kauffman provided images for uses such as the embellishment of furniture, and the products of Josiah Wedgwood constituted a new commercial aestheticisation of the home. The profound effects of all this on professional artists associated with the Royal Academy led to a "remasculinisation" of high art; Bermingham cites the angry outbursts of artists such as Benjamin Robert Haydon against crass commercialisation. There was a feminine critique, too: Mary Wollstonecroft and Hannah More warned women against the "mischief" of commercial consumption, joining William Hazlitt in his tirades against corruption of taste and female vulgarity.

Bermingham constructs a welcome feminist reframing of 19th-century female artistic accomplishments within the domestic space. Not just useless activities for filling idle hours but skills tied to the marriageability of women, they sometimes conflicted with prevailing notions of feminine modesty, as suggested in readings from Jane Austen. Flower painting, a specifically women's art despised by the Royal Academy, created a huge literature of manuals printed with new technologies and allowed women a degree of professionalisation through the study of botany.

The book concludes with a survey of female art education in the second half of the 19th century. In tracing the history of the government Schools of Design, Bermingham signals the end of the high period of the female amateur artist. She also retells the story of Fox Talbot's development of photography as a graphic art: Talbot's prophetic belief that photography would become the medium of the amateur very rapidly came true, causing drawing to lose its connection with everyday life and its place in the construction of a social self. Bermingham's well-argued conclusion is that realism thus became relegated to the style of the amateur. "Modernism's indifference to nature, and amateurism's reverence for it, is not only an origin of avant-garde abstraction but of all those views of glowing sunsets that we associate with amateur art."

 Amateur Artists and Drawing Masters 1600-1800 is at the British Museum until Sept 24.
